text:
In the Name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate

**The Introduction**
Indeed, all praise is for Allah. We praise Him, seek His help, and seek His forgiveness (1). We seek refuge in Allah from the evils within ourselves and from our bad deeds. Whoever Allah guides, none can misguide; and whoever He allows to go astray, none can guide. I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone, without partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and His Messenger.

“O you who believe! Fear Allah as He should be feared, and do not die except as Muslims.”

“O mankind! Fear your Lord who created you from a single soul, and created from it its spouse, and spread from the two of them many men and women. And fear Allah through whom you ask one another, and (honor) the ties of kinship. Indeed, Allah is ever watching over you.”

“O you who believe! Fear Allah and speak words that are upright. He will rectify your deeds for you and forgive your sins. And whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger has certainly achieved a tremendous success.”

To proceed: About twenty years ago, while I was still in my first place of migration (Damascus), I had begun printing my book *Da‘if al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib*, and I completed in it …
foot_note: 1. Some preachers add here the phrase: “and we seek His guidance,” but it has no basis in this noble sermon known as (The Sermon of Need) in any of its chains. I had collected these chains in a booklet about the Prophet ﷺ, in which it is clarified that he ﷺ would sometimes recite after it the well-known three verses from Surah Aal ‘Imran, al-Nisa’, and al-Ahzab. Some people rearrange them as they wish, and sometimes they add what is not part of it—without realizing that this contradicts his ﷺ guidance, and that it is not permissible to alter established remembrances, even by changing a single word, even if the meaning does not change! See the commentary on the hadith of al-Bara’ that follows (6 – Nawafil / 9 “al-Sahih”).

text: in that [work] a long distance, then my second migration to Amman in the year (1400 AH / 1980 AD) prevented its completion. Now that it has become facilitated for someone to undertake its printing and publishing after verifying it anew—that being the virtuous brother Sheikh Saad Al-Rashid—I have re-examined it in the manner I proceeded with its counterpart "Sahih at-Targhib wa at-Tarhib". I have explained that in its new introduction, so there is no need to state it here again; whoever desires the details may refer back to it, if Allah the Exalted wills. For this reason, it required me to make the ranks of the hadiths in the book five ranks, instead of the three previously. They are: 1 - Weak (Da'if). This is what contains a defaming defect from the known defects of hadith, such as the weakness of one of its narrators, or disturbance (Idtirab), or denouncability (Nakarah), or anomaly (Shudhudh), and the like. 2 - Very Weak (Da'if Jiddan). This is what has in its chain a narrator who is abandoned (Matruk) or severely weak, whose narrations contain so many denounced reports that it is feared they are of his fabrication, such as one about whom Imam Al-Bukhari says: "Munkar al-Hadith" (Denounced in Hadith). 3 - Fabricated (Mawdu'). This is what has in its chain a liar or a fabricator, or where the signs of fabrication are apparent on its text along with a clear defect in its chain. (1) 4 - Denounced (Munkar), or Very Denounced. This is that which has a weak narrator in its chain who contradicted a trustworthy narrator in
foot_note: 1. I say: This type does not become apparent except to one who is firmly grounded in this science, with precise insight into the meanings of the texts, widely read in the authentic Sunnah, and gifted with understanding of the Book of Allah and the Hadith of His Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. The author has sometimes noticed such things; see for example the long hadith of Mu'adh coming under number (27) and Hadith (596).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: its text, or the text itself may be denounced (Munkar), even if he did not contradict [anyone] (1). 5 - Anomalous (Shadh). This is what a trustworthy narrator relates contradicting one who is more trustworthy than him, especially if he contradicts a group of trustworthy narrators; this can be in the chain (2) and it can be in the text. Know, my brother reader! That the first three ranks are customarily used by the people of knowledge, past and present, unlike the last two ranks: The Denounced (Munkar) and the Anomalous (Shadh)—for they were known in the past but abandoned in modern times except rarely. Therefore, I saw that using them—along with the revival of knowledge that was about to be obliterated involved therein—contains a stronger and clearer explanation of the hadith's defect, just as I did in the other book by using the ranks "Hasan Sahih", "Sahih li-ghayrihi" (Authentic due to external factors), and "Hasan li-ghayrihi" (Good due to external factors) {as a bounty from Allah and favor}. Even though this cost me severe fatigue and strenuous effort, as I explained there, hoping for reward and recompense from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic; for the reward is in proportion to the hardship, especially in the service of the Hadith of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, distinguishing its weak from its authentic, and preserving his Sunnah which is an explanation of the Book of Allah, Blessed and Exalted. * I decided that the rank from those ranks should be printed in the margin of the page opposite the author's saying: "From so-and-so..." and the like. * I did not concern myself in the commentary with explaining their reasons except rarely, such as saying for example: In its chain is so-and-so, and he is weak, or very weak, or a liar, or it contains so-and-so, and he is weak, and he

…contradicted by so-and-so who is trustworthy, or it contains such-and-such a narrator who is reliable but was contradicted by someone more reliable than him, and similar matters. I did not commit to mentioning such details except rarely when necessary. However, I deemed it essential to do so in one specific situation: when it becomes clear to me that the author—or someone else—fell into an error by strengthening a hadith or authenticating one of its narrators, or if he hinted toward that. In this case, I committed to clarifying the matter as much as possible to prevent misunderstanding, and so that our fellow readers may gain insight into what we say or what is said.

* A hadith in the book may be attributed to a source that I did not have access to, and thus I could not determine the state of its chain of narration—though this is rare—such as the book *Tajrid as-Sihah* by Razin al-‘Abdari. If, upon examining the text, it appears to me to be inauthentic, I include it in this book of mine without assigning it any rank from the usual categories, and I print in its place the familiar question mark (?), in order to absolve myself of responsibility and to avoid burden. This is in cases where the author did not weaken it or mention its flaw. Otherwise, I classify it as weak, as you will see shortly in the hadith that follows under number (6).

* Sometimes the author cites an authentic hadith, but it contains a sentence or a word that is not authentic—or he cites it through another narration. In such cases, I was uncertain whether to include it in the *Sahih* or in the *Da‘if*, along with the necessary commentary. Similarly, uncertainty arose when the hadith itself was weak but contained a sentence that was authentic. In the first case, I preferred including the hadith in the *Sahih* while removing the unauthentic sentence or word from the text and placing it in the commentary, explaining the reason for its weakness, as I clarified in the introduction to the new edition of the *Sahih*—so there is no need to repeat that here. Conversely, with respect to the weak hadith, I found it appropriate to include it in this…

text: book while moving the authentic sentence down to the commentary if possible without disrupting the context of the hadith, stating its authenticity, and indicating its deletion by printing dots in its place; otherwise, I sufficed with the explanation, as I did with the long hadith of Shahr bin Hawshab coming under number (21). I commented on it explaining the authenticity of his saying, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in it: "Verily Satan has despaired that he would be worshipped in the Arabian Peninsula", and similar is the hadith of Ibn Abbas under number (32), and many, very many others as the readers will see, if Allah the Exalted wills. An example of what is indicated by dots is the hadith of Abu Darda coming in (5 - Prayer / 10), and its examples in the "Sahih" are many. The context of the hadith might assist in excising the authentic sentence from it and printing it in the "Sahih", but the hadith might have been cited by the author in the chapter suitable for it without the sentence. For example, the hadith of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade me from reciting while I am bowing, and said: "O Ali! The likeness of the one who does not straighten his spine..." The Hadith: He mentioned it in the chapter "Warning against not completing the bowing..." due to its relevance to what follows the sentence. So my mentioning it in the "Sahih" would be unsuitable for the mentioned chapter as is apparent, so I saw fit to keep it with the hadith, and comment on it stating its authenticity. The author indicated its weakening by prefacing it with his saying: "Ruwiya" (It was narrated), but some ignorant people proceeded upon its apparent meaning, so they weakened the hadith without excepting the sentence, as will be explained in the commentary on it there (5 - Prayer / 34). This is what came to mind to mention in this introduction as a methodology for what I proceeded upon in this beneficial book, if Allah the Exalted wills, asking the Master, Glory be to Him and Exalted, to take my hand and grant me success in what He loves and is pleased with of speech and action. Indeed, it is necessary for me to remind here that I had written a very comprehensive and useful introduction

text: placed before my book "Sahih at-Targhib wa at-Tarhib", containing numerous chapters and new benefits regarding Al-Mundhiri's book "At-Targhib" and its merits, and what is critiqued about him and other authors in the science of Hadith; much of which is difficult to find elsewhere. Nevertheless, I see no necessity to republish it here, because I assume that whoever acquired this will acquire with it its counterpart "Sahih at-Targhib wa at-Tarhib", so he will find it in its introduction, so I refer him to it. However, I must present a summary of it that suits the subject of this book. So I say: I have explained therein the terminology of Al-Hafiz Al-Mundhiri, may Allah have mercy on him, in his "Targhib", and that he divided his hadiths into two sections: One: He prefaced with the word (An - From), which indicates to him its strength. The other: He prefaced with the word (Ruwiya - It was narrated) in the passive voice, which indicates to him its weakness. And that he included in each of the two sections three categories, and that it is an ambiguous, confusing, and inconsistent division; the general readers can hardly derive his intent from it. I detailed the discussion on that extensively; I do not think anyone addressed it or preceded me to it, and the credit for all of that belongs to Allah alone, and to Him belongs all praise and commendation. Among that is that he included in the first section "what approached the Sahih and Hasan"—according to his saying—from what is weak and known for weakness among the Hadith scholars. For he said, following his mentioned statement: "Likewise if it was: Mursal (hurried), or Munqati' (interrupted), or Mu'dal (problematic/missing two consecutive narrators), or its chain contains an ambiguous narrator... or it was narrated as Marfu' (elevated to the Prophet) while the correct view is it is Mawquf (stopped at a Companion), or connected while the correct view is it is Mursal, or its chain was weak but some of those who extracted it authenticated or improved it"! And I mentioned some examples there. * And that he sometimes imitated the lenient ones in authentication such as At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Hibban, and Al-Hakim, such as the coming hadiths (2, 29, 34, 35) and others, and this is very frequent. * And among that is that in many hadiths, he says in their extraction: "Its narrators are trustworthy" and the like. In that, he is either correct or mistaken. He prefaces it with his first terminology: (An), so one who has no knowledge imagines that the hadith is Sahih or Hasan, while it contains a defaming defect from the defects referred to previously such as Irsal (omission of the first narrator), Inqita' (interruption), and Shudhudh (anomaly); which repels its improvement (Hasan status), let alone its authentication (Sahih status). Such as the hadith of Ibn Abbas warning against the bathhouse; he was truthful in his saying about it: "And its narrators are all relied upon in the Sahih", but it was hidden from him—and Allah knows best—that it is Anomalous (Shadh); due to its trustworthy narrator contradicting one who is more trustworthy than him, for he narrated it as Mursal. Similar is the hadith of Aisha: "I adhered to the Siwak", both are in (4 - Purification under number 127 and 147). The examples of this kind are very, very many. And one of the worst is his saying regarding the hadith of Tha'labah bin al-Hakam on the virtue of scholars (61): "Its narrators are trustworthy"! Yet it contains a narrator accused of fabrication! * And among that is that he does not distinguish what he prefaces of hadiths with his saying: (Ruwiya) between what is Weak, or Very Weak, or Fabricated, and between what is Anomalous (Shadh) or Denounced (Munkar); except rarely. So the readers do not know the rank of the hadith in reality, unless he follows it with something that indicates it from his explanation, and this is very rare.

text: * I have explained there the prohibition entailed by this terminology, and the examples of that are very many such that counting them is difficult in such an introduction. See for example the coming hadiths (3, 6, 7, 11, 12, 15, and 23). And of the rare scarce instances I pointed out is the long hadith of Mu'adh at the end of the Book of Sincerity, prefaced by his saying: "Ruwiya"; yet he concluded the discussion on it after extracting it: "In summary, the signs of fabrication are apparent on it in all its paths, and with all its wordings". * And among that is his reliance in authentication on Ibn Hibban and others who were known among the scholars as being lenient in authentication (Tawthiq), while the authenticated narrator is unknown (Majhul) upon verification. In addition to other matters that made the benefit of the book "At-Targhib" very little; indeed, perhaps it was one of the strong reasons for the spread of weak and flimsy hadiths among students and even scholars of various specializations who have no knowledge of this noble science, due to its misleading terminologies! Contrary to what was intended of distinguishing between the Authentic and the Weak. * And in the introduction to the "Sahih"—from which I summarized the mentioned benefits—is a very important chapter, I can only transfer it here; due to its close connection to this book of ours, because it contains examples suitable for this introduction, and they may be supplements to some of the written benefits, so I apologize to the noble readers if they find it lengthy. I said there: "40 - Types of Al-Mundhiri's Important Illusions in Broad Lines with Examples.

text: As for what follows...", up to half of page 89. I concluded the introduction saying: "What I have dedicated myself to for the service of this book is solely distinguishing its authentic from its weak—as I explained in the beginning of this introduction—because it is the most important thing to me after the Book of Allah, Blessed and Exalted. It is not valid in any way to pair with it anything except what is authentic of the Hadith from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, for it is the second source upon which the Ummah has agreed". Based on this, if any errors are found in this project of mine following its original source, my excuse is what I have mentioned, and an excuse is accepted by noble people." Nevertheless, Allah the Exalted has granted me success and facilitated for me—and to Him belongs the Favor and Grace—to correct many of the various errors that occurred in the original, which have no relation to what I dedicated myself to, as I explained in the introduction to the new edition of the first part of "Sahih at-Targhib". This correction was completely neglected by those three commentators who appeared to the people with a new edition of Al-Mundhiri's book "At-Targhib" in four huge, decorated, embellished volumes; its appearance pleases you, but its reality grieves you. For it is filled with types of obscene errors and trivial thoughts, which indicate decisively the ignorance of those undertaking its commentary and verification—a scandalous, extreme ignorance with no limits, in everything that crosses the readers' minds of the sciences that one claiming to verify this book should be realized in. This book, about whose multitude of errors and illusions Al-Hafiz Ibrahim an-Naji complained—as mentioned previously. They are ignorant in language, verification, and returning to the original sources, let alone

…Fiqh, the sciences of Hadith, and the disciplines of criticism and praise (Jarh wa Ta'dil). And to state the truth: they are not proficient in anything except imitation, stealing the efforts of others, and pretending to possess knowledge that they were never given—along with arrogance, affected learning, and a love of showing off and opposing others. I have explained this sufficiently in the previously referenced introduction, mentioning some significant examples that refute them and expose what was attributed to them. Whoever wishes to examine that may refer back to it.

However, I must mention here some additional examples of the ignorance found in their edition, specifically concerning the hadiths of this book of ours, *Da'if at-Targhib*, in fulfillment of what I promised in the introduction to *Sahih at-Targhib*, in a style similar to what I presented there. So I say:

1 – Their inability to verify the text and correct it by returning to the primary sources and classical usage of language—due to their ignorance of all of this. Examples include the word (yurabbithūn) in the hadith of ‘Ali regarding the encouragement to go early to the Friday prayer (7 – Jumu‘ah / 3 / under the first hadith). It is derived from *rabbatha–yurabbithu*, yet it was miswritten in the edition of those ignorant ones and in others as (tarayyatha). The explanation provided by the author is correct—and that alone is enough to teach the ignorant and awaken the heedless. See the following pages for further examples of this kind (pp. 77, 181, 187, 234, 239, 279, 316, 320, 333, and 335).

2 – Their grading as “Hasan” the hadiths narrated by weak narrators, those who commit deception (mudallisin), and unknown narrators—and their inconsistency in doing so. This includes the hadiths of Shahr, Layth ibn Sulaym, Muhammad ibn Ishaq, and others, despite knowing…

text: of the defect in some cases, such as the hadith of (Shahr) number (19), they classified it as Hasan, and said about him: "Sadduq" (Truthful), then they explicitly weakened his hadith coming after it, hadith (21)! That is only due to ignorance and imitation. If they had said in the first of them: "Hasan li-ghayrihi" (Good due to external factors)—as they said in others—it would have been lighter! Similar is Hadith (145), they quoted Al-Haythami declaring it defective due to Tadlis (deception), and they accepted it, yet they classified it as Hasan!! Similar is Hadith (148)—and see the following hadiths with numbers: (363, 466, 484, 518, 528, 592—and it is fabricated—and 599 and 644). 3 - They sometimes classify as Hasan, and sometimes Authenticate (Sahih) the hadiths about which the author or Al-Haythami says: "Its men are trustworthy" or "Its men are the men of the Sahih", or even what he says about: "Its men are documented". This is from their extreme ignorance of the science of Hadith terminology, for that does not mean more than the fulfillment of one of the conditions of Authenticity or Goodness, as I had explained in the introduction to "Sahih at-Targhib", and I pointed out this ignorance of theirs in the introduction to the new edition of it. The examples of that are very many in this first volume, so how about their multitude in the other volumes; one of the worst is that they classified as Hasan the Fabricated Hadith coming in (7 - Friday / 1 Hadith 6) regarding Allah's forgiveness for all Muslims on Friday! And see Hadith number (26), and Hadiths (573, 578, 615, 616, and 635). And what confirms to you their mentioned ignorance is that they said regarding a hadith from those hadiths where Al-Haythami added nothing to documenting its men: "And Al-Haythami authenticated it"! text: 4 - They improve (classify as Hasan) some hadiths based on supporting evidences (Shawahid), and sometimes based on a single witness (Shahid), while there is nothing of that in many cases, or it may be a deficient witness that testifies for part of the hadith without the other part, as I explained in "The Introduction to the Sahih" section (13). I mention here some examples, among them their saying regarding the hadith of Hudhayfah: "Allah does not accept from an innovator a fast... he leaves Islam as a hair is pulled from dough". They said: "Hasan due to its supporting evidences"! While it is Fabricated as I explained there number (43). Similar is the hadith of Umm Habiba regarding praying four rak'ahs before Asr (327). And similar to that is what will be alerted to under Hadiths (34, 131, 182, and 663), and many others. 5 - As for what they classified as Hasan or Sahih by itself; either by imitation or stumbling blindly; it is a frightening thing due to its quantity, and all of that with a stroke of a pen, without any commentary or direction. Based on what has become clear to me of their absolute ignorance, if it were said to them: "Why did you classify it as Hasan or Sahih?"; they would not be able to give an answer, or they would say: So-and-so classified it as Hasan, or so-and-so authenticated it! See for example numbers (7, 13, 26, 73, 80, 93, 117, 132, 145, 192, 214, 228, 259, 273, 300, 327, 339, 342, 343, 346, 363, 415, 426, 436, 453, 465, 473, 478, 565, 628, 635, and 637). And others which alert will be drawn to, if Allah the Exalted wills, also in this volume and the second volume. The first number of them (13) represents a special type of their ignorance, because the author cited the hadith from Abu Huraira regarding Riya (showing off) at length, indicating its weakness, then he said:

text: "And he narrated it briefly from the hadith of Ibn Umar, and said: A Hasan Hadith". Even though this is also weak as you will see explained there, the ignorant ones included both in the improvement (Hasan classification), so they said: "Hasan, narrated by At-Tirmidhi... from Abu Huraira... and from Ibn Umar"!! 6 - And among that is that they come across the author's authentication of the hadith and the agreement of someone like Al-Haythami with him, so they contradict, and say: "Hasan"; without any explanation as is their habit. That is from their reservations which inform the researcher that they feel their ignorance of this science, so they take a middle path between those who authenticated and those who might have weakened or it is possible, while the reality is that they are mistaken in the classification of Hasan. An example is the coming narration from Ibn Mas'ud: that "Whoever does not pay Zakat, there is no prayer for him"! Number (465), and similar is number (655). 7 - And among that is that they mix with the Authentic hadith what is not authentic of it. See examples in numbers (208, 489, 501, 569, 583, and 642). 8 - And similar is their mixing between what is Weak of the hadith, and what is Very Weak, so they apply to both of them: "Weak"! And they may quote after it from the speech of some Huffaz what contradicts it, and the hadith might be Fabricated!! See if you wish some numbers: (114, 484, 586 - 587, 587 - 588, 615, 645, 664, 675, and 677). 9 - And from their banes is their blind imitation, which is not accompanied by any research or verification, which the most ignorant of people are not incapable of. Narrated by Ibn Jarir at-Tabari as Mursal. 23 - (16) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Adi bin Hatim who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "On the Day of Resurrection, people will be ordered from the Fire to Paradise, until when they draw near to it, and smell its scent, and look at its palaces, and what Allah prepared for its people in it, it will be called out: Turn them away from it, for they have no share in it. So they will return with a regret the like of which the first ones never returned with. So they will say: Our Lord! Had You entered us into the Fire before showing us Paradise, -and in a narration: before showing us what You showed us of Your reward, and what You prepared in it for Your allies- it would have been easier for us. He said: That is what I intended for you. When you were alone you confronted Me with great sins, and when you met people you met them humbly, showing off to people the opposite of what you give Me from your hearts. You feared people and did not fear Me, you honored people and did not honor Me, and you left [things] for people and did not leave for Me. Today I will make you taste the painful punishment, along with what you were deprived of reward." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Al-Bayhaqi. 24 - (17) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Darda from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Indeed piety in work; is harder than work. Then the Satan keeps at him until he mentions it to people a second time, and he loves to be mentioned for it and praised for it, so it is erased from the public deeds and written as showing off (Riya'). So let a person who safeguards his religion fear Allah, for indeed showing off is Shirk.' Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi, and he said: 'This is from the unique narrations of Baqiyyah from his unknown Sheikhs.' Al-Hafiz Abdul-Azim said: 'I think it is Mawquf (stopped at the companion). So when Allah gathers them on the Day of Resurrection, He will say to the one who eats from the people: By My Might and Majesty, what did you intend by My worship? He will say: By Your Might and Majesty, I used it to eat from the people. He will say: What you gathered did not benefit you; take him to the Fire. Then He will say to the one who used to worship Him out of showing off: By My Might and Majesty, what did you intend by My worship? He will say: By Your Might and Majesty, to show off to the people. He will say: Nothing of it ascended to Me; take him to the Fire. Then He will say to the one who used to worship Him sincerely: By My Might and Majesty, what did you intend by My worship? He will say: By Your Might and Majesty, You know best what I intended by it. I intended by it Your Remembrance and Your Face. He will say: My servant has spoken the truth; take him to Paradise.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat' from the narration of Ubayd bin Ishaq Al-Attar (2), and the rest of its narrators are trustworthy,

I am the angel of mercy; my Lord commanded me not to let his deed pass me to another. He said: Then the recording angels ascend with the deed of the servant to the seventh heaven; consisting of fasting, prayer, spending, diligence, and piety, having a buzzing sound like the buzzing of thunder and a light like the light of the sun, accompanied by three thousand angels. So they pass with it to the seventh heaven. The angel entrusted with it says to them: Stop and strike the face of its owner with this deed, strike his limbs, and lock his heart. Indeed, I veil from my Lord every deed by which the Face of my Lord was not intended. Indeed, he intended by his deed other than Allah; he intended by it elevation among the jurists, mention among the scholars, and fame in the cities. My Lord commanded me not to let his deed pass me to another, and every deed that is not purely for Allah is showing off (Riya'), and Allah does not accept the deed of the one who shows off. He said: Then the recording angels ascend with the deed of the servant consisting of prayer, zakat, fasting, Hajj, Umrah, good character, silence, and remembrance of Allah the Exalted. The angels of the heavens accompany it until they cross all the veils to Allah, Mighty and Majestic. They stand before Him and testify for him regarding the righteous deed done sincerely for Allah. He said: So Allah says to them: You are the guardians over the deed of My servant, and I am the Watcher over his soul. Indeed, he did not intend Me with this deed, and he intended other than Me by it. So upon him is My curse. All the angels say: And upon him is Your curse and our curse. And all the heavens say: Upon him is the curse of Allah and our curse. And the seven heavens and whoever is in them curse him.

text: Mu'adh said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! You are the Messenger of Allah and I am Mu'adh. He said: 'Follow my example, even if there is shortcoming in your deed. O Mu'adh! Guard your tongue from slandering your brothers among the bearers of the Quran. Bear your sins yourself and do not burden them with them. Do not purify yourself by disparaging them. Do not elevate yourself over them. Do not mix the work of the world with the work of the Hereafter. Do not be arrogant in your gathering so that people beware of your bad character. Do not whisper to a man while another is with you. Do not act grandiosely over people lest the good of the world and the Hereafter be cut off from you. Do not tear people apart (backbite), lest the dogs of the Fire tear you apart on the Day of Resurrection in the Fire. Allah the Exalted said: {And by those who pull out sharply (An-Nashitat)}. Do you know what they are, O Mu'adh?' I said: What are they, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you? He said: 'Dogs in the Fire that tear off flesh and bone.' I said: May my father and mother be sacrificed for you! Who can bear these traits, and who can be saved from them? He said: 'O Mu'adh! Indeed, it is easy for him whom Allah makes it easy.' He said: So I never saw anyone reciting the Quran more than Mu'adh; out of caution against what is in this hadith. Narrated by Ibn Al-Mubarak in 'Kitab Az-Zuhd' from a man he did not name, from Mu'adh (1). And Ibn Hibban narrated it in other than the 'Sahih', and Al-Hakim and others. 28 - (21) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ali and others. In summary; the signs of fabrication are apparent on it in all its paths, and with all its wordings.
foot_note: 1. I did not find it in this complete form in 'Az-Zuhd' from Mu'adh. Al-Hafiz An-Naji pointed this out in 'Ujalat Al-Imla' (folio 10 - 12), and detailed the discussion on that thoroughly. Likewise, Ibn Hibban narrated part of it in 'Ad-Du'afa' (2/ 214 - 215), and from his path Ibn Al-Jawzi mentioned it in 'Al-Mawdu'at' (3/ 154 - 161) and from other paths including the path of Al-Hakim. He also cited it from the hadith of Ali, and judged all of that as fabricated. This is apparent to anyone with intellect.

text: Narrated by Ibn Abi Asim and others (1). 42 - (8) [Very Weak] And from Amr bin Awf, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to Bilal bin Al-Harith one day: 'Know, O Bilal!' He said: What should I know, O Messenger of Allah?! He said: 'Know that whoever revives a Sunnah from my Sunnah that has died out after me; he will have a reward like the reward of those who acted upon it, without diminishing anything from their rewards. And whoever introduces a misleading innovation (Bid'ah Dalalah) (2) that Allah and His Messenger do not approve of, upon him will be the like of the sins of those who acted upon it, without that diminishing anything from the burdens of the people.' Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Ibn Majah; both via the path of Kathir bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Awf from his father from his grandfather. At-Tirmidhi said: 'Hasan Hadith' (3). Al-Hafiz said: 'Rather, Kathir bin Abdullah is Matruk (abandoned) and flimsy as mentioned before; but the Hadith has witnesses (4)'.
foot_note:
1. See 'Zilal Al-Jannah' (1/ 9 - 10/ 7) and 'Ad-Da'ifah' (5560).
2. The word: "Dalalah" (misleading/misguidance) is in At-Tirmidhi but not Ibn Majah. It is also in Ibn Abi Asim in 'As-Sunnah' (No. 42 - My verification), and Ibn Wahb narrated it in his 'Musnad' (8/ 166/ 2), and from him Ibn Waddah in 'Al-Bida' (p. 38), and Ishaq Ar-Ramli in 'Hadith Adam' (2/ 2), and Al-Baghawi in 'Sharh As-Sunnah' (No. 110 - Islamic Office edition) without the mentioned word. Perhaps this difference is from Kathir bin Abdullah Al-Muzani - its narrator - for he is very weak; indeed Abu Dawud and others called him a liar, even if some considered the correctness of that unlikely, with an argument weaker than a spider's web, there is no space now to clarify and refute it.
3. I say: Meaning Hasan due to external evidence (Li-Ghayrihi), for in it is an indication from him of his weakening of its chain as he explained in a rule of his in his 'Ilal'. So the saying of some: 'It is questionable' is only from a lack of insight into this science. Yes, his mentioned grading of Hasan is rejected from its foundation; firstly due to the severity of the weakness of its narrator, and secondly because its text contains what has no witness, which is his saying: 'misleading innovation, that does not please Allah and His Messenger'. Therefore, some innovators clung to it and deduced from its implication that there is in Islam a 'good innovation' that pleases Allah and His Messenger! So it is said to him: Prove the Throne then sculpt (prove the basis first). And the witnesses which the author, may Allah have mercy on him, pointed to do not contain this sentence, as you will see in the upcoming chapter from 'As-Sahih'. Furthermore, the documentation of this hadith was distorted by the five investigators (!) of 'Ash-Shifa', so they said (2/ 28): 'Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Majah graded it Hasan'! This indicates their extreme ignorance of this art; for beginners in it do not miss that Ibn Majah is not in the habit of discussing the hadith and grading it Hasan! As for their obliviousness to its defect, it is fitting for one who claims verification without having knowledge of it.
4. I say: Meaning in general, otherwise his saying: 'Dalalah' has no witness as explained just now. So take note.

He said: What should I know, O Messenger of Allah? He said: 'That whoever revives a Sunnah from my Sunnah that has died out after me, he will have a reward like those who acted upon it without diminishing anything from their rewards. And whoever introduces a misleading innovation that Allah and His Messenger do not approve of; upon him will be the like of the sins of those who acted upon it, without that diminishing anything from the burdens of the people.' Narrated by Ibn Majah, and At-Tirmidhi who graded it Hasan (1). 43 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'There is no caller who calls to something except that he will stand on the Day of Resurrection bound to his call to what he called to, even if a man called [only] one man.' Narrated by Ibn Majah, and its narrators are trustworthy (2).
foot_note:
1. This hadith passed in the previous page with the commentary on it, so refer to it.
2. Thus he said! And it contains Layth bin Abi Sulaym, who is weak and confused (Mukhtalit). He was confused in its chain, sometimes attributing it to Abu Hurairah, and other times to Anas.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - Book of Knowledge 1 - (Encouragement for Knowledge, Seeking it, Learning it, and Teaching it, and What has Come Regarding the Virtue of Scholars and Learners). 44 - (1) [Denounced] And from Abdullah - meaning Ibn Mas'ud - may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'If Allah intends good for a servant, He gives him understanding in the religion, and inspires him with his guidance.' Narrated by Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir' with a chain that is not bad (1). 45 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'The best worship is Fiqh (understanding), and the best religion is Wara' (piety).' Narrated by At-Tabarani in his 'Three Mu'jams', and in its chain is Muhammad bin Abi Layla (2). 46 - (3) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Umar [and] (3) may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: 'A little Fiqh (4) is better than a lot of worship. And it is sufficient Fiqh for a person if he worships Allah, and it is sufficient ignorance for a person if he is impressed by his own opinion.'
foot_note:
1. I say: This gives the illusion that At-Tabarani has the addition "and inspires him with his guidance", but it is not so. Moreover, it is a Munkar (denounced) addition as I verified in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (5032). As for what is before it, it is in 'As-Sahih' here.
2. The second half of his hadith has a witness from the hadith of Hudhayfah, so see it here in 'As-Sahih'.
3. Dropped from the original, the manuscript, the edition of the three, and 'Al-Majma', and I restored it from 'Al-Awsat' and others.
4. Original: (Knowledge), and the correction is from 'Awsat At-Tabarani' (9/ 318/ 8693) and 'Shu'ab Al-Iman' by Al-Bayhaqi (2/ 265/ 1705). The three ignorant ones attributed it to him, yet they did not correct this word!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat', and in its chain is Ishaq bin Asid, who has some soft authentication, and elevating this hadith (to the Prophet) is strange (Gharib). Al-Bayhaqi said: 'And we narrated it authentically from the saying of Mutarrif bin Abdullah bin Ash-Shikhir', then he mentioned it. And Allah knows best. 1 - (Chapter) 47 - (4) [Fabricated] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Learn knowledge; for indeed learning it for Allah is fear (Khashyah), seeking it is worship, [revising it] (*) is Tasbih, researching it is Jihad, teaching it to one who does not know it is charity, and spending it for its people is nearness (to Allah). Because it is the signpost of the lawful and the prohibited, the lighthouse of the paths of the people of Paradise. It is the companion in loneliness, the friend in estrangement, the conversationalist in seclusion, the guide in prosperity and adversity, the weapon against enemies, and the adornment among friends. Allah raises peoples by it and makes them leaders and imams (1) in good whose footsteps are traced, whose deeds are emulated, and whose opinions are referred to. The angels desire their friendship (2), and wipe them with their wings. Every wet and dry thing seeks forgiveness for them, even the fish of the sea and its vermin, and the beasts of the land and its cattle. Because knowledge is the life of hearts from ignorance, and the lamps of the eyes from darkness. The servant reaches by knowledge the stations of the righteous and the high degrees in the world and the Hereafter. Thinking about it is equivalent to fasting, and studying it is equivalent to standing (in prayer). By it ties of kinship are joined, and by it the lawful is known from the prohibited. It is the leader of action, and action is its follower. The happy ones are inspired with it, and the wretched ones are deprived of it.'
foot_note:
1. In the original and the edition of Amarah: (Qa'imah - standing/list), and the correction is from the manuscript and 'Kitab Al-Ilm' by Ibn Abd Al-Barr.
2. Meaning: their friendship and love. (*) The preparer of the book for Ash-Shamilah said: In the printed version (Mudhakeratuhu - his notes/memoirs), and Sheikh Mashhur alerted to its correction in his edition.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ibn Abd Al-Barr An-Namari in 'Kitab Al-Ilm' from the narration of Musa bin Muhammad bin Ata Al-Qurashi: Abdur-Rahim bin Zaid Al-Ammi told us from his father from Al-Hasan from him. And he said: 'It is a [very] (1) Hasan hadith, but it does not have a strong chain, and we have narrated it from various paths as Mawquf.' Thus he said, may Allah have mercy on him, but elevating it (to the Prophet) is very strange. And Allah knows best. 48 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Seeking knowledge is an obligation upon every Muslim, and the one who places knowledge with other than its people is like one who hangs jewels, pearls, and gold on swine' (2). Narrated by Ibn Majah and others. 49 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Whoever is overtaken by his death while he is seeking knowledge; he meets Allah with nothing between him and the Prophets except the degree of Prophethood.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat'. 50 - (7) [Very Weak] And from Wathilah bin Al-Asqa', may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Whoever seeks knowledge and attains it; Allah writes for him two portions of reward, and whoever seeks knowledge and does not attain it; Allah writes for him one portion of reward.'
foot_note:
1. Addition from 'Kitab Al-Ilm' (1/ 55). Musa Al-Qurashi Al-Balqawi is a liar, and his Sheikh is Matruk.
2. I say: The first sentence of it is Sahih and has many witnesses, some of which are Hasan, and for that reason I included it in 'As-Sahih' as well.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir', and its narrators are trustworthy, but there is some criticism regarding them (1). 51 - (8) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Sakhbarah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Two men passed by the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, while he was reminding (teaching), so he said: 'Sit, for you are upon good.' When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, stood up and his companions dispersed from him, they stood up and said: O Messenger of Allah! You said to us: Sit, for you are upon good. Is it for us specifically or for the people generally? He said: 'There is no servant who seeks knowledge except that it is an expiation for what has passed.' Narrated by At-Tirmidhi briefly, and At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir', and the wording is his. (Sakhbarah) with a Fatha on the un-dotted Sin, a Sakin dotted Kha, a Ba, and a Ra followed by a Ta Marbuta; there is disagreement regarding his companionship. And Allah knows best. 52 - (9) [Very Weak] And from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'No earner has earned anything like the virtue of knowledge which guides its owner to guidance, or turns him back from ruin. And his religion does not become straight until his action becomes straight.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir' and the wording is his and 'As-Saghir'; except that he said in it: 'until his intellect becomes straight'. And their chains are close (Muqarib) (2). 53 - (10) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Dharr and Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with them both, that they said: 'Indeed, a chapter which a man learns is more beloved to me than a thousand rak'ahs of voluntary prayer.' And they said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said:
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, but it contains a Matruk narrator who fell from At-Tabarani's chain, but is established in the narration of others. The author did not notice him, and Al-Haythami, Al-A'zami, and the three commentators imitated him! And his saying: 'but there is some criticism regarding them' is another error. All of this is clarified in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (6709).
2. Thus he said! And it contains (Abdur-Rahman bin Zaid bin Aslam) who is Matruk. His saying: 'Al-Kabir' is an error perhaps from the copyist, and the correct is: 'Al-Awsat'. Then the mentioned wording is for 'As-Saghir', and the other is for 'Al-Awsat'. The details are in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (6710).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 'If death comes to the seeker of knowledge while he is in this state, he dies as a martyr.' Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat'; except that he said: 'It is better for him than a thousand rak'ahs.' 54 - (11) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'O Abu Dharr! That you go out (1) in the morning and learn a verse from the Book of Allah is better for you than praying one hundred rak'ahs. And that you go out in the morning and learn a chapter of knowledge - whether acted upon or not acted upon - is better for you than praying one thousand rak'ahs.' Narrated by Ibn Majah with a Hasan chain (2). 55 - (12) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Mas'ud from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: 'Whoever learns a chapter of knowledge to teach the people; is given the reward of seventy Siddiqs.' Narrated by Abu Mansour Ad-Daylami in 'Musnad Al-Firdaws', and it contains Nakarah (denouncement) (3). 56 - (13) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'There is no man who learns a word, or two words, or three, or four, or five from what Allah (Azza wa Jal) has ordained, and he learns them and teaches them; except that he enters Paradise.' Abu Hurairah said: So I never forgot a hadith after hearing them from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Narrated by Abu Nu'aym, and its chain is Hasan if Al-Hasan heard from Abu Hurairah (4).
foot_note:
1. With a Fatha on the Lam for initiation. And (An) with Fatha on Hamza is Masdariyyah (infinitive), forming the subject (Mubtada), and its predicate is his saying: "is better...", like the saying of the Exalted: {And that you fast is better for you}. Meaning: Your going out of the house in the morning... etc.
2. Thus he said! And it contains three narrators regarding whom there is criticism, one of them is (Ali bin Zaid bin Jad'an). Therefore, Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi weakened it in 'Al-Mughni' (1/ 8).
3. I say: Rather, it contains a liar according to Al-Iraqi and As-Suyuti, so see 'Ad-Da'ifah' (6803).
4. I say: It contains another defect which is Shudhudh (anomaly) and Contradiction. I undertook clarifying that in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (6804).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 57 - (14) [Weak] And from him; that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'The best charity is for a Muslim man to learn knowledge, then teach it to his Muslim brother.' Narrated by Ibn Majah with a Hasan chain via the path of Al-Hasan also from Abu Hurairah. 58 - (15) [Very Weak] And from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'The scholars of this Ummah are two men: A man whom Allah gave knowledge so he spent it for the people, and did not take greed for it, nor did he buy a price with it. For that one, the fish of the sea, the beasts of the land, and the birds in the sky seek forgiveness [and he comes to Allah as a noble chief, until he accompanies the Messengers] (1). And a man whom Allah gave knowledge but he was stingy with it towards the servants of Allah, and took greed for it, and bought a price with it. That one will be bridled on the Day of Resurrection with a bridle of fire. And a caller will call out: This is the one whom Allah gave knowledge, but he was stingy with it towards the servants of Allah, and took greed for it, and bought a price with it. And so on until the account is finished.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat', and in its chain is Abdullah bin Kharash; Ibn Hibban authenticated him alone as far as I know (3). 59 - (16) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Upon you is this knowledge before it is taken (seized), and its seizing is that it is lifted - and he joined between his middle finger and the one next to the thumb, like this, then said: - The scholar and the learner are partners in good, and there is no good in the rest of the people.' Narrated by Ibn Majah via the path of Ali bin Yazid from Al-Qasim from him.
foot_note:
1. (1 and 2) Addition from 'Al-Majma' and 'Fadl Al-Ilm' by Ad-Dawalibi (No. 14 - My verification).
3. I say: This authentication is of no value whatsoever; due to Ibn Hibban's known leniency in authentication, and because he himself mentioned what implies his weakness, which is his saying: "He may err"! And more important than all this is that he contradicted the critical Imams like the saying of Al-Bukhari and Abu Hatim: "Munkar Al-Hadith", and some accused him of lying and fabrication. See 'At-Tahdhib'.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: His saying: (And there is no good in the rest of the people) meaning: in the rest of the people after the scholar and the learner. It is close in meaning to his saying: 'The world is cursed, cursed is what is in it; except the remembrance of Allah and what follows it, and a scholar and a learner.' And it passed (1). 60 - (17) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Indeed, the likeness of the scholars on earth is like the likeness of the stars by which guidance is found in the darkness of the land and sea. If the stars are obliterated, the guides are about to go astray.' Narrated by Ahmad from Abu Hafs, the companion of Anas, from him, and I did not know him, and it also contains Rishdin. 61 - (18) [Fabricated] And from Tha'labah bin Al-Hakam the Companion, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Allah (Azza wa Jal) says to the scholars on the Day of Resurrection when He sits on His Throne to judge His servants: Indeed, I did not place My knowledge and My clemency in you except that I want to forgive you, for what was in you, and I do not care.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir', and its narrators are trustworthy (2). Al-Hafiz said, may Allah have mercy on him: 'And look at His saying, Subhanahu wa Ta'ala: "My knowledge and My clemency", and look deeply into it; it will become clear to you
foot_note:
1. I say: It is in 'As-Sahih', here in this chapter.
2. Thus he said! And it contains (Al-Ala' bin Maslamah Abu Salim), and he is accused of fabrication, as clarified in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (867). The three ignorant ones stole its summary, and used it to critique the author and those who followed him, saying: 'We say (!): It contains Al-Ala' bin Maslamah, who used to fabricate hadith'! Yet despite this, due to their ignorance, they prefaced the hadith by saying: 'Weak'!! And they did not say it is Fabricated, which is necessary from their finding fault with Al-Ala'!! Either due to their ignorance of what is necessitated, or out of (Oppose to be known). I fear that the name of this accused narrator was distorted, as happened in 'Tafsir Ibn Kathir' (3/ 141) and 'Jami' Al-Masanid': (Al-Ala' bin Salim), which is an error resulting in another error, which is his saying: 'Its chain is Jayyid'! I had relied on it before I came across its chain and its defect, so Allah guided me, and all praise is due to Allah.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: by His attributing it to Himself (Azza wa Jal) that the intended meaning is not the knowledge of most people of the time which is stripped of action and sincerity.' 62 - (19) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Musa who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Allah resurrects the servants on the Day of Resurrection, then distinguishes the scholars and says: O assembly of scholars! I did not place My knowledge in you to punish you. Go, for I have forgiven you.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir'. 63 - (20) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'The scholar and the worshipper are brought. It is said to the worshipper: Enter Paradise. And it is said to the scholar: Stop until you intercede for the people.' Narrated by Al-Asbahani and others. 64 - (21) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'The scholar and the worshipper are resurrected. It is said to the worshipper: Enter Paradise. And it is said to the scholar: Stay so that you may intercede for the people; because of how you improved their manners.' Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and others. 65 - (22) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'The virtue of the scholar over the worshipper is seventy degrees, between every two degrees is the running of a horse for seventy years. That is because the Satan introduces an innovation to the people, so the scholar spots it and forbids it, while the worshipper is occupied with the worship of his Lord, not turning to it nor knowing it.' Narrated by Al-Asbahani, and the end of the hadith resembles the Mudraj (interpolated text) (1).
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, and this applies in the hadith of a trustworthy narrator where it becomes clear to the researcher that such a person would not narrate such a thing, making it apparent that it cannot be Marfu'. But since the original narrator is not trustworthy; there is no basis for this saying regarding him, because it is possible that it is from his insertion. See 'Ad-Da'ifah' (6578).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Hadr Al-Faras) means: its running. 66 - (23) [Very Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'One Faqih (jurist) is harder on Satan than a thousand worshippers.' Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, and Al-Bayhaqi via the narration of Ruh bin Janah, he was alone in narrating it from Mujahid from him. 67 - (24) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: 'Allah is not worshiped with anything better than Fiqh (understanding) in religion. Indeed, one Faqih is harder on Satan than a thousand worshippers. And for everything there is a pillar, and the pillar of this religion is Fiqh.' And Abu Hurairah said: That I sit for an hour gaining understanding is more beloved to me than staying up a night until the morning (1). Narrated by Ad-Daraqutni, and Al-Bayhaqi; except that he said: 'More beloved to me than staying up a night until the morning.' And he said: 'What is preserved is [that] this wording is from the saying of Az-Zuhri' (2). 2 - (Chapter) 68 - (25) [Weak] And from Jabir who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Knowledge is of two types: Knowledge in the heart, that is the beneficial knowledge. And knowledge on the tongue, that is the proof of Allah against the son of Adam.'
foot_note:
1. Original: (Al-Qadar - Decree), and the correction is from 'Sunan Ad-Daraqutni', and the wording of Al-Bayhaqi witnesses to it.
2. He said it before the hadith (2/ 266) and after narrating the first part of it from the hadith of Ibn Umar as Marfu' without his saying: "Indeed one Faqih...", etc., and its chain is weak, unlike the chain of Abu Hurairah for it contains a liar. The clarification of that is in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (6912).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Al-Hafiz Abu Bakr Al-Khatib in his 'Tarikh' with a Hasan chain (1). And Ibn Abd Al-Barr An-Namari narrated it in 'Kitab Al-Ilm' from Al-Hasan as Mursal with a Sahih chain. 69 - (26) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Knowledge is of two types: Knowledge established in the heart, that is the beneficial knowledge. And knowledge in the tongue, that is the proof of Allah against His servants.' Narrated by Abu Mansour Ad-Daylami in 'Musnad Al-Firdaws', and Al-Asbahani in 'His Book' (2). And Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from Al-Fudayl bin Iyad from his saying, not Marfu'. 70 - (27) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Indeed, among knowledge is that which is like the hidden thing (Maknun), no one knows it except the scholars of Allah the Exalted. If they speak of it, no one denies it except the people of delusion regarding Allah, Mighty and Majestic.' Narrated by Abu Mansour Ad-Daylami in 'Al-Musnad', and Abu Abdur-Rahman As-Sulami in 'Al-Arba'in' regarding Sufism.
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, and it is questionable as I clarified in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (3945), and 'Al-Mishkat' (270).
2. Meaning 'At-Targhib Wa At-Tarhib'. There is a manuscript copy of it in the Public Library in Madinah, and a photocopy of it in the library of the Islamic University in Madinah. I have benefited from it greatly, and I made an index for its books and chapters, and endowed it to the library to facilitate reference for myself and for students wishing to verify, may Allah bless them. Then the book was printed in two volumes at the expense of a benefactor, may Allah reward him, but whoever documented its hadiths did not encompass everything. And this one, its chain contains (2112) Yusuf bin Atiyah who is Matruk, and below him is Ali bin Mudrik, Ibn Ma'in said: "Liar". And his Sheikh (Abdus-Salam bin Salih) is accused. Despite these afflictions, some Hafiz graded it Hasan, and the three commentators imitated him. It is documented in 'Ad-Da'ifah' number (3945).
3. Meaning: The people of heedlessness.

text: 2 - (Encouragement to Travel for Seeking Knowledge). 71 - (1) [Weak] And from Qabisah bin Al-Mukhariq, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and he said: 'O Qabisah! What brought you?' I said: My age has advanced, and my bones have thinned, so I came to you to teach me what Allah the Exalted will benefit me with. He said: 'O Qabisah! You have not passed by a stone, nor a tree, nor a clod of mud, except that it sought forgiveness for you. O Qabisah! When you pray Fajr, say three times: Glory be to Allah the Great and with His Praise; you will be cured from blindness, leprosy, and paralysis. O Qabisah! Say: O Allah, indeed I ask You from what is with You, pour upon me from Your favor, spread over me from Your mercy, and send down upon me from Your blessings.' Narrated by Ahmad, and in its chain is a narrator who was not named. 72 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ali who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'No servant has ever put on sandals, nor put on light footwear, nor worn a garment in seeking knowledge; except that Allah forgave him his sins as he steps over the threshold of his house.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat'. His saying: (Takhaffaf) means: wore his Khuff (leather socks/light footwear). 73 - (3) [Very Weak] And from Abu Darda who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: 'Whoever goes out in the morning intending knowledge to learn it for Allah; Allah opens for him a door to Paradise, and the angels spread their wings for him, and the angels of the heavens and the fish of the sea pray for him. And for the scholar is a
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: virtue over the worshipper like the moon on the night of the full moon over the smallest star in the sky. The scholars are the heirs of the Prophets. Indeed, the Prophets did not bequeath a dinar nor a dirham, but they bequeathed knowledge. So whoever takes it has taken an abundant share (1). And the death of a scholar is a calamity that cannot be mended, and a breach that cannot be closed (2). He is a star that has been obliterated. And the death of a tribe is easier than the death of a scholar.' Narrated by Abu Dawud, At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his 'Sahih', and they do not have: 'the death of a scholar' to the end (3). And Al-Bayhaqi narrated it - and the wording is his - from the narration of Al-Walid bin Muslim: Khalid bin Yazid bin Abi Malik told us from Uthman bin Ayman from him. And the hadith of Abu Ar-Rudain will come in the next chapter, Allah the Exalted willing.

1. Original: (Bi Huzzihi), and the correction is from the manuscript, and the ignorant ones missed it as usual!
2. (Ath-Thulmah): The defect/gap, and its plural is (Thulam), like: Ghurfah and Ghuraf.
3. And it passed without this addition in 'As-Sahih' in the beginning of the first chapter. It is from the ignorance of the three commentators here that they graded the hadith Hasan by referencing the hadith mentioned before without it! The details are in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (4838).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - (Encouragement to Hear Hadith, Convey it, and Copy it, and Warning against Lying about the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him - (1) ) 74 - (1) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'O Allah, have mercy on my successors.' We said: O Messenger of Allah! And who are your successors? He said: 'Those who come after me, narrating my hadiths and teaching them to the people.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat'. 75 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Ar-Rudain who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'There are no people who gather upon the Book of Allah, studying it among themselves; except that they are guests of Allah, and the angels surround them until they stand up or engage in other talk. And there is no scholar who goes out seeking knowledge fearing that he might die; or copying it fearing that it might be effaced; except that he is like the warrior going out in the way of Allah. And whoever is slowed down by his deeds, will not be hastened forward by his lineage' (2). Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir' from the narration of Ismail bin Ayyash (3).

And [I explained] the error of the author in his statement regarding the narrator: that he is (.. Ibn Abdullah An-Numairi), and the error of what is in "Kashf Al-Astar" that he is (Ziyad An-Numairi) with the addition of (An-Numairi)! A group was deceived by them, including the commentator on "Musnad Abu Ya'la", while the correct identification is (Ziyad) without attribution as in the narration of a group of Hafizs, and some of them attributed him saying: (Ziyad bin Maimun) and this is the correct one, and this one is Matruk (discarded/suspected of lying), whereas (An-Numairi) is Da'if (weak). And regarding the Matruk one, it is also said: (Ziyad bin Abi Hassan). And from the contradictions of the ignorant ones is their statement in one line (1/ 162): "Al-Bazzar narrated it in Kashf Al-Astar (1951) and in it is Ziyad bin Abi Hassan and he is Matruk." For indeed what is in "Al-Kashf" is (Ziyad An-Numairi) as mentioned, but their defecting it with the Matruk narrator is contradictory [to their previous identification]! So what is the reason? It is what we complain about regarding them; ignorance and gathering from here and there. They copied the defect from a verified source, then could not reconcile it with what is in "Al-Kashf", so they lied against it! And the end justifies the means [for them], which is feigning knowledge!! And Allah is the One sought for help.

He said: "People must surely teach their neighbors, admonish them, command them, and forbid them; and people must surely learn from their neighbors, accept admonition, and seek understanding, or I will hasten the punishment for them in the world." They said: O Messenger of Allah! Do we make others understand (anufattinu)? He repeated his statement to them, and they repeated their statement: Do we make others understand? foot_note: 1. Linguists said: "(Adhan) means: announcement. Allah the Exalted said: {And an announcement (Adhan) from Allah and His Messenger}, and He said: {And an announcer (Mu'adhin) announced}, and it is said: Adhan, Ta'dhin, and Adhin." In Sharia law: "The announcement of prayer with specific wordings, at specific times, its source is transmission from the bringer of the Sharia." Scholars have differed regarding its ruling. I say: The correct view is that it is obligatory (Fard) like the Iqamah; because the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, commanded both in more than one hadith, such as the hadith of the one who prayed badly. Therefore, adding to it is not permissible, just as adding to its beginning or its end is not permissible, for that is an innovation (Bid'ah), and it has preceded that every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire.

Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his 'Sahih', (1). 4 - (Warning against leaving the mosque after Adhan without excuse) 175 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: A man left after the Mu'adhin had called the Adhan, so he (2) said: As for this one, he has disobeyed Abu Al-Qasim, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Then he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, commanded us saying: 'If you are in the mosque and the prayer is called, let no one of you leave until he prays.' Narrated by Ahmad and the wording is his, and its chain is Sahih (3).
foot_note:
1. It contains (Ayyub bin Suwayd), who is truthful (Saduq) but errs. He contradicted the trustworthy narrator in his saying: "the prayer is established", and the preserved wording is "the call (Nida)" as you see here in 'As-Sahih'. This is one of dozens of proofs of the ignorance of the three commentators, and their lack of knowledge of this art, so they graded it Hasan based on its witnesses - they claimed - then they authenticated it in another place (1/ 261/ 406 - their edition)!
2. Meaning Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him.
3. Thus he said, and it is questionable as I clarified in 'At-Ta'liq Ar-Raghib' along with its contradiction to the narration of Muslim which the author pointed to in the original here, and it will come in 'As-Sahih' in (5 Prayer / 20 - Warning against abandoning attendance of congregation...).

text: 5 - (Encouragement for Supplication between Adhan and Iqamah) 176 - (1) [Denounced] And in a narration of his [meaning Ibn Hibban from Sahl bin Sa'd as Marfu']: 'Two hours in which a supplication is not rejected for a caller, when the prayer is established, and in the row in the way of Allah' (1). 177 - (2) [Very Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: 'When the caller calls, the gates of heaven are opened, and supplication is answered. So whoever is in distress or hardship, let him wait for the caller, so when he says Takbir he says Takbir, and when he says Tashahhud he says Tashahhud, and when he says: (Come to prayer); he says: (Come to prayer), and when he says: (Come to success); he says: (Come to success). Then he says: (O Allah, Lord of this perfect, truthful, answered call, which is responded to, the call of truth, and the word of piety, make us live upon it, and make us die upon it, and resurrect us upon it, and make us among the best of its people, alive and dead), then he asks Allah his need.' Narrated by Al-Hakim from the narration of Ufayr bin Ma'dan - and he is flimsy -, and he said: 'Sahih Al-Isnad'! His saying: (Falyatahayyan Al-Munadi) means: He waits with his supplication for when the Mu'adhin calls the Adhan so he answers him, then asks Allah the Exalted his need.
foot_note: 1. This wording, with the weakness of its chain, contradicts as mentioned shortly before the wording established in 'As-Sahih' due to its witnesses. See 'As-Sahih' number (266).

text: 6 - (Encouragement to Build Mosques in Places Needing Them) 178 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Whoever builds a mosque for Allah, be it small or large; Allah builds for him a house in Paradise.' Narrated by At-Tirmidhi. 179 - (2) [Denounced] And it was narrated from Bishr bin Hayyan who said: Wathilah bin Al-Asqa' came while we were building a mosque. He said: So he stood over us, greeted us, then said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: 'Whoever builds a mosque for Allah in which prayer is performed; Allah (Azza wa Jal) builds for him in Paradise one better than it.' Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani. 180 - (3) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Whoever builds a house in which Allah is worshipped; from lawful wealth; Allah builds for him a house in Paradise of pearls and rubies.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat' and Al-Bazzar without his saying: 'of pearls and rubies'.
foot_note: None

text: 7 - (Encouragement to Clean and Purify Mosques, and What Came regarding Incensing Them) 181 - (1) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated in 'Al-Kabir' from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: That a woman used to pick up speck/litter from the mosque, so she passed away. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was not informed of her burial. So the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'If anyone among you dies, inform me', and he prayed over her, and said: 'Indeed I saw her in Paradise [because she used to] (1) pick up speck from the mosque.' 182 - (2) [Weak Mu'dal] And Abu Ash-Sheikh Al-Asbahani narrated from Ubayd bin Marzuq (2) who said: There was a woman in Madinah who used to sweep the mosque, and she died. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, did not know about her. He passed by her grave and said: 'What is this grave?' They said: The grave of Umm Mihjan. He said: 'The one who used to sweep the mosque?' They said: Yes. So he lined up the people and prayed over her, then said: 'Which deed did you find best?'
foot_note:
1. Dropped from the original, the manuscript, and Amarah's edition so the meaning was corrupted, and likewise dropped from 'Al-Majma', (2/ 10) and the edition of the three ignorant ones. I restored it from 'Al-Kabir' (3/ 128/ 2). Its chain contains Fa'id bin Umar from Al-Hakam bin Aban, and this one is truthful but has illusions. And Fa'id bin Umar, thus it appeared in 'Al-Mu'jam', and I did not find him, but Al-Haythami mentioned it is an error, and the correct is "Abdul-Aziz bin Fa'id" and he is unknown. In Al-Abadilah his mention came in 'Al-Jarh' and 'Al-Mizan' and 'Al-Lisan'.
2. I say: Thus in the original, the manuscript, and the edition of the three commentators! And I think there is a deletion, and the correct is (Ubayd bin Abi Marzuq), as in 'Tarikh Al-Bukhari' and 'Al-Jarh' and others, and they did not mention any narrator from him other than Ibn Uyainah, and said: "He narrated a Mursal hadith". It is as if they are referring to this. Similar is in 'Ath-Thiqat' by Ibn Hibban, he listed him in 'Followers of the Followers'. So the hadith has two defects: Mu'dal (missing two or more narrators) and Jahalah (anonymity). And from the ignorance of the three is their saying (1/ 268): "Mursal, and the previous hadiths testify for it"! I say: Their testimony is deficient, they do not contain: "Which deed..." etc., and it is Munkar. So take note.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: They said: O Messenger of Allah! Does she hear? He said: 'You do not hear better than her.' He mentioned that she answered him: Sweeping the mosque. And this is Mursal. (Qamm Al-Masjid) with Qaf and Shadda on Mim: means sweeping it. 183 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Qirsafah; that he heard the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: 'Build mosques, and remove garbage from them. Whoever builds a mosque for Allah; Allah builds for him a house in Paradise.' A man said: O Messenger of Allah! Even these mosques that are built on the road? He said: 'Yes, and removing garbage from them are the dowries of the Houris.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir'. (Al-Qumamah) with Damma: garbage/sweepings. The name of Abu Qirsafah - with Kasra on Qaf - is Jandarah bin Khayshanah. 184 - (4) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'The rewards of my Ummah were displayed to me, even the speck of dust a man takes out of the mosque. And the sins of my Ummah were displayed to me, and I did not see a sin greater than a Surah from the Quran or a verse given to a man then he forgot it.' Narrated by Abu Dawud, At-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Majah (1), and Ibn Khuzaymah in his 'Sahih'; all of them from the narration of Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah bin Hantab from Anas. At-Tirmidhi said: 'Gharib Hadith, we do not know it except from this way. -He said-: And I discussed it with Muhammad bin Ismail - meaning Al-Bukhari - and he did not know it, and found it strange. Muhammad said: I do not know of Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah hearing
foot_note: 1. Attributing it to Ibn Majah is an error. Regarding forgetting the Quran, there is another hadith that will come in (13 - Book of Reciting Quran / 2 - Warning against forgetting the Quran) of this book: "Ad-Da'if".

Narrated by Ibn Majah, and its chain has potential for being Hasan (2). 186 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Wathilah bin Al-Asqa'; that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Keep your mosques free from your children, your insane ones, your buying and selling, your disputes, raising your voices, executing your punishments, unsheathing your swords. And make places for ablution at their doors, and incense them on Fridays.' Narrated by Ibn Majah. 187 - (7) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it in 'Al-Kabir' from Abu Darda, Abu Umamah, and Wathilah. 188 - (8) [Weak] And he narrated it in 'Al-Kabir' also with changes in word order (3) from the narration of Makhul from Mu'adh. And he did not hear from him. (Jamiruhah) means: incense/fumigate them, in measure and meaning.
foot_note:
1. He is Imam Ad-Darimi Al-Hafiz, author of 'As-Sunan' known as 'Al-Musnad'. He died in the year (255) and he was seventy-four.
2. I say: How so when it contains leniency and disconnection as clarified in the original?!
3. I say. Had he added: "and brevity", he would have been correct, because it does not mention insane people, raising [voices], and unsheathing [swords].

text: 8 - (Warning against Spitting in the Mosque and towards the Qiblah, and against announcing (1) lost property in it, and other things mentioned here) 189 - (1) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the hadith of Hudhayfah in 'As-Sahih'] in 'Al-Kabir', from the hadith of Abu Umamah and his wording is: He said: 'Whoever spits towards a Qiblah and does not bury it, it will come on the Day of Resurrection as hot as it can be, until it falls between his eyes.' 190 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: 'Indeed, when the servant stands in prayer, Paradise is opened for him, and the veils between him and his Lord are removed, and the Houris face him, as long as he does not blow his nose or spit phlegm.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir', and its chain is questionable. 191 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Sirin or someone else who said: Ibn Mas'ud heard a man announcing a lost property in the mosque, so he silenced him and scolded him, and said: 'We have been forbidden from this.'
foot_note: 1. Thus in the original and the manuscript, and the correct is "Nashdan". An-Naji said in 'Al-Ujalah' (50): "His saying: 'Inshad' (announcing/reciting) as a four-letter verb is objectionable, and likewise it is objectionable for Abu Dawud and Ibn Majah, and he added and narrated that as Marfu' from the hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather. And At-Tirmidhi combined in the chapter heading between announcing lost property and poetry, and this is all from variation in expression and following usage. Rather it is (Nashad) three-lettered, and evidenced by the hadith of Buraidah which the author cited during the chapter that a man announced (Nashada) in the mosque. He did not say 'Anshada'. Linguists said: One says: Nashada Ad-Dallah Yanshuduha - with Fatha on the first and Damma on the third - Nashdah and Nashdanan - with Kasra on the first - meaning: he sought it, so he is Nashid, and this is definitely the intent here. And (Anshadaha): means: he defined/identified it, so he is Munshid, and from it is the hadith: "The lost property of Makkah is not lawful except to a Munshid (one identifying/announcing it)", and this is not intended here. And the poet said: Isakhata An-Nashid lil-Munshid? Meaning the listening of the seeker to the finder. It is also said: Anshada Ash-Shi'r Yunshiduhu Inshadan (He recited poetry)."
