And indeed one of you remains in prayer as long as he is in the mosque until he leaves it.' Narrated by Ahmad with a Hasan chain (2). 193 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both; that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Qualities that are not appropriate in the mosque: It should not be taken as a path, nor should a weapon be unsheathed in it, nor should a bow be drawn in it, nor should arrows be scattered in it, nor should one pass through it with raw meat, nor should a Hadd punishment be struck in it, nor should retaliation be taken from anyone, nor should it be made a market.' Narrated by Ibn Majah.
foot_note:
1. I say: And in At-Tabarani's version (9/ 294/ 9268) is Ishaq bin Ibrahim, and he is (Ad-Dabari), and there is known criticism regarding his narration from Abdur-Razzaq, and this is one of them, and it is in 'Al-Musannaf' (1/ 441/ 1724).
2. I say: Thus he said, and Al-Haythami followed him, and the three commentators imitated them. Al-Hafiz weakened it in 'Al-Fath' (1/ 566), and it is chained with defects. Its explanation is in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (6815).

text: 9 - (Encouragement to Walk to Mosques Especially in Darkness, and What Came Regarding Its Virtue) 195 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Upon every joint (Misam) of a human is a charity every day.' A man from the people said: This is among the hardest of what you have informed us (1). He said: 'Your enjoining good and your forbidding evil is charity, your carrying for (2) the weak is charity, your removing filth from the road is charity, and every step you take to prayer is charity.' Narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah in his 'Sahih' (3). 196 - (2) [Weak] And from Zaid bin Thabit, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I was walking with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and we intended prayer, so he was taking short steps. He said: 'Do you know why I shorten the steps?' I said: Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: 'The servant remains in prayer as long as he is seeking prayer.' [Weak] And in a narration:
foot_note:
1. In some copies: (we have been tested with), which is the copy of Sheikh An-Naji. He said (54): "Thus in most copies, and in some, and likewise in other than this book which is the correct one: (you brought to us)". I say: And likewise it is in the printed 'Sahih Ibn Khuzaymah' (1498), and likewise in the margin of the manuscript indicated as a copy, but in its main text it appeared as here: "you informed us", so Allah knows best.
2. Original: (and your clemency upon), and in my two manuscripts: (and your carrying upon), and likewise in the edition of the ignorant ones, which is corrupt in meaning here as is apparent. The confirmed is from 'Sahih Ibn Khuzaymah' (2/ 377).
3. I say: It has a defect I clarified in 'As-Sahihah', (577), so let whoever wishes refer to it.

text: 'I only did it to increase my steps in seeking prayer.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir' as Marfu' and Mawquf on Zaid, and that is the correct one (1). 197 - (3) [Fabricated] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Going early and returning to the mosque is from Jihad in the way of Allah.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir' via the path of Al-Qasim from Abu Umamah (2). 198 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: 'Give glad tidings to those who walk in darkness (Al-Mudlijin) (3) to the mosques of pulpits of light on the Day of Resurrection, people will be terrified, and they will not be terrified.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir', and its chain is questionable (4). 199 - (5) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Those who walk much to the mosques in darkness, those are the ones plunging into the mercy of Allah the Exalted.' Narrated by Ibn Majah, and in its chain is Ismail bin Rafi', people spoke about him, and At-Tirmidhi said: 'Some people of knowledge weakened him, and I heard Muhammad - meaning Al-Bukhari - say: He is trustworthy, Muqarib Al-Hadith.'
foot_note:
1. I say: In the chain of the Mawquf at At-Tabarani's (4796) is one who narrates falsehoods as Ibn Adi said, yet Al-Haythami overlooked him and said: "Its men are men of the Sahih"! And the three imitated him! But it has come from others with a Sahih chain, as I verified in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (6816).
2. I say: Below him is a liar, and others narrated it as Mawquf. See 'Ad-Da'ifah' (2007).
3. Plural of: (Mudlij), who is one who travels by night. And (Ad-Duljah) with Damma and Fatha: is night travel. It is said: Adlaja with alleviation: if he traveled from the beginning of the night, and Iddalaja with Shadda: if he traveled from the end of it. And Allah knows best.
4. I say: In At-Tabarani (7634) it contains Salamah Al-Qaysi from a man of his household, and these two are unknown.

text: 200 - (6) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Whoever leaves his house for prayer and says: (O Allah, indeed I ask You by the right of those who ask You, and by the right of this walk of mine, for I did not go out in insolence, nor arrogance, nor showing off, nor for reputation, but I went out fearing Your anger and seeking Your pleasure, so I ask You to protect me from the Fire, and to forgive my sins; indeed no one forgives sins except You); Allah turns His Face towards him, and seventy thousand angels seek forgiveness for him.' text: 10 - (Encouragement to stick to Mosques and Sit in them) 203 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: 'If you see a man frequenting the mosques, bear witness to his faith. foot_note:

text: 11 - (Warning against Coming to the Mosque for One Who Ate Onions, Garlic, Leeks, Radishes and Similar Things That Have an Offensive Smell) 208 - (1) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the hadith of Jabir which is here in 'As-Sahih'] in 'Al-Awsat' and 'As-Saghir', and his wording is: He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Whoever eats from these vegetables: garlic, onions, leeks, and radishes; let him not approach our mosque; for indeed the angels are harmed by what the children of Adam are harmed by' (1). And its narrators are trustworthy; except Yahya bin Rashid Al-Basri. 12 - (Encouragement for Women to Pray in Their Houses and Stick to Them, and Warning Them against Leaving Them) [There is no hadith under it meeting the condition of our book, and all praise is due to Allah. See 'As-Sahih']
foot_note: 1. The hadith is Sahih without the mention of radishes, and it is in the other book from Jabir and others. Did the ignorant ones not distinguish between them? See 'As-Sahih' (333 - 337).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 13 - (Encouragement for the Five Prayers, Maintaining Them, and Believing in Their Obligation) 209 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Muslim Ath-Tha'labi (1) who said: I entered upon Abu Umamah while he was in the mosque, so I said: O Abu Umamah! Indeed a man told me from you that you heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: 'Whoever performs Wudu and perfects the Wudu, washing his hands, his face, wiping his head and ears, then stands for an obligatory prayer; Allah forgives him on that day what his feet walked to, what his hands grasped, what his ears listened to, what his eyes looked at, and what he spoke to himself of evil'? He said: By Allah, I indeed heard it from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, many times. Narrated by Ahmad, and the prevailing opinion on its chain is Hasan. And witnesses for it have passed in "Wudu" [4/ 7]. And Allah knows best. 210 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah and Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, addressed us one day and said: 'By the One in Whose Hand is my soul', (three times). Then he lowered his head, so every man among us lowered his head weeping, not knowing what he swore about. Then he raised his head, and there was joy in his face, which was more beloved to us than red camels. He said:
foot_note: 1. With Tha' Muthallathah and 'Ayn Muhmalah. It appeared in the original as: (At-Taghlabi): with Ta' Muthannah and Ghayn Mu'jamah, and he is unknown in status (Majhul Al-Hal) as I clarified in the original. So what is the water (basis) for grading its chain Hasan? Especially since it contains a Munkar sentence which is his saying: "what he spoke to himself"; for speech of the self is forgiven by the text of the Sahih hadith, and this sentence did not appear in any of the witnesses which the author, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, pointed to, so it was Munkar. For that reason I included it, and in what passed (4 - Purification / 7).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 'There is no man who prays the five prayers, fasts Ramadan, pays Zakat, and avoids the seven major sins; except that the gates of Paradise are opened for him, and it is said to him: Enter in peace.' Narrated by An-Nasa'i and the wording is his, and Ibn Majah (1), and Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban in their 'Sahihs', and Al-Hakim; except that they said: 'The eight gates of Paradise are opened on the Day of Resurrection, until they clap/bang, then he recited: {If you avoid the major sins which you are forbidden, We will remove from you your lesser sins and admit you to a noble entrance}.' And Al-Hakim said: 'Sahih Al-Isnad' (2). 211 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Indeed the first thing Allah obligated upon people from their religion is prayer, and the last thing to remain is prayer, and the first thing accounting will be for is prayer. Allah says: Look into the prayer of My servant; if it is complete; it is written as complete, and if it is deficient; He says: Look, does My servant have any voluntary prayer? If voluntary prayer is found for him, the obligatory prayer is completed from the voluntary. Then He says: Look, is his Zakat complete? If it is complete; it is written for him as complete, and if it is deficient; He says: Look, does he have charity? If he has charity, his Zakat is completed for him.' Narrated by Abu Ya'la. 212 - (4) [Weak] And from Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: 'The key to Paradise is prayer.'
foot_note:
1. I did not see it with Ibn Majah, nor did As-Suyuti attribute it to him in 'Az-Ziyadah'.
2. Thus he said, and it contains in all of them (Suhayb Mawla Al-Utwariyyin). Adh-Dhahabi said: 'He is hardly known'.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ad-Darimi (1), and in its chain is Abu Yahya Al-Qattat. 213 - (5) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'There is no faith for one who has no trustworthiness, and no prayer for one who has no purity, and no religion for one who has no prayer. Indeed, the position of prayer in religion is like the position of the head in the body.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat' and 'As-Saghir' and he said: 'Al-Hussein bin Al-Hakam Al-Hibri was alone in narrating it' (2). 214 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; that he said to those around him from his Ummah: 'Guarantee me six things and I will guarantee you Paradise.' They said: And what are they, O Messenger of Allah? He said: 'Prayer, Zakat, Trustworthiness, the private parts, the stomach, and the tongue.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat' and he said: 'It is not narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, except with this chain.' Al-Hafiz said: 'And there is no harm in its chain' (3).
foot_note:
1. I did not see it in his 'Sunan', but Ahmad and others narrated it.
2. With Kasra on the un-dotted Ha and Fatha on the Ba: attributed to clothes called: Al-Hibrah, and he is unknown. However, the first half of the hadith is Sahih, having witnesses, and for that reason I included it in what will come in 'As-Sahih' (23 - Manners / 30 - Encouragement to fulfill promise...), and the sentence of 'Purity' passed in it with another narration (4 - Purification / 6).
3. Thus he said! And Al-Haythami followed him, and the three imitated them. It is chained with unknown narrators, and the clarification of this is in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (2899).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 14 - (Encouragement for Prayer Absolutely, and the Virtue of Bowing, Prostrating, and Humility) 215 - (1) [Weak] And from Hudhayfah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'There is no state the servant is in that is more beloved to Allah than seeing him prostrating, dusting his face in the dirt.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat' and he said: 'Uthman was alone in narrating it.' Al-Hafiz said: 'This Uthman is Ibn Al-Qasim, Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Ath-Thiqat)' (1). And the hadith of Anas will come in the next chapter, Allah the Exalted willing.
foot_note: 1. I say: And his father Al-Qasim is not known. At-Tabarani narrated it in 'Al-Kabir' from another path from Ibn Mas'ud as Mawquf on him. And its chain is Hasan. Then I corrected myself and said: I came across its chain in 'Al-Awsat' and found that (Al-Qasim) was distorted for the author and Al-Haythami as well, and the correct is (Al-Haytham), and the defect is from At-Tabarani's Sheikh. Its clarification is in 'Ad-Da'ifah' (6817); and he has (Hal) instead of: (Halah).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 15 - (Encouragement to pray at the beginning of its time) 216 - (1) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from a man of Banu Abdul-Qais called Iyad; that he heard the Prophet (PBUH) say: "Stick to the remembrance of your Lord, and pray your prayer at the beginning of its time; for Allah will double [the reward] for you." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (1). 217 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The beginning of the time for prayer is the pleasure of Allah, and the end of it is the pardon of Allah." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Ad-Daraqutni. 218 - (3) [Fabricated] And Ad-Daraqutni also narrated from the hadith of Ibrahim bin Abdul-Aziz bin Abdul-Malik Ibn Abi Mahdhurah from his father from his grandfather who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The beginning of the time is the pleasure of Allah, the middle of the time is the mercy of Allah, and the end of the time is the pardon of Allah, Mighty and Majestic." 219 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "The virtue of the beginning of the time over its end; is like the virtue of the Hereafter over the world." Narrated by Abu Mansur Ad-Dailami in "Musnad Al-Firdaws". 220 - (5) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Prophet (PBUH) passed by his companions one day and said to them: "Do you know what your Lord, Blessed and Exalted, says?"
foot_note: 1. Al-Haythami found fault with it due to (An-Nahhas bin Qahm); he is weak, but it contains another liar, see "Ad-Da'ifah" (6721).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: They said: Allah and His Messenger know best. -He said it three times-. He said: "[He says:] By My Might and Majesty, no one prays it at its time; except that I admit him to Paradise. And whoever prays it outside its time; if I will I have mercy on him, and if I will I punish him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and its chain is Hasan (good) if Allah the Exalted wills (1). 221 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever prays the prayers at their time, and perfects their ablution, and completes their standing, humility (Khushu'), bowing, and prostration, it (the prayer) exits white and bright saying: May Allah preserve you as you preserved me. And whoever prays it outside its time, and does not perfect its ablution, nor complete its humility, nor its bowing, nor its prostration, it exits black and dark saying: May Allah waste you as you wasted me. Until when it is where Allah wills, it is wrapped as an old garment is wrapped, then his face is struck with it." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat".
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, and the three ignorant ones imitated him (1/ 333), even though they quoted from Al-Haythami what implies its weakness! And it contains three consecutive narrators who are unknown, see "Ad-Da'ifah" (1338).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 16 - (Encouragement for congregational prayer, and what was reported regarding one who went out intending the congregation but found the people had prayed) 222 - (1) [Munkar] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Prophet (PBUH) said: "If this one staying behind from the prayer in congregation knew what was for this one walking to it, he would have come to it even if crawling on his hands and knees." Narrated by At-Tabarani in a hadith that will come in full in "Abandoning the Congregation" [Here/ 20] if Allah the Exalted wills. 223 - (2) [Weak] And [from Anas] (1) from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH); that he used to say: "Whoever prays in a mosque in congregation for forty nights, never missing the first Rak'ah of the Isha prayer; Allah writes for him thereby freedom from the Fire." Narrated by Ibn Majah and the wording is his, and At-Tirmidhi and he said: "Similar to the hadith of Anas." Meaning the one preceding [Here in "As-Sahih"], and he did not mention its wording, and he said: "This hadith is Mursal." Meaning that Umarah bin Ghaziyah, the narrator from Anas, did not meet Anas. And Razin (2) Al-Abdari mentioned it in his "Jami'", but I did not see it in any of the original sources he collected. And Allah knows best.
foot_note:
1. An addition to the original which is necessary to understand the Irsal (disconnection) that the author will mention, and he will repeat it with explanation (19 - Chapter/ Hadith Three). 
2. With Fatha on Ra as in "Al-Qamus" and others. He is the Andalusian Saragossan, and he was mentioned previously with some of his biography. It appeared in Amarah's edition here and there and in what follows as (Ruzin) in diminutive form, and it is an error from him which the ignorant ones imitated (1/ 339). See the previous comment on Hadith (6). Furthermore, the author's statement: "But I did not see it..." etc. might be an insertion here, for it has no meaning, as Ibn Majah and At-Tirmidhi extracted it! However, he only mentioned this as a comment without a chain!

See "As-Sahih"] 18 - (Encouragement for prayer in the wasteland) 224 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "There is no spot upon which Allah is remembered with prayer, or with remembrance, except that it rejoices (1) at that to its furthest limits, down to the seven earths, [and] boasts to the spots around it. And there is no slave who stands in a wasteland of the earth intending to pray except that the earth adorns itself for him." Narrated by Abu Ya'la.
foot_note: 1. The original: (Istashrafat - looked out), and likewise the manuscript and the edition of the ignorant ones (1/ 342)! The correction is from Abu Ya'la and others, and the addition is from him and the manuscript as well.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 19 - (Encouragement for the Isha and Morning prayers specifically in congregation, and discouragement from delaying them) 225 - (1) [Weak] And in some of Imam Ahmad's narrations of this hadith [meaning the hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih"]: "Were it not for the women and offspring in the houses, I would have established the Isha prayer, and commanded my young men to burn what is in the houses with fire." 226 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever prays Isha in congregation; has taken his share of Laylat al-Qadr." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 227 - (3) [Weak] And from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH); that he used to say: "Whoever prays in a mosque in congregation for forty nights, never missing the first Rak'ah of the Isha prayer; Allah writes for him thereby freedom from the Fire." Narrated by Ibn Majah from the narration of Ismail from Umarah bin Ghaziyah from Anas bin Malik from Umar. At-Tirmidhi indicated it but did not mention its wording, and said: "It is a Mursal hadith." Meaning that Umarah bin Ghaziyah - and he is Al-Mazini Al-Madani - did not meet Anas. [Passed 16 - Chapter/ Hadith One]. 228 - (4) [Munkar] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Whoever performs ablution then comes to the mosque, and prays two Rak'ahs before Fajr, then sits until
foot_note: None

text: he prays Fajr; his prayer on that day is written among the prayer of the righteous (Abrar), and he is written in the delegation of the Most Merciful (Ar-Rahman)." Narrated by At-Tabarani from Al-Qasim Abu Abdur-Rahman (1) from Abu Umamah. 229 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Salman (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever goes early to the Morning prayer; goes with the banner of Faith, and whoever goes early to the market; goes with the banner of Satan." Narrated by Ibn Majah.
foot_note: 1. I say: He is Hasan in Hadith if he does not contradict [others], and below him are those spoken against. I learned this after "At-Tabarani" was printed. The text (Matn) is Munkar (denounced), contradicting the verbal and practical Sunnah regarding the Sunnah prayer of Fajr at home. I extracted the hadith in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6723), after having graded it Hasan previously in adherence to what I mentioned in the introduction of "As-Sahih" about relying on Al-Mundhiri with the mentioned condition number (35). The ignorant ones imitated me and graded it Hasan. Allah guided me, and Allah spoke the truth: {And those who strive for Us - We will surely guide them to Our ways}.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 20 - (Discouragement from missing the congregation without excuse) 230 - (1) [Weak] From Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever hears the call and no excuse prevents him from following it - they said: What is the excuse? He said: Fear or illness -; the prayer he prayed will not be accepted from him" (1). Narrated by Abu Dawood, Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Ibn Majah similarly. 231 - (2) [Weak] And Razin added in his "Jami'" [meaning in the hadith of Abu Darda which is in "As-Sahih" here]: "Indeed the wolf of the human is Satan; when he is alone with him, he eats him." 232 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And in a narration by Abu Dawood [meaning in the Mawquf hadith of Ibn Mas'ud here in "As-Sahih"] (2): And were you to abandon the Sunnah of your Prophet, you would have disbelieved (3). And the hadith of Abu Umamah passed with the meaning as Marfu' [16 - Chapter/ Hadith One]. 233 - (4) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH); that he said: "Jafa' (rudeness/estrangement), all Jafa', and disbelief and hypocrisy, is one who hears Allah's caller calling to prayer but does not answer him." Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani from the narration of Zaban bin Fa'id.
foot_note:
1. I say: I only included it here due to the addition of the Question and Answer, otherwise the hadith without it is Sahih, as you see in "As-Sahih" at the beginning of this chapter. 
2. I say: Abu Dawood has no other narration than this, contrary to what the author's expression implies. An-Naji pointed this out, may Allah have mercy on him, as I also pointed out in "Sahih Abi Dawood" (559). 
3. I say: The preserved wording is: "La-dalaltum" (You would have gone astray), which is the narration of Muslim and others. See "As-Sahih" (16 - Chapter).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: [Weak] And in a narration by At-Tabarani: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "It is sufficient misery and failure for a believer to hear the Mu'adhin performing Tathwib for prayer and not answer him." (Tathwib) here: A name for the Iqamah of prayer. 234 - (5) [Munkar] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: Ibn Umm Maktoum came - and he was blind, and he is the one regarding whom {He frowned and turned away (1) Because there came to him the blind man} was revealed, and he was a man from Quraysh - to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), and said to him: O Messenger of Allah! May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, I am as you see; my years have advanced, my bones have thinned, my sight has gone, and I have a guide whose leading does not suit me. Do you find a license/concession for me to pray the prayers in my house? The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Do you hear the Mu'adhin in the house where you are?" He said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "I do not find a license for you. And if this one staying behind from the prayer in congregation knew what was for this one walking to it; he would have come to it even if crawling on his hands and knees." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" via the path of Ali bin Yazid Al-Alhani (1) from Al-Qasim from Abu Umamah. 235 - (6) [Munkar] And from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: Ibn Umm Maktoum came to the Prophet (PBUH) and said:
foot_note: 1. Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Mughni": "They weakened him, and Ad-Daraqutni abandoned him." And the ignorant ones said: "Hasan due to its witnesses"! Yet among the witnesses they pointed to, none contain the sentence about crawling! It is in "As-Sahih" without it, and abbreviated. They likewise graded the hadith of Jabir coming after it as Hasan, and both are extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6722).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: O Messenger of Allah! My house is far, and I am blind, but I hear the Adhan. He said: "If you hear the Adhan then answer, even if crawling or dragging." Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", but he did not say: "or dragging". 236 - (7) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): That he was asked about a man who fasts the day and stands (in prayer) the night, but does not attend the congregation nor the Jumu'ah (Friday prayer); he said: This one is in the Fire. Narrated by At-Tirmidhi as Mawquf.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 21 - (Encouragement for voluntary prayer in the houses) 237 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Musa (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: A group from the people of Iraq went out to Umar. When they came to him, they asked him about the prayer of a man in his house? Umar said: I asked the Messenger of Allah (PBUH)? He said: "As for the prayer of a man in his house, it is light, so illuminate your houses." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih" (1). 238 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Honor your houses with some of your prayers." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih" (2).
foot_note:
1. Thus in the original, but we did not find it in the printed "Sahih Ibn Khuzaimah". Rather, Ibn Majah and others narrated it, and it contains an unknown narrator as explained in "At-Ta'liq Ar-Raghib". 
2. Adh-Dhahabi criticized it citing Ibn Adi regarding its narrator (Abdullah bin Farrukh): "His hadiths are not preserved (Mahfuz)." It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2680).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 22 - (Encouragement for waiting for prayer after prayer) 239 - (1) [Weak] [Meaning Ali, may Allah be pleased with him] said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed the slave, if he sits in his place of prayer after the prayer, the angels pray for him, and their prayer for him is: O Allah forgive him. And if he sits waiting for the prayer they pray for him, and their prayer for him is: O Allah forgive him, O Allah have mercy on him" (1). Narrated by Ahmad, and in it is Ata' bin As-Sa'ib. 240 - (2) [Weak] And from Dawood bin Salih who said: Abu Salamah said to me: O son of my brother! Do you know regarding what {O you who have believed, persevere and endure and remain stationed} was revealed? I said: No. He said: I heard Abu Hurairah say: In the time of the Prophet (PBUH) there was no raid for which one would be stationed (Ribat), but it is waiting for prayer after prayer. Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad" (2).
foot_note:
1. The hadith has been authenticated from Abu Hurairah and others regarding waiting for prayer only, without [the mention of] sitting after it, so see it here in "As-Sahih". 
2. I say: In it is (Mus'ab bin Thabit), Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Kashif": "He was deemed soft (layyin) due to his mistakes."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 23 - (Encouragement to maintain the Morning and Asr prayers) 241 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever prays the Morning prayer (Al-Ghadah), and his Dhimmah (protection/covenant) is violated; then the sanctuary of Allah has been violated, and his Dhimmah betrayed, and I am the seeker of his Dhimmah." Narrated by Abu Ya'la.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 24 - (Encouragement for a person to sit in his prayer place after the Morning prayer and the Asr prayer) 242 - (1) [Weak] And from Sahl bin Mu'ad from his father (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever sits in his prayer place when he finishes the Morning prayer until he prays the two Rak'ahs of Duha, saying nothing but good; his sins are forgiven, even if they were more than the foam (Zabad) of the sea" (1). Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Dawood, and Abu Ya'la and his wording is: (2) He said: "Whoever prays the Fajr prayer, then sits remembering Allah until the sun rises; Paradise becomes obligatory for him." (Al-Hafiz said): "The three narrated it via the path of Zaban bin Fa'id from Sahl, and it has been graded Hasan. And some authenticated it." 243 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) raising it (to the Prophet), he said: "Whoever prays Fajr, then remembers Allah until the sun rises; the Fire will never touch his skin." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. 244 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Al-Hasan bin Ali (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever prays the Morning prayer then remembers Allah, Mighty and Majestic, until the sun rises, then prays
foot_note:
1. (Ar-Rabad): - with two Fathas - from the sea and others is like froth/foam. 
2. In the original and Amarah's edition: (And I think), and the correction is from the manuscript.

text: two Rak'ahs or four Rak'ahs; the Fire will not touch his skin." And Al-Hasan took his skin and pulled it. Narrated by Al-Baihaqi. 245 - (4) [Munkar] And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) used to, when he prayed Fajr, not stand from his sitting place until prayer became possible (permitted)..." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and its narrators are trustworthy; except Al-Fadl bin Al-Muwaffaq; for there is speech regarding him (1). 246 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Amrah (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I heard the Mother of the Believers - meaning Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) - say: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever prays Fajr - or he said the Morning prayer - then sits in his seat, and does not engage in vain talk regarding any worldly matter, and remembers Allah until he prays the Duha four Rak'ahs; he exits from his sins like the day his mother bore him, having no sin." Narrated by Abu Ya'la and the wording is his, and At-Tabarani. 247 - (6) [Weak] And it was narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Prophet (PBUH) sent an expedition towards Najd, so they took much spoils, and hastened their return. A man among us who did not go out said: We have not seen an expedition faster in return, nor better in spoils than this expedition! So the Prophet (PBUH) said: "Shall I not guide you to a people better in spoils and faster in return? People who attended the Morning prayer, then sat remembering Allah until the sun rose. Those are faster in return,
foot_note: 1. I say: He has been accused of fabrication, and this hadith of his is Munkar (denounced) compared to the Sahih hadith mentioned at the end of this chapter in the other book "As-Sahih". The explanation of that is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6726).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: and better in spoils." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi in "Ad-Da'wat" from his "Jami'". 248 - (7) [Weak] And Al-Bazzar mentioned in it [meaning the hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih" here] that the speaker: "We have not seen..." is Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him). And he said at its end: So the Prophet (PBUH) said: "O Abu Bakr! Shall I not guide you to what is faster in return, and better in spoils? One who prays the Morning prayer in congregation, then remembers Allah until the sun rises." 249 - (8) [Weak] And At-Tabarani [narrated] [the hadith of Jabir bin Samurah which is here in "As-Sahih"], and its wording is: "He used to, when he prayed Subh, sit remembering Allah until the sun rose."
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 25 - (Encouragement regarding Adhkar said after the Morning, Asr, and Maghrib prayers) 250 - (1) [Weak] And from Al-Harith bin Muslim At-Tamimi (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (PBUH) said to me: "When you pray Subh, say before you speak: (O Allah protect me from the Fire - seven times -), for if you die on that day of yours; Allah writes for you protection from the Fire. And if you pray Maghrib, say before you speak: (O Allah protect me from the Fire - seven times -), for if you die on that night of yours; Allah writes for you protection from the Fire." Narrated by An-Nasa'i and this is his wording, and Abu Dawood from Al-Harith bin Muslim from his father Muslim bin Al-Harith. (Al-Hafiz said): "And that is the correct view, because Al-Harith bin Muslim is a Tabi'i, as said by Abu Zur'ah and Abu Hatim Ar-Razi." 251 - (2) [Fabricated] And he narrated in it [meaning the hadith of Mu'adh bin Jabal which is in "As-Sahih" At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat"], and in "Al-Kabir" also from the hadith of Abu Ad-Darda, and its wording is: "Whoever says after the Morning prayer, while bending his legs, before he speaks: (There is no deity worthy of worship but Allah alone, He has no partner, to Him belongs the dominion, and to Him is the praise, He gives life and causes death, in His Hand is the good, and He is over all things competent - ten times -); Allah writes for him with every time ten good deeds, erases from him ten bad deeds, raises him ten degrees, and they are for him on that day of his a fortress from every dislike, and a guard from the accursed Satan. And he has for every time the [reward of] freeing a slave from the children of Ismail, the price of each slave is twelve thousand. And no sin reaches him on that day except Shirk with Allah. And whoever says that after the Maghrib prayer; has the like of that."
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 252 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever says after Fajr three times, and after Asr three times: (I seek forgiveness from Allah, whom there is no deity worthy of worship but Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer, and I repent to Him); his sins are expiated from him; even if they were like the foam of the sea." Narrated by Ibn As-Sunni in his "Book" (1). Al-Hafiz said: "As for what he says after the prayers, and when he enters upon morning, and when he enters upon evening, each has a chapter coming if Allah the Exalted wills. [In (6 - Voluntary Prayers/14 and 14 - Remembrance/ 11)]". [Weak] And the hadith of Qabisah passed in "Chapter of Traveling to Seek Knowledge" number [3 - Knowledge/ 2], and in it is that the Prophet (PBUH) said to him: "O Qabisah! If you pray Subh, say three times: (Glory be to Allah the Mighty and with His praise); you will be cured from blindness, leprosy (Judham), and paralysis (Falij)" (2). Narrated by Ahmad.
foot_note:
1. Meaning "Amal Al-Yawm wal-Laylah" number (123). 
2. (Al-Judham): With Damma on Jeem, a known disease, may Allah protect us from it. And (Al-Falij): A disease occurring in one side of the body longitudinally, nullifying its sensation and movement, and perhaps it occurs in both sides and happens suddenly, we ask Allah for protection from it.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 26 - (Discouragement from missing Asr without excuse) 253 - (1) [Weak] And Ibn Majah, and his wording is [meaning the hadith of Buraydah, may Allah be pleased with him] he said: "Hasten the prayer on a cloudy day, for whoever misses the Asr prayer, his deeds are nullified" (1).
foot_note: 1. I only included it here because of its first part, for it is Shadh (anomalous), and the preserved [narration] is that it is from the saying of Buraydah himself (may Allah be pleased with him) as I explained in "At-Ta'liq Ar-Raghib". As for its second part, it is Sahih, narrated by Al-Bukhari and others from Buraydah and others.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 27 - (Encouragement for leading prayer with completeness and excellence, and discouragement from it in the absence of these) 254 - (1) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both), that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever leads a people let him fear Allah, and let him know that he is a guarantor responsible for what he guaranteed. If he does well he has a reward like the reward of those who prayed behind him, without diminishing anything from their rewards. And whatever deficiency occurs, it is upon him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" from the narration of Ma'arik bin Abbad. 255 - (2) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both), that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Three are upon mounds of musk - I think he said: on the Day of Resurrection -, a slave who fulfilled the right of Allah and the right of his masters, a man who led a people while they were pleased with him, and a man who calls to the five prayers every day and night." Narrated by Ahmad, and At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan Hadith". [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat" with a chain that has no harm, and its wording is: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Three whom the Great Terror will not grieve, nor will the Reckoning reach them, and they will be upon a mound of musk, until the reckoning of the creatures is finished: A man who recited the Quran seeking the Face of Allah, and led a people with it while they were pleased with him" the Hadith. [And it passed in the First Chapter under number 5]. And in the Chapter are hadiths: "The Imam is a guarantor and the Mu'adhin is a trustee" and others, and it passed in "Adhan", [See them in "As-Sahih"].
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 28 - (Discouragement from a man leading people while they dislike him) 256 - (1) [Weak] From Abdullah bin Umar; that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) used to say: "Three, Allah does not accept a prayer from them: One who leads a people while they dislike him, a man who comes to prayer Dibaran - and Dibaran: is that he comes to it after he misses it -, and a man who enslaved a free man" (1). Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah; both from the narration of Abdur-Rahman bin Ziyad Al-Ifriqi. 257 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) who said: "Three, their prayer does not rise above their heads a span: A man who led a people while they dislike him, a woman who spent the night while her husband is angry with her, and two brothers who are Mutasariman (cutting ties) (2)". Narrated by Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Three, prayer is not accepted from them: A leader of a people while they dislike him, a woman who spent the night while her husband is angry with her, and two brothers who are Mutasariman".
foot_note:
1. Meaning: Enslaved him. Meaning he took him as a slave, either by concealing his freedom from him, or by force and coercion by using him unwillingly after freedom. 
2. Meaning: Cutting each other off for more than three [days], and what is meant is the cutting off which is not permissible religiously.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 29 - (Encouragement regarding the first row, and what came regarding straightening rows and compacting (1) in them, and the virtue of their right sides, and one who prays in the back row for fear of harming others if he advanced) 258 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ali bin Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Straighten so your hearts straighten, and touch so you have mercy." Shuraih said: "(Touch) meaning crowd together (2) in prayer." And others said: "(Touch): Connect." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 259 - (2) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed Allah and His angels send blessings on the right sides of the rows." Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah with a Hasan chain (3). 260 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever leaves the first row for fear of harming someone, Allah doubles the reward of the first row for him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat".
foot_note:
1. From (Ar-Rass), it is said: Rassa al-bina' yarussuhu rassan: If he sticks some of it to some, and from it is His saying, Exalted is He: {As if they are a [solid] structure joined firmly}. I say: Its description is that the man sticks his shoulder to his companion's shoulder, and his ankle to his companion's ankle, as established from the Companions behind the Prophet (PBUH), so check for it "As-Sahihah" (32) and the hadith of Anas bin Malik and the hadith of An-Nu'man bin Bashir coming in "As-Sahih", the first here, and the other in (31 - Chapter). 
2. In the original and Amarah's edition: (Crowd together or), which is an error. I corrected it from the manuscript and others. 
3. I say: It has a defect hidden from the author and others, and the preserved [wording] is: "on those who connect the rows" as Al-Baihaqi said. See "Al-Mishkat" (1096), and do not be deceived by the Three who graded it Hasan, for they are but imitators! Transporters!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 30 - (Encouragement to connect rows and fill gaps) 261 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Juhayfah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever fills a gap in the row; is forgiven." Narrated by Al-Bazzar with a Hasan chain (1). And Abu Juhayfah's name is Wahb bin Abdullah As-Suwa'i. 262 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed Allah and His angels send blessings on those who connect the rows. And no slave connects a row; except that Allah raises him a degree by it, and the angels sprinkle goodness upon him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and there is no harm in its chain (2). 263 - (3) [Weak] And from Mu'adh (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Two steps, one of them is the most beloved of steps to Allah, and the other is the most hated of steps to Allah. As for the one Allah loves; it is a man who looked at a gap in the row and filled it. And as for the one Allah hates; it is when a man wants to stand up, he stretches his right leg, places his hand on it, fixes the left, then stands." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih according to the condition of Muslim" (3). 264 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: It was said to the Prophet (PBUH): The left side of the mosque has become deserted, so the Prophet (PBUH) said:
foot_note:
1. Rather it is Weak as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" under number (5278). 
2. It is not so, as I explained in "As-Sahihah" (2532). 
3. I say: Adh-Dhahabi rejected it by saying: "No, for Khalid [narrating] from Mu'adh is interrupted (Munqati')." I say: And in it is (Ahmad bin Al-Faraj), and he is weak.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever populates the left side of the mosque; two shares of reward are written for him." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah and others. 265 - (5) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever populates the left side of the mosque due to the scarcity of its people, he has two rewards." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" from the narration of Baqiyyah bin Al-Walid.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 31 - (Discouragement regarding men delaying to the back of their rows, and women advancing to the front of their rows (1), and regarding crooked rows) 266 - (1) [Very Weak] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) who said: "You will surely straighten the rows or faces will be obliterated, and you will surely lower (2) your gaze or your sight will be snatched." Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani from the path of Ubaydullah bin Zahr from Ali bin Yazid (3), and some accepted him (4).
foot_note:
1. See the hadiths of this part of the chapter in "As-Sahih". 
2. The original: (Wa lataghmidunna - close eyes) with the addition of Meem, and likewise in "Al-Musnad" (5/ 258), and "Al-Majma'" (2/ 90), and the edition of the (Three)! An-Naji said (73/ 1): "The correct form is by dropping the Meem from (Al-Ghadd - lowering), and it is apparent." And correctly it occurred in At-Tabarani but his wording differs from this, and it will come in the beginning of (17 - Marriage). 
3. The original, the manuscript, and Amarah's edition: (Zaid), which is an error, he is Ali bin Yazid Al-Alhani; Al-Bukhari said: "Munkar in Hadith". 
4. Meaning: Accepted him despite weakness in him. This meaning was hidden from some, so in the margin of the original came the text: "Thus in some copies 'mash-shahu ba'duhum', and in some 'mash-shaha', and it is not clear, perhaps 'wah-hahu' (weakened him) some of them, because regarding Ubaydullah bin Zahr there is speech coming at the end of the book if Allah the Exalted wills." I say: The phrase is clear with no ambiguity for one who cares for the books of the people [scholars], for his saying: "mash-shahu" means accepted him and was content with him, but this is only said regarding someone about whom there is speech regarding his memory; so his hadith is accepted in the grade of Hasan not Sahih, and at the very least is used as a witness. And this Ibn Yazid is weak as Al-Hafiz asserted in "At-Taqrib", and likewise Ibn Zahr, rather some abandoned them.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 32 - (Encouragement regarding saying Amin behind the Imam in supplication, and what he says in standing up [from Ruku'] and opening supplication (1)) 267 - (1) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the hadith of Aisha which is before this in "As-Sahih"] (2) in "Al-Awsat" with a Hasan chain, and its wording is: He said: "Indeed the Jews are a people (3) who envied their religion, and they are an envious people, and they did not envy the Muslims for anything more than three: Returning the Salam (Greeting), establishing the rows, and their saying behind their Imam in the prescribed prayer: (Amin)." 268 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: We were sitting with the Prophet (PBUH) and he said: "Indeed Allah has given me three characteristics, He gave me prayer in rows, He gave me the Tahiyyah (Greeting); for it is the greeting of the people of Paradise, and He gave me the Amin, and He did not give it to anyone from the Prophets before me, except that Allah might have given it to Harun; Musa supplicates and Harun says Amin." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", from the narration of Zarbi the freed slave of the family of Al-Muhallab, and he hesitated regarding its establishment. 269 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "When the Imam says: {Not of those who have evoked [Your] anger or of those who are astray}, those behind him say: (Amin), if it coincides with (Amin) of the people of heaven and the people of earth; Allah forgives the slave what preceded of his sin." - He said: -
foot_note:
1. See the hadiths of this part of the chapter in "As-Sahih". 
2. I say: This conjunction implies that At-Tabarani narrated it from the hadith of Aisha as well, but it is not so, rather it is from the hadith of Mu'adh (may Allah be pleased with him). Furthermore, its chain is not Hasan, how can it be when it has five defects, I explained them in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5048). 
3. The original, the manuscript, and the edition of the Three Verifiers: "Qad" (Indeed), and the correction is from "Majma' Al-Bahrain" and "Majma' Az-Zawa'id", then "Al-Awsat".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "And the likeness of the one who does not say: (Amin) is like the likeness of a man who raided with a people, so they drew lots, and their arrows came out, but his arrow did not come out. He said: Why did my arrow not come out? He said: You did not say: (Amin)." Narrated by Abu Ya'la from the narration of Laith bin Abi Sulaym. 270 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The Jews did not envy you for anything as much as they envied you for (Amin) (1), so say (Amin) frequently." Narrated by Ibn Majah. 271 - (5) [Weak] And from Abu Musbih Al-Muqra'i who said: We used to sit with Abu Zuhayr An-Numayri (may Allah be pleased with him), - and he was from the Companions, he spoke the best speech -, so if a man among us supplicated with a supplication he would say: Seal it with (Amin); for (Amin) is like the seal on a scroll. Abu Zuhayr An-Numayri said: Shall I inform you about that? We went out with the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) one night walking, and we came upon a man who was persistent in asking (supplicating), so the Prophet (PBUH) stopped listening to him. The Prophet (PBUH) said: "It is incumbent if he seals." A man from the people said: With what should he seal? He said: "Amin, for if he seals with (Amin); it becomes incumbent."
foot_note: 1. Up to here the hadith is Sahih having witnesses, see them in "As-Sahih", in this chapter.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: So the man who asked the Prophet (PBUH) turned away, and came to the man and said: Seal O so-and-so with (Amin) and rejoice. Narrated by Abu Dawood. (Musbih) with Damma on Meem and Kasra on Ba which is followed by a motionless Ha. And (Al-Muqra'i) with Damma on Meem, and it was said with Fatha but Damma is more famous, and Sukun on Qaf followed by an extended Ra, ascribed to a village in (Damascus). 272 - (6) [Weak] And from Habib bin Maslamah (1) Al-Fihri - and his supplication was answered - who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "No group gathers and some of them supplicate, and some of them say Amin; except that Allah answers them." Narrated by Al-Hakim.
foot_note: 1. In the original and Amarah's edition and the Ignorant ones: (Salamah), which is an error, and the correction is from "Al-Mustadrak", books of men, and the manuscript.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 33 - (Discouragement from the follower raising his head before the Imam in bowing and prostration) 273 - (1) [Shadh] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih"] in "Al-Awsat" with a good chain (1), and its wording is: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Does one of you feel safe if he raises his head before the Imam, that Allah might turn his head into the head of a dog?!" 274 - (2) [Weak] And he [At-Tabarani] narrated it in "Al-Kabir" as Mawquf on Abdullah bin Mas'ud; with chains one of which is good (2). [And its wording is: Does one of you feel safe if he raises his head in prayer before the Imam that his head returns as the head of a dog]. 275 - (3) [Shadh] And Ibn Hibban narrated it in his "Sahih" from the hadith of Abu Hurairah also from the Prophet (PBUH), and its wording is: "Does the one who raises his head before the Imam not fear, that Allah might turn his head into the head of a dog." 276 - (4) [Weak] And from him also from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "The one who lowers and raises before the Imam; his forelock is but in the hand of a Satan." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani with a Hasan chain (3). And Malik narrated it in "Al-Muwatta" and stopped it (Mawquf) on him and did not raise it.
foot_note:
1. I say: Nay, rather it is Shadh (anomalous), and the preserved [wording] is: "his image into the image of a donkey", and its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5049), and the ignorant ones did not differentiate between the two wordings so they included both in their saying (1/ 401): "Sahih, narrated by...", and they mentioned in the extraction At-Tabarani and Ibn Hibban!! 
2. Thus he said! And he has no chain from Ibn Mas'ud except one, moreover it is interrupted, and its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5049), and therein is the explanation that the hadith of Abu Hurairah before it is Shadh or Munkar, and the preserved is: "head of a donkey". 
3. I say: In it is an unknown narrator whom no one documented except Ibn Hibban, along with Malik's narration from him as Mawquf. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1657).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 34 - (Discouragement from not completing bowing and prostration, and straightening the spine between them, and what came regarding humility/Khushu') 277 - (1) [Fabricated] And from Abu Hurairah also (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said one day to his companions while I was present: "If one of you owned this column, he would hate for it to be mutilated! How does one of you proceed to mutilate his prayer which belongs to Allah?! So complete your prayer; for Allah does not accept except what is complete." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a Hasan chain (1). (Al-Jad'): Cutting a part of something. 278 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) who said: "Indeed the prescribed prayer has a weight with Allah, whoever decreases anything from it, is held accountable for it in it based on what he decreased." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. 279 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) forbade me from reciting while I am bowing, (2) and said: "O Ali! The likeness of the one who does not straighten his spine in his prayer, is like the likeness of a pregnant woman who carried, and when her delivery approached she miscarried, so she is neither possessing a pregnancy, nor is she possessing a child." Narrated by Abu Ya'la and Al-Asbahani, and added:
foot_note:
1. I say: How, when it contains one whom Abu Hatim and others accused of lying?! And it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5282). 
2. I say: This portion of it was narrated by Muslim (2/ 48) with another Sahih chain. As for the three commentators, due to their ignorance of this science, and the scarcity of their merchandise in Hadith, they weakened it and moved on! Without paying attention to the authenticity of this sentence.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "The likeness of the one who prays, is like the likeness of the trader, his profit is not pure for him, until his capital is pure for him. Likewise the one who prays, his voluntary prayer is not accepted until he performs the obligatory." 280 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "There is no one who prays except there is an angel on his right, and an angel on his left. If he completes it they ascend with it, and if he does not complete it they strike his face with it." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. [Very Weak] And the hadith of Anas from the Prophet (PBUH) passed in "[15 - ] Chapter of Prayer on its Time", and in it: "And whoever prays it outside its time, and does not perfect its ablution, nor complete its humility, nor its bowing, nor its prostration, it exits black and dark, saying: May Allah waste you as you wasted me. Until when it is where Allah wills, it is wrapped as an old garment is wrapped, then his face is struck with it." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 281 - (5) [Weak] And from Uthman bin Abi Dahrish (1) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Allah does not accept a deed from a slave until his heart witnesses with his body." Narrated by Muhammad bin Nasr Al-Marwazi in "Kitab As-Salat" like this as Mursal, and Abu Mansur Ad-Dailami connected it in "Musnad Al-Firdaws" with Ubayy bin Ka'b, and the Mursal is more correct.
foot_note: 1. Thus in the original, and it agrees with the manuscript and "At-Tarikh Al-Kabir" of Al-Bukhari and "Al-Jarh wat-Ta'dil". And in Amarah's edition (Dahrashan), which is a distortion. Furthermore, he is of unknown status (Majhul Al-Hal), a late narrator from the Sheikhs of Ibn Uyaynah. And his hadith is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5050).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 282 - (6) [Weak] And from Al-Fadl bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The prayer is in twos (two by two); you testify (tashahhadu) (1) in every two rak'ahs, and you humble yourself, plead, show submissiveness, and raise your hands (2) —he says: you lift them—to your Lord, with their palms facing your face, and say: 'O Lord! O Lord!' Whoever does not do that, then it is such and such." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and An-Nasa'i, and Ibn Khuzaymah in his "Sahih", though he hesitated about its firmness. They all narrated it from Layth bin Sa'd: Abdur-Rabbi bin Sa'id told us, from Imran bin Abi Anas, from Abdullah bin Nafi' bin Al-Amya', from Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith, from Al-Fadl. At-Tirmidhi said: "Other than Ibn Al-Mubarak said in this hadith: 'Whoever does not do that, then it is deficient (khidaj).' And—he said:—I heard Muhammad bin Isma'il—meaning Al-Bukhari—saying: Shu'bah narrated this hadith from Abdur-Rabbi, but he erred in places. —He said:—And the hadith of Layth bin Sa'd is more authentic than the hadith of Shu'bah." (Al-Hafiz said): "And no one narrated from Abdullah bin Nafi' bin Al-Amya' except Imran bin Abi Anas, and Imran is trustworthy." It was narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah via the path of Shu'bah from Abdur-Rabbi from Ibn Abi Anas from Abdullah bin Nafi' bin Al-Amya' from Abdullah bin Al-Harith from Al-Muttalib bin Abi Wada'ah. The wording of Ibn Majah is: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The prayer is in twos; you testify in every two rak'ahs, show misery, show submissiveness, raise your hands, and say: 'O Allah, forgive me,' and whoever does not do that, then it is deficient (khidaj)." (Al-Khattabi said): "The scholars of Hadith consider Shu'bah to be in error in this hadith—then he related the statement of
foot_note:
1. A present tense verb with one of the 'ta' letters omitted, meaning: 'tatahhadu' (you perform tashahhud). The same applies to the rest of the verbs. This is indicated by the narration of Abu Dawood coming up, which is worded: "an tanshud" (that you implore/recite), and other things have been said. 
2. Meaning: You raise them; as the explanation from the author will come.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Al-Bukhari mentioned previously, and said:—Ya'qub bin Sufyan said regarding this hadith similar to Al-Bukhari's statement, and he faulted Shu'bah and considered Layth bin Sa'd correct. Likewise said Muhammad bin Ishaq bin Khuzaymah. He said: And his saying (taba'as) means displaying misery and poverty, and (tamaskan) is from maskanah (submissiveness). It is also said: Its meaning is stillness and dignity, and the 'mim' is an addition in it. And (iqna' al-yadayn) is raising them in supplication and asking. And (al-khidaj) means here: Deficient in reward and virtue." End quote (1). 283 - (7) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah the Mighty and Majestic said: I only accept prayer from one who humbles himself by it to My Greatness, does not display arrogance over My creation, does not spend the night persisting in disobedience to Me, spends the day in My remembrance, and shows mercy to the poor, the wayfarer, and the widow, and shows mercy to the afflicted. That person's light is like the light of the sun; I protect him with My Might, and I have My angels guard him. I make for him light in darkness and forbearance in ignorance. His likeness among My creation is like the likeness of Firdaws in Paradise." Narrated by Al-Bazzar from the narration of Abdullah bin Waqid Al-Harrani, and the rest of its narrators are trustworthy. 284 - (8) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Indeed, if the servant prays but does not complete his prayer—its humility (khushu') or its bowing—and turns around frequently, it will not be accepted from him. And whoever drags his garment out of arrogance, Allah will not look at him, even if he is noble before Allah." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 285 - (9) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas in a Marfu' report (attributed to the Prophet): "The likeness of the prescribed prayer is like the likeness of a scale; whoever gives full measure receives full measure."
foot_note: 1. Meaning the speech of Al-Khattabi, which is in "Ma'alim as-Sunan" (1/ 87 - 88).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi like this. And others narrated it from Al-Hasan as Mursal (hurried/disconnected), and that is the correct view. 286 - (10) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Abi Bakr: That Abu Talha Al-Ansari was praying in a garden (ha'it) of his, when a dubsi (a type of bird) flew up. It began fluttering back and forth seeking an exit but could not find one. This pleased him (distracted him), so he followed it with his eyes for a moment, then returned to his prayer, but he did not know how much he had prayed. So he said: "A trial has befallen me regarding this property of mine." He came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and mentioned what had happened to him in his prayer, and said: "O Messenger of Allah! It is charity (sadaqah), so place it wherever you wish." Narrated by Malik. And Abdullah bin Abi Bakr did not catch the story (referring to the event/person). It was narrated from another path (1), wherein neither Abu Talha nor the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, were mentioned. Its wording is: That a man from the Ansar was praying in a garden of his in (Al-Quff)—one of the valleys of Medina—during the season of fruit, and the palm trees were laden, surrounded by their fruit. He looked at them and they pleased him, then he returned to his prayer, but he did not know how much he had prayed. So he said: "A trial has befallen me regarding this property of mine." He came to Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him—who was the Caliph at that time—and mentioned that to him, saying: "It is charity, so put it in the path of good." So he sold it for fifty thousand, and that property was named: (The Fifty). (Al-Ha'it): Is the orchard. And (Ad-Dubsi) with a Damma on the unpointed Dal, Sukun on the Ba, and Kasra on the unpointed Sin followed by a stressed Ya: It is a small bird; it is said to be the male turtledove. 287 - (11) [Weak Mawquf] And from Al-A'mash who said: Abdullah—meaning Ibn Mas'ud—used to be like a thrown garment (limp/still) when he prayed. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Al-A'mash did not meet Ibn Mas'ud.
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, which is an illusion. For both stories are in Malik's "Al-Muwatta" (1/ 119 - 120) via one path, which is the path of the mentioned Abdullah bin Abi Bakr.

text: 35 - (Warning against raising one's gaze to the sky during prayer) [There is no hadith under this chapter meeting the condition of this book. See "As-Sahih"] 36 - (Warning against looking around in prayer and other things mentioned) 288 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "When a man stands in prayer, Allah turns His Face toward him. If he looks away, He says: 'O son of Adam! To whom do you turn? To what is better for you than Me? Turn to Me.' If he turns away a second time, He says the same. If he turns away a third time, Allah, Blessed and Exalted, turns His Face away from him." Narrated by Al-Bazzar. 289 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed, when the servant stands for prayer—I think he said:—he is only before the Most Merciful, Blessed and Exalted. If he looks away, Allah, Blessed and Exalted, says: 'To whom do you turn? To someone better than Me? Turn to Me, O son of Adam, for I am better than the one you turn to.'" Narrated by Al-Bazzar as well. 290 - (3) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said to me: "O my son! Beware of looking around in prayer, for looking around in prayer is destruction." The Hadith. Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from the narration of Ali bin Zaid from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from Anas, and he said: "A Hasan Hadith," and in some copies: "Sahih."
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (The Dictator said): "Ali bin Zaid bin Jud'an will be discussed later, and the narration of Sa'id from Anas is not famous." 291 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever performs ablution and perfects the ablution, then prays two rak'ahs and supplicates to his Lord; his supplication will surely be answered, either hastened or delayed. Beware of looking around in prayer, for there is no prayer for the one who looks around. If you are overcome (by it) in voluntary prayer, do not be overcome in the obligatory prayer." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". And in a narration of his also, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever stands in prayer and looks around, Allah rejects his prayer back upon him." 292 - (5) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Allah continues to face the servant with His Face as long as he does not look around or break his ablution. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" as a Mawquf report from Abu Qilabah from Ibn Mas'ud, and he did not hear from him. 293 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "When one of you stands for prayer, let him focus on it until he finishes it. And beware of looking around in prayer, for one of you is conversing with his Lord as long as he is in the prayer." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 294 - (7) [Weak] And from Umm Salamah bint Abi Umayyah, the wife of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that she said: During the time of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, when the worshiper stood to pray, his gaze would not exceed the place of his feet. When the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, passed away (1), the people were such that when one of them stood to pray, his gaze would not exceed the place of his forehead. Then Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, passed away, and it was (the time of) (1) Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, so the people were such that when one of them stood to pray, his gaze would not exceed the place of the Qibla. Then Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, passed away, and it was (the time of) (1) Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, and the Fitnah (tribulation) occurred, so people began looking right and left." Narrated by Ibn Majah with a Hasan chain, except that Musa bin Abdullah bin Abi Umayyah Al-Makhzumi had no narrations extracted by the authors of the Six Books except Ibn Majah, and I do not recall any disparagement or endorsement regarding him (2). And Allah knows best.
foot_note:
1. Original: (fa-tuwuffiya - then he passed away), (fa-kana - then it was). Correction is from Ibn Majah (1634), and the Three overlooked it. The sentence about the death of Umar is not present in his version. 
2. I say: No one declared him trustworthy; rather, he is Unknown (Majhul) as stated by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar. Furthermore, there is apparent denouncability (nakarah) in his text.

text: 37 - (Warning against wiping pebbles and the like in the place of prostration and blowing into it without necessity) 295 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "When one of you stands in prayer, let him not wipe the pebbles, for Mercy is facing him." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi who classified it Hasan, An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs". The wording of Ibn Khuzaymah is: "When one of you stands in prayer, indeed Mercy faces him, so do not move the pebbles." They all narrated it from the narration of Abu Al-Ahwas from him (1). 296 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Salih, the freed slave of the family of Talha, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I was with Umm Salamah, the wife of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. A relative of hers—a young man with a jummah (2)—came and stood to pray. When he wanted to prostrate, he blew [to clear the dust]. She said: Do not do that, for the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say to a black boy of ours: "O Rabah! Dust your face [in the soil]." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih". And At-Tirmidhi narrated it from the narration of Maymun Abu Hamzah from Abu Salih from Umm Salamah who said: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saw a boy of ours called Aflah blowing when he prostrated. So he said: "O Aflah! Dust your face" (3).
foot_note:
1. I say: (Abu Al-Ahwas) is Unknown, and Ibn Ma'in said: "He is nothing." 
2. It is hair of the head that falls to the shoulders. "An-Nihayah". 
3. I say: This (Abu Salih) is not known, as stated by Adh-Dhahabi, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5485).

text: 39 - (Warning against passing in front of a praying person) 298 - (1) [Anomalous (Shadh)] And [meaning the hadith of Abu Juhaim] was narrated by Al-Bazzar with the wording: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "If the one passing in front of the praying person knew what was upon him, it would be better for him to stand for forty autumns than to pass in front of him." And its men are the men of the Sahih (1). [Weak] At-Tirmidhi said: And it was narrated from Anas (2) that he said: "For one of you to stand for a hundred years is better for him than to pass in front of his brother while he is praying." 299 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "If one of you knew what is upon him for walking in front of his brother, intercepting him while he is conversing with his Lord, then for him to stand in that place for a hundred years would be more beloved to him than the step he took." Narrated by Ibn Majah with a Sahih chain (3), and Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs", and the wording belongs to Ibn Hibban.
foot_note:
1. I say: Yes, but it is not from Abu Juhaim, rather from Zaid bin Khalid, and this is Anomalous (Shadh). Likewise is his saying: "Forty autumns." The preserved narration is what is in the "Sahih": "Abu An-Nadr said: I do not know if he said: Forty days or months or years." It does not contain the certainty of "forty autumns". I have explained this sufficiently in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6911). 
2. Thus in the original and the edition of the Three! What is in At-Tirmidhi (2/ 160 - Shakir) is: "It has been narrated from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that he said..." He did not mention Anas, but rather the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and perhaps that is the correct version. I did not find anyone who connected it to Anas. 
3. Thus he said! But it contains an unknown narrator, and another who is not strong. It is extracted in "Ar-Rawd" (1129) and others.
