text: 40 - (Warning against abandoning prayer intentionally, and delaying it beyond its time out of negligence) 300 - (1) [Weak] And from Ubada bin as-Samit, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: My close friend, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, advised me with seven qualities, saying: "Do not associate anything with Allah, even if you are cut to pieces, or burned, or crucified. Do not leave the prayer intentionally; for whoever leaves it intentionally has exited the Religion (Millah). Do not commit disobedience; for it is the wrath of Allah. And do not drink wine; for it is the head of all errors." The Hadith. Narrated by At-Tabarani and Muhammad bin Nasr in "Kitab As-Salah" with two chains that are acceptable (la ba'sa bihima) (1). 301 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "There is no share in Islam for the one who has no prayer, and there is no prayer for the one who has no ablution" (2). Narrated by Al-Bazzar. 302 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "There is no faith for the one who has no trust, and no prayer for the one who has no purification, and no religion for the one who has no prayer. Indeed, the position of prayer in the religion is like the position of the head in the body." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and "As-Saghir" and he said: "Al-Husayn bin Al-Hakam Al-Hibri is unique in narrating it." [Passed in Chapter 13].
foot_note:
1. I say: It is actually one chain! And in both their versions it contains Salamah bin Shuraih. Adh-Dhahabi said: "He is not known"! It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5991). In it is a refutation of those who use the hadith to argue for the disbelief of one who leaves prayer out of laziness, and against the three commentators who classified it as Hasan due to supporting evidence, while there is no supporting evidence for the phrase "exiting the Religion" and others. Some contemporary writers whom we think well of have fallen into similar errors. 
2. I say: However, the second half of it is authentic. See the commentary on Hadith (203) in "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 303 - (4) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: When my eyesight went (qama basari), it was said: "Shall we treat you, provided you leave the prayer for some days?" He said: "No. Indeed the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'Whoever leaves the prayer meets Allah while He is angry with him.'" Narrated by Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and its chain is Hasan (1). (Qamat al-'ayn): When its sight is gone while the pupil remains intact. 304 - (5) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever leaves the prayer intentionally has committed disbelief openly." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a chain that is acceptable (2). 305 - (6) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both—Hammad bin Zaid said: I do not know but that he—raised it to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: "The handholds of Islam and the foundations of the Religion are three, upon them Islam is founded. Whoever leaves one of them is, by that, a disbeliever whose blood is lawful: The testimony that there is no god but Allah, the prescribed prayer, and the fast of Ramadan." Narrated by Abu Ya'la with a Hasan chain (3). And Sa'id bin Zaid, the brother of Hammad bin Zaid, narrated it from Amr bin Malik An-Nukri from Abu Al-Jawza' from Ibn Abbas as Marfu', and he said in it:
foot_note:
1. In its chain is Salim bin Mahmud, whose condition is unknown. I have extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4571). 
2. Thus he said, but it contains Abu Ja'far Ar-Razi, who has poor memory. See "Ad-Da'ifah" (2508). 
3. I say: How so, when its narrator hesitated in raising it (to the Prophet), and below him is one who has poor memory, and much more which is explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (94)? So whoever wishes for detail should refer to it.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever leaves one of them is a disbeliever in Allah; no obligatory or voluntary deed will be accepted from him, and his blood and wealth have become lawful" (1). 306 - (7) [Weak] And from Buraydah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Pray early on a cloudy day, for whoever leaves the prayer has committed disbelief." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih". [Passed in Chapter 26]. 307 - (8) [Weak] And from Ziyad bin Nu'aim Al-Hadrami who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Four things Allah has obligated in Islam; whoever performs three of them, they will not avail him anything until he performs them all: The Prayer, Zakat, Fasting Ramadan, and Hajj to the House." Narrated by Ahmad, and it is Mursal. 308 - (9) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever leaves a prayer intentionally; Allah nullifies his deeds, and the protection (dhimmah) of Allah is absolved from him, until he returns to Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, with repentance." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. 309 - (10) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Whoever does not pray is a disbeliever. Narrated by Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah in "Kitab Al-Iman" (2), and Al-Bukhari in his "Tarikh" as Mawquf.
foot_note:
1. An-Naji said: "Al-Asbahani added: after his saying: 'he is by that a disbeliever': 'You find him with much wealth but he does not perform Hajj, so he remains a disbeliever and his blood is not lawful. And you find him with much wealth but he does not pay Zakat, so he remains by that a disbeliever, and his blood is not lawful.'" I say: It is also in Abu Ya'la (2/ 621). 
2. I say: It contains an unknown narrator. See my commentary on the book "Al-Iman" (42/ 126).

text: 310 - (11) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: Whoever leaves the prayer has committed disbelief. Narrated by Muhammad bin Nasr Al-Marwazi, and Ibn Abd al-Barr as Mawquf. 311 - (12) [Weak Mawquf] And from Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: Whoever does not pray is a disbeliever. Narrated by Ibn Abd al-Barr as Mawquf (1). 312 - (13) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: That he mentioned the prayer one day and said: "Whoever preserves it, it will be a light, a proof, and a salvation for him on the Day of Resurrection. And whoever does not preserve it, he will have no light, no proof, and no salvation, and on the Day of Resurrection he will be with Qarun, Pharaoh, Haman, and Ubayy bin Khalaf." He said: "They are those who delay the prayer beyond its time." Narrated by Al-Bazzar from the narration of Ikrimah bin Ibrahim, and he said:
foot_note:

2. Thus he said, but the correct view is Adh-Dhahabi's statement: "Its chain is not like that (not up to that standard)."

text: "Al-Hafiz narrated it as Mawquf, and no one raised it (to the Prophet) other than him." Al-Hafiz, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "And this Ikrimah is Al-Azdi; there is consensus on his weakness, and the correct view is that it is Mawquf." 314 - (15) [Very Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever combines two prayers without an excuse has come to a door from the doors of Major Sins (Kaba'ir)." Narrated by Al-Hakim (1) and he said: "Hanash is Ibn Qais, trustworthy." (Al-Hafiz said): "Rather, he is extremely flimsy; we know of no one who declared him trustworthy except Husayn bin Numair (2)." 315 - (16) [Weak] Al-Bazzar narrated from the hadith of Ar-Rabi' bin Anas from Abu Al-Aliyah or another from Abu Huraira who said: "Then he—meaning the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace—came upon [a] people whose heads were being smashed with rocks. Every time they were smashed, they returned as they were, and nothing of that [punishment] ceased from them. He said: 'O Gabriel! Who are [these?' He said:] (3) 'These are those whose heads felt too heavy for the prescribed prayer.'" He mentioned the hadith regarding the story of Isra' and the obligation of prayer.
foot_note:
1. I say: And At-Tirmidhi as well, but he weakened it. 
2. I say: And his endorsement has no value, due to his contradicting the Imams of Criticism and Endorsement, and because he is not one of them. 
3. This addition and the one before it are from the manuscript, "Zawa'id Al-Bazzar" (p. 9), and "Majma' Az-Zawa'id" (1/ 67). Furthermore, the chain of Al-Bazzar contains (Abu Ja'far Ar-Razi), who has poor memory, and in some of his wordings there is severe oddity (nakarah) as stated by Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 6 - Book of Voluntary Prayers (An-Nawafil) 1 - (Encouragement to preserve twelve Sunnah Rak'ahs during the day and night) [There is no hadith under this chapter meeting the condition of our book. See "As-Sahih"] 2 - (Encouragement to preserve two Rak'ahs before Fajr) 316 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: A man said: O Messenger of Allah! Guide me to a deed by which Allah will benefit me. He said: "Stick to the two rak'ahs of Fajr; for in them is a virtue." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". And in a narration of his also, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Do not leave the two rak'ahs before the Fajr prayer; for in them are the objects of desire (Ar-Ragha'ib)." And Ahmad narrated part of it: "And the two rak'ahs of Fajr, preserve them, for in them are the objects of desire." 317 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "My close friend, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, advised me with three: Fasting three days of every month, Witr before sleeping, and the two rak'ahs of Fajr." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" with a Jayyid (good) chain (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: Thus he said, and I have not yet come across its chain to look into it, but I suspect it is not free from a defect, even if it is a contradiction in the text. For it is in Muslim similar to the narration of Abu Dawood mentioned in "As-Sahih" (16 - Encouragement for Duha Prayer), and in it is: "and the Duha prayer" instead of: "and the two rak'ahs of Fajr."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: It is in Abu Dawood and others; except for his saying: "the two rak'ahs of Fajr," mentioning in their place: "the two rak'ahs of Duha." And it will come, if Allah the Exalted wills. 318 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "{Say: He is Allah, One} is equivalent to a third of the Quran, and {Say: O Disbelievers} is equivalent to a quarter of the Quran." He used to recite them in the two rak'ahs of Fajr (1), and he said: "These two rak'ahs contain the desire of the age (raghab ad-dahr)" (2). Narrated by Abu Ya'la with a Hasan chain, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and the wording is his. 319 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Do not leave the two rak'ahs of Fajr, even if the horses (cavalry) chase you." Narrated by Abu Dawood.
foot_note:
1. Up to here the hadith is Sahih due to its supporting evidence. 
2. In the original, the edition of Amarah, and the Three Ignorant Ones: "Ad-Durr" (pearls). The correction is from "Kabir At-Tabarani", "Al-Majma'", and the manuscript. Abu Ya'la does not have the last sentence of it. In their chain is a weak narrator who became confused, as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5051). The hadith without it has supporting evidence, so refer to "As-Sahihah" (586) and "Sifat As-Salah"; therefore I included it in "As-Sahih", here without it.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - (Encouragement for prayer before Dhuhr and after it) 320 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Ayyub, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Four before Dhuhr in which there is no Taslim (greeting/ending); the gates of the sky are opened for them." Narrated by Abu Dawood and the wording is his, and Ibn Majah, and in their chains is a possibility for improvement (Tahsin) (1). 321 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Thawban, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to like to pray after midday. Aisha said: O Messenger of Allah! I see you like the prayer at this hour? He said: "In it the gates of the sky are opened, and Allah, Blessed and Exalted, looks with mercy upon His creation. It is a prayer that Adam, Noah, Abraham, Moses, and Jesus used to preserve." Narrated by Al-Bazzar. 322 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever prays four rak'ahs before Dhuhr, it is as if he performed Tahajjud with them during his night. And whoever prays them after Isha, they are like their equivalent from Laylat al-Qadr." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 323 - (4) [Weak] And from Bashir bin Sulaiman from Amr bin Al-Ansari from his father from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever prays four before Dhuhr; it is like the equivalent of freeing a slave from the children of Ishmael." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and its narrators up to Bashir are trustworthy.
foot_note: 1. The hadith without his saying: "in which there is no Taslim" is Hasan. See "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 324 - (5) [Weak] And from Abdur-Rahman bin Hamid from his father from his grandfather; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The prayer of the Hajir (midday heat) is like the night prayer." (The narrator said): I asked Abdur-Rahman bin Hamid about (Al-Hajir)? He said: When the sun declines (passes the zenith). Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and in its chain is softness. The grandfather of Abdur-Rahman is Abdur-Rahman bin Awf, may Allah be pleased with him. 325 - (6) [Weak Mawquf] And from Al-Aswad, Murrah, and Masruq who said: Abdullah [bin Mas'ud] said: There is nothing from the day prayer that equals the night prayer except four before Dhuhr. And their virtue over the day prayer is like the virtue of the congregational prayer over the solitary prayer. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and it is a Mawquf report that is acceptable (la ba'sa bihi) (1). 326 - (7) [Weak] And it was narrated from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Four before Dhuhr and after the Zawal (decline of sun) are counted like their equivalent in the Sahar (pre-dawn). There is nothing except that it glorifies Allah at that hour." Then he recited: {Its shadows incline to the right and left, prostrating to Allah, while they are humble} [An-Nahl: 48]. Narrated by At-Tirmidhi in the "Tafsir" section of his "Jami'" and he said: "A Gharib (strange) Hadith, we do not know it except from the hadith of Ali bin Asim."
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, which is a clear leniency, for it has three defects as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5053).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 4 - (Encouragement for prayer before Asr) 327 - (1) [Weak] And from Umm Habiba bint Abi Sufyan, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever preserves four rak'ahs before Asr; Allah will build for him a house in Paradise." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and in its chain is Muhammad bin Sa'd the Mu'adhin; it is not known who he is (1). 328 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Umm Salamah from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever prays four rak'ahs before Asr; Allah forbids his body to the Fire." The Hadith. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 329 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I came while the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was sitting among people of his Companions, among them Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. I caught the end of the hadith, while the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was saying: "Whoever prays four rak'ahs before Asr; the Fire will not touch him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 330 - (4) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "My Ummah will not cease praying these four rak'ahs before Asr until they walk upon the earth forgiven, a decisive forgiveness." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and it is Gharib.
foot_note: 1. I say: Similar is in "Majma' Az-Zawa'id", and the Three Ignorant Ones copied it, and prefaced it by saying: "Hasan due to its supporting evidences"! And they lied, for there is no witness for it with this wording. If they meant the hadiths that follow, then why did they weaken them and not classify them as Hasan? Stumbling blindly!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 5 - (Encouragement for prayer between Maghrib and Isha) 331 - (1) [Very Weak] From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever prays six rak'ahs after Maghrib, and does not speak ill between them; they will be equated to the worship of twelve years." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and Ibn Khuzaymah in his "Sahih", and At-Tirmidhi; all from the hadith of Umar bin Abi Khath'am, from Yahya bin Abi Kathir, from Abu Salamah from him. At-Tirmidhi said: "A Gharib Hadith." 332 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever prays twenty rak'ahs after Maghrib; Allah will build for him a house in Paradise." End quote (1). And this hadith which At-Tirmidhi referred to was narrated by Ibn Majah from the narration of Ya'qub bin Al-Walid Al-Mada'ini, from Hisham bin Urwah, from his father, from Aisha. And Ya'qub was declared a liar by Ahmad and others. 333 - (3) [Weak] And from Muhammad bin Ammar bin Yasir who said: I saw Ammar bin Yasir praying six rak'ahs after Maghrib, and he said: I saw my beloved, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, praying six rak'ahs after Maghrib, and he said: "Whoever prays six rak'ahs after Maghrib; his sins are forgiven, even if they were like the foam of the sea." A Gharib Hadith, narrated by At-Tabarani in "The Three", and he said:
foot_note: 1. Meaning the speech of At-Tirmidhi, the beginning of which is at the end of the previous hadith.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Salih bin Qatan Al-Bukhari is unique in narrating it." (Al-Hafiz said): "And regarding this Salih, I do not recall now any disparagement or endorsement (1)." 334 - (4) [Weak] And from Al-Aswad bin Yazid who said: Abdullah bin Mas'ud said: How excellent is the Hour of Negligence—meaning the prayer between Maghrib and Isha. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" from the narration of Jabir Al-Ju'fi, and he did not raise it (to the Prophet). 335 - (5) [Weak] And from Makhul conveying it to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever prays two rak'ahs—and in a narration: four rak'ahs—after Maghrib before speaking; his prayer is raised in Illiyyun." Mentioned by Razin, and I did not see it in the sources (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: So he is Unknown (Majhul), and those above him are also unknown as I explained in the original work. 
2. I say: Ibn Nasr narrated it in "Qiyam Al-Layl" (31), as did Ibn Abi Shaybah (2/ 198), and Abdur-Rahman (3/ 70/ 4833) via the first narration, and its chain is weak and Mursal.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 6 - (Encouragement for prayer after Isha) 336 - (1) [Very Weak] Narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Four before Dhuhr are like four after Isha, and four after Isha are like their equivalent from Laylat al-Qadr." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". And the hadith of Al-Bara' has passed [Chapter 3]: "Whoever prays four rak'ahs before Dhuhr, it is as if he performed Tahajjud with them during his night. And whoever prays them after Isha, they are like their equivalent from Laylat al-Qadr." 337 - (2) [Weak] And in "Al-Kabir" (1) from the hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever prays Isha, the last prayer, in congregation, and prays four rak'ahs before he leaves the mosque; it is like the equivalent of Laylat al-Qadr."
foot_note: 1. Likewise in "Al-Majma'", but I did not see it in "Al-Kabir"; rather, it is in "Al-Awsat". From its path, I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5060), and it is authentic as a Mawquf report from a group of Sahabah without the phrase: "before he leaves the mosque," as I explained there.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 7 - (Encouragement for Witr prayer, and what came regarding one who does not perform Witr) 338 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever prays Duha, fasts three days of the month, and does not leave Witr while traveling or resident; the reward of a martyr is written for him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and there is oddity (nakarah) in it. 339 - (2) [Weak] And from Kharijah bin Hudhafah who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, came out to us one day and said: "Allah has supplied you with a prayer that is better for you than red camels; it is the Witr. He has assigned it for you between the last Isha and the rising of Fajr." Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah, and At-Tirmidhi who said: "A Gharib Hadith, we do not know it except from the hadith of Yazid bin Abi Habib." End quote. And Al-Bukhari said: "The hearing of some of them from others in its chain—meaning the chain of this hadith—is not known" (1). 340 - (3) [Weak] And from Buraydah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Witr is a right (Haqq), so whoever does not perform Witr is not of us. Witr is a right, so whoever does not perform Witr is not of us. Witr is a right, so whoever does not perform Witr is not of us —three times—." Narrated by Ahmad, and Abu Dawood, and the wording is his. And in its chain is Ubaidullah bin Abdullah Abu Al-Munib Al-Ataki. And Al-Hakim narrated it and said: "Authentic in chain" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: It is authentic via another path, without his saying: "it is better for you than red camels," and therefore I included it in "As-Sahih". The Three Commentators did not notice this difference—as is their habit—so they said stumbling blindly: "Hasan"! Despite Al-Bukhari and At-Tirmidhi weakening it. 
2. I say: And Adh-Dhahabi refuted him saying: "I say: Abu Al-Munib, Al-Bukhari said: He has denounced reports (manakir)."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 8 - (Encouragement for a person to sleep while pure (in Wudu) intending to rise for prayer) 341 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever retires (awa) to his bed while pure, remembering Allah until drowsiness overtakes him; he does not turn over at any hour of the night asking Allah for good from the good of this world and the Hereafter, except that Allah gives it to him." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from Shahr bin Hawshab from Abu Umamah and he said: "A Hasan [Gharib] Hadith." (Awa) is without Madd (elongation) (1).
foot_note: 1. This explanation appeared in the original at the end of the first hadith of the next chapter in the other book, so I moved it here because it is its place. The Three Ignorant Ones did not notice this, so they kept it in its place without comment!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 9 - (Encouragement for words one says when retiring to his bed, and what came regarding one who slept without remembering Allah the Exalted) 342 - (1) [Weak] And from Rafi' bin Khadij from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "If one of you lies down on his right side then says: (O Allah, I have submitted my soul to You, turned my face to You, leaned my back to You, and delegated my affair to You. There is no refuge from You except to You. I believe in Your Book and in Your Messenger), if he dies that night; he enters Paradise." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "This is a Hasan Gharib Hadith" (1). 343 - (2) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him; that he said to Ibn Aghyad (2): Shall I not tell you about myself and Fatimah, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who was among the most beloved of his family to him, and she was with me (my wife)? I said: Yes. He said: Indeed she ground with the hand mill until it left marks on her hand, and carried the waterskin until it left marks on her chest, and swept the house until her clothes became dusty. Some servants came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so I said:
foot_note:
1. This is strange from At-Tirmidhi then the Author, and the Ignorant Ones imitated him! Indeed his saying: (wa bi-rasulika - and in Your Messenger) is an error from the narrator. Al-Bara', may Allah be pleased with him, fell into it, so the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, corrected him and said: "No, (wa bi-nabiyyika - and in Your Prophet) whom You sent," and it is in "As-Sahih" at the beginning of the chapter. 
2. Original: (A'bud) with a Ba, and likewise in the manuscript, and similarly in "Abu Dawood" (5063), and in "Al-Musnad" also (1/ 153) and the edition of the Ignorant Ones. The correct version is what is in "Al-Khulasah" that it is (Ibn Aghyad) with a silent unpointed letter and Fatha on the pointed Ya, and he is Unknown (Majhul) as stated by An-Naji (84). The hadith is in "As-Sahihayn" from other than his path in abbreviated form. Had the author preferred their narration, he would have been correct. Therefore, I see that it is necessary to mention it for the reader to rely on, and because he did not mention it elsewhere. So see it in the other book, in the chapter referred to previously. Yes, the story has another context mentioned by the author in (14/ 11 - Encouragement for Verses and Adhkar of Prayers / Second Hadith), containing his saying, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: (By Allah, I will not give you and leave the people of As-Suffah with their bellies folded from hunger...), but this portion of it was extracted by Ahmad (1/ 79) with a Sahih chain from Ali.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "If you went to your father and asked him for a servant." So she went to him, but found people speaking with him (1), so she returned. He came to her the next day and said: "What was your need?" She remained silent. So I said: I will tell you, O Messenger of Allah! She ground with the hand mill until it left marks on her hand, and carried the waterskin until it left marks on her chest. When the servants came, I ordered her to come to you to ask you for a servant to save her from the heat of what she is in. He said: "Fear Allah, O Fatimah! Perform the obligation of your Lord, do the work of your family, and when you take to your bed, glorify Allah (Tasbih) thirty-three times, praise Him (Tahmid) thirty-three times, and magnify Him (Takbir) thirty-four times. That is a hundred; it is better for you than a servant." She said: I am pleased with Allah and His Messenger. He added in a narration (2): "And he did not give her a servant." Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim, and Abu Dawood and the wording is his (3), and At-Tirmidhi briefly and he said: "And there is a story in the hadith," but he did not mention it.
foot_note:
1. Meaning: A group talking. It is a plural not based on analogy, carried on its counterpart, like (samir) or (summar), for 'summar' are those who converse, as in "An-Nihayah". It was in the original: "hudatha", so I corrected it from it and from "Abu Dawood". 
2. This narration is not connected, but rather from the narration of Ali bin Al-Hasan as Mursal. 
3. I say: Attributing it to the Two Sheikhs involves great leniency, for it is in their collections via other than the path of (Ibn Aghyad) in abbreviated form. Its context contradicts his context, as becomes clear by comparing it with their context which I mentioned in the other book as indicated previously. Therefore, Al-Hafiz An-Naji critiqued it, and spoke at length clarifying the paths of the hadith and its wordings and their extraction (83 - 87). The Three Commentators did not notice the difference in the two contexts—as is their habit—so they prefaced their extraction with extreme ignorance saying: "Sahih, narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim and Abu Dawood..." And Allah is the One sought for help. To make matters worse, and confirming their ignorance, they included it in what they called "Tahdhib At-Targhib" (123 - 124)! In which they singled out—so they claimed—the Authentic and Hasan hadiths!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 344 - (3) [Weak] And from Al-Irbad bin Sariyah, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to read the Musabbihat (Surahs starting with Glorification of Allah) before he went to sleep, saying: "Indeed in them is a verse better than a thousand verses." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and At-Tirmidhi, and the wording is his and he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith." And An-Nasa'i, who said: "Muawiyah—meaning Ibn Salih—said: Some people of knowledge used to count the Musabbihat as six: Surah {Al-Hadid}, {Al-Hashr}, {As-Saff} (Al-Hawariyyin), Surah {Al-Jumu'ah}, {At-Taghabun}, and {Glorify the Name of your Lord, the Most High}." 345 - (4) [Weak] And from Shaddad bin Aws, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "There is no Muslim who takes to his bed, and reads a Surah from the Book of Allah, except that Allah appoints an angel over him, so nothing that harms him approaches him, until he wakes (yahubba) from his sleep whenever he wakes." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi. And Ahmad narrated it; except that he said: "Allah sends an angel for him to guard him from everything that harms him, until he wakes whenever he wakes." And the narrators of Ahmad are the narrators of "As-Sahih" (1). (Habba) means: Woke up from his sleep. 346 - (5) [Weak] And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "When a man retires to his bed, an angel and a devil rush to him. The angel says: 'Seal with good,' and the devil says: 'Seal with evil.' If he remembers Allah then sleeps, the angel spends the night guarding him. When
foot_note: 1. I say: How so, when it contains (Al-Hanzali), who is Unknown and not recognized, and is not from the men of the Sahih?!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: he wakes up, the angel says: 'Open with good,' and the devil says: 'Open with evil.' If he says: 'Praise be to Allah who returned my soul to me, and did not cause it to die in its sleep. Praise be to Allah who {holds the heavens and the earth lest they cease} to the end of the verse. Praise be to Allah who {holds the sky lest it fall upon the earth, except by His permission}'; then if he falls from his bed and dies, he enters Paradise." Narrated by Abu Ya'la with a Sahih chain, and Al-Hakim, who added at its end: "Praise be to Allah who gives life to the dead, and He is over all things competent," and he said: "Authentic on the condition of Muslim" (1). (Yakla'uhu) means: Guards and protects him. 347 - (6) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "If you place your side on the bed and read {The Opening of the Book} and {Say: He is Allah, One}; then you are secure from everything except death." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and his men are the men of "As-Sahih"; except Ghassan bin Ubaid. 348 - (7) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever wishes to sleep in his bed and sleeps on his right side, then reads: {Say: He is Allah, One} a hundred times, when it is the Day of Resurrection, the Lord says to him: 'O My servant! Enter Paradise on your right.'" Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib Hadith." 349 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said:
foot_note: 1. I say: It contains in both their versions and others the 'an'anah (narrating with 'from') of Abu Az-Zubayr. The Three Ignorant Ones classified it as Hasan, so neither did they authenticate it by imitation, nor did they find it defective by following scientific rules; due to their ignorance!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever says when he retires to his bed: (I seek forgiveness from Allah [the Great], whom there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer, and I repent to Him) [three times] (1); his sins are forgiven even if they were like the foam of the sea, even if they were the number of the leaves of the trees, even if they were the number of the sands of Alij, and even if they were the number of the days of the world." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi via the path of Al-Wassafi, from Atiyyah, from Abu Sa'id, and he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith, we do not know it except from this mode; from the hadith of Ubaidullah bin Al-Walid Al-Wassafi." (The Dictator said): "This Ubaidullah is flimsy (wahi), but Isam bin Qudamah followed him in it; and he is trustworthy. Al-Bukhari extracted it in his 'Tarikh' from his path similarly. And this Atiyyah is Al-Awfi, discussion of him will come." 350 - (9) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever says when he retires to his bed: (Praise be to Allah who is Exalted so He dominated, and was Hidden so He knew, and Owned so He decreed. Praise be to Allah who gives life and causes death, and He is over all things competent); he exits his sins like the day his mother bore him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Hakim, and from his path Al-Bayhaqi in "Ash-Shu'ab" and others. 351 - (10) [Weak] And [meaning the hadith of Abu Huraira which is in "As-Sahih"] was narrated by At-Tirmidhi and others from the hadith of Abu Ayyub similarly, and in some of its paths with him (2) he said: "Let me go and I will teach you a verse from the Book of Allah which you will not place on wealth or child except that a devil will never approach you. I said: And what is it? He said: I cannot speak it; the Verse of {The Chair} (Ayat Al-Kursi)."
foot_note:
1. This and what is before it fell from the original, and they are in At-Tirmidhi. And in Ahmad (3/ 10) is the second (phrase), and the Ignorant Ones did not notice the first! It occurred to An-Nawawi in his "Adhkar" to replace 'leaves of the trees' with "number of the stars", which is an illusion as stated by An-Naji (87), and the virtuous investigator of "Al-Adhkar" (77) did not notice it. 
2. This word: (with him/'indahu) is inserted, as Al-Hafiz An-Naji pointed out (89), for the hadith of Abu Ayyub is in At-Tirmidhi (2/ 144) and it does not have this wording. Rather, it is in Ahmad (5/ 423) similarly without his saying: "I cannot speak it." The wording of At-Tirmidhi will come in (13/ 7 - Encouragement to Recite the Noble Verse). And the hadith of Ayyub has no relation to this chapter as is apparent, and Al-Hafiz An-Naji pointed that out (88). And the Three Ignorant Ones overlooked all of this!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 10 - (Encouragement for words to say when waking up at night) 352 - (1) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him; that he heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Indeed, when Allah the Exalted returns the soul of the believing servant to him during the night, and he glorifies Him (Tasbih), praises Him (Tamjid), seeks His forgiveness, and supplicates to Him; it is accepted from him." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. 353 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever says when he stirs at night: (In the name of Allah) ten times, and (Glory be to Allah) ten times, (I have believed in Allah and disbelieved in Taghut) ten times; he is protected from everything (1) he fears, and it is not fitting for a sin to overtake him until the like of it [the next night]." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat".
foot_note: 1. Original: (Dhanb - sin), and the correct version is what I established [Shay' - thing]. The claimants of verification overlooked it, so they established the error even though they referred to "Al-Majma'", where it is correct.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 11 - (Encouragement for Qiyam al-Layl [Night Prayer]) 354 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! Indeed when I see you, my soul becomes pleasant and my eye becomes cool. Inform me about everything. He said: "Everything was created from water." So I said: Inform me of something which if I do, I will enter Paradise. He said: "Feed food, spread peace, maintain ties of kinship, and pray at night while people are asleep; you will enter Paradise in peace" (1). Narrated by Ahmad, Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab At-Tahajjud", and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" and the wording is his, and Al-Hakim who authenticated it. 355 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Indeed in Paradise there is a tree; from its top come out garments, and from its bottom come out horses of gold, saddled and bridled with pearls and rubies, they do not defecate nor urinate, they have wings, their stride is as far as the eye can see. The people of Paradise will ride them, and they will fly with them wherever they wish. Those who are lower than them in rank will say: O Lord! By what did Your servants attain all this honor? He said: It will be said to them: They used to pray at night while you were sleeping, they used to fast while you were eating, they used to spend [in charity] while you were stingy, and they used to fight [in Jihad] while you were cowardly." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya.
foot_note: 1. This segment is witnessed [supported] by the hadith of Abdullah bin Salam in the chapter in "As-Sahih". So take note.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 356 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Asma bint Yazid, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "People will be gathered on one plain on the Day of Resurrection, then a caller will call out saying: Where are those whose {sides shunned their beds} [As-Sajdah: 16]? So they will stand up, and they are few. They will enter Paradise without account, then the rest of the people will be ordered to the reckoning." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi. 357 - (4) [Weak] And from Salman Al-Farsi, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Stick to the night prayer (Qiyam al-Layl); for it is the habit (da'b) (1) of the righteous before you, a means of drawing near to your Lord, an expiation for bad deeds, a deterrent from sin, and a means of expelling disease from the body." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" from the narration of Abdur-Rahman bin Sulaiman bin Abi Al-Jawn (2). 358 - (5) [Very Weak] And At-Tirmidhi narrated it in "Ad-Da'awat" from his "Jami'" from the narration of Bakr bin Khunais, from Muhammad bin Sa'id Ash-Shami, from Rabi'ah bin Yazid, from Abu Idris Al-Khawlani, from Bilal, may Allah be pleased with him. And Abdur-Rahman bin Sulaiman is in a better state than Muhammad bin Sa'id. 359 - (6) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated in "Al-Kabir" from Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "There is no man who wakes up at night, wakes his wife, and if sleep overcomes her he sprinkles water on her face, so they stand in their house and remember Allah the Mighty and Majestic for an hour of the night; except that they are forgiven."
foot_note:
1. (Ad-Da'b): Habit and manner/state. It may be vowelized [Da'ab]. Its origin is from (Da'aba fi al-'amal): If he strove and tired, but the Arabs transformed its meaning to habit and manner. Stated in "An-Nihayah". 
2. In "As-Sahih" there is what suffices for it from the hadith of Abu Umamah; without the sentence about expelling disease.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 360 - (7) [Weak] And from Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The virtue of night prayer over day prayer is like the virtue of secret charity over public charity." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" with a Hasan chain (1). 361 - (8) [Weak] And it was narrated from Samura bin Jundub, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, ordered us to pray at night, little or much, and to make the last of that a Witr." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Bazzar. 362 - (9) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas, raising it [to the Prophet], who said: "A prayer in my mosque is equal to ten thousand prayers, a prayer in the Sacred Mosque is equal to one hundred thousand prayers, and prayer in the land of Ribat [guarding the frontier] is equal to two million prayers. And more than all of that; are two rak'ahs which a servant prays in the depth of the night, desiring by them nothing but what is with Allah the Mighty and Majestic." Narrated by Abu Ash-Shaykh Ibn Hayyan in "Kitab Ath-Thawab". 363 - (10) [Weak] And from Iyas bin Muawiyah Al-Muzani, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "There must be a prayer at night, even if it is [the duration of] milking a sheep. And whatever is after the Isha prayer is from the night." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its narrators are trustworthy; except Muhammad bin Ishaq (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: Yes, were it not that one of its narrators from Ath-Thawri was contradicted in raising it [to the Prophet], for a group of trustworthy narrators narrated it as Mawquf from Ath-Thawri. Furthermore, the one who contradicted them has weakness regarding his memory. Thus, the likes of this, his hadith is not Hasan; rather it is Shadh (anomalous) or Munkar (denounced). The detail of this summary is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4010). 
2. Meaning he is a Mudallis [one who conceals his source]. And Iyas bin Muawiyah Al-Muzani is from the junior Tabi'in. Saying "may Allah be pleased with him" regarding him gives the illusion that he is from the Sahabah, so take note. The Three Commentators overlooked this, just as they ignored the Tadlis, so they said: "Hasan"!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 364 - (11) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I mentioned (1) the night prayer, so some of them said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Half of it, a third of it, a quarter of it, the interval between milking a she-camel (fuwaq), the interval between milking a sheep." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and its men are relied upon in "As-Sahih", and it is part of a hadith (2). (Fuwaq of a camel) with Damma on the Fa: Here it is the duration between lifting your hands from the udder during milking and bringing them back. 365 - (12) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas [also], may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, ordered the night prayer and encouraged it until he said: "Stick to the night prayer, even if it is one rak'ah." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat". 366 - (13) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The nobles of my Ummah are the carriers of the Quran, and the people of the night." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and Al-Bayhaqi. 367 - (14) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever among you prays at night, let him recite aloud; for the angels pray with his prayer
foot_note:
1. Thus in the original. In "Al-Majma'": "tadhakartu" (I recalled/discussed). In "Musnad Abu Ya'la" it is in a script that could be read both ways! And the copy is not good. In the manuscript: "dhakartu" (I mentioned), and perhaps that is correct. 
2. There is no basis for his saying: "and it is part of a hadith" as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3912). Furthermore, there is interruption in the chain because it is from the narration of (Bukair) (who is Ibn Abdullah Al-Ashajj, father of Makhramah), and they did not mention any narration for him from any of the Sahabah. Al-Hakim said: "His narration is only from the Tabi'in."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: and listen to his recitation. And the believing Jinn who are in the air, and his neighbors in his dwelling, pray with his prayer and listen to his recitation. And by his recitation, he drives away from his house and the houses around him the immoral Jinn and the rebellious devils. Indeed, the house in which the Quran is recited has a tent of light over it; the inhabitants of the heaven are guided by it just as one is guided by a shining star in the depths of the seas and in the barren land. When the companion of the Quran dies, that tent is raised. The angels look from the sky and do not see that light, so the angels receive him from heaven to heaven, and the angels pray for his soul among the souls. Then the guardian angels who were with him receive him, then the angels seek forgiveness for him until the Day of Resurrection. There is no man who learns the Book of Allah, then prays for an hour of the night, except that that past night advises the coming night to wake him for his hour, and to be light upon him. When he dies and his family is busy with his funeral preparation, the Quran comes in a handsome, beautiful form and stands at his head until he is wrapped in his shrouds; the Quran is then on his chest inside the shroud. When he is placed in his grave and covered, and his companions leave him, Munkar and Nakir come to him and make him sit in his grave. The Quran comes until it is between him and them. They say to it: 'Step aside so we can question him.' It says: 'No, by the Lord of the Kaaba! He is my companion and my close friend, and I will not forsake him in any condition. If you were commanded with something, proceed to what you were commanded and leave me in my place, for I will not leave him until I enter him into Paradise.' Then the Quran looks at its companion and says: 'I am the Quran which you used to recite aloud and recite silently, and you used to love me, so I am your beloved. And whoever I love, Allah loves him. After the questioning of Munkar and Nakir, you will have no worry nor grief.' So Munkar and Nakir question him and ascend. He and the Quran remain. It says: 'I will surely spread for you a soft bed, and I will surely cover you with a handsome, beautiful cover, for how you stayed awake for me during your night and exhausted yourself during your day.' -He said:- So the Quran ascends to the heaven faster than a glance, and asks Allah for that for him, so He gives it
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: that. Then a million angels from the near ones of the sixth heaven descend with it. The Quran comes and greets him, saying: 'Did you feel lonely? I have not ceased, since I left you, to speak to Allah the Blessed and Exalted until I took for you a bed, a cover, and a key, and I have come to you with it. So stand so the angels may spread it for you.' He said: 'So the angels raise him up gently, then his grave is expanded for him the distance of four hundred years. Then a bed is placed for him whose lining is green silk filled with musk of the finest scent. Pillows of Sundus and Istabraq (silk brocade) are placed at his feet and head. Two lamps of the light of Paradise are lit for him at his head and feet, shining until the Day of Resurrection. Then the angels lay him on his right side facing the Qibla. Then jasmine of Paradise is brought, and they ascend from him. He remains, he and the Quran. The Quran takes the jasmine and places it on his nose fresh, so he inhales it until he is resurrected. The Quran returns to his family and informs them (1) [of his news] every day and night, and checks on them as a compassionate father checks on his child with good. If anyone of his children learns the Quran, he gives him glad tidings of that. And if his offspring are bad offspring, he supplicates for their rectification and turning [to Allah], or as he mentioned."' Narrated by Al-Bazzar and he said: "Khalid bin Ma'dan did not hear from Mu'adh. Its meaning is that the reward of the Quran comes (2) as he said: 'Indeed the morsel comes on the Day of Resurrection like Uhud' (3), meaning its reward comes." End quote.
foot_note:
1. Original: (Fayujizuhum), and the correction is from the "Manuscript", "Kashf Al-Astar", and "Al-Bahr Az-Zakhar" (7/ 99). It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6821). 
2. This interpretation is questionable. See the coming commentary in "As-Sahih" in (9 - Book of Fasting / 1) Hadith of Ibn Amr: "Fasting and the Quran intercede..." 
3. I say: With this wording it is weak. Narrated by Ahmad (2/ 404). And from this mode At-Tirmidhi narrated it similarly, and it will come in "8 - Charity / 9 - Encouragement for Charity and Urging it".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: The Hafiz said: "In its chain is one whose condition is unknown, and in its text is much strangeness, rather apparent denouncability (nakarah). Al-Uqayli and others spoke about it." 368 - (15) [Fabricated] And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and others narrated it from Ubada bin as-Samit as Mawquf on him, and perhaps that is more likely. 369 - (16) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever spends a night light of food and drink, praying; the Hoor al-Ayn hover around him until he wakes up." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 370 - (17) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah does not disappoint a man who stands in the depth of the night and opens Surah {Al-Baqarah} and {Al Imran}." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and in its chain is Baqiyyah (1). 371 - (18) [Weak] And from Abu Ubaidah who said: Abdullah said: It is written in the Torah: Allah has prepared for those whose sides shun their beds what no eye has seen, no ear has heard, and has not crossed the heart of a human, nor does a near angel know it, nor a sent prophet. He said: And we recite it: {And no soul knows what has been hidden for them of comfort for eyes} [As-Sajdah: 17] The Verse. Narrated by Al-Hakim and he authenticated it.
foot_note: 1. I say: Baqiyyah is not mentioned in this hadith as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5064).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: The Hafiz said: "Abu Ubaidah did not hear from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, though it was said: he heard." 372 - (19) [Weak] And [meaning the hadith of Ibn Amr which is in "As-Sahih"] was narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" from this path also; except that he said: "And whoever stands with two hundred verses is written among the Muqantarin." His saying: (Among the Muqantarin) means: Among those for whom a Qintar of reward is written. 373 - (20) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "A Qintar is twelve thousand Uqiyyah. An Uqiyyah is better than what is between heaven and earth." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (1). 374 - (21) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever reads ten verses in a night is not written among the heedless. Whoever reads a hundred verses, the Qunut (devotion) of a night is written for him. Whoever reads two hundred verses is written among the Qanitin (devout). Whoever reads four hundred verses is written among the Abidin (worshippers). Whoever reads five hundred verses is written among the Hafizin (preservers). Whoever reads six hundred verses is written among the Khashi'in (humble). Whoever reads eight hundred verses is written among the Mukhbitin (submissive). And whoever reads a thousand verses, a Qintar becomes his. A Qintar is one thousand two hundred Uqiyyah, and an Uqiyyah is better than what is between heaven and earth—or he said: better than what the sun rises upon—. And whoever reads two thousand verses is among the Mujibin." Narrated by At-Tabarani. (Al-Mujib): One who performed an act that necessitates Paradise for him. It is also applied to one who performed an act that necessitates the Fire for him.
foot_note: 1. I say: Ibn Majah also narrated it, and Ahmad with a chain that has some issues which I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4076).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 375 - (22) [Denounced (Munkar)] And [the hadith of Abu Huraira which is in "As-Sahih"] was narrated by Al-Hakim, and his wording—which is also a narration of Ibn Khuzaymah—he said: "Whoever prays in a night with one hundred verses; is not written among the heedless. And whoever prays in a night with two hundred verses; is written among the sincere Qanitin (devout)." And Al-Hakim said: "Authentic on the condition of Muslim" (1). 12 - (Warning against a person praying and reciting while drowsy) [No hadith meeting the condition of our book was mentioned under it. See "As-Sahih"]
foot_note: 1. I say: This is an illusion, for Ibn Abi Az-Zinad was not relied upon by Muslim; rather, he narrated something from him in the Introduction. Furthermore, he has weakness. See "As-Sahihah" (642).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 13 - (Warning against a person sleeping until morning and abandoning any night prayer) 376 - (1) [Very Weak] At-Tabarani narrated in "Al-Awsat" the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud with the wording: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "When a servant intends to pray at night, an angel comes to him and says: Rise, for morning has come, so pray and remember your Lord. Then Satan comes to him and says: You have a long night, and you will rise! If he rises and prays; he enters the morning active, light of body, and cool of eye. And if he obeys Satan until morning; he [Satan] urinates in his ear." 377 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The mother of Solomon bin David said to Solomon: O my son! Do not sleep too much at night, for excessive sleep at night leaves a man poor on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Ibn Majah and Al-Bayhaqi, and in its chain is a possibility for improvement (Tahsin). 378 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed Allah hates every Ja'zari, Jawwaz, Sakhab in the markets, a corpse by night, a donkey by day, knowledgeable in the matter of the world, ignorant in the matter of the Hereafter." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Asbahani. The linguists said: "(Al-Ja'zari): The intensely angry/arrogant. (Al-Jawwaz): The glutton. (As-Sakhab): The shouter." End quote.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 14 - (Encouragement for verses and Adhkar one says when morning comes and when evening comes) 379 - (1) [Weak] And from Ma'qal bin Yasar from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever says when he enters the morning three times: (I seek refuge in Allah, the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing, from the accursed Satan), and reads three verses from the end of Surah {Al-Hashr}; Allah appoints for him seventy thousand angels, praying for him until he enters the evening. And if he dies on that day, he dies a martyr. And whoever says it when he enters the evening is in that same station." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from the narration of Khalid bin Tahman, and he said: "A Gharib Hadith." And in some copies: "Hasan Gharib" (1). 380 - (2) [Very Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace; that he said: "Whoever says when he enters the morning: {So exalted is Allah when you reach the evening and when you reach the morning (17) And to Him is [due all] praise throughout the heavens and the earth. And [exalted is He] at night and when you are at noon (18) He brings the living out of the dead and brings the dead out of the living and brings to life the earth after its lifelessness. And thus will you be brought out}; he attains what he missed in that day of his. And whoever says them when he enters the evening attains what he missed in his night." Narrated by Abu Dawood and he did not weaken it, but Al-Bukhari spoke about it in his "Tarikh". 381 - (3) [Denounced (Munkar)] And it was narrated from Hudhayfah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "He is not of us who swears by the Trust (Amanah), and he is not of us who betrays a Muslim man regarding his family and his servant (2). And whoever says when he enters the evening and when he enters the morning: (O Allah, I call You to witness that You are
foot_note:
1. I say: Perhaps it is an incorrect copy, for Adh-Dhahabi said in the biography of Khalid: "At-Tirmidhi did not classify it as Hasan, and it is a very Gharib hadith." 
2. Up to here the hadith is authentic from another narration, which will come in (17 - Marriage / 10 - Warning against turning a woman against her husband...).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Allah, there is no deity except You, alone with no partner for You, and that Muhammad is Your servant and Messenger. I acknowledge Your favor upon me, and I acknowledge my sin, so forgive me, for none forgives sins except You). If he says it on that day of his when he enters the morning and dies on that day before evening; he dies a martyr. And if he says it when he enters the evening and dies that night; he dies a martyr." Narrated by Abu Al-Qasim Al-Asbahani and others. 382 - (4) [Weak Mawquf] And from Umm Ad-Darda from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Whoever says when morning comes and when evening comes: {Sufficient for me is Allah; there is no deity except Him. On Him I have relied, and He is the Lord of the Great Throne} seven times; Allah will suffice him for what concerns him, whether he is truthful or lying. Narrated by Abu Dawood like this as Mawquf, and Ibn As-Sunni and others raised it (to the Prophet). It may be said: That the likes of this is not said based on opinion and reasoning, so its way is the way of the Marfu' (1). 383 - (5) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever says when he enters the morning or enters the evening: (O Allah, I have entered the morning calling You to witness, and calling the bearers of Your Throne, Your angels, and all of Your creation to witness; that You are Allah, there is no deity except You, and that Muhammad is Your servant and Messenger); Allah frees a quarter of him from the Fire. Whoever says it twice; Allah frees half of him from the Fire. Whoever says it three times, Allah frees three-quarters of him from the Fire. If he says it four times; Allah frees him from the Fire." Narrated by Abu Dawood and the wording is his, and At-Tirmidhi similarly and he said: "A Hasan Hadith" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: It is weak as Marfu' and as Mawquf, and its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5286). See the introduction to "As-Sahih" (p. 81) necessarily. 
2. I say: What is in the Bulaq and Homs editions is: "A Gharib Hadith"; meaning weak. And multiple scholars reported this from At-Tirmidhi, among them Al-Hafiz An-Naji, and this is what befits the condition of its chain.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And An-Nasa'i, and he added in it after "except You": "Alone with no partner for You." And At-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Awsat", and did not say: "Allah frees..." to the end, but said: "except that Allah forgives him whatever sin he committed in that day of his. If he says it when he enters the evening, Allah forgives him whatever he committed in that night of his." And it is like that in At-Tirmidhi. 384 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Salam—who is Mamtor Al-Habashi—: That he was in the mosque of (Hims) (1), and a man passed by him, so they said: This one served the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. So he stood up to him and said: Tell me a hadith you heard from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, which men did not circulate between you and him. He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever says when he enters the morning and when he enters the evening: (We are pleased with Allah as Lord, with Islam as religion, and with Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, as Messenger); except that it becomes a right upon Allah to please him." Narrated by Abu Dawood and the wording is his, and At-Tirmidhi from the narration of Abu Sa'd Sa'id bin Al-Marzuban from Abu Salamah from Thawban and he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith," and in some copies: "Hasan Sahih," which is far-fetched. And he has:
foot_note: 1. With Kasra on the unpointed Ha and Sukun on the Mim: A town in Sham. And his saying: (Khadama - served) in the active past tense. And his saying: (Men did not circulate it between you and him); in "As-Sihah": (Hands circulated it): This one took it once and this one once, meaning there was no intermediary of men between you and the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. And his saying: (We are pleased with Allah as Lord) includes pleasure with the legislative rulings and cosmic decrees. And Allah knows best.

text: "Whoever says when he enters the morning: (O Allah, whatever favor has come to me, or to any of Your creation, is from You alone with no partner for You; so for You is the praise, and for You is the gratitude); has performed the gratitude of his day. And whoever says the like of that when he enters the evening; has performed the gratitude of his night." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and An-Nasa'i and the wording is his. 386 - (8) [Weak] And Ibn Hibban narrated it in his "Sahih" from Ibn Abbas with his wording; without mentioning the evening, and perhaps it fell from my original (1). 387 - (9) [Weak] And from Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever glorifies Allah (Tasbih) a hundred times in the morning and a hundred times in the evening; is like one who performed Hajj a hundred times. Whoever praises Allah (Tahmid) a hundred times in the morning and a hundred times in the evening; is like one who provided a hundred horses in the path of Allah—or he said: fought a hundred battles in the path of Allah—. Whoever declares the oneness of Allah (Tahlil) a hundred times in the morning and a hundred times in the evening; is like one who freed a hundred slaves from the children of Ishmael. And whoever magnifies Allah (Takbir) a hundred times in the morning and a hundred times in the evening; no one will bring more on that day than what he brought; except one who said the like of what he said, or added to what he said." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from the narration of Abu Sufyan Al-Himyari—and his name is Sa'id bin Yahya—from Ad-Dahhak bin Hamzah, from Amr bin Shu'aib, and he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith." And Abu Sufyan, Ad-Dahhak, and Amr bin Shu'aib will be discussed later" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: There is no omission, for it is likewise in "Al-Ihsan" and "Al-Mawarid". His saying: (Ibn Abbas) is how it appeared in Ibn Hibban and others. It is a misspelling, the correct is (Ibn Ghannam), who is Abdullah Al-Bayadi mentioned previously, and the Three Ignorant Ones overlooked it! 
2. Here in "As-Sahih" there is what suffices for it, so refer to it.

O Allah, I ask You for satisfaction after the decree, the coolness of life after death, the pleasure of looking at Your Face, and a longing to meet You, without harmful adversity, nor misleading trial. And I seek refuge in You O Allah lest I oppress, or be oppressed, or transgress, or be transgressed against, or acquire a wrong or a sin You do not forgive. O Allah, Creator of the heavens and earth, Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, Possessor of Majesty and Honor. Indeed I covenant to You in this worldly life, and I call You to witness—and sufficient is Allah as a witness—that I testify that there is no deity except You, alone with no partner for You. To You belongs the dominion, and to You belongs the praise, and You are over all things competent. And I testify that Muhammad is Your servant and Messenger. And I testify that Your promise is truth, meeting You is truth, Paradise is truth, the Hour is coming with no doubt in it, and that You resurrect those in the graves. And that if You entrust me to myself, You entrust me to weakness, nakedness, sin, and wrong. And indeed I trust only in Your mercy, so forgive me all my sins, for indeed none forgives sins except You, and turn to me, indeed You are the Accepting of Repentance, the Merciful)." text: 410 - (2) [Weak] [At-Tirmidhi said]: Ahmad bin Abdah Ad-Dabbi told us: Abu Wahb (1) told us, saying: I asked Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak about the prayer in which Tasbih is done? Then he seeks refuge and reads: {In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful}, and {The Opening of the Book} and a Surah. Then he says ten times 25: (Glory be to Allah, and praise be to Allah, and there is no deity except Allah, and Allah is the Greatest). Then he bows and says it ten times 35. Then he raises his head and says it ten times 45. Then he prostrates and says it ten times 55. Then he raises his head and says it ten times 65. Then he prostrates the second time and says it ten times 75. He prays four rak'ahs like this. That is seventy-five Tasbihs in every rak'ah. He starts in every rak'ah with fifteen Tasbihs, then reads, then glorifies ten times. If he prays at night, I prefer that he makes Taslim in every two rak'ahs. If he prays by day, if he wishes he makes Taslim, and if he wishes he does not make Taslim. Abu Wahb said: Abdul Aziz—he is Ibn Abi Rizmah—informed me from Abdullah; that he said: He starts in the Ruku with (Glory be to my Lord the Great), and in the Sujud with (Glory be to my Lord the Most High) (three times), then he glorifies the Tasbihs. text: 19 - (Encouragement for the Prayer of Need and its Supplication). 415 - (1) [Weak Mawquf] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the Marfu' Hadith of Uthman bin Hunaif which is in "As-Sahih"] and mentioned a story at its beginning, which is: That a man used to visit Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, for a need of his, and Uthman would not pay attention to him nor look into his need. So he met Uthman bin Hunaif and complained about that to him. Uthman bin Hunaif said to him: Go to the place of ablution and perform ablution, then come to the mosque and pray two rak'ahs in it, then say: (O Allah, I ask You and turn to You by our Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, the Prophet of Mercy. O Muhammad! I turn by you to my Lord so that He may fulfill my need), and mention your need. Then come to me so that I may go with you. So the man went and did what he told him, then came to Uthman's door. The doorman came and took him by the hand and admitted him to Uthman bin Affan, and seated him with him on the carpet (Tunfusah), and said: What is your need? So he mentioned his need, and he fulfilled it for him. Then he said: I did not remember your need until this hour. And he said: Whatever need you have, come to us. Then the man left his presence and met Uthman bin Hunaif and said to him: May Allah reward you with good; he was not looking into my need nor paying attention to me until you spoke to him regarding me. Uthman bin Hunaif said: By Allah, I did not speak to him, but I witnessed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when a blind man came to him and complained to him about the loss of his sight. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to him: "Or will you be patient?" He said: O Messenger of Allah! I have no guide and it has become difficult for me. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to him: "Go to the place of ablution and perform ablution, then pray two rak'ahs, then supplicate with these supplications."

Since At-Tabarani's narration contains two stories; one Marfu', which is the story of the blind man with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and the other Mawquf, which is the story of the man with Uthman bin Hunaif, then with Uthman bin Affan; since the matter is as we clarified, At-Tabarani's authentication of the Hadith must be interpreted as applying to the Marfu' part of it, excluding the Mawquf. It is as if the author, may Allah have mercy on him, indicated this by presenting before the mentioned authentication his saying: "after mentioning its paths", to draw attention to what I clarified on one hand, and because if he had not said that, the reader's illusion would have gone to thinking that the intent is this complete Hadith containing the Mawquf. Supporting the interpretation of At-Tabarani's words as referring to the Marfu' is that the path of his narration contains a defect which I clarified in my printed treatise: "At-Tawassul: Its Types and Rulings". As for the three ignorant ones, they did not differentiate between the two stories - as is their habit - so they authenticated both of them without differentiating between them! And similar things have preceded from them!

text: 7 - Book of Friday 1 - (Encouragement for Friday Prayer and Hastening to it, and What Came regarding the Virtue of its Day and its Hour). 421 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever performs Ghusl on Friday, then wears from his best clothes, and touches perfume if he has it, then walks to the Friday prayer bearing tranquility, and does not step over anyone, nor harm him, then bows what is decreed for him, then waits until the Imam leaves; what is between the two Fridays is forgiven for him" (1). Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani from the narration of Harb from Abu Darda, and he did not hear from him. 422 - (2) [Weak] And from Ata Al-Khurasani who said: Nubaishah Al-Hudhali, may Allah be pleased with him, used to narrate from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: "Indeed, if a Muslim performs Ghusl on Friday, then comes to the mosque, harming no one, then if he does not find the Imam has come out; he prays what appears to him. And if he finds the Imam has come out; he sits, listens and remains silent, until the Imam finishes his Friday prayer and his speech. If all his sins are not forgiven in that Friday of his, it will be an expiation for the Friday (2) that follows it."

2. Original: "The Friday", and what I established is from "Al-Musnad", and perhaps it is more correct. Then I became certain of that by its agreement with the manuscript (81/ 1).

text: Narrated by Ahmad, and Ata did not hear from Nubaishah as far as I know. 423 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Atiq of Abu Bakr As-Siddiq and from Imran bin Husain, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever performs Ghusl on Friday; his sins and wrongdoings are expiated from him. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat", and in "Al-Awsat" also from Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, alone, and he said in it: "He had for every step the deed of twenty years." 424 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Lubabah bin Abdul-Mundhir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed Friday is the master of days, and the greatest of them with Allah. There is no angel near to Allah, nor sky, nor earth, nor winds, nor mountains, nor sea; except that they fear Friday." Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Majah with one wording. So whoever is close to the Imam and listens and is silent and does not engage in idle talk; he has two shares of reward. Whoever is far and listens and is silent and does not engage in idle talk; he has one share of reward. Whoever is close to the Imam and engages in idle talk and does not listen and is not silent; upon him are two shares of burden. Whoever says: 'Hush', has spoken, and whoever speaks has no Friday." Then he said: Thus I heard your Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say. Narrated by Ahmad and this is his wording, and Abu Dawud, and his wording is: "When it is Friday, devils go early with their banners to the markets, throwing obstacles (Tarabith) or delays (Rabayith) at people, and hindering them from Friday. And the angels go early and sit at
foot_note:
1. From (Rabbatha Yurabbithu) with Ba Muwahhadah in the middle of the verb, not with Ya Muthannah Taht as Mustafa Amarah restricted it in his commentary saying: (Yurayyithun): delaying. From it is the Hadith: Gabriel, peace be upon him, promised the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, to come to him, but he was slow (Ratha) upon him. Meaning he delayed." The three commentators imitated him, even though they attributed it to Ahmad (1/ 93) and it is with Ba Muwahhadah therein!! I say: This is from their many illusions and numerous distortions, while the upcoming explanation of the author and what he quoted from Al-Khattabi protects them from such an illusion! (Ar-Rabayith) with Ra and Ba Muwahhadah then Alif and Ya Muthannah Taht followed by Tha Muthallathah; plural of (Rabithah): which is the matter that holds a person back from his destination and hinders him from it. Its meaning: that devils occupy them and hinder them from striving to Friday until the virtuous times pass. Al-Khattabi said: "(At-Tarabith) is nothing, it is only (Ar-Rabayith) (1). And his saying: (throwing at people) is only: (delaying people). He said: And thus it was narrated to us in other than this Hadith" (2). And his saying: (Sah) with Sukun on Ha, and it is broken with Tanween: It is a word of rebuke for the speaker; meaning: Be silent. I say: He is a Tabi'i not known except from the narration of Abu Az-Zubayr from him, as derived from "Al-Jarh wat-Ta'dil" (3/ 1/ 305) and "Thiqat Ibn Hibban" (3/ 132 - 133). Based on this, the Hadith is Mursal, so his saying: "That they came" means his people, and likewise his saying: "He said to us". Meaning to his people. So take note.
