text: 460 - (9) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Whoever believes in Allah and His Messenger let him pay the Zakat of his wealth. And whoever believes in Allah and His Messenger let him say good or keep silent. And whoever believes in Allah and His Messenger and the Last Day (1) let him honor his guest." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 461 - (10) [Weak] And from Ubayd bin Umair Al-Laythi from his father who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said in the Farewell Pilgrimage: "Indeed the allies (Awliya) of Allah are those who pray, and who establish the five prayers which Allah has prescribed upon him, and fast Ramadan, and anticipate the reward of his fast, and pay Zakat seeking reward willingly, and avoid the major sins which Allah has forbidden." A man from his companions said: O Messenger of Allah! And how many are the major sins? He said: "Nine: The greatest of them is associating partners with Allah, killing a believer without right, fleeing from the battlefield, slandering a chaste woman, magic, consuming the orphan's wealth, consuming usury, disobeying Muslim parents, and violating the Sacred House, your Qiblah living and dead. No man dies not committing these major sins, and establishes prayer, and pays Zakat, except that he accompanies Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in the midst of Paradise whose doors are golden panels." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and its narrators are trustworthy (2), and there is discussion about some of them. Abu Dawud has part of it. (Buhbuhat Al-Jannah) with Damma on both Ba's and both Ha's Muhmalah: is its center.
foot_note:
1. Thus the original with the addition: (and the Last Day), and it is in "Al-Majma" in the second phrase. The three imitators relied on it without any verification, and it has no basis at all with At-Tabarani! It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5288). 
2. I say: Thus he said, and he graded it Hasan in what will come in (12 Jihad / 11), and the three commentators imitated him. Despite this, Al-Bukhari said about him: "Fihi Nazar" (He is questionable). It is documented in "Al-Irwa" (5/ 25), and parts of it have witnesses. See "Al-Fath" (12/ 182).

text: 464 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The first three to enter Paradise were displayed to me, and the first three to enter the Fire. He said: Who are these O Gabriel! 2. I say: It contains the 'an'ana of Al-Hasan Al-Basri, and below him is (Ismail bin Muslim) and he is Al-Makki; weak. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5552). As for the three ignorant ones, they mixed - as is their habit - between the Sahih of this hadith and the Da'if of it, so they prefaced it with their saying: "Sahih.."!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Shall I give you more?", he said: Yes. He said: "Keep [it] for those after you." Then he called me and scooped for me. So I said: O Messenger of Allah! Is it good for me or bad for me? He said: "No, rather bad for you." So I returned to him what he gave me, then I said: No, by the One in Whose Hand is my soul, I will not accept a gift from anyone after you. - Muhammad bin Sirin said: - Hakim said: So I said: O Messenger of Allah! Supplicate to Allah to bless me. He said: "O Allah bless him in the deal of his hand." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 492 - (5) [Weak] And from Ibn Abi Mulaikah who said: Perhaps the rein would fall from the hand of Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him), so he would strike the arm of his she-camel, make it kneel, and pick it up. He said: So they said to him: Why didn't you order us so we could hand it to you? He said: Indeed my beloved (Hibbi) (PBUH) commanded me not to ask people for anything. Narrated by Ahmad, and Ibn Abi Mulaikah did not meet Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him). (Al-Khitam) with Kasra on the dotted Kha: Is what is placed on the nose and mouth of the she-camel to lead it. 493 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Who will pledge allegiance?". So Thawban, the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), said: We pledge allegiance to you O Messenger of Allah: He said: "Upon that you do not ask anyone for anything." Thawban said: So what is for him O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Paradise", so Thawban pledged allegiance to him.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Abu Umamah said: I saw him in Makkah in the largest gathering of people, his whip would fall while he was riding, and perhaps it fell on a man's shoulder, so the man would take it to hand it to him, but he would not take it from him, until he himself would dismount and take it. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" via the path of Ali bin Yazid from Al-Qasim from Abu Umamah. 494 - (7) [Weak] (*) And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the hadith of Abdur-Rahman bin Awf which is in "As-Sahih"] in "As-Saghir" from the hadith of Umm Salamah, and he said in his hadith: "And no man pardoned an injustice; except that Allah increased him in honor by it, so pardon and Allah will honor you." And the rest is similar. 495 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The first three to enter Paradise were shown to me, and the first three to enter the Fire. As for the first three to enter Paradise, they are the Martyr, a owned slave who perfected the worship of his Lord and was sincere to his master, and a chaste abstinent one with dependents." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and it passed in full in "Withholding Zakat" [2 - Chapter]. 496 - (9) [Weak] And from Abu Salamah bin Abdur-Rahman bin Awf from his father (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I had a promise from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), so when Quraizah was conquered, I came so he would fulfill for me what he promised me, and I heard him say: "Whoever seeks sufficiency Allah enriches him, and whoever is content Allah satisfies him". So I said to myself: Undoubtedly I will not ask him for anything. Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and Abu Salamah did not hear from his father. Ibn Ma'in and others said so. 497 - (10) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said:
foot_note: 1. (*) The preparer of the book for Shamela said: This ruling fell from the printed version, and Sheikh Mashhoor established it in his edition of At-Targhib, and said: «We established it from the originals of the Sheikh - may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him-»

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "The hands are three: The Hand of Allah is the highest, and the hand of the giver is the one that follows it, and the hand of the beggar is the lowest until the Day of Resurrection. So abstain from begging and from asking as much as you can. If you are given something - or he said: good - let it be seen on you, and start with whom you support, and give from the surplus, and you are not blamed for sufficiency (Kafaf)" (1). Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and most of its narrators are documented. And Al-Hakim narrated it, and authenticated its chain (2). 498 - (11) [Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Beware of greed; for it is poverty. And beware of what requires apology." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" (3). 499 - (12) [Weak] And from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: A man came to the Prophet (PBUH), and said: O Messenger of Allah! Advise me and be brief. So the Prophet (PBUH) said: "You must have despair of what is in the hands of people, and beware of greed; for it is present poverty, and beware of what requires apology" (4). Narrated by Al-Hakim, and Al-Baihaqi in the book "Az-Zuhd" and the wording is his, and Al-Hakim said: "Sahih Al-Isnad". So he said. 500 - (13) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Contentment is a treasure that does not perish."
foot_note:
1. In "Al-Majma'" (3/ 97) it appeared as: (Al-'Afaf - Chastity), and it is a distortion. 
2. I say: From it in its chain is Ibrahim bin Muslim Al-Hajari, and he is lenient in Hadith, and Al-Hakim does not have the last sentence of it. 
3. I say: But the second half of it is established from the hadith of Anas and others as you see it extracted and verified in "As-Sahihah" number (354 and 401 and 1421). 
4. See "As-Sahih" here; so you know that most of it is Sahih due to others.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Al-Baihaqi in "Book of Zuhd", and its raising (to the Prophet) is Gharib (1). 501 - (14) [Weak] And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him): That a man from the Ansar came to the Prophet (PBUH) and asked him. He said: "Is there nothing in your house?". He said: Yes, a Hils (cloth) we wear part of it and spread part of it, and a Qa'b (cup) we drink water in. He said: "Bring them to me", so he brought them to him. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) took them in his hand and said: "Who will buy these two?" The man said: I will take them for a Dirham. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Who will increase upon a Dirham?" (two or three times). A man said: I will take them for two Dirhams. So he gave them to him, and took the two Dirhams and gave them to the Ansari, and said: "Buy food with one of them, and throw it to your family, and buy an adze (Qaddum) with the other, and bring it to me." So he brought it to him, and the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) tied a stick to it with his hand, then said: "Go and gather firewood, and sell, and let me not see you for fifteen days." So he did, and came having earned ten Dirhams, so he bought a garment with some and food with some. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "This is better for you than that begging comes as a spot on your face on the Day of Resurrection..." (2). Narrated by Abu Dawood, and Al-Baihaqi at length, and the wording is Abu Dawood's. At-Tirmidhi and An-Nasa'i extracted from it the story of selling firewood only, and At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Hadith". (Al-Hils) with Kasra on the un-dotted Ha and Sukun on Lam and with un-dotted Sin: is a thick cloth that is on the back of the camel, and others that are trodden upon and used like clothing and the like were named after it.
foot_note:
1. I say: In its chain (88/ 104) is a Matruk accused narrator, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3907). 
2. The completion of the hadith is established; see it in "As-Sahih" here (Hadith 43). As for the ignorant ones, they did not differentiate - as is their habit - between what is authentic of it and what is not, so they said: "Hasan.."!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 5 - (Encouragement for one whom poverty or need befalls to entrust it to Allah Almighty) . 502 - (1) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever goes hungry or is in need and conceals it from people, and confides it to Allah Almighty; it is a right upon Allah to open for him a year's sustenance from lawful means." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat". 6 - (Discouragement from taking what is given without the giver's good will) . [There is no hadith under it according to the condition of our book. See "As-Sahih"]
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 7 - (Encouragement for one to whom something comes without asking or longing of the soul to accept it, especially if he is needy, and the prohibition of rejecting it even if he is rich) . 503 - (1) [Weak] And from Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah bin Hantab: That Abdullah bin Amir sent a stipend and clothing to Aisha (may Allah be pleased with them both). She said to the messenger: O my son! I do not accept anything from anyone. When the messenger left she said: Return him to me. So they returned him. She said: I remembered something, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said to me: "O Aisha! Whoever gives you a gift without asking, accept it, for it is only provision Allah has sent to you." Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Baihaqi, and Ahmad's narrators are trustworthy, but At-Tirmidhi said: "Muhammad - meaning Al-Bukhari - said: I do not know of any hearing for Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah from any of the Companions of the Prophet (PBUH) except his saying: 'One who witnessed the sermon of the Prophet (PBUH) told me', and I heard Abdullah bin Abdur-Rahman say: We do not know of any hearing for Al-Muttalib from any of the Companions of the Prophet (PBUH)." (The Dictator said) may Allah be pleased with him: "He narrated from Abu Hurairah. As for Aisha; Abu Hatim said: Al-Muttalib did not meet Aisha. And Abu Zur'ah said: Trustworthy, I hope he heard from Aisha. So if Al-Muttalib heard from Aisha then the chain is connected, otherwise the messenger to her is not named. And Allah knows best." 504 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The giver from abundance is not better than the taker, if he is needy." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 505 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (PBUH) said: "The one who gives from abundance is not greater in reward than the one who accepts if he is needy." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Ibn Hibban in "Ad-Du'afa".
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 8 - (Discouragement for the asker to ask by the Face of Allah for anything other than Paradise, and discouragement for the one asked by the Face of Allah to refuse) . 506 - (1) [Weak] And from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Nothing is asked by the Face of Allah except Paradise." Narrated by Abu Dawood and others (1). 507 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Shall I tell you about Al-Khidr?". They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "While he was walking one day in the market of the Children of Israel, a Mukatab (slave seeking freedom) saw him and said: Give charity to me, may Allah bless you. Al-Khidr said: I believe in Allah, whatever Allah wills happens, I have nothing to give you. The poor man said: I ask you by the Face of Allah to give charity to me; for I saw tolerance in your face, and hoped for blessing with you. Al-Khidr said: I believe in Allah, I have nothing to give you except that you take me and sell me. The poor man said: Is this right? He said: Yes; I say: You have asked me by a great matter, indeed I will not disappoint you by the Face of my Lord, sell me. He said: So he brought him to the market and sold him for four hundred Dirhams. He stayed with the buyer for a time not using him for anything. He said: You bought me only seeking good from me, so order me with work. He said: I hate to burden you, you are a weak old man. He said: It does not burden me. He said: Stand and move these stones. And they could not be moved by less than six people in a day. So the man went out for some of his need then returned
foot_note: 1. I say: In its chain (1671) is Sulaiman bin Mu'adh At-Tamimi, and he is Ibn Qarm bin Sulaiman, weak due to bad memory, "Al-Mishkat" (1944), "Da'if Abi Dawood" (297).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: and he had moved the stones in an hour! He said: You have done well and beautifully, and you were capable of what I did not think you were capable of. He said: Then a journey presented itself to the man, so he said: I consider you trustworthy so take my place in my family a good replacement. He said: And order me with work. He said: I hate to burden you. He said: It does not burden me. He said: Make bricks for my house, until I return to you. He said: So the man went on his journey. He said: The man returned and he had constructed a building. He said: I ask you by the Face of Allah what is your way and what is your affair? He said: You asked me by the Face of Allah, and the Face of Allah threw me into this slavery. Al-Khidr said: I will tell you who I am? I am Al-Khidr whom you heard of. A poor man asked me for charity and I had nothing to give him. So he asked me by the Face of Allah, so I enabled him over my neck, and he sold me. And I tell you that whoever is asked by the Face of Allah and rejects his asker while he is able; will stand on the Day of Resurrection as skin with no flesh rattling. The man said: I believe in Allah, I burdened you O Prophet of Allah! And I did not know. He said: No harm, you did well and perfected. The man said: May my father and mother be sacrificed for you O Prophet of Allah! Judge in my family and wealth as you wish, or choose so I may clear your way. He said: I love that you clear my way so I can worship my Lord. So he cleared his way. Al-Khidr said: Praise be to Allah who bound me in slavery, then saved me from it". Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and others besides At-Tabarani, and some of our Sheikhs graded its chain Hasan, but it has remoteness (Bu'd). And Allah knows best.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 9 - (Encouragement for Charity and urging it, and what was reported regarding the effort of the one with little, and one who gives charity from what he does not love) . 558 - (1) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Barzah Al-Aslami (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed the servant gives charity with a crumb; it grows with Allah, Mighty and Majestic, until it becomes like Uhud." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 509 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed Allah, Mighty and Majestic, admits by a morsel of bread and a handful (Qabsah) of dates, and the like of that which benefits the poor person, three into Paradise: The master of the house who ordered it, the wife who prepares it, and the servant who hands it to the poor person." So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Praise be to Allah who did not forget our servants." Narrated by Al-Hakim, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and the wording is his in a hadith that will come in full if Allah wills (1). (Al-Qabsah) with Fatha on Qaf and Damma and Sukun on Ba and with un-dotted Sad: Is what the taker takes with the tips of his three fingers. 510 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas raising it (to the Prophet) he said: "Charity never decreased wealth, and no servant extended his hand with charity except that it was placed in the Hand of Allah before it fell into the hand of the beggar, and no servant opened a door of begging while he has no need for it except that Allah opened a door of poverty for him" (2).
foot_note:
1. Its beginning is: "Compete in archery and ride..", and the place where the author would include it is (12 - Jihad/ 8 - Encouragement for Archery), and he did not include it there nor in other chapters of Jihad, but he repeated it without its completion in what follows here (17 - Chapter). 
2. I say: I only included it here because of the middle sentence, otherwise its two ends are Sahih with their witnesses, so see them in "As-Sahih", the first end in the Chapter here, and the other in Chapter (4).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani. 511 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) addressed us and said: "O people! Repent to Allah before you die, and hasten to good deeds before you become occupied, and connect what is between you and your Lord by frequently remembering Him, and frequent charity in secret and public; you will be provided for, helped, and restored." Narrated by Ibn Majah in a hadith that passed in "Jumu'ah" [7/ 6 - Chapter]. 512 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) on the steps of the pulpit saying: "Guard against the Fire even with half a date, for it straightens the crooked, and repels an evil death, and falls for the hungry person in the position it falls for the satiated one." Narrated by Abu Ya'la and Al-Bazzar. And this hadith (1) has been narrated from Anas, Abu Hurairah, Abu Umamah, An-Nu'man bin Bashir and others from the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them). 513 - (6) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed charity extinguishes the anger of the Lord, and repels an evil death." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith" (2).
foot_note:
1. Meaning the first half of it, and it is in "As-Sahih", and Al-Haythami extracted it from them in "Al-Majma'" (3/ 105 - 106). 
2. The word (Hasan) did not appear in some copies of At-Tirmidhi, and it is more appropriate for the condition of its chain, for it has two defects, and their explanation is in "Al-Irwa" (3/ 390 - 391), and likewise in the hadith of Ibn Al-Mubarak, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5308).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: [Weak] And Ibn Al-Mubarak narrated in "Book of Birr" its last half, and its wording is: "Indeed Allah repels by charity seventy doors of evil death." (Yadra'u) with un-dotted Dal; meaning: repels (yadfa'u), its measure and meaning. 514 - (7) [Weak Mawquf] And from Malik (may Allah have mercy on him); that it reached him from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): That a poor person asked her while she was fasting, and there was nothing in her house except a loaf of bread, so she said to a freed maid of hers: Give it (1) to him. She said: You have nothing to break your fast with. She said: Give it (1) to him. She said: So I did. When evening came, a household or person who used to gift us, gifted us a sheep and its covering (kafan) (2), so Aisha called her and said: Eat from this, this is better than your disk (loaf). 515 - (8) [Weak Mawquf] Malik said: And it reached me: That a poor person asked Aisha, Mother of the Believers (may Allah be pleased with her), for food, and in front of her were grapes, so she said to a person: Take a grain and give it to him, so he started looking at her and wondering. Aisha said: Do you wonder? How many atoms' weights do you see in this grain? He mentioned it in "Al-Muwatta" like this as Balaghan (reached him) without a chain. His saying: (wa kafanuha) meaning: what covers it of food and the like. 516 - (9) [Weak] And from Al-Hasan who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said in what he narrates from his Lord, Mighty and Majestic; that He says: "O son of Adam! Deposit from your treasure with Me, no burning, no drowning, no stealing; I will give it back to you (uwaffikahu) when you are most in need of it".
foot_note:
1. The original in both places: (A'tiha - give her), and the correction is from "Al-Muwatta", and see "Al-Ujalah" (110/ 2). 
2. It was said in "Al-Mashariq": It was said: What covers it of disks and loaves.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Al-Baihaqi (1), and said: "This is Mursal". 517 - (10) [Weak] And it was narrated from Maimunah bint Sa'd; that she said: O Messenger of Allah! Give us a fatwa about charity. He said: "It is a barrier from the Fire for whoever seeks reward by it; seeking the Face of Allah, Mighty and Majestic". Narrated by At-Tabarani. 518 - (11) [Weak] And from Buraydah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "No man brings out anything from charity except that he loosens the two jaws (Lahya) (2) of seventy devils from it." Narrated by Ahmad, Al-Bazzar, At-Tabarani, and Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and he hesitated regarding the hearing of Al-A'mash from [Ibn] (3) Buraydah, and Al-Hakim and Al-Baihaqi, and Al-Hakim said: "Sahih according to their condition". 519 - (12) [Weak Mawquf] And Al-Baihaqi also narrated it from Abu Dharr as Mawquf on him, he said: No charity came out except that it loosens the two jaws (Lahya) (4) of seventy devils, all of them forbidding from it.
foot_note:
1. The original: "At-Tabarani and Al-Baihaqi", and what is established is from my two manuscripts. And in "Shu'ab Al-Baihaqi" (3/ 211): "Awda' (Deposit)" instead of: "Afrigh (Empty/Deposit)", and perhaps it is more correct. 
2. Dual of (Al-Lahya): And it appeared in the original (Lahya) in singular form, and the correction is from "Al-Musnad" and "Al-Mustadrak". It was said in "Al-Lisan": "(Al-Luhyan): The two walls of the mouth, and they are the two bones in which the teeth are from inside the mouth of every jawed creature". 
3. Dropped from the original, and I recovered it from the sources of extraction, and the three commentators neglected it - as is their habit - yet they graded its chain Hasan!! And it is interrupted, extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" with the Athar of Abu Dharr after it (6823). 
4. The original: (Lahya), and in the edition of the ignorant three (Lihya)! See the comment before it.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 520 - (13) [Very Weak] And from Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! What do you say about Prayer? He said: "The perfection of work". [I said: O Messenger of Allah! I ask you about Charity? He said: "Charity is a wondrous thing"]. (1) I said: O Messenger of Allah! You left the best deed in my soul or the best of it. He said: "What is it?". I said: Fasting. He said: "It is good; but not that". I said: O Messenger of Allah! And which Charity - and he mentioned a word - I said: What if I cannot? He said: "From the surplus of your food". I said: What if I do not do it? He said: "With half a date". I said: What if I do not do it? He said: "With a good word". I said: What if I do not do it? He said: "Leave people be from evil, for it is a charity you give to yourself". I said: What if I do not do it? He said: "Do you want to leave nothing of good in you?!". Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and the wording is his (2), and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" longer than it, and Al-Hakim and his wording will come if Allah the Exalted wills.
foot_note:
1. Dropped from the original, and I recovered it from "Kashf Al-Astar" (1/ 446). 
2. I say: Despite the severe weakness of its chain, it contains Munkar wordings; contrary to the narration of Ibn Hibban and Al-Hakim coming in "As-Sahih" (21 - Legal Punishments/ 1), and similar to it is the narration of Al-Baihaqi here in "As-Sahih" as well.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 521 - (14) [Weak] And it was narrated from Rafi' bin Khadij (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Charity blocks seventy doors of evil". Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 522 - (15) [Very Weak] And from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Give charity early; for calamity does not step over charity". Narrated by Al-Baihaqi as Marfu' and Mawquf on Anas, and perhaps it is more likely. 523 - (16) [Weak] And from him, he said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Give charity; for charity is your ransom from the Fire". Narrated by Al-Baihaqi via the path of Al-Harith bin Umair from Humaid from him. 524 - (17) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ali bin Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Give charity early, for calamity does not step over it". Narrated by At-Tabarani, and Razin mentioned it in his "Jami'", and it is not in any of the original sources. 525 - (18) [Weak] And from Rafi' bin Makith - and he was among those who witnessed Al-Hudaibiyah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Good treatment (Malakah) (1) is increase, and bad character is bad omen, and righteousness is increase in life, and charity extinguishes sin, and protects from an evil death". Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and it contains a man not named, and Abu Dawood narrated part of it.
foot_note: 1. It is said: So-and-so has good Malakah, if he is good in treatment to his slaves. "Nihayah".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 526 - (19) [Very Weak] And from Amr bin Awf (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed the charity of the Muslim increases life, prevents an evil death, and Allah removes arrogance and pride by it". Narrated by At-Tabarani via the path of Kathir bin Abdullah from his father from his grandfather Amr bin Awf. And At-Tirmidhi graded it Hasan, and Ibn Khuzaimah authenticated it for other than this text. 527 - (20) [Very Munkar] And from Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "A worshipper from the Children of Israel worshipped Allah in his hermitage for sixty years, then the earth rained and became green, so the monk looked out from his hermitage and said: If I went down and remembered Allah I would increase in good, so he went down with a loaf of bread or two loaves. While he was on the ground a woman met him, and he kept talking to her and she talking to him until he covered her (intercourse), then he fainted. He went down to the pond to bathe, and a beggar came, so he gestured to him to take the two loaves, then he died. The worship of sixty years was weighed against that adultery, so the adultery outweighed his good deeds, then the loaf or two loaves were placed with his good deeds, so his good deeds outweighed, and he was forgiven". Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (1). 528 - (21) [Sahih due to others] And from Al-Mughirah bin Abdullah Al-Ju'fi who said: We sat with a man from the companions of the Prophet (PBUH) called: Khasafah [or] (2) Ibn Khasafah, and he started looking at a fat man, so I said: What are you looking at? He said: I remembered
foot_note:
1. I say: It is most likely from the Isra'iliyyat, and it contains a man whom no one documented except Ibn Hibban, and Al-Uqaili weakened him, and it has been authenticated as Mawquf on Ibn Mas'ud, and it is in this chapter of "As-Sahih". 
2. See "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: a hadith I heard from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), I heard him say: "Do you know what is the strong one (Ash-Shadid)?". We said: The man who wrestles the man down. He said: "Indeed the strong one, the truly strong one: Is the man who controls himself in anger. Do you know what is the Raqub?". We said: The man who has no children born to him. He said: "Indeed the Raqub: Is the man who has children, but he did not send forth any of them (died before him)" (1). Then he said: [Weak] "Do you know what is the Su'luk (Destitute)?". He said: We said: The man who has no wealth. He said: "Indeed the Su'luk, the complete Su'luk; is the one who has wealth but did not send forth any of it". Narrated by Al-Baihaqi, and its chain should be looked into (2). (Al-Hafiz said): "And it will come if Allah the Exalted wills in 'Book of Clothing': 'Chapter on Charity to the Poor with what he wears' [18/ 8].
foot_note:
1. Up to here the hadith is Sahih due to others as will be explained here. 
2. I say: I have done so and found it to be a dark chain, Ahmad extracted it in his Musnad as well and Al-Khatib in "Al-Muttafaq" via the path of Shu'bah from Yazid bin Khasafah from Al-Mughirah bin Abdullah Al-Ju'fi with it, and this is a dark chain, containing three defects: First and Second: The ignorance (Jahalah) of this Al-Mughirah and Yazid bin Khasafah, and Third: The Idtirab (disturbance) in its chain, for Ahmad said: Muhammad bin Ja'far told us: Shu'bah told us said: I heard Urwah bin Abdullah Al-Ju'fi narrating from Ibn Hasbah or Abu Hasbah from a man who witnessed the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) delivering a sermon and said: so he mentioned it. And this is more correct, because all its men are trustworthy; except Ibn Hasbah or Abu Hasbah, and it shows that he is not a Companion, but rather an unknown man as preceded, so he is the defect of the hadith. But it has a witness from Ibn Mas'ud similarly without the issue of the Su'luk. Muslim extracted it (8/ 30) and Ahmad (1/ 382 - 383), and for that reason I included it also in the other book without it. And the author will mention from the hadith the issue of (Ash-Shadid) in (23 - Etiquette/ 10 - Discouragement from Anger). As for the ignorant three, they graded the hadith Hasan while quoting from Al-Haythami the ignorance of (Khasafah)!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 10 - (Encouragement regarding secret charity) . 529 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "When Allah created the earth it started to shake and overturn (1), so He anchored it with mountains and it stabilized. The angels marveled at the strength of the mountains, and said: O our Lord! Have You created a creation stronger than the mountains? He said: Yes, Iron. They said: Have You created a creation stronger than Iron? He said: Fire. They said: Have You created a creation stronger than Fire? He said: Water. They said: Have You created a creation stronger than Water? He said: Wind. They said: Have You created a creation stronger than Wind? He said: The son of Adam; if he gives charity with his right hand and hides it from his left". Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and Al-Baihaqi and others, and At-Tirmidhi said: "A Gharib Hadith". 530 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: ". . . And the first to enter Paradise are the people of Ma'ruf (Goodness/Kindness)". Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" (2). 531 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him): That Abu Dharr said: O Messenger of Allah! What is Charity? He said: "Multiplied multiples, and with Allah is the increase", then he recited: {Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan so He may multiply it for him many times over}.
foot_note:
1. (Mada, Yamidu): If it moved and tilted. And (Takaffa'u): Overturn. 
2. This hadith has come scattered in hadiths, without the sentence established here, for I have not found a valid witness for it until now, so whoever finds it let him move it there.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: It was said: O Messenger of Allah! Which charity is best? He said: "A secret to a poor person, or the effort of one with little", then he recited {If you disclose acts of charity, then it is well} the verse. Narrated by Ahmad at length, and At-Tabarani and the wording is his, and in their chains is Ali bin Yazid. 532 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Prophet (PBUH) said: "Three Allah loves, and three Allah hates. As for those He loves; a man came to a people and asked them by Allah, and did not ask them by a kinship between him and them; but they prevented him, then a man lagged behind them and gave him secretly, no one knowing of his gift except Allah, and the one he gave. And a people traveled their night; until when sleep became more beloved to them than what is equal to it, they laid down their heads, so he stood flattering Me and reciting My verses. And a man was in a detachment (Sariyyah) and met the enemy and they were defeated, so he advanced with his chest until he is killed or victory is granted to him. And the three whom Allah hates: The old adulterer, the arrogant poor, and the unjust rich". Narrated by Abu Dawood, Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and the wording is theirs; except that Ibn Khuzaimah did not say "they prevented him", and An-Nasa'i and At-Tirmidhi, he mentioned it in "Chapter on the speech of Al-Hur Al-Ein", and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; except that he said at its end: "And He hates the old adulterer, the miser, and the arrogant". And Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad" (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: In it with all of them is a man not known, and its attribution to Abu Dawood has a view as I clarified in the original. See "Al-Mishkat" (1922) and the comment on Ibn Khuzaimah (4/ 104).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 11 - (Encouragement for Charity to the spouse and relatives and prioritizing them over others) . 533 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed charity to a relative is doubled in reward two times". Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" via the path of Ubaydullah bin Zahr (1). 12 - (Discouragement for a person to be asked by his freed slave or relative from the surplus of his wealth and he is stingy towards him, or directing his charity to strangers while his relatives are in need) . 534 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "By the One who sent me with the truth, Allah will not punish on the Day of Resurrection one who had mercy on the orphan, and was soft to him in speech, and had mercy on his orphanhood and weakness, and did not lord over his neighbor with the favor of what Allah gave him". And he said: "O Nation of Muhammad! By the One who sent me with the truth, Allah does not accept charity from a man who has relatives in need of his connection, and he directs it to others. By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, Allah will not look at him on the Day of Resurrection". Narrated by At-Tabarani and its narrators are trustworthy. And Abdullah bin Amir Al-Aslami, Abu Hatim said: "He is not Matruk" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: He indicates that he is disputed, and he mentioned the sayings of the Hafizs regarding him at the end of the book, and he narrates it from (Ali bin Yazid) Al-Alhani, and finding fault with him is more appropriate, for Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Mughni": "They weakened him, and Ad-Daraqutni abandoned him". Therefore Al-Hafiz Al-Asqalani asserted that he is "Weak". And he said regarding (Ibn Zahr): "Sadduq (Truthful) who makes mistakes", and the hadith is in "Al-Mu'jam" (8/ 244/ 7834). 
2. I say: This only means that he is weak, not flimsy (Wahi), and for that Al-Hafiz and others weakened him, and it has other defects. And his absolute attribution to At-Tabarani implies it is in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir", but he extracted it in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Haythami restricted it to it, and I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3330).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 13 - (Encouragement for lending and what was reported regarding its virtue) . 535 - (1) [Very Weak] And [meaning the hadith of Abu Umamah which is in "As-Sahih"] Ibn Majah and Al-Baihaqi also narrated it; both from Khalid bin Yazid bin Abi Malik, from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "I saw on the night I was taken on the Night Journey (Isra') written on the gate of Paradise: Charity is for ten likes of it, and the loan is for eighteen" the Hadith. And Utbah bin Humaid is in my opinion better in condition than Khalid (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: And that is because (Khalid) is accused, and I extracted his hadith in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3637), and (Utbah bin Humaid) is Sadduq having delusions as Al-Hafiz said, and the author mentioned his hadith just before this, and for that I included it in "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 14 - (Encouragement for easing upon the one in difficulty, granting him respite, and remitting his debt). 536 - (1) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira also who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever relieves a Muslim of a distress, Allah the Exalted will make for him on the Day of Resurrection two branches of light on the Sirat (Path), by whose light a world of people will see, whom none can count except the Lord of Glory." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and it is Gharib (strange). 537 - (2) [Denounced (Munkar)] And [meaning the hadith of Abu Al-Yasar] was narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" with a Hasan chain (1), and its wording is: He said: I bear witness regarding the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that I heard him say: "Indeed, the first of people to be shaded in the shade of Allah on the Day of Resurrection is a man who granted respite to one in difficulty until he found something, or waived for him what he owed, saying: What I have against you is charity seeking the Face of Allah, and he tears up his record." His saying: "and he tears up his record," means: he cuts off the obligation that is upon him. 538 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever wants his supplication to be answered and his distress to be removed, let him relieve one in difficulty." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab Istina' Al-Ma'ruf" (2). 539 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever grants respite to one in difficulty until his ease; Allah will grant him respite regarding his sin until his repentance."
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, but it contains Ibn Lahi'ah, and his condition is known. He was unique with this context to the exclusion of everyone who narrated it from Abu Al-Yasar, and to the exclusion of everyone who followed (Abu Al-Yasar) from the Companions, and they are a group. I extracted their hadiths in "Ar-Rawd An-Nadir" (844), and from there I extracted this in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6917). 
2. I say: Ahmad also narrated it.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat". 540 - (5) [Very Weak] And from him who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, went out to the mosque while saying like this—and Abu Abdur-Rahman gestured with his hand towards the ground—: "Whoever grants respite to one in difficulty or waives [debt] for him; Allah will protect him from the heat (fayh) of Hell." Narrated by Ahmad with a Jayyid (good) chain (1), and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Istina' Al-Ma'ruf", and his wording is: He said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, entered the mosque saying: "Which of you would be pleased for Allah the Mighty and Majestic to protect him from the heat of Hell?" We said: O Messenger of Allah! All of us would be pleased. He said: "Whoever grants respite to one in difficulty or waives for him; Allah the Mighty and Majestic will protect him from the heat of Hell." 541 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Allah will shade a servant in His shade on the Day when there is no shade but His shade; one who granted respite to one in difficulty, or left off [debt] for a debtor." Narrated by Abdullah bin Ahmad in "Zawa'id Al-Musnad".
foot_note: 1. I say: It contains (Nuh bin Ja'wanah) As-Sulami, whom Ibn Abi Hatim did not know. He is Nuh bin Abi Maryam, and the name of his father or grandfather is (Ja'wanah). An-Nasa'i said: "Abu Ismah Nuh bin Ja'wanah, and it is said: Nuh bin Yazid bin Ja'wanah, and he is Nuh bin Abi Maryam the judge of Marw, he is not trustworthy nor trustworthy. Al-Muqri' narrated from him." Thus in "Tahdhib Al-Kamal". And Al-Muqri' is Abu Abdur-Rahman Abdullah bin Yazid Al-Masri, and he is the narrator of this hadith from (Nuh). I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6741).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 15 - (Encouragement for spending in ways of good out of generosity, and warning against withholding and hoarding out of stinginess). 542 - (1) [Weak] And from Qais bin Sal' Al-Ansari: That his brothers complained about him to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: He squanders his wealth and is lavish with it. I said: O Messenger of Allah! I take my share of dates and spend it in the way of Allah and on those who accompany me. So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, struck his chest and said: "Spend, Allah will spend on you, —three times—." Then when it was after that, I went out in the way of Allah and I had a mount, and today I am the most wealthy of my household and the most well-off. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and he said: "Sa'd (1) bin Ziyad Abu Asim was unique with it." 543 - (2) [Weak] And from Bilal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said to me: "O Bilal! Die poor, and do not die rich." I said: And how can I do that? He said: "Whatever you are provided do not hide, and whatever you are asked do not withhold." So I said: O Messenger of Allah! And how can I do that? He said: "It is that or the Fire." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Abu Ash-Shaykh Ibn Hayyan in "Kitab Ath-Thawab", and Al-Hakim who said: "Authentic in chain" (2) and he has: He said to me:
foot_note:
1. Original: "Sa'id", and likewise in "Al-Majma'" and the edition of the Three! It is a distortion, and that is why he said: "And I did not find anyone who wrote his biography." The correction is from the books of Rijal. His sheikh in it according to At-Tabarani (8536) and others is (Nafi' Mawla Hamnah), and he is unknown. And the first one, Abu Hatim said: "He is not strong." 
2. I say: Adh-Dhahabi rejected it by saying in his "Talkhis": "I say: Flimsy (Wahin)." I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6742).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Meet Allah poor, and do not meet Him rich," and the rest is similar. 544 - (3) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah resurrected two servants of His servants, to whom He had given much wealth and children. He said to one of them: O so-and-so son of so-and-so! He said: At Your service my Lord and at Your aid! He said: Did I not increase wealth and children for you? He said: Yes, O Lord! He said: And what did you do with what I gave you? He said: I left it for my children, fearing poverty (Al-Ailah) for them. He said: Indeed, if you knew the knowledge, you would have laughed little and cried much. Indeed, what you feared for them, I have brought down upon them. And He says to the other: O so-and-so son of so-and-so! So he says: At Your service O Lord and at Your aid! He said to him: Did I not increase wealth and children for you? He said: Yes O Lord! He said: So what did you do with what I gave you? So he said: I spent it in Your obedience, and trusted You for my children after me due to Your good bounty (Tawl). He said: Indeed, if you knew the knowledge, you would have laughed much and cried little. Indeed, what you trusted regarding them, I have brought down upon them." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat". (Al-Ailah) with Fatha on the unpointed 'Ain and Sukun on the Ya: It is poverty. And (At-Tawl) with Fatha on the Ta: It is favor, ability, and richness. 545 - (4) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Three birds were gifted to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. He gave his servant a bird. When it was the next day, she brought it to him. So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said to her: "Did I not forbid you from keeping anything for tomorrow? For Allah brings the provision of tomorrow." Narrated by Abu Ya'la and Al-Bayhaqi, and the narrators of Abu Ya'la are trustworthy (1).
foot_note: 1. Thus he said! But it contains one whom no one declared trustworthy except Ibn Hibban; and Al-Bukhari and Al-Uqayli declared him weak. I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6743).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 546 - (5) [Weak] And from Samura bin Jundub, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to say: "I do not enter this room except fearing that there might be wealth in it, so I would die without having spent it." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" with a Hasan chain (1). (La-aliju) means: I enter. And (Al-Ghurfah) with Damma on the dotted Ghain: It is the upper room ('ulliyyah). 547 - (6) And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him: That a Bedouin fought with the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, at Khaybar, and two dinars came to him from his share (2). The Bedouin took them and put them in a cloak, sewed over them, and wrapped over them. The Bedouin died, and the two dinars were found. That was mentioned to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he said: "Two cauterizations (kayyatan)." Narrated by Ahmad, and its chain is Hasan, acceptable in corroborating reports.
foot_note:
1. How so when it contains two unknown narrators, and one who is not strong. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6745). 
2. Meaning: His portion of the spoils. Ibn Al-Athir said: "(As-Sahm) originally means: one of the arrows used in drawing lots (Maysir), which are the Qidah. Then what the winner won was called his Sahm (share). Then it became frequent until every portion was called: Sahm. The plural of Sahm is (Ashum), (Siham), and (Suhman)."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 16 - (Encouraging a woman to give charity from her husband's wealth if he permits, and warning her against it if he does not permit). [There is no hadith under it meeting the condition of our book. See the commentary on the hadith of Abu Huraira in "As-Sahih"] 17 - (Encouragement for feeding food and giving water, and warning against withholding it). 548 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! Indeed when I see you, my soul becomes pleasant and my eye becomes cool. Inform me about everything. He said: "Everything was created from water." So I said: Inform me of something which if I do, I will enter Paradise. He said: "Feed food, spread peace, maintain ties of kinship, and pray at night while people are asleep; you will enter Paradise in peace" (1). Narrated by Ahmad, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" and the wording is his, and Al-Hakim who said: "Authentic in chain" [Passed in 6 - Voluntary Prayers / 11]. 549 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The expiations (Kaffarat) are: feeding food, spreading peace, and praying at night while people are asleep." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic in chain".
foot_note: 1. This paragraph has a supporting witness as I noted there.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (The Dictator said) may Allah be pleased with him: "How so when Abdullah bin Abi Humaid is abandoned (Matruk)?!" 550 - (3) [Weak] And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Among the things that necessitate mercy is feeding the poor Muslim." Narrated by Al-Hakim who authenticated it, and Al-Bayhaqi as connected and disconnected (Mursal) from his path also (1); except that he said: "Indeed among the things that necessitate forgiveness is feeding the hungry (Saghban) Muslim." And he said: Abdul Wahhab said: (meaning the hungry). And Abu Ash-Shaykh narrated it in "Kitab Ath-Thawab"; except that he said: "Indeed among the things that necessitate Paradise is feeding the hungry (Saghban) Muslim." (As-Saghban) with the unpointed Sin and the dotted Ghain followed by a single dotted Ba. 551 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed Allah the Mighty and Majestic enters three into Paradise for a morsel of bread and a handful of dates and the like of that which benefits the poor: The one who orders it, the wife who prepares it, and the servant who hands it to the poor." And the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Praise be to Allah who did not forget our servants." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Hakim, and it passed [here / 9 - Chapter with the wording of "Al-Awsat", and the wording here is Al-Hakim's]. (Al-Qabsah) with Fatha on the Qaf and Damma and with unpointed Sad: It is what the taker grasps with the tips of his three fingers.
foot_note: 1. Meaning from the path of Al-Hakim. Both revolve in "Shu'ab Al-Bayhaqi" (3/ 217/ 3364 and 6465) around Muhammad bin Al-Munkadir. Talhah bin Amr connected it from him from Jabir, and Hisham bin Hassan narrated it as Mursal from him. The Mursal is Jayyid (good). The connected one is very weak. Yet Al-Hakim authenticated it, and Adh-Dhahabi agreed with him as in the printed "Talkhis"! But Al-Munawi reported from him that he rejected it because Talhah is flimsy (Wahin). And this is the correct view.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 552 - (5) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "A worshipper from the Children of Israel worshipped Allah in his hermitage for sixty years. The earth was rained upon and became green, so the monk looked out from his hermitage and said: If I went down and remembered Allah I would increase in good. So he went down with a loaf or two of bread. While he was on the ground a woman met him, and he kept talking to her and she to him until he was intimate with her, then he fainted. He went down to the pond to bathe, and a beggar came, so he gestured to him to take the two loaves, then he died. The worship of sixty years was weighed against that zina (adultery), and the zina outweighed his good deeds. Then the loaf or two loaves were placed with his good deeds, and his good deeds outweighed, so he was forgiven." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" [Passed here / 9 - Chapter / Hadith 20]. 553 - (6) [Fabricated] And from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever feeds his brother until he satisfies him, and gives him water until he quenches his thirst; Allah will distance him from the Fire by seven trenches, between every two trenches is a distance of five hundred years." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Abu Ash-Shaykh Ibn Hayyan in "Ath-Thawab", and Al-Hakim and Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Hakim said: "Authentic in chain" (1). 554 - (7) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The best charity is to satisfy a hungry liver." Narrated by Abu Ash-Shaykh in "Ath-Thawab", and Al-Bayhaqi and the wording is his, and Al-Asbahani; all of them from the narration of Zarbi the Mu'adhin of Hisham from Anas. And the wording of Abu Ash-Shaykh and Al-Asbahani is: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say:
foot_note: 1. Thus he said! Yet it contains Raja' bin Abi Ata, about whom Al-Hakim himself said: "Possessor of fabricated reports"! See the detailed discussion on him in "Ad-Da'ifah" number (70).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "There is no deed better than satisfying a hungry liver" (1). 555 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Any believer who feeds a believer in hunger; Allah will feed him on the Day of Resurrection from the fruits of Paradise. And any believer who gives water to a believer in thirst; Allah will give him to drink on the Day of Resurrection from the Sealed Nectar. And any believer who clothes a believer in nakedness; Allah will clothe him on the Day of Resurrection from the green garments (2) of Paradise." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his (3), and Abu Dawood and his wording will come. At-Tirmidhi said: "A Gharib Hadith, and it has been narrated as Mawquf on Abu Sa'id, which is more authentic and more likely." 556 - (9) [Weak Mawquf] And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it in "Kitab Istina' Al-Ma'ruf" as Mawquf on Ibn Mas'ud, and his wording is: He said: People will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection more naked than they ever were, more hungry than they ever were, more thirsty than they ever were, and more tired than they ever were. So whoever clothed for the sake of Allah the Mighty and Majestic; Allah the Mighty and Majestic will clothe him. And whoever fed for the sake of Allah the Mighty and Majestic; Allah the Mighty and Majestic will feed him. And whoever gave water for the sake of Allah the Mighty and Majestic; Allah the Mighty and Majestic will give him water. And whoever acted for Allah; Allah will suffice him. And whoever pardoned for the sake of Allah the Mighty and Majestic; Allah the Mighty and Majestic will pardon him.
foot_note:
1. Extracted in "At-Targhib" (1/ 193/ 398), and Al-Bayhaqi in "Ash-Shu'ab" (3/ 217/ 3366) from the path of Zarbi - the Mu'adhin of Hisham bin Hassan - who said: I heard Anas bin Malik... And this Zarbi is flimsy (Wahin) as stated by Adh-Dhahabi in "Al-Kashif". As for the Ignorant Ones, they also found fault with it due to (Hisham bin Hassan) the Trustworthy, with speech they copied from Al-Munawi which would take long to refute, but it suffices to say: He is not mentioned in the chain except that (Zarbi) is his Mu'adhin!! 
2. Original: "Hulal" (suits), and the correction is from At-Tirmidhi, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad (3/ 14). And the Three Commentators overlooked it! 
3. An-Naji said: "This is one of the instances where he imitated Razin and 'Jami' Al-Usul', while his wording and the wording of Abu Dawood is the wording coming in 'Charity to the Poor...'". I say: Not at all, the matter is as the author, may Allah have mercy on him, said. See At-Tirmidhi "Kitab Al-Qiyamah 18 - Chapter". And Abu Dawood "Az-Zakah / 41 - Chapter".

text: And it was narrated as Marfu' with this wording (1). 557 - (10) [Weak] And it was narrated from Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever feeds a believer until he satisfies him from hunger (saghab); Allah will enter him into a gate from the gates of Paradise, which no one enters except the one who was like him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". (As-Saghab) with Fatha on the unpointed Sin and the dotted Ghain together: It is hunger. 558 - (11) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ja'far Al-Abdi and Al-Hasan who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed Allah the Mighty and Majestic boasts to His angels about those who feed food among His servants." And three things, whoever has them in him, Allah the Mighty and Majestic will shade him under His Throne on the Day when there is no shade but His shade: Ablution in unpleasant conditions, walking to the mosques in the dark, and feeding the hungry." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi with the first three only and he said: "A Gharib Hadith." And narrated by Abu Ash-Shaykh in "Ath-Thawab", and Abu Al-Qasim Al-Asbahani in full.

His companion began looking at him while he was prostrate, [having with him a vessel with some water], and said: By Allah, if this righteous servant dies of thirst while I have water, I will never attain any good from Allah. He comes until he stands and supplicates to his Lord the Mighty and Majestic, saying: O Lord! You have known his hand (favor) with me, and how he preferred me over himself,

The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Are they what urged you (a'malataka)?" He said: Yes. He said: "You speak justice, and give surplus." He said: By Allah I cannot speak justice all the time, and I cannot give surplus. He said: "Then you feed food, and spread peace." He said: This is also difficult. He said: "Do you have camels?"

text: He said: Yes. He said: "Look for a camel from your camels and a waterskin, then go to a household that does not drink water except every other day (ghibban) and give them water. Perhaps your camel will not perish, nor your waterskin tear, until Paradise becomes obligatory for you." He said: So the Bedouin set off saying Takbir. His waterskin did not tear, nor did his camel perish, until he was killed as a martyr. Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Bayhaqi, and the narrators of At-Tabarani up to Kudayr are narrators of the Sahih. And Ibn Khuzaymah narrated it in his "Sahih" briefly, and said: "I am not aware of Abu Ishaq hearing this report from Kudayr." (Al-Hafiz said): "Abu Ishaq did hear it from Kudayr, but the hadith is Mursal. Ibn Khuzaymah imagined that Kudayr had companionship (Suhbah) and extracted his hadith in his "Sahih", but he is a Shiite Tabi'i. Al-Bukhari and An-Nasa'i spoke about him, and Abu Hatim and others strengthened him. A group counted him among the Companions, an illusion from them, and it is not correct. And Allah knows best." (A'malataka) means: Sent you, employed you, and carried you to come and ask. And his saying: "They do not drink water except Ghibban" with Kasra on the dotted Ghain and Shaddah on the Ba: meaning: a day on and a day off. 564 - (17) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: A man came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and said: What deed, if I do it, I will enter Paradise? He said:

text: 9 - Book of Fasting 1 - (Encouragement for fasting absolutely, and what came regarding its virtue, and the virtue of the fasting person's supplication). 572 - (1) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Deeds (1) are seven: two obligating deeds, two deeds with their likes, a deed with ten of its likes, a deed with seven hundred [times], and a deed whose reward no one knows except Allah the Mighty and Majestic. As for the two obligating ones: whoever meets Allah worshipping Him sincerely associating nothing with Him; Paradise is obligated for him. And whoever meets Allah having associated with Him; the Fire is obligated for him. Whoever does a bad deed is recompensed with it. Whoever intends to do a good deed but does not do it is recompensed with the like of it. Whoever does a good deed is recompensed with ten. Whoever spends his wealth in the way of Allah, his spending is multiplied for him, the dirham seven hundred, and the dinar seven hundred. And fasting is for Allah the Mighty and Majestic, no one knows the reward of its doer except Allah the Mighty and Majestic." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Bayhaqi. It is in "Sahih Ibn Hibban" from the hadith of Khuraym bin Fatik similarly, but he did not mention "Fasting" in it. 573 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said:

text: 583 - (12) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Three whose supplication is not rejected: The fasting person when he breaks his fast, the just Imam, and the supplication of the oppressed; Allah raises it above the clouds, and opens the gates of the sky for it, and the Lord says: By My Might and Majesty, I will surely help you even if after a while." Narrated by Ahmad in a hadith, and At-Tirmidhi who classified it Hasan and the wording is his, and Ibn Majah. And Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs"; except that they said: "Until he breaks his fast". And Al-Bazzar narrated it briefly: [Very Weak] "Three, it is a right upon Allah not to reject a supplication for them: The fasting person until he breaks his fast, the oppressed until he is victorious, and the traveler until he returns" (1).

text: months. A month Allah made its fasting obligatory, and its night prayer voluntary. Whoever draws near in it with a characteristic, is like one who performed an obligation in other than it. And whoever performs an obligation in it is like one who performed seventy obligations in other than it. It is the month of patience, and the reward of patience is Paradise. And the month of consolation, and a month in which the believer's provision is increased. Whoever breaks the fast of a fasting person in it, it will be forgiveness for his sins, and freeing of his neck from the Fire, and he will have the like of his reward without decreasing anything from his reward." They said: O Messenger of Allah! Not all of us find what to break the fasting person's fast with? So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah gives this reward to one who breaks the fast of a fasting person on a date, or a drink of water, or a sip of milk (1). It is a month whose beginning is mercy, its middle is forgiveness, and its end is freedom from the Fire. Whoever lightens the burden of his slave in it, Allah forgives him and frees him from the Fire. So increase in it four characteristics: two characteristics by which you please your Lord, and two characteristics you cannot do without. As for the two characteristics by which you please your Lord, they are the testimony that there is no deity except Allah and you seek His forgiveness. As for the two characteristics you cannot do without, you ask Allah for Paradise, and seek refuge in Him from the Fire. And whoever gives water (2) to a fasting person, Allah will give him a drink from my Basin, a drink after which he will not thirst (3) until he enters Paradise." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah in his "Sahih", then he said: "If the report is authentic." And Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from his path. And Abu Ash-Shaykh Ibn Hayyan narrated it in "Ath-Thawab" briefly from them. [Very Weak] And in a narration of Abu Ash-Shaykh: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said:
foot_note:
1. (Al-Madhqah): A drink of milk mixed with water (mamzhuq).

3. Thus in "Sahih Ibn Khuzaymah" (3/ 192), and from his path Al-Bayhaqi in "Ash-Shu'ab" (3/ 306). Ibn Khuzaymah only weakened it because it is from the narration of Yusuf bin Ziyad, who is Abu Abdullah Al-Basri, Munkar al-Hadith as stated by Al-Bukhari and Abu Hatim. Ad-Daraqutni said: "Famous for falsehoods." And above him is Ali bin Zaid bin Jud'an, who is weak. But the calamity in this context is from the first.

And O Jibril, descend to the earth, so chain the rebellious devils and shackle them with shackles, then cast them into the seas, so that they do not spoil the fasting of the Ummah of Muhammad, my beloved (PBUH). He said: And Allah, Mighty and Majestic, says every night of the month of Ramadan to a caller who calls out three times: Is there any asker so I may give him his request? Is there any repenter so I may accept his repentance? Is there any seeker of forgiveness so I may forgive him? Who will lend to the One who is Wealthy, not destitute? And the One who fulfills, not unjust? He said: And for Allah, Mighty and Majestic, every day of the month of Ramadan at the time of breaking the fast are a thousand thousand (million) freed from the Fire; all of whom had deserved the Fire (1). So when it is the last day of the month of Ramadan, Allah frees on that day as many as He freed from the beginning of the month to its end. And when it is Laylat al-Qadr, Allah, Mighty and Majestic, commands Jibril (peace be upon him), so he descends in a large group of angels, and with them is a green banner, so they plant the banner on the back of the Kaaba. And he has one hundred wings, among them two wings he does not spread except on that night, so he spreads them on that night, and they surpass the East to the West. Then Jibril (peace be upon him) urges the angels on this night, so they greet every standing, sitting, praying, and remembering person, and shake their hands, and say Amin to their supplications until dawn breaks. So when dawn breaks, Jibril (peace be upon him) calls out: O assembly of angels! Depart, depart. So they say: O Jibril! What did Allah do regarding the needs of the believers from the Ummah of Ahmad (PBUH)? So he says: Allah looked at them on this night, and forgave them, except four." We said: O Messenger of Allah! Who are they? He said: "A man addicted to alcohol, one disobedient to his parents, one who severs kinship ties, and a Mushahin (one bearing malice)."

text: We said: O Messenger of Allah! What is the Mushahin? He said: "He is the one who cuts off relations (Musarim). So when it is the night of Fitr (breaking the fast), that night is named the Night of Prize. So when it is the morning of Fitr, Allah, Mighty and Majestic, sends the angels to every land, so they descend to the earth and stand at the mouths of the roads, calling out with a voice heard by everyone Allah created except Jinn and humans, saying: O Ummah of Muhammad! Go out to a Generous Lord who gives abundantly, and forgives great sins. So when they appear at their place of prayer, Allah, Mighty and Majestic, says to the angels: What is the reward of the hired worker when he has done his work? He said: So the angels say: Our God and Master! His reward is that You pay him his wages in full. He said: So He says: Then indeed I make you witnesses, O My angels, that I have made their reward for their fasting the month of Ramadan and their standing (in prayer) (1) My pleasure and My forgiveness. And He says: O My slaves! Ask Me, for by My Might and Majesty, you do not ask Me today for anything in your gathering for your Hereafter except that I give it to you, nor for your world except that I look into it for you. By My Might, I will surely cover your faults as long as you are mindful of Me. By My Might and Majesty, I will not disgrace you nor expose you among the people of penalties (limitations). Depart forgiven, you have pleased Me and I am pleased with you. So the angels rejoice and celebrate what Allah, Mighty and Majestic, gives this Ummah when they break their fast from the month of Ramadan." Narrated by Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan in "Kitab Ath-Thawab", and Al-Baihaqi and the wording is his, and there is no one in its chain who is unanimously agreed upon as weak (2). 595 - (12) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Said Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed the month of Ramadan is the month of my Ummah. Their sick become ill so they visit them. So if a Muslim fasts

For every woman of them are seventy thousand maidservants for her needs, and seventy thousand servants, with every servant a platter of gold, containing a color of food, he finds in the last morsel of it a pleasure he did not find in the first. Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and Al-Baihaqi from his path, and Abu Ash-Sheikh in "Ath-Thawab", and Ibn Khuzaimah said: "And in the heart there is something about Jarir bin Ayyub." [Very Weak] Narrated by Ahmad in a hadith, and At-Tirmidhi and he graded it Hasan, and Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs", and Al-Bazzar, and his wording is: "Three have a right upon Allah not to reject a supplication for them: The fasting person until he breaks his fast, the oppressed until he is victorious, and the traveler until he returns." text: 600 - (17) [Weak] And it was narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The rememberer of Allah in Ramadan is forgiven, and the asker of Allah in it is not disappointed."
