So Umar bin Al-Khattab said: O Messenger of Allah! A revelation descended? He said: "No." He said: An enemy appeared? He said: "No." He said: Then what? He said: "Indeed Allah forgives on the first night of the month of Ramadan for all the people of this Qiblah." And he pointed with his hand to it. So a man in front of him started shaking his head and saying: Bakh Bakh (Excellent). So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "O so-and-so! Did your chest become tight because of it?" He said: No, but I mentioned the hypocrite. He said: "Indeed the hypocrites are the disbelievers, and there is nothing for the disbelievers in that." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and Al-Baihaqi, and Ibn Khuzaimah said: "If the report is authentic, for I do not know Khalaf Abu Ar-Rabi' regarding integrity or disparagement, nor Amr bin Hamzah Al-Qaisi who is below him" (1). (Al-Hafiz said): "Ibn Abi Hatim mentioned them, and did not mention any disparagement regarding them. And Allah knows best." 602 - (19) [Munkar] And from Abdur-Rahman bin Awf (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) mentioned Ramadan preferring it over the months so he said:
foot_note: 1. I say: Al-Qaisi has been weakened. See my comment on "Sahih Ibn Khuzaimah" (3/ 189).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever stands (in prayer) in Ramadan out of faith and seeking reward; exits from his sins like the day his mother bore him." Narrated by An-Nasa'i and he said: "This is a mistake, and the correct is that it is from Abu Hurairah" (1). [Weak] And in a narration of his he said: "Indeed Allah obligated the fasting of Ramadan, and I established for you its standing (in prayer), so whoever fasts it and stands in it out of faith and seeking reward; exits from his sins like the day his mother bore him." 603 - (20) [Munkar] And Ahmad narrated via the path of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil bin Amr bin Abdur-Rahman from Ubadah bin As-Samit who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) informed us about Laylat al-Qadr and said: "It is in the month of Ramadan, in the last ten, the night of twenty-one, or twenty-three, or twenty-five, or twenty-seven, or twenty-nine, or the last night of Ramadan. Whoever stands in it seeking reward; is forgiven for what preceded of his sin and what is to come." And this addition (2) passed in the hadith of Abu Hurairah at the beginning of the chapter. 604 - (21) [Weak Mu'dal] And from Malik (may Allah have mercy on him); that he heard from one he trusts among the people of knowledge say: "Indeed the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) was shown the ages of people before him, or what Allah willed of that, so it was as if the ages of his Ummah were short so they would not reach in deeds the like of what others reached, so Allah gave him Laylat al-Qadr better than a thousand months." He mentioned it in "Al-Muwatta" like this.
foot_note:
1. Meaning his hadith preceded at the beginning of the chapter, and it is with another wording which you see in "As-Sahih". 
2. Meaning: "and what is to come", and it is a Munkar addition in the hadith of Ubadah, and Shadh in the hadith of Abu Hurairah referred to, and it is agreed upon without it, so see it in the beginning of this chapter from "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - (Discouragement from breaking the fast of any part of Ramadan without excuse) . 605 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever breaks the fast of a day of Ramadan without a concession, nor illness; fasting the entire lifetime will not make up for it, even if he fasted it." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and Al-Baihaqi; all of them from the narration of Ibn Al-Mutawwis - and it was said Abu Al-Mutawwis - from his father from Abu Hurairah. And Al-Bukhari mentioned it as a Mu'allaq (suspended) narration without certainty, so he said: And it is mentioned from Abu Hurairah raising it: "Whoever breaks the fast of a day of Ramadan without excuse nor illness; fasting the entire lifetime will not make up for it, even if he fasted it." And At-Tirmidhi said: "We do not know it from this perspective, and I heard Muhammad - meaning Al-Bukhari - say: Abu Al-Mutawwis's name is Yazid bin Al-Mutawwis, and I do not know for him other than this hadith" End. And Al-Bukhari also said: "I do not know if his father heard from Abu Hurairah or not." And Ibn Hibban said: "It is not permissible to use as proof what he alone narrated." And Allah knows best. 606 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) - Hammad bin Zaid said: And I do not know him except having - raised it to the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "The loops of Islam and the foundations of the religion are three, upon them Islam was founded. Whoever leaves one of them, then he is by it a disbeliever whose blood is lawful: The testimony that there is no deity but Allah, the prescribed Prayer, and the fasting of Ramadan." Narrated by Abu Ya'la with a Hasan chain. And in a narration: "Whoever leaves one of them then he is a disbeliever in Allah, and no obligatory nor voluntary deed is accepted from him, and his blood and wealth have become lawful." [Passed 5 - Prayer/ 40].
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 4 - (Encouragement to fast six of Shawwal) . 607 - (1) [Munkar] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih"] in "Al-Awsat" with a chain that has a view (defect) he said: "Whoever fasts six days after Fitr consecutively, then it is as if he fasted the entire year." 608 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever fasts Ramadan, and follows it with six of Shawwal; exits from his sins like the day his mother bore him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat".
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 5 - (Encouragement to fast the Day of Arafah. . ., and what came regarding the prohibition for the one who is a Hajj pilgrim at it) . 609 - (1) [Weak] And from Ata' Al-Khurasani: That Abdur-Rahman bin Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with them both) entered upon Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) on the Day of Arafah while she was fasting, and water was being sprinkled on her, so Abdur-Rahman said to her: Break your fast. She said: Should I break my fast when I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Indeed fasting the Day of Arafah expiates the year before it"?! (1). Narrated by Ahmad and his narrators are relied upon in "As-Sahih"; except that Ata' Al-Khurasani did not hear from Abdur-Rahman bin Abu Bakr. 610 - (2) [Weak] And from Masruq: That he entered upon Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) on the Day of Arafah and said: Give me drink. Aisha said: O boy! Give him honey to drink. Then she said: And are you not fasting, O Masruq? He said: No, I fear it might be the Day of Sacrifice (Adha). So Aisha said: It is not that, Arafah is only the day the Imam defines (stands at Arafah), and the Day of Sacrifice is the day the Imam sacrifices. Or have you not heard O Masruq: "That the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) used to equate it with a thousand days"?! Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a Hasan chain, and Al-Baihaqi (2).
foot_note:
1. In "As-Sahih" there are several hadiths in the chapter that suffice instead of this Marfu' one and exceed it in virtue, so refer to them. And the hadith is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5191). 
2. Thus he said, and it contains (Sulaiman bin Dawood Al-Kufi), Al-Hafiz said: "There is leniency in him", from (Dalham bin Salih) and he is weak. And it is extracted in the previous source, and the ignorant ones attributed it to Ibn Hibban quoting from "Fayd Al-Qadir" by Al-Munawi, and there is no responsibility on him because (HB - Al-Baihaqi) was distorted by the printer or copyist to (HB - Ibn Hibban) and this is a symbol for Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih",! And it is not in it, and I pointed this out in the mentioned source, then in the second verification of "Da'if Al-Jami'". And from the completeness of their ignorance and negligence is that they also defected it with (Sulaiman bin Ahmad Al-Wasiti), and he is not in the chain of At-Tabarani (6802 - Al-Haramain), and they did not attribute it to him due to their inability and lack of research and merchandise.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And in a narration by Al-Baihaqi: She said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) used to say: "Fasting the Day of Arafah is like fasting a thousand days". 611 - (3) [Munkar] And from Zaid bin Arqam (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH): That he was asked about fasting the Day of Arafah? He said: "It expiates the year you are in, and the year after it" (1). Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" from the narration of Rishdin bin Sa'd. 612 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him): "That the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) forbade fasting the Day of Arafah at Arafah." Narrated by Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih" (2). 613 - (5) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Awsat" from Aisha (3). Al-Hafiz said: "They differed regarding fasting the Day of Arafah at Arafah. Ibn Umar said: The Prophet (PBUH) did not fast it, nor Abu Bakr, nor Umar, nor Uthman, and I do not fast it. And Malik and Ath-Thawri used to choose breaking the fast. And Ibn Az-Zubair and Aisha used to fast the Day of Arafah, and that was narrated from Uthman bin Abi Al-As. And Ishaq was inclined to fasting. And Ata' used to say: I fast in the winter, and I do not fast in the summer. And Qatadah said: There is no harm in it if it does not weaken one from supplication. And Ash-Shafi'i said: Fasting Arafah is recommended for the non-pilgrim, as for the pilgrim, it is more beloved to me that he breaks his fast, to strengthen him for supplication. And Ahmad bin Hanbal said: If he is able to fast let him fast, and if he breaks his fast, for that is a day wherein strength is needed".
foot_note:
1. It has been authenticated with the wording: "The past year", and this contradicts what is here so pay attention, for the ignorant ones graded it Hasan due to their negligence, and see "As-Sahih". 
2. It contains an unknown narrator, Al-Hafiz said about him: "Maqbul (Accepted)". Meaning upon corroboration as he stated in the introduction, and as those who practiced this science know. And it is natural that the three commentators are ignorant of that, so they said: "Hasan", and quoted his mentioned saying! While they had come across my defecting it with the saying of Ibn Ma'in and Abu Hatim about him: "I do not know him" in my comment on "Sahih Ibn Khuzaimah" (3/ 292). Covering up their deed and loving to appear and differ, they did not attribute the hadith to Ibn Khuzaimah by number; contrary to their habit! And Allah is the One sought for help. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (404) and "Da'if Abi Dawood" (421). 
3. He extracted it in "Al-Awsat" (3/ 18/ 2327) via the path of Ibrahim bin Muhammad Al-Aslami from Safwan Ibn Sulaym from Ata' bin Yasar from her. I say: And this Ibrahim is Matruk (Discarded) extremely weak, so the hadith before it is not strengthened by him. And the name (Ibrahim bin) fell from "Al-Majma'" (3/ 189) so the defect became his father (Muhammad bin Abi Yahya), and he is Sadduq!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 6 - (Encouragement to fast the Month of Allah Al-Muharram) . 614 - (1) [Weak] And from Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) and a man asked him saying: Which month do you command me to fast after the month of Ramadan? He said to him: I have not heard anyone ask about this except a man I heard asking the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) while I was sitting with him, he said: O Messenger of Allah! Which month do you command me to fast after the month of Ramadan? He said: "If you are fasting after the month of Ramadan then fast Al-Muharram; for it is the month of Allah, and in it is a day Allah forgave a people, and He forgives another people in it." Narrated by Abdullah bin Imam Ahmad from other than his father, and At-Tirmidhi from the narration of Abdur-Rahman bin Ishaq - and he is Abu (1) Shaibah - from An-Nu'man bin Sa'd from Ali. And he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith". 615 - (2) [Fabricated] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever fasts the Day of Arafah, he has expiation for two years, and whoever fasts a day of Al-Muharram he has for every day thirty days." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir", and it is Gharib, and its chain has no harm (2). (Al-Haytham) bin Habib was authenticated by Ibn Hibban.
foot_note:
1. The original: (Ibn Abi Shaibah), and it is a typographical error, and he is weak by agreement. 
2. I say: This is a gross error I do not know how it happened to him; for it contains (Sallam At-Tawil) and he is a liar, and (Laith bin Abi Sulaym) is confused (Mukhtalit), and (Al-Haytham bin Habib) Adh-Dhahabi accused him regarding a report, and Ibn Hibban's authentication here is not considered. The ignorant ones were deceived by it so they said: "Weak" only.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 7 - (Encouragement to fast the Day of Ashura and expanding on the family during it) . 616 - (1) [Munkar] And from him also [meaning Ibn Abbas] he said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "There is no day having virtue over another day in fasting except the month of Ramadan and the day of Ashura." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Al-Baihaqi, and At-Tabarani's narrators are trustworthy (1). 617 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever expands upon his dependents and his family on the day of Ashura; Allah expands upon him the rest of his year." Narrated by Al-Baihaqi and others from paths, and from a group of Companions, and Al-Baihaqi said: "These chains even if they are weak, when some are added to others they gain strength. And Allah knows best" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: It contains one whose memory is spoken about, along with his contradicting the trustworthy narrators in his text, so it is Munkar for this and for contradicting the hadiths of the virtue of fasting the Day of Arafah and others. And the three commentators neglected this, so they said: "Hasan, Al-Haythami said: And its men are trustworthy"! It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (285). 
2. Thus he said, and all its paths are flimsy, and some are weaker than others, and I extracted them in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6824).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 8 - (Encouragement to fast Sha'ban, and what came regarding the Prophet's (PBUH) fasting of it, and the virtue of its middle night) . 618 - (1) [Weak] And At-Tirmidhi narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (PBUH) was asked: Which fasting is best after Ramadan? He said: "Sha'ban to honor Ramadan." He said: Then which charity is best? He said: "Charity in Ramadan." At-Tirmidhi said: "A Gharib Hadith". 619 - (2) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): That the Prophet (PBUH) used to fast all of Sha'ban. She said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! Is the most beloved of months to you that you fast it Sha'ban? He said: "Indeed Allah writes in it for every soul dying that year, so I love that my time comes while I am fasting." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and it is Gharib, and its chain is Hasan (1). 620 - (3) [Very Weak] And Al-Baihaqi narrated from the hadith of Aisha; that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Jibril (peace be upon him) came to me and said: This is the night of the middle of Sha'ban, and to Allah in it are freed ones from the Fire by the number of the hairs of the sheep of Banu Kalb (2). Allah does not look in it to a polytheist, nor to a Mushahin (one bearing malice), nor to one severing kinship ties, nor to a Musbil (one trailing garments in pride), nor to one undutiful
foot_note:
1. I say: It has two defects, and their explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5086). 
2. The name of a known tribe. And the hadith is in "Shu'ab Al-Iman" (3/ 383 - 385), and in it is (Muhammad bin Isa bin Hayyan Al-Mada'ini): Sallam bin Sulaiman At-Tawil told us, and both are Matruk.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: to his parents, nor to one addicted to alcohol", and he mentioned the hadith at length. And it will come in full in "Abandonment" if Allah the Exalted wills [23 - Etiquette /11]. 621 - (4) [Weak] And Imam Ahmad narrated from Abdullah bin Amr (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Allah, Mighty and Majestic, looks at His creation on the night of the middle of Sha'ban, so He forgives His servants; except two: a Mushahin, and a murderer" (1). 622 - (5) [Weak] And from Aisha (2) (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) stood at night and prayed, and he prolonged the prostration until I thought he had passed away. When I saw that I stood up until I moved his thumb, and it moved, so I returned. [And I heard him say in his prostration: (I seek refuge in Your pardon from Your punishment, and I seek refuge in Your pleasure from Your anger, and I seek refuge in You from You, I cannot enumerate praise upon You, You are as You praised Yourself)]. When he raised his head from prostration and finished his prayer he said: "O Aisha! - or O Humaira! - Did you think that the Prophet (PBUH) had betrayed you (Khasa biki)?".
foot_note:
1. I say: In its chain (2/ 176) is Ibn Lahi'ah, and he is weak, and it is in "As-Sahih" with the wording: "Except for a polytheist or a Mushahin". 
2. I say: Thus it appeared here, and the correct is what will come in (23 - Etiquette/ 11): "And from Al-Ala' bin Al-Harith; that Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said...". And the difference between what is here and what is there is not hidden from the people of knowledge, for what is here implies that the narrator - who was not named - connected it from Aisha, and what is there implies that he sent it (Mursal) from her, and for that Al-Baihaqi said after the hadith: "This is Mursal Jayyid (Good)". And the author interpreted it saying: "Meaning that (Al-Ala') did not hear it from Aisha". And his saying "Jayyid", is not good in my critique; for Al-Ala' bin Al-Harith had become confused (Mukhtalit) as in "At-Taqrib".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: I said: No by Allah O Messenger of Allah! But I thought that you passed away due to the length of your prostration. He said: "Do you know which night this is?". I said: Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: "This is the night of the middle of Sha'ban. Indeed Allah, Mighty and Majestic, looks at His servants on the night of the middle of Sha'ban, so He forgives those seeking forgiveness, and has mercy on those seeking mercy, and delays the people of hatred as they are." Narrated by Al-Baihaqi via the path of Al-Ala' bin Al-Harith from her, and he said: "This is Mursal Jayyid". Meaning that Al-Ala' did not hear it from Aisha. And Allah, Glorified and Exalted, knows best. It is said: (Khasa bihi): If he betrayed him (1) and did not fulfill his right. And the meaning of the hadith: Did you think that I betrayed you, and went in your night to another, and it is with the dotted Kha and un-dotted Sin. 623 - (6) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "When it is the night of the middle of Sha'ban then stand its night, and fast its day; for Allah Blessed and Exalted descends in it at sunset to the lowest heaven and says: Is there any seeker of forgiveness so I may forgive him? Is there any seeker of provision so I may provide for him? Is there any afflicted person so I may cure him? Is there such, is there such? Until dawn breaks." Narrated by Ibn Majah.
foot_note: 1. The original: "Ghadarahu (Betrayed him)", and perhaps the correct is what we established, then I verified it when I saw it likewise in Al-Baihaqi in "Ash-Shu'ab" (3/ 383) from the saying of Al-Azhari, and the three commentators neglected it. Furthermore, the supplication which I enclosed in brackets [] is not in this narration, but rather in the other narration of Al-Baihaqi preceding the hadith of Ibn Amr, so it is as if the author permitted this combination between them, and it will come without this supplication in the place referred to just now, and it is established in "Sahih Muslim" from her in other than this story, and it is extracted in "Sahih Abi Dawood" (823). And see "Sifat As-Salah".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 9 - (Encouragement to fast three days of every month especially the White Days (1)) . 624 - (1) [Weak] And from him [meaning Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas (may Allah be pleased with them both)] he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Nuh (peace be upon him) fasted the entire lifetime except the day of Fitr and Adha, and Dawud (peace be upon him) fasted half the lifetime, and Ibrahim (peace be upon him) fasted three days of every month, he fasted the lifetime, and broke the fast the lifetime." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Al-Baihaqi, and in their chain is Abu Firas, I did not find regarding him any disparagement or modification, and I do not think he is known (2). And Allah knows best. 625 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Maimunah bint Sa'd (may Allah be pleased with her); that she said: O Messenger of Allah! Give us a fatwa about fasting? He said: "From every month three days, whoever is able to fast them, for every day expiates ten bad deeds, and cleanses the sin (3) just as water cleanses the garment." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 626 - (3) [Fabricated] And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both): That a man asked the Prophet (PBUH) about fasting? He said: "Stick to the white ones: three days of every month." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and its narrators are trustworthy (4).
foot_note:
1. An-Naji said (126/ 1): "Thus it was found defining Al-Ayyam (The Days), and likewise it occurs in many books of Fiqh, An-Nawawi said: And it is an error according to the people of Arabic counted in the solecism of the commoners; because all days are white (light), but the correct form is: Ayyam Al-Bid (Days of the Whites), adding Al-Bid to Ayyam. Meaning: Days of the White Nights". 
2. I say: Rather he is a known Thiqah (Trustworthy), from the men of "At-Tahdhib" as explained in the original, then in "Ad-Da'ifah", number (6751), but the defect of the hadith is from Ibn Lahi'ah as explained there. 
3. In a copy: (Adh-Dhunub - Sins) instead of (Al-Ithm - Sin). And what I established matches what is in "At-Tabarani Al-Kabir" (25/ 35/ 60) and "Majma' Az-Zawa'id". 
4. I say: And Al-Haythami follows him, and it is from their gross delusions, for it contains (Sulaiman bin Dawood Ash-Shadhakuni), for despite his memory more than one called him a liar. And I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5192), and the authentic hadiths in the chapter suffice without it. As for the ignorant ones, they said: "Hasan due to its preceding witnesses"!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 10 - (Encouragement to fast Monday and Thursday) . 627 - (1) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih"], and its wording is: He said: "The records of the people of earth are copied into the records of the people of heaven, on every Monday and Thursday, so every Muslim who does not associate anything with Allah is forgiven; except a man between whom and his brother there is rancor" (1). 628 - (2) [Weak] And from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Deeds are presented on Monday and Thursday, so whoever is seeking forgiveness is forgiven, and whoever is repenting his repentance is accepted, and the people of grudges are returned (2) with their grudges until they repent." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its narrators are trustworthy (3).
foot_note:
1. It contains one whose status is unknown, and others along with the strangeness of its wording, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5275). 
2. Thus here, and in what will come (23 - Etiquette/ 11), and likewise it occurred in the Zahiriyah manuscript, and in "Al-Majma'" (7/ 66): "WAYADHARU (And He leaves)", and it is the correct form indicated by the context, and the narration of Al-Khatib in "At-Talkhis" with the wording: "Wa yada'u (And He leaves)", which is the wording of the hadith of Abu Tha'labah coming there. 
3. I say: Yes, but it contains the 'an'ana of (Abu Az-Zubair) from Jabir, and he is a Mudallis, and Al-Khatib defected it with waqf (being Mawquf), and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6825), and the Three authenticated it...! And in the original before this is another hadith of Jabir differing from this slightly, I deleted it because it is not in the manuscript, nor attributed to anyone, and I only found it with this wording which is at At-Tabarani.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 11 - (Encouragement to fast Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, and Sunday, and what came regarding the prohibition of singling out Friday for fasting, or Saturday) . 629 - (1) [Weak] It was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever fasts Wednesday and Thursday; freedom from the Fire is written for him." Narrated by Abu Ya'la. 630 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from him also, he said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever fasts Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday; Allah builds for him a house in Paradise, its outside is seen from its inside, and its inside from its outside." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 631 - (3) [Weak] And he narrated it in "Al-Kabir" from the hadith of Abu Umamah (1). 632 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him); that he heard the Prophet (PBUH) say: "Whoever fasts Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday; Allah builds for him a palace in Paradise, of pearls, rubies, and chrysolite, and writes for him freedom from the Fire." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Baihaqi. 633 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever fasts Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, then gives charity on Friday with what is little or much; every sin he committed is forgiven for him, until he becomes like the day his mother bore him free from sins."
foot_note: 1. I say: Its chain is the chain of Ibn Abbas, the utmost matter is that one of its narrators was confused in its chain, so sometimes he said: From him, and sometimes he said: From Abu Umamah. And it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5193).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Al-Baihaqi. 634 - (6) [Munkar] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever fasts Friday; Allah writes for him ten days whose number is from the days of the Hereafter, the days of the world do not resemble them." Narrated by Al-Baihaqi from a man from Jusham from Abu Hurairah, and from a man from Ashja' from Abu Hurairah as well. And he did not name the two men. And this hadith, assuming its existence (1), is interpreted as if he fasted Thursday before it, or intended to fast Saturday after it. 635 - (7) [Weak] And from Ubaydullah bin Muslim Al-Qurashi from his father who said: I asked - or the Prophet (PBUH) was asked - about fasting the Dahr (lifetime)? He said: "No, indeed your family has a right upon you. Fast Ramadan and what follows it, and every Wednesday and Thursday, then you have fasted the Dahr and broken the fast." Narrated by Abu Dawood and An-Nasa'i, and At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith". The Dictator Abdul-Azim (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "And its narrators are trustworthy" (2).
foot_note:
1. Thus in the original and the manuscript. As if he means: its existence as Sahih, and it is not Sahih, rather it is Munkar. In the path to the Jushami man is (Abu Khalid Al-Uqaili) number (3862) and his name is (Yazid bin Bayan) and he is weak. And in the path from the Ashja'i man is (Isa bin Musa bin Iyas bin Al-Bukair) number (3863), Abu Hatim said: Weak. And Ibn Hibban mentioned him in "Ath-Thiqat" (5/ 216 and 7/ 234). 
2. I say: Ubaydullah bin Muslim Al-Qurashi was not authenticated by anyone except Ibn Hibban, and it was said about him: (Muslim bin Ubaydullah) inverted, which is more famous, and no one narrated from him except one, therefore Adh-Dhahabi left him blank in "Al-Kashif". And Al-Hafiz indicated that by saying in "At-Taqrib": "Maqbul (Accepted)", which is appropriate for At-Tirmidhi declaring it Gharib. As for his saying: "Hasan", perhaps it is an insertion from some copyists, for it did not occur in Fuad Abdul-Baqi's edition, nor in Ad-Da'as's edition, nor in Al-Mubarakpuri's copy which has his commentary, likewise Al-Hafiz Al-Mizzi did not mention it in "Tuhfat Al-Ashraf" (7/ 221). As for the ignorant ones, they imitated the authentication! Without any research or verification. And it is extracted in "Da'if Abi Dawood" (420).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 636 - (8) [Weak] And in a narration by Ibn Khuzaimah [in the hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih"]: "Indeed Friday is a day of Eid, so do not make your day of Eid your day of fasting, unless you fast before it or after it." 637 - (9) [Weak] And from Amir bin Ludain Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard (1) the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Indeed Friday is your Eid, so do not fast; unless you fast before it or after it." Narrated by Al-Bazzar with a Hasan chain. 638 - (10) [Weak] And from Ibn Sirin who said: Abu Ad-Darda used to enliven the night of Friday, and fast its day. Salman came to him - and the Prophet (PBUH) had established brotherhood between them - and slept at his place. Abu Ad-Darda wanted to stand his night (in prayer), so Salman stood up to him and did not leave him until he slept, and broke his fast. So Abu Ad-Darda came to the Prophet (PBUH) and informed him, so the Prophet (PBUH) said: "Uwaimir! Salman is more knowledgeable than you, do not single out the night of Friday for prayer, nor its day for fasting." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" with a Jayyid (Good) chain (2). 639 - (11) [Weak] And from Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her): That the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) used to fast most of the days on Saturday and Sunday, and he used to say: "They are two days of Eid for the polytheists, and I want to oppose them." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih" and others (3).
foot_note:
1. I say: This is an error arising from a drop in the chain of Al-Bazzar; for this Amir has no companionship, between him and the Prophet (PBUH) in this hadith is Abu Hurairah, and he is the one saying in it: "I heard", as came in the narration of Ibn Khuzaimah before it, and it is a narration of Ahmad and others. The verifier of "Kashf Al-Astar" did not notice this! Let alone the three ignorant commentators on "At-Targhib" (2/ 166/ 1552), so they all quoted Al-Haythami's grading of Hasan and supported it!! And it contains one who is not known, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5344 and 6826). 
2. I say: Rather it is Weak due to its disconnection between Ibn Sirin and Abu Ad-Darda, and Al-Haythami defected it with that (3/ 200). 
3. I say: It has a defect that became clear to me after effort, I revealed it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1099) along with its contradiction to the prohibition of fasting Saturday except in obligatory fasts as I explained in "Al-Irwa".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 12 - (Encouragement to fast a day and break fast a day, which is the fast of Dawud peace be upon him . [There is no hadith under it according to the condition of our book. See "As-Sahih"]. 13 - (Discouragement for a woman to fast voluntarily while her husband is present except with his permission) . 640 - (1) [Munkar] And from him [meaning Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him)] he said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Any woman who fasts without her husband's permission, and he wants her for something; but she refuses him; Allah writes against her three major sins." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", from the narration of Baqiyyah (1), and it is a Gharib hadith, and it has Nakarah (denouncement). And Allah knows best. 641 - (2) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated (2) a hadith from Ibn Abbas from the Prophet (PBUH) and in it: "And from the right of the husband over the wife is that she does not fast voluntarily except with his permission, if she does she goes hungry and thirsty, and it is not accepted from her." And it will come in full in "An-Nikah" if Allah the Exalted wills [17/ 3 - Chapter].
foot_note:
1. I say: He indicates that he is a Mudallis, and he used 'an'ana, and I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2473) and mentioned there the possibility that he received it from one of those accused of lying then practiced Tadlis, so refer if you wish. 
2. Thus in the original, and likewise it is in the place referred to above, and I see it only as an error, for I did not see it in any of At-Tabarani's Mu'jams, rather Abu Ya'la and Al-Bazzar narrated it, and in their chains is a Matruk narrator, and I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3515).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 14 - (Discouragement for the traveler from fasting if it is difficult for him, and encouragement for him to break the fast) . 642 - (1) [Shadh] And it [meaning the hadith of Ka'b bin Asim Al-Ash'ari which is in "As-Sahih"] is with Ahmad with the wording: "Laisa min am-birr; am-siyam fi am-safar" (It is not righteousness to fast in travel) (1). And its men are men of "As-Sahih". 643 - (2) [Weak] And from Abdur-Rahman bin Awf (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The faster of Ramadan in travel, is like the breaker of fast in residence." Narrated by Ibn Majah as Marfu' like this, and An-Nasa'i with a Hasan chain (2); except that he said: It used to be said: "The faster in travel, is like the one breaking fast in residence." And in a narration: "The faster in travel, is like the breaker of fast in residence." (Al-Hafiz said): "The saying of the Companion: 'It used to be said such and such', is it attached to the Marfu' or the Mawquf? There is disagreement
foot_note:
1. An-Naji said (126/ 2): "This is a dialect of some people of Yemen, they make the Lam of definition (Al-) a Mim, and it is possible that the Prophet (PBUH) addressed Ka'b bin Asim Al-Ash'ari, the narrator of this hadith, with it like that because it is his dialect, and it is possible that this Al-Ash'ari pronounced it according to what he was accustomed to of his dialect so the narrator carried it from him and reported it with the wording he heard from him. Our Sheikh Ibn Hajar said in 'Talkhisihi Takhrij Ahadith Ar-Rafi'i li Ibn Al-Mulaqqin': 'And this second is more plausible to me'. And Al-Hafiz Du'laj bin Ahmad said in 'Musnad Al-Muqillin min As-Sahabah (may Allah be pleased with them)' after narrating it in the mentioned dialect from the path mentioned by the author from 'Musnad Ahmad' from Ma'mar from Az-Zuhri from Safwan Ibn Abdullah bin Safwan bin Umayyah bin Khalaf Al-Jumahi from Umm Ad-Darda and she is As-Sughra from Ka'b Al-Ash'ari: 'And Ibn Juraij, Al-Layth, Sufyan - meaning Ibn Uyaynah -, Yunus and Malik narrated it in the famous language from Az-Zuhri'. He said: And Yazid bin Zurai' bin Ma'mar narrated it from Az-Zuhri likewise". I say: And it is the Preserved (Mahfuz) as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1130). As for the ignorant three, they mixed - as is their habit - the Preserved with the Shadh, and said "Sahih"! 
2. I say: It is interrupted between Abu Salamah bin Abdur-Rahman bin Awf and his father, for he did not hear from him.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: famous between the Muhaddithin and Usuliyyin regarding it, this is not the place to elaborate on it, but the majority are on that if he does not attribute it to the time of the Prophet (PBUH) it is Mawquf. And Allah knows best". 644 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Tu'mah who said: I was with Ibn Umar, and a man came to him and said: O Abu Abdur-Rahman! I am strong enough to fast in travel? So Ibn Umar said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever does not accept the concession of Allah, Mighty and Majestic; upon him is sin like the mountains of Arafah." Narrated by Ahmad, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". And our Sheikh Al-Hafiz Abu Al-Hasan (may Allah have mercy on him) used to say: Ahmad's chain is Hasan (1). And Al-Bukhari said in "Kitab Ad-Du'afa": "It is a Munkar hadith". And Allah knows best. 645 - (4) [Fabricated] And At-Tabarani narrated in "Al-Awsat" also and "Al-Kabir" from Abdullah bin Yazid bin Adam who said: Abu Ad-Darda, Wathilah bin Al-Asqa', Abu Umamah, and Anas bin Malik told me; that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed Allah loves that His concessions are accepted, just as the servant loves the forgiveness of his Lord" (2).
foot_note:
1. And so Al-Haythami said, and in its chain is Ibn Lahi'ah, and he was confused in its chain, so no wonder Al-Bukhari denounced it. And the explanation of that is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1949). As for the ignorant ones, they contradicted themselves, prefacing it by saying: "Weak", then quoting from Al-Haythami: "And Ahmad's chain is Hasan"! And affirming it!! 
2. See "Ad-Da'ifah" (508); for this Ibn Adam, Ahmad said: "His hadiths are fabricated", and Al-Haythami's saying about him: "Ahmad and others weakened him" is from his leniency, and the Three imitated him!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 15 - (Encouragement for Suhur especially with dates) . 646 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Seek help with the Suhur meal for the fast of the day, and with the midday nap (Qailulah) for the standing (prayer) of the night." Narrated by Ibn Majah, Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and Al-Baihaqi; all of them via the path of Zam'ah bin Salih from Salamah - he is Ibn Wahram - from Ikrimah from him; except that Ibn Khuzaimah said: "And with the midday nap of the day for the standing of the night" (1). 647 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Prophet (PBUH) said: "Three have no account upon them in what they ate if Allah the Exalted wills, if it was Halal: The fasting person, the one taking Suhur, and the one stationed (Murabit) in the path of Allah." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 648 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from As-Sa'ib bin Yazid (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "An excellent Suhur is dates." And he said: "May Allah have mercy on those taking Suhur." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". (2)
foot_note:
1. I say: It would have been better for the author to quote from Ibn Khuzaimah his weakening of it in the chapter he convened for it saying: "If arguing with the report of (Zam'ah bin Salih) is permissible; for there is something in the heart about him; due to his bad memory". And his Sheikh (Salamah) is weak as well. And I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2758). 
2. Here in the original is the hadith of Salman bin Amir Ad-Dabbi coming in the beginning of Chapter (17), and it is apparent that it is an insertion from some copyists; as it has no relation to the chapter as is clear, and for that reason I did not mention it.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 16 - (Encouragement to hasten breaking the fast and delay Suhur) . 649 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Allah Mighty and Majestic said: Indeed the most beloved of My servants to Me, are the quickest of them in breaking the fast." Narrated by Ahmad, At-Tirmidhi and he graded it Hasan, and Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs" (1). 650 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ya'la bin Murrah who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Three things Allah loves: Hastening the breaking of fast, delaying the Suhur, and placing one hand over the other in prayer" (2). Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat".
foot_note:
1. See its defect in "Al-Mishkat" (1989). 
2. I say: And it has been authenticated from Ibn Abbas as Marfu' with the wording: "We assembly of Prophets were commanded to hasten our breaking of fast..." the hadith similarly. See "Sifat As-Salah" (p. 78 - Seventh Edition).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 17 - (Encouragement to break fast with dates, if not found then with water) . 651 - (1) [Weak] From Salman bin Amir Ad-Dabbi (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "When one of you breaks his fast let him break it with dates; for it is a blessing, if he does not find dates then water; for it is pure." Narrated by Abu Dawood, At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih". And At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Sahih Hadith" (1). 652 - (2) [Weak] And Abu Ya'la narrated it [meaning the hadith of Anas which is in "As-Sahih"] saying: "The Prophet (PBUH) used to love to break his fast with three dates or something not touched by fire." 653 - (3) [Weak] And from him [meaning Anas] he said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever finds dates let him break his fast with them, and whoever does not find let him break his fast with water; for it is pure." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih according to their condition" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: And Ibn Khuzaimah also (2067) and in their chains is Jahalah (unknown status), see "Al-Irwa" (4/ 49 - 51). 
2. Thus he said, and Al-Bukhari, At-Tirmidhi and Al-Baihaqi defected it due to contradiction, and the Preserved is that it is from his action (PBUH) so see "Al-Irwa" (4/ 48 - 51).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 18 - (Encouragement to feed the fasting person) . 654 - (1) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Salman (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever feeds a fasting person with food and drink from Halal; the angels pray for him in the hours of the month of Ramadan, and Jibril prays for him on Laylat al-Qadr." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan in "Kitab Ath-Thawab"; except that he said: "And Jibril shakes his hand on Laylat al-Qadr." And he added in it: "And whomever Jibril (peace be upon him) shakes hands with, his heart softens, and his tears increase." He said: So I said: O Messenger of Allah! What do you see about one who (1) does not have? He said: "Then a handful of food." I said: What do you see if he does not have a morsel of bread? He said: "Then a sip of milk." He said: What do you see if he does not have? He said: "Then a drink of water." (Al-Qabsah) with un-dotted Sad: Is what the taker takes with his three fingertips. And the hadith of Salman which Ibn Khuzaimah narrated in his "Sahih" passed [Here/2], and in it: "Whoever feeds a fasting person in it - meaning in Ramadan - it is forgiveness for his sins, and freeing of his neck from the Fire, and he has the like of his reward without anything diminishing from his reward." They said: Not all of us find what to feed the fasting person? So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Allah gives this reward to one who feeds a fasting person a date or a drink of water, or a sip of milk" the Hadith.
foot_note: 1. Thus in the original, and perhaps the correct is (In - If) as in his saying following, and as it appeared in "Kamil Ibn Adi". See "Ad-Da'ifah" (1333).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 19 - (Encouragement for the fasting person when non-fasting people eat with him) . 655 - (1) [Weak] From Umm Umarah Al-Ansariyyah (may Allah be pleased with her): That the Prophet (PBUH) entered upon her so she presented food to him, he said: "Eat." She said: I am fasting. So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed the angels pray for the fasting person when food is eaten with him until they finish, - and perhaps he said: until they are satisfied -." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and Ibn Majah, and Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs", and At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Sahih Hadith". And in a narration by At-Tirmidhi: "The fasting person if the non-fasting people eat with him the angels pray for him" (1). 656 - (2) [Fabricated] And from Sulaiman bin Buraydah from his father who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said to Bilal: "Lunch, O Bilal!". He said: I am fasting. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "We eat our provisions, and the surplus of Bilal's provision is in Paradise. Did you feel, O Bilal! That the fasting person's bones glorify (make Tasbih), and the angels seek forgiveness for him as long as food is eaten with him?". Narrated by Ibn Majah and Al-Baihaqi; both from the narration of Baqiyyah: Muhammad bin Abdur-Rahman told us from Sulaiman. And this Muhammad bin Abdur-Rahman is unknown (2), and Baqiyyah is a Mudallis, and his declaration of hearing does not benefit with ignorance (Jahalah). And Allah knows best.
foot_note:
1. I say: It has a defect, which is the ignorance of (Layla) and the contradiction, so see "Ad-Da'ifah" (1332) if you wish. As for the ignorant ones, they took a middle path, neither considering the defect, nor imitating the authenticity of those who authenticated it! Rather they said: "Hasan"! Striking blindly!! 
2. I say: Rather he is known, for he is Al-Qushairi, Abu Hatim said: "He used to fabricate Hadith", see the third volume of "Ad-Da'ifah" (1331).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 20 - (Discouragement for the fasting person from backbiting, obscenity, lying, and the like) . 657 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Ubaidah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Fasting is a shield as long as he does not tear it." Narrated by An-Nasa'i with a Hasan chain, and Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and Al-Baihaqi. 658 - (2) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Awsat" (1) from the hadith of Abu Hurairah, and added: It was said: And with what does he tear it? He said: "With a lie or backbiting." 659 - (3) [Weak] And from Ubaid, the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH): That two women fasted, and a man said: O Messenger of Allah! Indeed there are two women here who have fasted, and they are about to die of thirst! So he turned away from him or remained silent, then he returned - and I think he said: - at midday (Hajirah), he said: O Prophet of Allah! Indeed by Allah they have died, or are about to die! He said: "Call them." He said: So they came. He said: So a cup or bowl was brought, so he said to one of them: "Vomit." So she vomited pus, blood, puss, and flesh, until she filled half the cup. Then he said to the other: "Vomit", so she vomited pus, blood, puss, fresh flesh, and other things, until she filled the cup. Then he said:
foot_note: 1. I say: In its chain (5/ 271/ 4533 and 8/ 398/ 7810) is Ar-Rabi' bin Badr, and he is Matruk, and At-Tabarani said: "No one else narrated it".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "These two fasted from what Allah made lawful for them, and broke their fast on what Allah made unlawful for them; one of them sat next to the other and they began eating the flesh of people." Narrated by Ahmad, and the wording is his, and by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and Abu Ya'la; all of them from a man who was not named, from Ubayd. 660 - (4) [Very Weak] It was also narrated by Abu Dawud At-Tayalisi, and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Dhamm Al-Ghibah" (Disparagement of Backbiting), and Al-Bayhaqi from the Hadith of Anas. It will come in the chapter of "Al-Ghibah" (Backbiting) God willing [23/ 19]. (Al-Uss) with a Damma on the 'Ain and Shadda on the Sin (both un-dotted): is a large drinking vessel. And (Al-Abit) with a Fatha on the 'Ain (un-dotted) followed by a Ba (single dot below) then Ya (two dots below) and Ta (un-dotted): is fresh [meat/blood].
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 21 - (Encouragement for I'tikaf (Seclusion in the Mosque) (1)). 661 - (1) [Fabricated] It was narrated from Ali bin Hussein from his father, may Allah be pleased with them, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever observes I'tikaf for ten days in Ramadan; it is like two Hajj and two Umrahs." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi. 662 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: That he was observing I'tikaf in the mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when a man came to him, greeted him, and then sat down. Ibn Abbas said to him: "O so-and-so! I see you depressed and sad." He said: "Yes, O cousin of the Messenger of Allah! So-and-so has a right of allegiance over me, and by the sanctity of the inhabitant of this grave (2), I am unable to fulfill it." Ibn Abbas said: "Shall I speak to him on your behalf?" He said: "If you wish." He said: So Ibn Abbas put on his sandals and left the mosque. The man said to him: "Did you forget what you were in?" He said: "No, but I heard the inhabitant of this grave, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and the time with him is recent - and his eyes shed tears - saying: 'Whoever walks to fulfill the need of his brother and achieves it; it is better for him than I'tikaf of ten years. And whoever observes I'tikaf for a day seeking the Countenance of Allah the Exalted; Allah will place between him and the Fire three trenches, [every trench] (3) further apart than the distance between the two horizons (East and West).'" Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Bayhaqi and the wording is his, and Al-Hakim briefly, and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad". Thus he said (4)! (Al-Hafiz said): "The Ahadith regarding the I'tikaf of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, are famous in the 'Sahihs' and others, and they are not under the condition of our book."
foot_note:
1. (I'tikaf) Linguistically: sticking to something and confining oneself to it, whether good or evil. Islamically: confining oneself to the mosque for worship in a specific manner, and it is a Sunnah, and becomes obligatory by vow according to consensus. This Sunnah has been abandoned in most Islamic lands, and we do not see anyone performing it, even the scholars of the Ummah and the role models among them, nor do we see anyone encouraging it or urging towards it. We ask Allah to guide Muslims to act according to what the Messenger, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, brought. End quote.
2. This is swearing by other than Allah, which is Shirk as will come in (23/ 126). The chain of the story has weakness, which I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5345). The author will repeat it without this part in (22/ 12).
3. Addition from At-Tabarani, and his narration will come there.
4. Referring to rejecting it, and Adh-Dhahabi declared it invalid. However, its brief wording has a witness from the Hadith of Ibn Umar, which I documented in "As-Sahihah" (906) with the wording: "a month" instead of: "ten years".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 22 - (Encouragement for Sadaqat al-Fitr and Clarifying its Emphasis (1)). 663 - (1) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Tha'labah - or Tha'labah bin Abdullah - bin Su'ayr (2) from his father who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "A Sa' of wheat or grain, for every two, young or old, free or slave, male or female, rich or poor. As for your rich, Allah purifies him, and as for your poor, Allah returns to him more than what he gave." Narrated by Ahmad and Abu Dawud (3). (Su'ayr): It is with the un-dotted 'Ain in the diminutive form. 664 - (2) [Weak] And from Jarir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The month of Ramadan is suspended between the heaven and the earth, it is not raised except by Zakat al-Fitr." Narrated by Abu Hafs bin Shahin in "Fada'il Ramadan" and he said: "Gharib Hadith, Jayyid Isnad" (4). 665 - (3) [Very Weak] And from Kathir bin Abdullah Al-Muzani from his father from his grandfather who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was asked about this verse {He has certainly succeeded who purifies himself (14) And mentions the name of his Lord and prays}? He said: "It was revealed regarding Zakat al-Fitr." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah in his "Sahih". (Al-Hafiz said): "Kathir bin Abdullah is flimsy."
foot_note:
1. The charity was attributed to Fitr (breaking fast) because it becomes obligatory upon breaking the fast of Ramadan. Ibn Qutaybah said: "What is meant by Zakat al-Fitr is the Zakat of souls (Zakat an-Nufus), taken from (Fitrah) which is the origin of creation. Its ruling is obligatory by consensus, and no consideration is given to those who differed and deviated. And Allah knows best."
2. Original: (Abi Su'ayr), and the correct is: "bin Su'ayr" dropping the Kunya particle, as pointed out by An-Naji. The three commentators overlooked it as is their habit!
3. I say: It contains someone with poor memory, and he was contradicted in its text by a truthful narrator who did not mention its second half: "rich or poor". As for the three ignorant ones, they said: "Hasan due to its supporting evidence"! Yet there is no supporting evidence for it in this complete form!
4. Thus he said: And it is questionable from two aspects: First, it contains an unknown narrator, for whose sake Ibn Al-Jawzi included it in "Al-Ilal Al-Mutanahiyah". See "Ad-Da'ifah" (No. 43). The three commentators confused things here and reversed the attribution, attributing this Hadith to Ibn Khuzaymah, and the one after it to Ibn Shahin!! And they equated them in weakness, while the second is severely weak as indicated by the author.

text: 10 - Book of the Two Eids (1) and Sacrifice (Udhiyah). 1 - (Encouragement to Enliven the Nights of the Two Eids). 666 - (1) [Fabricated] From Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Whoever stands (in prayer) during the nights of the two Eids seeking reward; his heart will not die on the day hearts die." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and its narrators are trustworthy; except that Baqiyyah is a Mudallis (obfuscator) and used 'an' (from) (2). 667 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever enlivens the five nights; Paradise becomes obligatory for him: The night of Tarwiyah, the night of Arafah, the night of Nahr (Sacrifice), the night of Fitr, and the night of the middle of Sha'ban." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. 668 - (3) [Fabricated] And from Ubadah bin As-Samit, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever enlivens the night of Fitr and the night of Adha; his heart will not die on the day hearts die." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and "Al-Kabir" (3).
foot_note:
1. Book of (The Two Eids): Dual of ('Eid); Eid al-Adha and Eid al-Fitr. Derived from ('Awd - return) because it recurs every year or because joy returns with its return. Or because of the abundance of Allah's returns (favors) upon His servants in it. Its plural is: (A'yad) with Ya, even though its root is Waw, because it is necessary in the singular, or to distinguish between it and 'Awad (sticks) of wood.
2. I say: He narrated it from Thawr bin Yazid, from Khalid bin Ma'dan, from Abu Umamah. Al-Asbahani narrated it in "At-Targhib" from another path from Umar bin Harun Al-Balkhi from Thawr bin Yazid with it. This Al-Balkhi is a liar, so it is feared that Baqiyyah narrated it from him and then obfuscated (did Tadlis). See "Ad-Da'ifah" (521 and 5163). The Hadith of Mu'adh with Al-Asbahani (367) and others contains someone accused of lying, and it is documented there under number (522).
3. And likewise in "Al-Majma" (2/ 198), and he mentioned that it contains (Umar bin Harun Al-Balkhi) mentioned just now. I am doubtful of its attribution to "Al-Awsat" for I did not see it in its "Index" nor in "Majma' Al-Bahrain". Yes, I found it in my "Mu'jam" which I compiled from the manuscripts of Az-Zahiriyyah attributed to At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" as in "Al-Muntaqa minhu" by Adh-Dhahabi (folio 2/ 1 - 2), so perhaps it is in some copies of it. Ibn Al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said in the context of the guidance of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, on the night of Nahr from "Zad Al-Ma'ad": "Then he slept, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, until morning, and he did not enliven that night, nor is anything authentic from him regarding enlivening the nights of the two Eids."

Narrated by Ibn Majah, and At-Tirmidhi who said: "Hasan Gharib Hadith", and Al-Hakim who said: "Sahih Al-Isnad". At-Tirmidhi said: And it is narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; that he said: "The Udhiyah is for its owner a good deed for every hair." 672 - (2) [Fabricated] And this Hadith which At-Tirmidhi indicated was narrated by Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim and others; all of them from 'A'idhullah from Abu Dawud from Zaid bin Arqam who said: The companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: O Messenger of Allah! text: performed Hajj to this House before you by two thousand years, - Anas said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: And the House on that day was a red hollow ruby, having two doors, whoever circumambulates sees who is inside the House, and whoever is inside the House sees who circumambulates -, so Adam completed his rituals. Then Allah the Exalted revealed to him: O Adam! Have you completed your rituals? He said: Yes, O Lord! He said: So ask your need, you will be given. He said: My need is that You forgive me my sin and the sin of my child. He said: As for your sin O Adam! We forgave it when you fell into your sin; and as for the sin of your child; whoever of them knows Me, believes in Me, and confirms My messengers and My Book; We forgave him his sin." Narrated by Al-Asbahani also. 698 - (15) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Ja'far Muhammad bin Ali from his father from his grandfather who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "There is no male servant nor female servant who is stingy with spending what he spends in what pleases Allah; except that he spends multiples of it in what displeases Allah. And there is no servant who abandons Hajj for a worldly need, except that he sees its annihilation before that need is fulfilled - meaning the obligatory Hajj - and there is no servant who abandons walking in the need of his Muslim brother, whether it is fulfilled or not; except that he is afflicted with assisting in a sin against him, and he is not rewarded in it." Narrated by Al-Asbahani also, and it contains Nakarah (denouncement). (Yadinna) with Dad Mu'jamah, meaning: becomes stingy and miserly. 699 - (16) [Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed the Kaaba has a tongue and two lips, and it complained saying: O Lord! My visitors have become few, and my pilgrims have become few. So Allah (Azza wa Jal) revealed: I am creating humans who are humble, prostrating, yearning for you as the pigeon yearns for its eggs."
foot_note: None

text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 700 - (17) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed David the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: My God! What is for your servants upon You if they visit You in Your House? He said: Every visitor has a right upon the visited. O David! Indeed they have a right upon Me that I grant them wellness in the world, and forgive them when I meet them." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" also. 701 - (18) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Sahl bin Sa'd, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "No Muslim goes out in the way of Allah as a Mujahid or a pilgrim raising his voice (Muhill) or saying Talbiyah; except that the sun sets with his sins and he emerges from them." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" also. 702 - (19) [Weak] And Abu Al-Qasim Al-Asbahani narrated it from the Hadith of Anas bin Malik similarly, [meaning the Hadith of Ubadah bin As-Samit which is in "As-Sahih"]; except that he said in it: "As for your standing at Arafat; indeed Allah the Exalted looks upon the people of Arafat and says: My servants have come to Me disheveled, dusty, they came to Me from every deep valley. He boasts of them to the angels. Even if you had sins like the sands of Alij, the stars of the sky, and the drops of the sea and rain; Allah forgives you. As for your throwing of pebbles; it is stored for you with your Lord when you are most in need of it. As for your shaving your head; for every hair that falls from you, you will have light on the Day of Resurrection. As for your circumambulation of the House; you return emerging from your sins as the day your mother gave birth to you."
foot_note: None

text: 703 - (20) [Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever goes out in this manner for Hajj or Umrah and dies in it, will not be presented (for account) nor held accountable, and it will be said to him: Enter Paradise." She said: And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed Allah boasts of those who circumambulate." Narrated by At-Tabarani, Abu Ya'la, Ad-Daraqutni, and Al-Bayhaqi. 704 - (21) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed this House is a pillar of the pillars of Islam. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". (Ad-Di'amah) with Kasra on Dal Muhmalah: is the column of the house and the tent. 705 - (22) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from him also, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever dies on the way to Makkah, going or returning; will not be presented (for account), nor held accountable, [and] (1) is forgiven." Narrated by Al-Asbahani.
foot_note: 1. Addition from "Targhib Al-Asbahani" (1/ 441), the narrator explicitly mentioned doubt in it, and it contains someone who fabricates Hadith. text: 2 - (Encouragement for Spending in Hajj and Umrah, and What Came Regarding One Who Spends in Them from Unlawful Wealth). 706 - (1) [Weak] And from Buraidah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Spending in Hajj is like spending in the way of Allah; seven hundred fold." Narrated by Ahmad, At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad's chain is Hasan (1). 707 - (2) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated in "Al-Awsat" also from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Hajj in the way of Allah, spending in it (2); the Dirham is worth seven hundred." 708 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The pilgrims and performers of Umrah are the delegation of Allah. If they ask they are given, if they call they are answered, and if they spend He replaces it for them. By the One in whose Hand is the soul of Abu Al-Qasim! No one saying Takbir says Takbir on a highland (Nashz), nor does one saying Talbiyah say Talbiyah on an elevation of elevations; except that what is before him says Talbiyah and Takbir; until the earth ends." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi.
foot_note:
1. I say: It contains Ata bin As-Sa'ib, and he had become confused, and another person in whom there is ignorance. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3530). 
2. Original: (Spending in Hajj is like spending in the way of Allah), and the correction is from "Awsat At-Tabarani" (6/ 324/ 5690), and "Majma' Al-Bahrain" and "Majma' Az-Zawa'id". The three commentators attributed it to him yet they did not correct it! Adding insult to injury, they said: "Hasan due to its preceding witness", meaning the Hadith of Buraidah, and their path is one, and it contains ignorance. Despite their quoting it from Al-Haythami, they stubbornly said: "Hasan"!! It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3530).

text: (An-Nashz) with Fatha on Nun and Sukun on Shin Mu'jamah (1) and with Zai: is the elevated place. 709 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The pilgrims and performers of Umrah are the delegation of Allah. He gives them what they asked, answers what they called for, and replaces for them what they spent; the Dirham for a thousand thousand Dirhams." He said: The valley of (Usfan). Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi; both from the narration of Zam'ah bin Salih from Salamah bin Wahram, and there is no harm in their Hadith in follow-ups (Mutaba'at), and Ibn Khuzaymah and others have used them as proof. (Usfan) with Damma on 'Ain and Sukun on Sin Muhmalah: A place two stages from Makkah. And (Al-Bakarat) plural of (Bakrah) with Sukun on Kaf: which is the young female camel. And (An-Nimarat) (1) with Kasra on Mim plural of (Nimrah): which is a striped garment. 714 - (2) [Weak] And from him from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Moses performed Hajj on a red bull, wearing a Qatwani cloak." Narrated by At-Tabarani from the narration of Laith bin Abi Sulaim, and the rest of its narrators are trustworthy. 715 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both: That a man said to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: Who is the pilgrim? He said:

text: "The unkempt, the unperfumed"... (1) He said: And what is the way (Sabil)? He said: "Provisions and a mount." Narrated by Ibn Majah with a Hasan chain. And At-Tirmidhi has from him: A man came and said: O Messenger of Allah! What makes Hajj obligatory? He said: "Provisions and a mount." And he said: "Hasan Hadith". Narrated by Ahmad, and Ibn Majah, and the wording is his. 718 - (3) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Kabir", and Al-Bayhaqi from the Hadith of Amir bin Rabi'ah, may Allah be pleased with him (2). [Very Weak] (*) And the Hadith of Sahl bin Sa'd proceeded in the first chapter [Number 19], containing: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "No Muslim goes out in the way of Allah as a Mujahid, or a pilgrim raising his voice (Muhill) or saying Talbiyah; except that the sun sets with his sins and he emerges from them." text: 6 - (Encouragement to enter Ihram from Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa). 719 - (1) [Weak] From Umm Hakim bint Abi Umayyah bin Al-Akhnas from Umm Salamah, may Allah be pleased with her; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever enters Ihram for Umrah from (Bayt Al-Maqdis) (1); he is forgiven." Narrated by Ibn Majah with a Sahih chain (2). And in a narration of his: She said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever enters Ihram for Umrah from Bayt Al-Maqdis; it is an expiation for what preceded it of sins." She said: So my mother went out from Bayt Al-Maqdis for Umrah. And Ibn Hibban narrated it in his "Sahih", and his wording is: She said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Whoever enters Ihram from Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa for Umrah; his past sins are forgiven." He said: So Umm Hakim rode to Bayt Al-Maqdis until she entered Ihram for Umrah from there. And Abu Dawud and Al-Bayhaqi narrated it, and their wording is:
foot_note:
1. (Bayt Al-Maqdis): It is with Fatha on Mim and Sukun on Qaf and Kasra on Dal lightened, or with Damma on Mim and Fatha on Qaf and Dal with Shadda; its meaning is the Purified place by which one is purified from sins. It is a well-known city, and it has many virtues singled out in writing, some of which will come in Chapter (14), the most important being Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa which is one of the three mosques to which journeys are undertaken. The Jews have occupied it among what they occupied of (Palestine), may Allah return it to the Muslims; as He returned it to them after the Crusaders occupied it. But Allah says: {Indeed, Allah will not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves}. So Muslims must change what is in themselves of deviant beliefs and bad morals, if they truly want Allah Almighty to change what has befallen them. 
2. I say: How so when it contains ignorance, and confusion in its text and chain as the author himself clarified in "Mukhtasar As-Sunan"?! Some of it appears to you from the narrations cited by the author here. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (211).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever enters Ihram for Hajj or Umrah from Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa to Al-Masjid Al-Haram; his past and future sins are forgiven, or Paradise becomes obligatory for him." The narrator doubted which of the two [he said]. And in a narration of Al-Bayhaqi: She said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Whoever enters Ihram for Hajj and Umrah from Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa to Al-Masjid Al-Haram; his past and future sins are forgiven, and Paradise becomes obligatory for him" (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: There is no significant difference between this narration and the one before it; except that there is no doubt in it. And that is of no avail because the path is one, and it contains ignorance and confusion as I mentioned shortly before.

text: 7 - (Encouragement for Tawaf (Circumambulation) and Touching the Black Stone and the Yemeni Corner, and What Came Regarding Their Virtue and the Virtue of the Station (Maqam) and Entering the House). 720 - (1) [Weak] He said [meaning Ibn Umar]: And I heard him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "No man (1) raises a foot nor places it; except that ten good deeds are written for him, ten bad deeds are removed from him, and he is raised ten degrees." Narrated by Ahmad, and this is his wording. 721 - (2) [Weak] And from Humaid bin Abi Sawiyyah who said: I heard Ibn Hisham ask Ata bin Abi Rabah about the Yemeni Corner while he was circumambulating the House? Ata said: Abu Hurairah told me: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Seventy angels are entrusted with it. Whoever says: O Allah I ask You for pardon and well-being in the world and the Hereafter, {Our Lord, give us in this world [that which is] good and in the Hereafter [that which is] good and protect us from the punishment of the Fire}, they say: (Amin)." When he reached the Black Corner he said: O Abu Muhammad! What reached you regarding this Black Corner? Ata said: Abu Hurairah told me; that he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Whoever negotiates with it, is only negotiating with the Hand of the Most Merciful." Ibn Hisham said to him: O Abu Muhammad! And the Tawaf? Ata said: Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, told me; that he heard the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Whoever circumambulates the House seven times and does not speak except with (Subhan Allah, and Al-Hamdu Lillah, and La
foot_note: 1. Meaning the circumambulator around the Kaaba as indicated by the narration of Ibn Khuzaymah coming in the other book. It came absolutely in another Hadith, but without doubling for writing, and placing and raising as in this Hadith of Ibn Umar in "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: ilaha illa Allah, and Allahu Akbar, and La Hawla wa La Quwwata illa Billah); ten bad deeds are erased from him, ten good deeds are written for him, and he is raised ten degrees by it. And whoever circumambulates and speaks while in that state; wades in mercy with his feet like one wading in water with his feet." Narrated by Ibn Majah from Ismail bin Ayyash: Humaid bin Abi Sawiyyah told me. And some of our Sheikhs graded it Hasan (1). 722 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Allah sends down one hundred and twenty mercies every day upon the pilgrims of His Sacred House; sixty for the circumambulators, forty for those praying, and twenty for those looking." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi with a Hasan chain (2). 723 - (4) [Weak] And from him who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever circumambulates the House fifty times; emerges from his sins as the day his mother gave birth to him." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "Gharib Hadith, I asked Muhammad - meaning Al-Bukhari - about this Hadith? He said: It is only narrated from Ibn Abbas as his saying." 724 - (5) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: "Whoever performs ablution and perfects the ablution, then comes to the Corner to touch it; he wades in mercy. If he touches it and says: (Bismillah, wa Allahu Akbar, I testify that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone, with no partner, and I testify that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger); mercy overwhelms him. If he circumambulates the House; Allah writes for him for every foot seventy thousand good deeds, and removes from him seventy thousand
foot_note:
1. I say: Al-Hafiz An-Naji disapproved of grading it Hasan, and why not, when Ismail bin Ayyash is weak in narrating from Hijazis, and this is one of them; for Humaid bin Abi Sawiyyah is Makkan, along with the fact that he himself is also weak! And Ismail was alone in narrating it as At-Tabarani said in "Al-Awsat" (9/ 183).

text: bad deeds, raised for him seventy thousand degrees, and he is granted intercession for seventy of his household. If he comes to the Station (Maqam) of Abraham and prays two rak'ahs there with faith and anticipation of reward; Allah writes for him the freeing of four [teen] (1) slaves from the children of Ismail, and he emerges from his sins as the day his mother gave birth to him." Narrated by Abu Al-Qasim Al-Asbahani as Mawquf. 725 - (6) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the Hadith of Ibn Abbas which is in "As-Sahih"] in "Al-Kabir", and his wording is: "Allah will resurrect the Black Stone and the Yemeni Corner on the Day of Resurrection, having two eyes, two tongues, and two lips, bearing witness of fulfillment for those who touched them" (2). 726 - (7) [Weak] And At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and he added [meaning in the Hadith of Ibn Amr which is in "As-Sahih"]: "It testifies for the one who touched it with truth, and it is the Right Hand of Allah (Azza wa Jal), with which He shakes hands with His creation." And Ibn Khuzaymah in his "Sahih", and he added: "It speaks on behalf of the one who touched it with intention, and it is the Right Hand of Allah with which He shakes hands with His creation." 727 - (8) [Weak] And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Call this Stone to witness good; for it is an intercessor whose intercession is accepted on the Day of Resurrection, having a tongue and two lips bearing witness for the one who touched it." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and its narrators are trustworthy; except that Al-Walid bin Abbad is unknown.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 728 - (9) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the Hadith of Ibn Abbas which is in "As-Sahih"] in "Al-Awsat" and "Al-Kabir" with a Hasan chain, and his wording is: He said: "The Black Stone is from the stones of Paradise, and there is nothing on earth from Paradise other than it. It was white like crystal (Maha), and were it not for what touched it of the filth of Jahiliyyah (pre-Islamic ignorance), no afflicted person would have touched it except that he would be cured." And in a narration of Ibn Khuzaymah he said: "The Black Stone is a white ruby from the rubies of Paradise, only the sins of the polytheists blackened it. It will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection like Uhud; bearing witness for those who touched it and kissed it from the people of the world." (Al-Maha) shortened, plural of (Mahah): which is crystal. 729 - (10) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: "The Black Corner descended from the sky, and was placed on Abu Qubais as if it were a white crystal. It remained for forty years, then it was placed on the foundations of Abraham." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", as Mawquf with a Sahih chain. 730 - (11) [Very Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, faced the Stone, then placed his lips on it weeping for a long time. Then he turned, and there was Umar bin Al-Khattab weeping. He said: "O Umar! Here tears are shed." Narrated by Ibn Majah, Ibn Khuzaymah in his "Sahih", and Al-Hakim who authenticated it, and from his path Al-Bayhaqi and he said: "Muhammad bin Awn was alone in narrating it."
