text: 8 - (Encouragement for Righteous Deeds in the Ten Days of Dhul-Hijjah, and its Virtue). 733 - (1) [Weak] And At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" with a Jayyid (good) chain [meaning from Ibn Abbas as Marfu'], and his wording is: He said: "There are no days greater with Allah nor are deeds in them more beloved to Allah than the days of the ten, so increase in them Tasbih (Glory be to Allah), Tahmid (Praise be to Allah), Tahlil (There is no god but Allah), and Takbir (Allah is Greatest)." 734 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "There are no days more beloved to Allah that He be worshipped in than the ten of Dhul-Hijjah; fasting every day of them is equivalent to fasting a year, and standing every night of them is equivalent to standing the Night of Decree (Lailat al-Qadr)." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, and Al-Bayhaqi. At-Tirmidhi said: "Gharib Hadith, we do not know it except from the narration of Mas'ud bin Wasil, from An-Nahhas bin Qahm. He did not know it from other than this route." 735 - (3) [Weak] (Al-Hafiz said): Al-Bayhaqi and others narrated from Yahya bin Isa Ar-Ramli: Yahya bin Ayyub Al-Bajali told us from Adi bin Thabit - and these three are famous trustworthy narrators about whom there is some discussion (1) - from Sa'id bin Jubayr from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "There are no days better with Allah, nor are deeds in them more beloved to Allah (Azza wa Jal) than these days - meaning the ten -, so increase in them Tahlil, Takbir, and remembrance of Allah. Indeed fasting a day of them is equivalent to fasting a year, and deeds in them are multiplied seven hundred fold."
foot_note: 1. Up to here ends Al-Hafiz's discussion on the Hadith of Abu Hurairah in the original, and likewise in Amarah's edition. Contrary to the manuscript! Thus the Hadith became, due to their poor printing, without documentation or chain!

He said: A man said: O Messenger of Allah! Are they better or their number in Jihad in the way of Allah? He said: "They are better than their number in Jihad in the way of Allah. Allah, Blessed and Exalted, descends to the lowest heaven, and boasts to the people of the heaven about the people of the earth, saying: Look at My servants, they have come to Me disheveled, dusty, exposed to the sun (Dahin), they came from every deep valley, hoping for My mercy, and they have not seen My punishment. So no day is seen with more freeing from the Fire than the Day of Arafah." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, Al-Bazzar, Ibn Khuzaymah, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" and the wording is his, and Al-Bayhaqi and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "When it is the Day of Arafah, Allah, Blessed and Exalted, boasts of them to the angels, saying: Look at My servants, they have come to Me disheveled, dusty, exposed to the sun from every deep valley. I call you to witness that I have forgiven them. The angels say: Among them is so-and-so who is burdened with sins (Murahhaq), and so-and-so. He said: Allah (Azza wa Jal) says: I have forgiven them." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "There is no day with more freeing from the Fire than the Day of Arafah." Ibn Khuzaymah's wording is similar, differing only in a letter or two. (Al-Murahhaq): Is the one who commits prohibitions and perpetrates corruptions.
foot_note: 1. Up to here the Hadith is Sahih due to external evidence (Li-Ghayrihi), and it has preceded in "As-Sahih", in the chapter before this. So take note.

And that is only because of what he sees of the descent of mercy, and Allah's overlooking of great sins. Except what was seen on the Day of Badr, for indeed he saw Gabriel arranging the angels (1)." Narrated by Malik and Al-Bayhaqi from his path and others, and it is Mursal. (Adhar) with Dal and Ha Muhmalah followed by Ra: Meaning furthest and most humiliated. 740 - (3) [Weak] And from Ubadah bin As-Samit, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said on the Day of Arafah: "O people! Indeed Allah (Azza wa Jal) has bestowed favor (Tatawwala) (2) upon you on this day and forgiven you, except for the grievances among you. And He has granted your evildoers to your good-doers, and your wicked to your righteous, and given your good-doers what they asked. So move on in the name of Allah." When he was at (Jam') (3) he said: "Indeed Allah (Azza wa Jal) has forgiven your righteous ones, and allowed your righteous ones to intercede for your wicked ones. Mercy descends and encompasses them, then forgiveness spreads in the earth, falling upon every repentant one who guarded his tongue and hand. Iblis and his soldiers are on the mountains of Arafat looking at what Allah does with them. When mercy descends, Iblis and his soldiers call out with woe and destruction."
foot_note:
1. Meaning: arranging them, driving them, and lining them up for war, as if he is restraining them from separating and scattering. And Allah knows best. 
2. Meaning: He bestowed favor upon them on this day... etc. from (At-Tawl) meaning: favor. And his saying: (except the Tabi'at) meaning: injustices/grievances. And Allah knows best. 
3. A proper name for Muzdalifah. The three ignorant ones interpreted it (2/ 154) as Arafat!! That is the extent of their knowledge!

So his panic that I saw made me laugh." Narrated by Ibn Majah from Abdullah bin Kinanah bin Abbas bin Mirdas; that his father informed him from his father. So Allah revealed to him: I have done so, except for the oppression of some of them against others. As for their sins between Me and them, I have forgiven them. He said: O Lord! Indeed You are capable of rewarding this oppressed one with good for his grievance, and forgiving this oppressor. He did not answer him that evening. When it was the morning of (Al-Muzdalifah) he repeated the supplication, so Allah answered him: I have forgiven them. He said: So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, smiled. Some of his companions said to him: O Messenger of Allah! You smiled in an hour you did not used to smile in? He said: "I smiled at the enemy of Allah, Iblis. Indeed when he knew that Allah had answered me regarding my Ummah, he fell calling out with woe and destruction, and throwing dust on his head." text: 751 - (2) [Weak] And from Suwaid bin Sa'id who said: I saw Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak in Makkah come to Zamzam water and ask for a drink from it, then he faced the Kaaba and said: O Allah, indeed Ibn Abi Al-Mawali told us from Muhammad bin Al-Munkadir from Jabir; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Zamzam water is for whatever it is drunk for." And this, I drink it for the thirst of the Day of Resurrection. Then he drank. Narrated by Ahmad [and Al-Khatib in his "Tarikh"] with a Sahih chain (1), and Al-Bayhaqi who said: "Gharib from the Hadith of Ibn Abi Al-Mawali from Ibn Al-Munkadir, Suwaid was alone in narrating it from Ibn Al-Mubarak from this path from him" End quote. And Ahmad and Ibn Majah narrated the Marfu' part of it (2) from Abdullah bin Al-Mu'ammal; that he heard Abu Az-Zubayr
foot_note:
1. Original: "Narrated by Ahmad with a Sahih chain." And on its margin in the printed version: a blank space was left here and it was written on it that it is blank in all copies, except that our unique copy has no deficiency, and it mentions that the one who narrated the Hadith is Ahmad. And Allah knows best. I say: This is an error, for the Hadith was never narrated by Ahmad with this completeness, rather he narrated the Marfu' part of it only as the author will clarify. So the unique copy is not reliable, especially with its contradiction to all copies, including the Zahiriyyah manuscript (folio 140/ 2), in which it is: "Narrated with a Sahih chain", thus he did not mention the narrator. For that reason, An-Naji said in "Al-Ujalah" (folio 135/ 1): "Thus in all copies, and he intended: Al-Khatib in his "Tarikh", but what you see intervened between this and what he mentioned, so ambiguity and doubt occurred." I say: He remained silent about his saying: "with a Sahih chain", and that is an illusion from both of them. How so when it is from the narration of Suwaid bin Sa'id as you see, and he is weak. Al-Hafiz said: "Truthful in himself, except that he became blind and started accepting what was not from his Hadith, and Ibn Ma'in spoke harshly about him." Despite this, the three graded it Hasan! But the Marfu' part of it is established; because it came from another path as you see in the book. Abu Az-Zubayr explicitly mentioned hearing in it with Ibn Majah and Al-Bayhaqi in another narration from him, which is documented in "Al-Ahadith As-Sahihah" (883), and for that reason I included it in "As-Sahih" here. 
2. This portion of it is established.

text: 14 - (Encouragement for Prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram, the Mosque of Medina, Bayt Al-Maqdis, and Quba). 755 - (1) [Denounced] And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Whoever prays in my Mosque forty prayers without missing a prayer; is written for him freedom from the Fire, freedom from punishment, and he is absolved of hypocrisy." Narrated by Ahmad and its narrators are narrators of the Sahih (1), and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". It is with At-Tirmidhi with other than this wording. [Passed in "As-Sahih" 5 - Prayer/ 16]. 756 - (2) [Very Weak] And from him who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "A man's prayer in his house is (equal to) one prayer, his prayer in the mosque of the tribes is (equal to) twenty-five prayers, a prayer in the mosque in which congregation is held is (equal to) five hundred prayers, a prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa is (equal to) fifty thousand prayers, a prayer in my Mosque is (equal to) fifty thousand prayers, and a prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram is (equal to) one hundred thousand prayers." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and its narrators are trustworthy; except that Abu Al-Khattab Ad-Dimashqi's biography is not present with me now, and none of the authors of the six books narrated from him except Ibn Majah. And Allah knows best. 757 - (3) [Denounced] And from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram is (equal to) one hundred thousand prayers, prayer in my Mosque is (equal to) one thousand prayers, and prayer in Bayt Al-Maqdis is (equal to) five hundred prayers." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Ibn Khuzaymah in his "Sahih", and his wording is: He said:
foot_note: 1. I say: No, rather it contains an unknown person and denouncement in wording and meaning. Its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (364). As for the three ignorant ones, they graded it Hasan!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "A prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram is better than in other mosques by one hundred thousand prayers, a prayer in the Mosque of Medina is better than a thousand prayers in others, and a prayer in the Mosque of Bayt Al-Maqdis is better than in other mosques by five hundred prayers." Al-Bazzar narrated it, and his wording is: He said: "The virtue of prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram over others is one hundred thousand prayers, in my Mosque one thousand prayers, and in the Mosque of Bayt Al-Maqdis five hundred prayers." And Al-Bazzar said: "Its chain is Hasan." Thus he said (1). 758 - (4) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Bilal bin Al-Harith, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Ramadan in Medina is better than a thousand Ramadans in other lands, and a Friday in Medina is better than a thousand Fridays in other lands." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 759 - (5) [Anomalous] And from Abu Hurairah and Aisha, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "A prayer in my Mosque is better than a thousand prayers in other mosques, except Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa" (2). Narrated by Ahmad, and its narrators are narrators of "As-Sahih":
foot_note:
1. I say: He indicates the rejection of his grading it Hasan, and it is so; because it contains (two weak narrators) as I explained in "Al-Irwa" (4/ 342 - 343), then in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5355). And its text is Munkar (denounced); for contradicting the Hadith: Prayer in the Prophet's Mosque is better than four prayers in Bayt Al-Maqdis. It is here in "As-Sahih". Despite this weakness and denouncement, the ignorant ones graded it Hasan! 
2. I say: This exception is an error from some narrators in Ahmad (No. 7725), and the correct is: "Except Al-Masjid Al-Haram" as preceded in several Ahadith from Abu Hurairah and others in "As-Sahih". Ahmad also narrated it correctly with this same chain (No. 7720), so the author should not have included it due to the obviousness of its error.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 760 - (6) [Very Weak] And from Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Prayer in this Mosque of mine is better than a thousand prayers in others except Al-Masjid Al-Haram, Friday in this Mosque of mine is better than a thousand Fridays in others except Al-Masjid Al-Haram, and the month of Ramadan in this Mosque of mine is better than a thousand months of Ramadan in others except Al-Masjid Al-Haram." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi (1). 761 - (7) [Very Weak] And he and others also narrated it from the Hadith of Ibn Umar similarly (2). And the Hadith of Bilal preceded briefly [two Hadiths before]. 762 - (8) [Very Weak] He [Al-Bayhaqi] said: "And Yusuf bin Tahman narrated it [meaning the Hadith of Sahl bin Hunaif which is in "As-Sahih"] from Abu Umamah bin Sahl from his father from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with its meaning, and added: 'And whoever goes out upon purity intending nothing but this Mosque of mine - meaning the Mosque of Medina - to pray in it; it is like the status of a Hajj.' (Al-Hafiz said): "Yusuf bin Tahman was alone with this addition, and he is flimsy. And Allah knows best." 763 - (9) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated in "Al-Kabir" from him who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever performs ablution and perfects the ablution then enters the Mosque of Quba, and bows four rak'ahs in it; that is equal to freeing a slave."
foot_note:
1. I say: In "Ash-Shu'ab" (3/ 486/ 4147), and it contains (Abu Al-Hasan Muhammad bin Nafi' bin Ishaq Al-Khuza'i) whom I did not know, and others narrated it, and its chain contains an abandoned narrator. See "Irwa Al-Ghalil" (No. - 1130). 
2. Al-Bayhaqi said (4148): "Its chain is weak at once (Bi-marrah)."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 764 - (10) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ka'b bin Ujrah, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever performs ablution and perfects the ablution then intends the Mosque of Quba desiring nothing else, and nothing drives him to go early except prayer in the Mosque of Quba, so he prays four rak'ahs in it, reciting in every rak'ah the Mother of the Quran (Al-Fatihah); he has like the reward of a performer of Umrah to the House of Allah." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and this addition in the Hadith is Munkar (1).
foot_note: 1. Meaning his saying: "four rak'ahs", and the Hadith is Sahih without it, so refer to "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 15 - (Encouragement to Reside in Medina until Death, and What Came Regarding its Virtue, and the Virtue of Uhud and Wadi Al-Aqiq). Al-Hafiz said: [Fabricated] There preceded in the chapter before it what fits in its thread and is close to it, the Hadith of Bilal bin Al-Harith: "Ramadan in Medina is better than a thousand Ramadans in other lands, and a Friday in Medina is better than a thousand Fridays in other lands." [Very Weak] (*) And the Hadith of Jabir also, containing: "Except Al-Masjid Al-Haram." 765 - (1) [Denounced] And from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Prices rose in Medina, and hardship intensified, so the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Be patient and rejoice, for I have blessed your Sa' and your Mudd. Eat and do not separate; for the food of one is enough for two, and the food of two is enough for four, and the food of four is enough for five and six. Indeed blessing is in the Jama'ah (group). Whoever is patient upon its hardship and severity; I will be an intercessor and witness for him on the Day of Resurrection. Whoever leaves it desiring other than it; Allah will replace him with someone better than him in it. And whoever intends ill for it; Allah will dissolve him as salt dissolves in water." Narrated by Al-Bazzar with a Jayyid chain (1).
foot_note: 1. Thus he said which is very strange, because Al-Bazzar commented on it clarifying its weakness saying: "Amr bin Dinar was alone in narrating it, and he is lenient, and his Hadiths are not shared by anyone." Stranger than it is the statement of Al-Haythami: "Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and its men are men of the Sahih"! The reason for this is that they thought this (Amr bin Dinar) is the Makkan trustworthy one by agreement, while he is (Amr bin Dinar Qahraman Al Az-Zubayr) who is weak by agreement. Ibn Hibban even said: "He is alone with fabricated narrations from trustworthy narrators". Most of what is in this Hadith came scattered in authentic Ahadith, so he composed this from them - intentionally or inadvertently - and added to it what is not in them. I have explained all that in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5532). (*) The preparer of the book for Ash-Shamilah said: This ruling fell from the printed version, and Sheikh Mashhur mentioned it in his edition of At-Targhib, and said he took it from the previous chapter, where it was mentioned under number (760).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 766 - (2) [Weak] And from Hatib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever visits me after my death, it is as if he visited me during my life. And whoever dies in one of the two Harams will be resurrected among the safe ones on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi from a man from the family of Hatib - whom he did not name - from Hatib. 767 - (3) [Weak] And from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Whoever visits my grave - or he said: whoever visits me - I will be an intercessor or witness for him on the Day of Resurrection. And whoever dies in one of the two Harams, Allah will resurrect him among the safe ones on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi (1) and others from a man from the family of Umar whom he did not name, from Umar. 768 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever dies in one of the two Harams will be resurrected among the safe ones on the Day of Resurrection. And whoever visits me seeking reward to Medina will be in my neighborhood on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi also. 769 - (5) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Medina is the dome of Islam, the abode of Faith, the land of Migration, and the dwelling of the lawful and forbidden." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", with a chain that is not bad (2). 770 - (6) [Very Denounced] And from Sa'd, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, returned from Tabuk, men from those who stayed behind from the believers met him,
foot_note:
1. The author went too far in sourcing, for the Hadith is in "Musnad At-Tayalisi" (12/ 65). Moreover, this and the one before it are one Hadith in whose chain one of its unknown narrators became confused as clarified in "Al-Irwa" (4/ 333 - 335). I referred to this in "Ad-Da'ifah" under Hadith (6830). 
2. Thus he said, and it contains two weakened narrators, as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (No. - 761).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: so they stirred up dust. Some of those with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, covered their noses. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, removed the veil from his face; and said: "By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, indeed in its dust is a cure from every disease - he said: I think he mentioned - and from leprosy and vitiligo." Razin Al-Abdari mentioned it in his "Jami'", and I did not see it in the fundamentals (sources) (1). 771 - (7) [Weak] And from him [meaning Anas bin Malik] who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Uhud is a mountain that loves us and we love it. If you come to it, eat from its trees, even from its thorns (Idhah)." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" from the narration of Kathir bin Zaid. And narrated by Ibn Majah from the narration of Muhammad bin Ishaq from Abdullah bin Muktif from Anas - and this is a flimsy chain - who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed Mount Uhud loves us and we love it, and it is upon a garden gate (Tur'ah) from the gates of Paradise. And 'Air is upon a gate from the gates of Hell." (The Dictator) may Allah be pleased with him said: "It has been authenticated from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, from more than one path and from a group of Companions; that he said to Uhud: 'This is a mountain that loves us and we love it.' The addition to this with At-Tabarani is very strange."
foot_note: 1. I say: Sheikh An-Naji supported him (folio 136/ 2); but he followed it with narrations he mentioned similarly, and did not comment on them at all, and they are very weak, some weaker than others, containing liars and abandoned narrators as I detailed in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3957 and 6614). Yet the ignorant ones relied on his vague narrations and prefaced the quotation from him by saying: "Hasan due to its witnesses"!! As if due to their extreme ignorance they do not know that lepers were in Medina, and the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, commanded avoiding their contagion in authentic Ahadith in the "Sahihain" and others.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Idhah) preceded (1). And (At-Tur'ah) with Damma on Ta Muthannah Fawq and Sukun on Ra followed by 'Ain Muhmalah open: is the garden, and also the gate, and it is the intended meaning in this Hadith. 772 - (8) [Weak] It came explained in the Hadith of Abu Anbas bin Jabr, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to Uhud: "This is a mountain that loves us and we love it, upon a gate from the gates of Paradise. And this 'Air is a mountain that hates us and we hate it, upon a gate from the gates of the Fire." Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat". 773 - (9) [Weak] And it was narrated from Sahl bin Sa'd, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Uhud is a pillar from the pillars of Paradise." Narrated by Abu Ya'la and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 774 - (10) [Very Denounced] And from Salamah bin Al-Akwa', may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I used to hunt wild animals and catch them, and gift their meat to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "If you were to hunt them at (Al-Aqiq) (2) I would bid you farewell when you go, and meet you when you come; for I love Al-Aqiq." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" with a Hasan chain (3).
foot_note:
1. Meaning in "As-Sahih / Third Hadith", and it is with Kasra on 'Ain Muhmalah and with Dad Mu'jamah and after the Alif is Ha, plural of (Idhahah), which is the Khamt tree. 
2. A valley near (Dhul-Hulaifah). 
3. I say: No; for it contains Musa bin Muhammad At-Tamimi, and he is as Al-Bukhari said: "Munkar Al-Hadith". I documented it in "Ad-Da'ifah" under number (5869).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 16 - (Warning against Frightening the People of Medina or Intending them with Evil). 775 - (1) [Weak] And in a narration of At-Tabarani [meaning from the Hadith of As-Sa'ib bin Khallad from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him] he said: "Whoever frightens the people of Medina, Allah will frighten him on the Day of Resurrection, and be angry with him (1) and will not accept from him any obligatory or voluntary deed." 776 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever harms the people of Medina, Allah harms him, and upon him is the curse of Allah, the angels and all people. No obligatory or voluntary deed will be accepted from him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 777 - (3) [Weak] And from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "O Allah, suffice against whoever overwhelms them with harm - meaning the people of Medina -, and no one intends it with evil; except that Allah dissolves him as salt dissolves in water." Narrated by Al-Bazzar with a Hasan chain (2), and its end is in "As-Sahih" similarly. And (Dahamahum) vocalized; meaning: overwhelmed them quickly.
foot_note:
1. His saying: "and be angry with him" was not mentioned in the paths of the Hadith except from the narration of (Musa bin Ubaidah) with At-Tabarani (7/ 170 - 171) from As-Sa'ib. And this (Musa) is weak. Otherwise in another narration from Jabir, and it contains one who is not used as proof, especially when contradicting. It is documented in "As-Sahihah" under number (2671). 
2. And thus he said in "Al-Majma", and its chain with Al-Bazzar (2/ 51/ 1183) contains Ibn Lahi'ah. The commentators graded it Hasan due to its witnesses - they claimed - while the first half of it is Gharib with no witness! The second half is in "Muslim" (4/ 113 and 122), and Ahmad (1/ 180) with the wording: "Whoever intends the people of Medina with overwhelming force or evil Allah dissolves him like..", so establishing the beginning is questionable. And Allah knows best. It is the first Hadith in "As-Sahih" from this chapter.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 12 - Book of Jihad (1). 1 - (Encouragement for Ribat (Guarding the Frontier) in the Way of Allah (Azza wa Jal). 778 - (1) [Weak] And from Umm Darda, may Allah be pleased with her, raising the Hadith, she said: "Whoever performs Ribat in any of the coasts of the Muslims for three days; it suffices him for the Ribat of a year." Narrated by Ahmad from the narration of Ismail bin Ayyash from the Madinans, and the rest of its chain are trustworthy. 779 - (2) [Weak] And At-Tabarani [narrated] in "Al-Awsat" longer than it [meaning the Hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih"], and he said in it: "And the Murabit (one guarding), if he dies in his Ribat; the reward of his deed is written for him until the Day of Resurrection, and his provision is brought to him morning and evening, and he is married to seventy Houris, and it is said to him: Stop and intercede, until the Reckoning is finished." And its chain is close (Muqarib) (2). 780 - (3) [Fabricated] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was asked about the reward of Ribat? (3) He said:
foot_note:
1. The origin of (Jihad) in language: Al-Jahd, which is hardship. And in Sharia: exerting effort in fighting the disbelievers. 
2. And in a copy: And its chain are trustworthy. Perhaps it is anomalous, for the chain is weak, and its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5303). 
3. Original: (Al-Murabitah), and on its margin: "And in a copy: "about the reward of Ribat", and the first is more correct". I say: What we established is the correct one; for its agreement with what is in "Al-Awsat" (No. - 8226 - my photocopy) and "Majma' Al-Bahrain" and others.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever performs Ribat for a night guarding behind the Muslims; he has the reward of those behind him who fasted and prayed." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a Jayyid chain (1). 781 - (4) [Weak] And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Whoever performs Ribat for a day in the way of Allah; Allah places between him and the Fire seven trenches, every trench like seven heavens and seven earths." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and its chain has no harm (2) God willing, and its text is Gharib. 782 - (5) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ubayy bin Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The Ribat of a day in the way of Allah behind the exposed parts of the Muslims seeking reward; other than the month of Ramadan; is greater in reward than the worship of a hundred years fasting and praying. And the Ribat of a day in the way of Allah behind the exposed parts of the Muslims; seeking reward in the month of Ramadan; is better with Allah and greater in reward - I think he said: better - than the worship of two thousand years fasting and praying. If Allah returns him to his family safe; the sins of a thousand years are not written against him, and good deeds are written for him, and the reward of Ribat runs for him until the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and signs of fabrication are apparent on it, and no wonder, for its narrator is Umar bin Subh (3) Al-Khurasani (4), and were it not in the sources I would not have mentioned it.
foot_note:
1. I say: No, for it contains an accused person, and its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5325). 
2. I say: It contains with At-Tabarani No. (4825) Abu Taybah Isa bin Sulaiman, and he is weak as Al-Haythami said, and Al-Hafiz said in "At-Taqrib": "Truthful but errs". 
3. Original and Amarah's print and the three commentators: (Subayh) diminutive, and likewise it occurred in "Ibn Majah" (2/ 175 - At-Taziyah), and it is an error, and the correction is from "Al-Khulasah" and other books of narrators. 
4. Meaning he is one of the liars known for fabricating Hadith.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 783 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed the prayer of the Murabit is equal to five hundred prayers, and the spending of a Dinar and Dirham from him is better than seven hundred Dinars spent elsewhere." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi. 784 - (7) [Very Weak] And Abu Ash-Sheikh (1) and others narrated from the Hadith of Anas: "Indeed prayer in the land of Ribat; is (equal to) two million prayers." And it contains Nakarah (denouncement). 785 - (8) [Very Weak] And from Utbah bin An-Nuddar (2), may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "If your raiding becomes distant (Intata) (3), and debts increase, and spoils become lawful; then the best of your Jihad is Ribat." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih".
foot_note:
1. I have not come across its chain now, but it is apparent that it is more denounced than the one before it. 
2. With Damma on Nun and Fatha on Dal Muhmalah with Shadda, ending with Ra Muhmalah, as in "Al-Isabah" and "Al-Ujalah" (136/ 2). Ad-Daraqutni said: "And At-Tabarani distorted it and said: (Ibn Al-Mundar) with Ba and Dal Mu'jamah". I say: And it occurred in the original and Amarah's print: (Ibn Al-Mundhir)! And it is also a distortion. And it occurred correctly in "Mawarid Az-Zam'an" (1625) and "Al-Majma" also (5/ 290) from the narration of At-Tabarani. And their chain contains Suwaid bin Abdul-Aziz, and he is Matruk (abandoned). 
3. It is on the weight of (Ihtata), meaning: your raiding becomes far, and it is from Niyat Al-Mafazah, which is its distance, as if it was hung to another desert that hardly ends.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2 - (Encouragement for Guarding in the Way of Allah Almighty). 786 - (1) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Whoever guards behind the Muslims in the way of Allah Blessed and Exalted voluntarily, not taken by a ruler; will not see the Fire with his eyes except for the fulfilling of the oath; for Allah Almighty says: {And there is none of you except he will come to it}. Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la and At-Tabarani, and there is no harm in it in follow-ups (1). (Tahillat Al-Qasam) is with Fatha on Ta Muthannah Fawq and Kasra on Ha Muhmalah and Shadda on Lam followed by Ta feminine; its meaning: expiation of the oath, which is the swear. 787 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Guarding a night in the way of Allah; is better than a man fasting and praying among his family for a thousand years, the year is three hundred and sixty days, the day like a thousand years." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and it seems to be fabricated. And Abu Ya'la narrated it briefly saying: "Whoever guards a night on the sea shore; it is better than his worship among his family for a thousand years." 788 - (3) [Weak] And from Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Guarding a night in the way of Allah; is better than a thousand nights; whose nights are prayed, and days are fasted."
foot_note: 1. It contains Zabban bin Fa'id, and he is weak as Al-Hafiz and others said.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad" (1). 789 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Three eyes the Fire will not touch: an eye that was gouged out in the path of Allah, an eye that kept guard in the path of Allah, and an eye that wept from the fear of Allah." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad". (The Dictator said) may Allah be pleased with him: "Rather, in its chain is Umar bin Rashid Al-Yamani" (2). 790 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah [also] (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Every eye will be weeping on the Day of Resurrection, except an eye that lowered its gaze from the prohibitions of Allah, an eye that stayed awake in the path of Allah, and an eye from which something like the head of a fly came out due to the fear of Allah." Narrated by Al-Asbahani.
foot_note:
1. I say: It is not as he said, because it contains Mus'ab, who is Ibn Thabit bin Abdullah bin Az-Zubair, and Mus'ab was weakened by Ahmad and others, moreover he did not hear from his grandfather Ibn Az-Zubair. 
2. He indicates its weakness, and Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him for it in "Talkhisihi" (2/ 82) saying: "I say: They weakened Umar".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution – Riyadh
text:
3 – (Encouragement to spend in the path of Allah, to equip fighters, and to support (1) their families in their absence).

791 – (1) [Weak] Al-Bazzār narrated the hadith of the Night Journey (al-Isra’) through the chain of al-Rabi‘ ibn Anas, from Abu al-‘Aliyah or others, from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him): that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was "brought a horse that, with every step it took, its reach extended as far as the eye could see. He rode it, and Gabriel accompanied him. He passed by a people who would plant in a single day and harvest in a single day; whenever they harvested, it returned as it had been! He said: ‘O Gabriel, who are these?’ He replied: ‘These are those who strive in the path of Allah; a single good deed is multiplied for them seven hundredfold, and whatever they spend, Allah replaces it.’" Then he mentioned the rest of the hadith at length. [A portion of it has already passed at the end of 5 – Prayer.]

792 – (2) [Weak] And from Ibn ‘Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: When the verse {The example of those who spend their wealth in the path of Allah is like a grain that grows seven ears; in every ear is a hundred grains. Allah multiplies for whom He wills, and Allah is All-Encompassing, All-Knowing} was revealed, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "O Lord, increase for my nation." So the verse was revealed: {Indeed, the patient will be given their reward without measure}. Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his *Sahih* and by al-Bayhaqi.

793 – (3) [Weak] And from al-Hasan, from ‘Ali ibn Abi Talib, Abu al-Darda’, Abu Hurayrah, Abu Umamah al-Bahili, [and ‘Abdullah ibn ‘Umar] (2), and ‘Abdullah ibn ‘Amr, and Jabir ibn ‘Abdullah, and ‘Imran ibn …
foot_note:
1. This is how it appears, but the correct wording is: “and their *succession*, i.e., caring for them in their absence.” See *Sahih at-Targhib*.
2. An addition from Ibn Majah, overlooked by the three commentators—as is their habit—contrary to their claim of precise verification! Rather, their work is closer to corrupting than to editing, to the extent that their ignorance led them to invert the narration and render it: ‘from al-Hasan ibn ‘Ali ibn Abi Talib’! They altered ‘from Ali’ to ‘ibn Ali’, resulting in removing (Ali ibn Abi Talib) from the chain and inserting his son al-Hasan into it—something that has absolutely no basis, as I demonstrated in *al-Silsilah al-Da‘ifah* (6834).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Husain (may Allah be pleased with them); all of them narrating from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH); that he said: "Whoever sends spending (money) in the path of Allah, and stays in his house, he has for every dirham seven hundred dirhams. And whoever fights in person in the path of Allah, and spends in that direction of his, he has for every dirham seven hundred thousand dirhams." Then he recited this verse {And Allah multiplies for whom He wills}. Narrated by Ibn Majah via Al-Khalil bin Abdullah - and I do not recall any disparagement or modification regarding him - from Al-Hasan from him. And Ibn Abi Hatim narrated it from Al-Hasan from Imran only. (Al-Hafiz said): "Al-Hasan did not hear from Imran nor from Ibn Amr. Al-Hakim said: 'Most of our Sheikhs are of the view that Al-Hasan heard from Imran' end quote. The majority are of the view that he did not hear from Abu Hurairah either, but he heard from others (1). And Allah knows best". 794 - (4) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Tuba (goodness) is for him who engages frequently in the remembrance of Allah during Jihad in the path of Allah; for he has for every word seventy thousand good deeds, each good deed of them is ten-fold, along with what he has with Allah of increase." It was said: O Messenger of Allah! What about spending? He said: "Spending is according to that measure." Abdur-Rahman said: So I said to Mu'adh: Indeed, spending is [rewarded] seven hundred fold! Mu'adh said: Your understanding is little; that is only if they spend it while they are residing with their families, not as warriors. But if they go out to fight and spend, Allah stores for them from the treasuries of His mercy what the knowledge of the servants is cut off from, and He described them as 'Those are the party of Allah, and the party of Allah are the victorious'.
foot_note: 1. I say: Whomever Al-Hasan heard from, his hadith from him is "Sahih", if he explicitly declares hearing from him; because he was a Mudallis (one who conceals the source), so take note.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and in its chain is a narrator who was not named. 795 - (5) [Weak] And Ibn Majah also narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever equips a warrior until he is independent (ready); he has the like of his reward until he dies or returns." 796 - (6) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Sahl bin Hunaif; that Sahl told him: That the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever helps a Mujahid in the path of Allah, or a debtor in his hardship, or a Mukatab (slave buying his freedom) in his bondage, Allah will shade him in His shade on the Day when there is no shade but His shade." Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Baihaqi; both of them via Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil from him (1). 797 - (7) [Weak] And from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever shades the head of a warrior; Allah will shade him on the Day of Resurrection. And whoever equips a warrior in the path of Allah; he has the like of his reward. And whoever builds a mosque for Allah in which the name of Allah is mentioned; Allah builds a house for him in Paradise." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Baihaqi (2) [Part of it passed before in a hadith].
foot_note:
1. I say: This Abdullah is Hasan in Hadith, but the defect is from his Sheikh Abdullah bin Sahl; for no one authenticated him; not even Ibn Hibban! 
2. It contains a disconnection between Umar and his narrator Uthman bin Abdullah bin Suraqah.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 4 - (Encouragement to keep horses for Jihad, not for showing off or reputation, and what came regarding their virtue, and encouragement regarding what is mentioned about them, and the prohibition of cutting their forelocks; because goodness and blessing are in them). 798 - (1) [Weak] And from Asma bint Yazid (may Allah be pleased with her); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Horses, goodness is tied to their forelocks forever until the Day of Resurrection. So whoever keeps them as preparation in the path of Allah, and spends on them seeking reward in the path of Allah, then their fullness, hunger, quenching of thirst, thirst, dung, and urine are success in his scales on the Day of Resurrection. And whoever keeps them for showing off, reputation, arrogance, and pride; then their fullness, hunger, quenching of thirst, thirst, dung, and urine are loss in his scales on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Ahmad with a Hasan chain (1). 799 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Khabbab bin Al-Aratt (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Horses are three: A horse for Ar-Rahman (The Most Merciful), a horse for Man, and a horse for Satan. As for the horse of Ar-Rahman; it is what is adopted for the path of Allah, and upon which the enemies of Allah are fought (2). As for the horse of Man; it is what is used for breeding (belly) and bearing loads. And as for the horse of Satan; it is what is bet upon and gambled upon." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and it is Gharib.
foot_note:
1. I say: How [can it be Hasan] when it contains Shahr bin Hawshab, and he is weak as stated by Al-Haythami (5/ 266) and others?! 
2. Original: (Qutila - were killed), and likewise in "Al-Majma'", and the correction is from "At-Tabarani Al-Kabir" (4/ 707) [Qutila - are fought].

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 800 - (3) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Horses are three: A horse for Ar-Rahman, a horse for Man, and a horse for Satan. As for the horse of Ar-Rahman; it is the one kept in the path of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, so its fodder, urine, and dung... - and he mentioned what Allah willed -. As for the horse of Satan; it is that which is gambled upon and bet upon. As for the horse of Man; it is the mare a man keeps seeking its offspring (belly), so it is a screen from poverty." Narrated by Ahmad also with a Hasan chain (1). 801 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from 'Areeb from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Horses, goodness and gain are tied to their forelocks until the Day of Resurrection, and their owners are assisted regarding them, and the one who spends on them is like the one stretching his hand with charity, and their urine and dung are for their owners with Allah on the Day of Resurrection like the musk of Paradise." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat", and it contains Nakarah (denounced content). 802 - (5) [Weak] And from Ma'qil bin Yasar (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: Nothing was more beloved to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) than horses, then he said: O Allah, forgiveness, no, rather (2) women. Narrated by Ahmad, and its narrators are trustworthy.
foot_note:
1. Thus he said! And the Three imitated him! And it contains weakness, ignorance (of a narrator), and inconsistency (Idtirab) which I explained in the original, and in "As-Sahih" there is what suffices instead of it. 
2. Original: (Ghufranaka), and the correction is from "Atraf Al-Musnad" (5/ 356/ 7317) [Ghafran].

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 803 - (6) [Weak] And An-Nasa'i narrated it from the hadith of Anas, and his wording is: Nothing was more beloved to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) after women than horses (1). 804 - (7) [Weak] And from Utbah bin Abd As-Sulami (may Allah be pleased with him); that he heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Do not cut the forelocks of horses, nor their manes (2), nor their tails, for their tails are their fly-swatters (3), their manes are their warmth, and their forelocks have goodness tied in them." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and in its chain is an unknown man. 805 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Wahb (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "You should keep every Kumait (bay/dark red horse) with a white forehead (Agarr) and white legs (Muhajjal), or a Chestnut (Ashqar) with a white forehead and white legs, or a Black (Adham) with a white forehead and white legs." Narrated by Abu Dawood and the wording is his, and An-Nasa'i longer than this.
foot_note:
1. It is from the narration of Qatadah, and there was disagreement regarding him. Sa'id bin Abi Arubah narrated it from him from Anas, extracted by An-Nasa'i (2/ 119) and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" (2/ 425/ 1729). Abu Hilal opposed him and said: Qatadah told us from a man - who is Al-Hasan if Allah wills - from Ma'qil bin Yasar. And Abu Hilal's name is (Muhammad bin Sulaym Ar-Rasibi) and there is leniency in him, extracted by Ahmad (5/ 27). There is no doubt that the narration of Ibn Abi Arubah is more likely than his narration, but Qatadah practices Tadlis, and he used 'an'ana (said 'from'), along with the suspicion of an intermediary in Abu Hilal's narration, who is Al-Hasan Al-Basri, and he is also a Mudallis! Especially since what is preserved from Anas as Marfu' is with the wording: "Beloved to me from your world are..." the Hadith, and he did not mention horses in it, so the heart is not open to the authenticity of the hadith. And Allah knows best. (Note): Al-Haythami (5/ 258) attributed the hadith of Ma'qil to At-Tabarani, and I did not see it in "Al-Kabir" nor in "As-Saghir" nor in "Majma' Al-Bahrain". 
2. (Al-Ma'arif): The hair of the horse's neck. 
3. And his saying: (Madabbuha) plural of (Madabbah): What flies are swatted away with.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 5 - (Encouragement for the Ghazi (warrior) and Murabit (stationed guard) to increase good deeds, such as fasting, prayer, remembrance, and the like). [Weak] And it passed in "Chapter of Spending in the Path of Allah" [3 - Chapter] from Abu Hurairah: "That the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), on the night he was taken on the Night Journey, came upon a people planting in a day and harvesting in a day; whenever they harvested, it returned as it was. He said: O Jibril! Who are these? He said: These are the Mujahideen in the path of Allah, the good deed is multiplied for them seven hundred fold, and whatever they spend of anything He replaces it." Narrated by Al-Bazzar. 806 - (1) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever fasts a day in the path of Allah [voluntarily] other than in Ramadan, is distanced from the Fire by one hundred years; the travel of a trained fast horse." Narrated by Abu Ya'la via the path of Zaban bin Fa'id. [Passed 9 - Fasting /1]. 807 - (2) [Weak] And [At-Tabarani] narrated it [meaning the hadith of Amr bin Abasah which is in "As-Sahih"] in "Al-Kabir" from the hadith of Abu Umamah; except that he said in it: "Allah distances his face from the Fire a journey of one hundred years; the galloping of a trained fast horse." And An-Nasa'i narrated it from the hadith of Uqbah; he did not say in it: "the galloping of the horse" to the end (1). 808 - (3) [Weak] And from Sahl bin Mu'adh from his father (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said:
foot_note: 1. I say: Its chain is Hasan, and it is a strong witness for the hadith of Amr bin Abasah which is in "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Indeed, prayer, fasting, and remembrance are multiplied over spending in the path of Allah by seven hundred fold." Narrated by Abu Dawood via the path of Zaban from him. 809 - (4) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Tuba (goodness) is for him who engages frequently in Jihad in the path of Allah in the remembrance of Allah, for he has for every word seventy thousand good deeds, each good deed of them is ten-fold, along with what he has with Allah of increase" the Hadith. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and in it is a man who was not named. 810 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Mu'adh (1) from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH): That a man asked him saying: Which of the Mujahideen has the greatest reward? He said: "The one among them who remembers Allah, Blessed and Exalted, the most" the Hadith. Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani, and it will come in full if Allah wills [14 - Remembrance / 1]. 811 - (6) [Weak] And from Sahl bin Mu'adh from his father (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever recites a thousand verses in the path of Allah; Allah writes him with the Prophets, the Truthful, the Martyrs, and the Righteous." Narrated by Al-Hakim via the path of Zaban from him, and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: Thus he generalized so he gave the impression that it is (Mu'adh bin Jabal); because he is the one meant when generalized, especially since he placed it after the hadith of (Mu'adh), but it is (Mu'adh bin Anas) as in "Al-Musnad" (3/ 438) and At-Tabarani (20/ 186/ 407). It would have been more appropriate for the author to restrict it or make it from the narration of his son (Sahl bin Mu'adh) as he did in the following hadith, then there would be no harm on him after that to generalize in this attribution to him, and he also generalized the attribution to him in the place referred to!! The three commentators were ignorant of all this as is their habit regarding what is more important than it. 
2. Thus he said! And it is from his leniency which Adh-Dhahabi followed him on in his "Talkhis", although he said in his "Kashif": "Zaban bin Fa'id Al-Masri, virtuous, good, weak".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (The Dictator said) may Allah be pleased with him: "It is apparent that the Murabit (stationed guard) is also in the path of Allah, so his good deed is multiplied, just as the deed of the Mujahid is multiplied." 812 - (7) [Weak] And it has been narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) - raising it - he said: "A prayer in my mosque equals ten thousand prayers, and a prayer in the Sacred Mosque equals one hundred thousand prayers, and the prayer in the land of Ribat equals two million prayers" the Hadith. Narrated by Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan in "Kitab Ath-Thawab". 813 - (8) [Very Weak] And Al-Baihaqi narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed the prayer of the Murabit equals five hundred prayers, and the spending of the Dinar and Dirham from him is better than seven hundred Dinars spent elsewhere." And Allah knows best.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 6 - (Encouragement to set out in the morning or evening in the path of Allah, and what came regarding the virtue of walking and dust in the path of Allah and fear in it). 814 - (1) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from him [meaning Sahl bin Sa'd (may Allah be pleased with him)] he said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "No Muslim sets out in the evening in the path of Allah as a Mujahid or a pilgrim saying Tahlil (La ilaha illa Allah) or Talbiyah; except that the sun sets with his sins." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". [Passed 11 - Hajj /1]. 815 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever goes out (Fasala) in the path of Allah then dies or is killed; he is a martyr, or his horse or camel throws him breaking his neck (Waqasahu), or a venomous creature stings him, or he dies on his bed by whatever death (Hatf) Allah willed he died; then he is a martyr, and he has Paradise." Narrated by Abu Dawood from the narration of Baqiyyah bin Al-Walid from Ibn Thawban, and he is Abdur-Rahman bin Thabit bin Thawban, and the discussion on Baqiyyah and Abdur-Rahman will come [meaning at the end of the book]. (Fasala) with un-dotted Sad with Fatha; meaning: exited. (Waqasahu) with Qaf and un-dotted Sad with Fatha; meaning: threw him and broke his neck. (Al-Hatf) with Fatha on the un-dotted letter and Sukun on the two-dotted letter above: is death. 816 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (PBUH) in what he narrates from his Lord, He said: "Any servant of My servants who goes out as a Mujahid in the path of Allah seeking My pleasure;
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: I guarantee for him that I return him (1) with what he obtained of reward or booty, and if I take his soul; I forgive him [and have mercy on him]." Narrated by An-Nasa'i. 817 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "There is no man whose face becomes dusty in the path of Allah except that Allah secures him from the smoke of the Fire on the Day of Resurrection, and there is no man whose feet become dusty in the path of Allah except that Allah secures his feet from the Fire on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Baihaqi (2). 818 - (5) [Weak] And from Abu Ad-Darda - raising the hadith to the Prophet (PBUH) - he said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Allah, Mighty and Majestic, does not combine in the belly of a servant dust in the path of Allah and the smoke of Hell. And whoever's feet became dusty in the path of Allah [Allah forbids the rest of his body to the Fire. And whoever fasts a day in the path of Allah] (3) Allah distances the Fire from him on the Day of Resurrection a journey of a thousand years for a hurried rider. And whoever is wounded a wound in the path of Allah receives the seal of the Martyrs, it has light on the Day of Resurrection, its color is like the color of saffron, and its smell is like the smell of musk, the earlier and later peoples recognize him by it; they say: Such and such has the stamp of martyrs on him. And whoever fights in
foot_note:

3. Dropped from the author's pen apparently, and Al-Haythami followed him in that, so I recovered it from "Al-Musnad", and the Three neglected it so they did not recover it!

text: the path of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, for a Fuwaq (milking interval) of a she-camel; Paradise becomes obligatory for him" (1). Narrated by Ahmad and the narrators of his chain are trustworthy; except that Khalid bin Duraik did not meet Abu Ad-Darda, and it was said: He heard from him. 819 - (6) [Weak] And from Rabi' bin Ziyad; that he said: While the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) was traveling, he came upon a young man from Quraish who had moved aside from the road traveling (2), so the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Is that not so-and-so?". foot_note:
1. This sentence has a strong witness, so see it if you wish in "As-Sahih" in the coming chapter, Hadith (3). 
2. Original: (Yatir - flying), and the correction is from "Al-Marasil" by Abu Dawood (p. 33). 
3. (Adh-Dharirah): A type of perfume made of mixtures. As in "An-Nihayah".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and "Al-Awsat". (Al-'Idhq) with Kasra on the un-dotted Ayn and Sukun on the dotted Dhal followed by Qaf: It is the date bunch (Qinu), and it is what is meant here, and with Fatha on Ayn: The palm tree. 7 - (Encouragement to ask for Martyrdom in the path of Allah Almighty) . text: 8 - (Encouragement regarding Archery in the path of Allah and learning it, and discouragement from abandoning it after learning it out of disinterest) . 821 - (1) [Weak] And from him [meaning Uqbah bin Amir (may Allah be pleased with him)] he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Indeed Allah admits three people into Paradise by a single arrow: Its maker who seeks good in his making of it, the one who shoots with it, and its Munbil (handler/supplier). Shoot and ride, and that you shoot is more beloved to me than that you ride. And whoever abandons archery after having learned it out of disinterest in it, then it is a blessing he has abandoned, or he said: He has been ungrateful for it" (1). Narrated by Abu Dawood and the wording is his, and An-Nasa'i, and Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad", and Al-Baihaqi via the path of Al-Hakim and others (2). And in a narration by Al-Baihaqi: He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Indeed Allah, Mighty and Majestic, admits three people into Paradise by a single arrow: Its maker who seeks good in his making of it, the one who equips with it in the path of Allah, and the one who shoots with it in the path of Allah." (Munbiluhu) with Damma on Mim and Sukun on Nun and Kasra on Ba with one dot. Al-Baghawi said: "He is the one who hands the arrows to the archer, and he is of two types: One: He stands beside the archer or behind him, handing him the arrows one after another so he shoots. And the other: That he returns to him the arrows that were shot. And it is narrated: (Al-Mumidd bihi), and whichever of the two matters he does, he is an aider (Mumidd) with it" end quote.
foot_note:
1. This last sentence has what suffices instead of it in "As-Sahih", so see the hadith of Abu Hurairah there. 
2. I say: In its chain is Jahalah (unknown status) and Idtirab (inconsistency) which I explained in "Da'if Abi Dawood" (433).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Hafiz Abdul-Azim the Dictator said): "And it is possible that what is meant by his saying: (Munbiluhu) i.e.: The one who gives it to the Mujahid, and equips him with it from his wealth as supply for him and strengthening. And the narration of Al-Baihaqi indicates this". 822 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Ad-Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Whoever walks between the two targets (Gharadayn); he has for every step a good deed." Narrated by At-Tabarani. (Al-Gharad) with Fatha on the dotted Ghain and Ra followed by dotted Dad: Is what the archers aim to hit. 823 - (3) [Munkar] And from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever shoots a shot in the path of Allah, whether it falls short or reaches; he has the like of the reward of freeing four people from the children of Ismail." Narrated by Al-Bazzar from Shabib bin Bishr (1) from Anas. 824 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Muhammad ibn Al-Hanafiyyah who said: I saw Abu Amr Al-Ansari - and he was a Badri, 'Aqabi, Uhudi - fasting and twisting from thirst, saying to his servant: Woe to you, shield me. So the servant shielded him until he drew an arrow with a weak draw until he shot three arrows, then he said I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say:
foot_note: 1. Al-Haythami said: "He is Thiqah (trustworthy), and there is weakness in him". I say: Therefore I fear he erred in his saying: "four", for it came in more than one Sahih hadith with the wording: "a slave (raqabah)", and some of them passed in "As-Sahih", and it also came in a narration via another path from Anas. Abu Nu'aym extracted it in "Al-Hilyah" (6/ 306), so what Shabib contradicted is not used as proof, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6615).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever shoots with an arrow in the path of Allah whether it falls short or reaches; it will be a light for him on the Day of Resurrection" (1). So he was killed before the sunset, may Allah be pleased with him. Narrated by At-Tabarani. 825 - (5) [Munkar] And Ibn Majah [narrated] [meaning the hadith of Uqbah bin Amir]; except that he said: "Whoever learns archery then abandons it has disobeyed me" (2). [Weak] And the hadith of Uqbah bin Amir passed in the beginning of the chapter, and in it: "Whoever abandons archery after having learned it out of disinterest in it; then it is a blessing he has abandoned, or he said:
foot_note:
1. This text (Matn) has come in some Sahih hadiths, so see the hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih" in this chapter. 
2. I say: And the Preserved is the narration of Muslim: "Then he is not of us, or he has disobeyed". And see it if you wish in "As-Sahih" in this chapter. And the hadith of Ibn Majah contains two unknown narrators, and I explained that in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6837).

text: 9 - (Encouragement for Jihad in the path of Allah Almighty. And what came regarding the virtue of wounds in it, and supplication at the battle line and fighting). 826 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The best of deeds with Allah Almighty is faith in which there is no doubt, and a battle (Ghazw) in which there is no stealing from booty (Ghulul), and an accepted Hajj (Hajj Mabrur)." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs", and it is in the "Two Sahihs" and others similarly, and it passed [in the beginning of Hajj] (1). 827 - (2) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) went out with the people towards the expedition of (Tabuk). When he entered morning he prayed the Fajr prayer with the people, then the people rode. When the sun rose the people became drowsy following the night journey (Duljah), and Mu'adh stuck to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) following his trace, while the people's mounts scattered on the middle of the road; eating and walking. While Mu'adh was on the trace of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), and his she-camel eating once and walking another, Mu'adh's she-camel stumbled, so he reined it in (2) with the rein, so it bolted until the she-camel of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) shied away from it. Then the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) removed his veil from himself, and looked around and behold there was no one in the army closer to him than Mu'adh. So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) called out saying: "O Mu'adh!". He said: At your service O Messenger of Allah! He said:
foot_note:
1. And at the beginning of the Chapter in the original with the wording of the "Two Sahihs" - and it is in "As-Sahih" -, and with this wording of Ibn Khuzaimah, not attributed to Ibn Hibban, so we dispensed with mentioning what is mentioned there; because it is consecutive repetition with no benefit. 
2. Original: "Fahanakaha", and likewise in "Al-Majma'" (5/ 272), and what I established is from "Musnad Ahmad" (5/ 245), and perhaps it is the correct one, and An-Naji asserted it, and said: "Meaning: He pulled it towards him violently when it stumbled, and it is explained in the hadith itself".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Come closer." So he approached him until their mounts touched, one to the other. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "I did not think the people were as far from us as their place is." Mu'adh said: O Prophet of Allah! The people became drowsy so their mounts scattered grazing and walking. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "And I was drowsy." When Mu'adh saw the cheerfulness of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) and his being alone with him, he said: O Messenger of Allah! Permit me to ask you about a word that has sickened me, made me ill, and grieved me. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Ask whatever you wish." He said: O Prophet of Allah! Tell me of a deed that will enter me into Paradise, I do not ask you about anything else. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Bakh, Bakh, Bakh (Expression of approval/wonder), you have indeed asked about a great thing, you have asked about a great thing, you have asked about a great thing, (three times), and it is indeed easy for whom Allah wills good for him, and it is easy for whom Allah wills good for him, and it is easy for whom Allah wills good for him." He did not tell him a thing, except that he repeated it three times, out of eagerness so that he would master it from him. The Prophet of Allah (PBUH) said: "Believe in Allah and the Last Day, establish prayer, give Zakat, and worship Allah alone associating nothing with Him; until you die while you are upon that." He said: O Messenger of Allah! Repeat for me. So he repeated it three times. Then the Prophet of Allah (PBUH) said: "If you wish O Mu'adh! I will tell you the head of this matter, the pillar of this matter, and the peak of the hump?"
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: So Mu'adh said: Yes O Messenger of Allah! Tell me, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you. The Prophet of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed the head of this matter is that you testify that there is no deity but Allah, alone with no partner, and that Muhammad is His slave and Messenger. And that the pillar of this matter is establishing prayer, and giving Zakat. And that the peak of the hump of it is Jihad in the path of Allah. I was only commanded to fight people until they establish prayer, give Zakat, and testify that there is no deity but Allah alone with no partner, and that Muhammad is His slave and Messenger. If they do that, they have protected themselves, and protected their blood and wealth, except by its right, and their account is upon Allah" (1). And the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "By the One in Whose Hand is the soul of Muhammad, no face became pale, nor foot became dusty in a deed by which the degrees of the Hereafter are sought after the prescribed prayer like Jihad in the path of Allah. And no scale of a servant is heavier than a beast that dies [for him] (2) in the path of Allah, or carries in the path of Allah." Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Bazzar via the path of Shahr bin Hawshab from Mu'adh, and I do not think he heard from him. And Ahmad also narrated it, and At-Tirmidhi and authenticated it, and An-Nasa'i and Ibn Majah; all of them via the path of Abu Wa'il from him abbreviated. And it will come in "Silence" if Allah the Exalted wills [23 - Etiquette /20]. 828 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "The peak of the hump of Islam is Jihad, none attains it except the best of them." Narrated by At-Tabarani.
foot_note:
1. The second half of the last section from his saying: "I was commanded to fight..." is Sahih, it has many witnesses in the "Two Sahihs" and others, and I have extracted a good amount of them in "As-Sahihah", so refer to it under numbers (407 - 411). 
2. Addition from "Al-Musnad" (5/ 245). And from the ignorance of the three commentators is that they graded it Hasan despite the author's defecting it with disconnection, let alone the weakness of Shahr for which he is known, and this hadith is one of the proofs for that, for he added additions in it not found in the narration of Abu Wa'il coming in "Silence", noting that it is also disconnected as the author will clarify there.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 829 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Amr bin Abasah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Whoever fights in the path of Allah for a Fuwaq (milking interval) of a she-camel; Allah forbids the Fire on his face" (1) Narrated by Ahmad. 830 - (5) [Weak] And from Abu Al-Mundhir (may Allah be pleased with him): That a man came to the Prophet (PBUH) and said: O Messenger of Allah! Indeed so-and-so has died so pray over him. Umar said: He is a wicked man so do not pray over him. The man said: O Messenger of Allah! Did you not see the night I spent guarding; for he was among them. So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) stood and prayed over him, then followed him until he reached his grave and sat, until when he finished with him he threw three handfuls (of dust) over him, then said: "People praise you with evil, and I praise you with good." Umar said: And what is that O Messenger of Allah? The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Leave us alone O Ibn Al-Khattab! Whoever strives in the path of Allah, Paradise is obligatory for him." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its chain has no harm if Allah the Exalted wills (2). 831 - (6) [Weak] And from Makhul who said: Those asking permission from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) for Hajj increased on the day of the expedition of (Tabuk), so the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "A Ghazwa (expedition) for one who has performed Hajj is better than forty Hajjs"
foot_note:
1. I say: It has been authenticated in another hadith with the wording: ". . . then Paradise has become obligatory for him". See in "As-Sahih", here in the hadith of Abu Hurairah number (7), and Mu'adh (23). And a witness for it passed recently in the end of the hadith of Abu Ad-Darda number (6) here (6 - Chapter). 
2. Thus he said: And it contains one whom Al-Haythami did not know. See "Majma' Az-Zawa'id" (5/ 276), and what was indicated in the previous comment suffices instead of it, so take note.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Abu Dawood in "Al-Marasil" from the narration of Ismail bin Ayyash. 832 - (7) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "A Hajj is better than forty Ghazwas, and a Ghazwa is better than forty Hajjs. - He says: - If a man performed the Hajj of Islam then a Ghazwa is better for him than forty Hajjs, and the Hajj of Islam is better than forty Ghazwas." Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and its narrators are known trustworthy ones, and Anbasah bin Hubairah was authenticated by Ibn Hibban, and I did not find any disparagement regarding him (1). 833 - (8) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "A Hajj for one who has not performed Hajj is better than ten Ghazwas, and a Ghazwa for one who has performed Hajj is better than ten Hajjs" the Hadith. Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Baihaqi, and it will come in full in "Sea Warriors" if Allah wills [12 - Chapter]. 834 - (9) [Munkar] And in a narration by Ibn Hibban [in the hadith of Sahl bin Sa'd which is in "As-Sahih"]: "Two hours in which the supplication is not rejected for a supplicant: When the prayer is established, and in the row in the path of Allah." [Passed 5 - Prayer/ 9]. (2) (Yulham) with un-dotted Ha means: They engage one another in war.
foot_note:
1. Ibn Abi Hatim said about him (3/ 1/ 403) from his father: "Unknown (Majhul)". And Adh-Dhahabi followed him. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3481). 
2. See the comment on it there.

text: 10 - (Encouragement for sincerity of intention in Jihad, and what came regarding one who wants reward and booty and fame, and the virtue of warriors if they do not gain booty). 835 - (1) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas (may Allah be pleased with them both); that he said: "O Messenger of Allah! Inform me about Jihad and Ghazw? He said: "O Abdullah bin Amr! If you fight patiently and seeking reward; Allah resurrects you patient and seeking reward. And if you fight showing off and seeking abundance; Allah resurrects you showing off and seeking abundance. O Abdullah bin Amr! Upon whatever state you fought or were killed; Allah resurrects you on that state." Narrated by Abu Dawood [Passed 1 - Sincerity /2]. 836 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: A man said: O Messenger of Allah! I stand in the standing (battle) wanting the Face of Allah, and I want my bravery to be seen? The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) did not reply to him until {So whoever would hope for the meeting with his Lord - let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone} was revealed. Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs" (1) [Passed there].
foot_note: 1. Thus he said! And it is rejected because the Trustworthy one narrated it Mursal, and that is the correct view as Al-Baihaqi said, and its explanation passed there.

text: 11 - (Discouragement from fleeing the battlefield (Zahf)) . 837 - (1) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Thawban (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Three, no deed benefits with them: Shirk with Allah, disobedience to parents, and fleeing from the battlefield." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (1). 838 - (2) [Weak] And from Ubaid bin Umair Al-Laithi from his father who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said in the Farewell Hajj: "Indeed the allies (Awliya) of Allah are those who pray, and whoever establishes the five prayers which Allah prescribed upon him, and fasts Ramadan, and seeks reward in his fasting, and gives Zakat seeking reward, his soul happy with it, and avoids the major sins which Allah forbade." A man from his companions said: O Messenger of Allah! And how many are the major sins? He said: "Nine: The greatest of them is associating partners with Allah, killing a believer without right, fleeing from the battlefield, slandering a chaste woman, magic, eating the orphan's wealth, eating usury, disobedience to Muslim parents, and violating the Sacred House; your Qiblah alive and dead. No man dies not having committed these major sins, and establishes prayer, and gives Zakat; except that he accompanies Muhammad (PBUH) in the middle (Buhbuhah) of a Paradise whose doors are panels of gold." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" with a Hasan chain [Passed 8 - Charity /1]. (Buhbuhat Al-Makan) with two un-dotted Has and two Damma Ba's: is its middle.
foot_note: 1. I say: In it is Yazid bin Rabi'ah bin Yazid, and he is very weak as Al-Haythami said, and the three commentators quoted it from him, yet they did not understand that this implies his hadith is very weak so they said: "Weak" only!!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Hafiz said): Ash-Shafi'i (may Allah be pleased with him) used to say: "If the Muslims fight and meet double their number of the enemy, it is forbidden for them to turn away except maneuvering for war or joining another company. And if the polytheists are more than double them, I do not like for them to turn away, but they do not deserve wrath in my view from Allah if they turned away from them without maneuvering for war or joining another company, and this is the view of Ibn Abbas famously reported from him" (1).
foot_note: 1. "Al-Umm" by Imam Ash-Shafi'i (4/ 92) with slight difference in some words.

text: 12 - (Encouragement for the expedition in the sea, and that it is better than ten expeditions on land) . 839 - (1) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "A Hajj for one who has not performed Hajj is better than ten Ghazwas, and a Ghazwa for one who has performed Hajj is better than ten Hajjs, and a Ghazwa in the sea is better than ten Ghazwas on land, and whoever crosses the sea it is as if he crossed all the valleys, and the one seasick (Maa'id) in it is like one wallowing in his blood." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and Al-Baihaqi; both from the narration of Abdullah bin Salih, the scribe of Al-Layth. And Al-Hakim narrated from it: "A Ghazwa in the sea is better than ten Ghazwas on land" to the end. And he said: "Sahih according to the condition of Al-Bukhari". And it is as he said: And what was said regarding Abdullah bin Salih does not harm, for Al-Bukhari used him as proof (1). (Al-Maa'id) is the one whose head spins (2) and leans from the sea wind, (Al-Mayd): Leaning/Swaying. 840 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Imran bin Husain (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever fights a battle in the sea in the path of Allah - and Allah knows best who fights in His path -
foot_note:
1. I say: If he said: "He narrated from him" as he said at the end of the book it would be closer to correctness, because I have not seen anyone declare that Al-Bukhari used him as proof, rather they mentioned that he narrated from him in suspension (Ta'liq), and there is much speech about him, so the heart is not at ease to use as proof what he alone narrates like this hadith, and he mentioned him in "Al-Mizan" among what was denounced from him, and I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1230). 
2. An-Naji said: (140/ 1): "This is a generated slang language, (the author) was permissive in it and lenient".
