text: he has performed to Allah all His obedience, and sought Paradise with every seeking, and fled from the Fire with every fleeing." Narrated by At-Tabarani in his "Three Mu'jams" (1). 841 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Wathilah bin Al-Asqa' (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever missed the Ghazwa with me let him fight in the sea." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: In it is (Umar bin As-Subh), Ibn Hibban said: "He fabricates". And Al-Haythami said: "Matruk (Discarded)", and the ignorant ones quoted it from him, yet they said about the hadith: "Weak"!! And it is extracted in "Al-Rawd" (747). 
2. Contains a Matruk narrator, but narrated from others as verified in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2003).

text: 13 - (Discouragement from Ghulul (stealing from war booty) and severity regarding it, and what came regarding one who conceals a Ghal (thief of booty)) . 842 - (1) [Weak] And from Zaid bin Khalid (may Allah be pleased with him): That a man from the companions of the Prophet (PBUH) died on the day of Khaibar, so they mentioned it to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) and he said: "Pray over your companion." So the people's faces changed at that. He said: "Indeed your companion stole (Ghalla) in the path of Allah." So we searched his belongings, and found beads from the beads of the Jews not worth two dirhams. Narrated by Malik, Ahmad, Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah (1). 843 - (2) [Weak] And from Habib bin Maslamah who said: I heard Abu Dharr say: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "If my Ummah does not steal (Ghulul), no enemy will ever stand against them." Abu Dharr said to Habib bin Maslamah: Does the enemy hold firm against you for the duration of milking a sheep? He said: Yes, and three sheep with much milk. Abu Dharr said: You have stolen, by the Lord of the Kaaba. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a Jayyid (good) chain, there is nothing said in it except the Tadlis of Baqiyyah bin Al-Walid, and he has declared hearing (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: In it is Abu Amrah the freed slave of Zaid bin Khalid, and he is unknown, and the Three authenticated it; imitating some of them, and it is an error whose cause I explained in "Al-Irwa" (3/ 174 - 175). 
2. I say: But above him is the ignorance of Abdur-Rahman bin 'Arq Al-Yahsabi as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5169), and the Three graded it Hasan imitating and due to their ignorance of this unknown narrator!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 844 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Hazim (1) who said: The Prophet (PBUH) was brought a leather mat (Nit') from the booty, it was said: O Messenger of Allah! This is for you to shade yourself with from the sun. He said: "Do you like that your Prophet shades himself with a shade of Fire?!" Narrated by Abu Dawood in his "Marasil", and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and added: "On the Day of Resurrection". 845 - (4) [Weak] And from Yazid bin Mu'awiyah; that he wrote to the people of Basra: Peace be upon you. As for what follows, a man asked the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) for a rope (Zimam) of hair from the booty, so the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "You asked me for a rope of Fire; it was not for you to ask me for it, nor was it for me to give it." Narrated by Abu Dawood in "Al-Marasil" also. 846 - (5) [Weak] And from Samurah bin Jundub (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: As for what follows, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) used to say: "Whoever conceals a Ghal (thief of booty) then he is like him." Narrated by Abu Dawood. (Yaktumu Ghallan); meaning: covers up for him.
foot_note: 1. He is Al-Ansari, his companionship is disputed, and it is not established in my view. See "Ad-Da'ifah" (5113).

text: 14 - (Encouragement regarding Martyrdom, and what came regarding the virtue of Martyrs) . 847 - (1) [Weak] And from Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd who said: The Prophet (PBUH) was shown them in sleep, he saw Ja'far as an angel with two wings stained with blood, and Zaid opposite him. Narrated by At-Tabarani, and it is Mursal with a Jayyid chain (1). 848 - (2) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Ja'far (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Congratulations to you O Abdullah! Your father flies with the angels in the sky." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan chain (2). 849 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The martyrs are three: A man who went out with his self and wealth in the path of Allah, he does not want to (3) fight nor be killed; increasing the numbers of Muslims, if he dies or is killed; all his sins are forgiven, and he is protected from the punishment of the grave, and secured from the Terror, and married from the Hoor Al-Ein, and the robe of honor is placed on him, and the crown of dignity and eternity is placed on his head. And the second: Went out with his self and wealth seeking reward, wanting to kill and not be killed, if he dies or
foot_note:
1. I say: It is weak due to its Irsal (disconnection), and his saying: "and Zaid opposite him" is Munkar, for not appearing in other narrations, although they are all defective, and they are extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6841), nor in the established narrations extracted in "As-Sahihah" (1226). 
2. Thus he said, and Al-Haythami followed him then the Three! And it is a pure error, it has three defects, one of them is (Abdullah Ibn Harun...) Ad-Daraqutni said: "Matruk Al-Hadith", and others weakened him. And the detail is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6639). Only the sentence of flying is authentic from the hadith, so see this chapter in "As-Sahih". 
3. Thus in the manuscript and Amarah's edition, and "Zawa'id Al-Bazzar" (Number - 1715), and the original: (illa an - except that), and perhaps the correct is what we established as the context indicates.

text: is killed; his kneeling [position] will be with Abraham, the Friend of the Most Merciful, before Allah the Blessed and Exalted, in a seat of truth near a Powerful Sovereign. The third: He went out with his self and his wealth seeking reward, intending to kill and be killed. If he dies or is killed; he will come on the Day of Resurrection brandishing his sword, placing it on his shoulder, while the people are kneeling. He will say: 'Make way for us, for we have sacrificed our blood and our wealth for Allah the Blessed and Exalted.' -The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said:- 'By the One in Whose Hand is my soul! If he were to say that to Abraham, the Friend of the Most Merciful, or to a Prophet among the Prophets, they would step aside (zahala) from the path for them, due to what they see of their due right, until they come to pulpits of light under the Throne and sit upon them; watching how judgment is passed among the people. They do not find the distress of death, nor are they distressed in the Barzakh, nor does the Blast frighten them, nor does the Reckoning, the Balance, or the Sirat concern them. They watch how judgment is passed among the people, and they do not ask for anything except that they are given it, nor do they intercede for anything except that their intercession is accepted, and they are given whatever they love from Paradise, and they settle wherever they love in Paradise.' Narrated by Al-Bazzar, Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Asbahani, and it is a Gharib (strange) hadith. (Zahala) is with the letter Zai and the unpointed Ha. This is in the narration of Al-Bazzar. Al-Asbahani said in his narration: 'They would step aside (la-tanahha) for them from the paths.' The meaning of (zahala) and (tanahha) is one. 850 - (4) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'When the servants stand for the Reckoning, a people will come placing their swords on their necks, dripping
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: blood. They will crowd at the gate of Paradise. It will be asked: Who are these? It will be said: The martyrs, they were alive and provided for.' Narrated by At-Tabarani in a hadith that will come in full, if Allah the Exalted wills [2 - Judgement / 12], and its chain is Hasan (1). 851 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'Shall I not inform you about the most generous of the generous? Allah is the Most Generous of the generous, and I am the most generous of the children of Adam. And the most generous of them after me is a man who learned knowledge and spread his knowledge; he will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection as a nation by himself, and a man who sacrificed himself for Allah the Mighty and Majestic until he was killed.' Narrated by Abu Ya'la and Al-Bayhaqi. [Passed in 3 - Knowledge / 7]. 852 - (6) [Very Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The martyr was mentioned in the presence of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so he said: 'The earth does not dry from the blood of the martyr before his two wives rush to him, as if they are two wet-nurses (zi'ran) who had lost (azallata) their weaned camels in a desolate land (barah), and in the hand of each one of them is a garment better than the world and what is in it.' Narrated by Ibn Majah from the narration of Shahr bin Hawshab from him. (Az-Zi'r) with a kasrah on the pointed Zaa followed by a sukun on the Hamzah: means the nursing mother. The meaning is: that his two wives from the Hoor al-Ayn rush to him and show affection to him and shade him just as the nursing she-camel shows affection to her weaned calf. It is possible that it is (adallata) with the letter Dad, so the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, likened their rushing
foot_note: 1. I say: This classification as Hasan has no basis. Abu Nu'aym found it strange and said: "Al-Fadl bin Yasar was unique in narrating it," and Al-Uqayli declared him weak. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1277), and it also contains the 'an'anah (narrating with 'from') of Al-Hasan Al-Basri.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: to him with eagerness, affection, and longing to the rushing of the nursing she-camel to her calf that she had lost (adallathu). This possibility is supported by his saying: "in a desolate land (barah) of the earth." And Allah knows best (1). And (Al-Barah) with a fathah on the Ba and the unpointed Ha: is the wide land with no crops or trees. 853 - (7) [Weak] And from Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "The martyrs are four: A believing man, good in faith; he met the enemy and was true to Allah until he was killed. That is the one whom people will raise their eyes to look at on the Day of Resurrection like this, -and he raised his head until his cap (qalansuwah) fell off, so I do not know if he meant Umar's cap or the Prophet's cap, may Allah bless him and grant him peace? He said:- And a believing man, good in faith; he met the enemy, so it was as if his skin was struck by the thorns of an acacia tree (talh) out of cowardice (jubn), a stray arrow (sahm gharb) came to him and killed him. He is in the second degree. And a believing man who mixed a good deed with another bad one; he met the enemy and was true to Allah until he was killed. That is in the third degree. And a believing man who transgressed against himself (sinned); he met the enemy and was true to Allah until he was killed. That is in the fourth degree." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Al-Bayhaqi, and At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Gharib hadith." (2)
foot_note:
1. An-Naji said: "This probability is the correct one which allows no other, and it is clear and known." I say: And likewise it appeared in "Ibn Majah" (2/ 184 - At-Taziyah). 
2. Thus he said, and this is from his known leniency. It contains Abu Yazid Al-Khawlani the Tabi'i; he is unknown (majhul) as Al-Hafiz said. Yet, the three [commentators] classified it as Hasan! It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2004).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Qalansuwah): Is what is worn on the head. And (At-Talh) with a fathah on the unpointed Ta and sukun on the Lam: A type of thorny tree. And (Al-Jubn) with a dammah on the Jim and sukun on the Ba: Is fear and lack of courage. And (Sahm Gharb) also in the possessive construct (Sahmu Gharbin), and with sukun on the Ra and moving it in both cases also, has four ways: It is the one whose shooter is not known, nor where it came from. 854 - (8) [Weak] And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it [meaning the hadith of Abu Huraira in "As-Sahih"] through the path of Ismail bin Ayyash longer than it, and he said in it: "They are the martyrs whom Allah resurrects with their swords hanging around their necks around His Throne. Angels from the gathering place come to them with mounts of ruby, their reins (1) are of white pearl, with saddles of gold, their halters (1) are of sundus and istabraq (silk brocade), and their cushions are softer than silk. Their stride is as far as the sight of men. They travel in Paradise on horses, saying when the excursion is long: Let us go [to our Lord] (2) to see how He judges between His creation. Allah laughs at them, and if Allah laughs at a servant in a place, there is no reckoning for him." 855 - (9) [Weak] And from 'Amir bin Sa'd from his father: That a man came to the prayer while the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was praying. When he reached the row he said: (O Allah, give me the best of what You give Your righteous servants). When the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, finished the prayer, he said:
foot_note:
1. Plural of (zimam) like (kitab). Al-Jawhari said: "(Az-Zimam): The cord that is tied to the nose-ring or the nose-piece, then the lead rope is tied to its end, and the lead rope may be called zimam." The intended meaning here is the first one, evidenced by his saying afterwards: "a'innatuha" (their reins), plural of ('inan), weight of kitab as well, for it is the strap of the bridle by which the beast is held. 
2. Addition from "Al-Matalib Al-Aliyah" (3/ 266) by the narration of Abu Ya'la. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5432).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Who was the speaker just now?" The man said: It was I, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Then your steed will be hamstrung and you will be martyred." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, Al-Bazzar, Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Hakim who said: "Sahih on the condition of Muslim" (1).
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, and Adh-Dhahabi agreed with him. But (Muhammad bin Muslim bin 'A'idh) has fallen from its chain (1/ 207), and he is the defect of the hadith, for he is unknown (majhul), and he is established in the chain of the others, and it is a narration of Al-Hakim (2/ 74). It is extracted in the original work.

text: 15 - (Warning against a person dying without having fought (Ghazwa), nor intending to fight, and mentioning types of death that join their people with the martyrs, and warning against fleeing from the plague). 856 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever meets Allah without any trace of Jihad; meets Allah with a defect in him." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Ibn Majah; both from the narration of Ismail bin Rafi' from Sumayy from Abu Salih from him. At-Tirmidhi said: "A Gharib hadith." (Section) 857 - (2) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from Uqbah bin 'Amir, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Five, whoever dies in any of them is a martyr: The one killed in the way of Allah is a martyr, the one who drowns in the way of Allah is a martyr, the one who dies of a stomach disease in the way of Allah is a martyr, the one who dies of plague in the way of Allah is a martyr, and the woman who dies in childbirth in the way of Allah is a martyr." Narrated by An-Nasa'i (1). 858 - (3) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "You will migrate to Sham (the Levant) and it will be conquered for you, and there will be a disease among you like a blister/ulcer or
foot_note: 1. In his "Sunan" (2/ 62) and its men are trustworthy; except Abdullah bin Tha'labah Al-Hadrami, and no one declared him trustworthy except Ibn Hibban. However, the hadith has supporting evidences that strengthen it, so refer to "Ahkam Al-Jana'iz" (p. 50-57 / Al-Ma'arif), but they do not contain his saying regarding other than the one killed in the way of Allah the repetition of "in the way of Allah" in the other characteristics, so it is Munkar (Denounced) with this repeated addition.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: like a stab (1) which takes the soft parts of a man, by which Allah grants them martyrdom, and by which He purifies their deeds." O Allah, if You know that Mu'adh heard it from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, then give him and his family the plentiful share of it. So the plague struck them and not one of them remained, then he was stabbed in his index finger, and he used to say: It does not please me that I have red camels in exchange for it. Narrated by Ahmad from Ismail bin Ubaidullah from Mu'adh, and he did not meet him.
foot_note: 1. Thus in the original, and in "Al-Musnad" (5/ 241): "Kal-harrah" with the unpointed Ra, and in "Al-Majma'" (2/ 311): "Kal-hazzah" with the Zai, and the three [commentators] attributed it to Ahmad! And this is from their lies and ignorance! Perhaps the correct word is (Kal-khazzah) with the two pointed letters (Kha and Zai). An-Naji said (143/ 2): "It is with the Kha and the Zai, both pointed. It is said: 'Khazzahu sahm' (an arrow pierced him), and 'ikhtazzahu': meaning he pierced him and stabbed him so he pierced him."

text: 13 - Book of Reciting the Quran 1 - (Encouragement to recite the Quran in prayer and otherwise, the virtue of learning and teaching it, and encouragement for the prostration of recitation). 859 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever listens to a verse from the Book of Allah; a doubled good deed is written for him, and whoever recites it, it will be a light for him on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Ahmad from Ubadah bin Maysarah - and there is disagreement regarding his trustworthiness - from Al-Hasan from Abu Huraira, and the majority hold that Al-Hasan did not hear from Abu Huraira. 860 - (2) [Very Weak] And from Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The Lord, Blessed and Exalted, says: Whoever is distracted by the Quran from asking Me, I will give him the best of what I give the askers. And the superiority of the Speech of Allah over all other speech is like the superiority of Allah over His creation." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan Gharib hadith" (1). 861 - (3) [Weak] And from Sahl bin Mu'adh from his father; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever reads the Quran and acts upon it; his father will be clothed with a crown on the Day of Resurrection, its light is better than the light of the sun in the houses of the world. So what do you think of the one who acted upon this?" Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim; both from Zabban from Sahl. Al-Hakim said: "Sahih in chain" (2).
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, but in its chain is Muhammad bin Al-Hasan bin Abi Yazid Al-Hamdani; Ibn Ma'in and Abu Dawood called him a liar. Therefore, Adh-Dhahabi said: "At-Tirmidhi called it Hasan but he did not do well (in that judgment)." 
2. I say: Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him saying (1/ 568): "I say: Zabban is not strong." Al-Hafiz said: "Weak." It is extracted in "Da'if Abi Dawood" (259).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 862 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah does not listen to a servant in anything better than two units of prayer he prays. Indeed, righteousness is sprinkled over the head of the servant as long as he is in his prayer. And the servants do not draw near to Allah with anything like that which came out of Him. Meaning the Quran." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan (1) Gharib hadith." 863 - (5) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Three will not be terrified by the Great Terror, nor will the Reckoning reach them; they will be on a dune of musk until the reckoning of the creatures is finished: A man who recited the Quran seeking the Face of Allah and led a people in prayer while they were pleased with him, a caller who calls to the prayers seeking the Face of Allah, and a man who did well in what is between him and his Lord and in what is between him and his patrons." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and "As-Saghir" with a chain that has no harm. He also narrated it in "Al-Kabir" similarly, and added at the beginning: Ibn Umar said: If I had not heard it from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, except once and once until he counted seven times, I would not have narrated it. [Passed in 5 - Prayer / 1].
foot_note: 1. Thus in the original, and it is most likely that the word (Hasan) is inserted by some scribes; because it contradicts the full statement of At-Tirmidhi, for he said (2913): "...and Bakr bin Khunais, Ibn Al-Mubarak spoke about him, and abandoned him in the end of his work." Also, it did not appear in the printed copies, and I have three of them, the most correct being the copy of "Tuhfat Al-Mubarakfuri" (3/ 54). Al-Hafiz Al-Mizzi also did not mention it in his "Tuhfah". Furthermore, it contradicts the author's indication of its weakness by prefacing it with his saying: "Ruwiya" (It was narrated)... among other things that some of which suffice to alert the heedless if they only knew!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 864 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, sent a delegation and they were numerous. He asked them to recite, so he asked every man among them to recite -meaning what he had of the Quran-. He said: He came to a man who was among the youngest of them in age and said: "What do you have, O so-and-so?" He said: I have such and such, and Surah Al-Baqarah. He said: "Do you have Surah Al-Baqarah?" He said: Yes. He said: "Go, for you are their leader." A man from among their nobles said: By Allah, nothing prevented me from learning Al-Baqarah except the fear that I would not stand [in prayer] with it. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Learn the Quran and recite it; for the likeness of the Quran for the one who learns it and recites it is like a bag filled with musk whose scent diffuses in every place. And the one who learns it and sleeps while it is in his hollow (heart/chest) is like a bag that is tied shut on musk." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and he said: "A Hasan hadith" (1). And Ibn Majah briefly, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih". 865 - (7) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever recites the Quran has secured Prophethood between his sides, except that it is not revealed to him. It is not fitting for the companion of the Quran to get angry (2) with those who get angry, nor to be ignorant with those who are ignorant
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, and the three [commentators] imitated him. It contains (Ata Mawla Abi Ahmad), a Tabi'i who is not known; as Adh-Dhahabi said. 
2. Meaning: To rage.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: while the Speech of Allah is inside him." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih in chain" (1). 866 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "You will not return to Allah with anything better than that which came out of Him. Meaning the Quran." Narrated by Al-Hakim who authenticated it (2). Narrated by Abu Dawood in his "Marasil" from Jubair bin Nufair. 867 - (9) [Weak] And from Abdullah -meaning Ibn Mas'ud- may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Indeed this Quran is the Banquet of Allah, so accept His Banquet as much as you can. Indeed this Quran is the Rope of Allah, the Clear Light, the Beneficial Cure, a protection for those who hold fast to it, and salvation for those who follow it. It does not deviate so as to need correction, nor does it become crooked so as to need straightening. Its wonders do not cease, and it does not wear out from much repetition. Recite it; for Allah rewards you for its recitation ten good deeds for every letter. Indeed I do not say to you: {Alif Lam Mim} is a letter, but Alif, and Lam, and Mim" (3). Narrated by Al-Hakim from the narration of Salih bin Umar from Ibrahim Al-Hajari from Abu Al-Ahwas from him. He said: "Salih bin Umar was unique in narrating it from him, and it is Sahih" (4).
foot_note:
1. I say: It contains (Tha'labah Abu Al-Kanud Al-Hamrawi), and there is ignorance regarding him. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5118). 
2. I say: It contains (Abdullah bin Salih), and he contradicted Ibn Mahdi who narrated it as Mursal. Its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1957). Furthermore, it is part of the hadith of At-Tirmidhi previously mentioned here under number (4). 
3. I say: The last part of it is authentic from another path which you can see here in "As-Sahih". 
4. I say: Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him saying (1/ 555): "But Ibrahim bin Muslim [Al-Hajari] is weak." I say: It was narrated from him as Mawquf, and that is what is correct. However, the last sentence has been supported as I verified in "As-Sahihah" (3327), and it is in "As-Sahih" at the beginning of this chapter.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 868 - (10) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever recites the Quran and memorizes it, making lawful what it allows and unlawful what it forbids; Allah will admit him to Paradise by it, and grant him intercession for ten of his family members, all of whom had deserved the Fire." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and At-Tirmidhi with this wording, and he said: "A Gharib hadith" (1). 869 - (11) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "O Abu Dharr! That you go out in the morning and learn a verse from the Book of Allah is better for you than praying one hundred rak'ahs. And that you go out in the morning and learn a chapter of knowledge, whether it is acted upon or not, is better than praying one thousand rak'ahs." Narrated by Ibn Majah with a Hasan chain (2). [Passed in 3 - Knowledge / 1]. 870 - (12) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri: That he saw a dream that he was writing {Sad}, and when he reached its (place of) prostration, he said: He saw the inkwell, the pen, and everything around him fall down in prostration. He said: I told this to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he did not cease prostrating with it. Narrated by Ahmad, and its narrators are narrators of "As-Sahih" (3).
foot_note:
1. I say: The complete statement is: "And its chain is not authentic...", because it contains a narrator who is Matruk (abandoned) and some called him a liar. And above him is an unknown narrator. 
2. It is not as he said; as previously explained there. 
3. Al-Haythami said likewise, but it is disconnected (Munqati'), for in Ahmad (3/ 78 and 84) it is from the path of Bakr Al-Muzani, and they did not mention any narration for him from Abu Sa'id. Al-Bayhaqi narrated it in "As-Sunan" (2/ 320) from him saying: An informant informed me from Abu Sa'id. So the chain goes back to an unknown informant. For such reasons we say: The statement of Al-Hafiz: "its narrators are narrators of As-Sahih" does not imply authenticity. Due to the ignorance of the three [commentators] about this, they said cautiously - as is their habit -: "Hasan"!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2 - (Warning against forgetting the Quran after learning it, and what came regarding one who has nothing of it in his hollow). 871 - (1) [Weak] From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed, the one who does not have any Quran inside him is like a ruined house." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim; both from the path of Qabus bin Abi Zabyan from his father from Ibn Abbas. Al-Hakim said: "Sahih in chain" (1). And At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Sahih hadith" (1). 872 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The rewards of my Ummah were displayed to me, even the speck of dust a man removes from the mosque. And the sins of my Ummah were displayed to me, and I did not see a sin greater than a Surah from the Quran or a verse given to a man which he then forgot." Narrated by Abu Dawood, At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, and Ibn Khuzaymah in his "Sahih"; all from the narration of Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah bin Hantab from Anas. (Al-Hafiz said): "Discussion of it preceded in 'Cleaning the Mosques' [5 - Prayer / 7]".
foot_note: 1. I say: Thus they said! Adh-Dhahabi critiqued Al-Hakim saying (1/ 554): "I say: Qabus is lenient." Al-Hafiz said likewise in "At-Taqrib". As for the Three Ignorant Ones, they said: "Hasan due to its supporting evidences," and they lied; for it has no witness!!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 873 - (3) [Weak] And from Sa'd bin Ubadah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "There is no man who recites the Quran then forgets it, except that he will meet Allah mutilated (ajzama)." Narrated by Abu Dawood from Yazid bin Abi Ziyad from Isa bin Fa'id from Sa'd. (Al-Hafiz said): "Yazid bin Abi Ziyad is Al-Hashimi, their freed slave, his Kunya is Abu Abdullah, discussion of him will come. Furthermore, Isa bin Fa'id only narrated from someone who heard Sa'd. This was stated by Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Hatim and others." Al-Khattabi said: "Abu Ubaid said: Al-Ajzam: The one with a cut hand. Ibn Qutaibah said: Al-Ajzam here means: The leper (majzhum). Ibn Al-A'rabi said: It means that he meets Allah void of hands from any good, using the hand as a metonym for what the hand contains. Another said: It means: He has no argument/proof. We have narrated it from Suwayd bin Ghaflah" (1).
foot_note: 1. "Ma'alim As-Sunan" (2/ 139).

text: 3 - (Encouragement for a supplication to be said for memorizing the Quran). 874 - (1) [Fabricated] From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: While we were with the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, came to him and said: May my father be ransomed for you! This Quran has escaped from my chest, and I do not find myself able to retain it. So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said to him: "O Abu Al-Hasan! Shall I not teach you words by which Allah will benefit you, and benefit whomever you teach them to, and establish what you have learned in your chest?" He said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! Teach me. He said: "When it is Friday night, if you are able to stand in the last third of the night, for it is a witnessed hour, and supplication in it is answered. And my brother Jacob said to his sons: {I will ask forgiveness for you from my Lord} saying: Until Friday night comes. If you cannot, then stand in the middle of it. If you cannot, then stand in the beginning of it. Pray four Rak'ahs. Recite in the first Rak'ah {Fatihat al-Kitab} and Surah {Yasin}, in the second Rak'ah {Fatihat al-Kitab} and {Ha-Mim Ad-Dukhan}, in the third Rak'ah {Fatihat al-Kitab} and {Alif-Lam-Mim Tanzil As-Sajdah}, and in the fourth Rak'ah {Fatihat al-Kitab} and {Tabarak Al-Mufassal}. When you finish the Tashahhud, praise Allah, and praise Allah well, and send blessings upon me and do it well, and upon the rest of the Prophets, and seek forgiveness for the believing men and believing women, and for your brothers who preceded you in faith. Then say at the end of that: (O Allah, have mercy on me by my abandoning sins forever as long as You keep me alive, and have mercy on me lest I take upon myself what does not concern me, and provide me with good sight into what pleases You with me. O Allah, Originator of the heavens
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: and the earth! Possessor of Majesty and Honor, and Glory that is unattainable. I ask You, O Allah, O Rahman, by Your Majesty and the Light of Your Face, to bind my heart to the memorization of Your Book as You taught me, and grant me that I recite it in the manner that pleases You with me. O Allah, Originator of the heavens and the earth! Possessor of Majesty and Honor, and Glory that is unattainable. I ask You, O Allah, O Rahman! By Your Majesty and the Light of Your Face, to illuminate my sight with Your Book, and to unleash my tongue with it, and to relieve my heart with it, and to expand my chest with it, and to employ my body with it. For indeed, no one aids me upon the truth other than You, and no one gives it except You. And there is no power nor strength except by Allah, the Most High, the Magnificent). O Abu Al-Hasan! You do that for three Fridays, or five, or seven. You will be answered by the permission of Allah. By the One Who sent me with the truth, it has never failed a believer." Ibn Abbas said: By Allah, Ali did not wait except for five or seven until he came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in a gathering like that and said: O Messenger of Allah! In the past I used to not grab except four verses or so, and when I recited them to myself they would escape me. Today I learn forty verses or so, and when I recite them to myself, it is as if the Book of Allah is before my eyes. And I used to hear the hadith and when I repeated it, it would escape me. Today I hear the hadiths, and when I speak them, I do not omit a letter from them. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said at that point: "A believer, by the Lord of the Kaaba, O Abu Al-Hasan." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan (1) Gharib hadith, we do not know it except from the narration of Al-Walid bin Muslim." And Al-Hakim narrated it and said:
foot_note: 1. There is doubt regarding the establishment of the word (Hasan) from At-Tirmidhi, which I clarified in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3374).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Sahih on their condition" (1); except that he said: "He reads in the second {Al-Fatihah} and {Alif-Lam-Mim As-Sajdah}, and in the third {Al-Fatihah} and {Ad-Dukhan}." Opposite to what is in At-Tirmidhi. And he said in the supplication: "And that You occupy (tashghala) my body with it." Instead of "employ (tasta'mila)". (The Dictator) may Allah be pleased with him said: "The paths of the chains of this hadith are Jayyid (good), but its text is very strange (Gharib jiddan). And Allah knows best."
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, and An-Naji critiqued him saying (144/ 2): "This is not conceded, for Al-Hakim's Sheikh Abu Ahmad, Al-Uqayli, and others spoke about him, so know that." I say: I have verified the statement regarding its weakness, rather its fabrication, from all its paths in the source referred to previously.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 4 - (Encouragement to maintain the Quran and beautify the voice with it). 875 - (1) [Anomalous (Shadh)] And Ibn Jarir At-Tabari narrated this hadith [meaning the hadith of Abu Huraira in "As-Sahih"] with a Sahih chain (1), and said in it: "Allah does not listen to anything as He listens to a Prophet with a beautiful voice singing/chanting (tarannum) the Quran." 876 - (2) [Weak] And Imam Ahmad, Ibn Majah, Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi narrated from Fadalah bin Ubaid; that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah (2) listens more intently to a man with a beautiful voice reading the Quran than a master of a singing slave-girl listens to his slave-girl." Al-Hakim said: "Sahih on their condition" (3). (Al-Qainah) with a fathah on the Qaf and sukun on the Ya with two dots below followed by Nun: Is the singing female slave. 877 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Indeed this Quran was revealed with sorrow, so when you read it, weep. If you do not weep, then pretend to weep. Sing with it, for whoever does not sing with the Quran is not of us" (4). Narrated by Ibn Majah.
foot_note:
1. I say: But the wording (At-Tarannum) in it is anomalous (Shadh), contradicting the wording of the Two Sheikhs (yataghanna), as I verified in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6640). Before this, I had included it in "Sifat As-Salah" relying on Al-Hafiz, so let it be deleted. 
2. Original: (Allah), and the correction is from the manuscript and those who extracted the hadith. 
3. Thus he said, and Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him saying: "I say: Rather, it is disconnected." It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2951). 
4. The last sentence is in "As-Sahih", so take note.

And {Yasin} is the heart of the Quran; no man reads it desiring Allah and the Last Abode except that he is forgiven." Narrated by Ahmad from a man from Ma'qal. Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah narrated from it the mention of {Yasin}. 879 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "... (1), and in it is a verse which is the chief of the verses of the Quran." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from Hakim bin Jubair from Abu Salih from Abu Huraira. And he said: "A Gharib hadith." [Weak] Al-Hakim narrated it from this path as well, and his wording is: "Surah {Al-Baqarah} contains a verse which is the chief of the verses of the Quran. It is not recited in a house in which there is a devil except that he leaves it: {Ayat al-Kursi}."
foot_note: 1. In the original here: "Everything has a hump, and the hump of the Quran is Surah {Al-Baqarah}," which is from the share of "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And he said: "Sahih in chain" (1). 880 - (3) [Weak] And from Sahl bin Sa'd, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "... (2) Whoever reads it in his house at night; Satan will not enter his house for three nights. And whoever reads it during the day; Satan will not enter his house for three days." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (3). 881 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed Allah ended Surah {Al-Baqarah} with two verses He gave me from His treasure which is under the Throne. So learn them and teach them to your women and children, for they are a prayer, a recitation, and a supplication." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih on the condition of Al-Bukhari." (Al-Hafiz said): "Al-Bukhari did not rely on Mu'awiyah bin Salih, rather Muslim relied on him. Discussion of him will come [meaning at the end of his book]." And Abu Dawood narrated it in his "Marasil" from Jubair bin Nufair (4). 882 - (5) [Weak] And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated from Sufyan raising it; he said: "Whoever reads the end of {Al Imran} and does not reflect upon it, woe to him," and he counted ten with his fingers.
foot_note:
1. I say: Rather it is weak, in its path is one who narrates denounced reports (manakir); as explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1348). 
2. In the original here: "Indeed everything has a hump, and the hump of the Quran is Surah {Al-Baqarah}," which is from the share of "As-Sahih". 
3. I say: It contains one who was not declared trustworthy except by Ibn Hibban, and Ibn Al-Qattan declared him unknown; as explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" also (1349), with the note that the first half is established without: "three nights...". 
4. I say: And that is correct: Mursal.

text: 9 - (Encouragement to read Surah {Yasin}, and what came regarding its virtue). 884 - (1) [Weak] From Ma'qal bin Yasar, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The heart of the Quran is {Yasin}. No man reads it desiring Allah and the Last Abode; except that Allah forgives him. Read it upon your dying ones." Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i and the wording is his (1), Ibn Majah, and Al-Hakim who authenticated it. 885 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed everything has a heart, and the heart of the Quran is {Yasin}. Whoever reads {Yasin}; Allah writes for him by reading it the recitation of the Quran ten times." He added in a narration: "Excluding {Yasin}" (2). Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib hadith." 886 - (3) [Weak] And from Jundub, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever reads {Yasin} in a night seeking the Face of Allah; is forgiven." Narrated by Malik, Ibn As-Sunni, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (3). (The Dictator) may Allah be pleased with him said: "And mention of Surah {Ad-Dukhan} will come in the chapter 'What is said day and night not specific to morning or evening' [14 - Remembrance / 10]".
foot_note:
1. I say: The others only have the command to read. Furthermore, in An-Nasa'i in "Al-Amal" its wording is: "And {Yasin} is the heart..." indicating it is abbreviated. It is complete in "Al-Musnad", and its chain contains ignorance and disturbance (idtirab). It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6843). 
2. I say: This addition is not in At-Tirmidhi, nor did it appear in any of the hadiths of {Yasin}, and As-Suyuti listed a large group of them in "Ad-Durr Al-Manthur" (5/ 256 - 257), nor did I know a meaning for it here, so it appears it is inserted. As for the three investigators!, they attributed it to At-Tirmidhi (2887) and moved on! 
3. I say: It contains the 'an'anah of Al-Hasan Al-Basri. Attributing it to Ibn As-Sunni is an error or leniency, for he has it (668) from Al-Hasan from Abu Huraira! It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah", number (6643), and this error will be mentioned in (14 - Remembrance / 10).

text: 10 - (Encouragement to read Surah {Tabarak Alladhi Biyadihi Al-Mulk}). 887 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: Some of the companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, set up a tent over a grave, while not thinking it was a grave. Suddenly, there was a person in the grave reading Surah {Al-Mulk} until he finished it. He came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and said: O Messenger of Allah! I set up my tent over a grave, and I did not think it was a grave, suddenly there was a person in the grave reading Surah {Al-Mulk} until he finished it. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "It is the Preventer, it is the Savior, it saves him from the punishment of the grave" (1). Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib hadith." 888 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "I wished that it was in the heart of every believer. Meaning {Blessed is He in whose hand is dominion}." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "This chain is Sahih according to the Yemenis" (2). 11 - (Encouragement to read {When the sun is wrapped up} and what is mentioned with it). [No hadith meeting the condition of our book was mentioned under it, and praise be to Allah. See "As-Sahih"]

text: 14 - Book of Remembrance (Dhikr) (1). 1 - (Encouragement to remember Allah the Exalted often, secretly and openly, and persisting in it, and what came regarding one who does not remember Allah often). 894 - (1) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from Mu'adh bin Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah, majestic is His remembrance, said: No servant remembers Me in himself except that I mention him in an assembly of My angels, and he does not mention Me in an assembly except that I mention him in the Highest Companions (Ar-Rafiq Al-A'la) (2)." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan chain. 895 - (2) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from Abu Al-Khariq who said: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "I passed on the night I was taken on the Night Journey by a man covered in the light of the Throne. I said: Who is this; is it an angel? It was said: No. I said: A Prophet? It was said: No. I said: Who is he? He said: This is a man who in the world had a tongue moist with the remembrance of Allah, his heart was attached to the mosques, and he did not incur cursing for his parents (3)." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya like this as Mursal (4).
foot_note:
1. In the original here "Book of Remembrance and Supplication", and they have been made into two separate books. 
2. Original: (Ar-Rafiq Al-Mala'), and the correction is from "At-Tabarani" and "Majma' Az-Zawa'id" (10/ 98). Furthermore, the hadith contains (Zabban) the weak, and its text is Munkar (denounced); due to its contradiction of some authentic hadiths, for the preserved wording in the first paragraph is: "...except that I mention him in Myself." See "As-Sahih". And it contains another contradiction, which is the mention of (Ar-Rafiq Al-A'la). It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6641). 
3. Meaning: He did not do an act for which he would be exposed to cursing them. Stated by Al-Hafiz An-Naji. 
4. Thus he said! The correct view is that it is Mu'dal (problematic/missing two consecutive narrators); because the narrator from (Abu Al-Mukhariq) died in the middle of the third century, and the chain contains ignorance. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6845).

text: 896 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And from Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd who said: It was said to Abu Darda: A man freed one hundred slaves? He said: Indeed, one hundred slaves from a man's wealth is a lot, but better than that is faith bound by night and day, and that the tongue of one of you remains moist with the remembrance of Allah. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya as Mawquf with a Hasan chain (1). 897 - (4) [Fabricated] And from Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace; that he used to say: "Indeed for everything there is a polish, and the polish of the hearts is the remembrance of Allah..." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and Al-Bayhaqi from the narration of Sa'id bin Sinan (2), and the wording is his. 898 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was asked: Which servants are best in degree with Allah on the Day of Resurrection? He said: "Those who remember Allah often." He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! And [what] of the fighter in the way of Allah? He said: "Even if he struck with his sword among the disbelievers and polytheists until it broke and was dyed with blood; those who remember Allah would be better in degree." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib hadith."
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, and the three [commentators] imitated him! And Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd did not meet Abu Darda as Abu Hatim said. From this mode Al-Bayhaqi also extracted it in "Ash-Shu'ab" (1/ 435/ 627). 
2. I say: He is Abu Mahdi Al-Homsi, Matruk (abandoned), Ad-Daraqutni and others accused him of fabrication as Al-Hafiz said. So it is strange from the author how he prefaces his hadith with (An)! It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4987). And from the ignorance of the three is that they imagined he is Abu Sinan Ash-Shaybani so they weakened him! While he is from the men of Muslim!! And the completion of the hadith indicated by dots I deleted; because it is strong due to the hadith of Jabir which is in this chapter of "As-Sahih".

text: And Al-Bayhaqi narrated it briefly, saying: It was asked: O Messenger of Allah! Which people are greatest in degree? He said: "Those who remember Allah." 899 - (6) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both; that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Four, whoever is given them has been given the good of this world and the Hereafter: A thankful heart, a remembering tongue, a body patient over trials, and a wife who does not seek betrayal (khawnan) (1) regarding herself and his wealth." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Jayyid (good) chain. 900 - (7) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Surely, peoples will remember Allah in the world on soft beds, and He will enter them into the highest degrees." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" from the path of Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham. 901 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Remember Allah so much that they say: A madman." Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Hakim who said: "Sahih in chain" (2).
foot_note:
1. Original: (Hawban), which is a misspelling repeated later in (17 - Marriage / 2). An-Naji proceeded upon it and interpreted it saying (146/ 1): "And (Al-Hub) with damma or fatha on the Ha, (Al-Hubah) is sin." This meaning, although close to (Khawnan); but this [Khawnan] is what is established in a good copy of "Kabir At-Tabarani" and "Al-Awsat" also number (7208) and others. The author's declaring its chain Jayyid is an illusion followed by a group, I explained its cause in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1066). 
2. I say: It also contains Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham, so how can it be Sahih?! And Adh-Dhahabi denounced it. It and the one after it are extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (515 - 517).

Narrated by At-Tabarani. [Weak] And Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from Abu Al-Jawza' as Mursal. 903 - (10) [Weak] And At-Tirmidhi [narrated] [meaning the Hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih"], and his wording is: O Messenger of Allah! And (Khatmuhu) with Fatha on Kha Mu'jamah and Sukun on Ta Muhmalah: is his mouth. 905 - (12) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "There is no day or night except that Allah (Azza wa Jal) has a charity in it that He bestows upon whom He wills of
foot_note: 1. I say: And with Shadda on Ra as in "Muslim" and "Al-Qamus".

text: His servants, and Allah has not bestowed upon a servant anything better than inspiring him to remember Him." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. 906 - (13) [Weak] And it was narrated from Mu'adh (1), may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: That a man asked him saying: Which of the Mujahideen has the greatest reward? He said: "The one among them who remembers Allah, Blessed and Exalted, the most." He said: Which of the fasting people (2) has the greatest reward? He said: "The one among them who remembers Allah, Blessed and Exalted, the most." Then he mentioned prayer, Zakat, Hajj, and charity, all of that while the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was saying: "The one among them who remembers Allah, Blessed and Exalted, the most." So Abu Bakr said to Umar: O Abu Hafs! The people of remembrance have taken all the good. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Yes." Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani. 907 - (14) [Weak] And from Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "If a man had dirhams in his lap distributing them, and another was remembering Allah, the one remembering Allah would be better."
foot_note:
1. I say: He is Ibn Anas Al-Juhani as in "Al-Musnad" (3/ 438), so the author should have restricted it; because when mentioned absolutely, Mu'adh bin Jabal is intended, and similar occurred from him in (12 - Jihad / 5). 
2. Original: (As-Salihin - the righteous), which is a distortion followed by Amarah and the three imitators in their edition!! The correction is from "Al-Musnad" and the context supports it, and Sheikh An-Naji alerted to this distortion.

text: 908 - (15) [Very Weak] And in a narration (1): "No charity is better than the remembrance of Allah." At-Tabarani narrated both of them, and their narrators' Hadith is Hasan. 909 - (16) [Weak] And from Umm Anas, may Allah be pleased with them both; that she said: O Messenger of Allah! Advise me. He said: "Abandon sins; for it is the best Hijrah (migration), and maintain the obligatory duties; for it is the best Jihad, and increase in the remembrance of Allah; for indeed you do not come to Allah with anything more beloved to Him than abundance of His remembrance." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Jayyid chain. [Weak] And in a narration by them (2) from Umm Anas: "And remember Allah much; for it is the most beloved of deeds to Allah that you meet Him with (3)." At-Tabarani said: "This Umm Anas - meaning the second one - is not the mother of Anas bin Malik" (4). 910 - (17) [Weak] From Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said:
foot_note:
1. Thus the author said, may Allah have mercy on him, and it implies that it is from the Hadith of Abu Musa himself, but it is not so. Rather, it is from the narration of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, as Al-Hafiz An-Naji pointed out. It and the first narration are both in "Mu'jam At-Tabarani Al-Awsat"; contrary to what the author's absolute attribution of them to At-Tabarani implies. And his saying: "their narrators' Hadith is Hasan", is not so as I verified in "Ad-Da'ifah" number (4348). 
2. Thus in the original matching the Zahiriyyah manuscript. Al-Haythami attributed the first narration to At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat", and likewise he attributed this one to them. Perhaps the phrase "in Al-Kabir and Al-Awsat" was dropped from the pen of the author or the copyist in the first one. By that, the dual pronoun referring to them would be correct. This one is in two places therein (6731 and 6818) and from one weak path. And Allah knows best. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5119).

He does not pass by a group of angels with them except that they seek forgiveness for their sayer, until the Face of the Most Merciful is greeted (Yuhayya) with them. Then Abdullah recited: {To Him ascends good speech and righteous work raises it}. Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad". (Al-Hafiz said): "Thus in my two copies (Yuhayya) with Ha Muhmalah and Shadda on Muthannah Taht". Then I saw it correctly also in "Tafsir Ibn Kathir", and "Ad-Durr Al-Manthur". And Allah knows best. I saw it recently in "Tafsir At-Tabari" (22/ 80) with the wording (Yahya). Whichever it is, their chain contains (Abdur-Rahman bin Abdullah Al-Mas'udi), and he had become confused, so how excellent is the one who authenticated it, or graded it Hasan like the three commentators.

text: 9 - (Encouragement to say: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah [There is no power nor strength except by Allah]). (The Dictator) may Allah be pleased with him said: "It has already been mentioned recently in many hadiths the mention of 'La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah', including the hadith of Abu Huraira..., and the hadith of Abu Sa'id..., and the hadith of Abu Al-Mundhir... so their proximity sufficed from repeating them. 969 - (1) [Weak] Makhul said [meaning in the hadith of Abu Huraira in "As-Sahih"]: "Whoever says: (Wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah, wa la manja min Allahi illa ilayhi - And there is no power nor strength except by Allah, and there is no refuge from Allah except to Him); Allah removes from him seventy doors of harm, the least of them is poverty." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "This hadith's chain is not connected, Makhul did not hear from Abu Huraira." [Weak] And An-Nasa'i and Al-Bazzar narrated it at length and as Marfu': "Wa la malja'a min Allahi illa ilayhi - And there is no shelter from Allah except to Him." And their narrators are trustworthy and relied upon. [Weak] And in a narration of his [meaning Al-Hakim] and he authenticated it also, he said: "O Abu Huraira! Shall I not guide you to a treasure from the treasures of Paradise?" I said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Say: (La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah, wa la malja'a wa la manja min Allahi illa ilayhi - There is no power nor strength except by Allah, and there is no shelter nor refuge from Allah except to Him)." He mentioned it in a hadith. 970 - (2) [Weak] And from him from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever says: (La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah); it is a cure for ninety-nine diseases, the least of them is worry."
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Hakim who said: "Sahih in chain" (1). (Al-Hafiz said): "Rather, its chain contains Bishr bin Rafi' Abu Al-Asbat, and discussion of him will come [at the end of his book]. 971 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Uqbah bin Amir who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever Allah bestows a blessing upon and wants it to remain; let him increase in saying: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 972 - (4) [Weak] And from Muhammad bin Ishaq who said: Malik Al-Ashja'i came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and said: My son Auf has been captured. He said: "I will send to him that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, orders you to increase in saying (La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah)." So the messenger came to him and informed him. So Auf devoted himself to saying: (La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah). They had bound him with leather straps (qidd) (2), but the straps fell off him and he went out. Suddenly he found a she-camel of theirs, so he rode it and came. Suddenly he came upon the livestock of the people (3), so he shouted at them and the last of them followed the first of them. He did not surprise his parents except by calling out at the door. His father said: Auf, by the Lord of the Kaaba. His mother said: Alas! How can Auf come; due to what he is in (4) of leather straps; so the father and the servant raced to the door,
foot_note:
1. Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him regarding Bishr saying: "Flimsy (Wahin)", and its explanation is in "As-Sahihah" (1528). 
2. With kasra: It is (the thong), originally a strap cut from untanned skin. "An-Nihayah". 
3. Meaning: Their livestock and camels. 
4. Original and Manuscript: (Ka'ib bi-alam ma fihi - depressed with the pain of what he is in), and the correction is from "Tafsir Ibn Kathir", attributing it to Ibn Abi Hatim.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: and there was Auf who had filled the courtyard with camels. So he told his father his story and the story of the camels. His father went to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and informed him of the news of Auf and the news of the camels. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said to him: "Do with them whatever you like, and whatever you would do with your own camels." And there was revealed: {And whoever fears Allah - He will make for him a way out And will provide for him from where he does not expect. And whoever relies upon Allah - then He is sufficient for him}." Narrated by Adam bin Abi Iyas in his "Tafsir", and Muhammad bin Ishaq (1) did not meet Malik.
foot_note: 1. He is the author of Al-Maghazi.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 10 - (Encouragement for Adhkar said by night and day not specific to morning and evening). 973 - (1) [Weak] And from Jundub bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever reads {Yasin} in a night seeking the Face of Allah; is forgiven." Narrated by Ibn As-Sunni, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (1). 974 - (2) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated from Abu Umamah who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever reads ten verses in a night is not written among the heedless. Whoever reads a hundred verses, the Qunut (devotion) of a night is written for him. Whoever reads two hundred verses is written among the Qanitin (devout). Whoever reads four hundred verses is written among the Abidin (worshippers). Whoever reads five hundred verses is written among the Hafizin (preservers). Whoever reads six hundred verses is written among the Khashi'in (humble). Whoever reads eight hundred verses is written among the Mukhbitin (submissive). And whoever reads a thousand verses, a Qintar becomes his. A Qintar is one thousand two hundred Uqiyyah, and an Uqiyyah is better than what is between heaven and earth—or he said: better than what the sun rises upon—. And whoever reads two thousand verses is among (2) the Mujibin." [Passed in 6 - Voluntary Prayers / 11]. 975 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever reads every day a hundred times: {Say, He is Allah, One}; the sins of fifty years are wiped from him; unless he has debt." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib hadith from the hadith of Thabit from Anas."
foot_note:
1. It contains the 'an'anah of Al-Hasan Al-Basri, and attributing it to Ibn As-Sunni is an error as explained previously in (13 - Quran / 9). 
2. Original: (fi - in), and the correction is from At-Tabarani (8/ 212) and "Al-Majma'" (2/ 268), and it appeared correctly previously.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 976 - (4) [Weak] And from Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever reads in a night: {So whoever would hope for the meeting with his Lord - let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone}; will have a light from (Aden Abyan) to Mecca filled with angels." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and its narrators are trustworthy; except that Abu Qurrah (1) Al-Asadi did not narrate from him, as far as I know, other than An-Nadr bin Shumail (2). 977 - (5) [Weak] And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever reads every night {Al-Waqi'ah} will not be afflicted by poverty, and in {Al-Musabbihat} is a verse like a thousand verses." Razin mentioned it in his "Jami'", and I did not see it in any of the original sources, and Abu Al-Qasim Al-Asbahani mentioned it in his book without a chain (3). 978 - (6) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever reads Surah {Ad-Dukhan} in a night; enters the morning with seventy thousand angels seeking forgiveness for him."
foot_note:
1. In the original and manuscript: (Abu Farwah), which is an error, and the correction is from "Zawa'id Al-Bazzar" and books of Rijal. 
2. I say: This means in their terminology that he is unknown (majhul), and Adh-Dhahabi and Al-Asqalani explicitly stated his ignorance. As I mentioned in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5134). 
3. I say: This implies he mentioned it in full, which is contrary to reality, for he only has in "At-Targhib" (1/ 399/ 930) the first half of it. The ignorant ones overlooked this error and even affirmed it, adding that they attributed it to three Huffaz including Al-Bayhaqi, while they only extracted the first part!! It is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (289). As for the other half, another chain with an unknown narrator was narrated from Al-Irbad bin Sariyah similarly. It is extracted in "At-Ta'liq Ar-Raghib" (1/ 210), and passed in (6 - Voluntary Prayers / 9). So the hadith is fabricated from two hadiths, Razin made them one hadith, and there are examples for this, I think some have passed.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Ad-Daraqutni. [Weak Fabricated] And in a narration of Ad-Daraqutni: "Whoever reads Surah {Yasin} in a night enters the morning forgiven. And whoever reads {Ad-Dukhan} on Friday night enters the morning forgiven" (1). 979 - (7) [Very Weak] And from Abu Al-Mundhir Al-Juhani, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I said: O Prophet of Allah! Teach me the best speech? He said: "O Abu Al-Mundhir! Say: (There is no deity except Allah alone with no partner for Him, for Him is the dominion, and for Him is the praise, He gives life and causes death, in His hand is the good, and He is over all things competent) a hundred times in a day; for you will be on that day the best of people in deed; except one who said the like of what you said" The Hadith. Narrated by Al-Bazzar from the narration of Jabir Al-Ju'fi. [Passed here Chapter 7]. 980 - (8) [Weak] And it was narrated from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever says: (La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah) a hundred times every day; poverty will never afflict him."
foot_note: 1. I say: He went too far in attributing it to Ad-Daraqutni, perhaps it is in his book "Al-Afrad", for Abu Ya'la extracted it with both paragraphs in his "Musnad" (11/ 93 - 94) from the path of Hisham bin Ziyad, from Al-Hasan who said: I heard (sic) Abu Huraira say: then he mentioned it as Marfu'. From this mode Ibn Ad-Durais extracted it in "Fada'il Al-Quran" (101/ 221) and Al-Bayhaqi in "Ash-Shu'ab" (2/ 484 - 485) similarly without Al-Hasan declaring hearing. At-Tirmidhi (2891) and Ibn As-Sunni (673) narrated the second paragraph like this, and At-Tirmidhi said: "We do not know it except from this mode, and Hisham Abu Al-Miqdam is weak, and Al-Hasan did not hear from Abu Huraira." This Hisham is accused. At-Tirmidhi and others also narrated it with a fuller wording, which is the one before it, and it contains another accused narrator, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6734). The first paragraph was narrated from other paths from Al-Hasan from Abu Huraira, and passed in (13 - Quran / 9) via the narration of Ibn Hibban from Jundub. The paths referred to have been mentioned with who narrated them along with some of their witnesses in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6623), therefore I differentiated between it and the other paragraph; limiting myself to weakening it without the other due to the lack of a valid witness for it.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya from Asad bin Wada'ah from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Its narrators are trustworthy except Asad (1). 981 - (9) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "There is no servant who says: (There is no deity except Allah) a hundred times; except that Allah resurrects him on the Day of Resurrection with his face like the moon on the night of the full moon, and no deed is raised for anyone on that day better than his deed, except one who said the like of his saying, or added." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 982 - (10) [Weak] And from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "That Gabriel, peace be upon him, descended to him and said: O Muhammad! If it pleases you to worship Allah for a night with His true worship, say: (O Allah, for You is praise, eternal praise with Your eternity. And for You is praise, everlasting praise with no end to it without Your will. And at every glance of an eye, or breath of a soul)." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Abu Ash-Shaykh Ibn Hayyan, and his wording is: He said: "O Muhammad! If it pleases you to worship Allah by night with His true worship or by day, say: (O Allah, for You is praise, eternal praise with Your eternity. And for You is praise, praise with no reward for its sayer except Your pleasure. And for You is praise at every glance of an eye, or breath of a soul)." In their chains is Ali bin As-Salt Al-Amiri; his status is not present with me. It passed similarly in Al-Bayhaqi [here end of Chapter 8]. And Allah knows best.
foot_note: 1. I say: He is a Levantine (Shami) from the junior Tabi'in, so his hadith is Mursal or Mu'dal; in addition to him being a Nasibi who reviled our master Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, and no one declared him trustworthy except An-Nasa'i.

text: 11 - (Encouragement for verses and Adhkar after the obligatory prayers). 983 - (1) [Weak] And [meaning the hadith of Abu Huraira in "As-Sahih"] At-Tirmidhi (1) narrated it and classified it Hasan, and An-Nasa'i from the hadith of Ibn Abbas similarly, and they said in it: "So when you pray say: (Glory be to Allah) thirty-three times, and (Praise be to Allah) thirty-three times, and (Allah is the Greatest) thirty-four times, and (There is no deity except Allah) ten times; for you will catch up with those who preceded you, and those after you will not surpass you." 984 - (2) [Weak] And from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, when he married him to Fatimah, sent with her a velvet coverlet (khamilah), a pillow of leather stuffed with palm fiber, two hand mills, a waterskin, and two jars. Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said to Fatimah, may Allah be pleased with her, one day: By Allah, I have drawn water from the well until my chest hurts, and Allah has brought your father captives, so go and ask him for a servant. She said: And I, by Allah, have ground until my hands are blistered. So she came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he said: "What brings you, O my little daughter?" She said: I came to greet you, and she felt shy to ask him, and returned. Ali said: What did you do? She said: I felt shy to ask him. So they both came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Ali said: O Messenger of Allah! I have drawn water until my chest hurts, and Fatimah said: I have ground until my hands are blistered, and Allah has brought you captives and abundance, so give us a servant. He said:
foot_note: 1. Meaning in his "Sunan" (2/ 265 - Shakir).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "By Allah I will not give you and leave the People of the Bench (Ahl as-Suffah) with their bellies folded (1) from hunger, not finding what to spend on them, but I will sell them and spend their prices on them." So they returned. Then the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, came to them, and they had entered under their velvet coverlet; if it covered their heads their feet were exposed, and if it covered their feet their heads were exposed. So they jumped up. He said: "Stay in your places." Then he said: "Shall I not inform you of something better than what you asked me for?" They said: Yes. He said: "Words Gabriel taught me." He said: "Glorify Allah (Tasbih) after every prayer ten times, praise Him (Tahmid) ten times, and magnify Him (Takbir) ten times. And when you retire to your bed, glorify thirty-three times, praise thirty-three times, and magnify thirty-four times." Ali said: By Allah I have not left them since I heard them from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Ibn Al-Kawwa' said to him: Not even the night of Siffin? He said: May Allah fight you O people of Iraq! Not even the night of Siffin. Narrated by Ahmad and the wording is his. And narrated by Al-Bukhari (2), Muslim, Abu Dawood, and At-Tirmidhi, and it passed in "What to say when retiring to bed" [6 - Voluntary Prayers / 9] with a different context. In this context there is strangeness, and its chain is Jayyid (good), and its narrators are trustworthy. Ata bin As-Sa'ib is trustworthy, and Hammad bin Salamah heard from him before his confusion (1). And Allah knows best.
foot_note:
1. He said in "An-Nihayah": "It is said: (Tawiya) from hunger, he folds a folding, so he is Tawin; meaning empty: The belly is hungry he did not eat. And Tawa yatwi: if he intended that." 
2. I say: Gathering Al-Bukhari and those mentioned with him here is baseless, due to the great difference between this narration and their narrations, especially the narration of the Two Sheikhs. This becomes clear to the reader by comparing their narration which I listed in "As-Sahih" (6 - Voluntary Prayers / 9) on one hand, and the narration of Abu Dawood which the author cited, and I mentioned there in this "Weak" book on the other hand, with this narration here. The difference will inevitably appear to you, and the author's leniency in extraction and attribution will become clear, may Allah forgive us and him.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Khamilah) with fatha on the dotted Kha and kasra on the Mim: A garment with a nap (plush), usually made into a [cover] (2), and it is also the velvet (Qatifah). (Min Adam) with fatha on the Alif and Dal; meaning: of leather, and it is said: of red leather. (Rahayayn) with fatha on the Ra and Ha and light Ya: Dual of (Raha). And his saying: (Sanawtu) with fatha on the unpointed Sin and Nun; meaning: I drew water from the well, so I was in place of the Saniyah, which is the she-camel used to irrigate the lands. And his saying: (Fastakhdimihi) meaning: Ask him for a servant, and likewise his saying: (Fa'akhdimna) with kasra on the Dal: meaning: give us a servant. And her saying: (Majalat yadaya) with fatha on the Jim and kasra; meaning: blistered (3) from excessive grinding. 985 - (3) [Weak] And from Al-Hasan bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever reads Ayat al-Kursi after the obligatory prayer; is in the protection of Allah until the next prayer." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan chain (4).
foot_note:
1. I say: He heard from him after the confusion as well, so this narration of his is not authentic with what it contains of contradiction to the narration of the Two Sheikhs which I pointed to and referred to previously. Yes, it contains a sentence authentic in "Al-Musnad", from another path I pointed to in the commentary on the hadith in the chapter the author referred to. 
2. Fell from the original and the edition of Amarah and the Three also! I restored it from the manuscript, and in the edition of the Three: (Aliyan)!! 
3. Original: (Taqatta'at - cut)! The intended meaning is that her hands developed blisters. 
4. I say: This is from the author's leniency, and the Three imitated him. In its chain is a weakened narrator, and one who is not known. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5135).

text: 986 - (4) [Denounced (Munkar) Mawquf] And from Abu Kathir the freed slave of Banu Hashim; that he heard Abu Dharr Al-Ghifari, the companion of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: Words, whoever mentions them a hundred times after every prayer: (Allah is the Greatest, and Glory be to Allah, and Praise be to Allah, and There is no deity except Allah alone with no partner for Him, and There is no power nor strength except by Allah), then even if his sins were like the foam of the sea, they would wipe them out. Narrated by Ahmad, and it is Mawquf (1). 987 - (5) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abdullah [bin Zaid] (2) bin Arqam from his father from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever says after every prayer: {Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of might, above what they describe (180) And peace upon the messengers (181) And praise to Allah, Lord of the worlds} [three times] (3); has measured with the fullest measure of reward." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 988 - (6) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever says after the prayer: (Glory be to Allah the Great and with His praise, there is no power nor strength except by Allah); stands up forgiven." Narrated by Al-Bazzar from Abu Az-Zahra' from Anas, and his chain to Abu Az-Zahra' is Jayyid, and I do not know Abu Az-Zahra'.

I had missed alerting to it in "Da'if Al-Jami' As-Saghir" (4268 - First Legal Edition), so let it be commented upon. For this and others I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6851).

text: 989 - (7) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever supplicates with these (1) supplications after every prescribed prayer; intercession from me becomes lawful for him on the Day of Resurrection: (O Allah give Muhammad the Wasilah (means of approach), and make his love in the chosen ones, and his degree in the high ones, and his abode in the near ones)." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and it is Gharib. 990 - (8) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever says after every prayer: (I seek forgiveness from Allah [Who there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer] (2) and I repent to Him); is forgiven, even if he had fled from battle." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat". 12 - (Encouragement for what to say and do for one who sees in his sleep what he dislikes). [No hadith meeting the condition of our book was mentioned under it, and praise be to Allah. See "As-Sahih"]
