publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 13 - (Encouragement for words to say for one who has insomnia or is startled at night). 991 - (1) [Weak Mawquf] [Amr bin Shu'aib from his father] said: And Abdullah bin Amr used to teach them [meaning the words mentioned in "As-Sahih"] to those of his children who understood, and those who did not understand, he wrote them in a scroll then hung it on his neck. Narrated by Abu Dawood, and At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and he said: "A Hasan Gharib hadith," ... (1) and Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih in chain." And he does not have restricting it to sleep. 992 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Khalid bin Al-Walid told the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, about terrors he sees at night that prevented him from the night prayer. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "O Khalid bin Al-Walid! Shall I not teach you words you say, you will not say them three times until Allah removes that from you?" He said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! May my father and mother be ransomed for you, I only complained of this to you hoping for this from you. He said: "Say: (I seek refuge in the complete words of Allah from His anger and His punishment, and the evil of His servants, and from the whisperings of the devils, and that they be present with me)."
foot_note: 1. In the original at the place of the dots: (and An-Nasa'i), so I deleted it; because this saying is not with him. It is with the others after the Marfu' hadith which is in "As-Sahih", and its wording belongs to At-Tirmidhi, and it contains the 'an'anah of Ibn Ishaq. I only mentioned it there because it has a witness, see the commentary on "Al-Kalim At-Tayyib" (p. 45) and "As-Sahihah" (2738).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Aisha said: So I did not wait but a few nights until Khalid bin Al-Walid came and said: O Messenger of Allah! May my father and mother be ransomed for you, by the One who sent you with the truth, I did not complete the words you taught me three times until Allah removed from me what I used to find. I would not mind if I entered upon a lion in his thicket at night. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". (Khisat al-Asad) with kasra on the dotted Kha: Is his place where he takes shelter. 993 - (3) [Weak] And from Khalid bin Al-Walid, may Allah be pleased with him: That insomnia afflicted him, so the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Shall I not teach you words, if you say them you will sleep? Say: (O Allah, Lord of the seven heavens and what they shaded, and Lord of the earths and what they carried, and Lord of the devils and what they misled, be for me a neighbor (protector) from the evil of all Your creation, lest any of them excesses against me or transgresses. Mighty is Your protection, and blessed is Your name)." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat" (1) and the wording is his, and its chain is Jayyid; except that Abdur-Rahman bin Sabit did not hear from Khalid. And he said in "Al-Kabir": "Mighty is Your protection, and glorious is Your praise, and there is no deity other than You." 994 - (4) [Very Weak] And At-Tirmidhi narrated it from the hadith of Buraidah with a chain containing weakness (2). And he said at its end: "Mighty is Your protection and glorious is Your praise, and there is no deity other than You, there is no deity except You."
foot_note:
1. Al-Haythami said likewise (10/ 126), and it is an error, the correct is: "and (As-Saghir)", (p. 205 - Indian). It is in "Ar-Rawd An-Nadir" (1/ 299).

text: 16 - (Encouragement for seeking forgiveness). 1000 - (1) [Denounced (Munkar)] From Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace; that he said: "Allah the Mighty and Majestic says: O children of Adam! All of you are sinners except whom I have pardoned; so seek My forgiveness I will forgive you. And all of you are poor except whom I have enriched; so ask Me I will give you. And all of you are astray except whom I have guided; so ask Me for guidance I will guide you. And whoever seeks My forgiveness knowing that I have power to forgive him, I forgive him and I do not mind. If the first of you and the last of you, the living of you and the dead of you, the moist of you and the dry of you; gathered upon the heart of the most wretched man among you, that would not decrease from My dominion the like of a gnat's wing. And if the first of you and the last of you, the living of you and the dead of you, the moist of you and the dry of you; gathered upon the heart of the most pious man among you, they would not increase in My dominion the like of a gnat's wing. And if the first of you and the last of you, the living of you and the dead of you, the moist of you and the dry of you, asked Me until the request of every one of them ended, and I gave them what they asked; that would not decrease what is with Me like the dip of a needle if one of you dipped it in the sea. That is because I am Generous, Glorious, One. My giving is speech, and My punishment is speech. Indeed My command to a thing if I want it is to say to it: Be, and it is." Narrated by Muslim, At-Tirmidhi who classified it Hasan, Ibn Majah, and Al-Bayhaqi and the wording is his. In its chain is Shahr bin Hawshab and Ibrahim bin Tahman (1). At-Tirmidhi's wording is similar; except that he said: "O My servants...". And Muslim's wording will come in the next chapter if Allah wills [in "As-Sahih"].
foot_note: 1. I say: This Ibrahim is trustworthy from the men of Al-Bukhari, and the speech said about him does not harm him. Rather its defect is Shahr, and he has poor memory. He is in the chain of everyone except Muslim, and his wording differs from Muslim's narration, such that it is not correct to say it testifies for it. Therefore, I listed it here. As for Muslim's narration, it will come in "As-Sahih", in the next chapter if Allah the Exalted wills. Therefore, Sheikh An-Naji attributed leniency to Al-Mundhiri, and wondered at his pairing Ibrahim with Shahr!

She said: He said one day: "O Aisha! Did you know that Allah has shown me the Name which if He is called by it He answers?"

For I found its chain through "Al-Maqsad Al-Ali" by Al-Haythami (2/ 344/ 1682), and the statement of the commentator on it: "Its chain is weak" is rejected. Had he remained silent as Al-Busiri remained silent on it, it would have been better for him. Perhaps he wanted to say something else like what I will mention - but faltered! For this (As-Sari bin Yahya) is from the followers of the Tabi'in, so the man he did not name would be an unknown Tabi'i. It becomes a weak Maqtu' with no proof in it. text: She said: So I said: May my father and mother be ransomed for you O Messenger of Allah! Teach it to me. He said: "It is not fitting for you O Aisha!" She said: So I moved away and sat for a while then got up and kissed his head then said: O Messenger of Allah! Teach it to me. He said: "It is not fitting for you O Aisha that I teach you; for it is not fitting that you ask by it for anything of the world." She said: So I got up and performed ablution then prayed two Rak'ahs, then said: O Allah, indeed I call upon You Allah, and call upon You Ar-Rahman, and call upon You Al-Barr Ar-Rahim, and I call upon You by all Your Beautiful Names what I know of them and what I do not know, that You forgive me and have mercy on me. She said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, laughed then said: "Indeed it is in the Names you called with." Narrated by Ibn Majah (1). 1023 - (6) [Very Weak] And [Al-Hakim] (2) added in a path he has [in the hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas which is in "As-Sahih"]: A man said: O Messenger of Allah! Was it for Jonah specifically or for the believers generally? The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Do you not hear the saying of Allah the Mighty and Majestic: {So We saved him from the distress. And thus do We save the believers}."
foot_note:
1. I say: It contains (Abu Shaibah) from Abdullah bin Ukaym Al-Juhani, and he is unknown, no one declared him trustworthy, not even Ibn Hibban! 
2. I say: In its chain is (Amr bin Bakr As-Saksaki), and he is Matruk. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5019).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 5 - (Warning against the praying person raising his head to the sky at the time of supplication, and against a person supplicating while heedless). 1026 - (1) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Hearts are vessels, and some of them are more retaining than others. So when you ask Allah the Mighty and Majestic, O people! Ask Him while you are certain of the answer. For indeed Allah does not answer a servant who calls upon Him from a heedless heart." foot_note: 1. I say: Al-Haythami said this, and Sheikh Ahmad Shakir exceeded them, saying in his commentary on "Al-Musnad" (10/ 184): "Its chain is Sahih"! Yes; the sentence regarding asking has a witness from the hadith of Abu Huraira, so it is Hasan due to it, and for that reason I mentioned it in "As-Sahih" also.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 7 - (Encouragement to Send Blessings Upon the Prophet, Peace and Blessings of Allah be Upon Him, Abundantly, and Warning Against Abandoning it When He is Mentioned, Peace and Blessings of Allah be Upon Him, Much and Often). 1028 - (1) [Weak] And At-Tabarani [narrated the Hadith of Anas which is in "As-Sahih"] in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat", and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever sends blessings upon me once, Allah sends blessings upon him ten times. And whoever sends blessings upon me ten times, Allah sends blessings upon him one hundred times. And whoever sends blessings upon me one hundred times, Allah writes between his eyes freedom from hypocrisy and freedom from the Fire, and Allah settles him on the Day of Resurrection with the martyrs." In its chain is Ibrahim bin Salim bin Rashid Al-Hujaymi, I do not know him with criticism or praise (1). 1029 - (2) [Weak] And from Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever sends blessings upon me once, Allah writes for him ten good deeds, erases from him ten bad deeds, raises him by it ten degrees, and they are for him equal to ten slaves." Narrated by Ibn Abi Asim in "Kitab As-Salah" from the freed slave of Al-Bara', he did not name him from him (2). 1030 - (3) [Denounced Mawquf] And from him [meaning Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with them both]: Whoever sends blessings upon the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, once; Allah and His angels send blessings upon him seventy times.
foot_note:
1. I say: Al-Haythami said similar (10/ 163): "...and I did not know him, and the rest of his men are trustworthy." I say: It contains one whom no one authenticated, who is the Sheikh of Al-Hujaymi (Abdul-Aziz bin Qais bin Abdur-Rahman), and I think he confused him with another. I have clarified this in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6853). The denounced part of the Hadith is what is other than the first sentence, for it has been authenticated from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, from several paths as I mentioned there.
2. I say: It contains an unknown narrator, which is an apparent defect, so I do not know how this aligns with his prefacing the Hadith with the form (An - From) which implies its strength, especially since the sentence about the slaves is denounced. The ruling on the rest of it is as we said regarding the one before it. From the ignorance of the three commentators and their contradiction is that they prefaced the Hadith with weakening, then said: "And its text has witnesses, see it in (Jala' Al-Afham)"! And in their last statement is deception (Tadlis) implying that it contains witnesses, while there is nothing but the Hadith with its chain, without any word about it from its author, may Allah have mercy on him! It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6625).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ahmad with a Hasan chain (1). 1031 - (4) [Fabricated] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the Hadith of Abu Talhah Al-Ansari which is in "As-Sahih"], and his wording is: He said: I entered upon the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and the lines of his face were shining. I said: O Messenger of Allah! I have never seen you in better spirits, nor showing more joy than this day of yours? He said: "And why should I not be in good spirits and show joy, when Gabriel, peace be upon him, just left me and said: O Muhammad! Whoever sends blessings upon you from your Ummah once; Allah writes for him ten good deeds, erases from him ten bad deeds, raises him by it ten degrees, and the Angel says to him the like of what he said to you. I said: O Gabriel! And who is that Angel? He said: Indeed Allah (Azza wa Jal) appointed an angel from the time of your creation until He resurrects you, no one from your Ummah sends blessings upon you except that he says: And upon you may Allah send blessings." 1032 - (5) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever sends blessings upon me; his prayer reaches me, and I send blessings upon him, and ten good deeds are written for him besides that."
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, and Al-Haythami followed him, and the three imitators, deceived by Ahmad Shakir's authentication of its chain, and it contains Ibn Lahi'ah. The refutation of it has preceded in the commentary on the Hadith of the Chapter (5). I add here and say: Even with it being Mawquf, it is denounced for contradicting the authentic Marfu' paths as preceded in the comment before it. As-Sakhawi overlooked all this and said (p. 77): "And its ruling is Marfu' since there is no room for Ijtihad in it"!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a chain that has no harm (1). 1033 - (6) [Denounced] And it was narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah said: "Whoever sends blessings upon me in a day a thousand times; will not die until he sees his seat in Paradise." Narrated by Abu Hafs Ibn Shahin (2). 1034 - (7) [Denounced] And it was narrated from Abu Kahil, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to me: "O Abu Kahil! Whoever sends blessings upon me every day three times, and every night three times; out of love or longing for me; it is a right upon Allah to forgive him his sins of that night and that day." Narrated by Ibn Abi Asim, and At-Tabarani in a long Hadith; except that he said: "It is a right upon Allah to forgive him for every time the sins of a year" (3).
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, and Al-Haythami found fault with it saying: "And it contains a narrator whom I did not know," and he was not correct. The defect is Abu Ja'far Ar-Razi who has poor memory, and he contradicted the authentic Ahadith agreed upon "Allah sends blessings upon him ten times", so he said on the tongue of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: "I send blessings upon him ten times", so it is also denounced. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5141), and from here appears the error of As-Sakhawi in following (p. 78) Al-Mundhiri in grading it Hasan.
2. I say: Meaning in his book "At-Targhib" (folio 261/ 2), and it contains a weak narrator and another who is not trustworthy. Its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5110), and Al-Hafiz Al-Asqalani and As-Sakhawi denounced it.
3. This is an error from the author, may Allah have mercy on him, pointed out by An-Naji, may Allah have mercy on him. For At-Tabarani's narration regarding sending blessings upon the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, is like the narration of Ibn Abi Asim (48 - 49). As for the one he attributed to At-Tabarani, it is in another sentence which the author's sight skipped to, and it is after the sentence of (Prayer). Its text in "Mu'jam At-Tabarani Al-Kabir" (18/ 361 - 362/ 928) is: "Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever testifies that there is no deity but Allah alone with certainty in it, it is a right upon Allah to forgive with every time (Original: once) the sins of a year." And likewise in "Majma' Az-Zawa'id" (4/ 218 - 219), and he mentioned from Adh-Dhahabi that its chain is dark. The author mentioned the Hadith completely at the end of his book (24 - Repentance / 9 - Encouragement for Fear), and there is also an omission in it which I rectified there. Furthermore, Al-Uqayli also weakened the Hadith, and it is documented in "As-Sahihah", under Hadith (2652). Ibn Abd Al-Barr pointed to it in the biography of Abu Kahil in "Al-Isti'ab" and said: "It is a Munkar Hadith." And Al-Jazari confirmed it in "Usud Al-Ghabah".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh

Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat". 1037 - (10) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "There are no two servants who love each other, one of them meets his companion, and they send blessings upon the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; except that they do not part until their sins are forgiven; what preceded of them and what followed." Narrated by Abu Ya'la. 1038 - (11) [Weak] And from Ruwayfi' bin Thabit Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever says: (O Allah, send blessings upon Muhammad, and cause him to descend the seat of nearness with You on the Day
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution – Riyadh
text:
"…on the Day of Resurrection); my intercession becomes guaranteed for him." Narrated by al-Bazzar and al-Tabarani in *al-Kabir* and *al-Awsat*, and some (1) of their chains are Hasan.

1039 – (12) [Weak – Mawquf] And from Ibn Mas‘ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: When you send prayers upon the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), then beautify your prayer upon him, for you do not know—perhaps it will be presented to him. They said to him: “Then teach us.” He said: Say:

“**O Allah, place Your prayers, mercy, and blessings upon the Master of the Messengers, the Leader of the God-fearing, and the Seal of the Prophets—Muhammad Your servant and messenger, the Imam of goodness, the leader of goodness, and the Messenger of mercy. O Allah, raise him to the Praised Station which the first and the last will envy him for. O Allah, send your prayers upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad, as You sent prayers upon Ibrahim and the family of Ibrahim; indeed, You are Praiseworthy, Glorious. O Allah, bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, as You blessed Ibrahim and the family of Ibrahim; indeed, You are Praiseworthy, Glorious.”**

Narrated by Ibn Majah as a *mawquf* report with an isnād that he graded Hasan (2).

1040 – (13) [Very Weak] And from Ibn ‘Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) ascended the minbar, then said “Āmīn” three times, then said: “Do you know why I said ‘Āmīn’?”
foot_note:
1. The original printed text reads: (i.e.), and the correction is from al-Hafiz al-Naji. However, he overlooked the damaging defect in the chain—just as the author and al-Haythami overlooked it—as well as overlooking its attribution to Ahmad. All of them narrated it through an unknown narrator, not authenticated by anyone other than Ibn Hibban. Therefore, al-Haythami’s phrase “and their chains are Hasan” is closer to accuracy, and I explained this in *al-Da‘ifah* (5142).
2. I say: No, this is not correct; for the chain contains al-Mas‘udi, who became confused in his later years. Hence al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: “A weak chain.” See *Sifat al-Salah* (pp. 172–175, Al-Ma‘arif).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: We said (1): Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: "Gabriel, peace be upon him, came to me and said: Whoever you are mentioned in his presence and he does not send blessings upon you; [enters the Fire]; may Allah distance him and crush him. I said: (Amin). He said: And whoever reaches his parents or one of them and does not treat them kindly enters the Fire; may Allah distance him and crush him. I said: (Amin). And whoever reaches Ramadan and is not forgiven enters the Fire; may Allah distance him and crush him. I said: (Amin)." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a lenient chain. 1041 - (14) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Jaz' Az-Zubaidi, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, entered the mosque and ascended the pulpit and said: "Amin, Amin, Amin." When he finished, it was said: O Messenger of Allah! We saw you do something you used not to do? He said: "Indeed Gabriel appeared to me at the first step and said: O Muhammad! Whoever reaches his parents and they do not cause him to enter Paradise; may Allah distance him, then distance him. I said: (Amin). Then he said to me at the second step: And whoever reaches the month of Ramadan and is not forgiven; may Allah distance him, then distance him. I said: (Amin). Then he appeared to me at the third step and said: And whoever you are mentioned in his presence and he does not send blessings upon you; may Allah distance him, then distance him. I said: (Amin)." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani.
foot_note: 1. Original: (I said), and the correction is from At-Tabarani (12/ 84/ 12551), and "Al-Majma", and the addition is from them. He followed the author in grading its chain as lenient and went further in finding fault with it, as I clarified in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6644).

text: (Al-Hafiz Al-Mumli said) may Allah have mercy on him: "Various chapters from this book have preceded, and other chapters will come, God willing: "What one says who fears something of Riya' (showing off)" preceded in "Chapter of Riya'" [1 - Book of Ikhlas/ 2] (1). publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 16 - Book of Sales and Others. 1 - (Encouragement to Earn through Selling and Others). 1042 - (1) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: That a man from the Ansar came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and asked him. He said: "Is there nothing in your house?" He said: Yes, a Hils (1) part of which we wear and part of which we spread, and a Qa'b in which we drink water. He said: "Bring them to me." So he brought them to him, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, took them in his hand and said: "Who will buy these two from me?" A man said: I will take them for a dirham. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Who will increase upon a dirham? (Two or three times)?" A man said: I will take them for two dirhams. So he gave them to him, took the two dirhams and gave them to the Ansari and said: "Buy food with one of them and throw it to your family, and buy an adze (Qaddum) with the other and bring it to me." So he brought it to him, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, tied a stick to it with his hand then said: "Go and gather firewood and sell, and let me not see you for fifteen days."
foot_note: 1. With Kasra on Ha Muhmalah and Sukun on Lam: A thick cloth placed on the back of the camel under the saddle. And (Al-Qa'b) with Fatha then Sukun: A cup.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: So he did, and came having earned ten dirhams. He bought a garment with some of it and food with some. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "This is better for you than begging coming as a mark (Nuktah) (1) on your face on the Day of Resurrection" the Hadith. Narrated by Abu Dawud and the wording is his, and An-Nasa'i, and At-Tirmidhi who said: "Hasan Hadith". And it preceded in full in "Begging" [8 - Charities/ 4] (2). 1043 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Indeed Allah loves the believing professional (one who earns a living)." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and Al-Bayhaqi. 1044 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever spends the evening tired from the work of his hand; spends the evening forgiven." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Asbahani from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (3). And more than one Hadith from this chapter preceded in "Begging" [8 - Charities/ 4] sufficient to not repeat them here.
foot_note:
1. His saying: (Nuktah) is with Damma on Nun and Sukun on Kaf: A trace like a dot. 
2. See the commentary on it there. 
3. I say: The apparent attribution differentiates between At-Tabarani's narration being from Aisha, and Al-Asbahani's being from Ibn Abbas, while in reality both are from Ibn Abbas, and it has no origin from Aisha. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2626).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2 - (Encouragement to be Early in Seeking Sustenance and Others, and What Came Regarding Sleeping in the Morning). 1045 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Be early (1) in seeking sustenance; for going early is blessing and success." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1046 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Sleeping in the morning prevents sustenance." Narrated by Ahmad (2), Al-Bayhaqi and others, and Ibn Adi mentioned it in "Al-Kamil", and its denouncement is apparent. 1047 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Fatimah bint Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, passed by me while I was lying down in the morning, so he moved me with his foot then said: "O little daughter! Rise and witness the sustenance of your Lord, and do not be among the heedless; for Allah distributes people's sustenance between the rising of dawn and the rising of the sun." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi. And he also narrated it from Ali who said:
foot_note:
1. He said in "Al-Lisan": "Bakara 'ala ash-shay' wa ilayhi ybakiru bukurun, wa bakkara tabkiran, wa ibtakara wa abkara wa bakarah: he came to it early, all with same meaning". And the original was: "Bakiru al-ghuduwwa fi talab" (Be early in going early in seeking), and the correction is from the sources of the Hadith. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" under Hadith (2837). 
2. Attributing it to him is an illusion, followed by Al-Haythami (4/ 62), rather his son Abdullah narrated it in "Zawa'id Al-Musnad" (1/ 73). It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3019). And in the original: "Sleeping in the morning..", which is an error perhaps from the copyist.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, entered upon Fatimah after he prayed Fajr while she was sleeping... so he mentioned it with its meaning (1). 1048 - (4) [Weak] And Ibn Majah narrated from the Hadith of Ali who said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade sleeping (2) before the rising of the sun."
foot_note:
1. I say: And its chain is the chain of the one before it, but one of its narrators was confused in it as I clarified in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5170). Therefore I did not assign it a number, but the ignorant ones numbered it! They limited themselves to weakening both, and from their incompetence is that they did not explain the defect of the first, and said regarding the other: "It contains Abdul-Malik bin Harun, weak." If they had any knowledge they would have reversed and said regarding this one what was said before. Moreover, this Abdul-Malik is worse than what they said. A group including Yahya declared him a liar, and Ibn Hibban said: "He fabricates Hadith." This is unlike the Hadith of Ali coming after it; for it is weak, and it is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" number (4719). 
2. Thus in the original, which is a gross error, the correct is (As-Sawm - Selling/Bargaining), as pointed out by An-Naji (folio 158/ 2).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - (Encouragement to Remember Allah Almighty in Markets and Places of Heedlessness). 1049 - (1) [Weak Mawquf] And from Abu Qilabah who said: Two men met in the market, so one of them said to the other: Come let us ask Allah for forgiveness while people are heedless. So they did. Then one of them died, and the other met him in a dream, so he said: Did you know that Allah forgave us the evening we met in the market? Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and others. 1050 - (2) [Weak Mu'dal] And from Yahya bin Abi Kathir who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to a man: "You will continue to be praying devoutly as long as you remember Allah standing, or sitting, or in your market, or in your club." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi as Mursal, and there is discussion about it (1). 1051 - (3) [Weak Mu'dal] And from Malik (2) who said: It reached me that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to say: "The one who remembers Allah among the heedless; is like the fighter behind those fleeing. And the one who remembers Allah among the heedless; is like a green branch on a dry tree." And in a narration: "Like the green tree in the middle of dry trees. And the one who remembers Allah among the heedless is like a lamp in a dark house. And the one who remembers Allah among the heedless, Allah shows him his seat in Paradise (3)
foot_note:
1. Perhaps he means because he narrated it in "Ash-Shu'ab" (1/ 412/ 569) from the path of Abu Bakr who said: Yahya told us... for this Abu Bakr I did not know. From the pretension to knowledge of the three commentators is that they found fault with it because (Yahya) is a Mudallis! This is only a defect if he uses 'an' (from) from someone else, and here as you see he made it Mu'dal (omitted links); for he is a Follower of the Followers (Tabi' At-Tabi'in), so the author's saying: "Mursal" is not precise, and they imitated him!! 
2. He is Malik bin Anas, Imam of Dar al-Hijrah, author of "Al-Muwatta", and it is not in it as will come from the author. The three commentators overlooked him and did not notice their gross error which occurred in their verified edition! 1. Thus he said, and it is a gross illusion, even if Al-Haythami followed him. How not when it contains Ash-Shadhakuni?! And more gross than it is the authentication of the Hadith by the three commentators, as if they deduced that from the trustworthiness (Tawthiq). If so, it is from their ignorance, but they are unstable in that. See "Ad-Da'ifah" (2853). 
2. I say: And likewise in the copy of "Tuhfat Al-Ahwadhi" (3/ 219), and "Tuhfat Al-Mizzi" (3/ 468/ 3466). And it appeared in the edition of Ad-Da'as (2192): "Hasan Sahih", with the addition of "Sahih". Whether this or that, it means "...due to external evidence (Li-Ghayrihi)"; because its chain contains Ali bin Zaid bin Jad'an, and he is weak due to his memory. Therefore when Al-Hakim narrated it (4/ 505 - 506) he remained silent about it and did not authenticate it despite his known leniency. As for the three commentators, they said here: "Hasan"! And in what will come: "Hasan due to its witnesses"! While some of its parts have no witness, including this one.

text: That food was thrown at the door of the mosque, so Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) - who was the Commander of the Faithful at that time - came out and said: What is this food? They said: Food brought to us or upon us. He said: May Allah bless it and the one who brought it to us or upon us. Some of those with him said to him: O Commander of the Faithful! It has been hoarded. He said: And who hoarded it? They said: Farrukh and so-and-so, the freed slave of Umar bin Al-Khattab, hoarded it. So he sent for them and they came to him. He said: What drove you to hoard the food of the Muslims? They said: O Commander of the Faithful! We buy with our money and sell! So Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever hoards food against the Muslims; Allah strikes him with leprosy and bankruptcy." So Farrukh said at that point: O Commander of the Faithful! I promise Allah and promise you that I will never return to hoarding food ever again, so he moved to Egypt. As for the freed slave of Umar, he said: We buy with our money and sell. Abu Yahya claimed that he saw the freed slave of Umar leprous and crushed. Narrated by Al-Asbahani like this. And Ibn Majah narrated the Marfu' part of it only from Yahya bin Hakim: Abu Bakr Al-Hanafi told us: Al-Haytham bin Rafi' told us: Abu Yahya Al-Makki told me. And this is a good connected chain, and its narrators are trustworthy (1), but Al-Haytham was criticized for narrating this hadith despite being trustworthy. And Allah knows best. 1103 - (4) [Munkar] And from Mu'adh (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Miserable is the hoarding servant; if Allah lowers prices he grieves, and if He raises them he rejoices." And in a narration:
foot_note: 1. I say: Rather Abu Yahya Al-Makki is unknown, and the report is Munkar as Adh-Dhahabi said, and Al-Bukhari said: "There is a view regarding its chain."

foot_note:

text: with what He wills. And whoever incurs a debt not intending to pay it back then dies; Allah the Exalted takes retribution for his creditor on the Day of Resurrection." So He takes from his good deeds and puts them in the good deeds of the other, and if he has no good deeds He takes from the bad deeds of the other and puts them on him" (1). 1125 - (5) [Weak] And in a narration [meaning in the hadith of Aisha which is in "As-Sahih"]: "Whoever has a debt his concern is to pay it, or intends to pay it; a guard from Allah never ceases to be with him." Narrated by Ahmad... (2) 1126 - (6) [Weak] And from Imran bin Husain (3) (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: Maimunah used to incur debt frequently, so her family spoke to her about that, and blamed her, and were upset
foot_note:
1. I say: This is in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (8/ 290/ 7949) from the narration of Ja'far bin Az-Zubair from Al-Qasim, and Ja'far is a liar as Al-Haythami said (4/ 132). 
2. The place of the dots in the original: ". . . and its narrators are relied upon in As-Sahih; except that there is a disconnection in it." And this applies to the narration before it - and it is in "As-Sahih" with its witnesses -, as for this one, there is no disconnection in it, but its defect is Jahalah (unknown narrator), and the hadith is extracted in "As-Sahihah" under Hadith (2822). 
3. Thus in the original, and followed by (Amarah), and the three commentators! And it is an error, and the correct is: (Ibn Hudhaifah) as in the books the hadith was attributed to and others like "Musnad Abd bin Humaid" (Folio 198/ 2), and "Musnad Abu Ya'la" (4/ 1687), and he is a Tabi'i not known as Adh-Dhahabi said, and it appears the error is from the author; evidenced by the phrase (may Allah be pleased with them both); unless it is from the copyist.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: with her. So she said: I will not leave debt when I heard my Khaleel (Close Friend) and Safiy (Chosen One) (PBUH) say: "There is no one who incurs a debt Allah knows he intends to pay; except that Allah pays it for him in the world." Narrated by An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih". 1127 - (7) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the hadith of Suhayb which is in "As-Sahih"] in "Al-Kabir", and its wording is: He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Any man who marries a woman intending not to give her anything of her dowry; dies on the day he dies as a fornicator. And any man who buys a sale from a man intending not to give him anything of its price; dies on the day he dies as a betrayer in the Fire." And in its chain is Amr bin Dinar; Matruk (1). 1128 - (8) [Weak] And from Al-Qasim the freed slave of Mu'awiyah; that it reached him that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever incurs a debt wanting to pay it, eager to fulfill it, then dies and does not pay his debt; indeed Allah is able to satisfy his creditor with whatever He wills from Himself, and forgive the deceased. And whoever incurs a debt wanting not to pay it, then dies upon that not paying his debt; it is said to him: Did you think that We would not fulfill so-and-so's right from you?! So He takes from his good deeds and they are made an addition to the good deeds of the creditor, if he has no good deeds He takes from the bad deeds of the creditor and they are put into the bad deeds of the debtor." Narrated by Al-Baihaqi and said: "Thus it came Mursal."
foot_note: 1. He is the steward of the family of Az-Zubair, as for Amr bin Dinar Al-Makki he is Thiqah Hujjah (Trustworthy Proof), so the author should have restricted it and not generalized! And it came from another strong path abbreviated, and for that I mentioned it in "As-Sahih". And the Three mixed up - as is their habit - between this and its wording here so they said: "Hasan due to its witnesses"!!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1129 - (9) [Weak] And from Abdur-Rahman bin Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Allah calls the debtor on the Day of Resurrection until he stands before Him, so He says: O son of Adam! For what did you take this debt, and for what did you waste people's rights? He says: O Lord! You know that I took it but I did not eat, nor drink, nor wear, nor waste, but there came upon [my hands]; either burning, or theft, or loss (Wadi'ah). So Allah says: My servant has spoken the truth, I am the most entitled to pay for you [Today]. So Allah calls for something and places it in the scale of his balance, so his good deeds outweigh his bad deeds; so he enters Paradise by the Grace of His Mercy." Narrated by Ahmad, Al-Bazzar, At-Tabarani, and Abu Nu'aym, one of their chains is Hasan (1). (Al-Wadi'ah): Is selling for less than what he bought for. 1130 - (10) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed debt is paid for its owner on the Day of Resurrection if he dies, except one who incurred debt in three cases: A man whose strength weakens in the path of Allah so he borrows to strengthen himself against Allah's enemy and his enemy. And a man beside whom a Muslim dies and he does not find what to shroud him and bury him with except by debt. And a man who feared celibacy (Uzbah) for himself so he marries fearing for his religion. Indeed Allah pays for these on the Day of Resurrection."
foot_note: 1. I say: Rather it is weak, in its chain is a weakened and unknown narrator, and it has no other chain, contrary to what the author's speech implies, and the explanation of that is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5338). Furthermore, the context is Ahmad's in one of his narrations, and the two additions are from him.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ibn Majah (1) like this, and Al-Bazzar and his wording is: "Three, whoever incurs debt in them then dies and has not paid, then Allah pays for him: A man who is in the path of Allah and his clothes wear out so he fears his Awrah will be exposed - or a word similar to it - so he dies and has not paid his debt. And a man beside whom a Muslim man dies and he does not find what to shroud him with nor what to bury him with, so he dies and has not paid his debt. And a man who feared hardship (Al-'Anat) for himself so he kept chaste by marrying a woman, then dies and has not paid; then indeed Allah pays for him on the Day of Resurrection." (Al-'Anat) with Fatha on Ayn and Nun both: Is sin and corruption (2). 1131 - (11) [Weak] And from Al-Bara' bin Azib (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) who said: "The debtor is a prisoner of his debt, complaining to Allah of loneliness." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and in it is Al-Mubarak bin Fadalah. 1132 - (12) [Weak] And from Abu Musa (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed the greatest of sins with Allah that a servant meets Him with - after the major sins which Allah forbade -; is that a man dies and upon him is a debt he leaves no payment for." Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Baihaqi.
foot_note:
1. Number (2435), and in it is Ibn An'um Abdur-Rahman bin Ziyad Al-Ifriqi from Imran bin Abd Al-Ma'afiri; and both are weak, and from this perspective Al-Bazzar extracted it (1340 - Kashf Al-Astar). 
2. I say: This interpretation is deficient here, and like it or even worse is Al-A'zami's saying in his comment on "Al-Kashf": "(Al-'Anat): Hardship, destruction, sin, mistake, and adultery"! That is because it does not specify the intended meaning here; and for that An-Naji said (Folio 166/ 1): "This interpretation is obstinacy, and had he expressed it as falling into adultery - which is definitely intended here as in the Quran: {That is for whoever fears affliction among you} - it would have been clearer, more eloquent, and briefer".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1133 - (13) [Weak] And from Shufayy bin Mati' Al-Asbahi; that the Prophet (PBUH) said: "Four harm the people of the Fire on top of the harm they already have, running between the boiling water and the Hellfire, calling out for woe and destruction. Some of the people of the Fire say to others: What is the matter with these that they have harmed us on top of the harm we have? He said: A man locked in a coffin of embers, a man dragging his intestines, a man whose mouth flows with pus and blood, and a man eating his own flesh. It is said to the owner of the coffin: What is the matter with the distant one (cursed one) that he harmed us on top of the harm we have? He says: Indeed the distant one died while holding people's wealth on his neck finding no repayment or fulfillment for it" the Hadith. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and At-Tabarani with a lenient chain. And it will come in full in "Backbiting" if Allah the Exalted wills [23 - Etiquette /19, and passed in 4 - Purification /4 more complete than here]. 1134 - (14) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH), if a funeral was brought to him, would not ask about anything of the man's deeds; but would ask about his debt? If it was said: He has debt; he refrained from praying over him, and if it was said: He has no debt; he prayed over him. So a funeral was brought, when he stood to say Takbir, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) asked: "Does your companion have debt?". They said: Two Dinars. So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) turned away from him and said: "Pray over your companion." So Ali said: They are upon me O Messenger of Allah! He is free of them. So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) stepped forward and prayed over him. Then he said to Ali bin Abi Talib: "May Allah reward you with good, may Allah release your pledge as you released your brother's pledge, for there is no deceased who dies having a debt; except that he is pledged (held) by his debt, and whoever releases a deceased's pledge; Allah releases his pledge on the Day of Resurrection."
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Some of them said: Is this for Ali specifically, or for the Muslims generally? He said: "Rather for the Muslims generally." Narrated by Ad-Daraqutni (1). 1135 - (15) [Weak] And he also narrated it similarly via the path of Ubaydullah Al-Wassafi from Atiyyah from Abu Said. 1136 - (16) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him): That a funeral was brought to the Prophet (PBUH) to pray over it, so he said: "Does he have debt?". They said: Yes. So the Prophet (PBUH) said: "Indeed Jibril forbade me to pray over one who has debt, and said: Indeed the debtor is pledged in his grave until his debt is paid for him", [so he refused to pray over him] (2). Narrated by Abu Ya'la. [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani and his wording is: He said: We were with the Prophet (PBUH), and a man was brought for him to pray over, so he said: "Does your companion have debt?". They said: Yes. He said: "So what benefit is it to you that I pray over a man whose soul is pledged in his grave, his soul does not ascend to the heaven, if a man guaranteed his debt; I would stand and pray over him; for my prayer benefits him."
foot_note:
1. I say: Meaning in "As-Sunan" (3/ 46 - 47), and in it is (Ata' bin Ajlan) Matruk, some called him a liar. And the Three attributed it to him under number (3/ 78)! But that is for the hadith of Abu Said Al-Khudri coming after it, and it is briefer than the hadith of Ali. And the first part of it is in "As-Sahih" at the end of the chapter up to his saying: "Pray over your companion". 
2. Dropped from the original, and I recovered it from "Abu Ya'la", and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6860).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 16 - (Discouragement from the delay of the rich, and encouragement to please the creditor). 1137 - (1) [Weak] And from Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Allah does not love the unjust rich, nor the ignorant old man, nor the arrogant poor." And in a narration: "Indeed Allah hates the unjust rich, the ignorant old man, and the arrogant poor." Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", from the narration of Al-Harith Al-A'war from Ali, and Al-Harith was documented, and there is no harm in him in Mutaba'at (supporting narrations) (1). 1138 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Prophet (PBUH) said: "Three Allah loves, and three Allah hates - so he mentioned the hadith until he said: - "And the three whom Allah hates: The old adulterer, the arrogant poor, and the unjust rich." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih", and the wording is theirs. And An-Nasa'i narrated it similarly, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and At-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim and they authenticated it [Passed in full 8 - Charity/ 10] (2). 1139 - (3) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Khawlah bint Qais wife of Hamzah bin Abdul-Muttalib (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: . . . . . . . . . . . . Then he said:
foot_note:
1. I say: How not when Ash-Sha'bi, Abu Ishaq As-Sabi'i and Ibn Al-Madini called him a liar?! And the hadith is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1805). 
2. I say: And previously there it was explained that its attribution to Abu Dawood is an error (Wahm). So take note.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever his creditor leaves while pleased with him; the beasts of the earth and the Nun (fish) of the water pray for him. And whoever his creditor leaves while angry; Injustice is written upon him in every day and night and Friday and month." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 1140 - (4) [Weak] And from her, she said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) owed a Wasq of dates to a man from Banu Sa'idah, so he came to him demanding payment, so the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) ordered a man from the Ansar to pay him, so he paid him dates inferior to his dates, so he refused to accept it, saying: Do you return [inferior] to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH)? He said: Yes, and who is more entitled to justice than the Messenger of Allah (PBUH)? So the eyes of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) filled with tears, then he said: "He spoke the truth, and who is more entitled to justice than me?. . ." (1). Then he said: "O Khawlah! Count for him and pay him; for there is no debtor who leaves from his creditor pleased; except that the beasts of the earth and the Nun of the seas pray for him. And there is no servant who delays (Yalwi) his creditor while he is able; except that Allah writes upon him a sin in every day and night." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and "Al-Kabir" from the narration of Hibban bin Ali; and there is disagreement regarding his documentation. And (Nun Al-Bihar): Its whales. And his saying: (Yalwi his creditor) meaning: delays him and procrastinates.
foot_note: 1. In the original here is the sentence: "May Allah not sanctify a nation..." moved to "As-Sahih" with the narration before it at the beginning of the previous hadith.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 17 - (Encouragement regarding words said by the debtor, the anxious, the distressed, and the prisoner). 1141 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Said Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) entered the mosque one day and behold a man from the Ansar called: Abu Umamah was sitting in it, so he said: "O Abu Umamah! What is the matter with me seeing you sitting in the mosque at other than prayer time?". He said: Worries have adhered to me, and debts O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Shall I not (1) teach you words if you say them Allah Mighty and Majestic removes your worry and pays off your debt?". He said: Yes O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Say when you reach morning and when you reach evening: (O Allah, I seek refuge in You from anxiety and grief, and I seek refuge in You from inability and laziness, and I seek refuge in You from miserliness and cowardice, and I seek refuge in You from the burden of debt and the overpowering of men)". He said: So I said that, and Allah removed my worry, and paid off my debt. Narrated by Abu Dawood. 1142 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) missed him on Friday, so when the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) prayed he came to Mu'adh and said: "O Mu'adh! What is the matter that I did not see you?". He said: O Messenger of Allah! A Jew is owed by me an ounce of gold dust, so I went out to you,
foot_note: 1. Original: (Ala), and the correction is from "Abu Dawood" (1555). And in its chain is a weak narrator I clarified in "Da'if Abi Dawood" (272).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: so he detained me from you. So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said to him: "O Mu'adh! Shall I not teach you a supplication you supplicate with; so if you had debt like (Sir) Allah would pay it for you - and (Sir) (1) is a mountain in Yemen -, so supplicate to Allah O Mu'adh! Say: O Allah, Owner of Sovereignty, You give sovereignty to whom You will and You take sovereignty away from whom You will. You honor whom You will and You humble whom You will. In Your Hand is [all] good. Indeed, You are over all things competent. You cause the night to enter the day, and You cause the day to enter the night; and You bring the living out of the dead, and You bring the dead out of the living. And You give provision to whom You will without account. Most Merciful of the world and the Hereafter and Merciful of them, You give whom You will from them, and You prevent whom You will. Have mercy on me, a mercy that enriches me from the mercy of anyone other than You". And in a narration: Mu'adh said: A man had some right over me so I feared him, so I stayed two days not going out, then I went out, and came to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) so he said: "O Mu'adh! What held you back?". I said: A man had some right over me, so I feared him until I became shy, and hated that he meets me. He said: "Shall I not command you with words you say them, if you had like mountains [of debt] Allah would pay it? ". I said: Yes O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Say: O Allah, Owner of Sovereignty". And he mentioned similar to it briefly; and added at its end:
foot_note: 1. Original: (Sabir) and likewise in the edition of the Three! And in "At-Tabarani" (Sabr)! And the correction is from "Al-Majma'" (10/ 185) and the Three attributed it to it!! And from "Mu'jam Al-Buldan". And see the first hadith in this chapter from "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "O Allah enrich me from poverty, and pay off the debt for me, and cause me to die in Your worship, and Jihad in Your path." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 1143 - (3) [Fabricated] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: Abu Bakr entered upon me and said: I heard from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) a supplication he taught me. I said: What is it? He said: "Isa Ibn Maryam used to teach his companions, he said: If one of you had a mountain of gold as debt and supplicated Allah with this Allah would pay it for him: (O Allah, Reliever of worry, Remover of grief, Answerer of the call of the distressed, Most Merciful of the world and the Hereafter, and Merciful of them, You have mercy on me, so have mercy on me with a mercy that enriches me from the mercy of anyone other than You)". Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) said: And I had a remainder of debt, and I hated debt, so I used to supplicate Allah with that, so Allah brought me a benefit, and paid off my debt for me. Aisha said: Asma bint Umais was owed by me a Dinar and three Dirhams, and she used to enter upon me and I would be shy to look at her face; because I did not find what to pay her, so I used to supplicate with that supplication and I did not stay but a little until Allah provided me with a provision; it was not charity given to me, nor inheritance I inherited, so Allah paid it for me, and I divided among my family a good division, and adorned the daughter of Abdur-Rahman with three ounces of silver, and a good surplus remained for us. Narrated by Al-Bazzar, Al-Hakim, and Al-Asbahani; all of them via Al-Hakam bin Abdullah Al-Ayli from Al-Qasim from her.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And Al-Hakim said: "Sahih Al-Isnad"! (Al-Hafiz) Abdul-Azim said: "How, when Al-Hakam is Matruk accused, and Al-Qasim (1) with what was said about him did not hear from Aisha?! ". 1144 - (4) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated this hadith [meaning the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud which is in "As-Sahih"] from the hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari similarly, and said at its end: A sayer said: O Messenger of Allah! Indeed the cheated one is truly he who is cheated of these words. He said: "Yes, so say them, and teach them, for whoever says them, and teaches them; seeking what is in them; Allah removes his distress, and prolongs his joy" (2). 1145 - (5) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever sticks to Istighfar (seeking forgiveness); Allah makes for him from every tightness a way out, and from every worry a relief, and provides for him from where he does not expect." Narrated by Abu Dawood and the wording is his, An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, and Al-Baihaqi; all of them from the narration of Al-Hakam Ibn Mus'ab, and Al-Hakim said:
foot_note:
1. I say: As if he means Ibn Abdur-Rahman Ad-Dimashqi the companion of Abu Umamah, and whether he meant this or another, it is not him, but rather it is Al-Qasim bin Muhammad, likewise it occurred in Al-Bazzar and Al-Hakim, and he heard from Aisha and she is his paternal aunt, and he is a Trustworthy Faqih, and the defect is (Al-Hakam) this one, Ahmad said: "His hadiths are fabricated". And Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him with it. 
2. I say: Al-Haythami defected it (10/ 137) saying: ". . And in it is one whom I did not know." And the ignorant Three quoted it from him, and commented on it saying (2/ 600): "And Sheikh Ahmad Shakir (may Allah have mercy on him) authenticated its chain (3712)"! So they lied against him unintentionally! But they were brought by their incompetence and ignorance, for the Sheikh only authenticated the chain of the hadith of Abu Mas'ud referred to above, and he was correct. But he fell into a gross error summarized as: That the hadith of Abu Musa was narrated by Abu Dawood, At-Tirmidhi and An-Nasa'i. . And he attributed it to Ibn Hajar! So see the explanation of that in "As-Sahihah" (1/ 386 - 387 - Al-Ma'arif).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Sahih Al-Isnad" [Passed 14 - Remembrance /16]. 1146 - (6) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas also (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah said: "Whoever says: (There is no deity but Allah before everything, and there is no deity but Allah after everything, and there is no deity but Allah, our Lord remains and everything perishes); is cured from worry and grief." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 1147 - (7) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever says: (La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah - There is no power nor strength except through Allah); it is a cure for ninety-nine diseases, the least of them is worry." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and Al-Hakim; both of them from the narration of Bishr bin Rafi' Abu Al-Asbat and Al-Hakim said: "Sahih Al-Isnad". And he added: And that was the last speech of Umar bin Abdul-Aziz at death (1). 1149 - (9) [Very Weak] And Al-Hakim added in a narration of his [meaning from the hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas which is in "As-Sahih"]:
foot_note: 1. I say: In this narration is (Al-Ghallabi) who fabricates, as explained in "As-Sahihah" under Hadith (2755), and the Three blundered - as is the custom - so they mixed this narration with the narration in "As-Sahih" and prefaced both by saying: "Hasan"! Random striking!!

text: So a man said: O Messenger of Allah! Was it for Yunus specifically, or for the believers generally? The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Do you not hear the saying of Allah, Mighty and Majestic: {And We saved him from the distress. And thus do We save the believers}? ". [Passed 15 - Supplication /2]. 1150 - (10) [Weak] And from Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Shall I not teach you the words which Musa (peace be upon him) spoke when he crossed the sea with the Children of Israel? ". We said: Yes O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Say: (O Allah to You is the praise, and to You is the complaint, and You are the One sought for help, and there is no power nor strength except through Allah the Most High the Great) ". Abdullah said: So I never left them since I heard them from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). Narrated by At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" with a Jayyid chain (1). 1151 - (11) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "When the caller calls the gates of heaven are opened, and supplication is answered, so whoever a distress or hardship befalls let him seek the time of the caller (Mu'adhin), so if he says Takbir he says Takbir, and if he testifies he testifies, and if he says: (Come to prayer) he says: (Come to prayer), and if he says: (Come to success) he says: (Come to success), then he says: (O Allah, Lord of this perfect call, and truthful answered [call], for which the call of truth and word of piety is answered, make us live upon it, and make us die upon it, and resurrect us upon it, and make us among the best of its people alive and dead). Then he asks Allah his need".
foot_note: 1. I say: Rather Weak, Al-Haythami defected it by saying: ". . And in it are those I did not know." And they are three in a row, and it is in "Ar-Rawd An-Nadir" (609). (*) The preparer of the book for Shamela said: Thus in the printed version, and the noble Verse is (Wa najjaynahu - And We saved him)

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Al-Hakim from the narration of Ufair bin Ma'dan and he is flimsy (Wah), and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad"!. [Passed 5 - Prayer /5]. 1152 - (12) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "No matter distressed me except Jibril appeared to me and said: O Muhammad! Say: (I have relied upon the Living who does not die, and {Praise be to Allah, who has not taken a son and has had no partner in [His] dominion and has no [protector] out of weakness; and glorify Him with [great] glorification}) ". Narrated by At-Tabarani, and Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad" (1). 1153 - (13) [Weak Mu'dal] And Al-Asbahani narrated from Ibrahim - meaning Ibn Al-Ash'ath - who said: I heard Al-Fudayl saying: A man in the time of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) was captured by the enemy, so his father wanted to ransom him, but they refused him except for a large amount he could not afford, so he complained about that to the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Write to him to increase saying: (I have relied upon the Living who does not die, and {Praise be to Allah, who has not taken a son} to its end) ". He said: So the man wrote it to his son, and he started saying it, so the enemy became heedless of him, so he drove forty camels and came, and arrived with them to his father. (Al-Hafiz said): "And this is Mu'dal". And it passed in "Chapter on La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah Al-Ali Al-Azim" [14 - Remembrance /9] from Muhammad Ibn Ishaq who said: Malik Al-Ashja'i came to the Prophet (PBUH) and said: My son Awf has been captured, so he said to him: "Send to him that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) commands you to increase saying: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" so he mentioned the hadith.
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, and in its chain (1/ 509) is Sa'd bin Sa'id bin Abi Sa'id Al-Maqburi, and he is lenient in Hadith. Then I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6317).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 18 - (Discouragement from the lying Ghamus oath). 1154 - (1) [Weak] And from Al-Ash'ath bin Qais (may Allah be pleased with him): That a man from Kindah and another from Hadramaut disputed before the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) regarding a land in Yemen, so the Hadrami said: O Messenger of Allah! Indeed my land, this man's father usurped it from me, and it is in his hand. He said: "Do you have proof?". He said: No, but I make him swear: By Allah he does not know that it is my land his father usurped from me (1), so the Kindi prepared for the oath, so the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "No one cuts off wealth by an oath; except that he meets Allah while he is mutilated (Ajdzam)." So the Kindi said: It is his land. Narrated by Abu Dawood - and the wording is his -, and Ibn Majah (2) abbreviated saying: "Whoever swears an oath to cut off by it the wealth of a Muslim man wherein he is lying (Fajir); meets Allah mutilated." 1155 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed swearing is but perjury (Hinth) or regret."
foot_note:
1. Meaning: I make him swear by this. 
2. Ibn Majah did not narrate it, nor did Al-Mizzi attribute it to him in "At-Tuhfah" (1/ 77 - 78), and from the confusion of the three commentators regarding misleading attribution is that they attributed it to Ibn Majah under number (2323) and this is the number of the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud preceding in "As-Sahih", and they mentioned the same number there. Furthermore, it is briefer than what is here, and with the wording: "meets Allah while He is angry with him", and it is the Preserved in this story, and had the author attributed it to Ahmad instead of Ibn Majah he would have been correct, for it is in his "Musnad" (5/ 212). And likewise Ibn Abi Shaibah (7/ 4/ 2189), Al-Baihaqi (10/ 45), and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (1/ 203/ 637) narrated it.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" also. [Passed Here /12]. 1156 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And from Jubayr bin Mut'im (may Allah be pleased with him): That he ransomed his oath with ten thousand, then said: By the Lord of the Kaaba if I swore I would have sworn truthfully, but it is something I ransomed my oath with. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a Jayyid chain (1). 1157 - (4) [Weak Mawquf] And he narrated (2) in it also from Al-Ash'ath bin Qais (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I bought my oath once with seventy thousand.
foot_note:
1. I say: How when it contains Mu'awiyah bin Yahya As-Sadafi; they weakened him, especially what was from the narration of Ishaq Ibn Sulaiman from him! And this is from it. 
2. I say: Meaning in "Al-Awsat" also. And in it (2/ 335/ 1582) is (Isa bin Al-Musayyib Al-Bajali), and he is weak as Abu Dawood and others said.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 19 - (Discouragement from Riba (Usury)). 1158 - (1) [Very Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Four, it is a right upon Allah not to admit them to Paradise, nor let them taste its bliss: The one addicted to alcohol, the eater of Riba, the eater of the orphan's wealth without right, and the one undutiful to his parents." Narrated by Al-Hakim from Ibrahim bin Khuthaim bin Arak - and he is flimsy (Wah) - from his father from his grandfather from Abu Hurairah and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad"! (1) 1159 - (2) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Salam (may Allah be pleased with him), from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) who said: "The Dirham the man gains from Riba; is greater with Allah than thirty-three adulteries he commits in Islam." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" via the path of Ata' Al-Khurasani from Abdullah, and he did not hear from him (2). 1160 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, Al-Baghawi and others narrated it as Mawquf on Abdullah, and it is the Correct, and the wording of the Mawquf in one of its paths: Abdullah said: Riba is seventy-two sins (Huban), the least of them as sin is like one who commits with his mother in Islam, and a Dirham from Riba is worse than thirty-something adulteries. He said:
foot_note:
1. I say: And Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him (2/ 37) saying: "I say: Ibrahim, An-Nasa'i said: Matruk". 
2. From the confusions of the ignorant Three is that they defected it quoting from Al-Haythami with (Umar bin Rashid)! But Al-Haythami only defected the hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib mentioned in the original after four hadiths with him, and under it they also quoted his mentioned defect! And it is the correct one. And it is in "As-Sahih" due to others.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And Allah permits standing for the righteous and the wicked on the Day of Resurrection, except the eater of Riba (usury), for {they will not stand [in the grave] except as one stands who is being beaten by Satan into insanity} [Al-Baqarah: 275] (1). 1161 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever aids a wrongdoer with falsehood to refute a right by it; has been absolved of the protection (dhimmah) of Allah and the protection of His Messenger, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. And whoever eats a dirham of Riba; it is like thirty-three adulteries. And whoever's flesh has grown from Suht (illicit gain); the Fire is more worthy of him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat", and Al-Bayhaqi who did not mention "Whoever aids a wrongdoer" and said: "Indeed Riba is seventy-some doors, the least of them is like a man having intercourse with his mother in Islam, and a dirham of Riba is worse than thirty-five adulteries" The Hadith. 1162 - (5) [Weak] And from Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "There is no people among whom Riba (usury) appears; except that they are taken by famine (as-sanah), and there is no people among whom bribery appears; except that they are taken by terror." Narrated by Ahmad with a chain containing observation (2). (As-Sanah): The drought year, whether rain falls in it or not. 1163 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said:
foot_note:
1. I say: And thus Al-Bayhaqi narrated it in "Ash-Shu'ab" (5514) from the path of Ata Al-Khurasani; that Abdullah bin Salam said: so he mentioned it as Mawquf (stopped at the companion). And this is a disconnected chain, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6758). 
2. I say: There is apparent leniency in this, because its chain is serial with defects, the most prominent being (Ibn Lahi'ah), and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1236).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "I saw on the night I was taken on the Night Journey (Isra), when we reached [to] (1) the seventh heaven; I looked above me and I saw thunder, lightning, and thunderbolts. He said: Then I came upon a people whose bellies were like houses, wherein were snakes seen from the outside of their bellies. I said: O Gabriel! Who are these? He said: These are the eaters of Riba." Narrated by Ahmad in a long hadith, and Ibn Majah briefly, and Al-Asbahani; all of them from the narration of Ali bin Zaid from Abu As-Salt from Abu Huraira. 1164 - (7) [Very Weak] And Al-Asbahani also narrated from the path of Abu Harun Al-Abdi - and his name is Umarah bin Juwayn, and he is flimsy (wahin) - from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri: "That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, when he ascended to the heaven, looked at the heaven of the world, and there were men whose bellies were like huge houses, their bellies were leaning, and they were piled (munaddadun) upon the path (sabilah) of the people of Pharaoh. They are displayed to the Fire every morning and evening. They say: Our Lord, do not establish the Hour ever. I said: O Gabriel! Who are these? He said: These are the eaters of Riba from your Ummah {they will not stand [in the grave] except as one stands who is being beaten by Satan into insanity}." Al-Asbahani said: "His saying (munaddadun) means: thrown one upon another. And (As-Sabilah): The passersby; meaning: The people of Pharaoh tread upon them, those who are displayed to the Fire every morning and evening." End quote. 1165 - (8) [Weak] And from Al-Qasim bin Abdul Wahid Al-Wazzan who said: I saw Abdullah bin Abi Awfa, may Allah be pleased with them both (2), in the market among the money changers (sayarifah)
foot_note:
1. Dropped from the original, and I restored it from "Al-Musnad" (2/ 353) and it does not contain "I saw", and likewise it is in "Targhib Al-Asbahani" (1/ 289/ 647). And Ali bin Zaid - who is Ibn Jud'an - is weak. And Abu As-Salt is unknown. 
2. His father's name is Alqamah bin Khalid Al-Aslami, he and his father were Companions, and he lived long after the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he was the last of the Companions to die in Kufa.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: So he said: O assembly of money changers! Receive glad tidings. They said: May Allah give you glad tidings of Paradise; with what do you give us glad tidings, O Abu Muhammad? He said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Receive glad tidings of the Fire." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a chain that has no harm (1). 1166 - (9) [Fabricated] And [meaning the hadith of Auf bin Malik in "As-Sahih"] Al-Asbahani narrated from the hadith of Anas, and its wording is: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The eater of Riba will come on the Day of Resurrection insane/stumbling (mukhabbalan), dragging his side (2), then he recited: {they will not stand [in the grave] except as one stands who is being beaten by Satan into insanity}." Al-Asbahani said: "(Al-Mukhabbal): The insane, [and Al-Mukhabbal: The paralyzed. And his saying: {who is being beaten by Satan into insanity}; meaning: Satan seizes him and throws him down, so he becomes insane]." 1167 - (10) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "There will surely come a time upon people wherein none of them remains but he eats Riba, and whoever does not eat it will be afflicted by its dust." Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah; both from the narration of Al-Hasan from Abu Huraira, and his hearing (from him) is disputed, and the majority hold that he did not hear from him. 1168 - (11) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "A group from this Ummah will spend the night in food and drink, and amusement and play, then they will wake up
foot_note:
1. I say: How so, when this Al-Qasim Al-Wazzan was not declared trustworthy by anyone, not even Ibn Hibban, and Adh-Dhahabi indicated in "Al-Mizan" that he is unknown, and Al-Asqalani explicitly stated that, and Al-Haythami faulted the hadith because of him in "Al-Majma'". The original had (Al-Warraq) so I corrected it from it and from "At-Tahdhib". 
2. Original: (Shafatahu - his lip), and the correction is from "Targhib Al-Asbahani" (2/ 574/ 1374), and the addition is from him.

foot_note: 1. Original: (Hajarah - stones), and the correction is from "Al-Bayhaqi" and "Musnad At-Tayalisi" as well, and the addition is from them. And (Al-Hasib): A strong wind carrying dust and pebbles. As in "Al-Lisan".

text: 20 - (Warning against usurping land and other things). 1169 - (1) [Very Weak] And in a narration of At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (1) [meaning the hadith of Ya'la bin Murrah, may Allah be pleased with him, which is in "As-Sahih"]: "Whoever wrongs [by taking] a handspan of land; will be tasked to dig it until he reaches the water; then carry it to the Place of Gathering." 1170 - (2) [Very Weak] And from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever takes anything from the land without its right, will be collared with it from seven earths, neither repentance nor ransom will be accepted from him." Narrated by Ahmad (2) and At-Tabarani from the narration of Hamza bin Abi Muhammad. 1171 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn (3) Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! Which injustice is the most unjust? He said: "A cubit of land that a Muslim man detracts from the right of his Muslim brother. There is no pebble from the earth that he takes; except that he will be collared with it on the Day of Resurrection to the bottom of the earth, and no one knows its bottom except Allah who created it." Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and Ahmad's chain is Hasan (4).
foot_note:
1. Al-Haythami said (4/ 175): "And it contains Jabir Al-Ju'fi, and he is weak, but has been declared trustworthy." See "Ad-Da'ifah" (6760). 
2. I did not see it in his "Musnad", but he attributed it in "Al-Majma'" (4/ 175) to Abu Ya'la, Al-Bazzar, and At-Tabarani, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6761). 
3. Original: "Abi", which is an error, and the correction is from "Al-Musnad" and others. 
4. There is no justification for classifying it as Hasan nor for attributing it specifically to Ahmad, for the pivot of the narration in both is upon Ibn Lahi'ah, and he is weak. Furthermore, it has an interruption clarified by Ahmad Shakir (5/ 289), and among his oddities is that despite all that, he authenticated it! It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6762).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh

Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "As-Saghir" from the narration of Muhammad bin Uqbah As-Sadusi (1).

text: 21 - (Warning against building beyond need for boasting and competition in increase). 1173 - (1) [Very Weak] And from Wathilah bin Al-Asqa', may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Every building is a burden (wabal) upon its owner except what was like this - and he pointed with his palm - and every knowledge is a burden upon its owner except for one who acts upon it." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and it has witnesses. [Passed in 3 - Knowledge / 9]. 1174 - (2) [Weak] And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "If Allah intends evil for a servant, He makes bricks and clay pleasing/green (Khaddara) (1) to him until he builds." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "The Three" with a Jayyid (good) chain (2). 1175 - (3) [Very Weak] And he narrated in "Al-Awsat" from the hadith of Abu Bashir Al-Ansari; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "If Allah intends humiliation for a servant; he spends his money on building." 1176 - (4) [Very Weak] And from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever builds more than what suffices him; will be tasked to carry it on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" from the narration of Al-Musayyab bin Wadih, and this hadith is among what was denounced from him (3), and there is interruption in its chain.
foot_note:
1. Meaning: He endeared and adorned it, as Al-Munawi said. And the statement of the commentator on "Al-Awsat" (9/ 171): "Meaning He blessed him"; is an apparent lack of Arabic understanding! And a false interpretation here. 
2. Thus he said! But it contains the 'an'anah (narrating with 'from') of Abu Az-Zubayr. The Sheikh of At-Tabarani has been corroborated; contrary to what is implied by Al-Haythami's statement (4/ 69), as explained in "Ar-Rawd An-Nadir" (189). Al-Iraqi attributed it in "Takhrij Al-Ihya" to Abu Dawood from Aisha, which is an illusion that Al-Munawi followed him in, so he critiqued As-Suyuti who did not attribute it to him!! 
3. I say: Al-Haythami faulted it due to him, but this is questionable because he has been corroborated. The defect is from his sheikh Yusuf bin Asbat, along with the interruption between Abu Ubaidah and his father Ibn Mas'ud. Abu Hatim said: "A false hadith." It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (175).
