text: 22 - (Warning against withholding the hireling's wage, and the command to hasten giving it). 1182 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Allah the Exalted said: Three I am their opponent on the Day of Resurrection, and whoever I am his opponent, I will overcome him: A man who gave [a pledge] in My name then betrayed, a man who sold a free person and ate his price, and a man who hired a hireling and received full service from him but did not give him his wage." Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Ibn Majah, and others (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: The statement: "and whoever I am his opponent, I will overcome him" is in Ibn Majah but not Al-Bukhari. It was also narrated by Ibn Al-Jarud in "Al-Muntaqa" (579), Ahmad (2/ 358), and Abu Ya'la (p. 1547 - 1548); and in all of them is Yahya bin Sulaym At-Ta'ifi. Al-Hafiz said in "At-Taqrib": "Truthful but has poor memory." The statements of the Imams regarding him are numerous, even Al-Bukhari himself said about him: "What Al-Humaidi narrated from him is authentic." This is not from his narration from him in Al-Bukhari, nor in others who extracted his hadith as you can see in "Al-Irwa" (5/ 307 - 311), so review it for it contains beneficial scientific research.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 23 - (Encouragement of the owned person [slave] to fulfill the right of Allah the Exalted and the right of his masters). 1183 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "A slave who obeyed Allah and obeyed his masters; Allah will enter him into Paradise seventy autumns (years) before his masters. The master will say: Lord, this was my slave in the world! He [Allah] will say: I rewarded him for his deed, and I rewarded you for your deed." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and "Al-Awsat" (1), and he said: "Yahya bin Abdullah bin Abd Rabbih As-Saffar was unique with it from his father." (Al-Hafiz said): "I do not recall any disparagement or justification regarding them." 1184 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "A man (2) was entered into Paradise, and he saw his slave above his degree! He said: O Lord! This was my slave above my degree [in Paradise]! He [Allah] said: Yes, I rewarded him for his deed, and I rewarded you for your deed." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1185 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira also; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The first three to enter Paradise were displayed to me: A martyr, a chaste person who refrains [from asking/sin], and a slave who worshipped Allah well and was sincere to his masters."
foot_note:
1. I say: I think his mention of "Al-Awsat" is a slip of the pen from the author, followed by Al-Haythami in "Majma' Az-Zawa'id" (4/ 239). The correct source is: "As-Saghir" (p. 244 - Indian), and he said: "Yahya bin Abdullah was unique with it, from his father." And they are not known. It is in "Ar-Rawd An-Nadir" number (429). 
2. Original (A slave entered) and thus it appeared in "Al-Majma'", which is an error contradicting what is in its source "Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat" (8/ 174) and others; as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1767).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tirmidhi who authenticated it and the wording is his, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" [Passed in 8 - Charity / 2]. 1186 - (4) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Three will be on mounds of musk - I think he said: - on the Day of Resurrection: A slave who fulfilled the right of Allah and the right of his masters, a man who led a people [in prayer] and they were pleased with him, and a man who calls to the five prayers in every day and night." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith." And narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and "As-Saghir" and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Three whom the Great Terror will not grieve, nor will the Reckoning reach them, they will be on a mound of musk, until the reckoning of the creatures is finished: A man who recited the Quran seeking the Face of Allah; and led a people with it while they were pleased with him, a caller who calls to the prayers seeking the Face of Allah, and a slave who did well in what is between him and his Lord and what is between him and his masters." And he narrated it in "Al-Kabir" similarly; except that he said at its end: "And a slave whom the slavery of the world did not prevent from obeying his Lord." [Passed in 5 - Prayer / 1]. 1187 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The first forerunner to Paradise; is a slave who obeyed Allah and obeyed his masters." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat".
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1188 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "A miser will not enter Paradise, nor a deceiver (Khibb), nor one who treats property badly (Si' al-Malakah) (1). And the first to knock on the gate of Paradise; are the slaves (Mamlukin) if they did well in what is between them and Allah the Mighty and Majestic, and in what is between them and their masters." Narrated by Ahmad and Abu Ya'la with a Hasan chain, and part of it is in At-Tirmidhi and others (2). (Al-Khibb) with a Fatha on the dotted Kha and Kasra and Shaddah on the Ba: Is the deceiver, the cunning, the malicious.
foot_note:
1. Meaning: Mistreats his slave. Stated by Imam Ahmad in "Masa'il Abi Dawood" (p. 284). 
2. I say: Like Ibn Majah, and they both have the sentence (Al-Malakah) only. Ibn Majah has an addition that will come in (20 - Judgment / 10). In Ahmad (1/ 4) and Abu Ya'la (95) and the others, it is from the narration of Farqad As-Sabkhi and he is weak. At-Tirmidhi (1947) said after it: "A Gharib Hadith, and Ayub As-Sakhtiyani and more than one spoke regarding Farqad As-Sabkhi concerning his memory." The three commentators attributed to him that he authenticated it (Hasan), which is one of their countless illusions. The authentication might be in some copies, as the author mentioned it in the referenced place, but they attributed it to At-Tirmidhi with the number I mentioned, and it does not contain the authentication they attributed to him, so it is from their blunders. Nor did Al-Mizzi attribute it to him in "At-Tuhfah" (5/ 304/ 6618) in his phrase which I quoted from him, and Al-Baghawi said similar to it in "Sharh As-Sunnah" (9/ 349). It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6200).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 24 - (Warning the slave against running away from his master). 1189 - (1) [Weak] And from Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Three, Allah does not accept a prayer for them, nor does a good deed ascend to the sky for them: The drunkard until he becomes sober, the woman whose husband is angry with her, and the runaway slave until he returns and places his hand in the hand of his masters." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" from the narration of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil and the wording is his, and Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs" from the narration of Zuhair bin Muhammad (1). 1190 - (2) [Weak] And from Jabir [also], may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Any slave who dies during his running away; enters the Fire even if he was killed in the way of Allah." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" from the narration of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil, and the rest of its narrators are trustworthy (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: And he is weak in the narration of the Levantines from him, and this is one of them. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1075). 
2. I say: It is more appropriate to fault it due to the narrator from him (Zuhair bin Muhammad), for he has it (10/ 108/ 9228) from the narration of the Levantines from him, which is weak, and this is one of them; like the hadith before it. Were it not for that, the chain would be Hasan. See "Ad-Da'ifah" (1075).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 25 - (Encouragement for manumission, and warning against enslaving a free person or selling him). 1191 - (1) [Weak] And from Wathilah bin Al-Asqa', may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I was with the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in the expedition of (Tabuk), and there was a group from Banu Sulaym; they said: Our companion has committed a sin necessitating (Awjaba) (1) [Hellfire]. He said: "Free a slave on his behalf; Allah will free for every limb of it a limb of him from the Fire." Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Hakim who said: "Sahih on their condition" (2). (Awjaba) Meaning: Committed an act that necessitates the Fire for him. (Section) 1192 - (2) [Weak] From Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Three, prayer is not accepted from them: One who leads a people while they dislike him, a man who comes to prayer 'Dibaran' - and 'Ad-Dibar' is to come to it after its time has passed - and a man who enslaves his freed slave (Muharrarahu)" (3). Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah from the path of Abdur-Rahman bin Ziyad bin An'am from Imran Al-Ma'afiri from him. [Passed in 5 - Prayer / 28].
foot_note:
1. Meaning: Committed a sin for which he deserved the Fire. As in "An-Nihayah". And the sin: is murder as in a narration. See "Ad-Da'ifah" (907), for it contains clarification of Al-Hakim's illusion and the defect of the hadith, and the preferred narration of it. 
2. I say: It contains Al-Gharif bin Ad-Daylami who is unknown, Al-Hakim confused him with another trustworthy person. Its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (907). 
3. Thus it occurred here, and it is likewise in Abu Dawood and the context is his. And it passed with the wording: "Muharraran" (a free person), and this is in Ibn Majah with another context.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Khattabi said): "Enslaving the freed person happens in two ways: First: That he frees him then conceals his manumission or denies it, and this is the worse of the two matters. Second: That he detains him after manumission and uses him forcibly" (1). 1193 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah the Exalted said: Three I am their opponent on the Day of Resurrection, and whoever I am his opponent, I will overcome him: A man who gave [a pledge] in My name then betrayed, a man who sold a free person and ate his price, and a man who hired a hireling and received full service but did not pay him his wage." Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Ibn Majah, and others. [Passed here / 44]. ... [Glory be to You O Allah and with Your praise, I bear witness that there is no deity except You, I seek Your forgiveness and repent to You, and may Allah send blessings upon Muhammad the Unlettered Prophet, and upon his family and companions and grant peace]. The first volume of "Da'if At-Targhib wa At-Tarhib" is finished, and praise be to Allah the Mighty and Majestic. It is followed, if Allah wills, by the second volume, and its beginning is "17 - Book of Marriage and what relates to it".
foot_note: 1. "Ma'alim As-Sunan" (1/ 308) but he said: "And the other way: That he uses him forcibly after manumission".

17 - Book of Marriage and what relates to it .
1 - (Encouragement to lower the gaze, and discouragement from unleashing it, and from seclusion with a foreign woman and touching her) .
1194 - (1) [Very Weak] From Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said - meaning from his Lord Mighty and Majestic: "The glance is a poisoned arrow from the arrows of Iblis. Whoever leaves it out of fear of Me; I will replace it with faith whose sweetness he will find in his heart." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Hakim from the hadith of Hudhaifah. And he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad" (1).
(Al-Hafiz said): "They both extracted it from the narration of Abdur-Rahman bin Ishaq Al-Wasiti, and he is flimsy (Wah)."
1195 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "There is no Muslim who looks at the beauties of a woman [the first time] (2) then lowers his gaze; except that Allah creates for him an act of worship; whose sweetness he finds in his heart." Narrated by Ahmad, and At-Tabarani; except that he said: "Looks at a woman with the first glance."
foot_note:
1. I say: Adh-Dhahabi rejected it like the author, and it has two other defects, one of them: Idtirab (disturbance/inconsistency) in its chain, for once he said: From Ibn Mas'ud, and once: From Hudhaifah. And another time: From Ibn Umar! See "Ad-Da'ifah" (1065). 
2. Addition from "Al-Musnad" (5/ 264), and it is extracted there (1064).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text:
And Al-Baihaqi, and he said: "He only meant - if it is authentic, and Allah knows best - that his gaze falls upon her unintentionally, so he turns his gaze away from her out of piety."
1196 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Every eye will be weeping on the Day of Resurrection; except an eye that lowered its gaze from the prohibitions of Allah, an eye that stayed awake in the path of Allah, and an eye from which something like the head of a fly came out due to the fear of Allah." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. [Passed 12 - Jihad /2].
1197 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "You will surely lower your gazes, and guard your private parts; [or Allah will surely eclipse] (1) your faces." Narrated by At-Tabarani.
1198 - (5) [Very Weak] And from Abu Said (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "There is no morning except two angels call out: Woe to men from women, and woe to women from men." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad" (2).
foot_note:
1. Addition from At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (8/ 246/ 7840) and "Al-Majma'" and "Al-Jami' Al-Kabir" (2/ 639), and it appeared in the original as: (Layaksifanna Allah), so I corrected from the mentioned sources, and it appeared in the edition of the Three as: (Layakshifanna Allah) with the dotted Shin!! 
2. I say: Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him saying (2/ 159): "I say: Kharijah bin Mus'ab is Wah (flimsy)." And it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2018).

1199 - (6) [Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: While the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) was sitting in the mosque, a woman from Muzaynah entered; trailing her adornment in the mosque. So the Prophet (PBUH) said: "O people! Forbid your women from wearing adornment and strutting in the mosque; for the Children of Israel were not cursed until their women wore adornment and strutted in the mosques." Narrated by Ibn Majah.
1200 - (7) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) who said: "Beware of being alone with women, for by the One in Whose Hand is my soul, no man is alone with a woman; except that Satan enters between them. And for a man to crowd a pig smeared with mud or black slime (Ham'ah); is better for him than that his shoulder crowds the shoulder of a woman who is not lawful for him." A Gharib hadith, narrated by At-Tabarani. (Al-Ham'ah) with Fatha on the un-dotted Ha and Sukun on Mim followed by Hamza and Ta Marbuta: is the black fetid mud.

2 - (Encouragement to marry, especially a religious prolific woman) .
1201 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him); that he heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever wants to meet Allah pure and purified; let him marry free women (Al-Hara'ir) (1)." Narrated by Ibn Majah.
1202 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Ayyub (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Four are from the Sunnahs of the Messengers: Henna, Perfume, Siwak, and Marriage." And some narrators said: (Al-Haya' - Modesty) with Ya. Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith" [Passed 4 - Purification /10].
1203 - (3) [Weak] And Ibn Majah, and his wording is [meaning from the hadith of Abdullah bin Amr which is in "As-Sahih"]: He said: "Indeed the world is enjoyment, and there is nothing from the enjoyment of the world better than a righteous woman."
1204 - (4) [Weak] And from him; that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The world is enjoyment, and from the best of its enjoyment is a woman who helps her husband for the Hereafter. Miskin (poor) Miskin is a man who has no wife, Miskinah (poor) Miskinah is a woman who has no husband." Razin mentioned it, and I did not see it in any of his sources (2), and its last part is Munkar.
foot_note:
1. It was said: It is closer to interpret freedom as moral freedom; which is nobility of attributes. 
2. I say: It is composed of two hadiths: The first: Muslim and others narrated it, and you see it in "As-Sahih" in this chapter. And the other - which is his saying: "Miskin. ." -; At-Tabarani and others narrated it with a weak chain, as explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5177).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text:
1205 - (5) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH); that he used to say: "A believer has not benefited anything after Taqwa (fear) of Allah better for him than a righteous wife; if he commands her she obeys him, and if he looks at her she pleases him, and if he swears an oath upon her she fulfills it, and if he is absent from her she is sincere to him regarding herself and his wealth." Narrated by Ibn Majah from Ali bin Yazid from Al-Qasim from him.
1206 - (6) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Prophet (PBUH) said: "Four, whoever is given them has been given the good of the world and the Hereafter: A thankful heart, a remembering tongue, a body patient on affliction, and a wife who does not seek betrayal (Khawnan) (1) in herself and his wealth." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat", and one of the chains is Jayyid. [Passed 14 - Remembrance /1]. (Al-Hawb) with Fatha on the un-dotted Ha and also with Damma: Is sin (1).
1207 - (7) [Weak] And from Abu Najih; that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever can afford to marry but does not marry; then he is not of me." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan chain and Al-Baihaqi, and it is Mursal (2). And Abu Najih's name is (Yasar) with Ya with two dots below, and he is the father of Abdullah bin Abi Najih Al-Makki.
1208 - (8) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH): "Whoever marries a woman for her glory; Allah increases him nothing but humiliation. And whoever marries her for her wealth; Allah increases him nothing but poverty. And whoever marries her for her lineage; Allah increases him nothing but ignobility. And whoever marries a woman intending
foot_note:
1. In the original and others: (Hawban), and it is a distortion as previously alerted there, so refer to it. And the Three contradicted themselves, so they authenticated it there, and neglected here! Like the saying of the one who said: And I am but from. . 
2. I say: Despite its Irsal (disconnection) it is not Hasan; it contains someone unknown, and its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1934).

text:
nothing by her except to lower his gaze; and guard his private parts or join ties of kinship; Allah blesses him in her, and blesses her in him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat".
1209 - (9) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Do not marry women for their beauty, for perhaps their beauty may destroy them (1). And do not marry them for their wealth, for perhaps their wealth may make them transgress. But marry them for religion. And indeed a black slit-nosed/ear-pierced slave woman (2) with religion is better." Narrated by Ibn Majah via the path of Abdur-Rahman bin Ziyad bin An'am.
foot_note:
1. Meaning: Causes them to fall into destruction through vanity and arrogance. (Tatghihunna) meaning: Causes them to fall into disobedience and evils. 
2. Meaning: With part of the nose cut and pierced ear. And his saying: (Afdal - Better) meaning: Than the one with beauty and looks, and this is like the saying of the Exalted: {And a believing slave woman is better than a polytheist woman}. And Allah knows best.

3 - (Encouragement for the husband to fulfill the right of his wife and treat her well, and the woman regarding the right of her husband and obeying him, and discouragement for her from angering him and disobeying him) .
1210 - (1) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed among the most perfect believers in faith; is the best of them in character, and the kindest of them to his family." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, and Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih according to their condition", thus he said. And At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan hadith, and we do not know of Abu Qilabah hearing from Aisha."
1211 - (2) [Munkar] And from Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Any woman who dies while her husband is pleased with her; enters Paradise." Narrated by Ibn Majah, At-Tirmidhi and he graded it Hasan, and Al-Hakim; all of them from Musawir Al-Himyari from his mother from her. And Al-Hakim said: "Sahih Al-Isnad" (1).
1212 - (3) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I asked the Messenger of Allah (PBUH): Which person has the greatest right over the woman? He said: "Her husband." I said: Then which person has the greatest right over the man? He said:
foot_note: 1. I say: Rather it is Munkar with a weak chain, (Musawir) and his mother are unknown as Ibn Al-Jawzi and others said, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1426).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text:
"His mother." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and Al-Hakim, and Al-Bazzar's chain is Hasan (1).
1213 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: A woman came to the Prophet (PBUH) and said: O Messenger of Allah! I am the delegate of women to you. This Jihad, Allah has prescribed it upon men, if they succeed they are rewarded, and if they are killed they are alive with their Lord provided for. And we assembly of women serve them, so what is for us from that? He said: So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Convey to whom you meet of women; that obedience to the husband and acknowledging his right equals that, and few of you do it." Narrated by Al-Bazzar like this abbreviated, and At-Tabarani in a hadith wherein he said at the end: Then a woman came to him - meaning the Prophet (PBUH) -, and said: I am the messenger of women to you, and there is no woman among them who knows or does not know except that she desires my going out to you. Allah is the Lord of men and women and their God, and you are the Messenger of Allah to men and women. Allah prescribed Jihad upon men; if they succeed they become rich, and if they are martyred they are alive with their Lord provided for. So what equals that of their deeds in obedience? He said:
foot_note: 1. I say: There is no basis for this Hasan grading, nor for specifying it to Al-Bazzar, for his chain (1462) is like Al-Hakim's chain (4/ 150 and 175) not better than it; for their pivot is on Abu Utbah and he is unknown, as Al-Hafiz said. And An-Nasa'i also extracted it via his path in "Ishrat An-Nisa" from "Al-Kubra" (1/ 85/ 2), so the author's neglecting it is a deficiency.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text:
"Obedience to their husbands, and recognizing their rights (1), and few of you do it."
1214 - (5) [Weak] And from Qais bin Sa'd (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I came to (Al-Hirah) (2) and saw them prostrating to a Marzuban (Persian governor) of theirs, so I said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) is more entitled to be prostrated to. So I came to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) and said: I came to (Al-Hirah) and saw them prostrating to a Marzuban of theirs, so you are more entitled to be prostrated to. He said to me: "What do you think if you passed by my grave, would you prostrate to it?". I said: No. He said: "Do not do it; if I were to order anyone to prostrate to anyone; I would have ordered women to prostrate to their husbands; due to the right Allah has placed for them over them." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and in its chain is Sharik, and Muslim extracted from him in Mutaba'at (supporting narrations) and he was documented (3).
1215 - (6) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "If I were to order anyone to prostrate to anyone; I would have ordered the woman to prostrate to her husband. And if a man ordered his wife to move from a red mountain to a black mountain, or from a black mountain to a red mountain; it would be right (Nawl) (4) for her to do so."
foot_note:
1. Thus in the original following its source At-Tabarani (3/ 150/ 1) and on it is a mark (Sad) from some Hafizs, which indicates that the wording is established by transmission, corrupt in wording or meaning or weak. And if the hadith were authentic it could be understood by omitting the possessive noun estimated as: the rights of their husbands. And the wording of Al-Bazzar mentioned before supports it. Ibn Hibban narrated it in "Ad-Du'afa" with the wording: "Indeed obedience to the husband and acknowledging his right. . .", and I extracted the hadith in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5340). 
2. A city near Kufa, it is the city of An-Nu'man bin Al-Mundhir. 
3. And the hadith is Sahih without mentioning Al-Hirah, the Marzuban, and the grave. Rather that happened when Mu'adh came from Ash-Sham, and saw the patriarchs and bishops being prostrated to by people, as in the other book. 
4. It is with Fatha on Nun and Sukun on Waw; meaning: her duty/right, and what is appropriate for her. And Allah knows best.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text:
Narrated by Ibn Majah from the narration of Ali bin Zaid bin Jud'an, and the rest of its narrators are relied upon in "As-Sahih".
1216 - (7) [Munkar] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "It is not lawful for a woman who believes in Allah; to permit in her husband's house while he dislikes it, nor to go out while he dislikes it, nor to obey anyone regarding him, [nor to be rough with his chest], nor to withdraw from his bed, nor to strike him. If he is the one who is more unjust; then let her come to him until she pleases him. If [he] accepts from her then good and well; and Allah accepts her excuse, and strengthens (Aflaja) her argument, and there is no sin upon her. And if he does not accept; then she has conveyed her excuse to Allah." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad". Thus he said! (1) (Aflaja) - with Jim - her argument; meaning: manifested her argument and strengthened it.
1217 - (8) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): That a woman from Khath'am came to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) and said: O Messenger of Allah! Inform me what is the right of the husband over the wife? For I am a single woman (Ayyim), if I can [fulfill it], otherwise I will remain single. He said: "Indeed the right of the husband over his wife: If he asks her for herself while she is on the back of a camel saddle she should not deny herself to him. And from the right of the husband over the wife is that she does not fast voluntarily except with his permission, if she does she goes hungry and thirsty and it is not accepted from her. And she should not go out of her house except with his permission, if she does the angels of the sky and the angels of mercy and the angels of punishment curse her
foot_note: 1. I say: The author implies rejecting it, because it contains Ata' Al-Khurasani, and he is weak due to frequent mistakes and Tadlis, and he used 'an'anah. Therefore Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him saying (2/ 190): "I say: Rather Munkar, and its chain is disconnected." And from this perspective Al-Baihaqi narrated it in "As-Sunan" (7/ 293).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text:
until she returns." She said: Undoubtedly I will never marry. Narrated by At-Tabarani (1).
[Weak] And the hadith of Ibn Abbas from the Prophet (PBUH) passed in "Prayer" [5/ 28 - Chapter]: "Three, their prayer does not rise above their heads a span: A man who led a people while they dislike him, a woman who spent the night while her husband is angry with her, and two brothers who are Mutasariman (cutting ties) (2)." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and the wording is Ibn Majah's.
1218 - (9) [Weak] And from Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Three, no prayer is accepted from them, and no good deed ascends for them to the sky: The runaway slave until he returns to his masters and places his hand in their hands, the woman whose husband is angry with her until he is pleased, and the drunkard until he sobers up." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" from the narration of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil, and Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs" from the narration of Zuhair bin Muhammad (3), and the wording is Ibn Hibban's. [Passed 16 - Sales /24].
foot_note:
1. I say: Perhaps attributing it to At-Tabarani is an oversight; for I checked "Musnad Ibn Abbas" from his "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir", which is meant when generalized, I checked it more than once, and I did not find it. And Al-Haythami (4/ 307) only attributed it to Al-Bazzar, and it is in "Kashf Al-Astar" under number (1464). And Abu Ya'la narrated it similarly (2455). And in their chains is Husain bin Qais known as (Hanash) and he is very weak. And it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3515). 
2. His saying: "and a woman who spent the night while her husband is angry with her"; due to her not obeying him in what he wanted from her, and for this he said: "spent the night"; because that usually happens at night, otherwise the ruling is not specific to the night. And his saying: "and two brothers" i.e. by lineage and religion by being Muslims. And his saying: "Mutasariman": i.e.: cutting ties; i.e.: more than three [days] or in falsehood. And Allah knows best. Thus in the margin of the original. 
3. I say: This Zuhair is in the path of At-Tabarani as well, contrary to what the author's action implies. Furthermore, he is weak in the narration of the Shamis (Syrians) from him, and this is one of them; as explained there in the commentary.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1219 - (10) [Very Weak] And from him [meaning Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both)] he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Indeed, if a woman goes out of her house while her husband dislikes [that] (1); every angel in the sky curses her, and everything she passes by; except Jinn and humans, until she returns." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and its narrators are trustworthy; except Suwaid bin Abdul-Aziz.
foot_note: 1. Dropped from the original, and I recovered it from the "Two Majma's", and the hadith is in "Ad-Da'ifah" under number (5341).

4 - (Discouragement from favoring one of the wives, and abandoning justice between them) .
1220 - (1) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) used to divide and be just; and say: "O Allah this is my division in what I possess, so do not blame me in what You possess and I do not possess. Meaning the heart." Narrated by Abu Dawood, At-Tirmidhi, An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih". And At-Tirmidhi said: "Narrated as Mursal, and it is more correct."
foot_note: None

5 - (Encouragement to spend on the wife and dependents, and discouragement from neglecting them, and what came regarding spending on daughters and disciplining them) .
1221 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "The first three to enter Paradise were shown to me, and the first three to enter the Fire. As for the first three to enter Paradise: The martyr, a owned slave who perfected the worship of his Lord and was sincere to his master, and a chaste abstinent one with dependents. And as for the first three to enter the Fire: An oppressive ruler, a possessor of wealth who is selfish and does not fulfill the right of Allah in his wealth, and an arrogant poor person." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih". And At-Tirmidhi and Ibn Hibban narrated it similarly, [Passed 8 - Charity /2].
1222 - (2) [Weak] And from Jabir who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Every good deed is charity. And what a man spends on his family is written for him as charity. And what a man protects his honor with is written for him as charity. And whatever expense a believer spends, its replacement is upon Allah, and Allah is the Guarantor except what was in building or disobedience." Abdul-Hamid - meaning Ibn Al-Hasan Al-Hilali - said: So I said to Ibn Al-Munkadir: And what is "protects his honor with"? He said: What is given to the poet, and the one with a feared tongue. Narrated by Ad-Daraqutni, and Al-Hakim and he authenticated its chain. [Passed 16 - Sales /21].
(Al-Hafiz said): "And the mentioned Abdul-Hamid, discussion on him will come" (1).
foot_note: 1. See the comment there.

text:

Chapter
1224 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever sponsors an orphan belonging to him as a relative (1) or not a relative; then I and he are in Paradise like these two - and he joined his two fingers -. And whoever strives for three daughters; then he is in Paradise, and he has like the reward of a Mujahid in the path of Allah fasting and standing (in prayer)." Narrated by Al-Bazzar from the narration of Laith bin Abi Sulaym.
1225 - (5) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever has a female (child); and did not bury her alive, nor humiliate her, nor prefer his child - meaning the males - over her; Allah enters him into Paradise." Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim; both from Ibn Hudair - and he is not famous - from Ibn Abbas. And Al-Hakim said: "Sahih Al-Isnad".
His saying: (Lam Ya'idha) meaning: did not bury her alive, and they used to bury daughters alive, and from it is His saying
foot_note: 1. And thus in "Kashf Al-Astar" and "Majma' Az-Zawa'id" in places within them, meaning: he is a relative, and some commentators thought it was an error, but it is not so as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5342).

text:
The Exalted: {And when the girl [who was] buried alive is asked}.
1226 - (6) [Very Munkar] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "Whoever has three daughters; and is patient with their hardship, adversity, and ease; Allah enters him into Paradise by His mercy to them." A man said: And two, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "And two." A man said: O Messenger of Allah! And one? He said: "And one." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih Al-Isnad" (1). And it will come [22 - Righteousness /4]. "Chapter on sponsoring the orphan and spending on the poor and the widow" if Allah wills.

6 - (Encouragement for good names, and what came regarding the prohibition of ugly names and changing them) .
1227 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Ad-Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed you will be called on the Day of Resurrection by your names and the names of your fathers; so make your names good." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; both of them from Abdullah bin Abi Zakariyya from him. And Abdullah bin Abi Zakariyya is trustworthy worshipper. Al-Waqidi said: "He used to be equated with Umar bin Abdul-Aziz." But he did not hear from Abu Ad-Darda, and Abu Zakariyya's name is Iyas bin Yazid.
1228 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Wahb Al-Jushami - and he had companionship - (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Name yourselves with the names of the Prophets. . . (1). Narrated by Abu Dawood, and the wording is his, and An-Nasa'i.
foot_note: 1. Here in the original is an addition: "And the most beloved of names to Allah are Abdullah and Abdur-Rahman. . .", and it is from the share of "As-Sahih".

text:
7 - (Encouragement to discipline children) .
1229 - (1) [Weak] From Jabir bin Samurah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "For a man to discipline his child; is better for him than to give a Sa' (of charity)." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from the narration of Nasih from Simak from him. And he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith".
(Al-Hafiz said): "This Nasih; is Ibn Ubaidullah Al-Muhallami; flimsy (Wah), and this is among what the Hafizs denounced him for."
1230 - (2) [Weak] And from Ayyub bin Musa from his father from his grandfather; that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "No father gave (Nahala) a child a gift (Nuhl) (1) better than good manners." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi also and said: "A Gharib Hadith, and this according to me is Mursal."
(Nahala) with Fatha on Nun and the un-dotted Ha; meaning: gave and gifted.
1231 - (3) [Very Weak] And Ibn Majah narrated from Ibn Abbas from the Prophet (PBUH): "Honor your children, and improve their manners" (2).
foot_note:
1. Ibn Al-Athir said: "(An-Nuhl): Giving and gifting initially without compensation or entitlement, it is said: Nahalahu yanhuluhu nuhlan with Damma. And An-Nihlah - with Kasra -: The gift." And it appeared in the edition of the Three here (Nahala) also as in the beginning of the hadith, meaning on the form (Fa'ala) which the author restricted and explained, and it would have been more appropriate for him to restrict and explain its verbal noun (Masdar)!! 
2. I say: It contains two weak narrators, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1649).

8 - (Discouragement from a person attributing himself to other than his father, or taking as masters other than his masters) .
1232 - (1) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Whoever takes as masters other than his masters; let him take his seat in the Fire." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (1).
9 - (Encouragement for one who had three children die, or two, or one, regarding what is mentioned of abundant reward) .
1233 - (1) [Weak] And from Al-Harith bin Uqaish (2) (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "There are no two Muslims who have four children die; except that Allah enters them into Paradise by the virtue of His mercy." A man said: O Messenger of Allah! And three? He said: "And three." They said: And two? He said: "And two." [He said: "And indeed among my Ummah is he who will be magnified (3) for the Fire until he becomes one of its corners"].
foot_note:
1. I say: It is with him (1218 - Al-Mawarid) via the path of Safwan bin Salih: Al-Walid bin Muslim told us with his chain from (Hisn), and this one is unknown, and those before him practice Tadlis At-Taswiyah. 
2. With Qaf and the dotted letter in diminutive form, and the Hamza may be replaced by Waw. 
3. Original: (Yista'zamu). And the correction is from "Al-Mustadrak" (4/ 593), and "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (1/ 164/ 2), and "Al-Muntakhab min Al-Musnad" by Abd bin Humaid (Folio 66/ 1).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text:
Narrated by Abdullah bin Imam Ahmad in his "Zawa'id" and Abu Ya'la with a Sahih chain (1).
1234 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Barzah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "There are no two Muslims who have four forerunners (Afrat - children dying young) die; except that Allah enters them into Paradise by the virtue of His mercy." They said: O Messenger of Allah! And three? He said: "And three." They said: And two? He said: "And two." He said: "And indeed among my Ummah is surely he who is magnified for the Fire until he becomes one of its corners, . . . (2) by his intercession the like of Mudar will enter Paradise." Narrated by Abdullah bin Imam Ahmad, and his narrators are trustworthy, and I think it is the hadith of Al-Harith bin Uqaish which is before it. And the explanation of that will come if Allah wills (3).
1235 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Tha'labah Al-Ashja'i (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! Two children of mine died in Islam? He said: "Whoever has two children die in Islam; Allah enters him into Paradise by the virtue of His mercy to them."
foot_note:
1. I say: In it is Abdullah bin Qais unknown as Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar and others said, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4823). 
2. In the original here is the sentence: "And indeed from my Ummah is he who enters Paradise...", so I deleted it because it is not from the condition of the Weak. 
3. At the end of the book, and the summary of that: is that the hadith is from the Musnad of Al-Harith bin Uqaish which is before it, and that he narrated it to Abu Barzah, and it is not from the Musnad of Abu Barzah. And I verified that in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4823).

He said: So when it was after that Abu Hurairah met me; so he said to me: Are you the one whom the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said to regarding the two children what he said? I said: Yes. He said: That he says it to me; is more beloved to me than what Homs and Palestine closed upon. Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani, and Ahmad's narrators are trustworthy (1). (Falastin) with Kasra on Fa and Fatha on Lam and Sukun on the un-dotted Sin: A district in Sham. And Fa may be Fatha.
1236 - (4) [Weak] And from Mu'adh (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "There are no two Muslims who have three children pass away; except that Allah enters them into Paradise by the virtue of His mercy to them." They said: O Messenger of Allah! Or two? He said: "Or two" (2). They said: Or one? He said: "Or one", then he said . . . Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani, and Ahmad's chain is Hasan, or close to Hasan (3).
foot_note:
1. Thus he said: And Al-Haythami followed him! And in it is Umar bin Nabhan Al-Hijazi; no one authenticated him except Ibn Hibban, and there is ignorance (Jahalah) in him; as Adh-Dhahabi and others said, and in it also is the 'an'ana of Abu Az-Zubair and Ibn Juraij. And it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6861). 
2. I say: The hadith up to here is Sahih having witnesses which you see in "As-Sahih" some of which are with the two Sheikhs, and it has a completion having witnesses which you will find there. And see "Al-Mishkat" (1/ 551). 
3. I say: The second is closer, so see "Al-Mishkat" (1754).

1237 - (5) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both); that he heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever has two forerunners (Faratan) from my Ummah Allah enters him into Paradise by them". So Aisha said to him: So whoever has one forerunner? He said: "And whoever has one forerunner O Muwaffaqah (Successful one)! ". She said: So whoever has no forerunner from your Ummah? He said: "Then I am the forerunner of my Ummah, they will never be afflicted by the like of me." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith" (1).
(Al-Farat) with Fatha on Fa and Ra: Is the one who did not reach maturity of the male and female children (2), and its plural is (Afrat).
10 - (Discouragement from corrupting a woman against her husband and a slave against his master) .
[He did not mention a hadith under it according to the condition of our book, and praise be to Allah. See "As-Sahih"].
foot_note:
1. I say: In the transmission of the author of "Al-Mishkat" from him there is no saying: "Hasan", and it is closer; for it contains (Abd Rabbih bin Bariq Al-Hanafi) whom the majority weakened, and Al-Uqaili mentioned him in "Ad-Du'afa", and likewise Ibn Adi (4/ 174) and he and Adh-Dhahabi cited this hadith for him pointing to its Nakarah (denouncement). And As-Saji said: "Al-Harashi narrated Munkar hadiths from him." See "Al-Mishkat" (1735) and "Mukhtasar Ash-Shama'il" (335). 
2. An-Naji said (Folio 171/ 2): "This is a strange explanation, and very weak phrasing, I do not know anyone from the people of Gharib and Language who expressed it so. Originally (Al-Farat): The one who precedes the water-seekers and prepares the ropes and buckets, and plasters the basins, and waters for them. The author interpreted (Al-Farat) similar to this in "Working on Charity" from this book [8 - Charity /3/ 12 - Hadith /As-Sahih] and likewise in other places so he did well and excellently, but he deviated here and was strange as you see. . .".

1238 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (PBUH) who said: "The most hated of Halal (lawful things) to Allah is Divorce." Narrated by Abu Dawood and others. Al-Khattabi said: "And the famous view regarding it is from Muharib bin Dithar from the Prophet (PBUH) Mursal, Ibn Umar was not mentioned in it, and Allah knows best".

Forbid your women from wearing adornment and strutting in the mosque, for the Children of Israel were not cursed until their women wore adornment, and strutted in the mosques". Narrated by Ibn Majah [Passed here 1 - Chapter].

13 - (Discouragement from spreading secrets especially what is between spouses) .
1240 - (1) [Munkar] From Abu Said (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Indeed among the worst of people in station before Allah on the Day of Resurrection; is the man who confides to his wife and she confides to him, then he spreads her secret." And in a narration: "Indeed among the greatest of trusts before Allah on the Day of Resurrection; is the man who confides to his wife and she confides to him, then he spreads her secret." Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood and others (1).
1241 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Said Al-Khudri also from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) who said: "As-Siba' is Haram." Ibn Lahi'ah said: "He means by it the one who boasts about intercourse." Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, and Al-Baihaqi; all of them via the path of Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham, and more than one authenticated it.
(As-Siba') with Kasra on the un-dotted Sin followed by Ba with one dot is what is famous. And it was said: With the dotted Shin.
1242 - (3) [Weak] And from Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Gatherings are by trust; except three gatherings: Shedding forbidden blood, or forbidden private part (adultery), or seizing wealth without right." Narrated by Abu Dawood from the narration of the son of the brother of Jabir bin Abdullah and he is unknown. And in it also is Abdullah bin Nafi' As-Sa'igh, Muslim and others narrated from him, and there is speech regarding him.

See the discussion on it in "Adab Az-Zafaf" (p. 63 - 70 and 142 - 143 - Al-Islamiyyah), and the two narrations are Muslim's (4/ 157) and the addition is from him, and the original was: "one of them spreads the secret of his companion"! And what is established and the addition is from him. And the other narration is Abu Dawood's.

1243 - (1) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Ad-Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "[Indeed] the best thing you visit Allah with in your graves and your mosques; is white." Narrated by Ibn Majah.
2 - (Encouragement regarding the Qamis (Shirt) (1), and discouragement from its length and the length of other things worn, and dragging it out of pride, and trailing it (Isbal) in prayer and otherwise) .
1244 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Buraydah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: We were with the Prophet (PBUH), and a man from Quraish came strutting in a suit of his, so when he stood up from the Prophet (PBUH) he said: "O Buraydah! This one, Allah will not set up any weight for him on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Al-Bazzar.
1245 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) came out to us while we were gathered and said: "O assembly of Muslims! Fear Allah and join your ties of kinship; for there is no reward
foot_note: 1. See its hadiths in "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text:
faster than joining ties of kinship, and beware of oppression (Baghy); for there is no punishment faster than the punishment of oppression, and beware of disobedience to parents; for the scent of Paradise is found from a distance of a thousand years, and by Allah, no disobedient one finds it, nor one who severs ties of kinship, nor an old adulterer, nor one dragging his Izar out of pride, indeed pride belongs to Allah Lord of the worlds" the Hadith. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" [It will come in full 22 - Righteousness /2].
1246 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) say: "Whoever drags his garment out of pride; Allah will not look at him on the Day of Resurrection, even if he was noble to Allah." Narrated by At-Tabarani from the narration of Ali bin Yazid Al-Alhani.
1247 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH); that he said: "Jibril (peace be upon him) came to me and said to me: This is the night of the middle of Sha'ban, and to Allah in it are freed ones from the Fire by the number of the hair of the sheep of Kalb, Allah does not look in it to a polytheist, nor to a Mushahin, nor to one severing kinship ties, nor to a Musbil (one trailing garments), nor to one undutiful to his parents, nor to one addicted to alcohol." Narrated by Al-Baihaqi.
1248 - (5) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: While a man was praying trailing his Izar; the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said to him: "Go and perform ablution."
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: So he went and performed ablution. Then he came, then he said to him: "Go and perform ablution." So another man said to him: O Messenger of Allah! What is the matter with you that you ordered him to perform ablution then kept silent about him? He said: "He was praying while trailing his Izar, and indeed Allah does not accept the prayer of a man trailing (his garment)." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and Abu Ja'far Al-Madani if he is Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Husain then his narration from Abu Hurairah is Mursal, and if he is someone else then I do not know him (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: He is certainly someone else, and he is Al-Ansari the Mu'adhin, and he is unknown. See "Al-Mishkat" (761) and "Da'if Abi Dawood" (97). And the author's speech gives the impression that he narrated it from Abu Hurairah directly, and it is not so; for between them is Ata' bin Yasar.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - (Encouragement for words to say for one who wears a new garment). 1249 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, wore a new garment and said: (Praise be to Allah who clothed me with what I cover my nakedness with, and adorn myself with in my life). Then he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever wears a new garment and says: (Praise be to Allah who clothed me with what I cover my nakedness with, and adorn myself with in my life), then takes the garment which has worn out and gives it in charity; he will be in the protection of Allah, in the preservation of Allah, and in the covering of Allah; living and dead." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and he said: "A Gharib hadith," and Ibn Majah and Al-Hakim; all from the narration of Asbagh bin Zaid from Abu Al-Ala' from him. And Abu Al-Ala' is unknown, and Asbagh will be mentioned later. And Al-Bayhaqi and others narrated it via the path of Ubaidullah bin Zahr from Ali bin Yazid from Al-Qasim from him, and he mentioned it, and said in it: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever wears a garment - I think he said: - new, and says when it reaches his collarbone the like of that, then takes his old garment and clothes a poor person with it; he will not cease to be in the neighborliness of Allah, in the protection of Allah, and in the shelter of Allah, living and dead, living and dead, living and dead, as long as a thread (silk) (1) remains of the garment." He added in some of his narrations: Yasin said: So I said to Ubaidullah: From which of the two garments? He said: I do not know.
foot_note: 1. With a kasra on the unpointed Sin; plural of (Silk): Thread.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1250 - (2) [Very Weak] And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "No servant has Allah bestowed a blessing upon and he knew it was from Allah; except that Allah wrote for him its gratitude before he praises Him for it. And no servant committed a sin and regretted it; except that Allah wrote for him forgiveness before he seeks His forgiveness. And no servant bought a garment for a Dinar or half a Dinar and wore it, then praised Allah; except that it did not reach his knees until Allah forgave him." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Hakim said: "I do not know of any impugned narrator among its narrators." Thus he said. (1) 4 - (Warning against women wearing thin garments that describe the skin). [No hadith meeting the condition of our book is under it. See "As-Sahih"].
foot_note: 1. I say: It contains one who is not followed in his hadith as Adh-Dhahabi said in his "Talkhis". But I found another path for it; except that it contains a Matruk (abandoned) narrator, and its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5347).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 5 - (Warning men against wearing silk and sitting on it, and adorning themselves with gold, and encouraging women to leave both). 1251 - (1) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever wears silk in the world; will not wear it in the Hereafter, and if he enters Paradise the people of Paradise will wear it but he will not wear it." Narrated by An-Nasa'i, Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Hakim who said: "Sahih in chain" (1). 1252 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "He does not enjoy silk who hopes for the Days of Allah." Narrated by Ahmad, and it has a story. 1253 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Only he wears silk in the world; who does not hope to wear it in the Hereafter." Al-Hasan said: What is the matter with people whom this reaches from their Prophet yet they put silk in their clothes and houses?! Narrated by Ahmad via the path of Mubarak bin Fadalah from Al-Hasan from him.
foot_note: 1. I say: Thus he said, but it contains Dawood As-Sarraj, who is unknown as Ibn Al-Madini and others said. And it is Munkar (denounced) in its second half, because it did not appear in the authentic hadiths of the chapter, and you see some of them in "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1254 - (4) [Very Weak] And from Juwayriyah who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever wears a silk garment in the world (1); Allah the Mighty and Majestic will clothe him in a garment of Fire on the Day of Resurrection." And in a narration: "Whoever wears a silk garment in the world; Allah will clothe him on the Day of Resurrection in a garment of humiliation or a garment of fire." Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani, and in its chain is Jabir Al-Ju'fi. 1255 - (5) [Very Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "I was shown that I entered Paradise, and lo, the highest people of Paradise were the poor of the Muhajirin and the offspring of the believers, and lo, there was no one less in it than the rich and the women. It was said to me: As for the rich, they are at the gate being held to account and purified, and as for the women, the two reds distracted them: Gold and Silk" The Hadith. Narrated by Abu Ash-Shaykh Ibn Hibban and others (2) via the path of Ubaidullah bin Zahr from Ali bin Yazid (3) from Al-Qasim from him. [Weak] And the hadith of Abu Umamah passed [16 - Sales / 19] from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said:
foot_note:
1. His saying: "in the world" is not in this narration in Ahmad (6/ 324) and the context is his, but it is in the other narration of Ahmad also (6/ 430). This was in the original with the wording: "humiliation of fire" so I corrected it from it and from "Jami' Al-Masanid" (15/ 349) and extremities of "Al-Musnad" (8/ 398). It seems the author combined the two narrations, as well as the two narrations of At-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (24/ 65/ 170 and 171), and the pivot of the narrations is upon Sharik from Jabir!! 
2. I say: Like Ahmad, so attributing it to him was more appropriate, even if the path is one, see "Ad-Da'ifah" (5346). 
3. Original: (Zaid), and the correction is from the "Manuscript", "Al-Musnad" and books of Rijal.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "A group from this Ummah will spend the night in food and drink and amusement and play, then they will wake up having been transformed into monkeys and pigs. And swallowing by the earth and bombardment will surely afflict them, until people wake up saying: The earth swallowed the Banu so-and-so tonight, and the house of so-and-so was swallowed tonight. And stones will surely be sent upon them from the sky; just as they were sent upon the people of Lot upon tribes therein and upon houses. And the barren wind; which destroyed Ad will surely be sent upon them upon tribes therein and upon houses; due to their drinking wine, wearing silk, taking singing girls (Qaynat), eating Riba, and severing kinship ties," and Ja'far forgot one trait. Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 6 - (Warning against men imitating women or women imitating men in dress, speech, movement, or the like). 1256 - (1) [Denounced (Munkar)] And At-Tabarani [meaning from the hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, in "As-Sahih"], and he has (1): That a woman passed by the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, carrying a bow, so he said: "Allah cursed women who imitate men, and men who imitate women." 1257 - (2) [Weak] And from a man from Hudhail who said: I saw Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with them both, and his house was in the Hill (non-sacred area) and his mosque in the Haram. He said: While I was with him he saw Umm Sa'id the daughter of Abu Jahl carrying a bow, and walking the walk of a man. Abdullah said: Who is this? I said: This is Umm Sa'id bint Abu Jahl. He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "He is not of us who imitates men from among women, nor who imitates women from among men." Narrated by Ahmad and the wording is his, and its narrators are trustworthy; except the ambiguous man, who was not named. And At-Tabarani briefly, and he dropped the ambiguous man so he did not mention him.
foot_note: 1. Meaning in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir"; this is the intended meaning upon absolute attribution, but the author often differs, and this is one of them; for he only narrated it in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat" in the biography of Ali bin Sa'id Ar-Razi (No. 4160 - my numbering) with his chain from Abdur-Rahman bin Ziyad Ar-Rasasi: Muhammad bin Muslim At-Ta'ifi told us, from Amr bin Dinar, from Ibn Abbas. And At-Ta'ifi has weakness, and Ar-Rasasi was not declared trustworthy except by Ibn Hibban; yet he said: "He might err." So the hadith mentioning the woman and the bow is Munkar (denounced) contradicting what is in "Sahih Al-Bukhari" and others, and it is here in "As-Sahih" as I indicated above.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1258 - (3) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, cursed the effeminate men; who imitate women, and the masculine women; who imitate men, and the one who rides the desert alone" (1). Narrated by Ahmad and its men are the men of "As-Sahih"; except Tayyib bin Muhammad, and there is criticism about him, and the hadith is Hasan (2). 1259 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Four are cursed in the world and the Hereafter; and the angels said Amen: A man whom Allah made male so he feminized himself and imitated women, and a woman whom Allah made female so she masculinized herself and imitated men, and the one who misleads a blind person, and a man who is celibate (hasur), and Allah did not make anyone Hasur except Yahya bin Zakariya." Narrated by At-Tabarani via the path of Ali bin Yazid Al-Alhani, and in the hadith is strangeness. 1260 - (5) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: An effeminate man who had dyed his hands and feet with henna was brought to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "What is the matter with this one?" They said: He imitates women. So he ordered regarding him and he was exiled to (An-Naqi'). It was said: O Messenger of Allah!
foot_note:
1. Ahmad added in a narration (2/ 289): "So that became hard on the companions of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, until that became apparent in their faces, and he said: The one who stays overnight alone." 
2. I say: Not at all; for cursing the rider of the desert is Munkar (denounced), we do not know it except in this hadith. And At-Tayyib bin Muhammad was not declared trustworthy except by Ibn Hibban; and Adh-Dhahabi said: "He is hardly known." Furthermore, the narrator from him, Ayub bin An-Najjar, is a Mudallis, and he narrated it with 'an'anah.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Will you not kill him? He said: "Indeed I have been forbidden from killing those who pray." Narrated by Abu Dawood, he said: "And Abu Usamah said: And (An-Naqi') is an area outside Medina, and it is not (Al-Baqi'); meaning it is with Nun not Ba." (Al-Hafiz said): "Abu Dawood narrated it from Abu Yasar Al-Qurashi from Abu Hashim from Abu Huraira. And in its text is denouncability (nakarah), and this Abu Yasar I do not know his name. Abu Hatim Ar-Razi said when asked about him: 'Unknown'. But it is not so; for Al-Awza'i and Al-Layth narrated from him; so how can he be unknown?! And Allah knows best (1)".
foot_note: 1. I say: There is no contradiction; for ignorance (Jahalah) is of two types: ignorance of condition (haliyah) and ignorance of identity (ayniyah). If Abu Hatim's statement is interpreted as ignorance of condition; the problem disappears. Al-Hafiz translated him with it in "At-Taqrib", and translated Abu Hashim with it as well. Which is an illusion from him; for this one is unknown in identity (majhul al-ayn), no one narrated from him except this Abu Yasar, therefore Adh-Dhahabi said: "He is not known". So it is more appropriate to fault the hadith due to him. And it is Munkar as Adh-Dhahabi said in the biography of the first. After writing the above, I saw in the margin of the Zahiriyah manuscript the text: "Yazid; unknown condition, meaning he was not declared trustworthy, and he did not mean he is unknown in identity. Ibn Hajar."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 7 - (Encouragement to abandon extravagance in clothing out of humility and following the example of the most noble creation Muhammad, may Allah bless him and his family and grant them peace, and his companions, and warning against clothing of fame, pride, and boasting). 1261 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed Allah the Mighty and Majestic loves the one who is humble in dress (Mutabadhil), who does not care what he wears." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi (1). 1262 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him: "That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, ate rough [food], and wore rough [clothes]; he wore wool, and wore patched sandals." It was said to Al-Hasan: What is rough? He said: Coarse barley, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, could not swallow it except with a gulp of water. Narrated by Ibn Majah, and Al-Hakim and the wording is his; both from the narration of Yusuf bin Abi Kathir, from Nuh bin Dhakwan. And Al-Hakim said: "Sahih in chain". (Al-Hafiz said): "Yusuf is not known, and Nuh bin Dhakwan, Abu Hatim said: He is nothing."
foot_note: 1. Meaning in "Ash-Shu'ab" (5/ 156/ 6176), and it contains an interruption which the Three Commentators were ignorant of, and they faulted it due to (Ibn Lahi'ah), while it is from the narration of Ibn Wahb from him! And this is their habit, they do not know that his narration from him is authentic, so they weakened some authentic hadiths due to this ignorance of theirs. See for example this chapter in "As-Sahih". And Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi did not find the source of this hadith so he said: "I did not find a basis for it"! See "Ad-Da'ifah" (2324).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1263 - (3) [Very Weak] And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "On Moses the day his Lord spoke to him was a cloak of wool, a jubbah of wool, a kummah of wool, and trousers of wool, and his sandals were from the skin of a dead donkey." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib hadith [we do not know it except from the hadith of Humaid Al-A'raj, and he is Ibn Ali Al-Kufi, Muhammad [meaning Al-Bukhari] said: Munkar al-Hadith (Denounced in hadith)]" (1), and Al-Hakim; both from Humaid Al-A'raj, from Abdullah bin Al-Harith, from Ibn Mas'ud. And Al-Hakim said: "Sahih on the condition of Al-Bukhari". (Al-Hafiz said): "Al-Hakim imagined that this Humaid Al-A'raj is Humaid bin Qais Al-Makki, but he is Humaid bin Ali (2), and it is said: Ibn Ammar; one of the abandoned narrators. And Allah knows best." (Al-Kummah) with a damma on the Kaf and shadda on the Mim: The small cap (qalansuwah) (3). 1264 - (4) [Weak Mawquf] And from Abu Al-Ahwas from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophets used to like to wear wool, milk sheep, and ride donkeys. Narrated by Al-Hakim as Mawquf and he said: "Sahih on their condition" (4). 1265 - (5) [Weak] And Ibn Majah narrated from Ubada bin as-Samit who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, came out to us one day wearing a jubbah of wool, with narrow
foot_note:
1. Original: "Hasan Gharib", so I corrected it from "At-Tirmidhi" (1734) and "Tuhfat Al-Ashraf" (7/ 64/ 9328), and the addition is from him, and it confirms that the word: "Hasan" is inserted by some scribes because it contradicts it. 
2. Adh-Dhahabi said likewise, but attributing the illusion in it to Al-Hakim is questionable to me; because Ibn Mardawayh narrated it like Al-Hakim's narration as Ibn Kathir mentioned. So the error is from someone else as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4082). 
3. And it is in our custom (Taqiyah). Stated by Al-Hafiz An-Naji Al-Halabi. 
4. I say: It contains the confusion (ikhtilat) of As-Sabi'i; as explained in "At-Ta'liq Ar-Raghib".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: sleeves, and he prayed leading us in it, having nothing on him other than it (1). 1266 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Innocence from pride is wearing wool, sitting with the poor believers (2), riding a donkey, and tying the goat or camel." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and others. 1267 - (7) [Weak Mursal] And from Al-Hasan: That the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to pray in the unstitched garments (murut) of his wives, and they were cloaks of wool from what is bought for six or seven (dirhams), and his wives used to wrap themselves in them. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and it is Mursal, and in its chain is softness. 1268 - (8) [Denounced (Munkar)] And At-Tabarani narrated [meaning the hadith of Abu Burdah in "As-Sahih"] with a Sahih chain also (3) similarly, and added at its end: "Our clothing is but wool, and our food is but the two black things: dates and water." 1269 - (9) [Weak] And from Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I went out on a winter morning hungry and the cold had hurt me, so I took a garment of wool that we had, then put it around my neck. And I tied it on my chest to warm myself with it, by Allah there was nothing in my house for me to eat, and if there was anything in the house of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace,
foot_note:
1. It contains weakness and interruption, as explained there. 
2. Original: (Muslims). The correction is from "Al-Bayhaqi", and "Da'if Al-Jami'" (2323) and others. 
3. I say: Absolute attribution gives the illusion that he narrated it in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir", but he narrated it in "Al-Awsat" (2/ 564/ 1967). And limiting the attribution to him implies that no one else who committed to extracting authentic hadiths in his book narrated it, and it is not so, for Al-Hakim extracted it (4/ 188), but it contains one whose memory was criticized and he contradicted trustworthy narrators in his addition, so it is Munkar (denounced), as I explained in the original.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: it would have reached me... so he mentioned the hadith (1) until he said: Then I came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and sat with him in the mosque, and he was with a group of his companions. Mus'ab bin Umair appeared to us in a cloak of his patched with fur, and he used to be the most pampered youth in Mecca and the most luxurious in life. When the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saw him he remembered the bliss he used to be in, and saw the state he was in, so his eyes shed tears and he wept. Then the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Are you better today or when a bowl of bread and meat is brought to one of you in the morning, and another is brought in the evening, and he goes out in a suit and returns in another, and you cover your houses as the Kaaba is covered?" We said: Rather we are better on that day; we devote ourselves to worship. He said: "Rather you are better today" (2). Narrated by Abu Ya'la and the wording is his. And At-Tirmidhi narrated it; except that he said: I went out on a winter day from the house of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace; and I had taken a tanned (ma'tun) (3) hide and cut a hole in its center, put it around my neck, and tied my waist with palm fiber, and I was severely hungry, so he mentioned the hadith, and did not mention the story of Mus'ab bin Umair in it, but mentioned his story in another place separately, and said in each of them: "A Hasan Gharib hadith". (Al-Hafiz said): "And in both its chains and the chain of Abu Ya'la is a man who was not named."
foot_note:
1. I say: It will come in full in (24 - Repentance and Asceticism / 6). 
2. This section from: "Are you better today..." to here is Sahih li-ghayrihi (authentic due to other evidence), and it will come in (19 - Food / 7) of "As-Sahih", and it is extracted in "As-Sahihah" (2384). 
3. (Al-Ma'tun): The stinking hide with hair falling out, it is said: The hide 'atana', so it is 'atin' and 'ma'tun': if its hair fell out and it stank in the tanning process. Thus in "An-Nihayah". And it occurred in "At-Tirmidhi" (2475): (Ma'tuban), and likewise in the edition of the Three! And they explained it by saying: "A tanned hide and it is said untanned"!!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Jawwabtu) its center, with shadda on the Waw; meaning: I cut a hole in its center like a pocket (jaib); which is the opening from which a person puts out his head. And (Al-Ihab) with a kasra on the Hamza: is the hide/skin, and it is said: what has not been tanned. 1270 - (10) [Weak] And from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, looked at Mus'ab bin Umair approaching, wearing a ram's skin (1) he had girded himself with. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Look at this one whose heart Allah has illuminated. I saw him between two parents who fed him the best food and drink, and I saw him wearing a suit he bought or was bought for two hundred dirhams. Then the love of Allah and the love of His Messenger called him to what you see." Narrated by At-Tabarani (2) and Al-Bayhaqi. 1271 - (11) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ash-Shifa' bint Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: I came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, asking him, and he began to apologize to me; and I was blaming him. Then the prayer time came, so I went out and entered upon my daughter who was married to Shurahbil bin Hasanah. I found Shurahbil in the house; so I said: The prayer time has come and you are in the house; and I began to blame him. He said: O aunt! Do not blame me; for I had a garment but the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, borrowed it! So I said: May my father and mother be ransomed; I have been blaming him all day and this is his condition and I did not realize!
foot_note:
1. It is the skin, and it is said: The skin is only called (ihab) before tanning, but after it, no. "Nihayah". (Qad tanattaqa bihi) Meaning: He tied it with a rope around his waist. 
2. The intended meaning upon absolute mention is his "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir", and I did not see it in "Musnad Umar" thereof, nor did I see it in "Majma' Az-Zawa'id" neither in "Clothing" nor in "Asceticism". Then I returned to the manuscript, and found a blank space in place of (At-Tabarani), so I felt that (At-Tabarani) is an addition by some scribes, and it would be more appropriate to put Abu Nu'aym in its place; for he narrated it in "Al-Hilyah". Furthermore, there is weakness and ignorance in its chain; and its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5195). As for the Three Ignorant Ones, they said: "Hasan"! Just like that, blindly!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Shurahbil said: It was nothing but an armor we patched. Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Bayhaqi. 1272 - (12) [Very Weak Mawquf] And it was narrated from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We attended the wedding of Ali and Fatimah, may Allah be pleased with them both, and we never saw a wedding better than it. We stuffed the mattress - meaning with palm fiber - and brought dates and raisins and ate. Her mattress on her wedding night was a ram's skin. Narrated by Al-Bazzar (1). 1273 - (13) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Thawban, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! What suffices me of the world? He said: "What satisfies your hunger, and covers your nakedness, and if you have a house to shade you that is it, and if you have a mount then excellent excellent (bakhin bakhin)." Narrated by At-Tabarani (2). 1274 - (14) [Weak] And from Abu Ya'fur (3) who said: I heard Ibn Amr being asked by a man: What should I wear of clothes? He said: What fools do not despise you for, and the wise do not fault you for. He said: What is it? He said: Between five dirhams to twenty dirhams.
foot_note:
1. And he said: "We do not know anyone narrated it like this except Abdullah, and he was not a Hafiz, and he was not corroborated on it, and he has hadiths he is unique in." And Abdullah is Ibn Maimun Al-Qaddah, very weak; as in "At-Taqrib". It occurred in "Kashf Al-Astar" (1408) in Al-Bazzar's statement: "Umar", and Sheikh Al-A'zami did not notice that it is a distortion of "Abdullah"! 
2. He gave the illusion by absolute attribution that it is in "Al-Kabir"; and it is not so; he only narrated it in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat"; see "Ad-Da'ifah" (5351). 
3. Original: (Abu Ya'qub), which is a misspelling, and the correction is from "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (32/ 188/ 2) and the manuscript.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani and its men are men of "As-Sahih" (1). 1275 - (15) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Umm Salamah, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "No one wears a garment to boast with it and for people to look at him; [except] Allah does not look at him; until he takes it off whenever he takes it off." Narrated by At-Tabarani (2). 1276 - (16) [Weak] And from Damrah bin Tha'labah, may Allah be pleased with him: That he came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, wearing two Yemeni suits; he said: "O Damrah! Do you think these two garments of yours will enter you into Paradise?" He said: O Messenger of Allah! If you seek forgiveness for me I will not sit until I take them off me.
