So the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "O Allah! Forgive Damrah." So he went quickly until he took them off. Narrated by Ahmad, and its narrators are trustworthy; except Baqiyyah (3). 1277 - (17) [Weak] And he also narrated [meaning Ibn Majah] from Uthman bin Jahm from Zirr bin Hubaish from Abu Dharr from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever wears a garment of fame; Allah turns away from him until he puts it down whenever he puts it down."
foot_note:
1. I say: Yes, but that does not necessitate the authenticity of the report; because this Ibn Abi Ya'fur, whose name is (Yunus), is disagreed upon; Ahmad and others weakened him, and Al-Hafiz said in "At-Taqrib": "Truthful but errs much." So the likes of him, his hadith is barely Hasan. 
2. See "Ad-Da'ifah" (5352). 
3. Meaning he is a Mudallis, and he narrated with 'an'anah. Furthermore, there is interruption between Damrah and the narrator from him Yahya bin Jabir; for he did not narrate from any of the Companions, but his narration is from the Tabi'in, he died in the year (126).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 8 - (Encouragement to give charity to the poor with what they wear such as clothes and the like). 1278 - (1) [Weak] From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "No Muslim clothes a Muslim with a garment; except that he is in the protection of Allah the Exalted as long as a rag of it remains on him." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim; both from the narration of Khalid bin Tahman. And Al-Hakim's wording is: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever clothes a Muslim with a garment; never ceases to be in the cover of Allah as long as a thread or yarn of it remains on him." At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Gharib hadith," and Al-Hakim said: "Sahih in chain" (1). 1279 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Any Muslim who clothes a Muslim a garment over nakedness; Allah clothes him from the green [garments] of Paradise. And any Muslim who feeds a Muslim upon hunger; Allah feeds him from the fruits of Paradise. And any Muslim who gives a Muslim water upon thirst; Allah the Mighty and Majestic gives him drink from the Sealed Nectar." Narrated by Abu Dawood from the narration of Abu Khalid Yazid bin Abdur-Rahman Ad-Dalani, and his hadith is Hasan (2),
foot_note:
1. I say: Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him saying (4/ 196): "I say: Khalid is weak." Al-Hafiz said: "He became confused (Ikhtalat)." 
2. Thus he said! There is much discussion about him, Al-Hafiz summarized it by saying in "At-Taqrib": "Truthful, errs much, and used to practice Tadlis."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: and At-Tirmidhi with advancement and delay, and its wording passed in "Feeding Food" [8 - Charity / 17], and he said: "A Gharib hadith, and it has been narrated as Mawquf on Abu Sa'id, which is more correct and more likely." 1280 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] (Al-Hafiz said): And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it in the book "Istina' Al-Ma'ruf" from Ibn Mas'ud as Mawquf on him, who said: People will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection more naked than they ever were, more hungry than they ever were, more thirsty than they ever were, and more tired (ansab) than they ever were. So whoever clothed for the sake of Allah the Mighty and Majestic; Allah the Mighty and Majestic will clothe him. And whoever fed for the sake of Allah the Mighty and Majestic; Allah the Mighty and Majestic will feed him. And whoever gave water for the sake of Allah the Mighty and Majestic; Allah the Mighty and Majestic will give him water. And whoever acted for Allah; Allah will suffice him. And whoever pardoned for the sake of Allah the Mighty and Majestic; Allah the Mighty and Majestic will pardon him. [Passed there]. (Ansab) meaning: More tired. (Al-Hafiz said) [Weak] And the hadith of Abu Umamah passed in "Chapter: What to say when wearing a new garment" [Here / 3 - Chapter], and in it: Umar said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Whoever wears a garment - I think he said: new - and says when it reaches his collarbone the like of that (1), then takes his old garment and clothes a poor person with it; he will not cease to be in the neighborliness of Allah, in the protection of Allah, and in the shelter of Allah, living and dead, living and dead, as long as a thread of the garment remains."
foot_note: 1. Meaning like the formula of praise mentioned in a narration there before this.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 9 - (Encouragement to keep white hair and dislike of plucking it). 10 - (Warning against dyeing the beard black). 11 - (Warning against the hair extender and the one asking for it, the tattooer and the tattooed, the plucker and the one asking for plucking, and the one filing teeth for beauty). (*) [There is no hadith under these three chapters meeting the condition of our book, and praise be to Allah. See "As-Sahih"] 12 - (Encouragement to use antimony (ithmid) kohl for men and women). 1281 - (1) [Weak] And he claimed [meaning Ibn Abbas in his hadith which is in "As-Sahih"]: "That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had a kohl container; he would apply kohl from it every night; three in this one; and three in this one."
foot_note: 1. (*) The preparer of the book for Shamela said: Under this chapter (No. 11), Al-Mundhiri included a hadith that Sheikh Al-Albani - may Allah have mercy on him - did not include in (Sahih At-Targhib) nor (Da'if), which is: [From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, came out regarding a Qussah (forelock/hair extension) and said: "Indeed, the women of the Children of Israel used to put this on their heads, so they were cursed and the mosques were forbidden to them." Narrated by At-Tabarani in Al-Kabir and Al-Awsat from the narration of Ibn Lahi'ah and the rest of its chain are trustworthy]. End of Al-Mundhiri's words, may Allah have mercy on him. Sheikh Mashhur included it in his edition, prefaced it with the ruling [Weak], and commented saying: "And in At-Ta'liq Ar-Raghib: [Weak], and in it is a reference to 'As-Silsilah Ad-Da'ifah' (No. 6765)." End of Sheikh Mashhur's words.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 19 - Book of Food and Others. 1 - (Encouragement to mention the name of Allah over food, and warning against leaving it). 1282 - (1) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Salman Al-Farsi, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever is pleased that Satan does not find food, nor a midday nap, nor a place to spend the night with him; let him give Salam when he enters his house, and mention the name of Allah over his food." Narrated by At-Tabarani. [Passed in 14 - Remembrance / 15]. 1283 - (2) [Weak] And from Umayyah bin Makhshi - and he was one of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace - may Allah be pleased with him: That a man was eating and the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was watching, and he did not mention the name of Allah until he was at the end of his food, then he said: In the name of Allah at its beginning and at its end. So the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Satan kept eating with him until he mentioned the name of Allah, so nothing remained in his belly except that he vomited it." Narrated by Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Al-Hakim who said: "Sahih in chain" (1). (Makhshi) with fatha on the Mim and sukun on the dotted Kha followed by a dotted Shin with kasra and Ya. Ad-Daraqutni said: "Umayyah did not narrate with a chain from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, other than this hadith. And likewise said Abu Umar An-Namari and others." Al-Hafiz said: "And mention of Basmala will come in the hadith of Ibn Abbas in [10 - Chapter] (Praising Allah after eating)".
foot_note: 1. I say: Not at all; for it contains (Al-Muthanna bin Abdur-Rahman), Ibn Al-Madini said: "Unknown, no one narrated from him except Jabir bin Subh." And Adh-Dhahabi followed him. It is in An-Nasa'i in "Al-Kubra" (Al-Walimah f 59/ 2).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2 - (Warning against using vessels of gold and silver, and its prohibition for men and women). 1284 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever wears silk and drinks in vessels (1) of silver; is not of us,... (1)". Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its narrators are trustworthy except Abdullah bin Muslim Abu Taybah. 3 - (Warning against eating and drinking with the left hand, and what came regarding the prohibition of blowing into the vessel and drinking from the mouth of the waterskin and from the crack of the cup). 1285 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade folding the mouths of waterskins." And that a man, after the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade that, got up at night to a waterskin and folded its mouth; and a snake came out onto him from it. Narrated by Ibn Majah via the path of Zam'ah bin Salih from Salamah bin Wahram, and the rest of its chain are trustworthy. (Khanatha) the waterskin and ikhtanathahu: If he folds its mouth outwards and drinks from it. 1286 - (2) [Weak] And from Isa bin Abdullah bin Unais from his father: That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, called for a leather vessel on the day of Uhud and said: "Fold the mouth of the vessel then drink from its mouth."
foot_note: 1. The word (vessels/aniyah) is not in "At-Tabarani" nor in "Al-Majma'", and the place of the dots is a sentence established in other hadiths; some of which passed in "As-Sahih" (17 - Marriage / 10) with an indication from the author to this hadith.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Abu Dawood from Ubaid (1) Allah bin Umar from him, and from his path Al-Bayhaqi who said: "It appears that the prohibition report was after this." (Al-Hafiz said): "And At-Tirmidhi also narrated it and said: 'Its chain is not authentic, Abdullah bin Umar is weak in hadith, and I do not know if he heard from Isa or not?'. And Allah knows best." 4 - (Encouragement to eat from the sides of the bowl not its middle). [No hadith meeting the condition of our book is under it. See "As-Sahih"].
foot_note: 1. With damma on the unpointed letter, diminutive. Thus it appeared in "Abu Dawood" (3721), and Al-Bayhaqi also in "Ash-Shu'ab" (2/ 207/ 2). And it appeared in At-Tirmidhi (1/ 345) "Abdullah" magnified, and he is the one weakened as will come. It appears to be an old difference, for Al-Ajurri narrated from Abu Dawood that he said: "It is not known from Ubaidullah, and the correct is from Abdullah bin Umar." And Al-Qattan narrated it from Ubaidullah bin Umar from Isa as Mursal, he did not say: from his father, mentioned in "At-Tahdhib". I say: Whether he is the magnified or the diminutive, its pivot is on Isa, and his justness (adalah) is not established. So there is no need for the deduction Al-Bayhaqi stated.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 5 - (Encouragement to eat vinegar and olive oil and to tear meat with teeth without cutting it with a knife - if the report is authentic -). 1287 - (1) [Fabricated] And Ibn Majah narrated from Muhammad bin Zadhan (1) who said: Umm Sa'd told me, saying: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, entered upon Aisha while I was with her, and said: "Is there any lunch?" She said: We have bread, dates, and vinegar. So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "What an excellent condiment is vinegar. O Allah, bless the vinegar; for it was the condiment of the Prophets before me, and no house becomes poor that has vinegar in it." 1288 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira as Marfu' saying: "Eat olive oil and anoint yourselves with it, for it is good and blessed." Narrated by Al-Hakim as a witness. 1289 - (3) [Weak] And from Safwan bin Umayyah who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Tear the meat with teeth (inhahu nahsan) (2); for it is more enjoyable and wholesome." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and Al-Hakim who said:
foot_note:
1. I say: A Madani Matruk (abandoned). Perhaps the author started with him without starting with the Companion as is the rule, to indicate that he is the defect of the hadith. But he missed that the narrator from him - who is Anbasah bin Abdur-Rahman - is worse than him; for Abu Hatim accused him of fabrication! Then wouldn't it have been better to preface it with the passive voice: (Ruwiya), then say if he wished: Ibn Majah narrated it and there is dispute about it..?! 
2. With the unpointed Sin: Taking meat with the edges of the teeth. And (An-Nahsh) with the dotted Shin: Taking it with all of them.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Sahih in chain", and its wording is: He said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saw me taking meat from the bone with my hand, so he said: "O Safwan!" I said: At your service. He said: "Bring the meat close to your mouth; for it is more enjoyable and wholesome." (The Hafiz) Abdul Azim said: "At-Tirmidhi narrated it from Abdul Karim bin Abi Umayyah the Teacher from Abdullah bin Al-Harith from him. And he said: This is a Gharib hadith we do not know except from the hadith of Abdul Karim." (Al-Hafiz said): "This Abdul Karim is flimsy (wahin), Al-Bukhari narrated from him in suspension (mu'allaq); and Muslim in follow-up (mutaba'ah). It has been narrated from other than his hadith, for Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim narrated it from the hadith of Abdur-Rahman bin Muawiyah from Uthman Ibn Abi Sulaiman from him. And Uthman did not hear from Safwan. And Allah knows best (1)". 1290 - (4) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Do not cut meat with a knife; for it is from the practice of the foreigners, but tear it with teeth; for it is more enjoyable and wholesome." Narrated by Abu Dawood and others from Abu Ma'shar, from Hisham bin Urwah, from his father, from her. And this Abu Ma'shar's name is Najih; he was not abandoned, but this hadith is among what was denounced from him. And it is authentic that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, "cut from the shoulder of a sheep, ate then prayed." And Allah knows best (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: It has another defect which is the poor memory of Ibn Muawiyah. I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2193). 
2. The author indicates with this authentic hadith the denouncability of Najih's hadith.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 6 - (Encouragement to gather over food). 1291 - (1) [Very Weak] And Ibn Majah also narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Eat together and do not separate; for blessing is with the group (Jam'ah)." And in it is Amr bin Dinar the steward of the family of Az-Zubayr; flimsy (wahi) in hadith. 7 - (Warning against excessive satiation and expanding in food and drink out of gluttony and insolence). 1292 - (1) [Weak Mawquf] And [meaning the hadith of Abu Juhaifah in "As-Sahih"] Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat", and Al-Bayhaqi, and they added: So Abu Juhaifah (putting Jim before Ha) did not eat his fill until he left the world; if he ate lunch he would not eat dinner, and if he ate dinner he would not eat lunch. [Weak Mawquf] And in a narration of Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya: Abu Juhaifah said: I have not filled my belly for thirty years. 1293 - (2) [Denounced (Munkar) Mawquf] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The first trial that occurred in this Ummah after its Prophet; was satiation. For when people's bellies became full their bodies became fat, so their hearts weakened, and their desires ran wild. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in "Kitab Ad-Du'afa", and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab Al-Ju'" (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: He extracted it (f 2/ 2) from the path of Ghassan bin Ubaid Al-Mawsili: Hamza Al-Basri told us with his chain from her as Mawquf. Adh-Dhahabi listed it in the biography of (Al-Mawsili) among his denounced reports, and I did not know his sheikh Hamza.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1294 - (3) [Weak] And from Ja'dah, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saw a man with a large belly, so he said with his finger: "If this was in other than this it would have been better for you." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and At-Tabarani with a Jayyid (good) chain, and Al-Hakim and Al-Bayhaqi (1). 1295 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed a huge tall man, who eats and drinks much, will be brought on the Day of Resurrection, and he will not weigh with Allah the wing of a gnat. Read if you wish: {and We will not assign to them on the Day of Resurrection any weight}." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and the wording is his... (2) 1296 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Bujayr (3) - and he was one of the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace - who said: Hunger afflicted the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, one day, so he took a stone and placed it on his belly, then said: "Lo, many a soul that is fed and soft in the world; will be hungry and naked on the Day of Resurrection. Lo, many a one honoring himself while he is humiliating it. Lo, many a one humiliating himself while he is honoring it." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. 1297 - (6) [Weak Mawquf] And from Al-Lajlaj, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I have not filled my belly with food since I embraced Islam with the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. I eat what suffices me, and drink what suffices me. Meaning my sustenance.
foot_note:
1. I say: It contains one who was not declared trustworthy except by Ibn Hibban, and only one person narrated from him, and (Ja'dah)'s companionship is not established, therefore I extracted it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1131). 
2. I say: The completion of his speech is in "As-Sahih", and in Al-Bayhaqi's chain (5670) is Salih Al-Murri; weak. 
3. It appeared in some copies and sources (Abu Bujayr), and the confirmed is from "Al-Ikmal" and "Asad Al-Ghabah" and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2368).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani with a chain that has no harm (1), and Al-Bayhaqi and added: "And he lived one hundred and twenty years; fifty in Jahiliyyah and seventy in Islam." 1298 - (7) [Weak] And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saw me having eaten twice in a day, so he said: "O Aisha! Do you love that you have no busyness except your belly?! Eating twice in a day is from extravagance, (and Allah does not like the extravagant)." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi, and in it is Ibn Lahi'ah. [Fabricated] And in a narration: He said: "O Aisha! Have you taken the world as your belly?! More than one meal every day is extravagance, (and Allah does not like the extravagant) (2). 1299 - (8) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "It is from extravagance that you eat everything you desire." Narrated by Ibn Majah, Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab Al-Ju'", and Al-Bayhaqi. Al-Hakim authenticated its chain for a text other than this, and others classified it Hasan (3).
foot_note:
1. Thus he said. It contains (19/ 218 - 219) Al-Mu'alla bin Al-Walid Al-Qa'qa'i, Ibn Hibban mentioned him in "Ath-Thiqat" (9/ 182) and said: "He might report oddities." And he said in "Al-Majma'": "And I did not know him"! I say: It appears the defect is above him; for As-Sarraj narrated it from other than his path from Abdur-Rahman bin Al-Ala' bin Al-Lajlaj from his father from his grandfather; and this Abdur-Rahman, no one narrated from him except Mubashir bin Ismail Al-Halabi as in "Al-Mizan"; so he is unknown. So he is the defect. From this mode Al-Bayhaqi extracted it in "Ash-Shu'ab" (2/ 165/ 1). 
2. And Al-Bayhaqi said after this: "In its chain is weakness." This is great leniency; for it contains liars below Ibn Lahi'ah; contrary to the first narration, and its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5362). 
3. I say: It has defects, Ibn Al-Jawzi mentioned two of them in "Al-Mawdu'at", so see them if you wish in "Ad-Da'ifah" (241).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1300 - (9) [Weak Athar] And Malik narrated from Yahya bin Sa'id; that Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, met Jabir bin Abdullah and with him was a porter (1) of meat; so Umar said: Does one of you not want to fold his belly for his neighbor and his cousin?! Where does this verse go from you {You exhausted your pleasures during your worldly life and enjoyed them}? Al-Bayhaqi said: "It was narrated from Abdullah bin Dinar as Mursal and Connected as his saying." Al-Halimi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "This threat from Allah the Exalted, although it is for the disbelievers who embark upon forbidden pleasures - and that is why He said: {so this Day you will be recompensed with the punishment of extreme humiliation} -; yet similar is feared for those engrossed in permissible pleasures; because whoever accustoms himself to them, his soul inclines to the world, so it is not safe that he becomes entangled in (2) desires and pleasures. Every time he answers his soul to one of them, it calls him to another, until it reaches a point where he cannot disobey his soul in any desire at all, and the door of worship is blocked before him. If the matter reaches this, it is not far-fetched that it be said to him: {You exhausted your pleasures during your worldly life and enjoyed them, so this Day you will be recompensed with the punishment of extreme humiliation}. So one should not accustom the soul to what inclines it to (3) greed, then it becomes difficult to rectify it. Let it be trained from the beginning on correctness; for that is easier than for it to be trained on corruption, then striving to return it to righteousness." And Allah knows best. 1301 - (10) [?] Al-Bayhaqi said: And we were narrated (4) from Ibn Umar: That he bought lean meat and put ghee on it, so Umar raised his hand and said: By Allah! They never gathered with the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, except that one of them was eaten and the other given in charity. So Ibn Umar said: Eat, O Commander of the Faithful! For by Allah! They will never gather with me again except that I do that.
foot_note:
1. With kasra on the unpointed Ha: What the carrier carried. The original was: (Hamil - carrier), which is an error spoiling the meaning, and the correction is from "Al-Muwatta" and "Al-Ujalah". 
2. Thus in the original, and perhaps it has a valid interpretation. 
3. Original: (bihi min), and the correction is from "Shu'ab Al-Bayhaqi" and "The Manuscript". 
4. Thus he said, he did not cite its chain. Yet the Three Ignorant Commentators said: "Sahih in chain".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 8 - (Warning against a person being invited to food and refusing without excuse, and the command to answer the inviter). 1302 - (1) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever is invited and does not answer; has disobeyed Allah and His Messenger. And whoever enters without invitation; enters as a thief and leaves as a raider." Narrated by Abu Dawood and he did not weaken it, from Durust bin Ziyad - and the majority are on weakening him, and Abu Zur'ah declared him flimsy - from Aban bin Tariq, and he is unknown. Stated by Abu Zur'ah and others. 9 - (Encouragement to lick the fingers before wiping them to attain the blessing). [No hadith meeting the condition of our book is under it. See "As-Sahih"].
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 10 - (Encouragement to praise Allah the Exalted after eating). 1303 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: Abu Bakr went out in the midday heat (Hajirah) to the mosque. Umar heard of that and said: O Abu Bakr! What brought you out at this hour? He said: Nothing brought me out except what I find of intense hunger. He said: And I, by Allah, nothing brought me out but it. While they were like that, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, came out to them and said: "What brought you two out at this hour?" They said: By Allah, nothing brought us out except what we find in our bellies of intense hunger. He said: "By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, nothing brought me out but it. So stand up." So they went until they came to the door of Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari. And Abu Ayyub used to store food or milk for the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. He was late for him that day, and he did not come at his usual time, so he fed it to his family, and went to his palm grove to work in it. When they reached the door, his wife came out and said: Welcome to the Prophet of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and those with him. The Prophet of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said to her: "Where is Abu Ayyub?" He heard him while he was working in a palm grove of his, so he came running, and said: Welcome to the Prophet of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and those with him. O Prophet of Allah! It is not the time you usually come. He, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "You spoke the truth." He said: So he went and cut a bunch (idhq) from the palm tree, containing everything; dates (tamr), fresh dates (rutab), and unripened dates (busr). He, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "What did you intend by this? Could you not have picked from its dates?" He said: O Messenger of Allah! I loved that you eat from its dates, fresh dates, and unripened dates. And I shall slaughter
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: for you with this. He said: "If you slaughter, then do not slaughter a milking animal." So he took a young female goat or a kid goat and slaughtered it, and said to his wife: Bake and knead for us, for you know better about bread. He took half the kid and cooked it, and roasted half of it. When the food was ready, and placed before the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and his companions, he took from the kid and placed it in a loaf, and said: "O Abu Ayyub! Take this to Fatimah; for she has not had the like of this for days." So Abu Ayyub went to Fatimah. When they ate and were satisfied, the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Bread and meat, and dates and unripened dates and fresh dates! - and his eyes shed tears - By the One in Whose Hand is my soul! Indeed this is the bliss about which you will be asked on the Day of Resurrection." This weighed heavily on his companions. So he said: "Rather, when you attain the like of this and you strike with your hands, say: (In the name of Allah), and when you are satisfied say: (Praise be to Allah who satisfied us and bestowed favor upon us and gave abundance, for indeed this is sufficient with this)." When he rose he said to Abu Ayyub: "Come to us tomorrow." And no one used to do him a favor except that he loved to repay him. He said: And Abu Ayyub did not hear that. So Umar said: Indeed the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, orders you to come to him tomorrow. So he came to him the next day and he gave him a slave girl (1), and said: "O Abu Ayyub! Treat her well; for we have not seen anything but good as long as she was with us."
foot_note: 1. Original: (Walidatahu - his slave girl), and the correction is from "Awsat At-Tabarani" and his "Saghir" and Ibn Hibban (2536). It is extracted in "Ar-Rawd" (453).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: When Abu Ayyub brought her from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he said: 'I do not find for the bequest of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) anything better for him than to emancipate her,' so he emancipated her. Narrated by At-Tabarani and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; both from the narration of Abdullah bin Kaysan from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas. (Haqq) al-ju' [intense hunger] with an undotted Ha' and a stressed Qaf: means its severity and distress. 1304 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Hammad bin Abi Sulayman who said: I ate dinner with Abu Burdah, so he said: Shall I not tell you what Abu Abdullah bin Qais told me? He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever eats and becomes full, and drinks and becomes quenched, and says: (Praise be to Allah who fed me and satisfied me, and gave me drink and quenched me); he leaves his sins as on the day his mother bore him." Narrated by Abu Ya'la (1). (Al-Hafiz said): "In this chapter, there are many famous Hadiths from the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that do not meet the condition of our book, so we did not mention them."
foot_note: 1. I say: It contains Muhammad bin Ibrahim Al-Shami. Ibn Hibban and Ad-Daraqutni said: "A liar." Al-Haythami did not know him. It contains another defect besides this one; see "Ad-Da'ifah" (1141).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 11 - (Encouragement to wash hands before food - if the report is authentic - and after it, and intimidation against sleeping while the smell of food is on the hand without washing it). 1305 - (1) [Weak] From Salman (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I read in the Torah: Indeed, the blessing of food is Wudu (washing) after it. So I mentioned that to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and informed him of what I read in the Torah. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The blessing of food is Wudu before it and Wudu after it." Narrated by Abu Dawood and At-Tirmidhi who said: "This Hadith is not known except from the narration of Qais bin Ar-Rabi', and Qais is weakened in Hadith." End quote. (Al-Hafiz said): "Qais bin Ar-Rabi' is truthful (Saduq), but there is criticism regarding him due to his poor memory, but the Isnad (chain) does not fall outside the limit of Hasan (Good). Sufyan used to dislike Wudu before food. Al-Bayhaqi said: Likewise, Malik bin Anas disliked it, and likewise our companion Ash-Shafi'i recommended leaving it, using the Hadith as proof, meaning the Hadith of Ibn Abbas who said: "We were with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and he came from the privy. Then he returned and food was brought to him, so it was said: Will you not perform Wudu? He said: I have not prayed (1) so that I should perform Wudu." Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, and At-Tirmidhi with similar wording; except that they said: So he said:
foot_note: 1. Thus it is in the original, "Al-Intiqa'", and "The Manuscript". An-Naji also found it like this and said (177/2): "Its implication is the assertive (Lam), but it is actually (Lima? Usalli fa-atawadda?!) 'Why? Am I praying so that I should perform ablution?!' with a kasrah on the Lam and fathah on the Mim of (Lima) and affirming the Ya at the end of (Usalli), as An-Nawawi recorded it in "Sharh Muslim" and said: "It is a rhetorical question of denial, meaning: Ablution is for one who wants to pray, and I do not want to pray right now." I say: Ash-Shafi'i's deduction is based on the premise that (Wudu) in both Hadiths is in its Shari'ah meaning, i.e., ablution for prayer, and not in the sense of merely washing hands. Based on this, the claim is more specific than the evidence. And this is assuming the Hadith of Salman and the upcoming Hadith of Anas are authentic.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Indeed, I was commanded to perform ablution only when I stand for prayer." 1306 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Whoever loves that Allah increases the goodness of his house, let him perform Wudu (wash hands) when his lunch is presented and when it is removed." Narrated by Ibn Majah and Al-Bayhaqi. The intended meaning of Wudu is washing the hands. 1307 - (3) [Fabricated] And from him [meaning Abu Hurairah] who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, Satan is sensitive (1) and licking, so beware of him regarding yourselves........." (*). Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim; both from Ya'qub bin Al-Walid Al-Madani from Ibn Abi Dhi'b from Al-Maqburi from him. At-Tirmidhi said: "A Strange (Gharib) Hadith from this perspective, and it has been narrated from the Hadith of Suhail bin Abi Salih from his father from Abu Hurairah." End quote. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic (Sahih) Isnad." (Al-Hafiz said): "Ya'qub bin Al-Walid Al-Azdi is considered a liar and accused; he is not to be used as proof. However, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Baghawi, and others narrated it from the Hadith of Zuhair bin Mu'awiyah from Suhail bin Abi Salih from Abu Hurairah as At-Tirmidhi indicated. Al-Baghawi said in 'Sharh As-Sunnah': 'A Hasan Hadith.' It is as he (may Allah have mercy on him) said; for Suhail bin Abi Salih - although there is some discussion about him - Muslim narrated from him in the 'Sahih' as proof and support, and Al-Bukhari narrated from him in conjunction with others. As-Sulami said: 'I asked Ad-Daraqutni: Why did Al-Bukhari leave Suhail out of the 'Sahih'? He said: I do not know
foot_note: 1. With an undotted Ha', not with a Jim; meaning: severe in sensing and perception. (Lahhas) means: frequently licking what he reaches, emphasized for exaggeration. As stated in "Al-Ujalah". (*) The compiler of the book for Ash-Shamila said: The portion the Sheikh removed from here belonging to the Weak category is «Whoever sleeps while there is the smell of grease (Ghamar) on his hand and something befalls him, let him blame no one but himself», and the Sheikh removed it from here but did not place it in the Sahih (and Sheikh Mashhoor noted this in the margin of his edition), even though the same wording is in the Sahih from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) under number (2168), and Sheikh Al-Albani said about it: Sahih.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: any excuse for him in that.' In summary, the discussion regarding him is lengthy. Shu'bah and Malik narrated from him, and the majority considered him trustworthy, so it is a Hasan Hadith. And Allah knows best (1)." 1308 - (4) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from Abu Sa'id (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Whoever sleeps while there is the smell of grease (Ghamar) on his hand and Waddah befalls him, let him blame no one but himself." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan Isnad (2). (Al-Ghamar) with a Fathah on the Ghain and Mim followed by a Ra': is the smell of meat and its greasiness. (3) (Al-Waddah) with a Fathah on the Waw and the Dad followed by an undotted Ha'. The intended meaning here is leprosy.
foot_note:
1. I say: The author only intended by this rectification the second half of the Hadith indicated by the dots, not the first half of it; for that is Fabricated (Mawdu') as stated by Adh-Dhahabi. Ya'qub Al-Madani was the sole narrator of it, and Al-Bayhaqi did not narrate it in the Hadith of Zuhair bin Mu'awiyah which the author referred to. He narrated it in "Ash-Shu'ab" (2/182/1) and in "As-Sunan" (7/276), and likewise Ahmad narrated it (2/263), and it is in the "Sahih", so be aware. 
2. I say: Not at all, for - even though it contains a weak narrator - Abdullah bin Salih was alone in saying: "Waddah", and he has weakness. The preserved wording is: "Something" (Shay'). See "As-Sahihah" (2956). 
3. This line is earlier in the original than this position, but we established it here for the necessity of explanation.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 20 - Book of Judgement and Others. 1 - (Intimidation against assuming Sultanah (1), judgeship, and emirate, especially for one who does not trust himself, and intimidation for one who trusts himself against asking for any of that). 1309 - (1) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Wahb: That Uthman bin Affan (may Allah be pleased with him) said to Ibn Umar: Go and be a judge. He said: Will you excuse me, O Commander of the Faithful! He said: Go and judge between the people. He said: Excuse me, O Commander of the Faithful! He said: I command you to go and judge between the people. He said: Do not be hasty. Did you not hear the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Whoever seeks refuge in Allah, has sought refuge in a Refuge"? He said: Yes. He said: Then indeed I seek refuge in Allah from being a judge. He said: What prevents you when your father used to judge? He said: Because I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Whoever is a judge and judges with ignorance is among the people of the Fire. And whoever is a judge and judges with injustice is among the people of the Fire. And whoever is a judge and judges with truth or with justice, asks to turn away from it barely [breaking even]." So what can I hope from it after that? Narrated by Abu Ya'la and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and At-Tirmidhi in summary from them, and he said in it: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say:
foot_note: 1. Thus in the original, and thus in An-Naji's citation of it. It is a generated word in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Waseet", and the intended meaning is (Sultah - Authority) as is clear.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever is a judge and judges with justice, it is fitting that he turns away from it barely [breaking even] (1)." So what can I hope for after that? And he did not mention the other two. He said: "A Strange (Gharib) Hadith, and its Isnad is not connected in my view." It is as he said, for Abdullah bin Wahb did not hear from Uthman (may Allah be pleased with him) (2). 1310 - (2) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "There will surely come upon the just judge on the Day of Resurrection an hour in which he wishes that he had never judged between two people regarding a date (Tamrah) ever." Narrated by Ahmad, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and his wording is: She said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "The just judge will be called on the Day of Resurrection, and he will encounter such severity of account that he will wish he had never judged between two people in his life (Umurihi) ever." (Al-Hafiz said): "Thus in my original copy of 'Al-Musnad' and 'As-Sahih' (3): 'Tamrah' (date) and 'Umurihi' (his life), and they are close in script; perhaps one of them is a misspelling (4). And Allah knows best."
foot_note:
1. Meaning: He returns restrained from it (neither gaining reward nor sin). 
2. I say: Also, the narrator from him (Abdul-Malik bin Abi Jamilah) is unknown (Majhul) from the followers of the Tabi'in. The commentator on "Musnad Abu Ya'la" imagined that he is a trustworthy Tabi'i who heard from Ibn Umar, in a confusion of his and an attempt to validate his Isnad as I clarified in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6864). 
3. On the margin of the manuscript: "The Alif and Lam are for specificity, and the intended is 'Sahih Ibn Hibban', so the ambiguity is removed." 
4. I say: I have no doubt that the word (Umurihi) is a mistake, due to Ibn Hibban's narration being unique in it unlike the narration of all the preserving Imams who narrated it, including At-Tayalisi, Al-Bayhaqi, and others. And in its Isnad there is anonymity (Jahalah). I have documented it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1142).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1311 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Wa'il Shaqiq bin Salamah: That Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) employed Bishr bin Asim (may Allah be pleased with him) over the alms of Hawazin. Bishr held back, so Umar met him and said: What held you back? Do we not have hearing and obedience? He said: Yes, but I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Whoever is given authority over anything of the affairs of the Muslims; he will be brought on the Day of Resurrection until he is stopped on the bridge of Hell. If he was benevolent, he is saved. And if he was an evildoer, the bridge will break with him and he will fall into it for seventy autumns (years)." He said: So Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) went out dejected and sorrowful. Abu Dharr met him and said: Why do I see you dejected and sad? He said: Why should I not be dejected and sad when I have heard Bishr bin Asim say: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Whoever is given authority over anything of the affairs of the Muslims; he will be brought on the Day of Resurrection until he is stopped on the bridge of Hell. If he was benevolent, he is saved. And if he was an evildoer, the bridge will break with him and he will fall into it for seventy autumns"?! Abu Dharr said: And did you not hear it from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)? He said: No. He said: I bear witness that I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Whoever is given authority over anything of the affairs of the Muslims; he will be brought on the Day of Resurrection until he is stopped on the bridge of Hell. If he was benevolent, he is saved. And if he was an evildoer, the bridge will break with him and he will fall into it for seventy autumns, and it is black and dark." So which of the two Hadiths is more painful to your heart? He said: Both of them have pained my heart, so who will take it [authority] with what is in it? Abu Dharr said: He whose nose Allah has cut off (humbled) and whose cheek He has stuck to the ground. As for us, we know nothing but good, and perhaps if you assign it to someone who does not act justly in it, you will not escape its sin. Narrated by At-Tabarani. And similar Hadiths will come in the next chapter, if Allah the Almighty wills.
foot_note: None

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Salata anfahu) with a Fathah on the un-dotted Sin and Lam followed by a Taa with two dots above; meaning: He severed it. 1312 - (4) [Weak] And from Abdullah - meaning Ibn Mas'ud - (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There is no judge who judges between people except that he comes on the Day of Resurrection with an angel holding the back of his neck, then he raises his head to the sky. If He says: Throw him, he throws him into an abyss for forty autumns." Narrated by Ibn Majah and the wording is his, and Al-Bazzar, and its wording will come in the chapter after it, Allah willing. And in their Isnad is Mujalid bin Sa'id (1). 1313 - (5) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: Hamzah bin Abdul-Muttalib (may Allah be pleased with him) came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah! Appoint me over something by which I can live. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O Hamzah! Is a soul that you revive more beloved to you, or a soul that you cause to die?" He said: A soul that I revive. He said: "Stick to yourself." Narrated by Ahmad, and its narrators are trustworthy; except Ibn Lahi'ah. 1314 - (6) [Weak] And from Al-Miqdam bin Ma'dikarib (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) struck his shoulders and then said: "You have succeeded, O Qudaym! If you die without having been a commander, nor a scribe, nor a 'Arif (monitor/policeman)."
foot_note: 1. I say: Ahmad also narrated it (1/430), and from his path At-Tabarani (10/19/10313), and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Al-Ahwal" (249/242). Despite the commentator weakening its Isnad, he followed it by saying: "And the Hadith is Sahih"! Without explaining the aspect of its authentication! Although it is Mawquf (stopped at the Companion) according to him. Likewise, Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated it (12/216/12591).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Abu Dawood, [Past 8 - Charities /3], and there is some talk regarding Salih bin Yahya bin Al-Miqdam that is not severe enough to discredit (1). 1315 - (7) [Weak] And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Whoever seeks judgeship and asks for intercessors for it; is entrusted to himself. And whoever is forced into it; Allah sends down an angel to guide him." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and he said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith" (2). And Ibn Majah, and his wording - which is a narration of At-Tirmidhi (3) -: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever asks for judgeship; is entrusted to himself. And whoever is forced into it; an angel descends upon him and guides him."
foot_note:
1. I say: This is a strange leniency, for the one who spoke against him is Imam Al-Bukhari, and no one authenticated him except Ibn Hibban, and his authentication is not relied upon when he is alone, so how about when contradicting an Imam like this! The others considered him unknown and did not authenticate him. Furthermore, there is a trace of interruption in it according to Ibn Hibban himself. I have clarified all of that in the documentation of this Hadith and another Hadith of his in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1133 and 1149). 
2. I say: Rather, it is Weak; there is confusion (Idtirab) in its Isnad from one of its weakened narrators. The explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1154). 
3. Original: (At-Tirmidhi), which is an apparent mistake that the three [commentators] missed! Its wording is like that of Ibn Majah, which differs from what is here. The wording here is: "An angel descended to him and guides him." And At-Tirmidhi's wording is: "Allah sends down an angel to him to guide him."

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2 - (Encouragement for one who is given authority over any of the Muslims' affairs to be just, whether he is an Imam or otherwise, and intimidation against causing hardship to his subjects, being unjust, cheating them, hiding from them, or closing his door to their needs). 1316 - (1) [Weak] And from him [meaning Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him] who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Three whose supplication is not rejected: The fasting person until he breaks his fast, the just Imam, and the supplication of the oppressed; Allah raises it above the clouds, and the gates of the sky are opened for it; and the Lord says: By My Might, I will surely help you even if after a while." Narrated by Ahmad in a Hadith, and At-Tirmidhi who classified it Hasan, and Ibn Majah, and Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs". [Past 5 - Prayer /10]. 1317 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "A day of a just Imam is better than the worship of sixty years..." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat", and the Isnad of "Al-Kabir" is Hasan (1). 1318 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O Abu Hurairah! Justice for an hour is better than the worship of sixty years, standing its nights and fasting its days. And O Abu Hurairah! Injustice for an hour in a ruling is more severe and greater with Allah Almighty than the sins of sixty years."
foot_note: 1. I say: There is objection to this from several aspects I mentioned in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1595). The summary is that the Hadith is defective due to anonymity and confusion in both Isnad and text. The Hadith has a continuation in the original which I removed because it has witnessing reports, some of which I documented in "As-Sahihah" (231) and some will come in "As-Sahih" (21 - Hudud /5).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: [Weak] And in a narration: "The justice of one day is better than the worship of sixty years." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. 1319 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The most beloved of people to Allah on the Day of Resurrection and the closest of them to Him in seat is a just Imam. And the most hated of people to Allah Almighty and the furthest of them from Him in seat is an unjust Imam." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" briefly; except that he (1) said: "The most severely punished of people on the Day of Resurrection is an unjust Imam." At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith" (2). 1320 - (5) [Very Weak] And from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The best of people in status with Allah on the Day of Resurrection is a gentle, just Imam. And the worst of Allah's servants in status with Allah on the Day of Resurrection is a clumsy (Khariq), unjust Imam (3)." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" from the narration of Ibn Lahi'ah, and his Hadith is Hasan in corroborations (4).
foot_note:
1. Perhaps it is better to say: "With the wording", because it implies restricting At-Tabarani's narration to it unlike the others. Reflect. 
2. Thus he said! And Atiyyah is weak and a mudallis (concealer). At-Tabarani narrated it with a very weak chain from Ibn Mas'ud. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (8159). 
3. With movement: Source of (Al-Akhraq), and Khariqa with a Fathah means Kharaqa, and the noun is (Kharaq) with a Dammah and Sukun. An-Naji said it. It means ignorance and stupidity. 
4. Thus he said! And Al-Haythami followed him, and the three commentators imitated them. It also contains Ahmad bin Rushdin; Ibn Adi said: "They accused him of lying." It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1157).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1321 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The unjust Imam will be brought on the Day of Resurrection, and the subjects will dispute with him, and they will defeat him in argument (Yafluju), so it will be said to him: Fill a corner of the corners of Hell." Narrated by Al-Bazzar. This Hadith is among what was denounced of Aghlab bin Tamim. (Fayafluju) against him with a Jim; meaning: they triumph over him with proof and evidence during the dispute. 1322 - (7) [Very Weak] And from Talhah bin Ubaidullah (may Allah be pleased with him); that he heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saying: "O people! Allah does not accept the prayer of an unjust Imam." Narrated by Al-Hakim from the narration of Abdullah bin Muhammad Al-Adawi and he said: "Authentic Isnad." (Al-Hafiz said): "This Abdullah is flimsy and accused, and this Hadith is among what is denounced of him." 1323 - (8) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Three from whom Allah does not accept the testimony of 'There is no god but Allah'; - and he mentioned among them - the unjust Imam." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1324 - (9) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "The Sultan is the shadow of Allah on Earth, every oppressed person from His servants seeks shelter in him. If he is just, he has the reward, and the subjects must show gratitude. If he is tyrannical, unjust, or oppressive, the burden is upon him, and the subjects must show patience. If the rulers are unjust, the sky withholds rain. If Zakat is withheld, the livestock perish. If adultery appears, poverty and misery appear. If the dhimmah (covenant) is betrayed, the disbelievers prevail. Or a similar statement."
foot_note: None

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ibn Majah, and its wording was presented previously [in "As-Sahih" 16 - Sales /9], and Al-Bazzar and the wording is his. (1) 1325 - (10) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever seeks the judgeship of Muslims until he attains it, then his justice overcomes his injustice; he gets Paradise. And if his injustice overcomes his justice; he gets the Fire." Narrated by Abu Dawood (2). 1326 - (11) [Weak] And from Abdullah - meaning Ibn Mas'ud - (may Allah be pleased with him) attributing it to the Prophet, said: "The judge will be brought on the Day of Resurrection and stopped at the brink of Hell. If he is commanded to be pushed; he will fall into it for seventy autumns." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and Al-Bazzar and the wording is his; both from the narration of Mujalid from Amir from Masruq from him, and the wording of Ibn Majah preceded in the chapter before it [Hadith 4]. 1327 - (12) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that Bishr bin Asim Al-Jushami (may Allah be pleased with him) told Umar (may Allah be pleased with him); that he heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "No one takes charge of anything of the people's affairs except that Allah stops him on the bridge of Hell, and the bridge shakes with him violently. He is either saved or not saved. No bone of his remains except that it separates from its companion. If he is not saved; he is taken into a dark pit like a grave in Hell, he does not reach its bottom for seventy autumns." And that Umar asked Salman and Abu Dharr: Did you hear that from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)? They said: Yes.
foot_note:

Whatever is given to reach a right or repel oppression; is not included in it, and Allah knows best.

He said: "They were all lessons: I wonder at one who is certain of death then he rejoices. I wonder at one who is certain of the Fire then he laughs. And I wonder at one who is certain of the Account tomorrow then he does not work." .......... I said: O Messenger of Allah! Increase me. He said: "Stick to long silence; for it is a repeller of Satan, and a help to you in the matter of your religion." .......... I said: O Messenger of Allah! Increase me. He said: "Let what you know of yourself hold you back from people, and do not find against them in what you do [yourself], and it is enough of a fault in you that you know from people what you are ignorant of in yourself, and you find against them in what you do [yourself]." text: 8 - (Intimidation against helping the falsifier and assisting him, and intercession that prevents a Hadd punishment from the limits of Allah, and other matters). 1359 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Ad-Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Any man whose intercession prevents a Hadd from the limits of Allah; he remains in the anger (Ghadab) of Allah (1) until he ceases. And any man who strives angrily for a Muslim in a dispute of which he has no knowledge; he has opposed Allah's right, and been eager for His wrath, and upon him is the curse of Allah continuously until the Day of Resurrection. And any man who spreads a word about a Muslim man (2) while he is innocent of it, shaming him with it in the world; it is a right upon Allah to melt him on the Day of Resurrection in the Fire, until he brings a way out (Nafadh) for what he said." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and the status of its Isnad is not present with me right now. And he narrated part of it with a Jayyid (Good) Isnad (3) saying: "Whoever mentions something about a person that is not in him to shame him; Allah imprisons him in the fire of Hell, until he brings a way out for what he said about him."
foot_note:
1. An-Naji said: "Rather the wording is: 'In the wrath (Sakhat) of Allah'. He narrated it in (Al-Kabir)." 
2. Meaning: He manifested upon him what shames him. It is said: The talk spread (Sha'a) and he spread it (Asha'ahu): if it appeared and he made it appear. And (An-Nafadh) with movement: The exit and escape. The meaning: He is punished until he brings a way out of it. 
3. I say: How can that be when it has three defects which I revealed in "Ghayat Al-Maram fi Takhrij Al-Halal wa Al-Haram" (250/437)?! The three [commentators] also blundered in it saying (3/142): "Hasan with its witnesses"! Only part of it has some witnesses, which are in "As-Sahih". What confirms their confusion and that they speak without thinking or knowledge is simply improvisation however it happens; is that they weakened it in another place (3/499), and the author repeated it in (23 - Manners /19), and their documentation in both places is one, and they will be questioned.

text: 1360 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever's intercession prevents a Hadd from the limits of Allah; has opposed Allah in His dominion. And whoever helps in a dispute not knowing if it is true or false; he is in the wrath of Allah until he ceases. And whoever walks with a people seen as a witness, while he is not a witness; he is like a false witness. And whoever claims a dream falsely; is tasked to tie a knot between two barley seeds. And abusing a Muslim is wickedness (Fusuq), and fighting him is disbelief (Kufr)." Narrated by At-Tabarani from the narration of Raja' (1) bin Sabih As-Saqati. 1361 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever helps an oppressor with falsehood to refute (Yudhida) (2) a truth with it; has become free of the Dhimmah (protection) of Allah and the Dhimmah of His Messenger." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Asbahani. 1362 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Aws bin Shurahbil, one of Bani Ashja'; that he heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Whoever walks with an oppressor to help him while knowing that he is an oppressor; has exited from Islam." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir", and it is a Strange (Gharib) Hadith.
foot_note:
1. His Kunya is Abu Yahya. It appeared in "Shu'ab Al-Iman" (2/452/1-2) as: "Raja' bin Yahya", which is a mistake from the copyist. He is weak. The Hadith is documented in "Al-Irwa" (7/350-351), and some of its sentences are authentic. 
2. Meaning: To invalidate a truth by it.

text: 9 - (Intimidation for the ruler and others against pleasing people with what angers Allah Almighty). 1363 - (1) And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever angers Allah to please people; Allah becomes angry with him, and He makes whoever he pleased with His anger angry with him. And whoever pleases Allah with the anger of people, Allah becomes pleased with him, and He makes whoever he angered with His pleasure pleased with him; until He beautifies him and beautifies his speech and action in his eye." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a strong Jayyid Isnad (1). 1364 - (2) [Fabricated] And from Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever pleases a sultan with what angers his Lord; has exited from the religion of Allah." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Allaq bin Abi Muslim was alone in narrating it from Jabir, and the narrators up to him are all trustworthy" (2). 1365 - (3) [Munkar] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever seeks the praise of people through disobedience to Allah; his praiser turns into a blamer." Narrated by Al-Bazzar (3). And in a narration by Al-Bayhaqi: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever desires the anger of Allah and the pleasure of people; his praiser among the people turns into a blamer" (4).
foot_note:
1. Thus he said. It contains Jabrun bin Isa, At-Tabarani's Sheikh, whom no one authenticated. And his Sheikh (Yahya bin Sulayman Al-Jufri) has some discussion about him. Refer to "As-Sahihah" number (2311) for it, and refer to "Ad-Da'ifah" (6650) for their biography. 
2. I say: This is a tremendous illusion which Al-Hakim and the author followed, then Adh-Dhahabi. For the narrator from Allaq is actually Anbasah bin Abdur-Rahman, and he is accused of fabrication. Therefore, I documented the Hadith in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5197). And the three commentators missed this defect as is their habit. 
3. and 
4. I say: In both narrations is (Qutbah bin Al-Ala Al-Ghanawi) who has weakness. Al-Uqayli said: "He is not to be followed." So it is Munkar due to contradicting the preserved wording, which is in "As-Sahih". It is documented in "As-Sahihah" (2311) =

text: 1366 - (4) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from 'Ismah bin Malik (1) who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever makes himself beloved to people by what they love (2) and confronts Allah the Exalted [with disobedience]; meets Allah the Exalted on the Day of Resurrection while He is angry with him." Narrated by At-Tabarani (3).
foot_note:
1. = from the narration of Ibn Hibban and others. It is from the blunders and confusion of the Three Ignorant Ones that they prefaced their extraction of the hadith with its three narrations by saying: "Hasan...". Then he extracted it from the weak narration of Al-Bazzar and Al-Bayhaqi, and the authentic narration of Ibn Hibban! And from their ignorance is that they quoted Al-Haythami weakening Qutbah and his father, so how could they say: "Hasan"?! (Haphazard mixing)!! 
1. In the original: "Abdullah bin 'Ismah bin Malik", and likewise in the manuscript; except that it has: "Fatik" instead of "Malik", and likewise in "Majma' Az-Zawa'id". When I searched for this name in the books of Rijal that I have, I did not find any mention of him, neither among the Companions nor others. Then it became likely to me what I established above that it is 'Ismah bin Malik, who is Al-Khatmi, for he is mentioned among the Companions, and that is in a research I placed in "Silsilat Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah" No. (2645 and 6654). 
2. Original: (Yuhibbuhu) with the deletion of Nun. And likewise in "The Manuscript" and "Al-Jami' Al-Kabir", and it occurred in "Al-Majma'" (Yuhibbunahu) with the confirmation of Nun according to the rule. 
3. Meaning in "Al-Kabir", and he explicitly stated that in "Al-Jami' Al-Kabir", but Al-Haythami restricted it to "Al-Awsat", and perhaps the first is more likely as I explained in the previous source. The hadith has passed similarly from Abu Huraira in (1 - Sincerity / 2) attributed to "Al-Awsat" as well.

text: 10 - (Encouragement to show compassion to Allah's creation from subjects, children, slaves, and others, and to have mercy on them and be kind to them. And warning against the opposite of that, and against torturing the slave and the animal and others without a legal reason, and what came regarding the prohibition of branding animals on their faces). 1367 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "He is not of us who does not respect the elder, and have mercy on the younger, and command the good, and forbid the evil." Narrated by Ahmad, At-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" [Passed in 3 - Knowledge / 5]. This wording has been narrated from the hadith of a group of Companions (1), and some of that has passed in "Honoring Scholars". 1368 - (2) [Weak] And from Nasih Al-Ansi from Rakb Al-Masri who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Blessed is he who humbled himself without deficiency, and abased himself without begging, and spent wealth he gathered without disobedience, and had mercy on the people of humiliation and poverty, and mixed with the people of Fiqh and wisdom" The Hadith. Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its narrators up to Nasih are trustworthy (2).
foot_note:
1. There is an illusion in it contrary to reality, because the group does not have in their hadith the sentence: "and command the good, and forbid the evil". Were it not for that, I would have included the hadith with their hadiths in "As-Sahih", so refer to them there. 
2. I say: And what does that avail, when (Nasih) is not a Companion, nor is he known, and Al-Bukhari when he mentioned him in "At-Tarikh" (4/ 2/ 136/ 2472) did not add to his saying: "Mut'im bin Al-Miqdam narrated from him" meaning the narrator from him here. Rather, (Rakb Al-Masri) companionship is not proven, therefore Ibn Hibban said in "Ath-Thiqat" (3/ 130): "It is said: That he has companionship, but his chain is not something to rely upon," indicating this. It is extracted at length in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3835), and it will come in full in (23 - Manners / 22), and part of it passed in (16 - Sales / 5).

text: We said: O Messenger of Allah! What does this camel say? He said: "This is a camel whose owners intended to slaughter it and eat its meat, so it fled from them, and sought help from your Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace." While we were like that, his owners came running. When the camel saw them, it returned to the head of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and took shelter with it! They said: O Messenger of Allah! This is our camel, it fled three days ago, and we did not find it except before you. He, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "But it is complaining to me, and what a miserable complaint." They said: O Messenger of Allah! What does it say? He said: "It says that it grew up in your safety for years, and you used to carry on it in the summer to the place of pasture, and when winter came you traveled to the place of warmth. When it grew old you used it for breeding, so Allah provided you from it with grazing camels. When this fertile year (1) reached it, you intended to slaughter it and eat its meat." They said: By Allah, that was so, O Messenger of Allah! He, upon him be peace, said: "Is this the reward of the righteous slave from his masters." They said: O Messenger of Allah! Then we will not sell it nor slaughter it. He, upon him be peace, said: "You have lied. It sought help from you and you did not help it, and I am more worthy of mercy than you. Indeed Allah has removed mercy from the hearts of the hypocrites, and placed it in the hearts of the believers." So he, upon him be peace, bought it from them for a hundred dirhams and said: "O Camel, go, for you are free for the sake of Allah Exalted." It grumbled (ragha) at the head of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so he, upon him be peace, said:
foot_note: 1. An-Naji said: "Thus it occurred, but it is: The barren year (Al-Jadbah)."

text: (Amen). Then it grumbled, and he said: (Amen). Then it grumbled, and he said: (Amen). Then it grumbled the fourth time, and he, upon him be peace, wept. We said: O Messenger of Allah! What does this camel say? He said: "It said: May Allah reward you, O Prophet, on behalf of Islam and the Quran with good, so I said: (Amen). Then it said: May Allah calm the fear of your Ummah on the Day of Resurrection as you calmed my fear, so I said: (Amen). Then it said: May Allah spare the blood of your Ummah from its enemies as you spared my blood, so I said: (Amen). Then it said: May Allah not place its might between them (internal conflict), "so I wept. For these characteristics I asked my Lord and He gave them to me, but He prevented me this one, and Gabriel informed me from Allah Exalted that the annihilation of my Ummah is by the sword. The Pen has run with what is to be." 1373 - (7) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, forbade instigating animals against each other." Narrated by Abu Dawood and At-Tirmidhi connected and Mursal from Mujahid, and he said about the Mursal: "It is more authentic."

text: 1374 - (8) [Weak] And from Rafi' bin Mukaith - and he was among those who witnessed Al-Hudaibiyah, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Good treatment (of what one owns) is increase (prosperity), and bad character is ill omen." Narrated by Ahmad and Abu Dawood from some of the sons of Rafi' bin Mukaith, and he did not name him from him. And Abu Dawood also narrated it from Al-Harith bin Rafi' bin Mukaith from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, as Mursal. 1375 - (9) [Weak] And from Abu Bakr As-Siddiq who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "One who treats what he owns badly will not enter Paradise." They said: O Messenger of Allah! Did you not inform us that this Ummah is the most numerous of nations in slaves and orphans? He said: "Yes, so honor them like the honor of your children, and feed them from what you eat." They said: Then what benefits us from the world? He said: "A horse you tie to fight on in the way of Allah, your slave suffices you, so if he prays then he is your brother, [so if he prays then he is your brother]." Narrated by Ahmad, Ibn Majah, and At-Tirmidhi limiting himself to his saying: "One who treats what he owns badly will not enter Paradise," and he said: "A Hasan Gharib hadith, and Ayub As-Sakhtiyani spoke regarding Farqad As-Sabkhi concerning his memory." And Abu Ya'la and Al-Asbahani also narrated it briefly, and he said: "The people of language said: Bad treatment (Sayyi' al-Malakah): If he is bad in dealing with his slaves."
foot_note: None

text: 1376 - (10) [Weak] And from Zaid bin Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said in the Farewell Pilgrimage: "Your slaves, your slaves, feed them from what you eat, and clothe them from what you wear, and if they commit a sin you do not want to forgive, then sell the servants of Allah and do not torture them." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. 1378 - (12) [Weak] And from Amr bin Huraith (1), may Allah be pleased with them both; that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whatever you lighten for your servant from his work; will be a reward for you in your scales." Umm Salamah went out to the rooms, and found the servant girl playing with a young animal (bahmah). She said: Do I not see you playing

text: 1388 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed the first deficiency that entered upon the Children of Israel was that a man would meet another man and say: O you, fear Allah and leave what you are doing; for it is not lawful for you. Then he meets him the next day while he is in his condition; so [that] does not prevent him from being his eating companion, his drinking companion, and his sitting companion. When they did that, Allah struck their hearts one against another, then said: {Cursed were those who disbelieved among the Children of Israel by the tongue of David and of Jesus, the son of Mary. That was because they disobeyed and [habitually] transgressed. They used not to prevent one another from wrongdoing that they did. How wretched was that which they were doing. You see many of them becoming allies of those who disbelieved. How wretched is that which they have put forth for themselves} to His saying: {defiantly disobedient} [Al-Ma'idah: 78-81]. Then he said: Nay; by Allah you must enjoin the good, and forbid the evil, and take the hand of the oppressor, and bend him to the truth a bending." Narrated by Abu Dawood and the wording is his, and At-Tirmidhi who said: "A Hasan Gharib hadith" (1), and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "When the Children of Israel fell into sins; their scholars forbade them; but they did not desist. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, sat up while he was reclining; and said: "No, by the One in Whose Hand is my soul, until you bend them to the truth a bending." text: A man from Quraysh broke the tooth of a man from the Ansar. So he sought Muawiyah's help against him. He said to Muawiyah: O Commander of the Faithful! This man broke my tooth. Muawiyah said to him: We will satisfy you from him. But the other man persisted with Muawiyah until he annoyed him (1). Muawiyah said: Deal with your companion. Abu Darda was sitting with him, so Abu Darda said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "There is no man who suffers an injury in his body and gives it as charity; except that Allah raises him a degree by it, and removes a sin from him by it." The Ansari said: Did you hear it from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him? He said: My ears heard it, and my heart retained it. He said: Then I leave it for him. Muawiyah said to him: No doubt, I will not disappoint you. So he ordered wealth for him. Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "Strange (Gharib) Hadith, and I do not know of a hearing for Abu As-Safar from Abu Darda." And Ibn Majah narrated the raised (Marfu') part of it from Abu As-Safar also from Abu Darda, and its chain is Hasan were it not for the interruption. 1463 - (5) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated [meaning the Hadith of Abdur-Rahman bin Awf which is in the "Sahih"] in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat" from the Hadith of Umm Salamah, and he said in it: "And no man forgave an injustice; except that Allah increased him in honor by it, so forgive and Allah will honor you." 1464 - (6) [Weak] And from Ubayy bin Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever is pleased that the building be raised for him, and the degrees be elevated for him; let him forgive whoever wronged him, give to whoever deprived him, and connect with whoever cut him off." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he authenticated its chain, but there is an interruption in it (2).
foot_note:

Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat", and their chain is Jayyid (good), Maimun bin Najih was authenticated by Ibn Hibban (2), and the rest of its narrators are famous trustworthy ones.

So whoever desires an image of a man or a woman enters into it" (1).
