Narrated by Al-Hakim and Al-Asbahani; both from the path of Bakkar bin Abdul-Aziz, and Al-Hakim said: "Authentic chain of narration" (2). 1487 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Abi Awfa, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when a comer came to him and said: A young man is dying. It was said to him: Say: La ilaha illa Allah, but he was unable to. He said: "Did he used to pray?" He said: Yes. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, rose and we rose with him. He entered upon the young man and said to him: "Say: La ilaha illa Allah." He said: I am unable. He said: "Why?" He said: He used to disobey his mother. So the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said:
foot_note:
1. Its beginning preceded in (18 - Clothing /2), and another part in (21 - Limits /7), and it is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5369). 
2. I say: Adh-Dhahabi rejected it by saying: "I say: Bakkar is weak." It is referenced in "Ghayat Al-Maram" (170/ 279).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Is his mother alive?" They said: Yes. He said: "Call her." So they called her. She came, and he said: "Is this your son?" She said: Yes. He said to her: "Do you see if a huge fire was kindled, and it was said to you: If you intercede for him we will let him go, otherwise we will burn him with this fire; would you intercede for him?" She said: O Messenger of Allah! In that case I would intercede. He said: "Then make Allah witness and make me witness that you are pleased with him." She said: O Allah, indeed I make You witness and I make Your Messenger witness that I am pleased with my son. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to him: "O young man! Say: La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu la sharika lah (There is no god but Allah alone, He has no partner), and I bear witness that Muhammad is His slave and Messenger." So he said it. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Praise be to Allah who saved him through me from the Fire." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and Ahmad briefly (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: Attributing it to Ahmad has a view (issue), even if Al-Haythami followed him as is his habit, and the three commentators imitated them, because Abdullah bin Ahmad, when he cited the first part of it in "Musnad of his father", said: "Then he mentioned the Hadith at length, and it was in the 'Book of my father' but he did not narrate it to us, and he struck it from 'his book'; because he was not pleased with the Hadith of Fa'id bin Abdur-Rahman, and he was abandoned in Hadith according to him." It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3183). However, his saying: (Praise be to Allah who saved him through me from the Fire) has been authentically reported from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in another story with Al-Bukhari and others from the Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him. It is referenced in "Ahkam Al-Jana'iz" (p. 21 - Al-Ma'arif).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - (Encouragement to connect ties of kinship even if cut, and intimidation regarding cutting them). 1488 - (1) [Weak] And from Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Whoever is pleased that his lifespan be extended, and his provision be expanded, and an evil death be warded off from him; let him fear Allah, and let him connect his ties of kinship." Narrated by Abdullah son of Imam Ahmad in his "Zawa'id", and Al-Bazzar with a Jayyid (good) chain, and Al-Hakim (1). 1489 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; that he said: "It is written in the Torah: Whoever loves that his lifespan be increased, and his provision be increased; let him connect his ties of kinship." Narrated by Al-Bazzar with a chain that has no harm, and Al-Hakim who authenticated it (2). 1490 - (3) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, hearing him say: "Indeed charity and connecting ties of kinship; Allah increases lifespan by them, wards off an evil death by them, and wards off by them the disliked and the feared." Narrated by Abu Ya'la.
foot_note:
1. I say: I do not know why he delayed Al-Hakim after Al-Bazzar, while his chain is the chain of (Abdullah), and in it is Abu Ishaq As-Sabi'i and he had mixed up along with Tadlis, and the path of Al-Bazzar, even though it has other defects, does not contain "and wards off an evil death". The Hadith without it is authentic due to its witnesses mentioned in the "Sahih" before it, and I referenced it for their sake in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5372). The three were ignorant so they said: "Hasan, narrated by Abdullah..."! 
2. I say: In it is Sa'id bin Bashir, and he is weak regarding his memory. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4526). The three claimed it is "Hasan due to its witnesses"! But there is no witness for the sentence of the Torah! And due to their ignorance of extraction, they did not mention Al-Bazzar's number, because his wording is: "In the Torah it is written..."!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1491 - (4) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah populates homes with people, and increases wealth for them, and He has not looked at them since He created them with hatred towards them." It was said: And how is that, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "By their connection of their ties of kinship." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan chain, and Al-Hakim who said: "Imran bin Musa Ar-Ramli the ascetic was alone in narrating it from Abu Khalid, so if his memory was preserved then it is authentic" (1). 1492 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Durrah bint Abi Lahab, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! Who are the best of people? He said: "The most pious of them to the Lord, the most connecting of them to kinship, the most enjoining of them to good, and the most forbidding of them from evil." Narrated by Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan in "Kitab Ath-Thawab", and Al-Bayhaqi in "Kitab Az-Zuhd" and others. [Passed 21 - Limits /1]. 1493 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Thawban, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Three hang from the Throne: The Womb (kinship) says: O Allah, I am by You so I should not be cut. The Trust (Amanah) says: O Allah, I am by You so I should not be betrayed. And the Blessing says: O Allah, I am by You so I should not be denied." Narrated by Al-Bazzar.
foot_note: 1. I say: And Adh-Dhahabi said likewise in his "Talkhis", and they refer to his bad memory which more than one pointed out, among them Ibn Hibban by his saying: "He makes mistakes and contradicts," and for that reason I referenced it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2425).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1494 - (7) [Weak] And from Hudhayfah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Do not be an 'Imma'ah' (blind follower); saying: If the people do good we do good, and if they oppress we oppress. But discipline yourselves; if the people do good that you do good, and if they do evil that you do not oppress." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "Hasan Hadith" (1). His saying: (Imma'ah) is with a Kasra on the Hamza and Tashdid on the Mim and Fatha on it, and with the neglected Ayn. Abu Ubaid said: "(Al-Imma'ah): Is the one who has no opinion of his own, so he follows everyone in his opinion." 1495 - (8) [Very Weak] And from Abu Hurairah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Three things, whoever has them in him, Allah will account him with an easy accounting, and admit him into Paradise by His mercy." They said: And what are they, O Messenger of Allah! May my father and mother be sacrificed for you? He said: "You give to who deprived you, you connect with who cut you off, and you forgive who wronged you. If you do that; Allah enters you into Paradise." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani, and Al-Hakim who said: "Authentic chain of narration." (Al-Hafiz said): "And in their chains is Sulaiman bin Dawud Al-Yamami, who is feeble." [Passed 21 - Limits /12]. 1496 - (9) [Weak] And from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Shall I guide you to the most noble character of this world and the Hereafter? That you connect with who cut you off, and give to who deprived you, and forgive who wronged you."
foot_note: 1. Thus is the original, but what is in "As-Sunan" (2008) is: "Hasan Gharib, we do not know it except from this face." Al-Baghawi indicated in "Sharh As-Sunnah" (13/ 32) its weakness, and I explained its aspect in "Naqd Nusus Al-Kattani" (26/ 15).

Narrated by At-Tabarani from the path of Zabban bin Fa'id (1). 1498 - (11) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ubadah bin As-Samit, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Shall I guide you to what Allah raises degrees by?" They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "You show forbearance to him who acts ignorantly towards you, you forgive him who wronged you, you give to him who deprived you, and you connect with him who cut you off." [Passed there]. Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and At-Tabarani; except that he said in its beginning: "Shall I inform you of what Allah honors the building by, and raises degrees by?" then mentioned it (2). 1499 - (12) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The fastest good in reward is righteousness and connecting ties of kinship, and the fastest evil in punishment is oppression and severing ties of kinship." Narrated by Ibn Majah

And he said regarding the other: "... and in it is Abu Umayyah bin Ya'la, and he is weak." I say: His name is (Ismail) and he is Matruk (abandoned). See "Al-Lisan".

text: 1500 - (13) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, raised (to the Prophet) who said: "The Seal is hanging on the leg of the Throne. If the womb (kinship) complains, and sins are committed, and Allah is dared against; Allah sends the Seal so it stamps upon his heart, so he does not understand anything after that." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and the wording is his, and Al-Bayhaqi, and its wording preceded in "Limits" [21/ 4], and Al-Bazzar said: "We do not know anyone who narrated it from At-Taimi - meaning Sulaiman - except Sulaiman bin Muslim, and he is a famous Basran" (1). 1501 - (14) [Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; that he said: "Jibril, peace be upon him, came to me and said: This is the night of the middle of Sha'ban, and Allah has in it those freed from the Fire equal to the number of the hairs of the sheep of Bani Kalb. Allah does not look in it at a polytheist, nor one harboring malice, nor a cutter of kinship ties, nor one who drags his garment, nor one disobedient to his parents, nor an addict of wine." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi in a Hadith that will come in its entirety in "Forsaking" [23 - Manners /11] if Allah wills. [Weak] And previously in it [meaning in "Drinking Wine" 21 - Limits /6] is the Hadith of Abu Umamah: "A people from this Ummah pass the night with food and drink, and amusement and play, so they wake up having been transformed into monkeys and pigs, because of their drinking of wine, their wearing of silk, their taking of singing girls,

text: and their cutting of kinship ties." [Very Weak] And previously in "Clothing" [18/ 2] is the Hadith of Jabir: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came out to us while we were gathered, and said: "O assembly of Muslims! Fear Allah, and connect your ties of kinship; for there is no reward faster than connecting ties of kinship. And beware of oppression; for there is no punishment faster than the punishment of oppression. And beware of disobedience to parents; for the scent of Paradise is found from a distance of a thousand years travel, and by Allah, no disobedient person finds it, nor one who severs kinship ties, nor one who drags his lower garment out of arrogance. Grandeur belongs only to Allah, Lord of the Worlds." 1502 - (15) [Weak Mawquf] And from Al-A'mash who said: Ibn Mas'ud was sitting in a circle after the morning prayer, so he said: I adjure by Allah a cutter of kinship ties to leave us, for we want to supplicate to our Lord, and the gates of heaven are locked (Murtajah) against the cutter of kinship ties. Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its narrators are relied upon in the "Sahih"; except that Al-A'mash did not reach Ibn Mas'ud. (Murtajah) with a Damma on the Mim and Fatha on the Ta with two dots above and lightening of the Jim; meaning: Locked. 1503 - (16) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Abi Awfa, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: We were sitting with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and he said: "No cutter of kinship ties sits with us today." So a young man from the circle rose and went to an aunt of his with whom there was some issue between them. He sought her forgiveness, and she sought his forgiveness, then he returned to the gathering. So the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said:
foot_note: None

And narrated by At-Tabarani briefly; that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: [Fabricated] "The angels do not descend upon a people among whom there is one who severs ties of kinship."

text: 4 - (Encouragement to care for the orphan, be merciful to him, spend on him, and strive for the widow and the poor). 1504 - (1) [Weak] And Al-Bazzar narrated it [meaning the hadith of Abu Huraira in "As-Sahih"] as connected [and Malik narrated it as Mursal], and his wording is: He said: "Whoever cares for an orphan, whether related to him or not related to him; then I and he will be in Paradise like these two - and he joined his two fingers -, and whoever strives for three daughters is in Paradise, and he has the reward of the fighter in the way of Allah, fasting and praying." [Passed in 17 - Marriage / 5]. 1505 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever supports three orphans; is like one who stands the night in prayer, fasts the day, and goes out in the morning and evening brandishing his sword in the way of Allah. And I and he will be in Paradise as two brothers (1); just as these two are sisters. And he joined his index and middle fingers." Narrated by Ibn Majah. 1506 - (3) [Very Weak] And from him also; that the Prophet of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever takes an orphan from among the Muslims to his food and drink; Allah will admit him to Paradise absolutely, unless he commits a sin that is not forgiven." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan Sahih hadith" (2).
foot_note:
1. Original: (ikhwanan - brothers), and the correction is from "Ibn Majah" (2/ 393), and An-Naji, may Allah have mercy on him, pointed it out. 
2. I say: This is a gross error regarding At-Tirmidhi, for he only said this about the hadith of Sahl which preceded in "As-Sahih" at the beginning of the chapter. As for this one, he weakened it by saying: "Hanash - meaning the one in its chain - is weak according to the scholars of Hadith." Al-Hafiz said: "Matruk (abandoned)", and it is in "Ad-Da'ifah" number (5343). It seems the reason is that the author's gaze moved after quoting the hadith of Ibn Abbas from (At-Tirmidhi) to the hadith of Sahl which follows it in his book, so he transferred his comment authenticating it to the hadith of Ibn Abbas!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1507 - (4) [Weak] And from Amr bin Malik Al-Qushayri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "... And whoever joins an orphan from among two Muslim parents to his food and drink [until Allah enriches him]; Paradise is obligatory for him." Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani, and Ahmad's narrators are relied upon; except Ali bin Zaid. 1508 - (5) [Fabricated] And from Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "No orphan sits with a people at their bowl, but that Satan approaches their bowl." A Gharib hadith, narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Asbahani; both from the narration of Al-Hasan bin Wasil. And our Sheikh Al-Hafiz Abu Al-Hasan, may Allah have mercy on him, used to say: "It is a Hasan hadith." And Al-Asbahani also narrated it from the hadith of Abu Musa (1). 1509 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed the most beloved of houses to Allah; is a house in which there is an honored orphan." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Asbahani. 1510 - (7) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "The best house among the Muslims; is a house in which there is an orphan who is treated well. And the worst house among the Muslims is a house in which there is an orphan who is treated badly."
foot_note: 1. And likewise in the manuscript, and it is a repetition whose benefit did not appear to me after the conjunction of Al-Asbahani to At-Tabarani preceded. He narrated it (2/ 1018) from two paths, one from (Al-Hasan bin Wasil), and the other from (Al-Hasan bin Dinar) with one chain from Abu Musa. Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Mughni": "Al-Hasan bin Dinar Abu Sa'id At-Tamimi, and it is said: Ibn Wasil - they abandoned him." So Abu Al-Hasan's classifying it as Hasan is not good. Rather it is fabricated, and Ibn Hibban said: "False with no basis." It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5373).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ibn Majah. 1511 - (8) [Weak] And it was narrated from Auf bin Malik Al-Ashja'i, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "I and a woman with dark (saf'a') cheeks will be like these two on the Day of Resurrection - and Yazid bin Zurai' gestured with his hand indicating the middle and index fingers -; a woman who became widowed (amat) from her husband, possessing rank and beauty, who confined herself to her orphans until they separated or died." Narrated by Abu Dawood. (As-Saf'a') with fatha on the unpointed Sin and sukun on the Fa followed by an unpointed 'Ain elongated. (Al-Hafiz said): "She is the one whose color changed to duskiness and blackness from the length of widowhood (aymah). He means by that she confined herself to her children and did not marry so she would need adornment and beautification for a husband." And (amat) the woman; with elongation on the Hamza and lightening the Mim: If she becomes an ayyim, which is one who has no husband; virgin or non-virgin (thayyib), whether she married or has not married yet. The intended meaning here is one whose husband died leaving her a widow. 1512 - (9) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "I am the first to open the gate of Paradise; except that I see a woman racing me to it; so I say to her: What is the matter with you! And who are you? She says: I am a woman who sat with orphans of mine." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and its chain is Hasan (1) if Allah wills. 1513 - (10) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever wipes the head of an orphan, not wiping it except for Allah; for every hair his hand passes
foot_note: 1. I say: It contains one who was not declared trustworthy except by Ibn Hibban, along with his saying: "He errs and contradicts," and Abu Hatim's saying about him: "Shaikh"; meaning not a proof as Adh-Dhahabi said. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5374).

text: over he will have good deeds. And whoever treats an orphan girl or boy under his care well; I and he will be in Paradise like these two. And he separated his two fingers, the index and the middle." Narrated by Ahmad and others via the path of Ubaidullah bin Zahr from Ali bin Yazid from Al-Qasim from him. 1514 - (11) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "By the One Who sent me with the truth as a Prophet; Allah will not punish on the Day of Resurrection one who had mercy on an orphan, spoke softly to him, and had mercy on his orphanhood and weakness, and did not act arrogantly towards his neighbor due to the bounty Allah gave him." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its narrators are trustworthy except Abdullah bin Amir, and Abu Hatim said: He is not Matruk (abandoned). 1515 - (12) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Beware of the crying of the orphan; for it travels in the night while people are asleep." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. 1516 - (13) [Very Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, raised it to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "That a man said to Jacob, peace be upon him: What took away your sight, and bent your back? He said: As for what took away my sight it is weeping over (Joseph), and as for what bent my back it is grief over his brother (Benjamin). So Gabriel, peace be upon him, came to him and said: Do you complain against Allah? He said: {I only complain of my suffering and my grief to Allah}. Gabriel said: Allah knows best about what you said than you. He said: Then Gabriel, peace be upon him, departed, and Jacob, peace be upon him, entered his house and said: O Lord! Do You not have mercy on the old sheikh? You took away my sight, and bent my back, so return to me my two sweet basils so I may smell them once; then do with me afterwards what You will!
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Gabriel came to him and said: O Jacob! Indeed Allah the Mighty and Majestic conveys Salam to you and says: Rejoice, for even if they were two dead ones I would resurrect them for you to delight your eye with them. And He says to you: O Jacob! Do you know why I took away your sight and bent your back? And why the brothers of Joseph did to Joseph what they did? He said: No. He said: Indeed a poor orphan came to you, and he was fasting and hungry, and you and your family slaughtered a sheep; so you ate it and did not feed him! And He says: Indeed I have not loved anything of My creation like my love for orphans and the poor, so make food, and invite the poor. - Anas said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: - So whenever Jacob entered the evening his caller would call out: Whoever is fasting let him attend the food of Jacob, and when he entered the morning his caller would call out: Whoever is breaking fast let him breakfast on the food of Jacob." Narrated by Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Asbahani and the wording is his. Al-Hakim said: "Thus in my hearing (Hafs bin Umar bin Az-Zubair), and I think Az-Zubair is an error; and that he is Hafs bin Umar Ibn Abdullah bin Abi Talhah. If it is so then the hadith is Sahih. And Ishaq bin Rahwaih extracted it in his Tafsir [Mursal] (1) he said: Amr bin Muhammad informed us: Zafir bin Sulaiman told us from Yahya bin Abdul Malik from Anas from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, similarly."
foot_note: 1. Meaning disconnected between Yahya and Anas, and it was dropped from the original, and I restored it from "Mustadrak Al-Hakim" (2/ 248). And (Zafir bin Sulaiman), despite his truthfulness, has many illusions. The hadith has disturbance (idtirab) and ignorance (jahalah) in its chain, and Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir denounced it, and it is more likely that it is from the Isra'iliyyat. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6880).

text: 5 - (Warning against harming the neighbor, and what came regarding emphasizing his right). 1517 - (1) [Weak] And Al-Asbahani [narrated] longer than it [meaning the hadith of Anas in "As-Sahih"], and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed a man is not a believer until his neighbor is safe from his calamities (bawa'iq), spending the night when he spends it safe from his evil. And indeed the believer; is he whose self is in toil from him, and people are in comfort from him." 1518 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ka'b bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: A man came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and said: O Messenger of Allah! I have settled in the locality of Banu so-and-so, and indeed the severest of them in harm to me is the closest of them to me in neighborliness. So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, sent Abu Bakr, Umar, and Ali to come to the mosque and stand at its door shouting: "Verily, forty houses are neighbors, and he will not enter Paradise whose neighbor fears his calamities." Narrated by At-Tabarani. (Al-Bawa'iq): Plural of (Ba'iqah) which is: Evil and its disaster, as came in the hadith of Abu Huraira mentioned previously [in "As-Sahih" in this chapter / Hadith 3]. 1519 - (3) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed Allah distributed your characters among you as He distributed your provisions among you. And indeed Allah the Mighty and Majestic gives the world to whom He loves and whom He does not love, but He does not give the religion except to whom He loves. So whoever He gives the religion, He has loved him. By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, a servant does not submit (Islam) until his heart and tongue submit, and he does not believe until his neighbor is safe from his calamities." I said: O Messenger of Allah! And what are his calamities? He said: "His wrong and his injustice. And he does not earn wealth from Haram and spend from it, so it is blessed for him, nor
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: does he give it in charity, so it is accepted from him, nor does he leave it behind his back except it is his provision to the Fire. Indeed Allah does not wipe out bad with bad, but He wipes out bad with good. Indeed the evil does not wipe out the evil." Narrated by Ahmad and others via the path of Aban bin Ishaq from As-Sabah bin Muhammad from him. [Passed in 16 - Sales / 5] (1). 1520 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever harms his neighbor has harmed me, and whoever harms me has harmed Allah. And whoever fights his neighbor has fought me, and whoever fights me has fought Allah the Mighty and Majestic." Narrated by Abu Ash-Shaykh Ibn Hayyan in "Kitab At-Tawbikh" (2). 1521 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, went out on a campaign and said: "Let no one accompany us today who has harmed his neighbor." A man from the people said: I urinated at the base of my neighbor's wall. He said: "Do not accompany us today." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and in it is denouncability (nakarah).
foot_note:
1. And there is a difference in some wordings from what is here. 
2. This hadith is not in the printed copy of "At-Tawbikh", and there is a gap in it in my view. Al-Ajlouni also attributed it to him and to Abu Nu'aym in "Kashf Al-Khafa" (2/ 219/ 2342). Adh-Dhahabi listed it in "Huquq Al-Jar" (f 5/ 2) briefly from the path of Dawood bin Ayub Al-Qamli: Abbad bin Bashir Al-Abdi told us, he said: I heard Anas bin Malik... so he mentioned it as Marfu'. And he said: "A denounced hadith." And he mentioned in the biography of this (Dawood) from "Al-Mizan" from Abbad... with two fabricated hadiths, and I think this is one of them according to him. And Allah knows best.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1522 - (6) -[Very Weak] And it was narrated from Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever closes his door against his neighbor fearing for his family and wealth; is not a believer. And he is not a believer whose neighbor is not safe from his calamities (1). Do you know what is the right of the neighbor? If he asks you for help you help him, if he asks you for a loan you lend him, if he becomes poor you support him, if he falls sick you visit him, if good befalls him you congratulate him, if calamity befalls him you console him, if he dies you follow his funeral, do not raise your building (2) above him blocking the wind from him except with his permission, do not harm him with the smell of your pot unless you scoop some for him from it, and if you buy fruit gift him some, if you do not do so then bring it in secretly, and do not let your child go out with it to anger his child." Narrated by Al-Khara'iti in "Makarim Al-Akhlaq". (Al-Hafiz said): "Perhaps his saying: 'Do you know what is the right of the neighbor' to the end is from the speech of the narrator, not Marfu'." 1523 - (7) [Very Weak] But At-Tabarani (3) narrated from Muawiyah bin Haydah who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! What is the right of the neighbor upon me? He said: "If he falls sick you visit him, if he dies you follow his funeral, if he asks you for a loan you lend him, and if he is in need you cover him" so he mentioned the hadith similarly.
foot_note:
1. From here the hadith begins in the printed copy of "Al-Makarim" (p. 40) with advancement and delay in some sentences. 
2. Original: (bil-bunyan - with buildings), and on its margin and in a copy: (bil-bina' - with building). I say: And it is the correct one matching the manuscript and "Al-Makarim". 
3. Al-Haythami said (8/ 165): "And it contains Abu Bakr Al-Hudhali, and he is weak." I say: Rather he is Matruk (abandoned), and it and the one before it are extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2587).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1524 - (8) [Very Weak] And Abu Ash-Shaykh Ibn Hayyan narrated in "Kitab At-Tawbikh" from Mu'adh bin Jabal who said: We said: O Messenger of Allah! What is the right of neighborliness? He said: "If he asks you for a loan you lend him, if he asks you for help you help him, if he is in need you give him, if he falls sick you visit him" so he mentioned the hadith similarly, and added at its end: "Do you understand what I say to you? No one will fulfill the right of the neighbor except a few whom Allah has mercy on. Or words similar to it." 1525 - (9) [Very Weak] And Abu Al-Qasim Al-Asbahani narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day; let him honor his neighbor." They said: O Messenger of Allah! And what is the right of the neighbor upon the neighbor? He said: "If he asks you, you give him" so he mentioned the hadith similarly, not mentioning the fruit in it. And it is not hidden that the multitude of these paths gives it strength. And Allah knows best (1). 1526 - (10) [Weak] And from Fadalah bin Ubaid, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Three are from the calamities (Al-Awaqir) (2): An Imam whom if you do good he does not thank, and if you do bad he does not forgive. And a bad neighbor who if he sees good he buries it, and if he sees evil he spreads it. And a woman who if you are present she harms you, and if you are absent from her she betrays you."
foot_note:
1. I say: It is as he said were it not for their severe weakness, and the confusion of their wordings, especially this one, for it is very denounced (Munkar jiddan), for its narrator (Ismail bin Rafi') - and he is Matruk - contradicted the trustworthy narrators from the companions of Abu Huraira who narrated the hadith from him without his saying: "They said: O Messenger of Allah...". See "Sahih Muslim" (1/ 49 - 50), and likewise Al-Bukhari narrated it, and it passed in the beginning of this chapter in "As-Sahih". The hadith is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2587) with what preceded it. 
2. Original: (Al-Fawaqir), which is the narration of Abu Nu'aym, and the established is from "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" and "Al-Majma'".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani with a chain that has no harm (1). 1527 - (11) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: A man came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and said: O Messenger of Allah! Clothe me. He turned away from him. He said: O Messenger of Allah! Clothe me. He said: "Do you not have a neighbor who has a surplus of two garments?" He said: Yes, more than one. He said: "May Allah not gather between you and him in Paradise." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1528 - (12) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Indeed Allah the Mighty and Majestic repels calamity from a hundred households of his neighbors because of the righteous Muslim. Then he recited: {And were it not that Allah checks the people, some by means of others, the earth would have been corrupted}." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat".
foot_note: 1. I say: How so when it contains (Muhammad bin Isam bin Yazid bin Ajlan Al-Hamdani), and no one declared him trustworthy; not even Ibn Hibban?! And Abu Nu'aym found this hadith of his strange. It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3087).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 6 - (Encouragement to visit brothers and righteous people, and what came regarding honoring visitors). 1529 - (1) -[Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Razin Al-Uqaili, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "O Abu Razin! Indeed, when a Muslim visits his Muslim brother; seventy thousand angels accompany him praying for him; saying: O Allah, just as he connected with him for Your sake, connect him [with Your mercy]." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1530 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Buraidah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Indeed in Paradise there are rooms whose outsides are seen from their insides, and their insides from their outsides, Allah prepared them for those who love each other in Him, those who visit each other in Him, and those who spend on each other in Him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1531 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And from Awn who said: Abdullah - meaning Ibn Mas'ud - said to his companions when they came to him: Do you sit together? They said: We do not leave that. He said: Do you visit each other? They said: Yes, O Abu Abdur-Rahman! Indeed, one of us misses his brother so he walks on his feet to the end of Kufa until he meets him. He said: Indeed you will not cease to be in good as long as you do that. Narrated by At-Tabarani, and it is interrupted (Munqati'). 1532 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Zirr bin Hubaish who said: We came to Safwan bin Assal Al-Muradi, so he said: Are you visitors? We said: Yes. He said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever visits his believing brother; wades in mercy until he returns, and whoever visits his believing brother [who is sick]; wades in the gardens of Paradise until he returns."
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 1533 - (5) [Weak] And from Umm Salamah, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said to me: "Fix the sitting place for us; for an angel descends to earth who has never descended to it before." Narrated by Ahmad, and its narrators are trustworthy, except that the Tabi'i was not named. 1534 - (6) [Weak] And from Umm Bujaid, may Allah be pleased with her; that she said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to come to us in Bani Amr bin Auf, so I would prepare sawiq (barley mush) for him in a bowl (qa'bah), and when he came I would give it to him to drink." Narrated by Ahmad, and its narrators are trustworthy; except Ibn Ishaq. (Umm Bujaid) with damma on the Ba and fatha on the Jim, and her name is (Hawwa' bint Yazid Al-Ansariyyah). (Al-Qa'b): A cup made of wood. 1535 - (7) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibrahim bin Nashit: That he entered upon Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Jaz' Az-Zubaidi, may Allah be pleased with him, so he threw him a pillow that was under him and said: Whoever does not honor his sitting companion; is not of Ahmad nor of Ibrahim, upon them both be blessings and peace. Narrated by At-Tabarani as Mawquf, and its narrators are trustworthy (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: Abu Hatim faulted it with interruption between Ibrahim and Abdullah, there is an unnamed man between them, see "Al-Ilal" (2/ 277).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 7 - (Encouragement for hospitality and honoring the guest, and emphasizing his right, and warning the guest against staying until he causes the people of the house to sin (1)). 1536 - (1) [Denounced (Munkar)] And from him [meaning Abu Karimah, who is Al-Miqdam bin Ma'd Yakrib Al-Kindi, may Allah be pleased with him] from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Any man who seeks hospitality from a people and the guest wakes up deprived; then helping him is a duty upon every Muslim, until he takes the hospitality of his night from his crops and wealth." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and Al-Hakim who said: "Sahih in chain" (2). 1537 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever establishes prayer, gives Zakat, fasts Ramadan, and honors the guest; enters Paradise." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir". 1538 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The angels [do not cease to] (3) pray upon one of you as long as his table is set." Narrated by Al-Asbahani.
foot_note:
1. See the hadiths of this section of the chapter in "As-Sahih". 
2. Thus he said, and it contains (Sa'id bin Al-Muhajir) and he is not known as Adh-Dhahabi and others said, and it is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6881). As for the Three Commentators, they exerted themselves and said: "Hasan"! Stumbling blindly! The hadith has been authenticated from Al-Miqdam with another shorter wording, you see it in "As-Sahih", so rely on it.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1539 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Good comes faster to the house in which food is eaten than the knife to the camel's hump." Narrated by Ibn Majah. 1540 - (5) [Weak] And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it from the hadith of Anas and others (1). (Al-Hafiz said): "The 'Chapter on Feeding Food' [8 - Charity / 17] has passed, and in it are more than one hadith suitable for this chapter, we did not repeat any of them." 1541 - (6) [Weak] And from Shihab bin Abbad; that he heard some of the delegation of Abdul Qais saying: We came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and their joy with us was intense. When we reached the people they made room for us, so we sat down. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, welcomed us and prayed for us, then he looked at us and said: "Who is your master and leader?" We all pointed to Al-Mundhir bin 'A'idh. So the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Is this Al-Ashajj?" - And that was the first day this name was applied to him because of a blow on his face by a donkey's hoof. We said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! He had stayed behind the people; tied their mounts, gathered their luggage, then took out his travel bag (aibah) and took off his travel clothes, and put on his good clothes. Then he came to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, while the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had stretched out his leg and was reclining. When Al-Ashajj came near him, the people made room for him and said: Here,
foot_note: 1. I say: He went too far, for Ibn Majah (3356) also narrated it, and its chain is triple narrating from a weak from a weak from Anas! And Abu Ash-Shaykh narrated it from Jabir as in "Takhrij Al-Ihya" (3/ 244) and said: "And all of them are weak."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: O Ashajj! The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, - sat up straight and pulled in his leg - said: "Here O Ashajj!" So he sat to the right of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. He welcomed him and was kind to him and asked him about their lands and named for him the village of (As-Safa) and (Al-Mushaqqar) (1) and others from the villages of (Hajar). He said: May my father and mother be ransomed for you O Messenger of Allah! You are more knowledgeable of the names of our villages than us. He said: "I have trodden your lands, and it was opened for me from it." He said: Then he turned to the Ansar and said: "O assembly of Ansar! Honor your brothers; for they are your likes in Islam, the most resembling thing to you in hair and skin, they submitted willingly not coerced, nor after being killed (mawturin), while a people refused to submit until they were killed." He said: When they woke up he said: "How did you see your brothers' honoring of you, and their hospitality to you." They said: The best of brothers, they softened our beds, and made our food good, and spent the night and morning teaching us the Book of our Lord Blessed and Exalted, and the Sunnah of our Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. So the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was pleased and rejoiced at that. The Hadith at length. Narrated by Ahmad with a Sahih chain (2).
foot_note:
1. With damma on the Mim and fatha on the pointed Shin and the stressed Qaf ending with an unpointed Ra: An ancient fortress in (Bahrain). Mentioned in "Al-Ujalah". And it appeared in the original: (Al-Muntaqar), and in "Al-Majma'" (Al-Munqirah), so I corrected it from "Al-Musnad" and others. And (As-Safa) is a fortress there also as in "Mu'jam Al-Buldan". 
2. Thus he said, but it contains Yahya bin Abdur-Rahman Al-Asari, Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Mizan": "He is not known, Abu Salamah At-Tabudhaki was unique in narrating from him"! I say: Rather (Yunus bin Muhammad) also narrated from him, and he is Abu Muhammad Al-Mu'addib, the trustworthy and reliable, and he is Ahmad's Sheikh in this hadith (3/ 432 and 4/ 206). This corroboration was hidden from the books of biographies I consulted like "Tarikh Al-Bukhari", "Al-Jarh", "Thiqat Ibn Hibban" (9/ 252), "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" and its branches. And the commentators on them also missed it.

Bring to our companions even crumbs; for I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Noble character, is from the deeds of Paradise." Narrated by Ahmad and its men are men of "As-Sahih"; except Ibn Lahi'ah.

Yet it contains (Ahmad bin Abdullah Ibn Abi Bazzah), and he is Munkar al-Hadith (denounced in hadith) as Al-Uqayli and others said. And Ibn Adi said: "This hadith is Munkar with this chain." So how can it be Hasan?! It is extracted in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1286).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 8 - (Warning against a person looking down on what is presented to him, or looking down on what he has to present to the guest). 1544 - (1) [Weak] From Abdullah bin Ubaid bin Umair who said: A group of the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, entered upon Jabir, so he presented to them bread and vinegar, and said: Eat; for I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "What an excellent condiment is vinegar. It is destruction for a man that a group of his brothers enter upon him and he looks down upon what is in his house to present to them, and destruction for the people that they look down upon what is presented to them." Narrated by Ahmad, At-Tabarani, and Abu Ya'la; except that he said: "And it is evil enough for a man to look down upon what is brought near to him." And some of their chains are Hasan (1). "What an excellent condiment is vinegar," is in "As-Sahih" (2). Perhaps his saying: "It is destruction for a man..." to the end is from the speech of Jabir, inserted (mudraj) not Marfu'. And Allah knows best.
foot_note:
1. I say: I think he means the chain of At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat"; for its narrators are trustworthy, but it contains the 'an'anah of (Abdur-Rahman bin Muhammad Al-Muharibi), and the rest of the chains are clearly weak, and the explanation of that is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5389). 
2. And it passed in "The Book of Food" (19/ 5).

text: 9 - (Encouragement to sow and plant fruit-bearing trees). 1545 - (1) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Whoever builds a building without injustice or transgression, or plants a plant without injustice or transgression, will have a running reward as long as any of the creation of the Most Merciful Blessed and Exalted benefits from it." Narrated by Ahmad from the path of Zabban. 1546 - (2) [Weak] And from a man from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say with these two ears of mine: "Whoever plants a tree and is patient in guarding it and tending to it until it bears fruit; will have in everything eaten from its fruit a charity with Allah the Mighty and Majestic." Narrated by Ahmad, and it contains a story, and its chain has no harm (1). 1547 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace; that he said: "There is no man who plants a plant; except that Allah writes for him of reward the amount of what comes out of that planting." Narrated by Ahmad, and its narrators are relied upon in "As-Sahih"; except Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz Al-Laithi (2). 1548 - (4) [Weak] And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, came to Bani Amr bin Auf on Wednesday, so he mentioned the hadith until

2. I say: He is weak, and became confused towards the end.

text: he said: "O assembly of Ansar!" They said: At your service O Messenger of Allah! He said: "You used to in Jahiliyyah when you did not worship Allah bear the burden [of the weak], and do good with your wealth, and act [kindly] towards the wayfarer, until when Allah bestowed upon you Islam and His Prophet, behold you fortify your wealth. In what the son of Adam eats there is reward, and in what the beast eats there is reward, and the bird is reward." He said: So the people returned and not one of them remained except he demolished thirty gates of his garden. Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Sahih in chain". (1) He said: "And in it is clear prohibition of fortifying walled gardens, palm groves, and vineyards and others from the needy and hungry eating anything from them." End quote.
foot_note: 1. I say: Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him in "At-Talkhis" (4/ 113 - 134) by pointing out the ignorance of its narrator (Muhammad bin Musa bin Al-Harith) from his father. And his father is like him! Its explanation is in "At-Ta'liq Ar-Raghib" and "Taysir Al-Intifa'".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 10 - (Warning against stinginess and miserliness, and encouragement for generosity and munificence). 1549 - (1) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Nothing destroyed Islam like miserliness destroyed it." Narrated by Abu Ya'la and At-Tabarani. 1550 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Nafi' who said: Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, heard a man say: The miser is more treacherous than the oppressor. So Ibn Umar said: You lied, I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "The miser will not enter Paradise." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1551 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "No deceiver (Khibb), nor Mannan (reminder of charity), nor miser will enter Paradise." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib hadith." (Al-Khibb) with fatha on the dotted Kha and kasra: Is the deceitful cheater. 1552 - (4) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Allah created the Garden of Eden with His hand, and dangled its fruits in it, and split its rivers in it, then looked at it and said to it: Speak. So it said: {Certainly will the believers have succeeded}. So He said: By My Might and Majesty, no miser will be neighbor to Me in you." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat" with two chains, one of them is Jayyid (1).
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, and it is not Jayyid for two reasons: One is that it is from the narration of Hisham bint Khalid from Baqiyyah. The other: Is that it does not contain: "So He said: By My Might...", and I have clarified this in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1284). Similar has been authenticated as Mawquf on Abu Sa'id with another addition you will see if Allah wills in (28 - Description of Paradise / 4) of "As-Sahih".

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1553 - (5) [Very Weak] And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it in "Sifat Al-Jannah" from the hadith of Anas bin Malik; and it will come if Allah wills [28 - Description of Paradise / 4] (1). 1554 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Three Allah loves, and three Allah hates, - so he mentioned the hadith until he said: - And He hates the adulterous old man, the miser, and the arrogant." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih". And it is in full in "Secret Charity" [8 - Charity / 10]. 1555 - (7) [Weak] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "The generous one is close to Allah, close to Paradise, close to people, far from the Fire. And the miser is far from Allah, far from Paradise, far from people, close to the Fire. And an ignorant generous person is more beloved to Allah than a miserly worshipper." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from the hadith of Sa'id bin Muhammad Al-Warraq from Yahya bin Sa'id from Al-A'raj from Abu Huraira, and he said: "[Gharib] It is only narrated from Yahya bin Sa'id from Aisha as Mursal." 1556 - (8) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who said: "Verily every generous one is in Paradise, a promise binding upon Allah, and I am his guarantor. And verily every
foot_note: 1. In its chain (18/ 20) is (Bishr bin Al-Husain Al-Asbahani), and he is Matruk (abandoned) accused of lying. The virtuous commentator on "Sifat Al-Jannah" by Abu Nu'aym was distracted, so he classified the hadith of Hisham bin Khalid referred to previously as Hasan (1/ 42), and used this hadith of Anas as a witness for it (1/ 43), claiming it is "not severely weak"! He also cited the hadith of Abu Sa'id as a witness for it, not noticing the difference in its wording from Hisham's hadith, as well as the hadith of Anas, which is long and contains the sentence about the miser. Detailed discussion on this is not possible here.

text: 23 - Book of Manners and Others. 1 - (Encouragement of Modesty (Haya') and what has been reported regarding its virtue, and Intimidation against Obscenity and Foul Speech). 1586 - (1) [Fabricated] And [meaning the hadith of Abu Umamah which is in "As-Sahih"] At-Tabarani narrated it with a similar meaning, and his wording is: He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "[Indeed] Modesty and inarticulateness are from Faith, and they bring one closer to Paradise and distance one from the Fire. 1. The author remained silent about it, which is not good. Al-Haythami said (1/92): "...And it contains Muhammad bin Muhsin Al-Ukkashi, and he is weak and not used as proof," which is lenient; because Al-Ukkashi is a liar as stated by Ibn Ma'in and Abu Hatim. text: 1593 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "A believer's nobility is his religion, his chivalry is his intellect, and his lineage is his character." There is no intellect like planning, no piety like restraint, and no lineage like good character." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" and others at the end of a long hadith, a portion of which was presented in [20 - Judiciary /5] (2).
foot_note:
1. Thus he said! And Adh-Dhahabi rejected it by saying: "I say: Az-Zanji is weak." Al-Hafiz said: "Truthful but has many delusions." So the classification of 'Hasan' by the commentator on "Musnad Abu Ya'la" (11/334) is rejected, especially since it was narrated as Mawquf on Umar, and the author said: "And perhaps that is more likely." Al-Bayhaqi's authentication of it is questionable to me, because he narrated it in his "Sunan" (10/195) via Ash-Sha'bi: I heard Ziyad bin Hudair say: I heard Umar say: then he mentioned it; but it contains (Musa bin Dawud), who is At-Tarsusi, and there is weakness in his memory. Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Mughni": "He was authenticated, and Abu Hatim said: There is confusion in his hadith." And he narrated it in "Ash-Shu'ab" (4/160/4658) via another path from Ash-Sha'bi who said: Umar said. This is disconnected; Ash-Sha'bi did not meet Umar. However, his chain to Ash-Sha'bi is authentic. Perhaps Al-Bayhaqi indicated its lack of confirmation from Umar by saying after the hadith in "As-Sunan" (7/136): "And something similar was narrated from Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) from his own speech. And Allah knows best." 
2. I say: Sheikh An-Naji corrected him saying (193/2): "Thus Ibn Majah narrated it briefly." I say: Its chain contains a weak narrator and another unknown one. And in Ibn Hibban's chain is a liar. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1910); so it is strange how the author prefaced it with (An - from) indicating its strengthening!

text: [Weak] And the hadith of Abu Dharr from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was presented in "Sincerity" [1/ 1/ 7]: "He has succeeded who purifies his heart for faith, makes his heart sound, his tongue truthful, his soul reassured, and his character straight" the Hadith. 1596 - (7) [Mursal Weak] And from Al-Ala bin Ash-Shikhir: That a man came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from in front of his face; and said: O Messenger of Allah! Which deed is best? He said: "Good character." Then he came to him from his right; and said: Which deed is best? He said: "Good character." Then he came to him from his left; and said: O Messenger of Allah! Which deed is best? He said: "Good character." Then he came to him from behind him - meaning from his back -, and said: O Messenger of Allah! Which deed is best? So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) turned to him and said: "What is wrong with you that you do not understand?! Good character is that you do not get angry if you are able." Narrated by Muhammad bin Nasr Al-Marwazi in "Kitab As-Salah" as Mursal like this. 1597 - (8) [Fabricated] It was narrated from Ammar bin Yasir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Good character is the Greatest Character of Allah." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat". 1598 - (9) [Weak] It was narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with both of them) from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "From Gabriel from Allah Almighty who said: Indeed this is a religion I have chosen for Myself, and nothing
foot_note: None

Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1601 - (12) [Very Weak] And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) met Abu Dharr and said: "O Abu Dharr! Shall I not guide you to two qualities that are lighter on the back, and heavier in the Scale than others?"
foot_note:
1. Thus he stated generally, but he only narrated it in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Haythami found a defect in it due to Mu'ammal Ath-Thaqafi, but he missed that his Sheikh is weaker than him. Its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3341). 
2. Thus in the original; in the passive voice. Based on this, either the original was "Wa Rawa" (And he narrated) in the active voice, making his saying after "Narrated by At-Tabarani..." redundant, or the saying "Wa Rawa" is redundant and the correct form is: "Wa 'anhu..." (And from him...). The addition is from "Al-Awsat", and it is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4436).

text: He said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "You must have good character and long silence. By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, creatures have not performed anything like them." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, At-Tabarani, Al-Bazzar, and Abu Ya'la with a Jayyid (good) chain, its narrators are trustworthy (1), and the wording is his. [Very Weak] And Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan narrated it in "Kitab Ath-Thawab" with a flimsy chain from Abu Dharr, and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O Abu Dharr! Shall I not guide you to the best of worship, the lightest of it on the body, the heaviest of it in the Scale, and the easiest of it on the tongue?" I said: Yes, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you. He said: "You must have long silence and good character, for you will not do anything like them." 1602 - (13) [?] And he also narrated it from the hadith of Abu Ad-Darda who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O Abu Ad-Darda! Shall I not inform you of two matters, whose burden is light, whose reward is great, and you will not meet Allah Almighty with anything like them? Long silence and good character." 1603 - (14) [Weak] And Malik narrated it (2) from Mu'adh who said: The last thing the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) advised me with when I placed my foot in the stirrup was that he said:
foot_note:
1. I say: How can that be when it contains (Bashar bin Al-Hakam Abu Badr), who is Munkar (denounced) in hadith as stated by Abu Zur'ah and others. See "Ad-Da'ifah" (2999). 
2. I say: He suspended it from him like this without a chain. It is one of the four hadiths that they said: were not found connected.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "O Mu'adh! Improve your character for the people." 1604 - (15) [Munkar] It was narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: Umm Habibah said: O Messenger of Allah! A woman has two husbands, then she dies and enters Paradise along with her two husbands; to which of them does she belong? To the first or to the last? He said: "She chooses the one of them with the best character who was with her in the world; he becomes her husband in Paradise. O Umm Habibah! Good character has gone with the good of this world and the Hereafter" (1). Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Bazzar briefly. And At-Tabarani also narrated it in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat" from the hadith of Umm Salamah at the end of a long hadith which will come in "Description of Paradise" Allah Almighty willing [28/ 13]. 1605 - (16) [Very Weak] It was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with both of them) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Good character melts sins just as water melts ice, and bad character spoils deeds just as vinegar spoils honey." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat", and Al-Bayhaqi. 1606 - (17) [Weak] And from a man of Muzaynah who said: It was said: O Messenger of Allah! What is the best thing a Muslim man is given? He said: "Good character." He said: So what is the worst thing a Muslim man is given? He said: "If you dislike for something to be seen from you in the gathering of people; do not do it when you are alone."
foot_note: 1. I say: Along with the weakness of its chain, it contradicts the authentic hadith with the wording: "The woman belongs to the last of her husbands." This is documented in "As-Sahihah" (1281).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Abdur-Razzaq in his "Book" from Ma'mar from Abu Ishaq from him (1). 1607 - (18) [Very Weak] It was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed these characters are from Allah. Whoever Allah wants good for; He grants him good character. And whoever He wants evil for; He grants him bad character." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1608 - (19) [Weak] And from Rafi' bin Mukaith - and he was among those who witnessed Al-Hudaibiyah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Good character is growth, and bad character is an ill omen. Righteousness is an increase in lifespan, and charity repels an evil death." Narrated by Ahmad and Abu Dawood briefly. Their chains contain an unnamed narrator, and the rest of their chain consists of trustworthy narrators (2). 1609 - (20) [Weak] It was narrated from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: It was said: O Messenger of Allah! What is the ill omen? He said: "Bad character." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1610 - (21) [Weak] And he also narrated it therein from the hadith of Aisha who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The ill omen is bad character" (3).
foot_note:
1. He included it in "Al-Musannaf" (11/ 144/ 20151). Abu Ishaq is As-Sabi'i, a Mudallis, and he narrated it with 'An' (from), and he had become confused [mixed up due to age]. The Muzani man appears to be a Companion, otherwise he is unknown. 
2. I say: It also contains (Uthman bin Zufar), who is the Damascene, unknown as stated in "At-Taqrib". It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3244). 
3. I say: Its defect is Abu Bakr bin Abi Maryam, and it is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (793).

text: 1611 - (22) [Fabricated] It was narrated from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "There is nothing except that it has repentance; except the possessor of bad character, for he does not repent from a sin; except that he returns to an evil worse than it." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir", and Al-Asbahani. 1612 - (23) [Fabricated] And in a narration of Al-Asbahani, from a man from the people of Al-Jazirah whom he did not name, from Maimun bin Mahran who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There is no sin greater with Allah Almighty than bad character, and that is because its possessor does not exit from a sin except that he returns - or he said: except that he falls - into a sin." And this is Mursal (1). 1613 - (24) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to supplicate; saying: "O Allah, indeed I seek refuge in You from discord (Shiqaq), hypocrisy (Nifaq), and bad character." Narrated by Abu Dawood and An-Nasa'i (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: Along with being Mursal, it contains (Marwan bin Salim Al-Jazari); he was accused of fabrication. It is documented along with the one before it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5266).

text: 3 - (Encouragement of Gentleness, Deliberation, and Forbearance). 1614 - (1) [Weak] It was narrated from Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Gentleness is a blessing (Yumn), and clumsiness/violence (Kharaq) is an ill omen." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1615 - (2) [Fabricated] It was narrated from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Three things, whoever has them, Allah spreads His wing (protection) over him and enters him into His Paradise: Gentleness with the weak, compassion for parents, and kindness to the slave." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Strange (Gharib) hadith." [Past 8 - Charity /17]. 1616 - (3) [Very Weak] It was narrated from Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "When Allah gathers the creatures, a caller will call out: Where are the People of Virtue? He said: A group of people will stand, and they are few, and they will proceed quickly towards Paradise. The angels will meet them and say: We see you proceeding quickly to Paradise, so who are you? They say: We are the People of Virtue. They say: And what is your virtue? They say: When we were wronged we were patient, and when we were treated badly we forbore. It will be said to them: Enter Paradise; excellent is the reward of the workers." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. 1617 - (4) [Very Weak] It was narrated from Ali bin Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, a servant attains by forbearance (Hilm) the degree of the one who fasts and prays."
foot_note: None

He said: "Do not stand up as the foreigners (non-Arabs) stand up, glorifying one another." Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah, and its chain is Hasan, containing Abu Ghalib - and his name is Hazuwwar (2), and it is said: Nafi'. And it is said: Sa'id bin Al-Hazuwwar. And Allah knows best.
foot_note:
1. I say: And this Abdur-Rahim has softness in him as Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Mughni". Likewise, Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Fath" (11/6) after attributing it to Abu Dawood: "Its chain is weak." I say: So the addition is Munkar for contradicting the hadith of Imran referred to, and Al-Hafiz said: "Its chain is strong." The defect of the hadith is from someone below him, and it contains confusion and anonymity, as Al-Hafiz stated in "Al-Fath" (11/ 49-50) and I clarified in "Ad-Da'ifah" (346). Yet the ignorant ones claimed it is Hasan due to its witnesses!

text: 6 - (Encouragement to Shake Hands, and Intimidation against Gesturing in Greeting, and what has been reported regarding Greeting Disbelievers). 1623 - (1) [Weak] And in a narration of Abu Dawood [meaning in the hadith of Al-Bara' which is in "As-Sahih"]: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "When two Muslims meet and shake hands, praise Allah, and seek forgiveness; they are forgiven." (Al-Hafiz said): "In this narration is (Abu Balj) with a Fathah on the Ba and a Sukun on the Lam followed by a Jim, and his name is Yahya bin Sulaym, and it is said: Yahya bin Abi Al-Aswad (1), and discussion on him will come. And [it contains] (Al-Ajlah) and his name is Yahya bin Abdullah Abu Hujayyah Al-Kindi (2), and the chain of this hadith has confusion." 1624 - (2) [Very Weak] At-Tabarani narrated from Abu Dawood Al-A'ma - who is abandoned - who said: Al-Bara' bin Azib met me, took my hand, shook it, and smiled in my face, then said: Do you know why I took your hand? I said: No, except that I thought you did it only for good. He said: Indeed the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) met me and did that to me, then said: "Do you know why I did that to you?" I said: No. He said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, when two Muslims meet and shake hands and each one smiles in the face of his companion, not doing so except for Allah; they do not separate until they are forgiven."
foot_note:
1. I say: This one is truthful (Saduq) but might make mistakes. However, the defect of this narration is his Sheikh (Zaid bin Abi Ash-Sha'tha), who is unknown. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2344). 
2. I say: This one is in the path of the "Sahih" hadith, and he is truthful.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1625 - (3) [Weak] And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "There are no two Muslims who meet and one of them takes the hand of his companion; except that it is a right upon Allah Almighty to attend to their supplication, and not separate their hands until He forgives them." Narrated by Ahmad and the wording is his, and Al-Bazzar and Abu Ya'la. The narrators of Ahmad are all trustworthy; except Maimun Al-Mara'i, and this hadith is among what was denounced of him. 1626 - (4) [Munkar] And from him [meaning from Abu Hurairah may Allah be pleased with him] who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, when two Muslims meet, shake hands, and ask about one another; Allah sends down between them a hundred mercies, ninety-nine for the most cheerful (Abash-hima) and most beaming of them in face, and the most kind and best of them in asking about his brother." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a chain that has some question (1). (Li-Abash-hima) meaning: For the one of them with more cheerfulness (Bashashah), which is the radiance of the face with joy, smiling, good reception, and kindness in asking. And (Atlaqihima) meaning: The one with the most and utmost radiance, which is synonymous with cheerfulness. 1627 - (5) [Very Weak] It was narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "When two Muslim men meet and one of them greets his companion, the more beloved of them to Allah is the one with the better cheerfulness towards his companion. When they shake hands, a hundred mercies descend upon them; for the initiator of them is ninety, and for the shaker is ten." Narrated by Al-Bazzar (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: Its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6585). 
2. I say: It contains (Umar bin Imran As-Sa'dani) so Al-Haythami did not know him because it is distorted; it is (Umar bin Amir As-Sa'di), thus it appeared in the narration of (Jam'), and he is accused. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (2385).

text: 7 - (Intimidation against a person looking into a house before he asks permission). 1632 - (1) [Weak] And from Ubadah - meaning Ibn As-Samit - (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was asked about asking permission in houses? He said: "Whoever's eye enters before he asks permission and greets; there is no permission for him, and he has disobeyed his Lord." Narrated by At-Tabarani from the hadith of Ishaq bin Yahya from Ubadah, and he did not hear from him, but its narrators are trustworthy. 1633 - (2) [Weak] And from Thawban (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Three things are not lawful for anyone to do: Let no man lead a people in prayer and single himself out with supplication to their exclusion; if he does so, he has betrayed them. Let him not look into the depth of a house before he asks permission; if he does so, he has entered. And let him not pray while he is suppressing the urge to urinate/defecate (Haqin) until he relieves himself." Narrated by Abu Dawood and the wording is his, and At-Tirmidhi who classified it Hasan, and Ibn Majah briefly. Abu Dawood also narrated it from the hadith of Abu Hurairah (1). 8 - (Intimidation against listening to the talk of people who dislike him hearing it). [The hadith under this section is not according to the condition of our book. See "As-Sahih"].
foot_note: 1. I say: There are two matters in this attribution: First, it does not contain the point of evidence, which is looking into the house. Second, it is the same hadith of Thawban before it, so it is one hadith. The utmost is that one of its narrators - who is weak - was confused in its chain; attributing it once to Thawban, and another time to Abu Hurairah, as I had clarified in "Da'if Abu Dawood" (numbers 11 and 12). Therefore, I did not differentiate between them in numbering, rather I gave them a single number.

text: 9 - (Encouragement of Isolation (Uzlah) for one who does not feel safe for himself when mixing with people). 1634 - (1) [Weak] It was narrated from Sahl bin Sa'd As-Sa'idi (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Indeed, the most amazing of people to me is a believer who believes in Allah and His Messenger, establishes prayer, pays Zakat, maintains his wealth, preserves his religion, and isolates himself from people." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Al-Uzlah" (1). 1635 - (2) [Mursal and Weak] And from Makhul who said: A man said: When is the Hour, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "The one questioned about it knows no more than the questioner, but it has signs, and the closeness of markets." They said: O Messenger of Allah! And what is the closeness of its markets? He said: "Their stagnation, rain (2) without plant growth, the spread of backbiting, the increase of children of adultery, the glorification of the wealthy, the raising of voices of the corrupt in the mosques, and the prevalence of the people of evil over the people of truth." A man said: So what do you command me? He said: "Flee with your religion, and be a saddle-blanket (Hils) of the saddle-blankets of your house (stay home)."
foot_note:
1. I say: He narrated it therein (5 - Hadith) via Ibn Lahi'ah: Bakr bin Sawadah told me from Sahl bin Sa'd As-Sa'idi... And Ibn Lahi'ah is weak. Then he narrated it at the end of the second part via Hushaym from Abdur-Rahman bin Yahya from Musa bin Al-Ash'ath, from a man of Quraish called Al-Harith bin Khalid, or Khalid bin Al-Harith who said: I was with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the expedition of Tabuk... so he mentioned the hadith. I do not know Musa or the narrator from him. 
2. Thus in the original, and in (Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya): "Kanasuha Matar", and the meaning is not clear to me.

text: Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya like this as Mursal (1). 1636 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with both of them): That Umar went out to the mosque, and found Mu'adh at the grave of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) weeping. He said: What makes you weep? He said: A hadith I heard from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "A little showing off (Riya) is Shirk, and whoever shows enmity to a friend of Allah has challenged Allah with war. Indeed Allah loves the righteous, pious, hidden ones; those who, if they are absent, are not missed, and if they are present, are not known. Their hearts are lamps of guidance, they emerge from every dark dusty place." Narrated by Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi in "Az-Zuhd", and Al-Hakim said: "Authentic, and it has no defect." [Past 1 - Sincerity /1]. 1637 - (4) [Weak] It was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "A time will come upon people when a person of religion will not preserve his religion; except one who flees with his religion from peak to peak, and from hole to hole. When that happens, livelihood will not be attained except through the displeasure of Allah. When that happens, a man's ruin will be at the hands of his wife and his child. If he has no wife or child; his ruin will be at the hands of his parents. If he has no parents; his ruin will be at the hands of his relatives or neighbors." They said: How is that, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "They shame him for his limited livelihood, so then he exposes himself to situations where he destroys himself."
foot_note: 1. I say: He narrated it at the end of "Al-Uzlah" (2/ 36) via Abdur-Rahman bin Muhammad Al-Muharibi, from Abdullah bin Al-Walid from Makhul. I do not know this (Abdullah). Among the Sheikhs of (Al-Muharibi) is (Ubaidullah bin Al-Walid Al-Wassafi), so I think it is him, and he is weak.

text: Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi in "Kitab Az-Zuhd" (1). 1638 - (5) [Weak] And from Imran bin Husain (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever devotes himself to Allah; Allah suffices him every burden, and provides for him from where he does not expect. And whoever devotes himself to the world; Allah entrusts him to it." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan in "Ath-Thawab", and At-Tabarani's chain is acceptable (Muqarib), [Past 16 - Sales /4] (2). And we dictated analogs for this hadith in "Economy" and "Greed" [16 - Sales /4], and analogs for it will come in "Asceticism" [24] Allah Almighty willing.
