text: 10 - (Intimidation against Anger, and Encouragement to repel and suppress it, and what to do when angry). 1639 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Al-Musayyib who said: While the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was sitting with his companions, a man insulted Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) and hurt him, but Abu Bakr remained silent. Then he hurt him a second time, and Abu Bakr remained silent. Then he hurt him a third time, so Abu Bakr retaliated. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stood up. [Abu Bakr] (*) said: Are you angry with me, O Messenger of Allah? The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "An angel descended from the sky denying what he said to you, but when you retaliated; the angel left and Satan sat down. I would not sit when Satan has taken a seat." Narrated by Abu Dawood like this as Mursal, and connected via Muhammad bin Ajlan (1) from Sa'id bin Abi Sa'id Al-Maqburi from Abu Hurairah with similar meaning. Al-Bukhari mentioned in his "Tarikh" that the Mursal is more correct. 1640 - (2) [Weak] And Ahmad narrated it [meaning the hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih"] (2) in a long hadith from a man who witnessed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) giving a sermon - and he did not name him - and he said in it: Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "What is the Sur'ah?" He said: They said: The wrestler (who throws people). He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The Sur'ah is wholly the Sur'ah, the Sur'ah is wholly the Sur'ah, the Sur'ah is wholly the Sur'ah:
foot_note:
1. Original: (Ghailan), which is an ugly misspelling, for there is no one named (Muhammad bin Ghailan) in the Six Books as Al-Hafiz An-Naji said. Ibn Ajlan is Hasan in hadith, but Al-Laith bin Sa'd and others contradicted him and narrated it as Mursal, which is why Al-Bukhari preferred it. 
2. I say: Its chain (5/367) contains Ibn Hasbah or Abu Hasbah, and he is unknown as in "At-Ta'jil". The three [commentators] classified it Hasan due to an authentic witness from the hadith of Abu Hurairah in "As-Sahih", but it is a deficient witness if they only knew. text: The man who gets angry, his anger intensifies, his face turns red, his skin shudders; but he suppresses his anger." (Al-Hafiz said): "(As-Sur'ah) with a Dammah on the Sad and a Fathah on the Ra: is the one who throws people down often with his strength. As for (As-Sur'ah) with a Sukun on the Ra: it is the weak one whom people throw down until he can hardly stand against anyone. Anyone who does something frequently, it is said of him: (Fu'alah) with Dammah on the first letter and Fathah on the second, like (Hufazah - memorize much), (Khuda'ah - deceives much), (Duhakah - laughs much) and the like. If the second letter has a Sukun, it is the opposite, meaning: the one to whom that is done frequently." 1641 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) led us in the Asr prayer one day, then he stood up delivering a sermon. He did not leave anything that will happen until the Day of Resurrection except that he informed us of it; he who remembered it remembered it, and he who forgot it forgot it. Among what he said was: "Indeed the world is sweet and green, and indeed (1) Allah has made you successors in it, so He is watching how you act. So beware of the world, and beware of women." Among what he said was: "Let not the awe of people prevent a man from speaking the truth if he knows it." He said: So Abu Sa'id wept and said: By Allah, we have seen things and we were afraid. Among what he said was: "Indeed, a flag will be set up for every traitor according to the measure of his treachery, and there is no treachery greater than the treachery of
foot_note: 1. Original: "Indeed the world is green and sweet, indeed Allah", and the correction is from "At-Tirmidhi". This paragraph of the hadith, from his saying: "Indeed the world is sweet... to his saying: at his buttocks", has a witness, so I included it in "As-Sahih".

text: a leader of the public; his flag is planted at his buttocks." Among what we memorized that day was: "Indeed, the children of Adam were created in [various] levels. [Among them is he who is born a believer, lives as a believer, and dies as a believer. Among them is he who is born a disbeliever, lives as a disbeliever, and dies as a disbeliever. Among them is he who is born a believer, lives as a believer, and dies as a disbeliever. Among them is he who is born a disbeliever, lives as a disbeliever, and dies as a believer]. Indeed, among them is the slow to anger and fast to return (calm down), and among them is the fast to anger and fast to return; so that is for that. Indeed, among them is the fast to anger and slow to return. Indeed, the best of them is the slow to anger and fast to return, [and] the worst of them is the fast to anger and slow to return. [Indeed, among them is the one good in repaying debt and good in demanding repayment, and among them is the one bad in repaying and good in demanding, and among them is the one good in repaying and bad in demanding; so that is for that. Indeed, among them is the one bad in repaying and bad in demanding. Indeed, the best of them is the one good in repaying and good in demanding. Indeed, the worst of them is the one bad in repaying and bad in demanding]. Indeed, anger is a burning coal in the heart of the son of Adam. Do you not see the redness of his eyes and the swelling of his neck veins? So whoever feels anything of that; let him stick to the ground." [He said: We began looking at the sun to see if anything of it remained. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, nothing remains of the world in what has passed of it; except as much as what remains of this day of yours in what has passed of it."]
foot_note: None

text: Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan hadith" (1). 1642 - (4) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with both of them): Regarding His Almighty's saying: {Repel [evil] by that [deed] which is better} he said: Patience at anger, and forgiveness at mistreatment. If they do so, Allah protects them, and humbles their enemy for them. Al-Bukhari mentioned it as suspended (Mu'allaq) (2). 1643 - (5) [Fabricated] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with both of them) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Three things, whoever has them, Allah shelters him in His protection, covers him with His mercy, and enters him into His love: He who gives thanks when given, forgives when capable, and calms down (Fatara) when angry." Narrated by Al-Hakim from the narration of Umar bin Rashid; and he said: "Authentic Isnad" (3). 1644 - (6) [Fabricated] It was narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever suppresses his anger; Allah withholds His punishment from him. And whoever guards his tongue; Allah covers his nakedness (faults)."
foot_note:
1. Thus he said! Even if he means it is Hasan due to others, that is not correct in absolute terms because many of its paragraphs have no witness. Therefore, I included it here, while restoring what was missing from the original marked by brackets [], and some of it was presented by the author in (6 - Sales /7), with an explanation of its defect in the commentary there. 
2. In "Tafsir {Ha-Mim As-Sajdah}" (8/ 556 - Fath), and At-Tabari connected it (24/ 76) via Ali bin Abi Talhah from Ibn Abbas with a more complete wording. This is a weak disconnected chain; this Ali did not see Ibn Abbas as Al-Hafiz said in "At-Taqrib". 
3. Thus he said, and Adh-Dhahabi rejected it saying (1/ 125): "I say: Rather it is flimsy; for Abu Hatim said about Umar bin Rashid Al-Jari: I found his hadith to be lies." It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5478).

text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1645 - (7) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If one of you gets angry while standing, let him sit down. If the anger leaves him [good], otherwise let him lie down." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; both from the narration of Abu Harb bin Al-Aswad from Abu Dharr. It has been said: Abu Harb only narrates from his uncle from Abu Dharr, and no hearing from Abu Dharr is preserved for him. Abu Dawood also narrated it from Dawud - who is Ibn Abi Hind - from Bakr (1); that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent Abu Dharr with this hadith. Then Abu Dawood said: "And it is the more correct of the two hadiths," meaning that this Mursal is more correct than the first. And Allah knows best. 1646 - (8) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: Two men cursed each other in the presence of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and one of them got exceedingly angry; until I imagined that his nose would tear apart from the intensity of his anger. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed I know a word, if he said it, what he finds of anger would go away from him." He said: What is it, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "He says: O Allah, indeed I seek refuge in You from the accursed Satan." He said: So Mu'adh began ordering him, but he refused and became stubborn (Mahika) (2) and began increasing in anger.
foot_note:
1. He is Ibn Abdullah Al-Muzani. An-Naji said it. I have documented the hadith in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6664). 
2. Original: (Dahika - laughed), and likewise in the 'Amarah' print, which is a strange misspelling having no basis or meaning. The correction is from "Abu Dawood" (4780) and the context belongs to him. And (Al-Mahk): is stubbornness/insistence.

text: Narrated by Abu Dawood, At-Tirmidhi, and An-Nasa'i (1); all from the narration of Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Laila from him. At-Tirmidhi said: "This hadith is Mursal, Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Laila did not hear from Mu'adh bin Jabal. Mu'adh died in the caliphate of Umar bin Al-Khattab, and Umar bin Al-Khattab was killed while Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Laila was a boy of six years." What At-Tirmidhi said is clear; for Al-Bukhari mentioned what indicates that the birth of Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Laila was in the year seventeen, and more than one stated that Mu'adh bin Jabal died in the plague of Amwas in the year eighteen, and it was said year seventeen. An-Nasa'i (2) narrated this hadith from Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Laila from Ubayy bin Ka'b. And this is connected. And Allah knows best. 1647 - (9) [Weak] And from Abu Wa'il the storyteller who said: We entered upon Urwah bin Muhammad As-Sa'di, and a man spoke to him and angered him. So he stood up and performed ablution, then said: My father told me from my grandfather Atiyyah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed anger is from Satan, and indeed Satan was created from fire, and indeed fire is extinguished by water. So if one of you gets angry, let him perform ablution." Narrated by Abu Dawood (3).
foot_note:
1. In "As-Sunan Al-Kubra" (6/ 104/ 10221) without his saying: "So Mu'adh began...", which belongs to Abu Dawood only excluding the others, and likewise Ahmad (5/ 240 and 244) and Ibn Abi Shaybah (5435 and 9631). (Jarir bin Abdul-Hamid) was alone in narrating it without the others, so it is Shadh (anomalous). 
2. I say: Its chain (10223) is Jayyid (good), but its narrator (Yazid bin Ziyad), who is Ibn Abi Al-Ja'd, contradicted the trustworthy narrators referred to previously in its chain, so the chain is Shadh. Furthermore, An-Nasa'i did not mention its wording. However, the Marfu' part of the hadith is witnessed by the hadith of Sulaiman bin Surad (may Allah be pleased with him), mentioned in this chapter of "As-Sahih" under number (10). It is documented in "Ar-Rawd An-Nadir" under the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud with its meaning (635). Despite the author finding a defect of disconnection in the hadith, the three commentators classified it Hasan (3/ 445)! If they had said: "Hasan due to its witnesses" - as is their habit - we would have found some excuse for them. But they... 
3. I say: It contains two unknown narrators as you can see its explanation in "Ad-Da'ifah" (582), yet the three [commentators] also said: "Hasan..."!

text: 11 - (Intimidation regarding shunning one another, harboring malice, and turning backs on one another). 1648 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Ayyub, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Do not turn your backs on one another, and do not cut ties with one another, and be, O servants of Allah, brothers. Shunning a believer is [permissible for] three [days]; if they speak [to each other, it is well], otherwise Allah Almighty turns away from them until they speak." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its narrators are trustworthy; except Abdullah bin Abdul-Aziz Al-Laythi. (1) 1649 - (2) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it [meaning the Hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in the "Sahih"] and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The registers of the people of the earth are copied into the registers of the people of the heaven every Monday and Thursday. So every Muslim who does not associate anything with Allah is forgiven; except a man who has malice between him and his brother." [Passed 9 - Fasting /10]. 1650 - (3) [Weak] And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Deeds are presented on Monday and Thursday. So he who seeks forgiveness is forgiven, and he who repents, his repentance is accepted, and the people of grudges (Dagha'in) are left with their grudges until they repent." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and its narrators are trustworthy. [Passed there]. (Ad-Dagha'in) with the letters Dad and Ghayn with dots: means grudges/hatreds. 1651 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, entered upon me and removed his two garments. Then, before long, he stood up and wore them. Intense jealousy seized me, thinking that he was going to some of my co-wives. So I went out following him until I caught up with him at (Al-Baqi' - Baqi' Al-Gharqad) seeking forgiveness for the believing men, believing women, and the martyrs. I said: May my father and mother be sacrificed for you! You are in the need of your Lord, and I am in the need of the world! So I returned

text: and entered my room, and I was breathing heavily (high breath). The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, caught up with me and said: "What is this breathing, O Aisha?" I said: May my father and mother be sacrificed for you! You came to me and removed your two garments, then before long you stood up and wore them. Intense jealousy seized me, thinking that you were going to some of my co-wives, until I saw you at (Al-Baqi') doing what you were doing. He said: "O Aisha! Did you fear that Allah and His Messenger would deal unjustly with you?! Jibril, peace be upon him, came to me and said: This is the night of the middle of Sha'ban, and Allah has in it those freed from the Fire; equal to the number of the hairs of the sheep of Kalb (1). Allah does not look in it at a polytheist, nor one harboring malice, nor a cutter of kinship ties, nor one who drags his garment (Musbil), nor one disobedient to his parents, nor an addict of wine." She said: Then he removed his two garments and said to me: "O Aisha! Do you give me permission to stand [in prayer] this night?" I said: Yes, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you! So he stood and prostrated for a long night, until I thought that he had passed away. So I stood up to feel for him, and I placed my hand on the sole of his feet, and he moved, so I rejoiced. And I heard him saying in his prostration: "I seek refuge in Your pardon from Your punishment, and I seek refuge in Your pleasure from Your wrath, and I seek refuge in You from You. Glorified is Your Face, I cannot enumerate praise upon You, You are as You have praised Yourself." When it was morning, I mentioned them to him. He said: "O Aisha! Learn them." I said: Yes. He said: "Learn them and teach them; for Jibril, peace be upon him, taught them to me, and commanded me to
foot_note: 1. Meaning: The tribe of (Kalb), which is one of the tribes of Yemen, and to it (Dihyah Al-Kalbi), may Allah be pleased with him, is attributed.

Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi (1). 1652 - (5) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Allah Almighty looks upon His creation on the night of the middle of Sha'ban, so He forgives His servants except two: One harboring malice, and a killer of a soul." Narrated by Ahmad with a lenient chain. [Passed 9 - Fasting /8]. 1653 - (6) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Three things, whoever does not have one of them, Allah forgives whatever is other than that for whom He wills: Whoever dies not associating anything with Allah, and was not a magician who follows sorcerers, and did not bear malice against his brother." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat" from the narration of Layth bin Abi Sulaym. 1654 - (7) [Weak] And from Al-Ala' bin Al-Harith; that Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, stood at night and prayed. text: I said: Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: "This is the night of the middle of Sha'ban. Indeed, Allah Almighty looks upon His servants on the night of the middle of Sha'ban, so He forgives those seeking forgiveness, has mercy on those seeking mercy, and delays the people of hatred as they are." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi as well, and he said: "This is a Jayyid (good) Mursal." [Passed there]. And it is possible that Al-Ala' took it from Makhul. (Al-Azhari said): "It is said of a man if he betrays his companion and does not give him his right: 'Qad khasa bihi' (He betrayed him), meaning with the letter Kha with a dot and the neglected Sin." 1655 - (8) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Three whose prayers do not rise above their heads by a handspan: A man who leads a people while they dislike him, a woman who spends the night while her husband is angry with her, and two brothers who have cut ties with each other." Narrated by Ibn Majah - and the wording is his - and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; except that he said: "Three whose prayer Allah does not accept..." then he mentioned similar to it. [Passed 5 - Prayer /28]. 12 - (Intimidation regarding saying to a Muslim: O Kafir!). [He did not mention under this heading a Hadith meeting the criteria of our book, and praise be to Allah. See the "Sahih"].

text: 13 - (Intimidation regarding verbal abuse and cursing; especially of a specific person, whether human [or animal] or others, and some of what came regarding the prohibition of cursing the rooster (1), the flea, and the wind (2), and intimidation regarding slandering a chaste woman and a slave). 1656 - (1) [Weak] And from Abdullah (3), may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "There are no two Muslims except that there is a screen from Allah Almighty between them. So if one of them says an obscene word (Hujr) to his companion; he rips the screen of Allah." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi thus raised (to the Prophet), and he said: "The correct view is that it is Mawquf (halted at the Companion)." (Al-Hujr) with a Damma on the Ha and a Sukun on the Jim: Is bad and obscene speech. 1657 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and a flea bit a man, so he cursed it. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Do not curse it; for it woke a prophet among the prophets for prayer." Narrated by Abu Ya'la - and the wording is his - and Al-Bazzar; except that he said: "Do not curse it; for it woke a prophet among the prophets for the dawn prayer." And its narrators are the narrators of the "Sahih"; except Suwayd bin Ibrahim (4). And At-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Awsat", and his wording is:
foot_note:

4. I say: And from his path, Al-Bukhari also narrated it in "Al-Adab Al-Mufrad" (1237), and Al-Bayhaqi in "Shu'ab Al-Iman" (2/ 94/ 2) from the path of Sa'id bin Bashir.

text: Fleas were mentioned in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so he said: "They wake one for prayer." And the narrators of At-Tabarani are trustworthy; except Sa'id bin Bashir. 1658 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We stopped at a place and fleas harmed us, so we cursed them. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Do not curse them, for what an excellent creature it is; for it woke you for the remembrance of Allah." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1659 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Whoever mentions a person with something that is not in him to shame him by it; Allah will confine him in the Fire of Hell; until he brings an exhaustion (justification) for what he said about him." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Jayyid (good) chain (1). And it and others will come in "Backbiting" if Allah wills [here /19]. 1660 - (5) [Fabricated] And from Amr bin Al-As, may Allah be pleased with him: That he visited an aunt of his, so she called for food for him. The slave girl was slow, so she said: Will you not hurry, O Zaniyah (Adulteress)! So Amr said: Subhan Allah! You have said something grave! Have you seen adultery from her? She said: No, by Allah. He said: Indeed, I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Any slave or woman who says to her slave girl: 'O Zaniyah!', and has not seen adultery from her; her slave girl will lash her on the Day of Resurrection; because there is no Hadd (legal punishment) for them in this world." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic chain of narration." (Al-Hafiz said): "How so, when Abdul-Malik bin Harun is Matruk (abandoned) and accused (2)." And previously in "Compassion" [20 - Judiciary /10] are Hadiths of this chapter which we did not repeat here.
foot_note:
1. Thus he said! And in it is a weak narrator and others as previously mentioned in (20 - Judiciary /8), and another will come (19 - Chapter). 
2. And Adh-Dhahabi said (4/ 370): "I say: Rather Abdul-Malik [meaning bin Harun bin Antarah] is abandoned by agreement, nay, it was said of him: Dajjal (Imposter)."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 14 - (Intimidation regarding cursing Time/Fate). [He did not mention under this heading a Hadith meeting the criteria of our book, and praise be to Allah. See the "Sahih"]. 15 - (Intimidation regarding scaring a Muslim, and pointing at him with a weapon and the like, whether serious or joking). 1661 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Amir bin Rabi'ah, may Allah be pleased with him: That a man took the sandal of another man and hid it while joking. That was mentioned to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Do not scare the Muslim; for the scaring of a Muslim is a great oppression." Narrated by Al-Bazzar, At-Tabarani, and Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan in "Kitab At-Tawbikh". 1662 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Al-Hasan - and he was an Aqabi (present at Aqabah pledge) and Badri (present at Badr) - may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were sitting with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when a man stood up and forgot his sandals. A man took them and placed them under him. The man returned and said: My sandals. The people said: We didn't see them. Then [a man] (1) said: Here they are. He (the Prophet) said: "Then how about the scare of the believer?!" He said: O Messenger of Allah! I only did it playing. He said: "Then how about the scare of the believer?! (Twice or thrice)." Narrated by At-Tabarani.
foot_note: 1. Addition from "Mu'jam At-Tabarani" (22/ 395), and in it is Husain bin Abdullah Al-Hashimi, and he is weak.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1663 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Whoever scares a believer; it is a right upon Allah not to secure him from the terrors of the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 1664 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever looks at a Muslim with a look by which he scares him without right; Allah will scare him on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 1665 - (5) [?] And Abu Ash-Sheikh narrated it from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah.

text: 16 - (Encouragement to reconcile between people). 1666 - (1) [Very Munkar] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Whoever reconciles between people; Allah sets right his affair, and gives him for every word he spoke the [reward of] freeing a slave, and he returns having been forgiven for what preceded of his sin." Narrated by Al-Asbahani, and it is a very strange (Gharib) Hadith.
foot_note: None

text: 17 - (Intimidation regarding a man's brother apologizing to him and him not accepting his excuse). 1667 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Be chaste regarding the women of people; your women will be chaste. Be dutiful to your fathers; your sons will be dutiful to you. And whoever's brother comes to him apologizing, let him accept that, whether he was right or wrong; for if he does not do so; he will not come to me at the Pond (Hawd)." Narrated by Al-Hakim from the narration of Suwayd from Qatadah from Abu Rafi' from him. And he said: "Authentic chain of narration." (Al-Hafiz said): "Nay, this Suwayd is Ibn Abdul-Aziz, feeble." [Passed 22 - Righteousness /1]. 1668 - (2) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani and others narrated the beginning of it without his saying: "And whoever's brother comes to him" to the end, from the Hadith of Ibn Umar with a Hasan chain (1). [Passed there]. (At-tanassul): Apologizing. 1669 - (3) [Mursal and Weak] And from Jawdan who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever apologizes to his Muslim brother and he does not accept from him; upon him is [a sin] like that of a tax collector." Narrated by Abu Dawud in "Al-Marasil", and Ibn Majah with two Jayyid (good) chains (2); except that he said:
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, and in it is an accused narrator as previously explained in the comment on it there.

It is referenced in "Ghayat Al-Maram" (p. 236) and "Ad-Da'ifah" (6665). And the statement of the three commentators: "Hasan Mursal" is from their blind imitation and ignorance of this science.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Upon him is the like of the sin of a tax collector." 1670 - (4) [Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Awsat" from the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah, and his wording is: He said: "Whoever apologizes to his brother and he does not accept his excuse; upon him is the like of the sin of a tax collector (Makkas)." Be dutiful to your fathers; your sons will be dutiful to you. And whoever apologizes to his Muslim brother and he does not accept his excuse; will not come to me at the Pond." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" (1). 1672 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Shall I not inform you of the worst of you?" They said: Yes, if you wish, O Messenger of Allah! He said:
foot_note: 1. I say: In its chain (7/ 160/ 6291) is Khalid bin Yazid Al-Umari - and he is a liar - from Abdul-Malik bin Yahya bin Az-Zubayr, who is unknown and no one considered him trustworthy except Ibn Hibban (7/ 95).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Indeed, the worst of you is the one who stays alone, beats his slave, and withholds his giving. Shall I not inform you of one worse than that?" They said: Yes, if you wish, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "He who hates people and they hate him." He said: "Shall I not inform you of one worse than that?" They said: Yes, if you wish, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Those who do not forgive a slip, nor accept an excuse, nor forgive a sin." He said: "Shall I not inform you of one worse than that?" They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "He from whom good is not hoped, and from whose evil one is not safe." Narrated by At-Tabarani and others.
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 18 - (Intimidation regarding Namimah (Tale-bearing)). 1673 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, passed on a very hot day towards (Baqi' Al-Gharqad). He said: People were walking behind him. He said: When he heard the sound of sandals, that affected his soul, so he sat until he put them in front of him, lest any arrogance enter his soul. When he passed by (Baqi' Al-Gharqad), he came upon two graves in which two men had been buried. He said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, stopped and said: "Who did you bury here today?" They said: So-and-so and So-and-so. [He said: "Indeed, they are being punished right now and tried in their graves"]. They said: O Prophet of Allah! And what is that (reason)? He said: "As for one of them, he did not keep himself clean from urine. And as for the other, he used to walk with tale-bearing." And he took a fresh palm branch, split it, then placed it on the [two] grave[s]. They said: O Prophet of Allah! Why did you do this? He said: "To lighten it for them." They said: O Prophet of Allah! Until when will they be punished? He said: "Unseen which no one knows but Allah. And were it not for the turmoil in your hearts, and your excess in speech; you would hear what I hear." Narrated by Ahmad from the path of Ali bin Yazid from Al-Qasim from him (1).
foot_note: 1. The Hadith passed in (4 - Purity /4), so see the discussion on it there.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1674 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Tale-bearing, verbal abuse, and partisanship are in the Fire." [Very Weak] And in a wording: "Indeed, tale-bearing and malice are in the Fire; they do not gather in the heart of a Muslim." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 1675 - (3) [Fabricated] And from Abu Barzah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Beware, indeed lying blackens the face, and tale-bearing is from the punishment of the grave." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, At-Tabarani, Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Bayhaqi. (Al-Hafiz said): "They all narrated it from the path of Ziyad bin Al-Mundhir from Nafi' bin Al-Harith from him. Ziyad is Abu Al-Jarud Al-Kufi, the blind; the Jarudiyyah sect of the Rafidah is attributed to him. (And Nafi') is Nufay' Abu Dawud, also blind, and both are abandoned and accused of fabrication" (1). 1676 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Busr, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "He is not of me who is envious, nor a tale-bearer, nor a fortune-teller, nor am I of him. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, recited: {And those who harm believing men and believing women for [something] other than what they have earned have certainly born upon themselves a slander and manifest sin}." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 1677 - (5) [Weak] And from Al-Ala' bin Al-Harith, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The backbiters (Hammazun), the slanderers (Lammazun), those who walk with tale-bearing, those who seek faults in the innocent; Allah will gather them in the faces of dogs." Narrated by Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan in "Kitab At-Tawbikh" as Mu'dal (perplexing/disconnected) like this.
foot_note: 1. I say: It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1496).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 19 - (Intimidation regarding Ghibah (backbiting) and Bahat (slander) and their explanation, and encouragement to refute them). 1678 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: "Indeed, Riba (usury) is seventy-some doors. The least of them is like one who has intercourse with his mother in Islam. And a Dirham of Riba is worse than thirty-five acts of adultery. The worst of Riba, the most growing of Riba, and the vilest of Riba is violating the honor of a Muslim and violating his sanctity." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and Al-Bayhaqi. At-Tabarani narrated the mention of Riba from it in a Hadith that passed [16 - Sales /19]. 1679 - (2) [Weak] And from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to his Companions: "Do you know what is the worst Riba with Allah?" They said: Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: "Indeed, the worst Riba with Allah is considering the honor of a Muslim lawful. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, recited: {And those who harm believing men and believing women for [something] other than what they have earned}." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and its narrators are the narrators of the "Sahih" (1). 1680 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from her that she said: I said to a woman once while I was with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: Indeed, she has a long skirt tail! He said:
foot_note: 1. Thus he said! And Al-Haythami followed him, and it is a mistake arising from the illusion of the narrator in its chain (8/ 4689) (Imran bin Anas Al-Makki) thinking he is the Madani. The first is weak, and the other is trustworthy from the men of Muslim, as per a verification you can see in "Ghayat Al-Maram" (251-253). This was hidden from many, including the commentator on "Musnad Abu Ya'la" so he said: "Its chain is authentic"! Being deceived by Al-Haythami's statement referred to! And the three commentators said: "Hasan"! And they did not authenticate it, striving [incorrectly]!!

text: "Alfizi Alfizi (Spit it out, spit it out)." So I spat out a piece of meat. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. (Alfizi) means: Throw what is in your mouth. And (Al-Bad'ah): The piece. 1681 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and a man stood up. They said: O Messenger of Allah! How incapable - or they said: How weak - So-and-so is! The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "You have backbitten your companion, and eaten his flesh." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and At-Tabarani (1) and his wording is: That a man stood up from the presence of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and they saw incapacity in his standing. They said: How incapable So-and-so is! The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "You ate your brother and backbit him." 1682 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, commanded the people to fast a day, and said: "Let no one (2) break his fast until I give him permission." So the people fasted until evening came. A man would come and say: O Messenger of Allah!
foot_note:
1. I say: He only narrated it in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat" (1/ 283-284/ 461), then said: "No one narrated it except Hammad bin Abi Humayd." And he is very weak as Al-Haythami said. 
2. The original: (Ahadun minkum - one of you), and the correction is from "Al-Ghibah" (53-55/ 31), and likewise "As-Samt" by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya (106/ 170), and from them is the following addition. In the chain of all is (Yazid bin Aban Ar-Raqashi), and he is abandoned as in "Al-Mughni", and likewise the narrator from him Ar-Rabi' bin Badr.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: I have remained fasting, so give me permission to break my fast. So he would give him permission; man after man. Until a man came and said: O Messenger of Allah! Two young women from your family remained fasting, and they are shy to come to you, so give them permission to break their fast. He turned away from him. Then he returned to him, and he turned away from him. Then he returned to him, and he turned away from him. Then he returned to him, and he turned away from him. He said: "They did not fast, and how has one fasted who spent this day eating the flesh of people?! Go and order them, if they were fasting, to vomit." So he returned to them and informed them. They vomited, and each one of them vomited [from it] a clot of blood. He returned to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and informed him. He said: "By the One in whose hand is the soul of Muhammad! Had they remained in their bellies, the Fire would have eaten them." Narrated by Abu Dawud At-Tayalisi, Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Dhamm Al-Ghibah" (Condemnation of Backbiting), and Al-Bayhaqi. 1683 - (6) [Weak] And Ahmad, Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya as well, and Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from the narration of a man who was not named from Ubayd, the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with similar meaning; except that Ahmad said: He said to one of them: "Vomit." She vomited pus, blood, suppuration, and flesh, until she filled half the bowl. Then he said to the other: "Vomit." She vomited pus, blood, suppuration, fresh flesh, and other things, until she filled the bowl. Then he said: "These two fasted from what Allah made lawful for them, and broke their fast on what Allah made forbidden for them,
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: one of them sat with the other, and they started eating from the flesh of people." And Ahmad's wording passed in its entirety in "Fasting" [9/ 21]. 1684 - (7) [Weak] And from Shufayy bin Mati' Al-Asbahi; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Four harm the people of the Fire along with the harm they already have. They run between the boiling water and the Hellfire, calling out for woe and destruction. Some of the people of the Fire say to others: What is the matter with these, they have harmed us along with the harm we already have? - He said: - A man locked in a coffin of hot coals, a man dragging his intestines, a man whose mouth flows with pus and blood, and a man eating his own flesh! It is said to the owner of the coffin: What is the matter with the distant one (Al-Ab'ad), he has harmed us along with the harm we already have?! He says: Indeed, the distant one died while having people's wealth on his neck. Then it is said to the one dragging his intestines: What is the matter with the distant one, he has harmed us along with the harm we already have?! He says: Indeed, the distant one did not care where urine touched him [he did not wash it]. Then it is said to the one whose mouth flows with pus and blood: What is the matter with the distant one, he has harmed us along with the harm we already have?! He says: Indeed, the distant one used to look at a word and find pleasure in it just as obscene speech (Ar-Rafath) is enjoyed. Then it is said to the one eating his own flesh: What is the matter with the distant one, he has harmed us along with the harm we already have?! He says: Indeed, the distant one used to eat the flesh of people through backbiting and walk with tale-bearing." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab As-Samt" and in "Dhamm Al-Ghibah", and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" with a lenient chain, and Abu Nu'aym who said: "Shufayy bin Mati' is disputed regarding his companionship; it was said: He has companionship." [Passed 4 - Purity /4]. (Al-Hafiz said): "Shufayy was mentioned by Al-Bukhari and Ibn Hibban among the Tabi'in." 1685 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever eats the flesh of his brother in the world; it will be brought near to him on the Day of Resurrection and it will be said to him: Eat it dead
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: as you ate it alive. So he will eat it, and scowl and scream (Yadijj)." Narrated by Abu Ya'la and At-Tabarani, and Abu Ash-Sheikh in "Kitab At-Tawbikh"; except that he said: (Yasih - cry out) (1) with the neglected Sad. All of them from the narration of Muhammad bin Ishaq, and the rest of the narrators of some of them are trustworthy (2). (Yadijj) with the Dad with a dot followed by Jim, and (Yasih); both have one meaning; thus said some linguists. It appears that the word (Yadijj) with the Dad with a dot contains an additional indication of panic or anxiety. And Allah knows best. And (Yaklah) with the neglected Ha; meaning: He frowns and contracts his face from dislike. 1686 - (9) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Aslami man came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and testified against himself regarding adultery four times, saying: I approached a woman unlawfully. And in each time the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, turned away from him. He mentioned the Hadith until he said: - He said: "What do you want with this statement?" He said: I want you to purify me. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered him to be stoned, so he was stoned. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, heard two men from the Ansar, one saying to his companion: Look at this one whom Allah concealed, but he did not leave himself alone until he was stoned like the stoning of a dog! He said: So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, remained silent. Then he traveled for an hour, and passed by the carcass of a donkey with its leg raised (3). He said: "Where are So-and-so and So-and-so?" They said: We are here, O Messenger of Allah! He said to them:
foot_note:
1. Meaning: From shouting (Sayah), and the first is from clamor (Dajij). It appears that (Yasih) is a distortion of (Yadijj) due to its closeness to it. And Allah knows best. Said by An-Naji. 
2. I say: The defect is the 'an'anah (narrating with 'from') of (Ibn Ishaq) for he is a Mudallis, and it is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6316). 
3. Meaning: Lifting it.

text: "Eat from the carcass of this donkey." They said: O Messenger of Allah! May Allah forgive you your past and future sins; who would eat from this? The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "What you obtained from the honor of this man just now; is worse than eating this carcass. By the One in whose hand is my soul! He is now in the rivers of Paradise." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (1). 1687 - (10) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: "The night the Prophet of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was taken on the Night Journey, he looked into the Fire, and there were people eating carrion. He said: Who are these, O Jibril? He said: These are those who eat the flesh of people. And he saw a man, red, blue, curly-haired (2) [disheveled when you see him]. He said: Who is this, O Jibril? He said: This is the killer of the She-Camel (of Salih)." Narrated by Ahmad, and its narrators are the narrators of the "Sahih"; except Qabus bin Abi Zabyan. 1688 - (11) [Very Weak] And from Rashid bin Sa'd Al-Maqra'i who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "When I was ascended; I passed by men whose skins were being cut with scissors of fire. I said: Who are these, O Jibril? He said: Those who beautify themselves for adultery. He said: Then I passed by a well foul of smell, and I heard intense voices in it. I said: Who are these, O Jibril? He said: Women who used to beautify themselves for adultery, and do what is not lawful for them. Then I passed by women and men hanging
foot_note:

text: by their breasts. I said: Who are these, O Jibril? He said: These are the slanderers (Lammazun) and backbiters (Hammazun), and that is the saying of Allah Almighty: {Woe to every backbiter and slanderer}." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi from the narration of Baqiyyah from Sa'id bin Sinan (1) and he said: "This is Mursal, and we have narrated it connected (Mawsul)." [Ibn Al-Mubarak] said: And it reached me from Al-Layth that he said: (Al-Lumazah): The one who faults you to your face, and (Al-Humazah): The one who faults you in absence. 1690 - (13) [Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah and Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with them, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Backbiting is worse than adultery." Razin mentioned it, but I did not see it in any of his sources with this wording, rather At-Tirmidhi narrated the beginning of it and authenticated it (1) and did not mention "envy", rather he said: "for wealth and honor", and the rest of the hadith was previously mentioned by Abu Dawud from the hadith of Abu Hurairah [here in the chapter]. 1727 - (5) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to me: "O my son! If you are able to wake up and go to sleep without any deception in your heart towards anyone, then do so" the Hadith. Narrated by At-Tirmidhi who said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith" (2). 1728 - (6) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were sitting with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, when he said: "A man from the people of Paradise will rise upon you now."
foot_note:
1. It is as he said, and it will come in (24 - Asceticism /6). 
2. I say: In its chain (2678) is Ali bin Zaid - who is Ibn Jud'an - and he is weak.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Then a man from the Ansar rose, his beard dripping from his wudu (ablution), holding his sandals in his left hand. When it was the next day, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said the same thing, and that man rose just like the first time. When it was the third day, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said the same statement again, and that man rose in the same state as the first. When the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, stood up, Abdullah bin Amr followed him and said: I quarreled with my father and swore that I would not enter upon him for three [days], so if you see fit to shelter me with you until they pass, I will do so? He said: Yes. Anas said: So Abdullah used to narrate that he spent those three nights with him, and he did not see him wake up for prayer at night at all, except that when he turned over and tossed in his bed, he remembered Allah Almighty and magnified Him until he [got up] (1) for the dawn prayer. Abdullah said: Except that I did not hear him say anything but good. When the three nights passed, and I almost belittled his deed, I said: O servant of Allah! There was no anger or desertion between me and my father, but I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say about you three times: "A man from the people of Paradise rises upon you now," and you rose on the three occasions. So I wanted to stay with you to see what your deed is, so that I could imitate it, but I did not see you do much deed. So what is it that reached with you to what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said? He said: It is nothing but what you saw. When I turned away, he called me and said: It is nothing but what you saw; except that I do not find in myself any deception towards any of the Muslims, nor do I envy anyone for any good that Allah has given him. Abdullah said: This is what reached with you, [and it is what we cannot endure] (2).
foot_note:
1. And 
2. The addition is from "Al-Musnad" and its origin is the "Musannaf" of Abdur-Razzaq, and the context belongs to Ahmad.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ahmad with a chain on the condition of Al-Bukhari and Muslim (1), and An-Nasa'i, and their narrators are relied upon by them as well; except his Sheikh Suwaid bin Nasr, and he is trustworthy. And Abu Ya'la and Al-Bazzar [narrated] similarly, and named the ambiguous man Sa'd, and said at the end of it: "So Sa'd said: It is nothing but what you saw, O son of my brother! Except that I do not spend the night bearing a grudge against a Muslim, or a word similar to it." An-Nasa'i added in a narration of his, and Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Asbahani: So Abdullah said: This is what reached with you, and it is what we cannot endure. 1729 - (7) [Weak] And Al-Bayhaqi also narrated it (2) from Salim bin Abdullah from his father who said: We were sitting with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he said: "A man from the people of Paradise will surely rise upon you from this door." Then Sa'd bin Malik came and entered from it - Al-Bayhaqi said: So he mentioned the hadith and said: - So Abdullah bin Umar said: I will not stop until I spend the night with this man to observe his deed - he said: So he mentioned the hadith regarding
foot_note:
1. I say: It is as he said, were it not that it is disconnected (Munqati') between Az-Zuhri and Anas; between them is a man who was not named, as stated by Al-Hafiz Hamza Al-Kinani according to what Al-Hafiz Al-Mizzi mentioned in "Tuhfat Al-Ashraf" (1/ 395), then Al-Naji, who said (198/ 2): "And this defect was not noticed by the author." Then he noted that An-Nasa'i only narrated it in "Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah" not in "Al-Sunan" according to the recurring custom in the book, so be aware. I say: Abdur-Razzaq extracted it in "Al-Musannaf" (11/ 287/ 20559), and from his path a group including Ahmad: He said: Ma'mar informed us from Az-Zuhri who said: Anas bin Malik informed me. This chain is apparently authentic, and the author and Al-Iraqi in "Takhrij Al-Ihya" (3/ 187) proceeded on that, and we proceeded on that for a period of time, until the defect became clear. Al-Bayhaqi said in "Al-Shu'ab" after it (5/ 265): "And Ibn Al-Mubarak narrated it from Ma'mar and said: From Ma'mar, from Az-Zuhri, from Anas. And Shu'ayb bin Abi Hamzah narrated it from Az-Zuhri, saying: Someone I do not accuse narrated to me from Anas... and likewise 'Aqil bin Khalid narrated it from Az-Zuhri", see "A'lam Al-Nubala" (1/ 109). Therefore, Al-Hafiz said after it in "Al-Nukat Al-Ziraf 'ala Al-Atraf": "It has become apparent that it is defective (Ma'lul)." 
2. I say: It contains Salih Al-Murri, and he is weak. And it contradicts the hadith before it in several ways as is apparent, yet the ignorant ones said: "Hasan due to its witness mentioned before"!

text: his entering upon him, he said: - So he handed me a cloak and I lay down on it near him, and I began observing him with my eye for a night. Whenever he woke up (Ta'arra), he glorified Allah (Tasbih), magnified Him (Takbir), declared His oneness (Tahlil), and praised Allah (Tahmid). Until the time of Suhur (pre-dawn) came, he stood up, performed ablution, then entered the mosque and prayed twelve Rak'ahs, with twelve Surahs from the Mufassal, not from the long ones nor the short ones, supplicating in every two Rak'ahs after the Tashahhud with three supplications; saying: (O Allah, give us good in this world and good in the Hereafter and protect us from the punishment of the Fire. O Allah, suffice us in what worries us of the matter of our Hereafter and our world. O Allah, we ask You for all good, and I seek refuge in You from all evil). Until when he finished - he said: So he mentioned the hadith about his belittling of his deed and his returning to him three times until he said: - So he said: I take to my bed, and there is no rancor (Ghimr) in my heart against anyone. (Tantifu) means: dripping. (Lahaytu) with an un-dotted Ha followed by a Ya underneath; meaning: I quarreled. (Ta'arra) with a Shaddah on the Ra, meaning: woke up. (Al-Ghimr) with a Kasrah on the dotted Ghayn and a Sukun on the Mim: is hatred/grudge. 1730 - (8) [Weak] And it was narrated from Al-Hasan who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, the Substitutes (Al-Abdal) of my Ummah did not enter Paradise by much prayer, nor fasting, nor charity, but they entered it by the mercy of Allah, generosity of souls, and soundness of breasts." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab Al-Awliya" as Mursal. 1731 - (9) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Successful is he who purifies his heart for faith, makes his heart sound, his tongue truthful, his soul content, and his character straight" the Hadith. Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi, and it was previously mentioned in its entirety in [the chapter of] "Sincerity" [1/ 1].
foot_note: None

text: 22 - (Encouragement of Humility, and Intimidation against Pride, Self-Conceit, and Boasting). 1732 - (1) [Weak] And from Nasih Al-Ansi from Rakb Al-Masri who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Tuba (Blessedness) is for him who humbled himself without deficiency, and lowered himself without poverty (1), and spent wealth he collected without disobedience, and had mercy on the people of humiliation and poverty, and mixed with the people of understanding and wisdom. Tuba is for him whose earnings are good, whose inner self is righteous, whose outer self is honorable, and who isolates his evil from people. Tuba is for him who acts upon his knowledge, spends the surplus of his wealth, and withholds the surplus of his speech." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and his narrators up to Nasih are trustworthy, and Abu Umar An-Namari and others graded this hadith Hasan. As for Rakb; Al-Baghawi said: "I do not know if he heard from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, or not?", and Ibn Mandah said: "We do not know of him having Companionship (Suhbah)." Others mentioned that he has Companionship, and I do not know of any other hadith for him (2). 1733 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Whoever humbles himself to Allah a degree; Allah raises him a degree, until He places him in the highest of 'Illiyyin (High Stations), and whoever acts arrogantly towards Allah a degree; Allah lowers him a degree, until He places him in the lowest of the low. Even if one of you were to work in a solid rock that has no door or opening (Kuwwah) (3);
foot_note:
1. The original: (Mas'alah - begging), and the affirmed is from "Al-Tabarani Al-Kabir" (5/ 69) and others, and it is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (3835). 
2. I say: The investigation is that he is unknown (Majhul), he and (Nasih), as Adh-Dhahabi stated. 
3. With a Fathah on the Kaf or a Dammah: A hole in the house.

text: what he hid would come out to people, whatever it was." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; both from the path of Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham from him, and Ibn Majah does not have "Even if one of you" to the end. 1734 - (3) [Fabricated] And [At-Tabarani narrated the hadith of Umar bin Al-Khattab which is in "Al-Sahih" (1) and his wording is: Umar bin Al-Khattab said on the pulpit: O people! Be humble, for I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Whoever humbles himself to Allah; Allah raises him, and says: May Allah raise you (Inta'ish na'ashak Allah), so he is great in the eyes of people, and small in himself. And whoever is arrogant; Allah crushes him, and says: Be driven away (Ikhsa'), so he is small in the eyes of people, and great in himself." 1735 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever humbles himself to his Muslim brother; Allah raises him, and whoever rises above him; Allah lowers him." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1736 - (5) [Weak Mawquf] And from Abdullah - meaning Ibn Mas'ud - may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Whoever shows off; Allah exposes him, and whoever seeks reputation, Allah makes him heard of (in a bad way), and whoever lengthens himself in self-aggrandizement, Allah lowers him, and whoever humbles himself in fear; Allah raises him. The Hadith. Narrated by At-Tabarani from the narration of Al-Mas'udi, and its elevation (Raf' - attributing to Prophet) is not in my two originals. 1737 - (6) [Very Weak] And from Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Beware of pride; for pride can be in a man even if he is wearing a cloak (Abaya)."
foot_note: 1. It gives the illusion that it is in "Al-Kabir" but it is not in it, and Al-Haythami (8/ 82) restricted it to "Al-Awsat". And it is in it under number (9/ 141/ 8303). And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it in "Al-Tawadu'" (102/ 78), and Al-Bayhaqi in "Al-Shu'ab" (6/ 275/ 8139) with a Hasan chain from Umar as Mawquf (stopped at the Companion), and that is the correct view.

text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and its narrators are trustworthy (1). 1738 - (7) [Weak] And from him [meaning Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him]: He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The first three to enter the Fire were presented to me: An imposed ruler, a wealthy person from whose wealth the right of Allah is not paid, and a proud poor person." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs". [Previously mentioned in 8 - Charity /2]. 1739 - (8) [Munkar - Denounced] And from Nafi', the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "An arrogant poor person will not enter Paradise, nor an old adulterer, nor one who reminds Allah of his deeds." Narrated by At-Tabarani from the narration of As-Sabah bin Khalid bin Abi Umayyah from Nafi'. And its narrators up to As-Sabah are trustworthy. [Previously mentioned in 21 - Hudud / 7]. 1740 - (9) [Weak] And from Uqbah bin Amir, may Allah be pleased with him; that he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "There is no man who dies, when he dies, and in his heart is a mustard seed's weight of pride; that Paradise is lawful for him to smell its scent, nor does he see it" the Hadith. Narrated by Ahmad from the narration of Shahr bin Hawshab from a man who was not named from him. 1741 - (10) [Munkar - Denounced] And it was narrated from Kuraib who said: I was leading Ibn Abbas in the alley of Abu Lahab, so he said: O Kuraib! Have we reached such and such place! I said: You are at it now. So he said: Al-Abbas bin Abdul-Muttalib told me

text: He said: "While I was with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in this place, a man came strutting between two garments, looking at his sides, and his self had impressed him; suddenly Allah caused the earth to swallow him in this place, so he sinks down in it until the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Abu Ya'la. 1742 - (11) [Weak] And it was narrated from Asma bint Umais, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Miserable is the servant, a servant who imagines and becomes arrogant, and forgets the Great, the Exalted. Miserable is the servant, a servant who becomes tyrannical and commits aggression, and forgets the Compeller, the Most High. Miserable is the servant, a servant who is negligent and amused, and forgets the graves and decay. Miserable is the servant, a servant who rebels and transgresses, and forgets the Beginning and the End. [Miserable is the servant, a servant who hunts the world with religion] (1). Miserable is the servant, a servant who hunts religion with doubts (2). Miserable is the servant, a servant whom greed leads. Miserable is the servant, a servant whom desire misguides. Miserable is the servant, a servant whom desire humiliates." [Weak] Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib Hadith, [and its chain is not strong]." And At-Tabarani narrated it from the hadith of Nu'aim bin Hammar Al-Ghatafani more concisely than it, and it was previously mentioned [16 - Sales /6].
foot_note:
1. Meaning: He seeks the world by means of the Hereafter. It is said: (Khatalahu Yakhtiluhu): If he deceived him and dodged him, and the wolf hunts (Khatala) the prey if he hides for it. "Nihayah". And the addition is from At-Tirmidhi. 
2. The original: (With desires - bil-shahawat), Al-Naji said (119/ 2): "It is a misspelling without doubt, and it is only (with doubts - bil-shubuhat), and that is the wording of At-Tirmidhi, and likewise the wording of the concise At-Tabarani which the author presented in 'Al-Wara' wa Tark Al-Shubuhat': 'A servant who makes prohibitions lawful by doubts', and this is apparent due to the hidden nature of it".

text: 1743 - (12) [Weak] And from Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Verily, in Hell there is a valley called: (Habhab), it is a right upon Allah to settle in it every stubborn tyrant." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, At-Tabarani, and Al-Hakim; all of them from the narration of Azhar bin Sinan. And Al-Hakim said: "Correct chain." [Previously mentioned 20 - Judiciary /2]. (Habhab) with a Fathah on the two Has and two Bas. 1744 - (13) [Weak] And from Salamah bin Al-Akwa', may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A man continues to exalt himself until he is written among the tyrants, so he is afflicted by what afflicted them." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan [Gharib] Hadith (1)". His saying: (Yadh-habu binafsihi - goes with himself) means: he elevates himself and becomes arrogant. 23 - (Intimidation against saying to a Fasiq (sinner) or Innovator: "My Master" (Sayyidi), or similar words indicating glorification). [The hadith under this is not on the condition of our book, and praise be to Allah. See "Al-Sahih"].

text: 24 - (Encouragement of Truthfulness, and Intimidation against Lying). 1745 - (1) [Weak Mu'dal] And from Mansur bin Al-Mu'tamir who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Seek truthfulness even if you see that destruction is in it, for indeed salvation is in it." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab Al-Samt" (The Book of Silence) like this as Mu'dal (perplexing/disconnected), and its narrators are trustworthy. 1746 - (2) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both: That a man came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah! What is the deed of Paradise? He said: "Truthfulness; if the servant speaks the truth, he becomes righteous, and if he becomes righteous, he believes, and if he believes, he enters Paradise." He said: O Messenger of Allah! And what is the deed of the Fire? He said: "Lying; if the servant lies, he becomes wicked, and if he becomes wicked, he disbelieves, and if he disbelieves, he - meaning enters the Fire." Narrated by Ahmad from the narration of Ibn Lahi'ah. 1747 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And from Malik; that it reached him; that Ibn Mas'ud said: A servant continues to lie and seek lying, until a black spot is impressed upon his heart, until his heart becomes black, so he is written with Allah among the liars. Malik mentioned it in "Al-Muwatta" like this, and it was previously mentioned similarly as connected and raised (Marfu') (1). 1748 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The believer is naturally disposed to all traits; except treachery and lying." Narrated by Ahmad, he said: Waki' told us: I heard Al-A'mash say: I was told from

Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi who said: "The correct view is that it is Mawquf." 1752 - (8) [Mursal Weak] And from Safwan bin Sulaim who said: It was said: O Messenger of Allah! Can a believer be a coward? Narrated by Ahmad from the narration of Ibn Lahi'ah. 1754 - (10) [Weak] And from An-Nawwas bin Sam'an, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "It is a great treachery that you tell your brother a hadith (statement); in which he believes you, while you are lying to him." text: Narrated by Abu Ya'la and At-Tabarani, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Bayhaqi; all of them from the narration of Ziyad bin Al-Mundhir from Nafi' bin Al-Harith [from him]. And the discussion on them was previously mentioned in "Namimah" [Here /18]. 1757 - (13) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Righteousness to parents increases life, Lying decreases provision, and Dua (supplication) repels the Decree." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. 1758 - (14) [Very Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "If a servant lies, the Angel moves a mile away from him; due to the stench of what he came with." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab Al-Samt", and At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Hadith" (1). 1759 - (15) [Weak] And from Asma bint Umais (2), may Allah be pleased with her, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! If one of us says about something she desires: 'I do not desire it', is that counted as a lie? He said: "Indeed, lying is written as lying; until the little lie is written as a little lie." Narrated by Ahmad - within a hadith - and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Al-Samt", and Al-Bayhaqi; all of them from the narration of Yunus bin Yazid Al-Ayli from Abu Shaddad from Shahr bin Hawshab from her, and from Abu Shaddad also from Mujahid from her. And some of our sheikhs claimed that Abu Shaddad is unknown and no one narrated from him except Ibn Juraij. But Yunus also narrated from him as we mentioned, and others, and he is not unknown. And Allah knows best.
foot_note:
1. Thus he said! And it contains someone whom Ad-Daraqutni accused of lying. See "Al-Da'ifah" (1828). 
2. The original: (Yazid), which is a mistake, for the hadith is in "Al-Musnad" (6/ 438), and "Al-Samt" (256/ 520), and "Shu'ab Al-Iman" (4/ 210/ 4821) from the hadith of Asma bint Umais, and from the second path, meaning from Yunus Al-Ayli from Abu Shaddad from Mujahid from Asma. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 26 - (Intimidation against Swearing by other than Allah, especially by Trust (Amanah), and against saying: "I am innocent of Islam" or "A disbeliever", and similar to that). 1761 - (1) [Very Weak] And Ibn Majah narrated from the hadith of Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, heard a man say: I am then a Jew. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "It has become incumbent [upon him]" (2).

1. I say: It is only authentic with the wording: "...two tongues of fire", and it is in "Al-Sahih" here, and referenced in "Al-Sahihah" (892) from paths that strengthen each other. 
2. Al-Busiri found a defect in it due to the 'an'anah of Baqiyyah, and the three followed him, but it is more appropriate to defect it due to his Sheikh (Abdullah bin Muharrir), for he is Matruk (abandoned) as Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Taqrib".

text: 27 - (Intimidation against despising a Muslim, and that no one has superiority over another except by Taqwa (Piety)). 1762 - (1) [Mursal Weak] And from Al-Hasan who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, for those who mock people, a door from Paradise will be opened for one of them in the Hereafter, and it will be said to him: Come! Come! So he comes with his distress and grief; and when he reaches it, it is closed before him. Then another door is opened for him, and it is said to him: Come! Come! So he comes with his distress and grief, and when he reaches it, it is closed before him. This continues until the door from the doors of Paradise is opened for one of them, and it is said to him: Come, but he does not come due to despair." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi as Mursal (1). 1763 - (2) [Very Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When it is the Day of Resurrection, Allah commands a caller to call out: Verily, I established a lineage, and you established a lineage. I made the most noble of you the most pious of you, but you refused except to say: So-and-so son of So-and-so is better than So-and-so son of So-and-so! So today I raise My lineage, and I lower your lineage." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and "Al-Saghir", and Al-Bayhaqi as Marfu' and Mawquf, and he said: "The preserved version is Mawquf" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: Along with its being Mursal from (Al-Hasan) who is Al-Basri, the chain to him is weak, containing (Al-Mubarak) from him. He is Ibn Fadalah, and he is a Mudallis (obfuscator), and he narrated with 'an' (from). 
2. I say: It is with Al-Bayhaqi in "Al-Shu'ab" (4/ 289 - 290/ 5139 - 5140) from the path of Talhah bin Amr... as Mawquf and Marfu'. And Talhah is Matruk. And it is referenced in "Al-Rawd Al-Nadir" (1065).

text: 28 - (Encouragement of Removing Harm from the Road, and other things that are mentioned). 1764 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Upon every joint (Maysam) of a human is a charity (Sadaqah) every day." A man from the people said: This is one of the hardest things you have informed us of. He said: "Your enjoining good and your forbidding evil is a charity, your carrying for the weak is a charity, your removing filth from the road is a charity, and every step you take towards prayer is a charity." Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih". [Previously mentioned 5 - Prayer /9]. 1765 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, told a hadith, and we have not rejoiced at anything since we knew Islam more intensely than our rejoicing at it. He said: "Indeed, the believer is rewarded for removing harm from the road, and for guiding the way, and for his expressing for the inarticulate (Artham) (1), and for his granting of milk, until he is rewarded for the goods that are bundled, and he touches them and his hand misses them, so his heart flutters because of that, so Allah returns them to him, and their reward is written for him." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and Al-Bazzar who added: "Indeed he is rewarded for coming to his wife, until he is rewarded for the goods that are in the edge of his garment and he touches them and misses their place - or a word similar to it -; so his heart flutters because of that, so Allah returns them to him, and their reward is written for him." And in its chain is Al-Minhal bin Khalifah, and he was authenticated by more than one. And what testifies for this hadith was previously mentioned (2).
foot_note:
1. He is the one who cannot correct his speech nor clarify it; due to a defect in his tongue or teeth, "Nihayah". 
2. I say: Except for the issue of the goods, for no witness was previously mentioned for it, and the chain is weak, as I explained in "Al-Da'ifah" (2276). And the three commentators overlooked this detail so they said: "Hasan due to its witnesses"! And they did not make an exception!

text: 29 - (Encouragement of Killing the Gecko (1), and what came regarding killing snakes and others that are mentioned). 1766 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever kills a snake; he has seven good deeds, and whoever kills a gecko; he has a good deed, and whoever leaves a snake out of fear of its consequence; he is not from us" (2). Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" without his saying: "And whoever leaves..." to the end. (Al-Hafiz said): "They narrated it from Al-Musayyib bin Rafi' from Ibn Mas'ud, and he did not hear from him." 1767 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Al-Ahwas Al-Jushami (3) who said: While Ibn Mas'ud was giving a sermon one day, suddenly he saw a snake walking on the wall, so he cut his sermon then struck it with his stick until he killed it, then said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Whoever kills a snake; it is as if he killed a polytheist whose blood is lawful." Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, and At-Tabarani as Marfu' and Mawquf, and Al-Bazzar; except that he said: "Whoever kills a snake or a scorpion." 1768 - (3) [Weak] And from Al-Abbas bin Abdul-Muttalib, may Allah be pleased with him; that he said to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "We want to sweep Zamzam, and in it are some of these Jinnan - meaning small snakes -? So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered their killing." Narrated by Abu Dawud, and its chain is authentic; except that I do not think Abdur-Rahman bin Sabit heard from Al-Abbas.

2. I say: But the last sentence is authentic due to its witnesses mentioned in "Al-Sahih" from Abu Hurairah and others. 
3. With a Dammah on the Jim and a Fathah on the Mu'jamah (Shin). His name is 'Auf bin Malik bin Nadlah. It was in the original (Al-Habashi) so I corrected it from "Al-Musnad" (1/ 395 and 421) and the books of narrators.

text: (Al-Jinnan) with a Kasrah on the Jim and a Shaddah on the Nun; plural of (Jann): which is the small snake as in the hadith, and it is said: The thin hidden one, and it is said: The thin white one. 1769 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Laila, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked about the Jinnan of the houses? [Previously mentioned 5 - Prayer /13]. 1771 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no faith for the one who has no trustworthiness (Amanah), and no prayer for the one who has no purification." text: 1773 - (4) [Very Weak] And from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "If my Ummah does fifteen traits; tribulation will befall it." It was said: And what are they, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "When the booty (Maghnam) becomes a personal fortune (Duwal), and trust (Amanah) becomes a spoil, and Zakat becomes a fine, and a man obeys his wife and disobeys his mother, and is dutiful to his friend and harsh to his father, and voices are raised in the mosques, and the leader of the people is the most despicable of them, and a man is honored out of fear of his evil, and wine is drunk, and silk is worn, and female singers and musical instruments are adopted, and the last of this Ummah curses the first of it; let them anticipate at that time a red wind, or swallowing by the earth, or transformation." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "We do not know anyone who narrated this hadith from Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Ansari; except Al-Faraj bin Fadalah." 1774 - (5) [Weak] And in a narration of At-Tirmidhi from the hadith of Abu Hurairah: "When Fai' (booty) is taken as personal fortune, and trust as a spoil, and Zakat as a fine, and learning is sought for other than religion, and a man obeys his wife, and disobeys his mother, and draws his friend near, and pushes his father away, and voices appear in the mosques, and the sinner of the tribe becomes their chief, and the leader of the people is the most despicable of them, and a man is honored out of fear of his evil, and female singers and musical instruments appear, and wines are drunk, and the last of this Ummah curses the first of it; let them anticipate at that time a red wind, and swallowing by the earth, and transformation, and casting (stones), and signs that follow one another, like a worn-out necklace whose string is cut so they follow one another." At-Tirmidhi said: "A Gharib Hadith" (1).
