text: 1775 - (6) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Thawban, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Three things are clinging to the Throne: The Womb (Rahim) says: O Allah, I am by You, so do not let me be cut. The Trust (Amanah) says: O Allah, I am by You, so do not let me be betrayed. And the Blessing (Ni'mah) says: O Allah, I am by You, so do not let me be denied (ungrateful for)." Narrated by Al-Bazzar. [Previously mentioned 22 - Righteousness /3]. 1776 - (7) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Abi Al-Hamsa', may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I engaged in a transaction with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, before he was sent (as a Prophet), and a remainder was left for him, and I promised him that I would bring it to him in a place, but I forgot, then I remembered that after three [days], so I came, and there he was at his place. He said: "O young man! You have caused difficulty for me, I have been here since three [days] waiting for you." Narrated by Abu Dawud, and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab Al-Samt"; both from Ibrahim bin Tahman from Badil bin Maisarah from Abdul-Karim from Abdullah bin Shaqiq from his father from him. And Abu Dawud said: "Muhammad bin Yahya said: This, according to us, is Abdul-Karim bin Abdullah bin Shaqiq." And Abu Ali bin As-Sakan mentioned Abdullah bin Abi Al-Hamsa' in "Kitab Al-Sahabah" and said: "Ibrahim bin Tahman narrated his hadith from Badil bin Maisarah from Ibn Shaqiq from his father, and it is said: From Badil from Abdul-Karim the Teacher." And it seems that what Abu Ali mentioned about dropping Abdul-Karim from it is the correct view. And Allah knows best (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: And Al-Bazzar and Ibn Hajar took the opposite view, so he said in "Al-Tahdhib" after mentioning the two aspects: "And the second is the correct one. Abu Bakr Al-Bazzar said: And the first is a mistake, because Shaqiq, the father of Abdullah, is from the Jahiliyyah and I do not know of any Islam for him." I say: Its defect on the first aspect is Abdul-Karim, who is Ibn Abi Al-Mukhariq the Teacher; for he is weak. And on the second aspect: Shaqiq the father of Abdullah Al-Uqayli; for he is unknown. And according to the saying of Muhammad bin Yahya that he is (Abdul-Karim bin Abdullah bin Shaqiq); then he is unknown as well.

text: 1777 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah the Exalted said: There are three against whom I am an opponent on the Day of Resurrection: A man who gave in My name then betrayed, a man who sold a free person then ate his price, and a man who hired a worker and received full work from him, but did not give him (1) his wage." Narrated by Al-Bukhari. Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (2), and it is with Abu Dawud and An-Nasa'i with other than this wording, and previously mentioned [in "Al-Sahih" 21 - Hudud /9] his saying: (Lam Yurah); Al-Kisa'i said: "It is with a Dammah on the Ya; from his saying: Arahtu Al-Shay'a fa-ana urihuhu: If I found its smell." And Abu Amr said: (Lam Yarih) with a Kasrah on the Ra; from (Ruhtu Arihu): If I found the smell. And others said: "With a Fathah on the Ya and the Ra, and the meaning is one, which is smelling the fragrance."
foot_note:
1. It is not in Al-Bukhari nor others: "The work", and the original was: "And did not pay him fully", so I corrected it from it and from what was previously mentioned (16/ 22).

I say: With this wording "five hundred" it is Munkar (denounced), it contains the 'an'anah of Al-Hasan Al-Basri along with the contradiction, and what is confirmed is the wording "one hundred", which is in "Al-Sahih" here. And from the ignorance of the three and their incoherence is that this wording occurred in their printed edition as "five hundred" as well! And in their referencing of both of them they said: "Hasan, narrated by Ibn Hibban (4881 and 4882)"! Darkness upon darkness, for the hadith in the location of the two numbers does not contain the sentence of (Distance) at all! Rather it is under two other numbers (7382 and 7383)! And the Hasan grading has no basis due to what I mentioned.

text: "Iyafah, Tiyarah, and Tarq are from Jibt." Narrated by Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (1). text: 33 - (Intimidation against making images of animals and birds in houses and elsewhere) (1). 1795 - (1) [Munkar] And Ahmad narrated from Ali who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was at a funeral and said: "Which of you will go to Madinah and not leave an idol without breaking it, nor a grave without leveling it, nor an image without smearing it?" A man said: I will, O Messenger of Allah! So he went, but he feared the people of Madinah [so he returned. Ali said: I will go, O Messenger of Allah!], He said: "Go then." [So he went], then returned and said: O Messenger of Allah! I did not leave an idol in it without breaking it, nor a grave without leveling it, nor an image without smearing it. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever returns to making anything of this; has disbelieved in what was revealed to Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)." And its chain is Jayyid (good) Allah willing (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: Whether they are three-dimensional (statues) or not, and whether pictured by pen and brush, or by machine (camera); all of that is forbidden except what is necessary like girls' dolls and the like, as I clarified in "Adab Az-Zifaf", then in "Ghayat Al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith Al-Halal wal-Haram". 
2. I say: It contains (Abu Muhammad Al-Hudhali), and it is said: (Abu Mawra'), Adh-Dhahabi said: "He is unknown." No one authenticated him, not even Ibn Hibban! And in its text is objectional content (Nakarah) not found in Muslim's narration which is in "As-Sahih" here. Despite all this, the three [commentators] collapsed and said: "Hasan"!!

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1796 - (2) [Munkar] And from Ali (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The angels do not enter a house in which there is an image, nor a Junub (ritually impure person), nor a dog." Narrated by Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; all from the narration of Abdullah bin Nujayy; Al-Bukhari said: "There is question regarding him" (1). 34 - (Intimidation against playing with Nard (Backgammon) (2)). 1797 - (1) [Weak] And Al-Bayhaqi said: We narrated from another path (3) from Muhammad bin Ka'b from Abu Musa from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "No one turns its dice waiting for what it brings; except that he has disobeyed Allah and His Messenger."
foot_note:
1. I say: It is Munkar due to the mention of (Al-Junub). The Hadith has been reported from a group of Companions in the "Two Sahihs" and others without it, and it is in "As-Sahih" in this chapter. In the chain of the Hadith is confusion and anonymity not noticed by those who classified it Hasan, Jayyid, or Sahih! As is clarified in "Da'if Abu Dawood" (No. 30). As for the three ignorant ones, they contradicted everyone and said: "Hasan due to its witnessing narrations"! And there is no witness for (the Junub). Yes, it was mentioned in another Hadith documented in "As-Sahihah" (1804). 
2. (An-Nard) with Fathah on Nun and Sukun on Ra': A known game, also called: Al-Ki'ab, and (An-Nardashir). An-Nawawi said: "(Nardashir) is Nard, so (Nard) is Arabicized Persian and (Shir) means: Sweet." 
3. The original: (Awjuh Ukhar - other paths), which is a mistake. The correction is from "Ash-Shu'ab" (5/ 237/ 6499). It is not known except through Humayd bin Bashir bin Al-Muharrir from Muhammad bin Ka'b. A group including Al-Bayhaqi in "As-Sunan" connected it from him, and he is unknown. It is documented in "Al-Irwa" (8/ 286).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 35 - (Encouragement to have a righteous companion, and intimidation against a bad companion (1), and what has been reported regarding one who sits in the center of a circle, and the etiquette of gatherings, etc.). 1798 - (1) [Weak] And from Hudhayfah (may Allah be pleased with him): "That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) cursed whoever sits in the center of the circle." Narrated by Abu Dawood (2). 1799 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Mijlaz; that a man sat in the center of a circle; Hudhayfah said: "Cursed upon the tongue of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) - or Allah cursed upon the tongue of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) - whoever sits in the center of the circle." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi who said: "A Hasan Sahih Hadith." And Al-Hakim with similar wording and said: "Sahih according to their conditions" (3).
foot_note:
1. See the Hadiths of this part of the chapter in "As-Sahih". 
2. I say: It contains Sharik Al-Qadi, and a disconnection between Hudhayfah and the narrator from him as follows. 
3. They all neglected the statement of Shu'bah - upon whom the chain revolves -: Abu Mijlaz did not reach Hudhayfah. Narrated by Ahmad (5/ 398). Therefore, Ibn Ma'in said: "Abu Mijlaz did not hear from Hudhayfah." It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (638). The three commentators ignored this defect and said regarding this and the one before it: "Hasan"!! Thus contradicting everyone from those who authenticated and those who found defects!!

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 36 - (Intimidation against a person sleeping on a roof that has no wall/barrier, or riding the sea when it is turbulent (1)). 1800 - (1) [Very Weak] And from Abdullah bin Ja'far (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever shoots at us at night (2); is not of us. And whoever sleeps on a roof that has no wall and dies; his blood is waste (no liability)." Narrated by At-Tabarani.
foot_note:
1. See the two Hadiths of this part of the chapter in "As-Sahih". 
2. Original: (Bin-Nabl - with arrows), and the correction is from "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (13/ 87/ 217). It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6685). The first sentence is authentic from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas and others, see it in "As-Sahihah" (2339).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 37 - (Intimidation against a person sleeping on his face without an excuse). 1801 - (1) [Weak] And from Ya'ish bin Tikhfah bin Qais Al-Ghifari who said: My father was one of the People of the Suffah (As-hab As-Suffah). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Come with us to the house of Aisha." So we went. He said: "O Aisha! Feed us." She brought Jashishah (1), and we ate. Then he said: "O Aisha! Feed us." She brought a Haysah like a Qata bird (2), and we ate. Then he said: "O Aisha! Give us drink." She brought a large cup ('Uss) of milk and we drank. Then he said: "O Aisha! Give us drink." She brought a small cup and we drank. Then he said: "If you wish, you may spend the night, and if you wish, you may go to the mosque." . . . . . . . . . (3) Narrated by Abu Dawood, and the wording is his.
foot_note:
1. (Al-Jashishah): What is coarsely ground from grain and cooked. (Al-Jash): Is light grinding, which is coarser than flour. It may be called: (Dashishah) with a Dal. 
2. Singular of (Qata), which is like a pigeon. 
3. Here in the original is the sentence forbidding lying on the stomach; I moved it to "As-Sahih" due to its witnessing narrations.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And An-Nasa'i narrated it from Qais bin Tughfah (with a dotted Ghain) who said: My father told me, and he mentioned it. And Ibn Majah from Qais bin Tahfah (with a Ha) from his father briefly. And Ibn Hibban narrated it in his "Sahih" from Qais bin Tughfah (with a dotted Ghain) from his father like An-Nasa'i. 1802 - (2) [Weak] And Ibn Hibban also narrated it from Ibn Tahfah or Tikhfah - depending on the varying manuscripts - from Abu Dharr who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed by me while I was lying on my stomach. He nudged me with his foot and said: "O Junaydib! Indeed this is the lying posture of the people of the Fire." Abu Umar An-Namari said: "There is much difference of opinion regarding it, and severe confusion. It was said: Tahfah bin Qais (with Ha), and Tihfah (with Ha), and Tughfah (with Ghain), and Taqfah (with Qaf and Fa), and Qais bin Tikhfah, and Abdullah bin Tikhfah from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and Tahfah from Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Their Hadith is all one; he said: I was sleeping in the Suffah and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) nudged me with his foot and said: 'This is a sleep that Allah hates.' He was from the People of the Suffah. Some scholars say: The companionship belongs to his father Abdullah, and he is the owner of the story." End quote. Al-Bukhari mentioned much difference regarding it and said: "Tughfah (with Ghain) is a mistake. And Allah knows best." (Al-Haysah) meaning a piece of Al-Hays: which is food made from dates, dried yogurt (aqit), and ghee (samn). Sometimes flour is used instead of dried yogurt. (Al-'Uss): A large thick cup estimated at eight or nine rotls (pounds).
foot_note: None

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 38 - (Intimidation against sitting between the shade and the sun (1), and encouragement to sit facing the Qiblah). 1803 - (1) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The most noble of gatherings; are those facing the Qiblah." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1804 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed everything has a nobility, and the nobility of gatherings; is what faces the Qiblah." Narrated by At-Tabarani. And there are other Hadiths on this besides these which are not free from criticism.
foot_note: 1. See its Hadiths in "As-Sahih".

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 39 - (Encouragement to dwell in Ash-Sham (The Levant) (1) and what has been reported regarding its virtue). 1805 - (1) [Weak] And from him [meaning Abdullah bin Hawalah]; that he said: O Messenger of Allah! Choose a land for me to be in, for if I knew you would remain, I would not choose anything over being near you. He said: "Stick to Ash-Sham" (2). When he saw my dislike for Ash-Sham, he said: "Do you know what Allah says about Ash-Sham? Indeed Allah Almighty says: O Sham! You are My chosen one from My lands, I admit into you the best of My servants..." Narrated by At-Tabarani via two paths, one of which is Jayyid (good) (3). 1806 - (2) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Hawalah [also] (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "I saw on the night I was taken on the Night Journey a white pillar looking like a pearl carried by the angels. I said: What are you carrying? They said: The Pillar of the Book, we were commanded to place it in Ash-Sham. And while I was sleeping, I saw the Pillar of the Book snatched from under my pillow. I thought that Allah Almighty had abandoned (4) the people of the earth. I followed it with my sight, and behold, it was a brilliant light in front of me; until it was placed in Ash-Sham."
foot_note:
1. With Sukun on Hamza, and it is lightened: The northern region of the Arabian Peninsula, including Syria, Jordan, and Palestine up to Ashkelon. See "Mu'jam Al-Buldan". 
2. This sentence is authentic with its witnessing narrations. I was forced to leave it here due to the necessity of context and understanding the intent. I removed from its end the sentence: "Indeed Allah has guaranteed me Ash-Sham and its people," because it contradicts the context firstly, and due to its authenticity as a statement of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so see it in "As-Sahih". 
3. See "Takhrij Ahadith Fada'il Ash-Sham" (Hadith 9), and "Ad-Da'ifah" (6775). 
4. Takhalla 'an al-amr: He left it.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: So Ibn Hawalah said: O Messenger of Allah! Choose for me. He said: "Stick to Ash-Sham." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its narrators are trustworthy (1). 1807 - (3) [Very Weak] And from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Ash-Sham is Allah's chosen land from His lands, to it He selects His best from His servants. So whoever exits from Ash-Sham to other than it; it is by His wrath. And whoever enters it from other than it; it is by His mercy." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Hakim; both from the narration of 'Ufayr bin Ma'dan - and he is flimsy -, from Sulaym bin Amir from him. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic Isnad." Thus he said. 1808 - (4) [Weak] And from Khalid bin Ma'dan; that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Prophethood descended in three places: Makkah, Madinah, and Ash-Sham. If it is brought out from one of them, it will never return to them." Narrated by Abu Dawood in "Al-Marasil" from the narration of Baqiyyah (2). 1809 - (5) [Weak] And from Abu Ad-Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The people of Ash-Sham and their spouses, offspring, male slaves, and female slaves to the end of the Peninsula are Murabitun (guardians). So whoever settles in a city of the cities; he is in Ribat (guarding). Or a frontier of the frontiers; he is in Jihad."
foot_note:
1. There is objection to this which I clarified in "Fada'il Ash-Sham" (p. 27), and some of it is established in "As-Sahih" here. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6775). 
2. I say: Baqiyyah is a known Mudallis, and I did not find the Hadith in the Mu'assasah edition of "Al-Marasil". A strange confusion occurred here by the three commentators; on one hand they said: "Mursal Hasan". And on the other hand they attributed it to Ahmad and others, which is exactly their extraction for the Hadith of Khuraym coming after two Hadiths. Due to their inability even to correct the proofs for printing, they missed this!!

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani and others from Mu'awiyah bin Yahya Abu Muti'; and he is Hasan in Hadith, from Artah bin Al-Mundhir from someone who told him from Abu Ad-Darda; and he did not name him. 1810 - (6) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani [narrated it] [meaning from the Hadith of Zaid bin Thabit] with a Sahih Isnad (1). Its wording is: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said while we were with him: "Tuba (glad tidings) for Ash-Sham." We said: What is with it, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "Indeed the Most Merciful spreads His mercy over it." 1811 - (7) [Weak] And from Khuraym bin Fatik (may Allah be pleased with him); that he heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "The people of Ash-Sham are Allah's whip in His earth, He takes vengeance by them against whom He wills of His servants. It is forbidden for their hypocrites to prevail over their believers, and they will not die except in worry and grief (2)." Narrated by At-Tabarani in Marfu' form like this, and Ahmad in Mawquf form - and perhaps that is the correct view - and the narrators of both are trustworthy. And Allah knows best.
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, and it is a grave illusion from him - followed by the three [commentators] - arising from overlooking At-Tabarani's Sheikh in it. Al-Haythami did the same, and they often do that as I alerted to in the Introduction. The Sheikh referred to is accused. In addition to that, the text is Munkar; as I clarified in "As-Sahihah" (503). See its preserved wording in this chapter of "As-Sahih". 
2. Original: (neither worry nor grief), correction from "At-Tabarani Al-Kabir". The defect of the Marfu' version is the Tadlis of Al-Walid bin Muslim, yet the ignorant ones classified it Hasan! It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (13).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 40 - (Intimidation against Tiyarah (Omens)). 1812 - (1) [Weak] And from Qatan bin Qabisah from his father (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Iyafah, Tiyarah, and Tarq; are from Jibt." Narrated by Abu Dawood and An-Nasa'i, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih". Abu Dawood said: "(At-Tarq): is Zajar, and (Al-Iyafah): is drawing lines." [And (Al-Jibt) with Kasrah on Jim: is everything worshipped besides Allah] (1) [Past here /32]. 41 - (Intimidation against keeping a dog except for hunting or livestock). [There is no Hadith under it according to the condition of our book, and praise be to Allah. See "As-Sahih"].
foot_note: 1. Addition from what preceded there. The Hadith was classified Hasan by the ignorant ones just as they classified it Hasan there imitating others, and I mentioned its defect there.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 42 - (Intimidation against a man traveling alone or only with another, and what has been reported regarding: The best number of companions). 1813 - (1) [Munkar] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) cursed the effeminate men who imitate women, the masculine women who imitate men, and the rider of the desert alone." Narrated by Ahmad from the narration of At-Tayyib bin Muhammad, and the rest of his narrators are narrators of "As-Sahih" [Past 18 - Clothing /6]. 1814 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "The best of companions are four, the best of Sarayas (1) are four hundred, the best of armies are four thousand, and twelve thousand will not (2) be defeated due to small numbers." Narrated by Abu Dawood and At-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs". At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith, and hardly anyone connects its chain [except Jarir bin Hazim] (3)." And he mentioned that it was narrated from Az-Zuhri as Mursal.
foot_note:
1. Plural of (Sariyyah) which is a detachment of the army, named so because it travels (Tasri) at night. Fa'ilah form meaning Fa'ilah. 
2. Original: (Lam), correction from "Abu Dawood" and others. At-Tirmidhi's wording: (La). 
3. Addition from "At-Tirmidhi" (1555). Jarir has something in his memory, and Al-Laith bin Sa'd contradicted him and narrated it Mursal. That is the correct view as I verified in the new edition of the second volume of "As-Sahihah" (986).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 43 - (Intimidation against a woman traveling alone without a Mahram). [He did not mention under it any Hadith according to the condition of the book, and praise be to Allah. See "As-Sahih"]. 44 - (Encouragement to remember Allah for one who rides his beast). 1815 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both): That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) let him ride behind him on his beast. When he settled on it, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said Takbir three times, Tahmid three times, Tasbih three times, Tahlil once, then he leaned back (1) on him and laughed. Then he turned to me and said: "There is no person who rides his beast and does what I did; except that Allah Almighty turns to him and laughs at him [as I laughed at you] (2)." Narrated by Ahmad. 1816 - (2) [Weak] And from Uqbah bin Amir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There is no rider who secludes himself in his journey with Allah and His remembrance; except that an angel rides behind him. And he does not seclude himself with poetry and the like; except that a Satan rides behind him." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan Isnad (3).
foot_note:
1. Thus in the original following "Al-Musnad", and "Jami' Al-Masanid" (32/ 119) and likewise in "Majma' Az-Zawa'id" (10/ 131). The meaning here is not clear to me. 
2. Addition from "Al-Musnad" (1/ 330) and "Majma' Az-Zawa'id". He found defect in it due to the weakness of Abu Bakr bin Abi Maryam. Yet the ignorant ones classified it Hasan, deceived by An-Naji's saying: "And Abu Dawood narrated similar to it and..." etc., while they do not have: "There is no person..." etc., and it has another defect which is the disconnection between Ali bin Abi Talhah and Ibn Abbas. 
3. Thus he said! And Al-Haythami followed him, and the three imitated them. It has three defects, explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6688).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 45 - (Intimidation against accompanying a dog and a bell in travel and elsewhere). 1817 - (1) [Munkar] And in a narration of Abu Dawood [meaning in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in "As-Sahih"]: "The angels do not accompany a group in which there is a leopard skin." He mentioned it in "Clothing" (1). 1818 - (2) [Weak] And from Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "The angels do not enter a house in which there is [a small bell (juljul), nor] a bell, and the angels do not accompany a group in which there is a bell." Narrated by Abu Dawood (2) and An-Nasa'i. 1819 - (3) [Weak] And from Amir bin Abdullah bin Az-Zubayr: That a female slave of theirs went with the daughter of Az-Zubayr to Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him); and on her legs were bells. Umar cut them off and said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Indeed, with every bell is a Satan." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and their female slave is unknown, and Amir did not reach Umar bin Al-Khattab.
foot_note:
1. Number (4130), I documented it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6687), and I verified therein that it is Munkar or Shadh. 
2. Attributing it to Abu Dawood is an illusion, which An-Naji missed alerting to. He only narrated (4231) from the Hadith of Aisha, which comes after a Hadith in the original, and it is in "As-Sahih". The addition is from An-Nasa'i (2/ 291), and it contains anonymity, for he narrated it via Hajjaj from Ibn Jurayj who said: Sulayman bin Babiya, the client of the family of Nawfal, told me from her. And this (Sulayman) is not known except by this narration. What confirms the ignorance of the three is that they faulted it with what is not a fault, saying (3/ 658): "Ibn Jurayj is a Mudallis (!), and Hajjaj bin Rawh, Ad-Daraqutni said: Abandoned..."! Ibn Jurayj is a famous trustworthy narrator, and he explicitly stated hearing. Hajjaj bin Rawh is not among An-Nasa'i's men; rather, it is Ibn Muhammad Al-Massisi, who is trustworthy and among the men of the Two Sheikhs. Detailed discussion to explain the reason for their mistake is too long for this place. To make matters worse; despite their severe weakening of its chain, they introduced it by saying: "Hasan due to its witnessing narrations"! While it has not a single witness! Except the Hadith of Bunanah coming after it, about which they also said: "Hasan due to its witnessing narrations" while saying: "Bunanah is not known"!! Yes, the second half of Umm Salamah's Hadith is authentic with witnesses you can see in "As-Sahih" in the chapter here. The negation in it is different from the negation in the first half and in the Hadith of (Bunanah) as is apparent. So reflect. And Allah is the Helper against the aggressors.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 46 - (Encouragement of Ad-Duljah - which is traveling at night -, and intimidation against traveling at the beginning of it (1), and against camping on the road, and separating at the stop, and encouragement to pray when people camp). 1820 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Three whom Allah loves, and three whom Allah hates. As for those whom Allah loves; a people who traveled their night, until when sleep became more beloved to them than anything equal to it; they camped and laid down their heads, but he stood up flattering Me and reciting My Verses" then he mentioned the Hadith. Narrated by Abu Dawood, At-Tirmidhi, An-Nasa'i, and Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their "Sahihs". And it preceded in full in "Secret Charity" [Past 8 - Charity /10]. 47 - (Encouragement to remember Allah Almighty for one whose beast stumbles). [There is no Hadith under it according to the condition of our book, and praise be to Allah. See "As-Sahih"].
foot_note: 1. See the comment on it in "As-Sahih".

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 48 - (Encouragement regarding words to say for one who stops at a place). 1821 - (1) [Weak Athar] And from Abdullah Busr (1) (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I went out from Homs and night compelled me to stop at (Al-Buqay'ah) (2), so I felt fear from the inhabitants of the earth (Jinn/animals). So I recited this Verse from {Al-A'raf}: {Indeed, your Lord is Allah, who created the heavens} to the end of the Verse. So some of them said to others: Guard him now until morning. When morning came, I rode my beast. Narrated by At-Tabarani, and his narrators are narrators of "As-Sahih"; except Al-Musayyib bin Wadih (3).
foot_note:
1. Thus in the original with un-dotted Sin, and likewise it appeared in "Al-Majma'" (10/ 133). In "Al-Ujalah" it appeared as (Bishr) with dotted Shin; perhaps it is a copyist error. 
2. Original: (Al-Bay'ah), and in An-Naji's transmission (Al-Baq'ah) and he said: "In most copies of At-Tirmidhi (Al-Bi'ah) with Kasrah on Ba' and Sukun on the last Ya', followed by 'Ayn then Ha' of feminity, which is an illusion and misspelling without doubt. The correct form and the wording of At-Tabarani and others is (Al-Buqay'ah) with Dammah on Ba', Fathah on Qaf, and Sukun on Ya' followed by 'Ayn then Ha' of feminity, diminutive of (Baq'ah). It is a proper name for a known spot there with water and channels, surrounded by adjacent spots between it and Homs less than two days." I say: Likewise it appeared in "Al-Majma'" (10/ 133): (Al-Buqay'ah) in diminutive form. 
3. I say: Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Mughni": "Abu Hatim said: 'Truthful but errs much,' and Ad-Daraqutni weakened him." The three [commentators] quoted Al-Haythami saying about him: "He is weak, but has been authenticated," yet they said: "Hasan"!!

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 49 - (Encouragement of a person supplicating for his brother in his absence, especially the traveler). 1822 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Two supplications have no veil between them and Allah; the supplication of the oppressed, and the supplication of a person for his brother in his absence." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 1823 - (2) [Very Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed the fastest supplication to be answered; is the supplication of an absent person for an absent person." Narrated by Abu Dawood and At-Tirmidhi; both from the narration of Abdur-Rahman bin Ziyad bin An'am, and At-Tirmidhi said: "A Strange (Gharib) Hadith." 1824 - (3) [Weak] And Al-Bazzar [narrated the Hadith of Abu Hurairah mentioned in "As-Sahih"], and his wording is: He said: "Three, it is a right upon Allah not to reject a supplication for them; the fasting person until he breaks fast, the oppressed until he triumphs, and the traveler until he returns." [Past 9 - Fasting /1].

Narrated by Ibn Majah. 1826 - (2) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated via the path of Abdul-Malik bin Marwan bin Antarah - and he is abandoned - from his father from his grandfather who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said one day: "Who do you count as a martyr among you?" Whoever is killed in the way of Allah is a martyr, the one who dies of falling is a martyr, the woman who dies in childbirth is a martyr, the drowned is a martyr, the one with pleurisy is a martyr, the burned is a martyr, and the stranger is a martyr." (Al-Hafiz said): "There have come a number of Hadiths stating that (death of a stranger is martyrdom); none of them reach the grade of Hasan as far as I know."

I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Al-Kifl was from the Children of Israel and did not refrain from any sin he did. A woman came to him,

text: so he gave her sixty Dinars on condition that he would have intercourse with her. When he sat between her legs like a man sits with his wife, she trembled and cried. He said: What makes you cry? Did I force you? She said: No, but it is an act I have never done, and nothing drove me to it except need. He said: You do this, while you have never done it before (1), go, for it (the money) is yours. And he said: No, by Allah, I will never disobey Allah after this ever. He died that night, and in the morning it was written on his door: Indeed Allah has forgiven Al-Kifl." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi who classified it Hasan and the wording is his, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; except that he said: "I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) more than twenty times saying", then mentioned similar to it. And Al-Hakim and Al-Bayhaqi from his path and others, and Al-Hakim said: "Authentic Isnad" (2). [Past 21 - Hudud /7]. 1837 - (11) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: There were two villages, one righteous and the other unjust. A man went out from the unjust village wanting the righteous village. Death came to him where Allah willed. The Angel and Satan disputed over him (3); Satan said: By Allah, he never disobeyed me. The Angel said: Indeed he went out seeking repentance. So it was judged between them to see which one he was closer to. They found him closer to the righteous village by a span, so he was forgiven. Ma'mar said: I heard someone say: Allah moved the righteous village closer to him.
foot_note:
1. At-Tirmidhi does not have (Qat - ever), it is in Ibn Hibban (2453 - Mawarid). 
2. It was explained there that its chain has anonymity and the rebuttal of those who authenticated or classified it Hasan! 
3. This narration is a mistake; it came from the narrator not memorizing the story well. The dispute was between the Angels of Mercy and Angels of Punishment. Yes, Satan was mentioned in some paths of the Hadith following this in the original, from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id, and I documented it in "As-Sahihah" (2640). I documented the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud in the other book (5254) and it is Mawquf as the author (may Allah have mercy on him) mentioned.

text: 5 - (Encouragement of poverty and lack of means, and what has been reported regarding the virtue of the poor, the needy, and the weak, and loving them and sitting with them). 1847 - (1) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went out one day holding the hand of Abu Dharr and said: "O Abu Dharr! Did you know that in front of us is a difficult pass that no one ascends except the light-burdened?" A man said: O Messenger of Allah! Am I among the light-burdened or the heavy-burdened? He said: "Do you have food for a day?" He said: Yes, and food for tomorrow. He said: "And food for after tomorrow?" He said: No. He said: "If you had food for three days; you would be among the heavy-burdened." Narrated by At-Tabarani (1). 1848 - (2) [Munkar] And Ahmad narrated [meaning the Hadith of Ibn Abbas which is in "As-Sahih"] with a Jayyid Isnad (2) from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr; except that he said in it:
foot_note:

And the addition (The Rich) is Munkar and did not appear in the Hadith of Ibn Abbas in the Two Sheikhs, which is in "As-Sahih" in this chapter. It is from the ignorance of the three commentators that they introduced their extraction of the two Hadiths by saying: "Sahih"!

So Umar wept and said: May my father and mother be sacrificed; would I be jealous against you, O Messenger of Allah? Then he turned to Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, and said: "O Uthman! Every prophet has a companion in Paradise, and you are my companion in Paradise." Then he took the hand of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, and said: "O Ali! Are you not pleased that your dwelling in Paradise is opposite my dwelling?" Then he turned to Talha and Az-Zubayr, may Allah be pleased with them both, and said: "O Talha and O Zubair! Every prophet has disciples (Hawari), and you two are my disciples." Then he turned to Abdur-Rahman bin Awf, may Allah be pleased with him, and said: "Your wealth has slowed you down from among my companions, until I feared you had perished. And I sweated profusely. I said: What slowed you down? You said: O Messenger of Allah! Due to the abundance of my wealth; I was kept standing and accounted, asked about my wealth: From where did I acquire it? And in what did I spend it?" So Abdur-Rahman wept and said: O Messenger of Allah! Here are a hundred camels that came to me tonight from the trade of Egypt; I make you witness that they are for the poor of the people of Medina and their orphans, perhaps Allah will lighten that Day for me. Narrated by Al-Bazzar and the wording is his, and At-Tabarani, and its narrators are trustworthy; except Ammar bin Saif, and he has been authenticated (1). foot_note: 1. I say: He indicates the softening of his authentication, which is the correct view, for Al-Bukhari said of him: "Munkar al-Hadith" (Denounced in Hadith). It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6592). It is a composite of Hadiths, some of which are authentic, like the Hadith of Umar's palace.

text: bin Awf, may Allah be pleased with him, enters Paradise crawling (1) due to the abundance of his wealth. The best of these [narrations] is not free from criticism, and none of them individually reaches the level of Hasan. His wealth was of the description the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, mentioned: 'Excellent is the righteous wealth for the righteous man.' So how could his degrees be decreased in the Hereafter or he be held back behind others from the rich of this Ummah, when this has not been reported regarding anyone else? What is authentic is only: 'The poor of this Ummah precede their rich' in general terms. And Allah knows best." 1854 - (8) [Very Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "I was shown that I entered Paradise, and lo, the highest of the people of Paradise were the poor of the emigrants (Muhajirin) and the offspring of the believers. And lo, there was no one in it fewer than the rich and women. It was said to me: As for the rich, they are at the door being accounted and purified. And as for the women, the 'two reds' distracted them: Gold and silk" the Hadith. Narrated by Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan and others from the path of Abdullah bin Zahr from Ali bin Yazid from Al-Qasim from him. [Passed 18 - Clothing /5].
foot_note: 1. An-Naji said: "I do not know of this being reported except from the Hadith of Aisha and Abdur-Rahman bin Awf himself. As for the first: Imam Ahmad narrated it in his 'Musnad' from the path of Umarah bin Zadhan, and it is among the Hadiths that Ahmad ordered to be struck out, saying: It is a denounced lie. Al-Bazzar also narrated it from the path of Aghlab bin Tamim. As for the second Hadith: Al-Bazzar also narrated it with a chain containing weakness. As-Sarraj narrated it in his 'Tarikh' with a chain whose men are trustworthy. As for the mention of Abdur-Rahman being delayed, the author mentioned it from the Hadith of Ibn Abi Awfa, and in its chain is softness. Ahmad narrated it with a soft chain as well from the Hadith of Abu Umamah, which is what the Sheikh cited from the book of Abu Ash-Sheikh [coming up] shortly, but he abbreviated Abdur-Rahman and his delay. And in Ahmad's version: 'And lo, the majority of the people of Paradise [were the poor of the emigrants].'" I say: The addition is from me, I retrieved it from "Al-Musnad" (5/ 259), and perhaps it fell from the author's pen. Similar is his saying: "shortly", perhaps it was a slip of the pen, for the author did not mention it except after a Hadith, which is the one coming here after this, and that is why I placed it in brackets.

text: 1855 - (9) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "O Allah, grant me life as a poor person (Miskin), cause me to die as a poor person, and resurrect me in the company of the poor on the Day of Resurrection" (1). Aisha said: Why, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "Because they enter Paradise before their rich by forty autumns. O Aisha! Do not turn away a poor person even with half a date. O Aisha! Love the poor and draw them near; for Allah will draw you near on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "Strange (Gharib) Hadith." 1856 - (10) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "O Allah, grant me life as a poor person, cause me to die as a poor person, and resurrect me in the company of the poor. And indeed the most wretched of the wretched; is he upon whom the poverty of the world and the punishment of the Hereafter are combined." Narrated by Ibn Majah up to his saying: "The poor", and Al-Hakim in its entirety and said: "Authentic chain of narration." And Abu Ash-Sheikh and Al-Bayhaqi narrated from Ata bin Abi Rabah who heard Abu Sa'id say: O people! Let not hardship drive you to seek provision from other than its lawful source; for I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "O Allah, cause me to die [returning to You] poor and do not cause me to die rich, and resurrect me in the company of the poor [on the Day of Resurrection]. For indeed the most wretched of the wretched; is he upon whom the poverty of the world

text: so return to me my two sweet basils so I may smell them once before death, then do with me what You wish. So make food for the poor; for the most beloved of My servants to Me are the Prophets and the poor. Do you know why I took away your sight, and bent your back, and the brothers of Joseph did to Joseph what they did? Indeed you slaughtered a sheep, and a poor orphan came to you while fasting, and you did not feed him anything from it. - He said: - So Jacob was after that, if he wanted lunch, he ordered a caller to call out: Whosoever among the poor wants lunch, let him have lunch with Jacob. And if he was fasting, he ordered a caller to call out: Whosoever among the poor is fasting, let him break his fast with Jacob, peace be upon him." Narrated by Al-Hakim, and from his path Al-Bayhaqi from Hafs bin Umar bin Az-Zubayr (1) from Anas. If it is so, then the Hadith is authentic. Ishaq bin Rahwaih extracted it in his 'Tafsir' saying: 'Amr bin Muhammad informed us: Zafir bin Sulaiman (2) told us from Yahya bin Abdul-Malik from Anas from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with similar meaning." 1860 - (14) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Shall I not inform you of the kings of Paradise?"

2. I say: He has weakness due to his many illusions. And he dropped (Ibn Abi Az-Zubayr) mentioned between Yahya bin Abdul-Malik - who is (Ibn Abi Ghaniyah) - and Anas. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6880). As for the ignorant ones, they graded it Hasan haphazardly!

Narrated by Ibn Majah and Al-Hakim; both from the narration of Yusuf bin Abi Kathir - and he is unknown - from Nuh bin Dhakwan, and he is feeble. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic chain of narration." And he has "Khashinan" (rough) instead of "Bashi'an". [Passed 18 - Clothing /7]. 1915 - (49) [Weak] And Al-Hakim [narrated the Hadith of Amr bin Al-As which is in the "Sahih"]; except that he said: "Three [days] of his time did not pass except that what was against him was more than what was for him." And he said: "Authentic according to their (Bukhari and Muslim) conditions." 1916 - (50) [Weak] [He said following the Hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in the "Sahih", and in it is the story of the hunger of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, Abu Bakr, and Umar, and their staying as guests with the Ansari man Abu Al-Haytham]: It came in "Al-Mu'jam As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat" by At-Tabarani and "Sahih Ibn Hibban" from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas and others that he was Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari. It appears that this story happened once with Abu Al-Haytham, and once with Abu Ayyub (1). And Allah knows best. The Hadith of Ibn Abbas was previously mentioned in "Praising Allah after Eating" [19 - Food /10]. 1917 - (51) [Weak] And from Zaid bin Arqam, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were with Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, and he asked for a drink. He was brought water and honey. When he placed it on his hand, he wept and sobbed, until we thought something was wrong with him, and we did not ask him about anything. When

text: he finished, we said: O Caliph of the Messenger of Allah! What made you weep like this? He said: While I was with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, I saw him pushing something away from himself, yet I saw nothing. I said: O Messenger of Allah! What do I see you pushing away from yourself, while I see nothing? He said: "The world stretched out to me; so I said: Get away from me. It said: Even if you escape me, you are not catching me [meaning those after you won't escape me]" (1). Abu Bakr said: That distressed me, and I feared that I might have contradicted the command of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; and the world has caught up with me. Narrated by Ibn Abi Al-Dunya and Al-Bazzar, and its narrators are trustworthy; except Abdul-Wahid bin Zaid. Ibn Hibban said: "His hadith is considered if there is a trustworthy narrator above him and a trustworthy narrator below him" (2). And here it is so. 1918 - (52) [Munkar Athar] And from Zaid bin Aslam who said: Umar asked for a drink, so water mixed with honey was brought. He said: Indeed it is good, but I hear Allah Almighty rebuking a people for their desires; He said: {You exhausted your good things in your worldly life and enjoyed them}, so I fear that our good deeds have been hastened for us. So he did not drink it. Mentioned by Razin, and I did not see it (3). 1919 - (53) [Munkar Athar] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both:
foot_note:
1. I say: This is the wording of Al-Bazzar. The wording of Ibn Abi Al-Dunya (16/ 11) is: "Indeed, if you escape from me, those after you will not escape from me"! Al-Hakim narrated it similarly (4/ 309) and authenticated it, but Adh-Dhahabi rejected it saying: "I say: Abdul-Samad was abandoned by Al-Bukhari and others." It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4878). 
2. Thus he said in "Ath-Thiqat" (7/ 124), and he was not accurate - as Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said in "Al-Lisan". Ibn Hibban also mentioned him in "Ad-Du'afa" (The Weak Narrators) (2/ 154-155) and was correct there. Adh-Dhahabi denounced this hadith of his in "Al-Mizan". Al-Haythami said regarding another hadith of his: "Very weak." See "As-Sahihah" (2609). 
3. I say: Ibn Abi Al-Dunya narrated it in "Al-Ju'" (Folio 3/ 1) from the path of Al-Hasan bin Dinar, from Al-Hasan, from Al-Ahnaf bin Qais, from Umar similarly at length. And (Al-Hasan bin Dinar) is Matruk (abandoned).

text: That Umar saw a dirham in the hand of Jabir bin Abdullah and said: What is this dirham? He said: I want to buy meat with it for my family, they have craved it (Qarimu). He said: Is it that every time you desire something you buy it?! Does not one of you wish to fold his stomach for his cousin and his neighbor? Where does this verse go from you: {You exhausted your good things in your worldly life and enjoyed them}? Narrated by Al-Hakim from the narration of Al-Qasim bin Abdullah bin Umar, and he is feeble, and I see he authenticated it along with this (1). His saying: (Qarimu ilayhi) means: Their desire for it intensified. And (Al-Qaram): Intense desire for meat to the point one cannot have patience from it. 1920 - (54) [Weak Athar] And Malik narrated from Yahya bin Sa'd; that Umar bin Al-Khattab caught up with Jabir bin Abdullah, and he mentioned it. The Hadith of Jabir was previously mentioned in "Intimidation regarding Satiety" [in the "Sahih" 19 - Food /7]. 1921 - (55) [Weak] And from Muhammad bin Ka'b Al-Qurazi who said: Someone who heard Ali bin Abi Talib told me that he said: We were sitting with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in the mosque when Mus'ab bin Umayr appeared before us; he had nothing on but a patched garment of his with fur. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, saw him, he wept for the luxury he used to be in, and the state he was in today. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "How will you be when one of you goes out in a garment (Hullah), and returns in another, and a bowl is placed before him, and another is lifted, and you cover your houses as the Kaaba is covered?" They said: O Messenger of Allah! We will be better then than we are today; we will be free for worship and sufficed regarding
foot_note: 1. I say: No, he did not authenticate it. Rather, he authenticated another Athar before it and mentioned this as a witness to it. Adh-Dhahabi said: "Al-Qasim is feeble." Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from another path briefly without the verse. It passed in the "Sahih".

text: provisions. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Rather, you are better today than you will be then." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from two paths, the wording of one of them was mentioned briefly [18 - Clothing /7], and the narrator from Ali was not named in them. He said: "Hasan Gharib Hadith." [Weak] And Abu Ya'la narrated it and did not name him either, and his wording is: From Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I went out on a winter morning and the cold had severely affected me. So I took a woolen garment we had, put it around my neck and tied it on my chest to warm myself with it. By Allah, there is nothing in my house to eat. If there was anything in the house of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, it would have reached me. I went out to some outskirts of Medina and went to a Jew in a garden. I looked at him from an opening in his wall. He said: What is with you, O Bedouin! Would you like a bucket [of water] for a date? I said: Yes, open the garden for me. So he opened it for me, and I entered. I started pulling the bucket, and he gave me a date, until I filled my palm. I said: That is enough from you now. So I ate them, then drank from the water. Then I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and sat with him in the mosque; while he was with a group of his companions. Then Mus'ab bin Umayr appeared before us in a patched garment of his with fur. He used to be the most pampered youth in Mecca, and the most luxurious in life. When the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, saw him, he remembered the luxury he used to be in, and saw the state he was in. His eyes flowed with tears and he wept. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said:
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Are you better today; or when a bowl of bread and meat is brought to one of you in the morning, and another in the evening, and he goes out in a garment and returns in another, and you cover your houses as the Kaaba is covered?" We said: Rather, we will be better then; we will be free for worship. He said: "Rather, you are better today." [Passed there]. 1922 - (56) [Weak] And from Fatimah, may Allah be pleased with her: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came to her one day and said: "Where are my two sons?" - meaning Hasan and Husain -. She said: We woke up and there is nothing in our house for anyone to taste. Ali said: I will go with them, for I fear they will cry to you while you have nothing. So he went to So-and-so the Jew. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, headed towards him and found them playing in a water basin (Sharabah) (1) with some leftover dates before them. He said: "O Ali! Will you not turn my two sons back before the heat intensifies?" He said: We woke up and there is nothing in our house. If you would sit, O Messenger of Allah, until I gather some leftover dates for Fatimah. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, sat until Ali gathered some leftover dates for Fatimah. He put them in a rag (2). Then he came forward, and the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, carried one of them, and Ali carried the other until they returned them. Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan chain (3).
foot_note:
1. With a Fatha on the Ra: A basin around the base of a palm tree filled with water to drink from. 
2. In "Al-Majma'" (10/ 316): (Surrah - pouch/bundle). 
3. And Al-Haythami said likewise! And in its chain (22/ 422/ 1040) is Awn bin Muhammad from his mother Umm Ja'far. She is unknown, no one authenticated her, and her son Awn is of unknown status (Majhul al-Hal), no one authenticated him except Ibn Hibban.

text: 1923 - (57) [Very Weak Mawquf] And it was narrated from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We attended the wedding of Ali and Fatimah. We have not seen a wedding better than it. We stuffed the bedding - meaning with fiber - and we were brought dates and oil and we ate. Her bed on her wedding night was a ram's skin. Narrated by Al-Bazzar. (Al-Ihab): The skin. And it is said: The un-tanned one. 1924 - (58) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prepared Fatimah for Ali, he sent with her a velvet bedding (Khamil) - Ata said: What is Khamil? He said: Plush fabric -, a pillow of leather stuffed with fiber and Idhkhir grass, and a water skin. They used to spread the Khamil and cover themselves with half of it. Narrated by At-Tabarani from the narration of Ata bin As-Sa'ib (1). 1925 - (59) [Very Weak] And At-Tirmidhi [narrated] (2) [the Hadith of Abu Hurairah which is in the "Sahih"] and his wording is: He said: I used to ask a man from the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, about verses from the Quran while I knew them better than him; I would only ask him so he might feed me something. Whenever I asked Ja'far bin Abi Talib, he would not answer me until he went with me to his house and said to his wife: O
foot_note:
1. I say: The author implies that he had become confused (due to old age). But Za'idah narrated it from him before his confusion in a shortened form, and it is in the "Sahih". 
2. I say: And he weakened it by saying: "Gharib Hadith...", and faulted it due to (Ibrahim bin Al-Fadl Al-Madani), who is Munkar al-Hadith (Denounced in Hadith) as Al-Bukhari said. There is another defect in it as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4879). As for the ignorant ones, they blundered and mixed this with the Hadith of Al-Bukhari referred to by my saying: "in the (Sahih)", so they said (4/ 112): "Sahih, narrated by Al-Bukhari (5432), and At-Tirmidhi"! Note that the number mentioned for Al-Bukhari is wrong, the correct one is (3708)!! That is because they do not master research, let alone verification!!

text: Asma! Feed us. When she fed us, he would answer me. Ja'far used to love the poor, sit with them, talk to them and they would talk to him. And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to nickname him 'Abu Al-Masakin' (Father of the Poor). 1926 - (60) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Three days passed over me without tasting food. I came wanting the Suffah, and I started falling down. The children started saying: Abu Hurairah has gone mad. He said: I started calling out to them saying: Rather you are the mad ones. Until we reached the Suffah, and I coincided with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, being brought two bowls of Tharid (bread and meat soup). He invited the People of the Suffah to it, and they were eating from it. I started stretching myself so he would invite me. Until the people stood up and there was nothing in the bowl except something on the edges of the bowl. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, gathered it so it became a mouthful. He placed it on his fingers and said to me: "Eat in the name of Allah." By the One in whose hand is my soul, I continued eating from it until I was satisfied. Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (1). 1927 - (61) [Weak Mawquf] And from Abu Barzah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were on a campaign, and we met some polytheists. We drove them away from a bread they had baked in hot ash (Mallah), and we fell upon it and started eating from it. We used to hear in the Jahiliyyah (Pre-Islamic period); that whoever eats bread becomes fat. So when we ate that bread; one of us started looking at his sides to see if he became fat? Narrated by At-Tabarani and its narrators are the narrators of the "Sahih" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: In it is (Hayyan) the father of Salim, and he is unknown. 
2. I say: Yes, but this does not mean it is established as I have warned repeatedly. It was extracted by At-Tabarani from the path of Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah as in "Jami' Ibn Kathir" (13/ 338), and Abu Bakr in "Al-Musannaf" (8/ 89 and 12/ 249), and Al-Bayhaqi in "As-Sunan" (9/ 60) from the path of Al-Hasan from Abu Barzah. Al-Hasan commits Tadlis, and he used 'an'anah (narrated with "from"). From the ignorance of the three and their collapse is their statement: "Hasan"!

text: (Ajhadnahum) meaning: We removed them from it and hurried them. 1928 - (62) [Shadh] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him: That hunger afflicted them while they were seven. He said: So the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, gave me seven dates, one date for each person. Narrated by Ibn Majah with an authentic chain (1). 1929 - (63) [Weak] And from Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "If you saw us while we were with our Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; you would have thought our smell was the smell of sheep. Our clothing was wool, and our food was the two black things: Dates and water." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and its narrators are the narrators of the "Sahih". It is in At-Tirmidhi and others without his saying: "Our clothing was..." to the end. It passed in "Clothing" [18 - Clothing /7]. 1930 - (64) [Weak] And from Ali bin Budhaymah who said: Salman's belongings were sold and amounted to fourteen dirhams. Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its chain is Jayyid (good), except that Ali did not meet Salman. (Al-Hafiz said): "If we were to expand on the livelihood of the Salaf and their asceticism, it would take volumes, but it is not a condition of our book. We only dictated this portion as a digression for blessing by mentioning them, and as a sample of what we left of their biographies. And Allah is the Granter of success to whoever desires, there is no Lord but Him."
foot_note: 1. An-Naji said (3/ 2/ 1): "Thus At-Tirmidhi narrated it briefly, and said: 'Sahih'. An-Nasa'i is briefer than both, and Al-Bukhari briefly and at length." I say: But in the narration of Al-Bukhari, he gave each person seven dates, and that is the preserved (Mahfuz) narration, as I explained in the original. So Ibn Majah's narration is Shadh (irregular).

text: 7 - (Encouragement to weep out of fear of Allah). 1931 - (1) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever remembers Allah and his eyes overflow out of fear of Allah until his tears hit the ground; he will not be punished on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic chain of narration" (1). 1932 - (2) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: When {Do you then wonder at this statement (59) And laugh and do not weep} was revealed, the People of the Suffah wept until their tears flowed onto their cheeks. When the Messenger of Allah heard their sound, he wept with them, so we wept because of his weeping. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "He who wept out of fear of Allah will not enter the Fire. And one who persists in sin will not enter Paradise. And if you did not sin; Allah would have brought a people who sin so He would forgive them" (2). Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi. 1933 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Zaid bin Arqam, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: A man said: O Messenger of Allah! How do I protect myself from the Fire? He said: "With the tears of your eyes, for an eye that wept out of fear of Allah; the Fire will never touch it." Narrated by Ibn Abi Al-Dunya and Al-Asbahani.
foot_note:
1. Thus he said! And in it is (Abu Ja'far Ar-Razi), and he is truthful (Saduq) but has bad memory and hallucinates often. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4594). 
2. This last sentence has an authentic origin from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah raised (to the Prophet) in "Sahih Muslim" and others. It is referenced in "As-Sahihah" (968).

text: 1934 - (4) [Munkar] And from Al-Abbas bin Abdul-Muttalib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Two eyes the Fire will not touch: An eye that wept in the middle of the night out of fear of Allah, and an eye that spent the night guarding in the path of Allah." Narrated by At-Tabarani from the narration of Uthman bin Ata Al-Khurasani, and he has been authenticated (1). 1935 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Every eye will be weeping on the Day of Resurrection; except an eye that lowered itself from the prohibitions of Allah, an eye that stayed awake in the path of Allah, and an eye from which [a tear] like the head of a fly came out due to the fear of Allah Almighty." Narrated by Al-Asbahani. [Passed 12 - Jihad /2]. 1936 - (6) [Weak] And from Ibn Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "There is no believer from whose eyes tears come out - even if it was like the head of a fly - out of fear of Allah, then it touches something of the heat of his face; except that Allah forbids him to the Fire." Narrated by Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Asbahani, and the chain of Ibn Majah is approachable (Muqarib) (2). 1937 - (7) [Mursal and Very Weak] And from Muslim bin Yasar who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "No eye welled up with its water; except that Allah forbade the rest of that body to the Fire. And no drop flowed on its cheek; and then dirt or humiliation covered that face. And if a weeping person wept in

text: a nation among nations, they would be shown mercy. And there is nothing except that it has a measure and a weight, except the tear; for seas of fire are extinguished by it." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi like this as Mursal, and in it is a narrator not named. And it was narrated from Al-Hasan Al-Basri, Abu Imran Al-Jawni, and Khalid bin Ma'dan not raised (to the Prophet), and that is more likely. 1938 - (8) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed Allah confided in Moses with one hundred and forty thousand words in three days. And among what He confided to him was that He said: O Moses! The pretenders have not adorned themselves for Me (1) with the like of asceticism in the world, and those who seek nearness have not sought nearness to Me with the like of piety (Wara') from what I have forbidden them, and the worshippers have not worshipped Me with the like of weeping from fear of Me." Then he mentioned the Hadith until he said: "And as for those who weep from fear of Me; for them is the Highest Company, no one shares in it." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Asbahani, and it passed in its entirety [here /6]. 1939 - (9) [Mursal Fabricated] And from Al-Haitham bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him; that he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, gave a sermon and a man wept before him. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "If every believer upon whom are sins like mountains were present with you today; they would have been forgiven due to the weeping of this man. That is because the angels weep and supplicate for him and say: O Allah, accept the intercession of the weepers for those who did not weep." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and he said: "Thus this Hadith came Mursal" (2).
foot_note:
1. The original: (Ilayya - to Me). 
2. I say: Using "may Allah be pleased with him" for its narrator implies he is a Companion, so take note. Along with its Mursal status, Al-Bayhaqi's sheikh (Abu Abdur-Rahman As-Sulami) is accused of fabrication. It and the Hadith of Muslim bin Yasar before it are referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3103).

text: 1940 - (10) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: When Allah Almighty revealed to His Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, this verse: {O you who have believed, protect yourselves and your families from a Fire whose fuel is people and stones}, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, recited it one day to his Companions. A youth fell down unconscious. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, placed his hand on his heart, and lo, it was beating. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "O youth! Say: La ilaha illa Allah (There is no god but Allah)." He said it, so he gave him glad tidings of Paradise. His Companions said: O Messenger of Allah! Is it from among us? He said: "Have you not heard His Almighty's saying: {That is for he who feared My position and feared My threat}." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic chain of narration." Thus he said. 1941 - (11) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, recited this verse: {Whose fuel is people and stones}, he said: "It was stoked for a thousand years until it became red, and a thousand years until it became white, and a thousand years until it became black. So it is pitch black (1), its flames are not extinguished." He said: Before the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was a black man who cried out weeping. Gabriel, peace be upon him, descended upon him and said: Who is this weeping one before you? He said: "A man from Abyssinia." And he praised him well. He said: Indeed Allah Almighty says: By My Might, My Majesty, and My Exaltation above My Throne, no eye of a servant weeps in the world out of fear of Me; except that I increase its

Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Asbahani. 1942 - (12) [Weak] And it was narrated from Al-Abbas bin Abdul-Muttalib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "If the skin of the servant shivers from fear of Allah; his sins fall off him, just as the dry leaves fall off the tree." Narrated by Abu Ash-Sheikh Ibn Hayyan in "Ath-Thawab", and Al-Bayhaqi and the wording is his. And in a narration of his he said: We were sitting with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, under a tree. The wind blew, and whatever dry leaves were on it fell, and the green leaves remained. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "What is the likeness of this tree?" The people said: Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: "The likeness of the believer is that if he shivers from fear of Allah Almighty; his sins fall off him, and his good deeds remain for him."
foot_note: None
