text: 8 - (Encouragement to remember death and shorten hope, and to hasten to do deeds, and the virtue of long life for one whose deeds are good, and the prohibition of wishing for death). 1943 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Remember often the Destroyer (Hathim) (1) of pleasures - meaning death - for indeed it is not in much except that it decreases it, nor in little except that it increases (segments) it." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan chain (2). [Very Weak] And previously in "Chapter on Intimidation regarding Injustice" [20 - Judiciary /5] is the Hadith of Abu Dharr, and in it: I said: O Messenger of Allah! What were the scrolls of Moses, peace be upon him? He said: "They were all lessons: I wonder at him who is certain of death; yet he rejoices. I wonder at him who is certain of the Fire; yet he laughs. I wonder at him who is certain of decree; yet he toils. I wonder at him who sees the world and its overturning of its people; yet he is reassured by it. And I wonder at him who is certain of the reckoning tomorrow; yet he does not work." Narrated by Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" and others. 1944 - (2) [Very Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, entered his prayer place and saw people appearing as if they were laughing (Yaktashirun) (3), so he said:
foot_note:
1. Meaning: Cutter. It is with the dotted Dhal, and it is said: With the neglected Dal. The first is what a group asserted; as in "Ujalat Al-Imla'" by Sheikh An-Naji (213/ 1-2). 
2. And Al-Haythami said likewise, and the three imitated them! In its chain (6/ 365/ 5776) is (Abdullah bin Umar Al-Umari), weak due to bad memory, and the narrator from him (Abu Amir Al-Asadi) is of unknown status. It is referenced in "Al-Irwa" (3/ 145-146). The Hadith of Abu Hurairah raised (to the Prophet) suffices instead of it, without his saying: "For indeed it is not...", and it is in the "Sahih" in this chapter. 
3. Meaning: Showing their teeth from laughter.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Behold, if you had increased the remembrance of the Destroyer of Pleasures; it would have distracted you from what I see: Death. So increase the remembrance of the Destroyer of Pleasures: Death; for indeed no day comes upon the grave except that it speaks in it, saying: I am the house of exile, and I am the house of solitude, and I am the house of dust, and I am the house of worms. When the believing servant is buried, the grave says to him: Welcome and greetings. Indeed, you were the most beloved of those who walked on my back to me. So since I have been put in charge of you today and you have come to me, you will see my treatment of you. - He said: - So it expands for him as far as his eye can see, and a door to Paradise is opened for him. And when the wicked or disbelieving servant is buried, the grave says to him: No welcome and no greetings. Indeed, you were the most hated of those who walked on my back to me. So since I have been put in charge of you today and you have come to me, you will see my treatment of you. - He said: - So it closes in on him until his ribs meet and differ (interlock) - He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, signaled (1) with his fingers, interlacing some into others -. He said: And seventy dragons (2) are assigned to him. If one of them were to blow on the earth; it would not grow anything as long as the world remained; it bites him and scratches him; until he is brought to the Reckoning." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The grave is but a garden from the gardens of Paradise, or a pit from the pits of the Fire." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and Al-Bayhaqi; both from the path of Ubaidullah bin Al-Walid Al-Wassafi - and he is feeble - from Atiyyah - and he is Al-Awfi - from Abu Sa'id. At-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan (3) Gharib Hadith, we do not know it except from this face."
foot_note:
1. Meaning: Signaled. The original was: (Fa-akhadha - took), so I corrected it from "At-Tirmidhi" (2462). It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4990). 
2. With Kasra and Tashdid: A type of snake, the largest of them. It appeared in "At-Tirmidhi" (2462): (And Allah assigns to him seventy...). 
3. The word (Hasan) is not established in some copies, and that is what befits the condition of its chain as you see.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1945 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We went out with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in a funeral procession. He sat at a grave among them and said: "No day comes upon this grave except that it calls out with a fluent, eloquent voice: O Son of Adam, you forgot me! Did you not know that I am the house of solitude, and the house of exile, and the house of desolation, and the house of worms, and the house of tightness, except for him whom Allah expands me for." Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The grave is either a garden from the gardens of Paradise, or a pit from the pits of the Fire." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1946 - (4) [Munkar] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, the tenth of ten. A man from the Ansar stood up and said: O Prophet of Allah! Who are the wisest of people, and the most resolute of people? He said: "Those who remember death the most, and are most prepared for death. Those are the wise ones; they went with the honor of the world, and the dignity of the Hereafter." Narrated by Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in "Kitab Al-Mawt", and At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" with a Hasan chain (1). 1947 - (5) [Weak] And from Sahl bin Sa'd As-Sa'idi, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: A man from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, died. The Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, began praising him and mentioning his worship, while the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was silent. When they became silent, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said:
foot_note: 1. And Al-Haythami said likewise, and the three imitated them. In it is (Mu'alla Al-Kindi), no one authenticated him except Ibn Hibban, and only two narrated from him. Yes, it has been corroborated without his saying: "They went with the honor...", for it is a Munkar addition. It is in the "Sahih" without it via the narration of Al-Bayhaqi. Furthermore, At-Tabarani narrated it in the "Three Mu'jams" and Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in "Makarim Al-Akhlaq" as in "Ar-Rawd" (489).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Did he used to remember death often?" They said: No. He said: "Did he used to leave much of what he desired?" They said: No. He said: "Your companion did not reach much of what you think." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Hasan chain (1). 1948 - (6) [Very Weak] And Al-Bazzar narrated it from the Hadith of Anas who said: A man was mentioned in the presence of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, for worship and striving. He said: "How is your companion's remembrance of death?" They said: We do not hear him mention it. He said: "Your companion is not there" (2). 1949 - (7) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said on the pulpit while people were around him: "O people! Be shy of Allah with true shyness." A man said: O Messenger of Allah! Indeed we are shy of Allah Almighty. He said:
foot_note:
1. And Al-Haythami said likewise! And the three imitated them. In it is one who is not known to have a biography by the testimony of Al-Haythami himself in other than this Hadith. Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi weakened it, as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" number (6507). 
2. I say: In chain (3622) is (Yusuf bin Atiyyah) and he is very weak as Al-Hafiz said. Yet the ignorant ones said: "Hasan...", and they attributed it to Al-Bazzar with the mentioned number! They do not master research or looking into chains and narrators!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Whoever among you is shy; let him not sleep a night except that his term (death) is before his eyes, and let him preserve the stomach and what it contains, and the head and what it gathers, and let him remember death and decay, and let him leave the adornment of the world." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1950 - (8) [Mursal Weak] And from Ad-Dahhak who said: A man came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah! Who is the most ascetic of people? He said: "He who does not forget the grave and decay, leaves the excess adornment of the world, prefers what remains over what perishes, does not count tomorrow as part of his days, and counts himself among the dead." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and it is Mursal. [Passed here /6]. 1951 - (9) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ammar, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Death is sufficient as a preacher, and certainty is sufficient as wealth." Narrated by At-Tabarani. 1952 - (10) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Four are from misery: Dryness of the eye, hardness of the heart, long hope, and greed for the world." Narrated by Al-Bazzar. [Passed 16 - Sales /4]. 1953 - (11) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Umm Al-Walid bint Umar who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came out one evening and said: "O people! Are you not ashamed?!" They said: Of what, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "You gather what you do not eat, and build what you do not inhabit, and hope for what you do not reach,
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Are you not ashamed of that?!" Narrated by At-Tabarani. 1954 - (12) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Usamah bin Zaid bought a slave girl for one hundred dinars to be paid in a month. I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Do you not wonder at Usamah buying for a month? Indeed Usamah has long hope. By the One in whose hand is my soul, my eyes have not blinked except that I thought my eyelashes would not meet until Allah takes my soul. And I have not raised a cup to my mouth thinking that I would put it down until I am taken. And I have not swallowed a morsel except that I thought I would not swallow it until I choke on it due to death. [O Children of Adam! If you have reason, then count yourselves among the dead] (1), by the One in whose hand is my soul {Indeed, what you are promised is coming, and you will not cause failure [to Allah]} [Al-An'am/ 134]." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab Qasr Al-Amal" (Shortening Hope), Abu Nu'aym in "Al-Hilyah", Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Asbahani. 1955 - (13) [Weak] And Al-Hakim [narrated the Hadith of Ibn Masud which is in the "Sahih"] and said: "Authentic chain of narration", and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "The Hour has drawn near, and people only increase in greed for the world, and they only increase in distance from Allah." 1956 - (14) [Weak] And from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: A man came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah! Advise me. He said:
foot_note: 1. Addition from Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and others. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4977).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Adhere to despairing of what is in people's hands. Beware of greed; for it is present poverty. Pray your prayer as if you are bidding farewell. And beware of what requires an apology." Narrated by Al-Hakim and Al-Bayhaqi in "Az-Zuhd", and Al-Hakim said (and the wording is his): "Authentic chain of narration." [Passed 8 - Charities /4]. 1957 - (15) [Very Weak] And from him [meaning Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him]; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Hasten to do good deeds before seven things; are you waiting for anything but poverty that makes one forget, or wealth that makes one transgress, or a sickness that corrupts, or senility that makes one feeble-minded, or a death that finishes one off, or the Dajjal; for he is the worst absent thing waited for, or the Hour; and the Hour is more grievous and more bitter." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from the narration of Muharrir - and it is said: Muhriz, with a Zai (1), and he is feeble -, from Al-A'raj from him, and he said: "Hasan Hadith"! 1958 - (16) [Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, addressed us saying: "O people! Repent to Allah before you die. Hasten to do good deeds before you are occupied. And connect what is between you and your Lord by remembering Him much, and by much charity in secret and public; you will be provided for, helped, and restored." Narrated by Ibn Majah. [Passed at length 7 - Friday /6].
foot_note: 1. Al-Hafiz An-Naji said: "It is disapproved of the author that he did not attribute him for distinction, while he is attributed in the narration itself: (Ibn Harun), and he is Taymi Madani from the individuals of At-Tirmidhi." I say: He is Matruk (abandoned), but it was narrated from another face from Abu Hurairah without the sentence (seven). See "Ad-Da'ifah" (1666).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1959 - (17) [Weak] And from Shaddad bin Aws, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "The wise is he who holds himself accountable; and works for what is after death. And the helpless is he who follows his soul's desires; and wishes upon Allah." Narrated by Ibn Majah, and At-Tirmidhi who said: "Hasan Hadith" (1). 1960 - (18) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "There is no one who dies except that he regrets." They said: And what is his regret, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "If he was a doer of good; he regrets that he did not increase. And if he was an evildoer; he regrets that he did not desist." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Al-Bayhaqi in "Az-Zuhd". 1961 - (19) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Shall I not inform you of the best of you?" They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "The best of you are the longest of you in life if they were upright." Narrated by Abu Ya'la with a Hasan chain (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: In it is Abu Bakr bin Abi Maryam and he is weak. It has another path, but it is very weak. Both are referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5319). 
2. I say: Al-Haythami followed him, and in it is Suhail bin Abi Hazim and he is weak as Al-Hafiz said. He contradicted the narrators of the Hadiths of the chapter in the "Sahih" so he added to them: "If they were upright", so it is Munkar here. As for the ignorant ones, they opposed them - contrary to habit - and acted knowledgeable, and wished they were correct - even if not rewarded - so they said: "Hasan due to its witnesses"! Which are against it not for it if they knew!! It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6696).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1962 - (20) [Very Weak] And from Abdullah bin Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed Allah has servants whom He spares from killing, prolongs their lives in good deeds, improves their provisions, grants them life in health, takes their souls in health on beds, and gives them the stations of martyrs." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and its chain is not present with me now (1). 1963 - (21) [Weak] And from Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Do not wish for death, for the terror of the Place of Ascent (death/resurrection) is severe. And indeed it is from happiness that the life of a servant is prolonged, and Allah grants him repentance." Narrated by Ahmad with a Hasan chain (2), and Al-Bayhaqi.
foot_note:
1. I say: It appears he is referring to (Ja'far bin Muhammad Al-Warraq), for Al-Haythami said: "I do not know him, and the rest of its men are trustworthy." This is a gross error from him followed by the three ignorant ones, because this (Ja'far bin Muhammad) is trustworthy from the men of "At-Tahdhib". Above him is (Hafs bin Sulaiman) - who is the Reciter - and he is Matruk (abandoned). 
2. Thus he said! And Al-Haythami followed him (10/ 203) and the imitating ignorant ones. In its chain is weakness and disturbance (Idtirab). Its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4979).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 9 - (Encouragement to Fear and its virtue). 1964 - (1) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Al-Kifl was from the Children of Israel and he did not abstain from any sin he committed. A woman came to him, so he gave her sixty dinars on the condition that he would be intimate with her. When he sat with her as a man sits with his wife, she trembled and cried. He said: What makes you cry? She said: Because this is an act I have never done, and nothing drove me to it except need. He said: You do this out of fear of Allah! So I am more worthy. Go, and what I gave you is yours, and by Allah, I will never disobey Him after this ever. Then he died that night, and in the morning it was written on his door: Indeed Allah has forgiven Al-Kifl. So the people marveled at that." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi who graded it Hasan, and Al-Hakim who said: "Authentic chain of narration." [Passed 1 - Chapter]. 1965 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Allah Almighty says: Take out of the Fire whoever remembered Me one day, or feared Me in a station." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Al-Bayhaqi, and At-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Gharib Hadith" (1). 1966 - (3) [Weak] And from Sahl bin Sa'd, may Allah be pleased with him: That a youth from the Ansar was entered by the fear of Allah, so he used to weep at the mention of the Fire until
foot_note: 1. I say: It is Hasan as he said were it not for the 'an'anah of (Al-Mubarak bin Fadalah), for he is a Mudallis. It is referenced by me in places including "Zilal Al-Jannah" (2/ 400 - 401).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: that kept him in the house. That was mentioned to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so he came to him in the house. When he entered upon him, the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, embraced him and he fell dead. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Prepare your companion; for fear cut his liver." Narrated by Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi from his path and others. And Al-Hakim said: "Authentic chain of narration" (1). 1967 - (4) [Very Weak] And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it in "Kitab Al-Kha'ifin" (Book of Those Who Fear), and Al-Asbahani from the Hadith of Hudhayfah (2). The Hadith of Ibn Abbas in "Weeping" passed closely in meaning, and the Hadith of Anas as well [Passed here /7]. (Al-Faraq) with Fatha on Fa and Ra: Is fear. And (Faladha kabidahu) with Fatha on Fa and Lam and with dotted Dhal; meaning: Cut his liver. 1968 - (5) [Munkar] And from Abu Kahil, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to me: "O Abu Kahil! Shall I not inform you of a decree Allah decreed upon Himself?" I said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said: "Allah brings life to your heart, and does not cause it to die on the day your body dies. Know, O Abu Kahil! That the Lord of Might is not angry with one who has fear in his heart, and the Fire does not eat a hair of him.
foot_note:
1. I say: Adh-Dhahabi rejected it due to the unknown status of some of its narrators, and said: "The report is semi-fabricated." It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5300). As for the statement of the commentator on "Targhib Al-Asbahani" (1/ 227): That Adh-Dhahabi agreed with Al-Hakim on authenticating it; it is from the illusions that even the three commentators did not fall into!! 
2. I say: Al-Asbahani extracted it (1/ 227/ 484) from the path of Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and it is referenced there.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever covers his nakedness out of shyness from Allah secretly and openly; it is a right upon Allah to cover his nakedness on the Day of Resurrection. Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever the sweetness of prayer enters his heart until he perfects its bowing and prostration; it is a right upon Allah to please him on the Day of Resurrection. Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever prays forty days and forty nights in congregation reaching the first Takbir; it is a right upon Allah to write for him innocence from the Fire (1). Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever fasts three days from every month with the month of Ramadan; it is a right upon Allah to quench him on the day of the Great Thirst. Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever withholds his harm from people; it is a right upon Allah to withhold the punishment of the grave from him. Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever is dutiful to his parents alive and dead; it is a right upon Allah to please him on the Day of Resurrection." I said: How is he dutiful to his parents if they are dead? He said: "Dutifulness to them is to seek forgiveness for them, and not to curse them, nor curse the parents of anyone so he curses his parents (2). Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever pays the Zakat of his wealth when it is due; it is a right upon Allah to make him among the companions of the Prophets. Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever his good deeds are few with him, and his bad deeds are great with him; it is a right upon Allah to make his scale heavy on the Day of Resurrection.
foot_note:
1. This paragraph has a witness from the Hadith of Anas, passed in the "Sahih" (5 - Prayer /16). 
2. The sentence of cursing has a witness from the Hadith of Ibn Amr, passed in the "Sahih" as well (22 - Righteousness /2).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever strives for his wife and child and what his right hand possesses, establishes the command of Allah among them, and feeds them from lawful sources; it is a right upon Allah to place him with the martyrs in their degrees. Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever prays upon me every day three times, [and every night three times] out of love for me and longing for me; it is a right upon Allah to forgive him [his sins of that night and that day. Know, O Abu Kahil! That whoever testifies that there is no god but Allah alone seeking help by it] (1); it is a right upon Allah to forgive him for every time the sins of a year" (2). Narrated by At-Tabarani, and it is in its entirety Munkar, and what testifies to parts of it has passed in places in this book. And Allah knows best of its condition. 1969 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "If you knew what I know; you would weep much, and laugh little, and you would go out to the high grounds supplicating (Taj'arun) to Allah, not knowing whether you will be saved or not saved." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic chain of narration" (3). (Taj'arun) with Fatha on the Ta with two dots above and Sukun on the Jim followed by an open Hamza; meaning: Crying out and seeking help.
foot_note:
1. Addition from "At-Tabarani" and "Al-Ujalah", and see the comment on the Hadith previously (15 - Supplication /7). 
2. It is referenced in "As-Sahihah" under Hadith (2652). 
3. I say: And it is a mistake as I explained in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4354), yet the ignorant ones said: "Hasan"! But the Hadith is authentic due to other evidence without its end: "Not knowing..." as I clarified there. In the "Sahih" here is a witness for it from Abu Dharr.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1970 - (7) [Weak] And it was narrated from Al-Abbas bin Abdul-Muttalib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "If the skin of the servant shivers from fear of Allah; his sins fall off him just as the leaves fall off the dry tree." Narrated by Abu Ash-Sheikh in "Kitab Ath-Thawab", and Al-Bayhaqi. [Passed here /7]. And in a narration of Al-Bayhaqi he said: We were sitting with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, under a tree. The wind blew, and whatever dry leaves were on it fell, and the green leaves remained. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "What is the likeness of this tree?" The people said: Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: "The likeness of the believer is that if he shivers from fear of Allah Almighty; his sins fall off him, and his good deeds remain for him." 1971 - (8) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: When Allah Almighty revealed to His Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, this verse: {O you who have believed, protect yourselves and your families from a Fire whose fuel is people and stones}, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, recited it one day to his Companions. A youth fell down unconscious. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, placed his hand on his heart, and lo, it was beating. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "O youth! Say: La ilaha illa Allah." He said it, so he gave him glad tidings of Paradise. His Companions said: O Messenger of Allah! Is it from among us? He said: "Have you not heard His Almighty's saying: {That is for he who feared My position and feared My threat}?!" Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic chain of narration." Thus he said. [Passed there].
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1972 - (9) [Munkar] And it was narrated from Wathilah bin Al-Asqa', may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Whoever fears Allah Almighty; Allah makes everything fear him. And whoever does not fear Allah; Allah makes him fear everything." Narrated by Abu Ash-Sheikh in "Kitab Ath-Thawab", and raising it (to the Prophet) is Munkar (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (485).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 10 - (Encouragement to Hope (Raja') and Good Opinion of Allah Almighty, especially at death). 1973 - (1) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "If you wish, I will inform you of the first thing Allah Almighty says to the believers on the Day of Resurrection, and the first thing they say to Him?" We said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Indeed, Allah Almighty says to the believers: Did you love meeting Me? They say: Yes, O our Lord. He says: Why? They say: We hoped for Your pardon and Your forgiveness. He says: My forgiveness has become due to you." Narrated by Ahmad from the narration of Ubaidullah bin Zahr. 1974 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Good opinion is part of good worship." Narrated by Abu Dawud, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" and the wording is theirs, and At-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim, and their wording is: He said: "Indeed, good opinion of Allah is part of good worship of Allah" (1). 1975 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And from Abdullah bin Masud who said: By the One besides Whom there is no god! No servant holds a good opinion of Allah; except that He grants him his opinion, and that is because all good is in His hand.
foot_note: 1. I say: In it according to all of them is (Sumair - and it is said Shutair - bin Nahar), and he is Nakirah (unknown/unrecognized). No one narrated from him except Muhammad bin Wasi' as in "Al-Mizan". As for the ignorant ones, they said: "Hasan due to its witnesses"! And they lied! It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3150).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani as Mawquf, and its narrators are the narrators of the "Sahih"; except that Al-A'mash did not meet Ibn Masud. 1976 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Allah Almighty ordered a servant to the Fire. When he stood at its edge, he turned around and said: By Allah, O Lord! My opinion of You was good. Allah Almighty said: Return him, I am as My servant thinks of Me." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi from a man from the descendants of Ubadah bin As-Samit - whom he did not name - from Abu Hurairah (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: It is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6150).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 25 - Book of Funerals and What Precedes Them. 1 - (Encouragement to ask for Pardon ('Afw) and Well-being ('Afiyah)). 1977 - (1) [Weak] From Anas (may Allah be pleased with him): That a man came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah! Which supplication is best? He said: "Ask your Lord for 'Afiyah (well-being) and Mu'afah (safety/pardon) in this world and the Hereafter." Then he came to him on the second day and said: O Messenger of Allah! Which supplication is best? He said to him the like of that. Then he came to him on the third day; and he said to him the like of that. He said: "If you are given 'Afiyah in this world and given it in the Hereafter; then you have succeeded." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and the wording is his, and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya; both from the hadith of Salamah bin Wardan from Anas. At-Tirmidhi said: "A Hasan [Gharib] Hadith" (1). 1978 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Supplication is not rejected between the Adhan and the Iqamah."
foot_note: 1. I say: Salamah is weak, but the first sentence regarding asking for 'Afiyah and Mu'afah has a witness from the hadith of Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) with an authentic chain, documented in "Ar-Rawd" (917) and elsewhere, and see "Al-Mishkat" (2489). As for the ignorant ones, they said: "Hasan due to its witnesses"! And out of their complete ignorance, they said about At-Tirmidhi: "And he said: Hasan Gharib, and in its chain is Salamah bin Wardan, weak," so they did not distinguish their statement from At-Tirmidhi's statement in any way!!

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: They said: So what should we say, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "Ask Allah for 'Afiyah in this world and the Hereafter" (1). Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan Hadith." [Past 5 - Prayer /3]. 1979 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Allah has never been asked for anything more beloved to Him than 'Afiyah." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib Hadith." And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it, and Al-Hakim in a hadith and said: "Authentic Isnad"! (Al-Hafiz said): "They all narrated it via the path of Abdul-Rahman bin Abi Bakr Al-Mulaiki - and his hadith is abandoned (Dhahib Al-Hadith) - from Musa bin Uqbah from Nafi' from him." 2 - (Encouragement regarding words to be said by one who sees an afflicted person). [There is no hadith under this section meeting the condition of our book, and praise be to Allah. See "As-Sahih"].
foot_note: 1. I say: The sentence of the supplication has been authenticated from another path, which is why I mentioned it there in "As-Sahih". Likewise, the sentence of ('Afiyah) is authentic in the hadith of Abu Bakr referred to previously. I only included the hadith here because of their question, so take note!

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - (Encouragement of Patience, especially for one afflicted in his self or wealth, and the virtue of calamities, illness, and fever, and what is reported regarding one who loses his sight). 1980 - (1) [Fabricated] And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Four things are not attained except with wonder: Patience, which is the beginning of worship, humility, remembrance of Allah, and having little." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Hakim; both from the narration of Al-Awwam bin Juwairiyah, and Al-Hakim said: "Authentic Isnad." It was mentioned previously in "Silence" [23 - Manners /20]. 1981 - (2) [Very Weak] And At-Tirmidhi narrated from Abu Dharr Al-Ghifari (1) (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Asceticism (Zuhd) in the world is not by forbidding the lawful, nor by wasting wealth. Rather, asceticism in the world is that you are not more confident in what is in your hand than what is in Allah's Hand, and that you are more desirous of the reward of the affliction if you are afflicted by it than if it (what was lost) had remained with you." At-Tirmidhi said: "A Gharib Hadith." 1982 - (3) [?] And from Ja'far bin Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Patience is the support of the Muslim." Mentioned by Razin Al-Abdari, and I did not see it. 1983 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard Abul-Qasim (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saying:
foot_note: 1. Original: (Anas), which is a mistake pointed out by An-Naji (may Allah have mercy on him) (215/ 1). The ignorant ones did not notice it despite attributing it to At-Tirmidhi by number as is their habit, and that is the extent of their verification!!

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Indeed Allah Almighty said: O Jesus! I am sending a nation after you; if what they love befalls them, they praise Allah, and if what they dislike befalls them, they seek reward and are patient, without forbearance (Hilm) or knowledge. He said: O Lord! How can this be? He said: I give them from My Forbearance and My Knowledge." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic on the condition of Al-Bukhari" (1). 1984 - (5) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Sakhbarah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever is given and gives thanks, is tested and is patient, oppresses and seeks forgiveness, and is oppressed and forgives." Then he fell silent. They said: O Messenger of Allah, what about him? He said: "{Those will have security and they are guided}." Narrated by At-Tabarani. (Sakhbarah) with a Fathah on the un-dotted Seen and Sukun on the dotted Kha followed by a Ba: It is said that he has companionship (Suhbah). And Allah knows best. 1985 - (6) [Weak] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "The martyr will be brought on the Day of Resurrection and stopped for reckoning, then the charitable person will be brought and stopped for reckoning, then the people of affliction will be brought, and no scale will be set up for them, nor will a register be set up for them, and the reward will be poured upon them in abundance, until the people of well-being will wish in the Standing that their bodies had been cut with scissors due to the excellence of Allah's reward."
foot_note: 1. Thus he said! And it contains (Abu Halbas Yazid bin Maisarah), and he is not from the men of Al-Bukhari, and no one authenticated him except Ibn Hibban, and his condition is unknown as in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4991).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" from the narration of Mujja'ah bin Az-Zubayr, and he has been authenticated (1). 1986 - (7) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If Allah loves a servant or wants to purify him; He pours affliction upon him abundantly, and pours it upon him heavily. If the servant calls out saying: 'O Lord!', Allah says: 'At your service, My servant. You do not ask Me for anything except that I give it to you; either I hasten it for you, or I store it for you.'" Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. 1987 - (8) [Weak] And it was narrated from Buraidah Al-Aslami (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "No man among the Muslims is afflicted by a prick or anything greater - he even mentioned a thorn - except for one of two traits: Either Allah forgives him a sin from his sins that would not have been forgiven except by the like of that, or He grants him a degree of honor that he would not have reached except by the like of that." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. 1988 - (9) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed Allah Almighty says to the angels: Go to My servant and pour affliction upon him abundantly, so he praises Allah. Then they return and say: O our Lord! We poured affliction upon him abundantly as You commanded us. He says: Go back, for I love to hear his voice." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir".
foot_note: 1. I say: It is as if he is indicating the softness of his authentication. No one authenticated him except Ibn Hibban (7/ 517). Ahmad said: "There is no harm in him in himself." Ad-Daraqutni weakened him. Ibn Khidash said: "He is not one to be relied upon." The last sentence of it has a witness from the hadith of Jabir, which is in "As-Sahih" here.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1989 - (10) [Very Weak] And he also narrated therein from him, he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed Allah tests one of you with affliction, just as one of you tests his gold with fire. From them is he who comes out like pure gold; that is the one whom Allah protected from doubts. And from them is he who comes out less than that; that is the one who doubts some doubt. And from them is he who comes out like black gold; that is the one who was seduced." 1990 - (11) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The calamity whitens the face of its owner on the Day faces turn black." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 1991 - (12) [Fabricated] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever is afflicted by a calamity in his wealth or in himself and conceals it and does not complain of it to the people; it is a right upon Allah to forgive him." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and there is no harm in its Isnad (1). 1992 - (13) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to a tree and shook it until its leaves fell as much as Allah willed them to fall. Then he said: "Indeed calamities and pains are faster in [removing] the sins of the son of Adam than I was with this tree." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and Abu Ya'la.
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, but it contains Hisham bin Khalid from Baqiyyah, which is a fabricated version as Ibn Hibban said. Abu Hatim said: "A fabricated hadith with no basis." Adh-Dhahabi agreed. Despite all this, the three ignorant ones classified it Hasan (4/ 180).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1993 - (14) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Bashir bin Abdullah bin Abi Ayyub Al-Ansari from his father from his grandfather who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) visited a man from the Ansar, leaned over him and asked him? He said: O Prophet of Allah, I haven't slept for seven [nights], and no one visits me. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O my little brother! Be patient. O my little brother! Be patient; you will exit your sins just as you entered into them." He said: And the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Hours of sicknesses remove hours of sins." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. 1994 - (15) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If the sins of a servant increase and he has nothing to expiate them; Allah tests him with grief to expiate them from him." Narrated by Ahmad and his narrators are trustworthy; except Laith bin Abi Sulaim. 1995 - (16) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Abdullah bin Khubaib [from his father] from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him); that he said to his companions: "Do you love not to get sick?" They said: By Allah, indeed we love well-being. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "And what good is there in one of you whom Allah does not remember (test)." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and in its chain is Ishaq bin Muhammad Al-Farwi (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: Even though he is one of Al-Bukhari's Sheikhs, narrating from him was criticized because he had become confused/senile, so his memory worsened.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1996 - (17) [Weak] And from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "No vein ever throbs on a believer; except that Allah removes a sin from him by it, writes a good deed for him, and raises him a degree." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a Hasan Isnad, and the wording is his, and Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic Isnad" (1). 1997 - (18) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "No servant falls sick with an illness; except that Allah orders his guardian (angel) that: Whatever bad deed he does, do not write it, and whatever good deed he does, write it as ten good deeds, and write for him of righteous deeds what he used to do when he was healthy, even if he does not do it." Narrated by Abu Ya'la and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. 1998 - (19) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Wonder at the believer and his anxiety over sickness! If he knew what was in sickness for him; he would love to be sick forever." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) raised his head to the sky and laughed. It was said: O Messenger of Allah! Why did you raise your head to the sky and laugh? The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "I wondered at two angels who were seeking a servant in a place of prayer where he used to pray, but they did not find him. They returned and said: O our Lord! Your servant so-and-so, we used to write for him in his day and night the deed
foot_note: 1. I say: There is confusion (Idtirab) in its chain; as Abu Hatim said, and its narrator has leniency; as Al-Hafiz said. The explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4456).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: that he used to do, but we found You have trapped him in Your ropes (sickness). Allah Blessed and Exalted said: Write for My servant his deed that he used to do in his day and night, and do not decrease anything from it. Upon Me is his reward for what I trapped him in, and for him is the reward of what he used to do." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Bazzar briefly. 1999 - (20) [Weak] And from Amir Ar-Ram (1) the brother of Al-Khadir (2) (may Allah be pleased with him) - Abu Dawood said: An-Nufayli said: It is Al-Khudr, but he said it like this - he said: I was in our land when banners and flags were raised for us. I said: What is this? They said: This is the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). So I came to him while he was under a tree where a garment was spread for him and he was sitting on it, and his companions had gathered around him. I sat near him, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) mentioned sicknesses and said: "Indeed, when a believer is afflicted by sickness and then Allah heals him from it; it is an expiation for his past sins, and an admonition for him in the future. And indeed, when a hypocrite gets sick and then is healed; he is like a camel whose owners tied it and then released it, it did not know why they tied it? And it did not know why they released it?" A man from those around him said: O Messenger of Allah! And what are sicknesses? By Allah, I have never been sick ever! He said: "Get away from us, for you are not of us" the Hadith. Narrated by Abu Dawood, and in its chain is a narrator who was not named. 2000 - (21) [Weak] And from Umayyah (3):
foot_note:
1. With the omission of the Ya. The author said in his summary of the Sunan: "And he is called: Ar-Rami". I say: Similar to Amr bin Al-Aas, Ibn Al-Had, Ibn Abi Al-Mawal and similar defective nouns (Manqus), they are pronounced with deletion of Ya and with its affirmation. Deletion is a dialect recited in the Seven Readings: (Al-Kabir Al-Muta'al) and similar. An-Naji said it (216/ 1). 
2. Meaning with Fathah on Kha and Kasrah on Dad. An-Nufayli said: "It is Al-Khudr, with Dammah on Kha and Sukun on Dad." This is the correct form, they are a clan of Muharib bin Khasafah. As in "Al-Ujalah". 
3. Original: (Umaimah), corrected from biographical books, and she is called: Aminah. Thus Ahmad narrated it (6/ 218), and At-Tirmidhi at the end of Tafsir {Al-Baqarah} number (2994) from the mentioned path, and he said: "Hasan Gharib", and he has (Umayyah), and her condition is unknown, and Ibn Zaid is Ibn Jad'an; weak.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: That she asked Aisha about this verse: {Whether you show what is within yourselves or conceal it} the verse, and {Whoever does evil will be recompensed for it}? Aisha said: No one has asked me about it since I asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to me: "O Aisha! This is Allah's admonition of the servant through what befalls him of fever, calamity, and a thorn; even the goods he puts in his sleeve and loses, so he panics over them, then finds them in his side-pocket (Dibn). Until the believer exits from his sins; just as red gold exits from the furnace." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya from the narration of Ali bin Zaid from her. (Ad-Dibn) with a Kasrah on the dotted Dad then a Sukun on the Ba followed by Nun: Is what is between the armpit and the flank. You say Adbantu Ash-Shay': When you put it in your Dibn and hold it. 2001 - (22) [Weak] And from Abu Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Headache and Malilah (fever in the bones) do not cease to be with the believer even if his sin is like Uhud; so it does not leave him while upon him is the weight of a mustard seed of that." And in a narration: "Malilah and headache do not cease to be with the Muslim man even if upon him of sins is greater than Uhud; until they leave him while upon him of sins is the weight of a grain of mustard." Narrated by Ahmad and the wording is his, and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and At-Tabarani, and it contains Ibn Lahi'ah and Sahl bin Mu'adh. (Al-Malilah) with Fathah on Meem followed by a Kasrah on Lam: Is the fever that is in the bone. 2002 - (23) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Malilah and headache do not cease to be with the male and female servant even if upon them of sins is like
foot_note: None

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Uhud; so it does not leave them while upon them is the weight of a mustard seed." Narrated by Abu Ya'la, and its narrators are trustworthy (1). 2003 - (24) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever gets a headache in the path of Allah and seeks reward; he is forgiven for what was before that of sin." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Bazzar with a Hasan Isnad (2). 2004 - (25) [?] And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed the Lord Glorified and Exalted says: By My Glory and Majesty, I do not take anyone out of the world whom I want to forgive; until I extract every sin on his neck through sickness in his body, and tightness in his provision." Mentioned by Razin, and I did not see it. 2005 - (26) [Mursal Weak] And from Yahya bin Sa'id: That death came to a man in the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so a man said: Congratulations to him, he died and was not afflicted by sickness. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Woe to you! [And] What makes you know that if Allah had afflicted him with a sickness, He would have expiated [by it] from his bad deeds?!"
foot_note:
1. And so said Al-Haythami! Which is from their leniency, for he narrates it (6150) from his Sheikh (Suwayd bin Sa'id) whom Al-Bukhari and others weakened. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" under the hadith of Abu Darda before it (2433). 
2. Thus he said, and Al-Haythami followed him, which is from their leniency, and the three imitated them! It contains Al-Ifriqi. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4615).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Malik from him as Mursal. 2006 - (27) [Mursal Munkar] And from Al-Hasan raised (Marfu'): "Indeed Allah expiates all of a believer's sins through the fever of one night." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya from the narration of Ibn Al-Mubarak from Umar bin Al-Mughirah As-San'ani from Hawshab from him and said: "Ibn Al-Mubarak said: This is from the good hadith" (1). 2007 - (28) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Whoever has a fever for a night and is patient and pleased with it from Allah Almighty; exits from his sins as on the day his mother bore him." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Kitab Al-Marad" (2) and others. Section 2008 - (29) [Munkar] And from Aisha bint Qudamah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "It is rare for Allah to take the two beloveds (eyes) of a believer; then enter him into the Fire. - Yunus said: Meaning his eyes -." Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani from the narration of Abdul-Rahman bin Uthman Al-Hatibi (3). 2009 - (30) [Weak] And from Zaid bin Arqam (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "No servant is tested after the loss of his religion with anything harder than the loss of his sight, and whoever is tested with his sight
foot_note:
1. I say: In the path to him is (Abu Ya'qub At-Tamimi), Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya's Sheikh, and I did not know him. And Umar bin Al-Mughirah As-San'ani is unknown; as stated by Al-Bukhari and others. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6144). 
2. Original: (Ar-Rida)! It is in "Al-Marad wal-Kaffarat" (63/ 83), and contains the 'An'anah of Al-Hasan Al-Basri, and (Zafir bin Sulaiman). It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6697). 
3. I say: Abu Hatim said: "He narrated Munkar hadiths from his father." Yet the ignorant ones classified it Hasan due to its witnesses!

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: and is patient until he meets Allah; meets Allah Blessed and Exalted with no account upon him." Narrated by Al-Bazzar from the narration of Jabir Al-Ju'fi (1). 2010 - (31) [Weak] And from Buraidah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "A servant will never be tested with anything harder upon him than Shirk with Allah, and a servant will never be tested with anything after Shirk with Allah harder upon him than the loss of his sight, and a servant is never tested with the loss of his sight and is patient; except that Allah forgives him." Narrated by Al-Bazzar from the narration of Jabir also (2). 2011 - (32) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever Allah takes away his sight and he is patient and seeks reward; it is a right upon Allah, obligatory, that his eyes do not see the Fire." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat" (3). 2012 - (33) [Munkar] And it was narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from Gabriel peace be upon him from his Lord Blessed and Exalted that He said: "Indeed Allah said: O Gabriel! What is the reward of My servant if I take his two beloveds (eyes) except looking at My Face, and neighboring in My Abode." Anas said: So I saw the Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) weeping around him, wishing that their sights would go away. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" (4).
foot_note:
1. (1 and 2) I say: He is weak, and some accused him. Yet the ignorant ones also said: "Hasan due to its witnesses"! 
3. I say: It contains one accused of lying. It is documented in "Ar-Rawd An-Nadir" (556). 
4. I say: I documented it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5773) with an explanation of illusions that occurred to Al-Haythami regarding some of its narrators, in which the ignorant ones imitated him.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 4 - (Encouragement regarding words to be said by one who feels pain in part of his body). 2013 - (1) [Very Weak] And from Abu Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Whoever among you complains of something or his brother complains to him, let him say: (Our Lord Allah who is in the Heaven, Hallowed be Your Name, Your Command is in the Heaven and the Earth; just as Your Mercy is in the Heaven; make Your Mercy on the Earth. Forgive us our sins (Hawb) and our faults. You are the Lord of the good. Send down mercy from Your Mercy, and a cure from Your Cure; upon this pain); and he will be cured." Narrated by Abu Dawood (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: And Al-Hakim narrated it (1/ 344), and said: "The two Sheikhs argued with the narration of other than Ziyad bin Muhammad Al-Ansari, and he is an Egyptian Sheikh with few hadiths." Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him saying: "I say: Al-Bukhari and others said: Munkar in Hadith."

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 5 - (Intimidation against hanging Amulets (Tama'im) and Charms). 2014 - (1) [Weak] From Uqbah bin Amir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Whoever hangs a Tamimah (amulet), may Allah not complete for him. And whoever hangs a Wada'ah (seashell), may Allah not leave him in peace." Narrated by Ahmad and Abu Ya'la with a Jayyid Isnad, and Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic Isnad" (1). 2015 - (2) [Weak] And from Imran bin Husain (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saw on a man's upper arm a ring - I think he said: - of brass, so he said: "Woe to you, what is this?" He said: For weakness (Al-Wahinah). He said: "Indeed it does not increase you except in weakness. Throw it away from you, for if you die while it is on you; you will never succeed ever." Narrated by Ahmad, and Ibn Majah without his saying: "Throw it away..." to the end, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" and he said: "For if you die while it is on you, you will be entrusted to it." And Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic Isnad".
foot_note: 1. I say: They were lenient, for it is neither Sahih nor Jayyid. It contains (Khalid bin Ubaid Al-Ma'afiri) who is not known except by this narration, and no one authenticated him except Ibn Hibban. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1266). As for the ignorant ones, they collapsed as usual and said: "Hasan"!

text: (Al-Hafiz said): "They all narrated it from Mubarak bin Fadalah from Al-Hasan from Imran. Ibn Hibban also narrated it with similar wording from Abu Amir Al-Khuza'i from Al-Hasan from Imran. This is Jayyid; except that Al-Hasan's hearing from Imran is disputed. Ibn Al-Madini and others said: He did not hear from him. Al-Hakim said: Most of our Sheikhs are of the view that Al-Hasan heard from Imran. And Allah knows best" (1). 2016 - (3) [Weak] And from the nephew of Zainab the wife of Abdullah, from Zainab (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: An old woman used to enter upon us to perform Ruqyah for Erysipelas (Al-Humrah). We had a bed with long legs. Abdullah used to clear his throat and make noise when he entered. He entered one day, and when she heard his voice she hid from him. He came and sat by my side, touched me and found the touch of a thread. He said: What is this? I said: Ruqyah (charm) for me in it for Erysipelas. He pulled it, cut it, and threw it away, then said: The family of Abdullah has become rich beyond Shirk. I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Indeed Ruqyah (incantations), Amulets, and Tiwalah (love spells) are Shirk." I said: I went out one day and so-and-so saw me, and my eye that was next to him began to tear. If I charmed it, the tearing stopped, and if I left it, it tore. He said: That is Satan, if you obey him he leaves you, and if you disobey him he pokes your eye with his finger. But if you had done as the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did, it would have been better for you and more likely to heal: You sprinkle water in your eye and say:
foot_note: 1. I say: The correct view is that his hearing from him is not established. Even if it were authentic; it would not be useful here, because (Al-Hasan) is a Mudallis and used 'An'anah, and the narrator from him (Mubarak bin Fadalah) is also a Mudallis and used 'An'anah. Therefore, whoever said from the Sheikhs: "Narrated by Ahmad with a chain that has no harm" was not correct! Nor did those who classified it Hasan like the three ignorant ones do well.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Remove the harm, O Lord of the people, and heal, You are the Healer, there is no healing but Your healing, a healing that leaves no illness." Narrated by Ibn Majah - and the wording is his -, and Abu Dawood briefly from him; except that he said: "From the nephew of Zainab." It is like this in some copies of Ibn Majah, and in both estimations he is unknown (1). And Al-Hakim narrated it more briefly than them and said: "Authentic Isnad." Abu Sulaiman Al-Khattabi said: "The forbidden Ruqyah is what is not in the Arabic tongue, for it is not known what it is? Perhaps magic or disbelief enters into it. But if the meaning is understood, and it contains the mention of Allah Almighty, then it is recommended and blessed. And Allah knows best."
foot_note: 1. I say: But Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: "He seems to be a Companion, but I did not see him named." The hadith has been authenticated briefly, so refer to it if you wish in this chapter of "As-Sahih".

text: 6 - (Encouragement of Cupping (Hijama), and when to be cupped). 2017 - (1) [Weak] And from him [meaning Abu Hurairah] who said: Abul-Qasim (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) informed me: "That Gabriel informed him: That cupping is the most beneficial thing people treat themselves with." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Authentic on their condition" (1). 2018 - (2) [Mo'dal Weak] And from Malik who reached him; that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If there was a remedy that reaches the disease; then cupping reaches it." Mentioned in "Al-Muwatta" like this. 2019 - (3) [Weak] And from Ikrimah who said: Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) had three boy cuppers. Two of them used to bring him and his family income, and one used to cup him and cup his family. He said: And Ibn Abbas said: The Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "What an excellent servant is the cupper, he removes blood, lightens the back, and polishes the eyesight." 2020 - (4) [Very Munkar] And he [meaning Ibn Abbas] said: Indeed the best of what you treat yourselves with is Snuff (Sa'ut), Oral Medicine (Ladud), Cupping, and Laxative (2). And the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was given medicine orally by Al-Abbas and his companions (3), so the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Who gave me medicine?" They all held back. He said:
foot_note:
1. Thus he said! It contains (Muhammad bin Qais An-Nakha'i) who is not of their men, nor did anyone authenticate him except Ibn Hibban, yet he said: "He errs and contradicts." And the ignorant ones classified it Hasan. 
2. It is medicine that causes easy bowel movement. 
3. This is false. Rather, his wives (peace be upon him) gave him medicine as in the "Two Sahihs", and in them after his upcoming statement: "Except his uncle Al-Abbas": "For he did not witness you." This is explicit in invalidating the mentioned statement, and evidence of the poor memory of Abbad bin Mansur. Despite this, the ignorant ones classified it Hasan.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Let no one remain in the house except that he is given medicine except his uncle Al-Abbas" (1). An-Nadr said: Al-Ladud: Al-Wajur (medicine poured into the mouth). foot_note:

3. Unknown, not recognized. Original was: (Kabshah) so I corrected it from "At-Tahdhib" and others. And Abu Bakrah has weakness.

text: 7 - (Encouragement to visit the sick and its emphasis, and encouragement to seek the sick person's supplication). 2025 - (1) [Weak] And from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever performs ablution and does it well, and visits his Muslim brother seeking reward; he is distanced from Hell by seventy autumns." I said: O Abu Hamzah! What is (the autumn)? He said: The year. Narrated by Abu Dawood from the narration of Al-Fadl bin Dalham Al-Qassab (1). 2026 - (2) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever visits a sick person and sits with him for an hour; Allah grants him the deeds of a thousand years in which he did not disobey Allah for the blink of an eye." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Book of Sickness and Expiations", and the signs of fabrication are evident on it. 2027 - (3) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Umar and Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with them) who said: "Whoever walks to fulfill his Muslim brother's need; Allah shades him with seventy-five thousand angels praying for him, and he continues to wade in mercy until he finishes. When he finishes, Allah writes for him a Hajj and an Umrah. And whoever visits a sick person; Allah shades him with seventy-five thousand angels, he does not raise a foot except that He writes a good deed for him by it, and does not place a foot except that He removes a bad deed from him and raises him a degree by it, until he sits in his seat. When he sits, mercy overwhelms him, and it remains like that until he returns to where he ends up at his home."
foot_note: 1. I say: Abu Dawood said: "His hadith is Munkar, and he is not satisfactory (Radi)."

text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and its Marfu' attribution is not in my original copy (1). He said: So I said: O Messenger of Allah! This is for the healthy person who visits the sick, so what is for the sick person (2)? He said: "His sins are removed from him." Narrated by Ahmad, and narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat" and added: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If the servant is sick for three days; he exits from his sins as on the day his mother bore him." Section 2029 - (5) [Very Weak] From Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If you enter upon a sick person, order him to pray for you, for indeed his supplication is like the supplication of the angels." Narrated by Ibn Majah and his narrators are famous trustworthy ones (3); except that Maimun bin Mahran did not hear from Umar.
foot_note:

2. Original: (So what is for the sick), and the correction is from "Al-Musnad" (3/ 174 and 255) and the addition is from it.

text: 8 - (Encouragement regarding words to be prayed for the sick, and words the sick person should say). 2032 - (1) [Very Weak] And from Sa'd bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said regarding His Almighty's saying: {There is no deity except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I have been of the wrongdoers}: "Any Muslim who supplicates with it in his sickness forty times, then dies in that sickness of his; is given the reward of a martyr. And if he heals, he heals while all his sins have been forgiven." Narrated by Al-Hakim from (1) Ahmad bin Amr bin Bakr As-Saksaki from his father from Muhammad bin Zaid from Ibn Al-Musayyib from him. 2033 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O Abu Hurairah! Shall I not inform you of a matter which is true, whoever speaks with it at the beginning of his lying down for his sickness; Allah saves him from the Fire?" I said: Yes, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you. He said: "Know that if you reach the morning you may not reach the evening, and if you reach the evening you may not reach the morning. If you say that at the beginning of your lying down for your sickness; Allah saves you from the Fire; that you say: (There is no god but Allah, He gives life and causes death, and He is Alive and does not die, and Glory be to Allah the Lord of
foot_note: 1. Original: (And he said: Narrated by), and likewise in Amarah's edition and others like the edition of the three, and it does not exist in "Mustadrak Al-Hakim" (1/ 505 - 506), so perhaps the correct form is what I established. This As-Saksaki is abandoned. Furthermore, the beginning of the hadith was narrated by the author by meaning, which is the complete hadith of Al-Hakim, containing that the Greatest Name of Allah is the supplication of Yunus, when he called out in the darkness: (There is no god but You...). A man said: O Messenger of Allah! Was it special for Yunus... He said: Do you not hear Allah's saying: {So We saved him from the distress}. The author mentioned the statement of the mentioned man previously (15 - Supplication /2).

If you die in that sickness of yours, then to the Pleasure of Allah and Paradise. And if you had committed sins, Allah turns to you in forgiveness." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Book of Sickness and Expiations", and its chain is not present with me right now (1). 2034 - (3) [Mo'dal and Weak] And it was narrated from Hajjaj bin Furafisah; that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There is no sick person who says: (Glory be to the King, the Holy, the Merciful, the King, the Judge, there is no god but You, Quieter of throbbing veins, and sleeper of sleepless eyes); except that Allah Almighty heals him." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya at the end of "Book of Sickness and Expiations" like this as Mo'dal (perplexing/disconnected).
foot_note: 1. I say: All its men are known trustworthy ones from the men of "At-Tahdhib"; except (Amir bin Yasaf), and I think the author did not know him. He is in "Thiqat Ibn Hibban" (8/ 501), and Ibn Ma'in also authenticated him, while others weakened him, including Ibn Adi, who said (5/ 85): "Munkar in Hadith from trustworthy narrators," then cited some hadiths for him, this being the first.

text: 9 - (Encouragement to make a Will and be just in it, and Intimidation against neglecting it or causing harm in it, and what is reported regarding one who emancipates and gives charity at death). 2035 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever dies on a will (having made a will) dies on a path and Sunnah, and dies on piety and martyrdom, and dies forgiven." Narrated by Ibn Majah. 2036 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: We were with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when a man came and said: O Messenger of Allah! So-and-so died. He said: "Was he not with us just now?" They said: Yes. He said: "Glory be to Allah! It is as if he was taken in anger. The deprived one is he who is deprived of his will." Narrated by Abu Ya'la with a Hasan Isnad (1). And Ibn Majah narrated it briefly saying: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The deprived one is he who is deprived of his will." 2037 - (3) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: "Leaving the will is shame in the world, and disgrace (Shanar) (2) in the Hereafter." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "As-Saghir" and "Al-Awsat".
foot_note:
1. How can that be when its chain (7/ 152/ 4122) contains Darast bin Ziyad: Yazid Ar-Raqashi told me from him?! And both are weak. Ibn Majah (2700) narrated from them. 
2. (Ash-Shanar): Defect and shame. It is said: It is the defect that contains shame.

text: 2038 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed a man - or a woman - performs obedience to Allah for sixty years, then death attends them and they harm in the will; so the Fire becomes obligatory for them." Then Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) recited: {From after any bequest which was made or debt, as long as there is no detriment [caused]} until he reached: {That (1) is the great attainment}. Narrated by Abu Dawood. And At-Tirmidhi and said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith" (2). And Ibn Majah, and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed a man performs the deeds of the people of good for seventy years, but when he makes a will he is unjust in his will, so he ends with the worst of his deeds, and enters the Fire. And indeed a man performs the deeds of the people of evil for seventy years, but is just in his will, so he ends with the best of his deeds, and enters Paradise" (3). 2039 - (5) [Munkar] And from Ibn Abbas from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Harming in the will is among the major sins." Then he recited: {Those are the limits of Allah, so do not transgress them}.
foot_note:
1. Thus it appeared in the narration: (Dhalika) without Waw, and the recitation is: {Wa Dhalika} with Waw. An-Naji (219/ 1) pointed this out, may Allah have mercy on him. 
2. I say: It contains Shahr bin Hawshab, and his condition is known. 
3. The author of "Musnad Al-Firdaws" attributed it to Muslim with his chain, which is a gross illusion as An-Naji said (219/ 2).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by An-Nasa'i (1). 2040 - (6) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever flees from the inheritance of his heir; Allah cuts off his inheritance from Paradise on the Day of Resurrection." Narrated by Ibn Majah. 2041 - (7) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "For a man to give charity during his life and health of a dirham; is better for him than to give charity at his death of a hundred." Narrated by Abu Dawood, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; both from Shurahbil bin Sa'd from Abu Sa'id (2). 2042 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Darda (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "The likeness of the one who emancipates [slaves] at his death; is like the one who gives gifts when he is satiated." Narrated by Abu Dawood. And At-Tirmidhi and said:
foot_note:
1. I say: In "As-Sunan Al-Kubra" (6/ 320/ 11092) and as Mawquf on Ibn Abbas. And its chain is authentic. Therefore, I say: His saying: "From the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)" is either an illusion from the author, or inserted by some copyists. Otherwise, attributing it to An-Nasa'i is the illusion or insertion, and the correct attribution is "Al-Uqayli", for he narrated it in full. Ad-Daraqutni and Al-Bayhaqi narrated it without his saying: "Then he recited...", and Al-Bayhaqi and others said: "The correct view is Mawquf." The three ignorant ones dared and transgressed their limits saying in their commentary on the hadith (4/ 224): "Mawquf Weak, An-Nasa'i narrated it in 'As-Sunan Al-Kubra' as Mawquf". I have refuted them and clarified their compounded ignorance in the documentation of the hadith in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5907). 
2. I say: The author indicated finding a defect in it due to (Shurahbil), for he is weak. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1321).

(Al-Hafiz said): "It was presented in 'Book of Sales' [16/ 15] what came regarding hastening to pay the debt of the deceased and the encouragement for that."

text: 10 - (Intimidation against a person hating death, and encouragement to receive it with satisfaction and joy if it descends out of love for meeting Allah Almighty). 2043 - (1) [Weak] And Ibn Majah narrated it [meaning the hadith of Fadalah bin Ubaid which is in "As-Sahih"] from the hadith of Amr bin Ghailan Ath-Thaqafi - and he is among those whose companionship is disputed - and his wording is: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "O Allah! Whoever believes in me and verifies me, and knows that what I brought is the truth from You; decrease his wealth and his children, make meeting You beloved to him, and hasten the decree for him. And whoever does not believe in me and does not verify me, and does not know that what I brought is the truth from You; increase his wealth and his children, and prolong his life." [Past 24 - Repentance /5]. 2044 - (2) [Weak] And from Abdullah bin Amr (may Allah be pleased with them both) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "The masterpiece of the believer is death." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Jayyid Isnad (1). 2045 - (3) [Weak] And from Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If you wish I will inform you what is the first thing Allah Almighty says to the believers on the Day of Resurrection, and what is the first thing they say to Him?" We said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! He said: "Indeed Allah Almighty says to the believers: Did you love meeting Me? They say: Yes, O our Lord! He says: Why? They say: We hoped for Your pardon and Your forgiveness. He says: My forgiveness has become obligatory for you." Narrated by Ahmad from the narration of Ubaidullah bin Zahr.
foot_note: 1. Thus he said, and it contains Al-Ifriqi, and he is weak as mentioned repeatedly. So Al-Haythami's saying: "And its narrators are trustworthy" is also a mistake. The three ignorant ones imitated without research or consideration and said: "Hasan"! It is documented in several places; the most extensive verification is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6890).

text: 11 - (Encouragement of words to be said by one who has suffered a bereavement). 2046 - (1) [Weak] And At-Tirmidhi [narrated] [meaning the hadith of Umm Salamah which is in "Al-Sahih"] and his wording is: She said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If a calamity befalls one of you, let him say: (Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return. O Allah, with You I seek reward for my calamity, so reward me for it and replace it for me with something better than it)." [Munkar] When Abu Salamah was dying, he said: O Allah, grant a successor in my family better than me.
