text: (Al-Kuda) with a Dammah on the Kaf and a shortened neglected Dal: It is the cemeteries (1). 2077 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, went out and saw women sitting. He said: "What makes you sit?" They said: We are waiting for the funeral. He said: "Do you wash?" They said: No. He said: "Do you carry?" They said: No. He said: "Do you lower [the body] with those who lower?" They said: No. He said: "Then return bearing burdens (of sin) and not rewarded." Narrated by Ibn Majah (2). 2078 - (6) And Abu Ya'la narrated it from the hadith of Anas (3).
foot_note:
1. Al-Naji said: "He was lenient here and loose in expression, and said in his 'footnotes': '(Al-Kuda) is the plural of (Kudyah) which is the solid piece of land, and graves are only dug in solid places so they don't collapse'." 
2. I say: It contains Ismail bin Salman, who is Al-Azraq Al-Tamimi, weak by agreement. And it occurred in "Zawa'id Ibn Majah" by Al-Busiri (... bin Sulaiman), and it is an error as I explained in "Al-Da'ifah" (2742). He is disputed over, and regarding him Abu Hatim said: "Salih (righteous)"! But he is not from the men of Ibn Majah! So a biography entered into another biography for him, and the three ignorant ones did not notice that, so they copied it and affirmed it!! 
3. I say: Its text does not contain the sentence of washing. And in its chain (4056 and 4284) is (Al-Harith bin Ziyad) unknown. And from the ignorance of the Three, their inability, and narrow-mindedness is their saying in their comment on it: "We did not find it in the printed Musnad"!!

text: 21 - (Intimidation against passing by the graves of oppressors, their dwellings, and their places of destruction while being heedless of what befell them (1), and some of what has come regarding the punishment of the grave and its bliss and the questioning of Munkar and Nakir, peace be upon them. Chapter 2079 - (1) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Ninety-nine dragons (Tinnin) are set upon the disbeliever in his grave, biting him and stinging him until the Hour is established. If one dragon of them were to blow on the earth, no greenery would grow." Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, and from his path Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; all of them from the path of Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham. 2080 - (2) [Weak] And Al-Bayhaqi narrated it [meaning the long hadith of Al-Bara regarding the punishment of the grave which is in "Al-Sahih"], then said: And Isa bin Al-Musayyib (2) narrated it from Adi bin Thabit from Al-Bara from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and mentioned in it the name of the two angels. He said regarding the believer:
foot_note:
1. See the hadith of this part of the chapter in "Al-Sahih". 
2. I say: Adh-Dhahabi said in "Al-Mughni": "Abu Dawud said: Weak. And Abu Hatim said: Not strong." I say: So the likes of his hadith would be Munkar (denounced) when contradicting [others] as is the case here, for the indicated authentic hadith does not contain what is in this one regarding the sentence of fangs and lips! And it is with Al-Bayhaqi in "Al-Shu'ab" (1/ 358). And the ignorant ones graded it Hasan! And they did not distinguish it from the authentic one before it, and this is little of their many confusions that cannot be counted. And regarding naming the two angels "Munkar and Nakir", there is another Jayyid (good) hadith referenced in "Al-Sahihah" (1391), and it is in "Al-Sahih" in this chapter.

text: "So he is returned to his bed, then Munkar and Nakir come to him, stirring the earth with their fangs, and scraping (Yaljifan) the earth with their lips (1), so they make him sit, then it is said to him: O you! Who is your Lord?" So he mentioned it. And he said regarding the mention of the disbeliever: "Then Munkar and Nakir come to him, stirring the earth with their fangs, and scraping (Yaljifan) (2) the earth with their lips, their voices like crashing thunder, and their eyes like flashing lightning. So they make him sit, then it is said: O you! Who is your Lord? He says: I do not know! Then it is called out from the side of the grave: You did not know, and they strike him with an iron sledgehammer, if those between the East and West gathered to lift it they could not lift it (3). His grave ignites with fire from it, and his grave constricts upon him until his ribs interlock." 2081 - (3) [Weak] And from him [meaning Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him] who said: We attended a funeral with the Prophet of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. When he finished burying it and the people turned away, the Prophet of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, he now hears the tapping of your sandals. Munkar and Nakir have come to him, their eyes like copper pots, their fangs like cow horns (Sayasi), and their voices like thunder. They make him sit and ask him: What did he use to worship? And who was his Prophet? If he was among those who worshipped Allah, he says: [I used to] worship Allah, and my Prophet is Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, he came to us with clear proofs and guidance, so we believed in him and followed him. That is the saying of Allah: {Allah keeps firm those who believe, with the firm word, in worldly life and in

1. (1 and 2) Thus in the original, and likewise in the edition of Umarah and others, and it has no meaning. Rather Al-Hafiz Al-Naji said: "This is a gross misspelling, it is only: (Yaksuhan or Yafhasan - Sweeping or Digging) the earth with their eyelashes (Ashfarihima)".

text: the Hereafter}. So it is said to him: Upon certainty you lived, and upon it you died, and upon it you will be resurrected. Then a door to Paradise is opened for him, and his grave is widened for him. And if he was from the people of doubt, he says: I do not know, I heard the people saying something so I said it. So it is said to him: Upon doubt you lived, and upon it you died, and upon it you will be resurrected. Then a door to Hell is opened for him, and scorpions and dragons are set upon him, if one of them blew on the world it would not grow anything. They bite him, and the earth is ordered so it constricts (1) until his ribs interlock." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" and he said: "Ibn Lahi'ah was solitary in it." (Al-Hafiz said): "Ibn Lahi'ah's hadith is Hasan in support (Mutaba'at), but as for what he is solitary in, few use it as proof. And Allah knows best" (2). (Sayasi Al-Baqar): Its horns. 22 - (Intimidation against sitting on the grave and breaking the bone of the dead). [There is no hadith under this on the condition of our book, and praise be to Allah. See "Al-Sahih"].
foot_note:
1. The original: (Fatadtamm), and likewise in the edition of Umarah, and on its margin: "And in N D (Fatan-damm). And in "Al-Majma'" (3/ 54): (Fatadummuhu), and it is closer to matching the image of "Al-Awsat". And the addition is from it, and it is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (5385). 
2. I say: Nothing of his hadith is used as proof except what was from the narration of the Abdullahs and their likes from him, or what trustworthy narrators agreed with him upon. And in this hadith of his are Munkar things for which I found no witness, like the sentence describing the eyes and fangs. And indeed, from the gathering of the ignorant ones and their incoherence is their grading this hadith as Hasan in imitation of what they quoted from Al-Haythami in "Al-Majma'" (3/ 52): "Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat', and its chain is Hasan"! This is from the ill-luck of gathering (indiscriminately) and inability to investigate. For Al-Haythami only said this about another hadith of Abu Hurairah twice as long as this one!! And he said about this one (3/ 54): "Narrated by At-Tabarani in 'Al-Awsat', and it contains Ibn Lahi'ah, and there is talk about him."

text: 26 - Book of Resurrection and the Terrors of the Day of Judgment. 1 - Chapter on Blowing into the Trumpet and the Establishment of the Hour (1). 2082 - (1) [Munkar - Denounced] And from Abdullah bin Al-Harith who said: I was with Aisha and with her was Ka'b Al-Ahbar, so he mentioned Israfil. So Aisha said: O Ka'b! Inform me about Israfil? Ka'b said: You have the knowledge. She said: Yes, inform me. He said: He has four wings: two wings in the air, a wing he is clad in, and a wing on his shoulder, [and the Throne is on his shoulder], and the Pen is on his ear. When the revelation comes down, the Pen writes then the angels study it. The Angel of the Trumpet is kneeling on one of his knees, and has raised the other, holding the Trumpet to his mouth, his back bent, [his gaze fixed towards Israfil], and he has been commanded that when he sees Israfil fold his wing, he is to blow into the Trumpet. So Aisha said: This is how I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a Hasan chain (2).
foot_note:
1. The author made this book into chapters - see "Al-Sahih" - and we saw fit to give the chapters serial numbers like sections. 
2. I say: Thus he said! And Al-Haythami and As-Suyuti in "Al-Durr Al-Manthur" (3/ 23) followed him, and the ignorant ones imitated them. Yet At-Tabarani said (10/ 132) after it: "No one narrated it except Mu'ammal bin Ismail", and he is weak due to his bad memory, and above him is (Ali bin Zaid) - who is Ibn Jud'an - weak like him. From his path Abu Nu'aym extracted it in "Al-Hilyah" (6/ 47 - 48), and found it Gharib, and the additions are from them. And likewise they are with Abu Al-Sheikh in "Al-Azamah" (2/ 694 - 696) from this face but it does not contain: "So Aisha said...". And he has another path (2/ 699/ 290) from Ka'b concisely and Maqtu' (disconnected). And Abu Nu'aym pointed to it. Its narrators are trustworthy men of Muslim, other than the Sheikh of (Abu Al-Sheikh): Shabab Al-Wasiti, and it appears he is (Shabab bin Isa bin Bint Aban) from the Sheikhs of (Bahshal) in "Tarikh Wasit" (p. 149), he cited a trace for him, and did not mention any criticism or praise for him as is his habit. And Allah knows best. And some liars narrated it as Marfu' to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so I referenced it in "Al-Da'ifah" (6895).

foot_note:

Even if (Abu Murayah) was trustworthy, so how [is it acceptable] when he is unknown and not famous as Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said. The original was (Abu Murayyah), and the correct spelling is what I affirmed, and I explained all of that in "Al-Da'ifah" (6896).

text: 2 - Chapter on the Gathering (Al-Hashr) and other things. 2086 - (1) [Weak] And from Umm Salamah, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "People will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection naked and barefoot." Umm Salamah said: So I said: O Messenger of Allah! What a disgrace! Will we look at each other? He said: "People will be occupied." I said: What will occupy them? He said: "The spreading of the scrolls, in them are weights of atoms and weights of mustard seeds." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with a correct chain (1). 2087 - (2) [Weak] And from Al-Hasan bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "People will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection barefoot and naked." A woman said: O Messenger of Allah! Then how will we see each other? He said: "Indeed the eyes will be staring [in horror]." And he raised his sight to the sky. She said: O Messenger of Allah! Supplicate to Allah to cover my nakedness. He said: "O Allah, cover her nakedness." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and it contains Sa'id bin Al-Marzuban, and he has been authenticated (2).
foot_note:
1. Thus he said! And it contains (1/ 462/ 837) (Abdul-Hamid bin Sulaiman) the brother of Fulaih, and he is weak. Adh-Dhahabi said: "They weakened him greatly." Al-Haythami claimed he is from the men of Al-Sahih! And the ignorant ones imitated them and said: "Hasan"! And it is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (5318), and Al-Haythami has another error regarding the name of another narrator in its chain which I explained there. The hadith is in "Al-Sahih" from Aisha without the sentence of "The Scrolls". 
2. I say: He is weak and a Mudallis, and some abandoned him. He contradicted in his chain and text as I explained in "Al-Sahihah" under (3469). As for the ignorant ones, they said "Hasan due to its witnesses"! Yet what follows the woman's saying: "we see each other" has no witness worth mentioning!

text: 2088 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "People will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection in three categories: a category walking, a category riding, and a category on their faces." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Hasan Hadith" (1). 2089 - (4) [Munkar - Denounced] And from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Truthful and Trusted One told me: "Indeed people will be gathered in three troops: A troop riding, fed, and clothed. A troop dragged by the angels on their faces and gathered to the Fire. And a troop walking and running" the Hadith. Narrated by An-Nasa'i (2). 2090 - (5) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Allah will resurrect on the Day of Resurrection people in the forms of ants; people will tread upon them with their feet. It will be said: What is the matter with these in the forms of ants? It will be said: These are the arrogant ones in the world." Narrated by Al-Bazzar.
foot_note:
1. Thus he said, and it is with him (3141) from the narration of Ali bin Zaid, from Aws bin Khalid, from Abu Hurairah. And from this face Ahmad extracted it (2/ 354 and 363). And Ali bin Zaid - who is Ibn Jud'an - is weak, and Aws is unknown. And the ignorant ones also said: "Hasan due to its witnesses." And they lied, for it has not even one witness except the sentence of walking on the face. And it is in "Al-Sahih". 
2. I say: Al-Hakim missed it (2/ 367) and authenticated it, and Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him saying it is Munkar containing (Al-Walid bin Abdullah bin Jami') whom Ibn Hibban weakened. And Abu Hatim defected it as his son narrated in "Al-Ilal" (2/ 224 - 225), so check it if you wish.

text: 2091 - (6) [Weak] And from Abdul-Aziz Al-Attar from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him - I do not know him [narrating it] except raising it (to the Prophet) - he said: "The son of Adam has not met anything since Allah Almighty created him more severe upon him than death. Then indeed, death is easier than what comes after it. And indeed they will meet from the terror of that Day a severity; until sweat will bridle them, such that if ships were to sail in it, they would sail." Narrated by Ahmad as Marfu' concisely, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" with doubt like this, and the wording is his, and their chain is Jayyid (1). 2092 - (7) [Weak] And from Abdullah - meaning Ibn Mas'ud - may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The whole earth will be fire on the Day of Resurrection, and Paradise is behind it [they will see] (2); its buxom maidens and equal-aged companions. By the One in Whose Hand is the soul of Abdullah! Indeed a man will overflow with sweat until it flows in the earth to the height of a man, then it rises until it reaches his nose, and the Account has not yet touched him. They said: Why is that, O Abu Abdur-Rahman? He said: From what he sees the people encountering. Narrated by At-Tabarani as Mawquf with a Jayyid strong chain.
foot_note:
1. Thus he said! And Al-Haythami followed him, and the Three imitated them so they said: "Hasan, Al-Haythami said.."! And (Abdul-Aziz Al-Attar) is unknown as Abu Hatim and Adh-Dhahabi said: And no one authenticated him except Ibn Hibban, contrary to his Sheikh Ibn Khuzaimah, for he disavowed responsibility for him. And it is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (4338). 
2. This addition is in At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (9/ 168/ 8771) and "Jami' Al-Masanid" (27/ 74/ 89) from him. And it did not appear in "Majma' Al-Haythami" (10/ 336) either, and its meaning is not apparent here, so perhaps it is an insertion. And Allah knows best. Then I saw it in "Al-Zuhd" by Waki' (2/ 648/ 365) with the wording: "Tara - is seen", and this is apparent, but the chain is not strong; because it is disconnected between Khaithamah bin Abdullah and Ibn Mas'ud, for he did not hear from him; as Ahmad and others said. So the authentication of the three contemporary commentators is only from their ignorance and imitation.

text: 3 - Chapter on the Reckoning (Al-Hisab) and other things. 2096 - (1) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Three registers will be brought out for the son of Adam on the Day of Resurrection: A register containing good deeds, a register containing his sins, and a register containing the blessings from Allah upon him. Then Allah will say to the smallest blessing - I think he said: in the register of blessings -: Take your price from his good deeds. So it consumes his good deeds, then steps aside and says: By Your Glory, I have not fully taken [my right]. And the sins and blessings remain while the good deeds are gone. So if Allah wants to have mercy on a servant, He says: O My servant, I have doubled your good deeds for you, and overlooked your bad deeds, - I think he said: and I have gifted you My blessings -." Narrated by Al-Bazzar (1). 2097 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both: That a man from Abyssinia came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah! So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

text: "By the One in Whose Hand is my soul; indeed a man will come on the Day of Resurrection with deeds that if placed on a mountain would weigh it down. Then a blessing from the blessings of Allah stands up and almost exhausts all of that, were it not for what Allah bestows of His mercy. Then it was revealed: {Has there not come upon man a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned} [Al-Insan: 1] to his saying: {And when you look there, you will see pleasure and great dominion} [Al-Insan: 20]." So the Abyssinian said: O Messenger of Allah! And will my eye see in Paradise the like of what your eye sees? The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Yes." So the Abyssinian wept until his soul overflowed (he died). Ibn Umar said: And I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, lowering him into his grave. He says: Take My servant by a blessing from My blessings. So no good deed remains for him except that that blessing absorbed it. So he says: Lord! By Your blessing and Your mercy. foot_note:

text: 2099 - (4) [Very Weak] (*) And from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came out to us and said: "My friend Gabriel just left me and said: O Muhammad! By the One who sent you with the truth; indeed Allah has a servant from His servants who worshipped Allah for five hundred years on top of a mountain in the sea; its width and length are thirty cubits by thirty cubits, and the sea surrounds it by four thousand Farsakhs from every side. He brought out for him a fresh spring the width of a finger, overflowing with fresh water, which gathers at the bottom of the mountain, and a pomegranate tree which produces a pomegranate for him every night. He worships during his day, and when evening comes he descends and takes from the water for ablution, and takes that pomegranate and eats it, then stands for his prayer. He asked his Lord at the time of death to take his soul while prostrating, and not to give the earth or anything that would corrupt him a way over him; until Allah resurrects him while he is prostrating. - He said: - So He did. So we pass by him when we descend and when we ascend. We find regarding him in the Knowledge that he will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection, and will be made to stand before Allah. The Lord will say to him: Enter My servant into Paradise by My mercy. He will say: Lord! Rather by my deeds. He will say: Enter My servant into Paradise by My mercy. He will say: Lord! Rather by my deeds. So Allah will say: Compare My servant with My blessing upon him and with his deeds. So the blessing of eyesight is found to encompass the worship of five hundred years, and the blessing of the body remains as surplus against him. So He says: Enter My servant into the Fire. So he is dragged towards the Fire, and he calls out: Lord! By Your mercy enter me into Paradise! He says: Return him. So he is made to stand before Him. He says: O My servant! Who created you when you were nothing? He says: You, O Lord! He says: Who strengthened you for the worship of five hundred years? He says: You, O Lord! He says: Who settled you on a mountain in the middle of the abyss, and brought out for you fresh water from salty water, and brought out for you a pomegranate every night, while it only comes out once a year, and you asked Him to take your soul while prostrating so He did? He says: You, O Lord! He said:

text: 4 - Chapter on the Pool (Hawd), the Scale (Mizan), and the Bridge (Sirat) (1). 2106 - (1) [Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "My Pool is from such to such; in it are vessels as numerous as the stars, more fragrant than musk, sweeter than honey, colder than ice, and whiter than milk. Whoever drinks a sip from it will never thirst again, and whoever does not drink from it will never quench his thirst." Narrated by Al-Bazzar and At-Tabarani, and their narrators are trustworthy; except Al-Mas'udi (2). 2107 - (2) [Munkar - Denounced] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "While I was standing at the Pool, suddenly a group appeared. When I recognized them, a man came out from between me and them and said: 'Come.' I said: 'To where?' He said: 'To the Fire, by Allah.' I said: 'What is their affair?' He said: 'They apostatized [after you] turning back on their heels.' Then suddenly another group appeared. When I recognized them, a man came out from between me and them and said to them: 'Come.' I said: 'To where?' He said: 'To the Fire, by Allah.' I said: 'What is their affair?' He said: 'They apostatized [after you] on their heels.' So I do not see anyone saved from them except like the stray cattle (Hamal al-Na'am)." Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim (3). [Hamal al-Na'am: Strays, and it means that the saved ones are few like stray cattle in relation to the whole herd] (*)
foot_note:
1. In it is an indication that the Bridge (Sirat) is after the Pool (Hawd), and this is what Al-Hafiz asserted in "Al-Fath" (11/ 405 - 406). 
2. I say: He had become confused (mixed up), and among his confusions, in addition to the authentic hadiths of the chapter, is his saying: "And whoever does not drink from it...". The three ignorant ones participated in this confusion by saying: "Hasan due to its witnesses"! They lied! It is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (6700). 
3. I say: This wording belongs to Al-Bukhari excluding Muslim, for the latter has (1/ 150) the other wording, which is part of "Al-Sahih". As-Suyuti did not attribute the first one in "Zawa'id Al-Jami' Al-Saghir" except to Al-Bukhari alone. Then I saw that Al-Naji had preceded me to this alert, yet the three heedless ones did not notice. However, his saying: "Standing" (Qa'im) contradicts the narration of Al-Bukhari - for it uses the wording: "Sleeping" (Na'im), without his saying: "at the Pool". It appears to be an addition from the author, taken from other Mutawatir hadiths regarding the Pool; but his saying: "Sleeping" is Munkar, and it is = (*) The preparer of the book for Al-Shamila said: What is between the brackets is not in the printed version, and Sheikh Mashhoor affirmed it in his edition, and said: «It is in the original» (The preparer of the book for Al-Shamila said: Meaning the Muniriyyah edition which the Sheikh took as a base for his work)

text: 5 - Chapter on Intercession (Shafa'ah) and other things. 2113 - (1) [Munkar - Denounced] And from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saying: O Messenger of Allah! Narrated by Ahmad, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih". 2114 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Every Prophet on the Day of Resurrection will have a pulpit of light, and I will be on the tallest and brightest of them. A caller will come calling: Where is the Unlettered Prophet? He said: So the Prophets will say: All of us are an unlettered prophet, so to which of us was he sent? He returns a second time and says: Where is the Unlettered Arab Prophet? He said: So Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, descends until he comes to the Gate of Paradise and knocks. It is said: Who is it? He says: Muhammad or Ahmad. It is said: Or has he been sent for? He says: Yes. So it is opened for him, and he enters. Then the Lord, Blessed and Exalted, manifests to him, and He does not manifest to anything before him. So he falls down prostrating to Allah, and praises Him with praises that no one before him praised Him with, and no one after him will praise Him with.
