Bring me what You promised me. He said: For you is every Muslim male and female, and believer male and female, and whoever believed in Me and My Messengers and did righteous deeds, and did not associate anything with Me, and did not take equals besides Me. He is safe. And whoever asks Me, I give him. And whoever lends to Me, I repay him. And whoever relies upon Me, I suffice him. Indeed I am Allah, there is no god but I. I do not fail in My promise. Successful are the believers. Blessed is Allah, the Best of Creators. So she said: I am satisfied. Then he came upon a valley, and heard an ugly sound. He said: O Gabriel! What is this sound? He said: This is the voice of Hell, saying: O Lord! Bring me my people, and what You promised me; for my chains, shackles, blaze, boiling water, pus (Ghassaq), and wash (Ghishlin) have become abundant. My bottom has become deep, and my heat intense. Bring me what You promised me. He said: For you is every polytheist male and female,
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: and wicked male and female, and every tyrant who does not believe in the Day of Reckoning. She said: I am satisfied." Then he mentioned the hadith regarding the story of the Night Journey (Isra) and the obligation of prayer and other things. Narrated by Al-Bazzar from Ar-Rabi' bin Anas from Abu Al-Aliyah or someone else from Abu Huraira (1). 2123 - (4) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Az-Zubair, may Allah be pleased with them both; that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by a people while they were laughing, so he said: "Do you laugh while the mention of Paradise and the Fire is amongst you?!" He said: So no one from them was seen laughing until he died. He said: And revealed regarding them was: {Inform My servants that it is I who am the Forgiving, the Merciful (49) And that it is My punishment which is the painful punishment}. Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and there is no one abandoned or accused in its chain. 2124 - (5) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him; that he gave a sermon and said: "Do not forget the two great things: Paradise and the Fire." Then he wept until his tears flowed or wet the sides of his beard, then said: "By the One in Whose Hand is the soul of Muhammad! If you knew what I know of the matter of the Hereafter; you would have walked to the high ground, and you would have poured dust on your heads." Narrated by Abu Ya'la (2). 2125 - (6) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Gabriel came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, at a time other than his usual time. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood
foot_note:
1. I say: Al-Haythami defected it due to the anonymity of his Tabi'i! And this is not precise, because the narrator hesitated between him and Abu Al-Aliyah - as you see - and he is trustworthy. Then he overlooked defecting it due to those below him. He is Abu Ja'far Al-Razi, and he is weak. Adh-Dhahabi and Ibn Kathir denounced this hadith of his, and Al-Hafiz weakened its chain in "Al-Fath" (1/ 462). 
2. I say: It contains Ayyub bin Shabib Al-San'ani, and he is unknown (Majhul Al-Ayn) as I verified in "Al-Da'ifah" (6898). And the saying of the three ignorant ones: "Hasan due to its witnesses" is from their lies and nonsense. May Allah guide them!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: to him and said: "O Gabriel! Why do I see you with a changed color?" He said: I did not come to you until Allah Almighty commanded the bellows of the Fire! So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "O Gabriel! Describe the Fire to me, and describe Hell to me." So Gabriel said: Indeed Allah, Blessed and Exalted, commanded Hell so it was stoked for a thousand years until it became white, then He commanded so it was stoked for a thousand years until it became red, then He commanded so it was stoked for a thousand years until it became black. So it is black and dark, its sparks do not light up, and its flames are not extinguished. By the One who sent you with the truth, if the amount of a needle's eye were opened from Hell; everyone on earth would die from its heat. And by the One who sent you with the truth, if [a garment from the garments of the Fire were hung between the heaven and the earth; everyone on earth would die from its heat. And by the One who sent you with the truth, if] (1) a keeper from the keepers of Hell appeared to the people of the world; everyone on earth would die from the ugliness of his face and the stench of his smell. And by the One who sent you with the truth, if a link from the links of the chain of the people of the Fire which Allah described in His Book were placed on the mountains of the world; it would melt and not settle until it reached the lowest earth. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Enough, O Gabriel! Lest my heart splits and I die." He said: So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, looked at Gabriel while he was weeping. He said: "You weep, O Gabriel! While you are in the status with Allah that you are?"
foot_note: 1. This addition and the one after it at the end of the hadith fell from the original, and I recovered them from "Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat". As for the ignorant ones who claim verification, they did not recover them despite their attributing the hadith to "Al-Majma'" by number, and the other addition is in it! The reason is known, which is that they only care about citation!! And I referenced the hadith in "Al-Da'ifah" (5401).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: He said: And why should I not weep? I am more deserving of weeping, perhaps I will be in the knowledge of Allah in a state other than the one I am in. And I do not know, perhaps I will be tested with what Iblis was tested with, for he was from the angels. And I do not know, perhaps I will be tested with what Harut and Marut were tested with. He said: So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, wept, and Gabriel, peace be upon him, wept. They continued weeping until it was called out to them: O Gabriel! And O Muhammad! Indeed Allah Almighty has secured you both from disobeying Him. So Gabriel, peace be upon him, rose, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, went out and passed by a group of the Ansar laughing and playing. He said: "Do you laugh while Hell is behind you?! If you knew what I know, you would laugh little, and weep much, and you would not find food and drink palatable, and you would go out to the high grounds imploring Allah." [Then it was called out: O Muhammad! Do not make My servants despair, I only sent you as a facilitator, and I did not send you as a complicator. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Aim for correctness and do your best"]. Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". And the explanation of some of its strange words was previously mentioned in another hadith in "Mention of Death" [24/ 9]. 2126 - (7) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Umar also: That Gabriel, peace be upon him, came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, sad and not raising his head. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to him: "Why do I see you sad, O Gabriel?" He said: I saw a scorch (Lafha) (1) from Hell; and my spirit has not returned to me yet.
foot_note: 1. The original: (Nafha - breath/gust), and it is a gross misspelling, and the correction is from "Al-Awsat", and it is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (5402).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat". 2127 - (8) [Weak] And it was narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, recited this verse: {Its fuel is men and stones} [At-Tahrim: 6]. He said: "It was stoked for a thousand years until it became red, and a thousand years until it became white, and a thousand years until it became black. So it is black and dark, its flames are not extinguished" the Hadith. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Asbahani. And it was previously mentioned in its entirety in "Weeping" [24 - Repentance /7]. 2128 - (9) [Very Weak] And from Anas bin Malik also from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Indeed this fire of yours is a part of seventy parts of the fire of Hell. And were it not that it was extinguished with water twice; you would not have benefited from it. And indeed it supplicates to Allah not to return it to it." Narrated by Ibn Majah with a flimsy chain, and Al-Hakim from Jasr bin Farqad - and he is flimsy - from Al-Hasan from him. And he said: "Correct chain"! (1)
foot_note: 1. Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him in his "Talkhis" (4/ 593) saying: "I say: (Jasr) is flimsy, and (Bakr) An-Nasa'i said: Not trustworthy." And (Jasr) was corrupted by the printer or copyist to (Hasan)! So the ignorant ones copied it as such, so the flimsy one became (Al-Hasan) meaning Al-Basri!! And the hadith is in "Al-Da'ifah" (3208).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 1 - Chapter on the Intensity of its Heat and Other Things. 2129 - (1) [Shadh - Anomalous] And from Abu Huraira; that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed this fire is a part of one hundred parts of Hell" (1). Narrated by Ahmad, and his narrators are narrators of "Al-Sahih". 2130 - (2) [Very Weak] And from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If a bucket (Gharb) from Hell were placed in the middle of the earth; its stench and intense heat would harm what is between the East and the West. And if a spark from the sparks of Hell were in the East; whoever is in the West would feel its heat." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and in its chain is a possibility for improvement (Tahsin) (2). (Al-Gharb) with a Fathah on the dotted Ghain and Sukun on the Ra followed by a Ba: It is a large bucket. 2131 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both; regarding the saying of the Exalted: {When it sees them from a distant place} [Al-Furqan: 12]: From a distance of a hundred years. And that is when Hell is brought, led by seventy thousand reins, each rein held by seventy thousand angels. If it were left, it would come upon every righteous and wicked person. {They will hear its raging and breathing}: It exhales a breath and leaves no drop of tear except that it falls, then it exhales a second time and it cuts the hearts from their places, cutting the uvulas and larynxes, and that is His saying: {And the hearts reached the throats} [Al-Ahzab: 10]. Narrated by Adam bin Abi Iyas in his "Tafsir" as Mawquf.
foot_note:
1. Anomalous with the wording (one hundred), and what is preserved from Abu Huraira in the "Two Sahihs" and others is with the wording "seventy". See it in this chapter of "Al-Sahih". 
2. I say: No, for it contains (4/ 411/ 3693) Tamam bin Najih, and he is accused of fabrication. And it is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (5022).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2 - Chapter on its Darkness, Blackness, and Sparks. 2132 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "The Fire was stoked for a thousand years until it became red, then it was stoked for a thousand years until it became white, then it was stoked for a thousand years until it became black. So it is black like the dark night." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, and Al-Bayhaqi, and At-Tirmidhi said: "The hadith of Abu Huraira regarding this is Mawquf and more correct, and I do not know anyone who raised it (to the Prophet) other than Yahya bin Abi Bukair from Sharik" (1). [?] Razin added: "And if the people of the Fire found this fire of yours, they would sleep in it, or he said: they would take a siesta (Qalu) in it." 2133 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: That he mentioned this fire of yours and said: "It is a part of seventy parts of the fire of Hell, and it did not reach you until - I think he said: - it was washed with water twice so that it shines for you. And the fire of Hell is black and dark." Narrated by Al-Bazzar, and it was previously mentioned [before 1 - Chapter]; that Al-Hakim authenticated it. 2134 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from him also, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, recited this verse: {Its fuel is men and stones} [At-Tahrim: 6]. He said: "It was stoked for a thousand years until it became red, and a thousand years until it became white, and a thousand years until it became black. So it is black and dark, its flames do not light up - and in a narration: its flames are not extinguished -".
foot_note: 1. I say: Sharik is Ibn Abdullah the Judge, and he is weak. Some of it is in "Al-Sahih", and it is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (1305).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Asbahani. And it was previously mentioned [24 - Repentance/7]. 2135 - (4) [Weak Mawquf] And from Alqamah from Ibn Mas'ud: {Indeed, it throws sparks [as huge] as a castle} [Al-Mursalat: 32]; he said: Indeed I do not say like a tree, but like forts and cities. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi with a chain that has no harm, containing Hudayj (1) bin Mu'awiyah; Abu Hatim authenticated him.
foot_note: 1. I say: With a Dammah on the un-dotted Ha, and it occurred in the edition of the ignorant ones with a dotted Kha. Moreover, Abu Hatim's authentication of him is not explicit for he said: "His status is truthfulness, there is weakness in some of his hadith, his hadith is written." This is closer to weakening, and the majority weakened him. Furthermore, it is with Al-Bayhaqi in "Al-Ba'th" (280/ 574) from his narration from Abu Ishaq, who is Al-Sabi'i, and he had become confused.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 3 - Chapter on its Valleys and Mountains. 2136 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "{Wail} is a valley in Hell, the disbeliever falls in it for forty autumns (years) before he reaches its bottom." Narrated by Ahmad, and At-Tirmidhi; except that he said: "A valley between two mountains, the disbeliever falls in it for seventy autumns before he reaches its bottom." And Ibn Hibban narrated it in his "Sahih" similar to At-Tirmidhi's narration, and Al-Hakim and he said: "Correct chain"! And Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from the path of Al-Hakim; except that he said: "The disbeliever falls in it for forty autumns before the reckoning of the people is finished." (Al-Hafiz said): They all narrated it from the path of Amr bin Al-Harith from Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham, except At-Tirmidhi; for he narrated it from the path of Ibn Lahi'ah from Darraj, and said: "Gharib, we do not know it except from the hadith of Ibn Lahi'ah from Darraj." 2137 - (2) [Weak] And from him from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: Regarding the saying of the Exalted: {I will cover him with arduous torment (Sa'uda)} [Al-Muddaththir: 17]; he said: "A mountain of fire that he is burdened to climb. When he places his hand on it, it melts, and when he lifts it, it returns. And when he places his foot on it, it melts, and when he lifts it, it returns. He climbs for seventy autumns, then falls likewise." Narrated by Ahmad, and Al-Hakim from the path of Darraj also, and he said: "Correct chain"!
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And At-Tirmidhi narrated it from the path of Ibn Lahi'ah from Darraj concisely; he said: "Al-Sa'ud is a mountain of fire in which the disbeliever climbs for seventy autumns, and falls in it likewise forever." And he said: "Gharib, we do not know it as Marfu' except from the hadith of Ibn Lahi'ah." (Al-Hafiz said): "Al-Hakim narrated it as Marfu' as previously mentioned from the hadith of Amr bin Al-Harith from Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham from him. And Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from Sharik from Ammar Al-Duhni from Atiyyah Al-Awfi from him as Marfu' also, and from the hadith of Isra'il and Sufyan; both from Ammar from Atiyyah from him as Mawquf with similar meaning and an addition." 2138 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him: {So they will meet Ghayy} [Maryam: 59]; he said: A valley in Hell; into which those who follow desires are cast. Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Bayhaqi from the narration of Abu Ubaidah from his father Abdullah bin Mas'ud, and he did not hear from him. And the narrators of some of its paths are trustworthy. And in a narration of Al-Bayhaqi he said: A river in Hell; deep bottomed, foul tasting. And this chain is Jayyid were it not for the disconnection. 2139 - (4) [Weak Mawquf] And from Anas bin Malik; regarding His saying: {And We made between them a mawbiqa (place of destruction)} [Al-Kahf: 52]; he said: A valley of pus and blood. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and others from the path of Yazid bin Dirham, and he is disputed over (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: Such dispute is of no use, because the majority are on weakening him, among them Ibn Ma'in, who said: "He is nothing." The reason is that he makes many mistakes as Ibn Hibban himself said. See "Al-Lisan". And the hadith is in "Kitab Al-Ba'th" (260/ 520), and in "Al-Du'afa" also by Al-Uqayli (4/ 386/ 2001).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2140 - (5) [Very Weak] And from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Seek refuge in Allah from the Pit of Sorrow (Jubb al-Huzn) - or Valley of Sorrow -." It was said: O Messenger of Allah! And what is the Pit of Sorrow - or Valley of Sorrow -? He said: "A valley in Hell; Hell seeks refuge from it every day seventy times, Allah prepared it for the reciters who show off." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi with a Hasan chain (1). 2141 - (6) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Seek refuge in Allah from the Pit of Sorrow." They said: O Messenger of Allah! And what is the Pit of Sorrow? He said: "A valley in Hell; Hell seeks refuge from it every day four hundred times." It was said: O Messenger of Allah! Who enters it? He said: "It was prepared for the reciters who show off with their deeds, and indeed among the most hated reciters to Allah; are those who visit the unjust rulers." Narrated by Ibn Majah and the wording is his, and At-Tirmidhi and he said: "A Gharib Hadith." [Previously mentioned - Sincerity /1]. 2142 - (7) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani narrated from the hadith of Ibn Abbas from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Indeed in Hell there is a valley; Hell seeks refuge from that valley every day four hundred times, prepared for those who show off from the Ummah of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him." [Previously mentioned in its entirety there].
foot_note: 1. The ignorant ones imitated him, indicating that it is in "Al-Ba'th" under number (530)! And it contains two defects I explained in "Al-Da'ifah" (5024).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2143 - (8) [Weak Maqtu'] And from Shufayy bin Mati' who said: Indeed in Hell there is a castle called: (Hawa); the disbeliever is thrown from its top for forty autumns before he reaches its bottom. Allah Almighty said: {And he upon whom My anger descends has certainly fallen (Hawa)} [Taha: 81]. And indeed in Hell there is a valley called: (Athaman); in it are snakes and scorpions, the size of one of them is like seventy Qullahs (large jugs) of poison, and the scorpion among them is like a saddled mule. It stings a man and what he feels of the heat of Hell does not distract him from the burning of its sting. It is for whom it was created. And indeed in Hell there is a valley called: (Ghayyan); flowing with pus and blood. And indeed in Hell there are seventy diseases, each disease like a part of the parts of Hell. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya as Mawquf on him (1), and there is disagreement about his companionship as previously mentioned. 2144 - (9) [Weak Maqtu'] And from Ata bin Yasar who said: Indeed in the Fire there are seventy thousand valleys, in every valley seventy thousand ravines, in every ravine seventy thousand holes, and in every hole a snake that eats the faces of the people of the Fire. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya from the narration of Ismail bin Ayyash (2). 2145 - (10) [Munkar Mawquf] And Al-Bukhari narrated in his "Tarikh" from the path of Ismail bin Ayyash from Sa'id bin Yusuf (3) from Yahya bin Abi Kathir from Abu Sallam from Al-Hajjaj bin Abdullah - Al-Thumali and he has companionship -; that Nufair bin Mujib - and he was from the companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, from their early ones - said:
foot_note:
1. He extracted it and the one after it in "Sifat Al-Nar" (Folio 3/ 2), and in this is an unknown narrator, and another is hidden (Mastur). And its explanation is in "Al-Ta'liq Al-Raghib". 
2. I say: He is weak in his narration from the Madinans, and this is one of them. 
3. I say: He is Al-Rahbi Al-Dimashqi; weak, and Adh-Dhahabi said: He has a Munkar hadith. Then he mentioned this. And from his path Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya also (Folio 6/ 2), and Al-Bayhaqi (526).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Indeed in Hell there are seventy thousand valleys, in every valley seventy thousand ravines, in every ravine seventy thousand dwellings, in every dwelling seventy thousand houses, in every house seventy thousand wells, in every well seventy thousand serpents, in the jaw of every serpent seventy thousand scorpions. The disbeliever or the hypocrite does not stop until he encounters all of that. (Al-Hafiz said): "Sa'id bin Yusuf, he is Al-Yamami Al-Himsi Al-Rahbi, Yahya bin Ma'in weakened him, and An-Nasa'i said: Not strong. Ibn Abi Hatim said: Not famous, and I do not see his hadith as Munkar. Thus he said, so this hadith was presented against him; due to the apparency of its denunciation (Nakarah). And Allah knows best."
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 4 - Chapter on the Depth of its Bottom. 2146 - (1) [Very Weak] And At-Tabarani (1) narrated it [meaning the hadith of Abu Huraira which is in "Al-Sahih"] from the hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, heard a sound that terrified him, then Gabriel, peace be upon him, came to him. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "What is this sound, O Gabriel?" He said: This is a rock that fell from the edge of Hell seventy years ago; and this is when it reached its bottom, so Allah loved to make you hear its sound. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was not seen laughing to the fill of his mouth until Allah took his soul. 2147 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If a rock weighing ten pregnant camels (Khalifat); were thrown from the edge of Hell; it would not reach its bottom for seventy autumns until it reaches (Ghayy) and (Atham)." It was said: And what are (Ghayy) and (Atham)? He said: "Two wells in Hell; into which the pus of the people of the Fire flows. They are the ones Allah mentioned in His Book: {But there came after them successors who neglected prayer and pursued desires; so they are going to meet Ghayy} [Maryam: 59], and His saying: {And whoever does that will meet Atham} [Al-Furqan: 68]." Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Bayhaqi as Marfu' (2), and others narrated it as Mawquf on Abu Umamah; and it is more correct.
foot_note:
1. The generalization implies it is in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir"! But it is only in "Al-Awsat" (1/ 453/ 819), and it contains a Matruk (abandoned) narrator, and it is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (6705). 
2. I say: It contains two weak narrators, I referenced it in "Al-Sahihah" under Hadith (1312). And in it is a statement that the Mawquf is not authentic either.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Khalifat) plural of (Khalifah): which is the pregnant she-camel. 2148 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "The pavilion of the Fire has four walls, the thickness of every wall is a distance of forty years." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, and Al-Hakim and he said: "Correct chain" (1).
foot_note: 1. It contains (Darraj) from Abu Al-Haytham. And he is weak in narrating from him as we mentioned repeatedly.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 5 - Chapter on its Chains and Other Things. 2149 - (1) [Weak] From Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If a lead ball like this - and he pointed to something like a skull - were sent from the sky to the earth; which is a distance of five hundred years; it would reach the earth before night. And if it were sent from the head of the Chain; it would travel forty autumns night and day; before it reaches its base [or its bottom] (1). Narrated by Ahmad, At-Tirmidhi, and Al-Bayhaqi; all of them from the path of Darraj from Isa bin Hilal Al-Sadafi from him, and At-Tirmidhi said: "Its chain is Hasan." 2150 - (2) [Weak] And from Ya'la bin Munyah [may Allah be pleased with him] raising the hadith to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Allah creates a black dark cloud, so it is said: O people of the Fire! What do you ask for? So they remember by it the cloud of the world; so they say: O our Lord! Drink. So it rains upon them shackles adding to their shackles, and chains adding to their chains, and live coals blazing upon them." Narrated by At-Tabarani. And it was narrated as Mawquf on him, and that is more correct (2). And (Ya'la bin Munyah) is a famous Companion; and (Munyah) is his mother, and it is said: his grandmother; and she is Bint Ghazwan sister of Utbah bin Ghazwan, and he is often attributed to his father: Umayyah.
foot_note:
1. Addition from At-Tirmidhi (2591) and "Al-Musnad" (2/ 197). And Abdullah bin Ahmad narrated it without it in "Zawa'id Al-Zuhd" (p. 19 - 20). 
2. I say: It is not authentic as Marfu' nor Mawquf, because their chain is one, and it contains weakness and disconnection, and its explanation is in "Al-Da'ifah" (5403).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2151 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "If a hammer (Maqma') of iron from Hell were placed on the earth, and the two weighty races (Jinn and Men) gathered for it; they could not lift it from the earth." Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, and Al-Hakim and he said: "Correct chain". And in a narration of Ahmad and Abu Ya'la he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "If a mountain were struck with a hammer of iron from Hell; it would crumble then return." And Al-Hakim narrated this also; except that he said: "It would crumble and become ash." And he said: "Correct chain" (1). (Al-Maqma'): The hammer, and it is said: The whip. 2152 - (4) [Weak] And from Muhammad bin Hashim who said: When this verse was revealed: {A Fire whose fuel is men and stones} [At-Tahrim: 6], the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, recited it, and a youth by his side heard it and fainted. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, placed his head in his lap out of mercy for him. He remained as long as Allah willed for him to remain, then opened his eyes and said: May my father and mother be ransomed for you, what is the stone like? He said: "Does it not suffice you what befell you? That one stone of it, if placed on all the mountains of the world, they would melt from it, and indeed with every person of them is a stone and a devil."
foot_note: 1. I say: Both narrations are from the hadith of Darraj from Abu Al-Samh, and he is weak as previously mentioned repeatedly, and they are referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (4349 and 4350).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya from Abdullah bin Al-Waddah: Aba'ah bin Kulaib told us, from Muhammad bin Hashim. And Aba'ah; Abu Hatim said: "Saduq (Truthful), there is denial (Inkar) in his hadith, Al-Bukhari extracted him in 'Al-Du'afa', moved from there" (1). 2153 - (5) [Munkar - Denounced] And from Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed the earths, between every earth to the one next to it is a distance of five hundred years. The highest of them is on the back of a whale whose ends have met in heaven, and the whale is on a rock, and the rock is in the hand of an angel. The second is the prison of the wind. When Allah wanted to destroy 'Ad; He commanded the keeper of the wind to send upon them a wind that would destroy 'Ad. He said: O Lord! Shall I send upon them wind the amount of a bull's nostril? The Compeller, Blessed and Exalted, said to him: Then you would overturn the earth and whoever is on it, but send upon them the amount of a ring. And it is that which Allah said in His Book: {It left nothing of what it came upon but that it made it like disintegrated ruins} [Adh-Dhariyat: 42]. The third has the stones of Hell. The fourth has the sulphur of Hell." They said: O Messenger of Allah! Does the Fire have sulphur? He said: "Yes, by the One in Whose Hand is my soul; indeed there are valleys of sulphur in it, if the firm mountains were sent into it they would melt. The fifth has snakes whose mouths are like valleys; they bite the disbeliever a bite leaving no meat on the bone (Wadam). The sixth has the scorpions of Hell, the smallest scorpion of them is like saddled mules, it strikes the disbeliever a strike whose pain makes him forget the heat of
foot_note: 1. I say: Defecting it due to (Muhammad bin Hashim) is more appropriate, because he is from the layer of (Followers of the Tabi'in) so it is Mu'dal (perplexing/disconnected). Furthermore, it appears he is the one in the book "Al-Jarh" (4/ 1/ 116): "Muhammad bin Hashim. Heard Abu Al-Zinad, Ya'qub bin Muhammad Al-Zuhri narrated from him, and he is unknown."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Hell. And the seventh is Saqar, and in it is Iblis chained in iron, one hand in front of him, and one hand behind him. If Allah wants to release him for whatever He wills of His servants, He releases him." Narrated by Al-Hakim and he said: "Abu Al-Samh was solitary in it, and I have mentioned his probity by the text of Imam Yahya bin Ma'in, and the hadith is authentic and they (Bukhari and Muslim) did not extract it" (1). (Al-Hafiz said): "Abu Al-Samh is Darraj, and before him is Abdullah bin Ayyash Al-Qitbani, and the discussion on both of them will come, and in its text is denunciation (Nakara). And Allah knows best." His saying: (Tukfi' al-Ard) with a Hamza; meaning: Overturn it. And (Al-Wadam) with a Fathah on the Waw and the dotted Dad together: Is anything upon which meat is placed, and the meaning here is that no meat remains of him except that it falls from its place. 6 - Chapter on its Snakes and Scorpions. [There is no hadith under this on the condition of our book, and praise be to Allah. See "Al-Sahih"]
foot_note: 1. I say: Adh-Dhahabi critiqued him saying (4/ 594): "I say: Rather Munkar... Darraj has many Manakir (denounced narrations)."

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 7 - Chapter on the Drink of the People of the Fire. 2154 - (1) [Weak] From Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: Regarding His saying: {Like Muhl (murky oil)} [Al-Kahf: 29]; he said: "Like the dregs of oil. When it is brought near his face; the skin of his face falls into it." Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tirmidhi from the path of Rishdin bin Sa'd from Amr bin Al-Harith from Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham, and At-Tirmidhi said: "We do not know it except from the hadith of Rishdin." (Al-Hafiz said): "Ibn Hibban narrated it in his 'Sahih', and Al-Hakim from the hadith of Ibn Wahb from Amr bin Al-Harith from Darraj. And Al-Hakim said: Correct chain." 2155 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: Regarding the saying of the Exalted: {And he will be given to drink water of purulent fluid (Sadid) (16) Which he will gulp} [Ibrahim: 16-17]; he said: "It is brought near his mouth and he dislikes it. When it is brought closer to him, it scorches his face, and the scalp of his head falls off. When he drinks it, it cuts his intestines until it comes out of his anus. Allah Almighty says: {And are given to drink scalding water that will sever their intestines} [Muhammad: 15], and He says: {And if they call for relief, they will be relieved with water like murky oil, which scalds the faces. Wretched is the drink} [Al-Kahf: 29]." Narrated by Ahmad, and At-Tirmidhi who said: "A Gharib Hadith", and Al-Hakim who said: "Authentic on the condition of Muslim" (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: The hadith occurred with him in three places (from Abdullah bin Busr), and it is a misspelling by some narrators with him and with others too. This (Abdullah) is a Companion from the men of Muslim, and likewise those below him, that is why he authenticated it on the condition of Muslim. But it is a misspelling, and the correct name is (Ubaidullah) in diminutive form, and he is unknown. And it is referenced in "Al-Da'ifah" (6897).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Al-Hamim - Scalding Water): This is mentioned in the Quran in His saying: {and will be given scalding water to drink that will sever their intestines} [Muhammad: 15]. It was narrated from Ibn Abbas and others that (Al-Hamim) is: The hot water that burns. Ad-Dahhak said: (Al-Hamim) has been boiling since Allah created the heavens and the earth until the day they are given it to drink, and it is poured over their heads. It was said: It is what gathers from the tears of their eyes in the basins of the Fire, so they are given it to drink. And other things were said (1). 2156 - (3) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "If a bucket of Ghassaq (purulent discharge) of Hell were poured into the world; it would make the people of the world stink." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from the Hadith of Rishdin from Amr bin Al-Harith from Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham, and At-Tirmidhi said: "We only know it from the Hadith of Rishdin." (Al-Hafiz said): "Al-Hakim and others narrated it from the path of Ibn Wahb from Amr bin Al-Harith with it; and Al-Hakim said: Authentic chain of narration." (Al-Ghassaq): This is mentioned in the Quran in His saying: {This - so let them taste it - is scalding water and [foul] purulence} [Sad: 57], and His saying: {They will not taste therein [any] coolness or drink (24) Except scalding water and [foul] purulence} [An-Naba: 24-25]. There is a difference of opinion regarding its meaning; it was said: It is what flows from between the skin of the disbeliever and his flesh. This was said by Ibn Abbas. It was said: It is the pus of the people of the Fire. This was said by Ibrahim, Qatadah, Atiyyah, and Ikrimah. Ka'b said: It is a spring in Hell into which flows the venom of every venomous creature, snake or scorpion or otherwise, and it stagnates. Then the human is brought and dipped into it once; and he comes out with his skin and flesh having fallen off the bones, and his skin and flesh hang from his heels and ankles, dragging his flesh as a man drags his garment. Abdullah bin Amr said: (Al-Ghassaq): Thick pus, if a drop of it were poured in the West,
foot_note: 1. This paragraph on the meaning of (Al-Hamim) is located in the original just before the Hadith of Abu Umamah, and we moved it here for the necessity of context.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: it would make the people of the East stink, and if it were poured in the East, it would make the people of the West stink. And other things were said. 2157 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Three will not enter Paradise: An addict of wine, a cutter of kinship ties, and a believer in magic. And whoever dies addicted to wine; Allah, Glorified and Exalted, will give him to drink from the River of Ghuta." It was said: And what is the River of Ghuta? He said: "A river flowing from the private parts of prostitutes; the smell of their private parts harms the people of the Fire." Narrated by Ahmad, Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Hakim who said: "Authentic chain of narration." (Al-Mumisat) with a Damma on the first Mim and Kasra on the second: Are the adulteresses. [Passed 21 - Limits /6]. 2158 - (5) [Weak] And from Asma bint Yazid; that she heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "Whoever drinks wine; Allah will not be pleased with him for forty nights. If he dies, he dies a disbeliever. And if he repeats; it is a right upon Allah to give him to drink from Tinat al-Khabal (Mud of Corruption)." It was said: O Messenger of Allah! And what is Tinat al-Khabal? He said: "The pus of the people of the Fire." Narrated by Ahmad with a Hasan chain. [Also passed there]. [Fabricated] And previously in it was the Hadith of Anas: "Whoever leaves the world while drunk; enters the grave drunk, and is resurrected from his grave drunk, and is ordered to the Fire drunk, [to a mountain called: Sakran (Drunk)], in which is a spring from which flows pus and blood, which is their food and drink as long as the heavens and earth endure."
foot_note: None

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 8 - Chapter on the food of the people of the Fire. 2159 - (1) [Weak] From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, recited this verse: {Fear Allah as He should be feared and do not die except as Muslims} [Al-Imran: 102], then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "If a drop of Zaqqum were to fall into the abode of the world, it would spoil the livelihood of the people of the world. So how about the one whose food it is?!" Narrated by At-Tirmidhi, An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih"; except that he said: "So how about the one who has no other food?!" And Al-Hakim; except that he said in it: He said: "By the One in whose hand is my soul! If a drop of Zaqqum were to fall into the seas of the earth, it would spoil - or he said: make bitter - the livelihood of the people of the earth. So how about the one whose food it is?!" And he said: "Authentic according to their (Bukhari and Muslim) conditions," and At-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Sahih Hadith." And it was narrated as Mawquf (halted at the companion) on Ibn Abbas (1). 2160 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Hunger will be cast upon the people of the Fire, equaling the punishment they are already in. So they will seek relief, and will be relieved with food of Dhari' (thorny plant) which neither nourishes nor avails against hunger. So they will seek relief with food;
foot_note: 1. I say: It is the most correct from him, and in it is a weak narrator, and in the Marfu' (raised to Prophet) version there is Tadlis (concealing defects). Its explanation is in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6782), a detailed explanation you won't see elsewhere.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: and will be relieved with food that chokes. So they will remember that they [used to] (1) pass choking food in the world with drink [so they seek relief with drink] (*). So boiling water (Hamim) will be pushed towards them with iron hooks. When it approaches their faces, it roasts their faces. When it enters their bellies, it cuts what is in their bellies. They will say: Call the keepers of Hell. So they will say: {Did there not come to you your messengers with clear proofs? They will say, "Yes." They will reply, "Then supplicate," but the supplication of the disbelievers is not except in error} [Ghafir: 50]. He said: So they will say: Call Malik. So they will say: {O Malik, let your Lord put an end to us!} [Az-Zukhruf: 77]. He said: So he will answer them: {Indeed, you will remain} [Az-Zukhruf: 77]. - Al-A'mash said: I was informed that between their call and Malik's answer to them is a thousand years -. He said: So they will say: Call your Lord, for no one is better than your Lord. So they will say: {Our Lord, our wretchedness overcame us, and we were a people astray (106) Our Lord, remove us from it, and if we return [to evil], we are indeed wrongdoers} [Al-Mu'minun: 106-107]. He said: So He will answer them: {Remain despised therein and do not speak to Me} [Al-Mu'minun: 108]. He said: At that, they will despair of all good, and at that, they will begin moaning, regret, and woe." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Al-Bayhaqi; both from Qutbah bin Abdul-Aziz from Al-A'mash from Shimr bin Atiyyah from Shahr bin Hawshab from Umm Darda from him. At-Tirmidhi said: "Abdullah bin Abdur-Rahman (2) said: People do not raise this Hadith (to the Prophet). He said: This Hadith was only narrated from Al-A'mash from Shimr bin Atiyyah from Shahr bin Hawshab from Umm Darda from Abu Darda as his saying, and it is not Marfu' (raised). And Qutbah bin Abdul-Aziz is trustworthy according to the people of Hadith" End. 2161 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: Regarding His Almighty's saying: {And food that chokes} [Al-Muzzammil: 13]; he said: Thorns that stick in the throat, neither entering nor exiting. Narrated by Al-Hakim as Mawquf from Shabib bin Shaybah from Ikrimah from him, and he said: "Authentic chain of narration."
foot_note:
1. Addition from At-Tirmidhi (2589). 
2. I say: He is Imam Ad-Darimi, author of "As-Sunan" known as "Musnad Ad-Darimi", and he is At-Tirmidhi's teacher in this Hadith. It is not authentic in my view at all; neither Marfu' nor Mawquf; because both revolve around (Shahr) as you see. The Mawquf was extracted by Ibn Jarir in "At-Tafsir" (18/ 46), and Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Sifat An-Nar" (Folio 5/ 2 - 6/ 1). (*) The preparer of the book for Ash-Shamela said: What is between the brackets is not in the printed version, and Sheikh Mashhur established it in his edition and said: It is established in "Al-Muniriyyah" and others, and in "At-Tirmidhi" and "Al-Ba'th wa An-Nushur" by Al-Bayhaqi.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 9 - Chapter on the hugeness of the people of the Fire and their ugliness therein. 2162 - (1) [Weak Mawquf] From Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: If a man from the people of the Fire were brought out to the world; the people of the world would die from the frightfulness of his appearance and the stench of his smell. He said: Then Abdullah wept severely. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya as Mawquf (1), and in its chain is Ibn Lahi'ah. 2163 - (2) [Weak] And from Ibn Umar (2), may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed, the disbeliever will drag his tongue a Farsakh (league) or two Farsakhs, and people will tread on it." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi from Al-Fadl bin Yazid from Abu Al-Mukhariq from him, and he said: "This is a Hadith we only know from this face. Al-Fadl bin Yazid is Kufan and more than one Imam has narrated from him. Abu Al-Mukhariq is not known" End. (Al-Hafiz said): Narrated by Al-Fadl bin Yazid from Abu Al-Ajlan who said: I heard Abdullah bin Umar (2) say: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed, the disbeliever will drag his tongue two Farsakhs on the Day of Resurrection; people will tread on it." Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi and others, and this is the correct version. At-Tirmidhi's statement: "Abu Al-Mukhariq is not known"
foot_note:
1. I say: It is with him in the aforementioned source (Folio 7/ 2 - 8/ 1). 
2. The original: (Ibn Amr), and likewise in the edition of the ignorant ones even though they attributed it to At-Tirmidhi with the number as is their habit. Likewise, they attributed it to the book "Al-Ba'th" by Al-Bayhaqi! And they missed attributing it to Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya in "Al-Ahwal" (143/ 126)! And it is (Ibn Umar) in all of them! And (Abu Al-Ajlan) appeared in place of (Abu Al-Mukhariq) in the last two sources. Al-Bayhaqi said: "This is a mistake, it is (Abu Al-Ajlan Al-Muharibi), and Al-Bukhari mentioned him in (Al-Kuna)." Adh-Dhahabi said: "This is the correct one, and he is not known." It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1986).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: is an illusion. Rather he is Abu Al-Ajlan Al-Muharibi. Al-Bukhari mentioned him in "Al-Kuna"; and Abu Bakr Murabba' Al-Hafiz said: "He has nothing from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with this chain except this Hadith" End. 2164 - (3) [Munkar] And from him also from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "The people of the Fire will become huge in the Fire; until between the earlobe of one of them and his shoulder is a distance of seven hundred years travel. And the thickness of his skin is seventy cubits, and his molar is like Uhud." Narrated by Ahmad, and At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat", and its chain is close to Hasan (1). 2165 - (4) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: Regarding His Almighty's saying: {The Day We will call forth every people with their record [of deeds]} [Al-Isra: 71]; he said: "One of them is called and given his book in his right hand. His body is extended to sixty cubits, his face is whitened, and a crown of shining pearls is placed on his head. He goes to his companions who see him from afar and say: O Allah, bring this one to us, and bless us in this. Until he comes to them and says to them: Rejoice, for every man among you has the like of this. - He said: - As for the disbeliever, his face is blackened, and his body is extended to sixty cubits in the form of Adam (human form), and he is made to wear a crown of fire. His companions see him and say: We seek refuge in Allah from the evil of this one, O Allah do not bring this one to us. He comes to them and they say: O Allah disgrace him. He says: May Allah distance you, for every man among you has the like of this."
foot_note: 1. I say: Rather its chain is weak, its text is Munkar (denounced), contradicting the authentic Hadiths except for the molar, which are in the "Sahih". It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (1323). The sentence (thickness of his skin) can also be excepted if the meaning of thickness is width, for in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah in the "Sahih" here there is a narration with a Hasan chain with the wording: "And the width of his skin is seventy cubits," so let it be considered. As for the ignorant ones, they rushed and said as is their habit: "Hasan due to its witnesses"!!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Narrated by At-Tirmidhi who said: "Hasan Gharib Hadith", and the wording is his, Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" (1), and Al-Bayhaqi. 2166 - (5) [Weak] And Ibn Majah narrated from the path of Isa bin Al-Mukhtar from Muhammad bin Abi Laila from Atiyyah Al-Awfi from Abu Sa'id from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; that he said: "Indeed, the disbeliever is magnified until his molar is greater than (Uhud), and the bulk of his body compared to his molar is like the bulk of the body of one of you compared to his molar." 2167 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: {And they will grimace therein} [Al-Mu'minun: 104]; he said: "The Fire scorches him; so his upper lip contracts until it reaches the middle of his head, and his lower lip droops until it hits his navel." Narrated by Ahmad, At-Tirmidhi who said: "Hasan Sahih Gharib Hadith," and Al-Hakim who said: "Authentic chain of narration" (2). Al-Hafiz Abdul-Azim said: "It has been reported that some of this Ummah will be magnified in the Fire just as the disbelievers are magnified therein." 2168 - (7) [Weak] Thus Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim and others narrated from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Qais who said: I was with Abu Burdah one night, and Al-Harith bin Uqaysh, may Allah be pleased with him, entered upon us. Al-Harith told us that night that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said:
foot_note:
1. I say: In it is (Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Karimah), father of (Ismail As-Suddi) - and he is unknown (Majhul al-Ayn) as previously mentioned. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (4827). 
2. I say: It is from the narration of Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "Indeed, from my Ummah is one whose intercession will cause more people than (the tribe of) Mudar (1) to enter Paradise. And indeed, from my Ummah is one who will grow for the Fire until he becomes one of its corners." The wording is Ibn Majah's, and its chain is Jayyid (good), and Al-Hakim said: "Authentic according to the condition of Muslim" (2). Its wording was previously mentioned "Regarding one whose three children die" [17 - Marriage /9 - Chapter]. Ahmad narrated it with a Jayyid chain as well; except that he said: "From Abdullah bin Qais who said: I heard Al-Harith bin Uqaysh narrate; that Abu Barzah said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say:... then he mentioned it." Thus it is in my original copy, and I see it as a misspelling, and its correction is: I heard Al-Harith bin Uqaysh narrate; Abu Burdah; as in "Ibn Majah". And Allah knows best. 2169 - (8) [Weak] And from Abu Ghassan Ad-Dabbi who said: Abu Hurairah said to me at the back of (Al-Harrah): Do you know Abdullah bin Kharash? [I said: No. He said:] (3) I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: "His thigh in Hell is like Uhud, and his molar is like Al-Bayda'." I said: Why is that, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "He was disobedient to his parents." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a chain I do not recall.
foot_note:
1. This sentence about intercession has supporting evidences, some of which were mentioned previously in the "Sahih" (26/ End of 5 - Section). 
2. I say: Not so, it contains an unknown narrator as previously mentioned there. 
3. Addition from "Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat" (7/ 439), and in its chain is one who is not known. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5306). In the original, instead of (Al-Harrah) was: (Al-Hirah)! And instead of the addition was (And I)! So I corrected them from "Al-Mu'jam" and "Al-Majma'", and the ignorant ones did not correct it as is their habit!

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 10 - Chapter on their varying degrees of punishment, and mention of the one with the lightest punishment. 2170 - (1) [Weak Mursal] And from Ubaid bin Umair who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed, the one with the lowest punishment among the people of the Fire is a man wearing two sandals from which his brain boils; as if it were a cauldron. His ears are embers, his molars are embers, his eyelids are flames of fire, and the insides of his sides come out from his feet. And the rest of them are like a few grains in much water; he boils over." Narrated by Al-Bazzar (1) as Mursal with an authentic chain. 2171 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: "Indeed, when Hell had its people driven to it, it met them and scorched them with a scorch, leaving no flesh on a bone; except that it dropped it onto the ankle." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat", and Al-Bayhaqi as Marfu' (2). And others narrated it as Mawquf on him, and that is more correct. 2172 - (3) [Weak Mawquf] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas: Regarding His Almighty's saying: {The criminals will be known by their marks, and they will be seized by the forelocks and the feet} [Ar-Rahman: 41]; he said: He will be gathered between his head and his feet; then he will be snapped as firewood is snapped. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi as Mawquf (3).
foot_note:
1. The phrase: (Al-Bazzar) did not appear in An-Naji's copy of "At-Targhib". He said: "He said: (Narrated as Mursal with an authentic chain). Thus it appeared in the copies here with an omission, and perhaps it is: Narrated by Hannad bin Abi As-Sari in "Az-Zuhd" as attributed to him by Ibn Rajab Al-Hanbali in his book: "Sifat An-Nar", or Al-Bayhaqi." I say: Perhaps the phrase: (Al-Bazzar) is an addition from some copyists, for Al-Haythami did not mention the Hadith at all in "Al-Majma'". It is in "Az-Zuhd" as he said (1/ 193/ 309), and likewise Ibn Abi Shaybah (13/ 157/ 1598). And Allah knows best. 
2. I say: In it is (Muhammad bin Sulaiman bin Al-Asbahani) who is weak. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5302). 
3. I say: He extracted it in "Al-Ba'th" (286/ 591), and in it is (Al-Kudaymi) who is a fabricator, and (Sharik) who is weak.

text: 1 - Chapter on the description of the people of Paradise entering Paradise, and other matters. 2181 - (1) [Very Weak] From Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: That he asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, about this verse: {The Day We will gather the righteous to the Most Merciful as a delegation} [Maryam: 85]. He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! A delegation is only riders? The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "By the One in whose hand is my soul; when they emerge from their graves they are met with white she-camels, having wings, upon them are saddles of gold. The straps of their sandals are light that glimmers. Every step of them is as far as the eye can see. They arrive at the gate of Paradise, and there is a ring of red ruby on plates of gold. And there is a tree at the gate of Paradise from whose root two springs flow. If they drink from one of them, the freshness of bliss flows in their faces. And if they perform ablution from the other, their hair never becomes disheveled. They strike the ring with the plate. If you were to hear the ringing of the ring, O Ali! It reaches every Hoori that her husband has arrived. So haste seizes her, and she sends her warden (Qayyim) to open the door for him. Were it not that Allah Almighty made him know himself; he would have prostrated to him due to what he sees of light and splendor. He says: I am your warden who has been appointed to your command. So he follows him and traces his path until he comes to his wife. Haste seizes her, so she comes out of the tent and embraces him, saying: You are my love and I am your love. I am the pleased one so I will never be angry. I am the comfortable one so I will never be miserable. I am the eternal one so I will never depart. He enters a house from its foundation to its ceiling is a hundred thousand cubits, built on stones of pearls and rubies. Red paths, green paths, and yellow paths. No path among them resembles its companion. He comes to the couch (Arikah) and there is a bed on it. On the bed are seventy mattresses. On every mattress are seventy wives. On every wife are seventy garments. The marrow of her leg is seen from inside the garments. Their intercourse is completed in the amount of a night. Rivers flow beneath them

Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya (1). 2194 - (4) [Weak] And from Sahl bin Sa'd, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Indeed, in Paradise there is a rolling place (Maragh) of musk; like the rolling place of your beasts in the world." Narrated by At-Tabarani with a Jayyid chain (2). 2195 - (5) [Weak] And from Kurayb; that he heard Usamah bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with him, say: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Is there anyone rolling up his sleeves (striving) for Paradise? For indeed Paradise has no equal. It is, by the Lord of the Kaaba, shining light, swaying basil, a lofty palace, a flowing river, ripe fruit, a beautiful fair wife, many garments, an eternal stay, in a sound abode, fruit and greenery, joy and bliss, in a high splendid place." They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah! We are striving for it. He said: "Say: If Allah wills (Insha'Allah)." So the people said: If Allah wills. Narrated by Ibn Majah, Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, Al-Bazzar, Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and Al-Bayhaqi; all of them from the narration of Muhammad bin Muhajir from Ad-Dahhak Al-Ma'afiri from Sulaiman bin Musa from him. And Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya also narrated it briefly saying: From Muhammad bin Muhajir Al-Ansari: Sulaiman bin Musa told me. Thus in relied upon origins; he did not mention Ad-Dahhak in it. Al-Bazzar said:
foot_note:
1. I say: In its chain in "Sifat Al-Jannah" are three weak narrators in a row, some weaker than others. I have referenced it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6902). 
2. I say: Nay; for in it is (Abdul-Hamid bin Sulaiman) whom the majority weakened, and Al-Haythami followed them in some Hadiths. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3012). As for the ignorant ones, they said: "Hasan"!

text: "We do not know anyone who narrated it from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, except Usamah. And we do not know a path for it from Usamah except this path. And we do not know anyone who narrated it from Ad-Dahhak except this man Muhammad bin Muhajir." (Al-Hafiz Abdul-Azim said): "Muhammad bin Muhajir - and he is Al-Ansari - is trustworthy, Muslim and others used him as proof. As for Ad-Dahhak, none of the authors of the Six Books extracted for him except Ibn Majah, and I have not found any criticism or praise regarding him except from Ibn Hibban. Rather, he is counted among the unknown narrators (Majhulin). And Sulaiman bin Musa is Al-Ashdaq; his mention will come (1)."
foot_note: 1. I say: He is Al-Umawi, disputed. The defect is from the narrator from him (Ad-Dahhak), and some Mudallis narrators dropped him from the chain. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (3358).

text: 5 - Chapter on the tents of Paradise, its rooms, and other things. 2196 - (1) [Weak Mawquf] And from Abdullah bin Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Indeed, for every Muslim is a Khayrah (1), and for every Khayrah is a tent, and for every tent are four doors. Through every door enters a gift, a present, and an honor; that was not there before. And no Marhat, nor Dafrat (2), nor Sukhrat, nor Tammahat {Fair ones with wide, lovely eyes}, {As if they were hidden eggs}. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya from the narration of Jabir Al-Ju'fi as Mawquf. 2197 - (2) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both: {Fair ones reserved in pavilions} [Ar-Rahman: 72], he said: The tent is of a hollow pearl, its length is a league, its width is a league, and it has a thousand doors of gold. Around it is a pavilion, its circumference is fifty leagues. An angel enters upon him from every door of it with a gift from Allah Almighty. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya as Mawquf (3).
foot_note:
1. Meaning: A Hoori (Khayrah), and the plural is (Khayrat) as in His Almighty's saying: {In them are good and beautiful women (Khayrat Hisan)}. This was hidden from the graduate of Dar Al-Ulum, so he restricted it in his edition with Fathas (Khayarah)! In both places!! And the ignorant ones imitated him (4/ 419). 
2. With neglected or dotted Dal; meaning: Foul-smelling. And his saying: (No Sukhrat nor Tammahat). I say: It seems to mean His Almighty's saying: {And with them will be women limiting [their] glances} [As-Saffat: 48]; meaning: Chaste women who do not look at other than their husbands. 
3. In "Sifat Al-Jannah": (96/ 325) from the path of Yusuf bin As-Sabah Al-Fazari, from Abu Salih from him. And Abu Salih is (Badham) the freed slave of Umm Hani; weak. And this Yusuf I did not know.

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2198 - (3) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Imran bin Husain and Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with them, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was asked about His saying: {And goodly dwellings in gardens of perpetual residence} [As-Saff: 12]? He said: "A palace in Paradise of pearl, in it are seventy abodes of red ruby, in every abode are seventy houses of green emerald, in every house are seventy beds, on every bed are seventy mattresses of every color, on every mattress is a woman. In every house are seventy tables, on every table are seventy colors of food. In every house are seventy male servants and female servants. The believer is given of strength (1) what enables him to attend to all of that in a single morning." Narrated by At-Tabarani, and Al-Bayhaqi similarly.
foot_note: 1. The original: (Bi-quwwah - with strength), and the correction is from "Kabir At-Tabarani" and others. It is referenced in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6706). The last sentence of it has a witness in a Hadith of Abu Hurairah referenced in "As-Sahihah" under number (367), and another from the Hadith of Zaid bin Arqam which you find in the "Sahih" (8 - Section).

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 6 - Chapter on the rivers of Paradise. 2199 - (1) [Very Munkar Mawquf] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both; regarding His saying Almighty: {Indeed, We have granted you, [O Muhammad], Al-Kawthar} [Al-Kawthar: 1], he said: It is a river in Paradise, its depth in the earth is seventy thousand leagues. Its water is whiter than milk, and sweeter than honey. Its banks are pearls, chrysolite, and rubies. Allah specified it for His Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, before the Prophets. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya as Mawquf (1). 2200 - (2) [Weak Mawquf] And from Simak: That he met Abdullah bin Abbas in Medina after he lost his sight. He said: O Ibn Abbas! What is the ground of Paradise? He said: White marble, of silver as if it were a mirror. I said: What is its light? He said: Have you seen the hour when the sun rises? That is its light; except that there is no sun in it nor bitter cold. He said: I said: What are its rivers? Are they in trenches? He said: No; rather they flow on the ground of Paradise, restrained; not overflowing here nor there. Allah said to them: Be, and they were. I said: What are the garments of Paradise? He said: In it is a tree containing fruit like pomegranates. If a friend (Wali) of Allah wants clothing from it, it descends to him from its branch, and splits open for him revealing seventy garments
foot_note: 1. I say: In "Sifat Al-Jannah" (55/ 145) with a very weak chain, containing (Muhammad bin Awn); Matruk. Along with being Mawquf, it contradicts what is authentically reported as Mawquf and Marfu'; that the rivers of Paradise flow on the surface of the ground. It is referenced in "As-Sahihah" (2513), and will come soon in the "Sahih" of this chapter.

text: colors after colors, then it closes up, returning as it was. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya as Mawquf with a Hasan chain (1). 2201 - (3) [Very Weak Mawquf] And it was narrated from Anas also who said: {In both of them are two springs, spouting} [Ar-Rahman: 66] with musk and amber, spouting onto the houses of Paradise; just as rain spouts onto the houses of the people of the world. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah as Mawquf (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: How can it be Hasan, when he has in it (55/ 144) Zumayl bin Simak, and no one authenticated him, and he is not known except in this narration as understood from "Al-Jarh" (1/ 2/ 620). From his path Abu Ash-Sheikh extracted it in "Al-Azamah" (3/ 1101/ 599). 
2. I did not see it in his "Musannaf". Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated it from him in "As-Sifah" (37/ 70): Yahya bin Yaman told us from Abu Ishaq from Aban from Anas. And (Aban) is Ibn Abi Ayyash; Matruk. And (Abu Ishaq) from him, I did not know him. Abu Nu'aym narrated it (2/ 49/ 203) from this Ibn Yaman, and he is weak. And in it appeared (Abu Ishaq Al-Hazzani)!

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 7 - Section on the Trees and Fruits of Paradise. 2202 - (1) [Weak Mawquf] And from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Extended Shade (Al-Zill Al-Mamdud) is a tree in Paradise on a trunk; the diligent rider travels in its shade for one hundred years, in all its sides. The people of Paradise, the people of the chambers and others, come out and converse in its shade. He said: So some of them desire and remember the amusement of the world, so Allah sends a wind from Paradise which moves that tree with every amusement that was in the world. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya via the path of Zam'ah bin Salih from Salamah bin Wahram. Ibn Khuzaimah and Al-Hakim corrected it, and At-Tirmidhi classified it as Hasan (1). 2203 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, in Paradise there is a tree whose trunks are of gold and whose branches are of chrysolite (peridot) and pearl. A wind blows on it and it claps (makes a sound); the listeners have never heard a sound of anything more delightful than it ever." Narrated by Abu Nu'aym in "Sifat Al-Jannah" (2).
foot_note:
1. I say: Others declared it weak, and this is the most correct view in my opinion; because (Zam'ah bin Salih) was weakened by the majority, and his Sheikh (Salamah) was weakened by more than one. It is in Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya (28/ 45), and likewise Abu Nu'aym (2/ 226/ 404). His saying: "Ibn Khuzaimah corrected it..." etc.; this is from their leniency, although mentioning Ibn Khuzaimah with them is questionable; because he said in his "Sahih": "There is something in my heart regarding it." And he said in another place: "I am free from responsibility for it." See "Ad-Da'ifah" (2758). 
2. In its chain (271 - 272/ 433) is Maslamah bin Ali, and he is abandoned (Matruk), and his successor (Tabi'i) was not named.

text: 8 - Section on the Eating and Drinking of the People of Paradise and Other Matters. 2204 - (1) [Fabricated] And At-Tabarani [narrated the Hadith of Zaid bin Arqam which is in "As-Sahih"] with a Sahih chain, and his wording (1) in one of his narrations said: While we were with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), a man from the Jews came, called Tha'labah bin Al-Harith, and said: Peace be upon you, O Muhammad! He said: "And upon you." The Jew said to him: You claim that in Paradise there is food, drink, and spouses? The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Yes; do you believe in the tree of musk?" He said: Yes. He said: "And do you find it in your book?" He said: Yes. He said: "Then the urine and impurity is sweat that flows from under their locks (of hair) to their feet as musk." 2205 - (2) [Weak] And from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) raising it (to the Prophet) said: "Indeed, the lowest of the people of Paradise all together; is one at whose head stand ten thousand servants. With every servant are two bowls; one of silver and one of gold. In every bowl is a color (of food) not like the other. He eats from the last of it just as he eats from the first of it; he finds in the last of it a pleasure and taste that he does not find in the first of it. Then after that, there is oozing of musk and belching of
foot_note: 1. I say: With this wording it is fabricated (Mawdu'). At-Tabarani said in "Al-Awsat": "Abdul-Nur bin Abdullah was unique in narrating it," and he is a liar as Adh-Dhahabi said, and Al-Uqayli accused him of fabrication. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5330). As for the ignorant ones, they mixed - as is their habit - between this fabricated one and the Hadith found in "As-Sahih", and covered both by saying: "Hasan"! Half-solutions!!

text: musk. They do not urinate, nor defecate, nor blow their noses." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and the wording is his, and At-Tabarani, and its narrators are trustworthy. [Passed here 2 - Section]. 2206 - (3) [Denounced] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, the lowest of the people of Paradise in rank; is one who has seven degrees, he is on the sixth and above him is the seventh. He has three hundred servants, and every morning and evening three hundred bowls are brought to him - and I do not know but he said: of gold - in every bowl is a color not in the other. He finds pleasure in the first of it as he finds pleasure in the last of it. And from drinks, three hundred vessels, in every vessel is a color not in the other. He finds pleasure in the first of it as he finds pleasure in the last of it. And he says: 'O Lord! If You permitted me, I would feed the people of Paradise and give them drink, and nothing of what I have would decrease.'" The Hadith. Narrated by Ahmad from Shahr from him. [It comes in full 11 - Section]. 2207 - (4) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "You will look at a bird in Paradise and desire it; so it will fall down (1) roasted before your hands." 2208 - (5) [Weak] And it was narrated from Maymunah (may Allah be pleased with her); that she heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Indeed, a man will desire a bird in Paradise; so it comes like a Bactrian camel (Bakhti) until it lands on his table, no smoke has touched it, nor bas fire touched it, so he eats from it until he is satisfied, then it flies away." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya (2).
foot_note:
1. The original: (Fayaji'u - so it comes), which is an apparent misspelling as An-Naji said (230/ 2). It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6784). 
2. In "Sifat Al-Jannah" (51/ 123), and therein is a Sheikh who was not named, and Husayn bin Sharik; known only in this narration; as in "Al-Jarh wa At-Ta'dil".

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2209 - (6) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, in Paradise there is a bird that has seventy thousand feathers. It comes and lands on the plate of a man from the people of Paradise, then it shakes, and from every feather falls a color whiter than snow, softer than butter, and sweeter than honey. There is no color in it that resembles its companion, then it flies away." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and At-Tirmidhi graded its chain Hasan for a text other than this one (1). 2210 - (7) [Weak Mawquf] And it was narrated from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: A pomegranate from the pomegranates of Paradise is gathered around by many people eating from it. If the mention of something one of them wants occurs to him, he finds it in the place of his hand where he is eating. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya (2). 2211 - (8) [?] And it was narrated with his chain also from him who said: Indeed, a date from the dates of Paradise is twelve cubits long, and it has no seed ('Ajam) (3).
foot_note:
1. I say: It contains two weak narrators; one of them is Atiyyah Al-Awfi. It is documented in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5026). 
2. I say: In its chain (51/ 121) is Hafs bin Umar Al-Adani, who is weak. 
3. I did not see it in Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya's book "Sifat Al-Jannah". The sentence: "It has no seed" is established in another narration from Ibn Abbas, presented in "As-Sahih" under (7 - Section). Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya narrated (29/ 48) in a narration from Abu Ubaidah (he is Ibn Abdullah bin Mas'ud) describing Paradise: "...The bunch of it is twelve cubits." And it contains Al-Mas'udi. And ('Ajam) is with the vowel movement on 'Ayn and Jim. Ibn As-Sikkit said: "The common people say: ('Ajm) with a sukun (stillness)"! It means the pit/seed.
