text: 9 - Section on Their Clothes and Suits. 2212 - (1) [Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "There is no one among you who enters Paradise except that he is taken to Tuba (tree), and its sleeves open up for him, so he takes from whatever of that he wishes: if he wishes white, if he wishes red, if he wishes green, if he wishes yellow, if he wishes black, like the anemones (Shaqaiq Al-Nu'man), but thinner and more beautiful." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya (1). 2213 - (2) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Indeed, a man reclines in Paradise for seventy years before he turns. Then a woman comes to him and strikes his shoulder. He looks at his face in her cheek, clearer than a mirror. The smallest pearl on her illuminates what is between the East and the West. She greets him, and he returns the greeting, and asks her: Who are you? She says: I am from the Increase (Al-Mazid). She wears seventy garments; the lowest of them is like (2) the anemones (Al-Nu'man) from Tuba. His gaze penetrates them until he sees the marrow of her shin from behind that. And upon her are crowns, the smallest pearl of which illuminates what is between the East and the West." Narrated by Ahmad via Ibn Lahi'ah from Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" via Amr bin Al-Harith from Darraj from Abu Al-Haytham. At-Tirmidhi narrated from it the mention of the crowns only, from the narration of Rishdin from Amr bin Al-Harith and said:
foot_note:
1. In its chain (56/ 146) is Sa'id bin Yusuf - who is Ar-Rahbi -, and Abu Utbah - whose name is Ahmad bin Al-Faraj Al-Himsi -, and they are weak. So Ibn Kathir's statement (2/ 278): "Gharib Hasan"; is not good. 
2. I say: Perhaps the meaning is: its thinness; i.e., like "the thinness of anemones" as in the previous Hadith. And Allah knows best.

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "We do not know it except from the narration of Rishdin"! 2214 - (3) [Very Weak Mawquf] And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The believer's abode in Paradise is a pearl containing forty thousand dwellings. In it is a tree that grows suits (Hulal). The man takes with his two fingers - and he gestured with the index finger and the thumb - seventy suits, belted with pearls and coral. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya as Mawquf (1). 2215 - (4) [Weak Maqtu'] And from Shurayh bin Ubaid who said: Ka'b said: If a garment from the garments of the people of Paradise were worn today in the world; whoever looks at it would swoon, and their eyes would not bear it. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya (2).
foot_note:
1. In its chain (56/ 148) is Abu Al-Muhazzim; and he is abandoned (Matruk). 
2. I say: He narrated it (56/ 149) via Ibn Al-Mubarak, and this is in "Az-Zuhd" (126/ 417 - Nu'aym's narration). It is Maqtu' (severed), disconnected; Shurayh bin Ubaid did not meet Ka'b, who is known as (Ka'b Al-Ahbar).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 10 - Section on the Bedding of Paradise. 2216 - (1) [Weak Mawquf] From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him); regarding His saying: {And upon couches raised high} [Al-Waqi'ah: 34]; he said: Its height is like that between the heaven and the earth, and the distance between them is five hundred years. Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and At-Tirmidhi who said: "A Hasan Gharib Hadith, we do not know it except from the narration of Rishdin - meaning from Amr bin Al-Harith - from Darraj." (Al-Hafiz said): "Ibn Hibban narrated it in his 'Sahih', and Al-Bayhaqi, and others from the narration of Ibn Wahb also from Amr bin Al-Harith from Darraj." 2217 - (2) [Very Weak] And it was narrated from Abu Umamah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was asked about the raised couches? He said: "If a mattress were dropped from the top of it; it would fall to its bottom for one hundred autumns." Narrated by At-Tabarani. Others narrated it as Mawquf on Abu Umamah, and that is more likely to be correct.
foot_note: None

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 11 - Section on the Description of the Women of the People of Paradise. [Weak] (Al-Hafiz said): The Hadith of Ibn Umar regarding the lowest of the people of Paradise was mentioned previously [2 - Section], and in it: "So he looks and behold, a Hawra' from the Hoor al-Ayn sitting on her royal couch, wearing seventy suits, no suit is of the color of its companion. The marrow of her shin is seen from behind the flesh, blood, and bone, and the clothing is over that. He looks at her and says: Who are you? She says: I am from the Hoor al-Ayn, from those who were hidden for you. He looks at her for forty years not turning his gaze from her. Then he lifts his gaze to the chamber, and behold, another more beautiful than her. She says: Is it not time for you to have a share of us? So he ascends to her for forty years not turning his gaze from her" the Hadith. 2218 - (1) [Denounced] And from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, the lowest of the people of Paradise in rank; is one who has seven degrees, he is on the sixth, and above him is the seventh. And he has three hundred servants, and every morning and evening three hundred bowls are brought to him - and I do not know but he said: of gold - in every bowl is a color not in the other. He finds pleasure in the first of it as he finds pleasure in the last of it. And from drinks, three hundred vessels, in every vessel is a color not in the other. He finds pleasure in the first of it as he finds pleasure in the last of it. And he says: O Lord! If You permitted me, I would feed the people of Paradise and give them drink, and nothing of what I have would decrease. And he has from the Hoor al-Ayn seventy-two wives, besides his wives from the world. And the seat of one of them takes the space of a mile." Narrated by Ahmad from Shahr from him. [Passed 8 - Section].
foot_note: None

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2219 - (2) [Denounced] And from Abdullah bin Abi Awfa (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, a man from the people of Paradise is married to five hundred Hawra', and four thousand virgins, and eight thousand matrons. He embraces each one of them for the duration of his life in the world." Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi, and in its chain is a narrator who was not named (1). 2220 - (3) [Weak] And from Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him); that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, the woman from the women of the people of Paradise, the whiteness of her shin is seen from behind seventy suits, until her marrow is seen. And that is because Allah Almighty says: {As if they were rubies and coral} [Ar-Rahman: 58]. As for the ruby; it is a stone that if you inserted a wire into it and then looked through it, you would see it from behind it." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih", and At-Tirmidhi - and the wording is his - and he said: "And it has been narrated from Ibn Mas'ud without raising it (to the Prophet), and that is more correct" (2). 2221 - (4) [Weak] And from Sa'id bin Amir bin Khuraym (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "If a woman from the women of the people of Paradise looked out; she would fill the earth with the scent of musk, and she would extinguish the light of the sun and the moon" the Hadith. Narrated by At-Tabarani and Al-Bazzar, and its chain is Hasan in corroborations.
foot_note:
1. I say: And it contains another man who is unknown, and it is a Denounced (Munkar) Hadith. I have documented it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6103). 
2. I say: It contains, both raised and stopped, (Ata bin As-Sa'ib), and he had become confused (mixed up).

publisher: Maktabat Al-Ma'arif for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: 2222 - (5) [Denounced] And it was narrated from Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) told me saying: "Gabriel, peace be upon him, told me saying: The man enters upon the Hawra', and she receives him with an embrace and a handshake. - The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: - With what fingertips (Banan) she hands to him! If some of her fingertips appeared, their light would outshine the light of the sun and the moon. And if a lock of her hair appeared, it would fill what is between the East and the West with its good scent. While he is reclining with her on his couch, suddenly a light shines upon him from above him, so he thinks that Allah Almighty has looked upon His creation. Behold, a Hawra' calls out: O ally of Allah! Do we not have a turn with you? He says: Who are you, O this one? She says: I am from those about whom Allah Almighty said: {And We have more} [Qaf: 35]. So he moves to her, and behold, she has beauty and perfection that the first did not have. While he is reclining with her on his couch, behold, another Hawra' calls out: O ally of Allah! Do we not have a turn with you? He says: Who are you, O this one? She says: I am from those about whom Allah Almighty said: {And no soul knows what has been hidden for them of comfort for eyes as reward for what they used to do} [As-Sajdah: 17]. So he continues moving from wife to wife." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" (1). 2223 - (6) [Weak] And from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him); regarding His saying: {As if they were rubies and coral}; he said: "He looks at his face in her cheek, clearer than a mirror. And the smallest pearl on her illuminates what is between the East and the West. And she wears seventy suits which his gaze penetrates;

foot_note:
1. I say: It is a very long Hadith, about eight pages, I know of no parallel to it. (Isma'il) - who is weak - was unique in narrating it from Muhammad bin Yazid - who is unknown -, and above him is the Ansari man who was not named. It is a chain of darknesses upon darknesses, leaving no doubt to the researcher that it is a composite Hadith, and some Huffaz mentioned that Isma'il compiled it from separate Hadiths, and it contains denounced phrases. Al-Bukhari said in the biography of (Muhammad bin Yazid) in "At-Tarikh Al-Kabir" (1/ 1/ 260/ 829): "(Isma'il bin Rafi') narrated the Hadith of the Trumpet from him, it is Mursal, and not authentic." It is in Al-Bayhaqi at the end of "Al-Ba'th" (325 - 334), and a group of Huffaz narrated it, including At-Tabarani in "Al-Ahadith Al-Tiwal" (25/ 266 - 277). 
2. It is not in the printed version of "Sifat Al-Jannah" by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. Ibn Al-Qayyim attributed it to him in "Hadi Al-Arwah" (1/ 376). It contains (Sa'id bin Zarbi), and he has wonders among the denounced narrations as Abu Hatim said, and from him Bashr bin Al-Walid, and he has weakness. 
3. I say: He came identified by Kunya in Abu Nu'aym as (Abu An-Nadr), and he is an unknown person, misspelt by his investigator to "Abu An-Nasr" with the un-dotted Sad. It is also not in the printed "Sifat" of Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya. I found its chain elsewhere, and documented it in "Ad-Da'ifah" (6903).

The correction is from "Sifat Al-Jannah" by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya (92/ 301), narrated from "Ibn Al-Mubarak", and from him Nu'aym bin Hammad (72 - 73/ 256). It is a strange misspelling; I do not know if it is from the author or the copyist. (Ayyash) was misspelt to (Abbas) then he added the supplication (may Allah be pleased...) from himself! The three ignorant ones did not notice this misspelling - as usual - despite attributing it to "Zuhd Ibn Al-Mubarak"!! This Abu Ayyash is Al-Ma'afiri Al-Masri. I did not find anyone who explicitly authenticated him. He is on the condition of Ibn Hibban, for three trustworthy narrators narrated from him. Al-Hakim authenticated the Hadith of Sacrifice for him, and Adh-Dhahabi agreed, and Ibn Khuzaimah also authenticated it. He is one of Ibn Hibban's Sheikhs. Therefore, I moved this Hadith from "Da'if Abu Dawood" to its "Sahih" in the Book of Sacrifice, classifying it as Hasan. The defect in the chain of this Athar is from the one below him, which is (Ubaydullah bin Zahr) for they weakened him. The addition is from "Az-Zuhd". 
3. It is not in the printed "Sifat". Ibn Al-Qayyim attributed it to him (1/ 274).

text: 2230 - (13) [Denounced] And it was narrated from Umm Salamah, the wife of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), may Allah be pleased with her, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! I said: O Messenger of Allah! Inform me about the saying of Allah Almighty: {As if they were rubies and coral}? He said: "Their purity is like the purity of the pearl in the shells that hands have not touched." I said: O Messenger of Allah! Inform me about the saying of Allah Almighty: {In them are good and beautiful women}? He said: "Good in character, beautiful in faces." I said: O Messenger of Allah! Inform me about the saying of Allah Almighty: {As if they were eggs well-protected}? He said: "Their delicacy is like the delicacy of the skin inside the egg which is next to the shell, [which is the Ghirqi'] (2)." I said: O Messenger of Allah! Inform me about the saying of Allah Almighty: {Uruban Atraban} [Loving and of equal age]?
foot_note:
1. With Dammah on Shin: Singular of Ashfar Al-Ayn, which are the edges of the eyelids where hair grows, i.e., the lashes. text: He said: "They are those who died in the abode of the world as old women, with eye discharge (Rums) and grey hair (Shumt). Allah created them after old age and made them virgins, {Uruban} loving/passionate, {Atraban} on one birth (same age)." I said: O Messenger of Allah! Are the women of the world better or the Hoor al-Ayn? He said: "The women of the world are superior to the Hoor al-Ayn, like the superiority of the outer garment over the lining." I said: O Messenger of Allah! And by what is that? He said: "By their prayer, their fasting, and their worship of Allah Almighty; Allah Almighty clothed their faces with light, and their bodies with silk. White in colors, green in clothes, yellow in jewelry. Their incense burners are pearls, and their combs are gold. They say: Behold, we are the eternal ones, we will never die. Behold, we are the ones in bliss, we will never be miserable. Behold, we are the residents, we will never depart. Behold, we are the pleased ones, we will never be angry. Blessed is he who belongs to us and we belong to him." I said: O Messenger of Allah! A woman among us marries two, three, or four husbands in the world; then she dies and enters Paradise and they enter with her; who will be her husband among them? He said: "O Umm Salamah! She chooses, so she chooses the best of them in character. She says: O Lord! This one was the best of them with me in character in the abode of the world; so marry me to him. O Umm Salamah; good character has gone with the good of the world and the Hereafter." Narrated by At-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" and "Al-Awsat" and this is his wording (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: And via his path Ad-Diya Al-Maqdisi narrated it in "Sifat Al-Jannah" (3/ 80/ 1 - 2) and said: "I do not know it except via the path of (Sulayman bin Abi Karimah), and there is talk about him." I say: There is no disagreement on his weakness. Ibn Adi said: "Most of his Hadiths are denounced (Manakir), and this is one of them." What testifies to what he said is his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "The woman belongs to the last of her husbands"; for it contradicts the last paragraph of the Hadith, so its denouncement is apparent.

1. In "Al-Ba'th" (210/ 418). There are others more worthy of attribution than him, like Ibn Abi Shaybah (13/ 100 - 101), Abdullah bin Ahmad in "Zawa'id Al-Musnad" (1/ 156), and Husayn Al-Marwazi in "Zawa'id Az-Zuhd" (523/ 1487). The commentator on "Al-Ba'th" attributed it to Ahmad and Ibn Al-Mubarak! Which is a mistake. It contains Abdul-Rahman bin Ishaq Abu Shaybah Al-Kufi; weak by agreement, from An-Nu'man bin Sa'd. 2. I say: He narrated it in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (7478). Among the illusions and contradictions is the statement of Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi in "Takhrij Al-Ihya": "...With a Hasan Isnad"! His student Al-Haythami contradicted him saying: "...It contains those I do not know"! The three ignorant ones quoted them and said: "Hasan"! A blind strike, and all of that is wrong; for it contains (Khalid bin Yazid bin Abi Malik) and he is weak, Ibn Ma'in accused him. Al-Bayhaqi narrated it via his path, and likewise Abu Nu'aym in "Sifat Al-Jannah" (434). The virtuous commentator discussed its narrators, but his sight strayed from this (Khalid) so he did not discuss him, and he is the defect. Therefore he classified it Hasan and expressed surprise at the author starting it with the passive voice! If the reason is known, the wonder ceases! For these illusions, I saw it obligatory to point them out with the briefest possible expression. Details are in "Ad-Da'ifah" (5028).

text: 13 - Section on the Market of Paradise. 2234 - (1) [Weak] And from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib; that he met Abu Hurairah, so Abu Hurairah said: I ask Allah to gather me and you in the market of Paradise. Sa'id said: Is there a market in it? He said: Yes. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) informed me: "Indeed, when the people of Paradise enter it, they settle in it according to the virtue of their deeds. Then they are permitted in the measure of a Friday from the days of the world, so they visit Allah. He reveals His Throne to them, and manifests to them in a garden from the gardens of Paradise. Pulpits of light, pulpits of pearl, pulpits of ruby, pulpits of chrysolite, pulpits of gold, and pulpits of silver are set up for them. The lowest of them - and there is no low one among them - sit on dunes of musk and camphor. They do not see the owners of the chairs as having a better seating than them." Abu Hurairah said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! Will we see our Lord? He said: "Yes, do you doubt in seeing the sun and the moon on the night of the full moon?" We said: No. He said: "Likewise you do not doubt in seeing your Lord Almighty. And no one remains in that gathering except that Allah speaks to him directly, until He says to a man among you: Do you not remember, O so-and-so, the day you did such and such! He reminds him of some of his treacheries in the world. He says: O Lord! Did You not forgive me? He says: Yes; by the vastness of My forgiveness you reached this station of yours. While they are like that, a cloud covers them from above, and rains perfume on them, the like of whose scent they never found anything ever. Then our Lord Blessed and Exalted says: Rise to what I have prepared for you of honor and take what you desire. He said: So we come to a market surrounded by angels, in it is what eyes have not seen the like of, nor ears heard, nor has it crossed hearts. He said: So is carried

text: to us what we desired. Nothing is sold in it, nor bought. In that market, the people of Paradise meet one another. text: 14 - Section on Their Visiting and Their Mounts. 2236 - (1) [Weak Mursal] From Shufayy bin Mati'; that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, among the bliss of the people of Paradise is that they visit each other on mounts (Mataya) and noble camels (Nujub). And they are given in Paradise horses, saddled and bridled, that do not defecate or urinate. They ride them until they end up where Allah Almighty wills. Then a cloud-like thing comes to them containing what no eye has seen nor ear heard. They say: Rain upon us. So the rain continues upon them until that ends above their hopes. Then Allah sends a wind, not harmful, which scatters dunes of musk from their right and their left. That musk takes to the forelocks of their horses, their manes, and their heads. Every man among them has a lock of hair (Jummah) as his soul desires. That musk clings to those locks, the horses, and other clothes. Then they proceed until they end up at what Allah wills. Behold, a woman calls one of them: O servant of Allah! Do you not have a need for us? He says: What are you, and who are you? She says: I am your wife and your love. He says: I did not know of your place. The woman says: Do you not know that Allah Almighty said: {And no soul knows what has been hidden for them of comfort for eyes as reward for what they used to do}? He says: Yes, by my Lord! Perhaps he is distracted from her after that standing for forty autumns; not turning nor returning. Nothing distracts him from her except the bliss and honor he is in." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya from the narration of Isma'il bin Ayyash (1).
foot_note: 1. I say: There is no reason in my view to find a defect through him; because he is trustworthy in his narration from the Levantines, and this is one of them. He narrated it (77/ 240) via Ibn Al-Mubarak - and this is in "Az-Zuhd" (69/ 239 - Nu'aym) - from him: Tha'labah bin Muslim told me - and this is a Levantine - from Ayyub bin Bashir Al-Ijli - and this is unknown; as Adh-Dhahabi said -, so finding the defect through him is more appropriate along with the disconnection (Irsal).

text: 15 - Section on the People of Paradise Visiting Their Lord Blessed and Exalted. 2240 - (1) [Very Weak] It was narrated from Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "When the people of Paradise settle in Paradise, an angel comes to them and says: Indeed Allah commands you to visit Him. So they gather. Allah Almighty commands David (Dawud), peace and blessings be upon him, so he raises his voice with Tasbih and Tahlil. Then the Table of Eternity (Khuld) is set." (1). They eat, then they are given drink, then they are clothed. They say: Nothing remains except looking at the Face of our Lord Almighty. So He manifests to them, and they fall in prostration. He said: They delegate to Allah Glory be to Him every Thursday. Thrones are set up for them. Every person among them knows his throne better than you know this throne of yours that you are on. When they sit on it

text: red and emerald green, its soil is musk and amber, yellow camphor, its grass is saffron blooming, and Alanjuj (1), blazing without fuel. Salsabil, Ma'in, and Rahiq (rivers) burst from its base. Its base is a sitting place from the sitting places of the people of Paradise which they frequent, and a conversation place that gathers them. While they are conversing in its shade one day, angels come to them leading noble camels (Nujub) created from ruby, then spirit was breathed into them. Reined with chains of gold, their faces like lamps in radiance and beauty. Their wool is red silk, and white Mir'izzi (2) mixed together. Observers have never looked at the like of them in beauty and splendor. Submissive without humiliation, picked without training. Upon them are saddles whose panels are of pearl and ruby, silvered with pearl and coral, their plates of red gold, covered with Abqari (3) and purple. They make those noble camels kneel for them, then say to them: Indeed your Lord sends you peace, and asks to visit you so you may look at Him and He looks at you, you speak to Him and He speaks to you, you greet Him and He greets you, and He increases you from His bounty and His vastness. Indeed He is Possessor of vast mercy and great bounty. So every man among them shifts onto his mount, then they proceed in an even row, nothing of it precedes another, nor does the ear of a she-camel precede the ear of its companion. They do not pass by a tree from the trees of Paradise except that it gifts them with its fruit, and moves away from their path hating to break their row, or separate between a man and his companion. When they are presented to the Compeller Blessed and Exalted; He unveils His Noble Face to them, and manifests to them in His Great Majesty. Their greeting therein is Peace.

text: They say: Our Lord, You are Peace, and from You is Peace, and Yours is the right of Majesty and Honor. Their Lord says to them: Indeed I am Peace, and from Me is Peace, and I have the right of Majesty and Honor. So welcome to My servants who preserved My commandment, observed My covenant, feared Me in the unseen, and were apprehensive of Me in every state. They say: By Your Glory and Majesty, and the highness of Your place, we did not estimate You Your true estimation, nor did we fulfill to You all Your right, so permit us to prostrate to You. Their Lord Blessed and Exalted says to them: Indeed I have removed from you the burden of worship, and rested your bodies for you. For long you have tired the bodies and humbled the faces [for Me]. Now you have come to My Spirit, My Mercy, and My Honor. So ask Me what you wish, and wish upon Me, I will give you your wishes. For I will not reward you today according to your deeds, but according to My Mercy, My Honor, My Bounty, My Majesty, the highness of My place, and the greatness of My status. So they continue in wishes, gifts, and grants, until the least of them wishes the like of the entire world, from the day Allah Almighty created it to the day He annihilated it! Their Lord says: You have fallen short in your wishes, and were satisfied with less than what you deserve. I have obligated for you what you asked and wished, [and attached your offspring to you] and increased you over what your wishes fell short of. So look at the gifts of your Lord which He gifted you. And behold, domes in the Highest Heights, and rooms built of pearl and coral, their doors of gold, their beds of ruby, their mattresses of Sundus and Istabraq, their pulpits of light. Light erupts from their doors and courtyards like the sun's ray, like the brilliant star in the light. And behold, lofty palaces in the highest of Illiyyin made of ruby, their light shines, were it not subjugated, it would blind the eyes. Whatever of those palaces is of white ruby is furnished with white silk. Whatever is of red ruby is furnished with red Abqari. Whatever is of green ruby is furnished with green Sundus. Whatever is of yellow ruby

text: is furnished with yellow purple, plated with green emerald, red gold, and white silver. Its bases and corners are of ruby, its balconies are domes of pearl, its towers are rooms of coral. When they leave to what their Lord gave them, workhorses (Baradhin) of white ruby are brought to them, spirit blown into them. Beside them are immortal boys (Wildan). In the hand of every boy among them is the rein of a workhorse. Their bridles and reins are of white silver ringed with pearl and ruby. Their saddles are beds lined up, furnished with Sundus and Istabraq. Those horses proceed with them, driving them and looking at the gardens of Paradise. When they end up at their dwellings, they find in them all that their Lord bestowed upon them of what they asked and wished. And behold, at the door of every palace of those palaces are four gardens: Two gardens {having spreading branches}, and two gardens {dark green [in color]} and {In both of them are two pouring springs} and {In both of them are of every fruit, two kinds} and {Fair ones reserved in pavilions}. When they settle in their dwellings, and their settlement is established with them, their Lord says to them: {Have you found what your Lord promised to be true}? They say: Yes, we are pleased, so be pleased with us. He says: By My pleasure with you, you have settled in My Abode, looked at My Face, and My angels shook hands with you. So congratulations, congratulations, a gift uninterrupted, having no distress or reduction. At that point {And they will say, "Praise to Allah, who has removed from us [all] sorrow. Indeed, our Lord is Forgiving and Appreciative (34) [He who] (1) has settled us in the Home of Duration out of His bounty. There touches us not in it any fatigue, and there touches us not in it weariness} [Fatir: 34-35]." Narrated by Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya and Abu Nu'aym like this as Mo'dal (perplexing/disconnected), and raising it (to the Prophet) is Denounced (Munkar) (1). And Allah knows best.
foot_note: 1. The verse appeared distorted unfortunately in the original following the narration of Ibn Abi Ad-Dunya, and in Amarah's edition like this: {...Sorow and settled us in the Home of Duration out of His bounty there touches us not in it any fatigue and there touches us not in it weariness Indeed our Lord is Forgiving and Appreciative}! This is a strange distortion; I do not know how the commentators and correctors missed it! Including the three ignorant ones, they left this dangerous distortion, even though they attributed the verse to [Fatir: 135]! Just as they do with Hadiths; they point to their numbers, and do not correct any error that might be in them, as I warned repeatedly. Furthermore, the correct attribution is [Fatir: 34 and 35]; for they are two verses! Likewise, the commentator on "Sifat Al-Jannah" erred in referencing it, mentioning the first number, and citing the verses as one flow without separation!!

text: 16 - Chapter on the people of Paradise looking at their Lord, Blessed and Exalted. 2244 - (1) [Fabricated] And it was narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "While the people of Paradise are in a gathering of theirs, a light shines for them at the gate of Paradise. They raise their heads, and behold, the Lord, Blessed and Exalted, has looked upon them and says: 'O people of Paradise! Ask Me.' They say: 'We ask You for Your pleasure with us.' He says: 'My pleasure has settled you in My abode and granted you My honor, and this is its time, so ask Me.' They say: 'We ask You for increase.' He says: 'So they are brought mounts (Naj'aib) of red ruby, their reins are of green emerald and red ruby. They are carried upon them, placing their hooves at the limit of their sight. Allah Almighty orders trees bearing fruit, so maidens from the Hoor al-Ayn come, saying: We are the comfortable ones and will never be miserable, we are the eternal ones and will never die, wives of noble believing people. And Allah Almighty orders dunes of white, fragrant musk, and scatters upon them a wind called: Al-Muthira (The Stirrer), until it ends with them at the Garden of Eden, and it is the center (Qasabah) of Paradise (1). The angels say: 'O our Lord! The people have come.' He says: 'Welcome to the truthful, welcome to the obedient.' He says: 'Then the Veil is lifted for them, and they look at Allah, Blessed and Exalted. They enjoy the Light of the Most Merciful so much that they do not look at one another. Then He says: Return them to the palaces with the gifts. So they return, having seen one another.'" The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "That is His saying: {An accommodation from [One who is] Forgiving and Merciful} [Fussilat: 32]." Narrated by Abu Nu'aym and Al-Bayhaqi, and the wording is his (2), and he said:

So they go out onto dunes of musk - Hudhayfah said: - And it is indeed whiter than this flour of yours. - He said: - Then the servants of the Prophets come out with pulpits of light, and the servants of the believers come out with chairs of ruby. - He said: - When they are placed for them and the people take their seats, Allah Blessed and Exalted sends upon them a wind called Al-Muthira (The Stirrer), which stirs up upon them heaps of white musk, inserting it under their clothes and bringing it out onto their faces and hair. That wind knows better how to apply that musk than a woman among you if that perfume were given to her by the permission of Allah. - He said: - [Then Allah Glorified reveals to the bearers of the Throne, so He is placed in the midst of Paradise, and between Him and them are veils. The first thing they hear from Him is that] He says: 'Where are My servants who obeyed Me in the unseen, and did not see Me, and believed My Messengers and followed My command? Ask Me, for this is the Day of Increase.' - He said: - So they gather on one word: 'O Lord! We are pleased with You, so be pleased with us.' - He said: - So Allah Almighty returns in answer to their saying: 'O people of Paradise! Your Face], show us that we may look at It.' So Allah Blessed and Exalted lifts those veils and manifests Himself to them. So there covers them

And the most honored of them to Allah is the one who looks at His Face morning

If anyone were to die of joy, the people of Paradise would have died, and if anyone were to die of grief, the people of the Fire would have died." ... (And let us conclude) the book with what Al-Bukhari, may Allah have mercy on him, concluded his book with, which is the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: "Two words are beloved to the Most Merciful, light on the tongue, heavy in the Balance: Subhan Allahi wa bi-hamdihi (Glory be to Allah and His is the praise), Subhan Allahil-Azim (Glory be to Allah, the Magnificent)." text: It happened that several chapters were dictated in places where it would have been more appropriate to mention them elsewhere. The reason for that was the lack of recalling them in those places, and remembering them in others, so we dictated them as it happened, and we presented the index of chapters at the beginning of the book for that reason. Likewise, many very authentic hadiths passed in this dictation, some meeting the conditions of the Two Sheikhs or one of them, and Hasan hadiths; we did not draw attention to much of that. Rather, I mostly said: 'Its chain is Jayyid (good)', or 'Its narrators are trustworthy', or 'Narrators of the (Sahih)', or the like. What prevented stating that explicitly was the possibility of a defect I did not recall during dictation. (1) Likewise, many Gharib (strange) and Shadh (anomalous) hadiths passed in text and chain, and I did not address their strangeness or anomaly (2). I ask Allah to make it purely for His Noble Face, and to bring benefit through it; indeed, He is the Possessor of Vast Bounty and Great Favor." ...
foot_note:
1. I say: This is a text from the author, may Allah have mercy on him, that his statement, and likewise others': "Its narrators are trustworthy..." does not mean strengthening the Hadith. I explained that in the introduction to the first edition of "Sahih At-Targhib wa At-Tarhib" and clarified it further - him and others - in the introduction to the new edition, and the introduction to this "Da'if"; so refer to it for it is important. However, coupling this statement with the one before it: "And its chain is Jayyid" is not good, because it is a text strengthening the Hadith, like saying: "Its chain is Hasan" as is known in the science of (Mustalah Al-Hadith), so take note! 
2. I say: And I have rectified that as much as I could as you see in this book. I praise Allah Almighty for what I have been successful in, and I seek His forgiveness for what I may have erred in. Indeed, He is Hearing, Responsive.

text: Ended by the grace and favor of Allah is the book "Da'if at-Targhib wa at-Tarhib" and the commentary upon it, asking the Master, Glorified and Exalted, by His Beautiful Names and Lofty Attributes to make my end good, and the end of my offspring, my relatives, and my loved ones wherever they are, and to admit us all into Paradise in peace {with those upon whom Allah has bestowed favor of the prophets, the steadfast affirmers of truth, the martyrs and the righteous. And excellent are those as companions} [An-Nisa: 69]. And Glory be to You, O Allah, and with Your praise, I bear witness that there is no god but You, I seek Your forgiveness and repent to You.
